description:
I absolutely adore this place!!! Ever since I discovered this place, I been coming here everytime I'm in SF!!! My favorites are their seared scallops and korean short ribs! Their sea scallops were cooked just right and melted in my mouth; one of the best scallop dishes I have had! The restaurant is fairly small and it fills up quickly so if you want to eat here, make sure you make a reservation through Yelp or by phone. 


***********My overall ratings************
Taste: 5 stars
Price: 5 stars (affordable fine dining!)
Environment & Cleanliness: 4.5 stars 
Service: 5 stars
author: Kimberly Y.

description:
I eat here far too often I'm told, but the sea bass dies for me to eat how can i not?

There are no disappointing items to be had here.  I've been systematically searching.  

The risk of bringing  new people here is future seating competition.  

catch 22 of deliciousness
author: Roger B.

description:
We were walking around North Beach and decided to check on Yelp for a good place for lunch. "The House" popped up with 4.5 stars so we walked right over. It was past the usual lunch hour rush so we were seated within a minute of arriving.

We ordered a few items to share.

Unagi avocado sandwich - I did not know this combo was even possible. I have only had unagi in sushi, but this sandwich was amazingly delicious. And only $14??? I have had fried chicken sandwiches which have cost more. This was a steal! 

Small plate - white shrimp & cheese chive dumplings - This was honestly the best shrimp & chive dumpling I have ever had and I have had many in various dim sum restaurants. The meat portion was absolutely perfect. 

Small plate - Grilled octopus came with tempura potatoes and aioli. The octopus & aioli were a great match. They could have left out the mushy tempura potatoes and I would have been thrilled.

I plan to come back. Great place & great service!
author: Kat M.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city! I love the Seabass, the fish itself is perfect and the noodles are to die for. I usually get the mussels, but they had a special with the clams and they were absolutely amazing! Not a huge fan of the beef noodles, but love all of the fish options I've tried so far! Delicious, and pretty quick service.
author: Christine L.

description:
Ok, we've been coming here for about the past 10 years. I always order the black cod special, or if it's not available, then I order the pork chop (ordered medium per their suggestion).  For appetizer, I order the salmon rolls  or the soft shell crab of it's one of the specials. 

Mango tapioca is the way to go for dessert. 

I love this place, and more than being happy, I have an inner sense of peace and joy as I imbibe the whole dining experience. No other restaurant makes me this happy. I hope The House stays this consistent and high quality for years to come.
author: Sheewon B.

description:
The House is definitely somewhere I can see myself coming often.  A really great place for a date night! The place is small inside and fills up fast but definitely a reservation helps! But I came here on a whim hoping they weren't going to be busy and I was in luck!! I got here before 6:30 so around 6:15 maybe? And I was seated right away on a Friday! Talk about lucky!! I noticed everyone who walked in after 6:30 was given a wait time of 45 mins to an hour. 

We ordered a Pinot nior and a cab to pair with our dinner and it was perfect! 

We ordered the scallops, sea bass and the rib eye! All of their items came out really quick. The sea bass came with garlic noodles and some green beans which paired really well with the bass. The rib eye was a bit fatty but it was cooked to perfection with mashed potatoes and cauliflower. I would say the scallops were just okay but if you like scallops you would enjoy it. :)

Anyways, definitely recommended!
author: Sherry L.

description:
I decided to make a reservation for 2 people since I heard that this place gets packed. My boyfriend and I came on a Tuesday at 7PM for dinner.

We ordered the following five items to share:

Miso black cod, crab avocado maki (5/5) - The cod with the sauce was delicious. This was my second favorite dish.

Deep-fried salmon roll, Chinese hot mustard (5/5) - This is like a salmon egg roll. Perfect dish for people who love salmon and deep fried food.

Soft shell crab with noodles (3/5) - The soft shell crab was alright. It came with cold noodles and I prefer to eat my noodles warm/hot. I felt like the liquid wasabi sauce didn't go well with the crab. I wasn't too fond of this dish. 

Grilled octopus with tempura potatoes (5/5) - I'm a huge fan of octopus and potatoes. This was my favorite dish. Everything was cooked and seasoned well.

Bittersweet chocolate truffle cake with ice cream (5/5) - This dessert dish is perfect for chocolate lovers.

Notes: The restaurant is pretty small, so there's limited seating space. Make sure to make reservations ahead of time. After 15 minutes being seated, the restaurant started to get packed. Parking is extremely difficult, so I recommend taking public transportation, walking, or carpooling. The service was excellent. The waiters/waitresses were attentive to refilling our water cups and clearing out the empty dishes on the table. The experience was pleasant and we really enjoyed our meals. The food came out pretty quick, except for the miso black cod, which took a while. We will definitely come back here to try other dishes on the menu.
author: Sylvia H.

description:
Perfect for a date night, cozy special occasion, or any kind of intimate gathering! The restaurant itself is quite small so I definitely wouldn't take a large group here but for groups of 4-5 I'd say it's perfect. It's a sweet little Asian fusion restaurant that encapsulates the name "The House" perfectly. 

I came here on a Wednesday night with three others and we were seated immediately even though our reservation was for an hour later. Service was quick & on point and they constantly checked on us to see if we wanted more water/wine. 

We decided to go all out and treat ourselves so we splurged on two large entrees and several appetizers. My favorites were the steak (so so tender and delicious), the cod (the sauce is to die for!), as well as the poke and shrimp & chives dumpling appetizers. The sauce on everything was amazing and made the respective flavors really jump out at us. 

For dessert we had the blueberry bread pudding with vanilla ice cream as well as the chocolate cake with coffee ice cream. I preferred the chocolate dish but both were definitely winners. 

This restaurant does have a pretty steep price tag but the food and ambiance are worth it in my opinion. I left dinner feeling full until the next morning!
author: Christine W.

description: This was our first spot to dine in San Fran and we was not disappointed. I'm so glad i called to make reservations bc they are super busy and the place is really tight. We started off with the oysters on a half shell and this was probably the best oysters i have ever had. I can't even describe the taste but it was delicious i probably could of ate like 50!! And then came our meal and it didn't disappoint either.
author: Lyna M.

description:
This gem is tucked off the main streets and feels intimate as its name suggests. 

The food has lovely fusion flavors blend together to make a modern delight. I love the wasabi noodles, which are both unique and fun. 

The service is prompt and friendly. 

Sound level can be a bit loud and tables are close together, but the food and atmosphere more than makes up for it.
author: Barron C.

description:
It's just as good as I remembered it. I came to the House in 2011 2012 and was completely blown away. (Even back in 2012 this place was completely booked and packed!) I had ordered the Ahi Tuna and a few other dishes back then. But I definitely remember how the Ahi Tuna tasted (After 5 years, that really says something). After my meal in 2012, the House became my all time favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Since then, I've been trying to find the time to come back and experience the House.

Boy, I was glad I made reservations at this place because I wouldn't have been able to wait 1 hour for a table (I was short on time). The co-owner was super nice and looked exactly how she did years ago (seriously this woman doesn't age). We ordered the fried salmon roll, prime rib, and Ahi tuna - MAN DID WE FINISH IT. I love seafood dishes and not too big on red meats; however, the prime rib was literally the best thing you can order. 

Also, their wine selection is great honestly should of bought a bottle. Definitely coming back and definitely still one of the best restaurants in San Francisco!!!
author: Ann N.

description:
Their black cod is my favorite. Their prime ribeye and deep-fried salmon rolls are also excellent.

I would eat here every day if I could afford it!
author: Janet M.

description:
I came here on a Sunday for lunch- super excited to try this place because I have a sweet spot for asian fusion. The restaurant is so small...come early or make reservations because there is such limited seating. 

We ordered the wasabi noodles, curry noodles, and deep fried salmon rolls. Everything was good! I'd definitely get the wasabi noodles again, but pass on the curry noodles to try a different offering. 

Service was great! This meal only made me want to try the other options next time- especially the sea bass, black cod, scallops, and short ribs
author: Jessica D.

description:
Octopus app: 5/5 delicious deep smoky flavor and the octopus is so deliciously tender. Didn't know octopus could be so tender. 

Oysters: 5/5 some of the meatiest, most delicious and fresh oysters I've had. The sauce you pour onto each oyster has a good balance of heat and acid. It was delicious! 

Pork chop: 5/5 sweetness that reminds of charsiu. Ate it all, fat and all! The potatoes and asparagus that comes with it is also yummy. As were the thin crisps of, could it be taro?

Sea bass: 4/5. The sea bass itself? It was a 5/5. So deliciously tender and buttery. Perfectly cooked and melts in your mouth! But the sauce needs some work, the green beans are super plain (though well cooked), and the noodles a bit plain and salty. Maybe some more garlic to the noodles to add some flavor? Maybe a bit more acid, like lemon, to brighten it up? Something is missing. 

Wasabi noodles: 4.5/5 the pork was a bit dry. Appreciated the kimchi like flavors throughout the dish. Well balanced and tasty. Not too spicy.
author: J P.

description:
Haven't been to The House for a while and the food are still very good. We dined there last night after finished watching the Blue Angels Air Show.  From the raw oysters, Pan seared Scallops, Grilled Octopus, Sea Bass w/wasabi noodles, to the Pork Chop,  you will never disappoint. 
Service is very attentive and food is as consistence as it used to be.  I came here for the good food and I didn't mind it's a bit noisy.  Will definitely come back again & again.
author: E P.

description:
Beautiful little spaces that do their own thing, night after night, and have it so dialed in that it's a delightful experience, are very rare to find. You may see a few more in big cities, because of the make-or-break nature of a saturated dining scene, but no matter where you are, this is a real feat.

Beating the odds failure for any restaurant, after all, is a pretty hefty task. So when I sat down at The House after a last-minute invitation from work family, I really didn't know what to expect other than I knew already like the space, cozy as it was, and that I was with some serious food fans.

It didn't take long to realize that The House knows what's up. That they're dialed in and focused on what they do, that they know their identity, and that they turn those tables efficiently while still allowing you to enjoy your evening. They're well-oiled.

If you can go with friends, I recommend it. There are so many items you'll want to try and being constrained to just one would have been rough. Between the four of us, we ordered grilled octopus, ribs, noodles & steak, tuna tartare, sea bass, a pork chop, and cod. The sea bass had come highly recommended from a coworker and definitely didn't disappoint, though after we started with that tartare I knew we were in good hands--seafood can be an art and again, they've got artists on staff. If I had to pick a weak link it would be the ribs, but you're just not going to be disappointed in them. If you could only get one thing, though, I'd stick with that sea bass and ask if the cod is on special. I dug it.

I expected to pay a little more, but for sure this isn't a cheap meal. They're efficient which means they keep prices competitive, but they're also making good food with fresh, quality ingredients and they gotta pay that rent. It's a great place for a classy work dinner if you know the folks, but more suited to something a bit more intimate--a nice night out catching up with old friends, somewhere to take your parents when they visit from out of town, or a third date when you really like them.
author: Jeffrey S.

description: We were looking forward to eating at The house because of all the fantastic reviews but honestly it was disappointing. One the place was so cramped that we could hardly breath and then our neighbors were so interested listening to our conversation. The food was ok at the most. We had salmon rolls and night special halibut. Nothing special about it.
author: Mariam H.

description: One of my favorite place in the area. My favorite is their sea bass (must order). Ive been here a few times and their specialty is their noodles, Flatiron steak, salmon roll and rock cod. Their menu does change but not much and they always have a few house special of the day- off the menu. Their service is wonderful. We love our waitress with the short hair cut. Overall we had a blast here. They do get pack so come early before they open. Lunch seems to be less pack.
author: Christy V.

description:
I love sea bass and after spending a day with BFF, we ended the evening at this restaurant because she said her mom is a picky diner but has been to this place a couple of times and thinks nothing of plopping down $31 for the sea bass entree. 

We got last minute reservations and the place was already packed before 6 PM. The waiters were really friendly not so much the female owner?  She walked around helping out but didn't seem to be having much fun on the job. 

Seasoning on my bass was great, moist and not over done. The accompanying crunchy green beans were really good . The garlic noodles had good texture but I wouldn't say was the best I've ever had. 

Hubby went for the rack of lamb, came with kim Chee side and over rice.  The rice was the reason he really ordered the dish. Told him he could've ordered a different entree and asked for a side of white rice.  BFF hubby ordered the steak and glass of lemonade. We were all full and didn't need any appetizer or dessert. Hubby ordered a glass of Pinot and it tasted pretty good.  Costly meal with beverages came to $200 with tax/tip but we would come back.
author: Ry T.

description:
Loved the experience here - tasted a good part of the menu with some friends and didn't have a bad bite. My only regret was not eating more. Between the bites we had (grilled octopus, BBQ St. Louis ribs, octopus, pork chop, sea bass, flat iron steak) -- I'd say with the appetizers: I'd go for the grilled octopus a 100x over and the pork ribs. I'd personally skip the tuna tartare next time. More bang for your buck elsewhere.

As far as the entrees, the grilled sea bass I had was heavenly and I was grateful that we shared and had bites of each others plates. The Korobuta pork chop was and the steak was definitely a highlight from my buddies dishes.

Overall, The House is a well oiled San Francisco machine and I wouldn't hesitate to dine here again.
author: Alex L.

description:
I've had my eye on The House for a while, but I have a general wariness for any Asian fusion type place, usually because it veers far too much towards the westernized side and overlooks the uniqueness of Asian cuisine. However, The House has achieved this balance with innovative and tasty food! 

I walked in at 7pm and thought I wouldn't be able to get a spot for 2 without a reservation, but luckily there are tables crammed into the hallway behind the central area you see when you look through the window. It's a tight squeeze, but I'd rather run into a couple elbows than not get my dinner. 

We ordered the grilled shrimp salad, deep-fried salmon rolls, Korean short rib special, and wasabi noodles with flatiron steak. The grilled shrimp salad was a bit weird to me - I couldn't really identify many pieces of shrimp among the pork skin, and I'm also not a huge fan of chicharrones. The deep fried salmon rolls had a deliciously thin fried layer, but the best part is the tingly sauce you dip them in. 

While the wasabi noodles had a good texture, I wasn't really tasting the wasabi until the very end. The real show-stopper was the Korean short ribs. They were so tender and cooked perfectly, the small mountain of fried shallots (or whatever it was) managed to be flavorful, and the kimchi had this hint of sweetness that you don't normally get from jarred kimchi from the supermarket. We paid around $50 pp and the portions were so filling and good!

It's a bit noisy and crowded, but this place is such a great deal for the food and the price you pay.
author: Sophie W.

description:
i've heard of this place for years, when it was really popular. my friend decided to take me here for my late birthday dinner. definitely didn't realize it was right by Chinatown and hidden.

It's pretty small and if you're seated in the far back area by the kitchen, it's pretty dim. 

They have specials, but we opted for the regular dinner menu instead. 

- grilled eel with avocado and sushi rice as our first small( so goood if you like eel) 
- pork spare ribs with cole slaw (very flavorful, maybe a bit too much)
- chicken salad with light peanut sauce (light! and really good)
- the infamous seabass with garlic noodles and green beans( simple and basic, but the seabass was cooked to perfection)

overall, the experience was good. the waiter and waitresss were accommodating! switched out the plates and utensils when the entree arrived. 

only con was that some of the food had maybe a bit too much flavor.
author: Audrey K.

description:
Once again the dinner at The House was outstanding.I had the soft shell crab with spicy noodles and Tony got the delicious pork chop. I am so happy to see it thriving and maintaining it level of 
Epicurean excellence.
author: Ann S.

description: place, I been coming here everytime I'm in SF!!! My favorites are their seared scallops and korean short ribs! Their sea scallops were cooked just right and melted in my mouth; one of the best scallop dishes I have had! The restaurant is fairly small and it fills up quickly so if you want to eat here, make sure you make a reservation through Yelp or by phone.
author: Michael M.

description:
Why 5 stars? Because the San Francisco restaurant industry strikes again.

   ---   ---   ---

I've been to San Francisco 10-12 times now and I'm usually there for work events. Because I work with many like-minded individuals, we take our dinners seriously. And when I say that, I mean that we often order everything that's even remotely appealing on the menu and share it all. It's the best way to eat - this is a fact, not an opinion.

At The House, I was with 3 other dudes I work with and we *housed* more than our fair share of this menu. We ordered oh-so many things:

-Ahi Tuna Tartare
-Grilled Octopus
-BBQ St. Louis Pork Ribs
-Warm Wasabi House Noodles, Angus flatiron steak
-Grilled Sea Bass
-Kurobuta Pork Chop
-Some sort of special for the night with cod

I think that's everything, but there's a decent chance I forgot something there. 

Everything ranged from good to amazing. The best three items were the octopus, the sea bass and the cod - they do their seafood quite well here!

If I lived in SF, this would definitely be a mainstay on my dinner circuit. It's a very small place, so definitely get reservations in advance!
author: Brett N.

description:
My god this place was bomb. I would say the reviews def match up to what we got! Everything was tasty for sure. It is a smaller place so make sure to book a reservation before coming!

Shrimp and onion dumpling (4 stars)- Pretty good dumplings. This was probably the only thing we ordered that wasn't OUTSTANDING. It was pretty average tasting.

Special fish of the day with truffle sauce (5 stars)- This was my favorite dish. They did such a good job cooking the fish, the sauce was amazing, and they added elements to make the dish all around textured. Crispy elements with the crunch on top. It was perfect! Still thinking about this :)

Halibut with noodles (5 stars)- Basic fish dish but my cousin has some dietary restrictions and so this was perfect for her. But even without all the fancy sauce or condiments this was very delicious and she enjoyed it!

Short rib special with kimchi (5 stars)- This was amazing! I was skeptical when this came because it was cut up and looked like a flat iron steak which is normally super chewy. But it wasn't and was soooo tender and full of flavor, also had some crunchiness goodies on top which made the dish even better.

Made a special vegetarian dish with noodles and tofu in a curry sauce (5 stars)- Awesome they could accommodate vegetarians with tasty dishes too since it's mainly an asian seafood place. But the sauce was extremely delicious and filling!

The place is also a little tight and our waiter was decent, they could probably work on smiling a little more but I'll be back for the food if I'm ever in the area again!
author: Sarina V.

description:
My boyfriend and I came to this place because it was highly recommended. We love seafood, and this place sounded delicious from the menu. We made a reservation for 1 pm, and were seated right away. Don't let the surrounding area deter you from going -- there's an adult store right next door, so just be aware of that. 

For our food, we ordered the sashimi appetizer, the wasabi noodles (delicious with a slight spicy kick and a perfectly cooked piece of salmon on top) and the pork chop (very juicy, with a tangy sauce). The waiter was very knowledgeable of the entire menu, and recommended these dishes to us ... what a hit! 

We also got the passion fruit-coconut creme brûlée which turned out to be a perfect choice as it was a very unique item, and was so refreshing to eat after our main meal. 

I would definitely come here again! If you are visiting SF and want to try something a little different, check out The House.
author: Anjuli D.

description: I'm truly smiling thinking of this restaurant. Not only do I come here every time I visit SF, but I make sure to go twice whether I'm visiting for two days or 1 week. The House has the best food ever! It's so delicious and it exceeds my expectations every time. There's nothing on the menu I won't have (hence why I have to go more than once). The vibe is extremely chill and fun! Great place for lunch or dinner! With friends or for a date night. I've sent so many friends and family there because I know they will love me even more for it! Make sure to call and make a reservation even though they will try to accommodate you without one. This way you get seated right away and are able to begin the greatest food experience. Their wine is delicious too!
author: Gabby F.

description:
The House is a small, Asian fusion restaurant around North Beach that provides a wonderful restaurant experience with great food variety, service, and ambiance. I came for lunch and had the fried salmon rolls (beautifully presented with spectacular crunch with moist salmon insides), the scallops (soft, flavorful), the mussels (literally putrid and we had to send them back), the sea bass (could've been more exciting but still soft and delicious), and a caramel flan (beautifully presented and delicious). Our servers were very accommodating to late arrivals though in general were not quite as hospitable as similarly priced restaurants. 

My personal experience was sadly ruined by rank mussels (which I am a little offended that we didn't get any discount on) but overall I would highly recommend it for a small group lunch or a casual date.
author: Andrew H.

description:
In this cozy little restaurant food is perfect. 

Like all good things you wait, sometimes upto 45 minutes that's how long I did.

I tried the wasabi noodles with steak, choice of food pairing, and the spice level was just right.  Portion sizes are good for one person, low appetite individuals can share an entree but combine it with a starter.

Must visit in SFO
author: Dilip M.

description:
Finally made it to The House, and it lived up to all of their amazing reviews. Highly recommended for a date night, or a good spot to take the parents. It's small and cozy, so not great for a big group. 

What we ordered:
-Salmon rolls 
-Sea Bass
-Wasabi noodles 

All 5 stars. Would come back to eat the salmon rolls and sea bass again and again. 

The service is quick, the food was delicious, the wine was good. 

Cannot wait to come back, might be my new favorite SF spot!
author: Morgan W.

description:
Best meal in SF I've had yet. 

This review is long overdue! I made a reservation and came here with 2 friends on a week night. When we got there around 6, it was still fairly empty. We got seated at a table furthest away from the door and were given menus. After some deliberations, we went with the sea bass, the pork chop, and the special, which was the short ribs - Korean style.

We split the meal family style, cutting up pieces here and there so we can all experience the menu. The short ribs were perfectly tender and moist with a bugolgi flavor. The pork chop was.... SO GOOD. The pomegranate sauce served with it was so delicious. There was a bit of fat on the chop we had to cut around. The sea bass was served with a side of noodles and Chinese long string beans. I would order the noodles on the side by itself.

For dessert, we ordered the coconut creme brulee, the chocolate cake with ice cream, and mango tapioca. The mango tapioca might be hands down the best dessert I've ever ordered at a restaurant. Damn was it good. 

Ambiance is casual but the price is what you'd see at a slightly higher end restaurant. The food is definitely worth it though.
author: Judy H.

description: A friend found this gem while on our trip to San Francisco. If you find yourself near china town make sure you make a reservation. The place is small but the service and food make it worthwhile. The food presentation is amazing and tastes even better!! Worth the trip!
author: Brenda M.

description:
This place books up quick. I came by myself on vacation at 5:15pm and they were already almost full. It's a simple and small place but they love quick and you can see they really appreciate their guests.

For starter I had the oysters with a cilantro spicy mignonette. Divine. Then got the sea bass based on what everyone was saying and it did not disappoint. Crispy in all the right places and succulent in all the others.

I wasn't too into their dessert but had a lovely plum wine to top it off.
author: Brandon B.

description:
One of my first friends that I made after moving to San Francisco took me here to show me one of the different neighborhoods of the Bay proper.  Having been here for about 8+ years, he was a really good reference to have not just for the city but also for eats.  I normally would not have sought out an Asian-Fusion restaurant, but I am really glad that he took me here.  Things we shared included:

seared ahi with green beans
seared scallops appetizer

Seared Scallops
PROS:
- cooked perfectly: perfect sear, not burnt, not overly tough from being overcooked, super soft
- whatever that glace and sauce was, it was super tasty.  I want to say it was some kind of citrus mayo but I could be off.  My memory fails me as this was over two months ago
CONS:
-none

Seared Ahi with green beans
PROS: 
- perfect quantity, even to share
- well cooked, not under and not over
- well seasoned: not too salty, not too bland
- green beans were not overly oily
- nice balance between carbs, protein, and vegetable
CONS:
- some kind of sauce or glaze would be nice but not entirely necessary

I'd definitely come back here.  The service was great, never had to wait or ask for any refills for water.  Admittedly, the wait is long but that's normal for a good place.  For those of you who refuse to wait, that's totally fine but for me a lot of things are worth the wait, food included.  I'd totally recommend this place as a good date place except for the fact that it is loud and the space is a bit cramped.  Good to catch up with a friend though for sure!
author: Vera L.

description:
The best San Fran trip ever!! Super happy that I finally get to experience The House, during my recent visit to SF with my cousin and her family who lives in Daly City. This is her favorite restaurant. Prior to visiting she gave me a list of restaurants and suggestions and after seeing the photos and Yelp reviews I told her lets go to The House!! 

Reservations confirmed, meet at The House at 11:30 am. We took the Bart and headed to SF's Chinatown before meeting up. I had my luggage  with me so the restaurant staff was nice to let me store them in the corner. The House is a tiny fusion restaurant, and during my dining experience we did feel crampy, when we got to our reserved table, but it was fine, The main thing I was grateful I am in SF, at The House, and get to spend time with family. The House sure filled up fast for lunch. 

Since my cousin doesn't eat seafood but loves The House's King Salmon entrée we let her do the ordering for us. She raves about the king salmon with wasabi noodles. We started off with complimentary pickled cucumber from The House, which was refreshing. Our waiter was friendly and patient. 

Note: The salmon entrée is spicy so don't forget to order it mild, my cousin noticed it was a little more spicy this time. 

Our orders: Salad, baby greens passion fruit , with vinaigrette ( 10.00)
I am not a fan of salad but this salad was very tasty, light, and refreshing. Baby greens, with slices of apple with a light vinaigrette dressing. 
White shrimp and Chinese chive dumplings ( 12.00) As I am eating the dumplings, I can see they don't skimp on the filling, its huge. This dumplings is nice, soft and cooked just perfect.
The grand finale, 4 orders of King Salmon with wasabi house noodles (15.00) Wow!! This entrée is AMAZING! I can see why this is my cousin's favorite entrée. This entrée is very fusion, I'll say with a mix of American, Chinese, & Korean. I loved the Wasabi noodles, very tasty, chewy, served with shredded cucumbers, pickled kim chee veggies, and a huge piece of King Salmon flavored and cooked to perfection. 
Our entire party of 5 enjoyed this entrée. The prices are reasonable! 

Parking: Parking could be a hassle in the city but super worth it, even though we Bart it, parking info. will be for my next visit.  Metered street parking lots at 766 Vallejo Street Garage and around the corner From The House at 65 Fresno Alley Parking Lot. 

The House is very popular, on Zagat's Top 50 Best Restaurants in San Francisco, on Zagat's 10 must eat dishes. 

Overall, I thank my cousin for the recommendations. Great times with family @ The House in San Fran. I can't wait to be back again!! 

It is a must to visit, when in San Fran!
author: Judy C.

description:
I have been wanting to try this place for years and I finally got the chance to. 

Tried the following:
1. Complimentary Salmon Roll - delicious!  The entire roll was salmon as you can see in my photo.  The sauce it comes with tastes like wasabi which I loved.  

2. Steamed mussels in garlic infused shrimp broth - this was really good. The mussels were a little small. The broth was delicious. Although, I actually prefer the buttery french version. 

3. Grilled Eel, avocado sushi rice, bonito flakes - really delicious.  This is probably my favorite of the appetizers I tried.

4. Caesar Salad, cripsy scallop - this was good. The best part was the fried scallop.  They cooked it just enough so the scallop was still tender.  The rest of the salad was kind of boring.  

5. Grilled sea bass, garlic ginger soy - absolutely delicious. The sea bass was again cooked just enough so that it was still flakey and soft. The soy sauce it came with was the perfect compliment. It comes with a portion of noodles and green beans. The noodles were delicious even though they were too soft for me. They would have been better if they cooked them for less time. The green beans were unremarkable. 

6. Ahi tuna, spicy mustard aioli - underwhelming. It looks more exciting than it tastes. The tuna was cooked well, still raw in the center. Overall, it was pretty bland. The rice isn't sushi rice either. It could have used more aioli. I ended up using the soy sauce from the sea bass to add more flavor to the tuna and rice (which is pretty much the plate)

7. Panacotta - this wasn't on the menu but the waitress mentioned it. I would pass on this. It's good if you want something not too sweet..but it's also not flavorful either. It's kind of like soft jello with some berries on top. 

8. Bittersweet chocolate truffle cake, coffee ice cream, coconut caramel - The cake was absolute delicious. If you are someone who loves dense chocolate cakes you'll like this.  It's actually not really a cake; it's more like a large slide of fudge.  I think vanilla ice cream would have been better than coffee. 

The service was eh. Not the usual super nice treatment you normally get at these types of places. But it wasn't terrible. My biggest complaint was the wait. I had 7:30 reservations and ended up waiting a half an hour. It kind of defeats the purpose of getting reservations if I still have to wait. 

TL;DR: Some of the dishes were really good, some weren't so much. If you have a reservation, still expect to wait. The eel appetizer, sea bass main, and chocolate cake were bomb. I would come back again.
author: Jon P.

description:
I don't venture into the city too often, but after my experience here, I will gladly wade through the terrible traffic and hard- to- find- and- expensive parking. This place clearly honed in my mind why San Francisco is such a great "foodie" city. The food here was incredible. And usually, after eating Asian food, I tend to feel like shit because of all the oil but after this meal, I felt real clean even though I just ate 2 people's worth of meals. 

Appetizers: We started with a half dozen of oysters ($13) and they were some fresh AF oysters and reeaal tasty. I mean, you're in SF, so expect some real good oysters but the oysters they have here were top notch. We also started with the octopus with potato tempura. This was also amazing and a must- have appetizer. Octopus was tender, and the potato tempura, which I've never had, were nice and crispy and tasted great with the sauce they put in. 

Entrees: Two of my lunchmates had the pork chop ($23) which looked AMAZING. It was made with a pomegranate seed sauce which I've never seen but  the two guys who were eating raved about it and licked every piece of meat off the bone. I had the sea bass ($24) with noodles and green beans. Everything was good on my plate, I was just hoping for the sea bass to have more flavor but the sauce they provided helped and was real tasty but a little on the salty side. My 4th lunchmate had the wasabi house noodles with salmon ($12). He said it was tasty as well, and it's one of the more affordable entrees. 

Dessert: Of course, with everything tasting so good, we had to try some desserts. The desserts we had are seasonal I believe so they change them every so often but will always be good! Two of us had their homemade cheesecake ($9) which was great and much better than cheesecake factory's! Another had the chocolate truffle cake.

Service was amazing as well, the staff was so nice and accommodating. Coming here you will absolutely not be sorry. This place is such a gem in chinatown.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
This place has been on my bookmarked list for some time. 

I made sure to make reservations for dinner when i was in Sf for the weekend.

I got the chilean sea bass which comes with garlic noodles and my boyfriend got the wasabi noodles. Both dishes were really good and had great flavor! We both didn't care too much for the steak in the wasabi noodles but the noodles were really good.chilean sea bass was really good as well. 

Will definitely be back!
author: Phuong K.

description:
Our dinner here began just as so many incredible meals do - a little Yelp research ahead of time!

So many folks mentioned this being the highlight of a trip to Frisco that I could not test fate and buck the advice.  I planned for The House to be the foodie cornerstone of our trip to the Bay area.

The House did not disappoint!

I made reservations a day ahead of time, and by the time we arrived, I was glad I did.  Walk-ins were being quoted 45+ mins at prime time on Friday night.

We were seated promptly right at the time of our reservation.  Although busy, the wait staff was attentive and worked their tails off.

I cannot overstate how incredible the food was at The House.  I enjoyed the evening's special entree, which was a sashimi plate, and beautiful bride took on an incredible steak.  That alone should tell you just how diverse the offering is at this place.  The wife's beef was among the best we've ever had (and that's from Cowtown'ers), and the sticky (read: sushi) rice with my sashimi was irresistible. 

We shared an appetizer and dessert, and walked 15 blocks back to our hotel with full and very happy tummies.

My only two knocks on the place would be that, as with many places in downtown SF, it's pretty cramped, and pretty loud.

Food = 6/5
Facility = 3/5
Service = 4/5
Ambiance = 2/5
Value = 3/5
author: M. O.

description:
Thought about giving this 5 stars but it was just not quite there from a service perspective.

Food - amazingly good and deserves 5 stars. Do not expect the normal Americanized Chinese food here. There is no Chow Mein or Kung Pow Chicken Instead they ha e elevated the food to a new level. I had the Flat Iron Steak and it was done very well. The mushrooms, potatoes, and crispy things went well together. My wife loved the prawns with noodles in curry sauce.

Service - this is where some improvement could be made. There was no refill of the iced tea or my wife's lemonade. The only reason I gave 4 stars instead of 5.
author: Mike P.

description:
This is a 4.5 star rating.

My friend made reservations for a Thursday night and the restaurant was PACKED. I got there a little bit early and waited for our table which was quickly cleared and I was seated a little after 7. Not a biggie. Something came up and my friend actually ended up being an hour late but none of the staff ever rushed me to order or to give up my seat (for this alone, I'd give them five stars).

Food:
Sashimi: Standard sashimi. Great for America.
Deep fried salmon roll: Literally every single table got this. Yummy. Worth the hype? You'll have to find out yourself! I enjoyed it though!
Octopus: OK. Cooked well but something just didn't come together for me.
I got the halibut with mashed potatoes and cream sauce which was good but I WISH I had gotten either the steak or the sea bass with the wasabi noodles. Which my friend got. And it was fairly yummy!

I'd like to go back to try some of their other signature items (which I usually never say). So, all in all, a success!
author: Michelle K.

description:
This is what a 5 star restaurant feels like! It's a pretty small place so I strongly encourage reservations. We came on Friday night and the line went out the door. Despite how busy it was, the staff did not miss a beat! Everything from the moment we entered to when we left went smoothly and efficiently. The service was great! 

For starters, we got the tuna tartare, mushroom truffle soup and oysters. The tuna tartare was pretty good but I thought the price was a bit steep as it only came with 3 pieces, which made it kind of awkward to share with 4 people. Mushroom truffle soup was good, and the oysters were fresh.

My boyfriend and I decided to share the rib eye which came with mashed potatoes and cauliflower. Thank goodness we didn't get our own entrees because there was no way we would have finished it! The rib eye was tender and full of flavor, I love when the juices mix with the mash! My friend ordered the short rib special which came with a side of rice and kimchi. This has to be my favorite of the night as I wanted to steal this dish for myself hahaha. The short rib was super buttery and melted in my mouth.

Will definitely come here again when I come back to SF!
author: Jessica C.

description: The hype is real! Cozy restaurant with prompt service and awesome food. Two words: wasabi noodles!  Please make sure someone at your table orders this dish.  Get a glass of wine and start with the shrimp dumplings.  Overall great experience - definitely towards the top of my list of restaurants in SF.
author: Nicole T.

description: I wanted to like this... but, I didn't. I ordered the Wasabi Noodles With Flat Iron Steak, and the Shrimp and Scallion Dumplings. It ALL needed salt. Like, all of it. Total bummer. The steak was cooked perfectly, and the noodles were a good texture.  I also asked for a sake recommendation, "I don't like sake." Oh, cool, but I'm pretty sure you're supposed to make something up. I mean... But the service was pretty poor throughout. The pickles were great, and you can walk across the street to The Baked Bear when you're done not eating your low-sodium dinner, because you'll still be hungry.
author: Corie L.

description:
Everything is good. 
Small place, always crowded 
Reservation is a must
They gave us a free appetizer Bc they made us wait past our reservation time. Very considerate 

My favorite was the ribeye and the unagi. I really love when Asians cook European style food. Someone about that particular fusion makes for a really great meal.  

Things are pretty expensive :/. But my taste buds thinks it was worth it.
author: Bao-Quynh J.

description:
What a great dinning experience!
Everything we tried was excellent! It is hard to decide what dish was the favorite, all amazing! Not unexpens, but def reasonable priced.
author: Mayra M.

description:
The apple pie ala mode is the best thing (and I've ever got it to-go after eating elsewhere in North Beach).  Ok now that I got dessert out of the way...

CALL FOR RESERVATIONS!!!! Don't be left out in the cold, literally and figuratively.

It's small and cozy and kind of hustle bustle loud because the tables are tight and they do pack the restaurant.

Food is great but I'm personally not a huge fan of the wasabi noodles.  I mean they're good but I think kind of more of a hype.
author: Traci H.

description:
By far my favorite restaurant in SF. The best and most affordable Asian Fusion the city has to offer. A small restaurant with about 10-15 tables, reservations are almost required to eat here without waiting too long. 

Be sure to listen to their daily specials that aren't on the menu. The waiter/tress will go over them with you and I always hear at least one (possibly two or three) that I end up ordering. I usually try something different each time because I have never been disappointed by one of their dishes.

I would highly recommend any of their fish entrees. I have never been disappointed. Anytime guests visit from out of town, I have to take them to The House and no one has ever been disappointed.
author: Justin Y.

description:
The sea bass, garlic noodles, and wasabi noodles here are some of my favorite things ever! The House was recommended to me about 5 years ago but it was way out of my price point as a college student. However, I knew I had to come back to San Francisco to try it so I did! 

The House is quite small with only about 10 tables so there can be a wait outside on a busy night. I made a reservation and only had to wait 5-10 minutes. We started off with the salmon roll and wasn't impressed. It was a very average appetizer. But our entrees came and we were head over heels! My boyfriend got the wasabi noodles and steak and I got their famous sea bass entree which came with garlic noodles and green beans. The wasabi noodle didn't have a strong wasabi flavor at all and I actually thought it needed a little more spice. The sea bass was so flaky and flavorful... I couldn't get enough of it! I wished there was more food on the plate for the amount we paid, but the service and quality of the food justified the price.
author: Mindy T.

description: The ribeye was great and done properly as ordered. The entire plate was well presented and went well together. The portion is just right for the the price. The staff are great and real ware of the wait time of the customers. The environment is small but comfortable. I highly suggest to be considerate to other and enjoy flour food but know that theres other waiting to eat. No parking available other then street parking so take time to find parking at least give an hour ahead of time especially on the weekends. Over all great quality food service price and portions.
author: Raymonchito U.

description:
The House comes really really close to being the best meal I had while visiting San Francisco - the first being Liho Liho Yacht Club. However, the house does not get the publicity it deserves, thus reservations are easier to get. 

The House is a tiny restaurant located in North Hill. It serves Asian fusion and everything my wife and I ordered that evening was superb! For starters we had the chicken salad, fried kale, toasted peanuts with sesame vinaigrette. This has to be the best salad I ever had. I could eat it for every meal! It's filling and delicious! We also ordered the scallop special. If they offer this, please order at least one plate! Omg! I dream about these succulent crustaceans! I would order two of these next time! 

For the main, we had the miso black cod, with crab avocado and the kurobuta pork chops. Both were excellent and highly recommended!

The dining room was a little tight and stuffy, but we had a great meal, good alcoholic drinks (can't remember them), and attentive service. I highly recommend this restaurant and will be back again next time I'm back in town.
author: Samson L.

description:
A really great Asian Fusion meal !
We will definitely come for another great meal.
Thumbs up!
author: Ziyi Z.

description:
A solid 4 stars.

The food at the house is unbalanced and the ambiance is nice as long as you don't mind being in close quarters and it getting loud. Imagine a large family gathering at a house! It's dark so it's nice for a date but I wouldn't say it's romantic as it's too busy.

The service is adequate. They refilled waters when needed and didn't bother us to much or try to make a ton of conversation. They don't need any improvement on this part whatsoever, but it wasn't anything to rave about. You come here for the food anyway!

We came for dinner on a Thursday night, the day after Valentine's Day to celebrate it.
Arrived at 725 for a 730 reservation. They seated me within a few mins and gave menus. They didn't bother me while I waited for my boyfriend to park the car which was nice.

I heard a family of 4 being told it was a 40 min wait for a walk in. And I never saw more than 1-2 small parties waiting at a time.
I also heard the waitress deny the party sitting next to me from ordering more food (they were a party of 6 and had mostly finished their entrees except one guy who was working on the last of it) stating that they have a time limit on the table because they have people waiting. From the looks of it, the guy had probably made 2-3 additional entree orders while the rest of his group just sat there waiting.

After parking down the street and around the corner, my boyfriend and I settled on the mussels and ahi tuna tartare for apps and the prime rib eye and sesame soy king salmon.

The food came out surprisingly fast for how busy it was. It probably took about 7 mins for the apps which came out at the same time.

The mussels were very good. I'm a huge fan of mussels in general, but these were cooked to perfection. The broth in them was very good as well, so we got some extra bread for dipping it.

The ahi was good as well, but I probably would have preferred to try the salmon rolls instead. The tartare was flavored well and fish was very fresh, it was just missing a little something to make the dish whole.

The entrees came to our table perfectly-timed, just as we were finishing up the appetizers and had some more room on our cozy two person table.

The salmon was perfectly cooked as well and the glaze on it was very good. It's an extremely light dish which is nice. (I only ordered this because I was being basic on the keto diet at the time.) But it was very enjoyable. I'm definitely familiar with bok choy which it the salmon sits on, but never have I ever seen it this perfectly cooked. Typically you need to chew it a little to break off pieces that are social acceptable for you to chew and swallow (and without choking) but my teeth cut into those babies like a warm knife on room temp butter! I was incredibly surprised!! The salmon was MOIST (sorry) and flavorful.
I was confused about the broth...the dish came with a bowl of rice, was I supposed to dump that in and eat it with the soup? (It seemed weird and I wasn't eating rice anyway) but the broth seemed too thin for that, but it was very good alone.

The ribeye was extremely good. There was very little inedible cartilage (which, hopefully you are familiar, is completely normal). The mashed potatoes were extremely...okay. It wasn't on the level as the ribeye or anything else we had was. It was just plain mashed potatoes. I can't say the texture or flavor was anything special. It was something you had at thanksgiving from someone that made it 1-2 times a year and you can accept. Though my boyfriend said he really like the cauliflower (which i didn't try) too many carbs LOL.

The creme brulee the table next to us got looked delicious, but we had plans to go across the street for dessert. In hindsight, should have gotten the creme brulee!

Overall, they cook everything perfectly. Seriously. And everything tastes good, which makes it good x2 but I think all of the dishes we tried are just missing that extra something to really bump it up a level.
author: Connie T.

description:
Why oh why am I just discovering this gem now?

My team decided to have lunch before we leave for the Thanksgiving holiday. For weeks up to that day, my coworkers and I have been looking at the menu and Yelp! pics drooling over what we want to order.

We roll up at 11:30, promptly seated since it wasn't busy yet. A bunch of us ordered the lychee iced tea. I love lychee and I've tried lychee everything everywhere and this place hands down the best lychee iced tea ever. They even put in a whole piece of lychee in your glass!

Our appetizers:
- Steamed manila clams: Part of their special. It was so good! The sauce had a little kick to it but the clams were perfectly textured and went very well with their sauce. 
- Seared scallops: Part of their special. I don't normally eat scallops but their presentation made me want to have a piece. It was good. the caviar and leafy greens really complimented the scallop.
- Grilled octopus, tempura potatoes with sriracha aioli. That's a fat piece of octopus! I couldn't taste the aioli or the potatoes because all I was able to focus on was the yummy octopus. 

Main dish: 
- Grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy (sauce), garlic noodles, and sautéed green beans. This dish alone is what will bring me back, several times over. The sea bass was so soft and fresh, the ginger garlic sauce wasn't as salty and it went so well with the sea bass. The garlic noodles were very good as was the green beans. 
-  Ahi Tuna: so fresh and flavorful with their sauce. 

Overall, everything we had was very good. Service was excellent, but I can see why some people will have their quips about the space. The place is small and tables are very close together.

Another reason to go back was because they didn't have the miso black cod and persimmon pie. The two things I was really looking forward to trying. Owner suggested we call ahead next time so they can prep it for us. Will definitely do that!
author: Erica C.

description:
We came here on Saturday, one day before Father's Day for an early Father's Day celebration for my hubby. I made reservation for 5:30pm and the place was packed. It was packed even when we left at 6:30pm and had a long line. It was very tight in space and stuffy. There were several tables with kids and yes they have high chairs. It was extremely awkward having to be so close to the table to our left because they were having a very personal conversation about how their guy friend is not ready to commit. While my husband and I couldn't wait to dig in and could only talk about how our food taste. Finally, we didn't have to chow down our food in 5 minutes and we can actually use a knife. 

We ordered some items from the special menu. I would've ordered more but it was so noisy I couldn't hear the waitress introduce the other options clearly. 

We ordered the scallops which were so tasty and yummy in my tummy. The sauce was a great complement to the scallops. I'll go back to The House just for the scallops alone. That's how good it was. 

We also ordered the clams. Don't expect to get a lot, they only give you 6 pieces of clams but they are very meaty. The sauce was also very delicious that I wanted to eat all the bread and soak it in the sauce. 

The grilled octopus was just okay. I can do without it. I found the meat to be a bit chewy but I liked the sauce. 

My angus ribeye cooked medium seemed a bit too rare for me but I loved the butter and garlic though. I had left overs and just couldn't bare to finish it. 1/3 of the ribeye was all fat that I had to cut off.  

My husband ordered the Alaskan Halibut which was better than my Angus ribeye. It was delicious! 

One thing I was happy to see on the menu was several varieties of tea. And you can ask for more hot water for your tea.

I do want to come back to try the test of the menu in the future.
author: Susan H.

description:
The House is my favorite restaurant in North Beach. Although comparing its Asian fusion fare with the Italian restaurants may not be fair, the House is a special place. 

I am writing this review after my fourth visit and I would like to emphasize that I was as impressed every time. The selling point is the food. The menu changes periodically while some items stay on the menu. For instance, white shrimp and chive dumpling is a staple and I highly recommend it. On this visit, I tried Bbq pork ribs. Although they were delicious, bbq ribs with cole slaw didn't scream Asian fusion. Wasabi house noodles with flatiron steak, on the other hand, was awesome and fit the bill. 

I highly recommend making reservation by calling. My note from our last visit was that the restaurant was packed and the service was too efficient to the point where we felt rushed. 

Despite the pace, the food here is solid. It is a romantic small place that I highly recommend for a low key special night.
author: Doruk B.

description:
My wife and I had a very mediocre experience at The House.

We started with the special shiitake mushroom soup with truffle oil (decent but under-seasoned) and the unagi with avocado rice and bonito flakes (our favorite dish).

For my entree, I had the ahi with rice, spinach and wasabi aioli. The ahi was over-cooked and had a mealy texture. The accompanying components did not add much flavor. My wife had the steak with wasabi noodles. The steak was cold and very bland, and the noodles were just ok.

For dessert, we shared the chocolate truffle cake with ice cream. The cake was rich and moist (a nice palate cleanser), but the ice cream had unappetizing bits of frozen ice crystals. 

Service was strangely quick: we were in and out within an hour. Our appetizers arrived within 5 minutes of ordering and our dessert came in less than 1 minute. It made us wonder if everything was pre-plated in anticipation for the dinner rush that was on the verge of starting. The waitress was in such a hurry to clear our table that she dropped our credit card when she returned it to us and didn't even bother to pick it up.

We really don't understand the hype behind this place. We wouldn't return.
author: Mike H.

description:
The House is one of my favs in the city.  It may be hard to score a reservation, but if you dine at an off-peak time you can just walk right in like we did.

I originally dined here on my bday earlier this year and just loved it so when we were on the hunt for a place to eat last night we took a chance that maybe there would be a spot open since it was already after 8pm.  Sure enough there was no wait!

Like last time, we started off with the Ahi tartare because it's so hard to resist.  You may argue who would pay $13 for 3 chips and a small heap of raw fish but if you close your eyes with every bite you'll be able to savor the poke and the nori chip that no Poke Bowl can replicate.  The other not-to-miss favorite would have to be the Seabass.  It's about a 4x4 inch grilled chilean Seabass that's cooked to perfection and served with a side of green beans on the night we went.  I wanted the ribeye, but since was already sold out so we opted for the flatiron steak which I would skip next time.  It was a bit dry and not what I would expect from The House.

The place is very small and cramped so if you aren't into eavesdropping on your neighbor's conversation and playing footsies with them then this place isn't for you.  Also since a table for 2 may be a bit small for the dishes, try to score a larger table or eat fast before the next plate comes or you'll be stacking dishes.  

Service is always great and the single bathroom is quite clean.  

If you dine here, let me know if the placemat is distracting to you like it is for me.  My peripheral kept making me think I dropped something!  Stop messing with me guys!
author: Alex L.

description:
Asian fusion on steroid, that's probably the best way I can describe this place.
The House was recommended by a lot of our friends who visited previously. I wasn't sure how busy or crowded this place would be on a Friday night so I called ahead to make the earliest reservation possible- They open at 5:30pm so 5:30pm it is. 

We got to the area a little bit earlier because we don't know the area very well and surely we got lost.  Btw the restaurant is not easily noticeable from the outside and it's located on an unassuming street (almost seems like you are going into a small alleyway). So the best way to find the place is once you made a right turn onto Grant Ave, look for an erotic lingerie place and the restaurant is right next to it. 

First impression- very simple décor with beige color tables lined from the front to back.  Organize, bright and clean. There is very little room between the tables but since we came early and the restaurant was not full so this wasn't an issue.

Once we were seated, our waiter presented us with a small menu and began to tell us about all the specials they have for the day. Little did they know, we already knew what we wanted before we walked in (thanks friends and Yelp), but we patiently waited for our waiter to finish and ordered the following:
Soft Shell Crab appetizer 
Grilled Sea Bass, garlic ginger soy sauce with garlic noodle and string beans entree
Grilled Ahi Tuna (rare), spicy mustard aioli with sticky rice 
 
The soft shell crab appetizer was nothing but spectacular both in presentation and in taste.  I'm a bit afraid to eat soft shell crab because sometimes they taste super mushy in the middle and gives this raw taste in the center.  I'm glad this is not the case here, the soft shell crab tasted fresh and cooked perfectly, crunchy on the outside and soft but still somewhat firm on the inside- exactly what you expect fresh seafood to taste like.  The sweet and sour tomato spaghetti? was an interesting side to accompany the soft shell crab, I'm not sure if it's a different take on the traditional sweet and sour sauce but it works great to balance out the greasiness and eliminate some fishiness from the soft shell crab. 

The Grill Sea Bass, garlic ginger soy sauce with garlic noodle and string beans had to be my favorite out of the three.  Sea Bass was perfectly cooked, it was flaky, buttery, well-seasoned and lightly grill on the outside for a slight smoky flavor.  The garlic noodle had a stronger flavor which went great with the light and buttery sea bass and the string beans served as a perfect balance between the fish and the noodle, giving it a refreshing and light crunchy texture. It was just delicious and the sea bass really melts in your mouth and both my wife and I had our eyes wide open after our first bite wondering how they made it so buttery. This is a must try!

The Grilled Ahi Tuna, spicy mustard aioli with sticky rice and snow pea leaves(?) was an excellent choice as well.  The presentation was amazing, 5 pieces of grilled Ahi Tuna, leaning on a sticky rice island with snow pea leaves on the side surrounded all by spicy mustard aioli with the rice and Ahi Tuna island was topped with fried taro straws, gorgeous, just gorgeous presentation.  The taste was as strong as it's presentation. The Ahi Tuna was fresh and seared nicely on the outside, the raw part of the tuna was not flavored but I'm okay with that since the spicy mustard aioli provided much of the seasoning. The spicy mustard aioli was not too mustardy but it was creamy and super flavorful. The rice and the snow pea leaves were a great compliment for the tuna to offset the fishiness and give the dish more variety of textures and flavor. By the way the snow pea leaves was silky smooth and well-seasoned.  The rice had a somewhat chewy texture and balanced the rich and creaminess of the dish well. The fried taro straws gave it that much needed crunch and extra flavor.  It's truly a texture and flavor overload and it's a dish I enjoyed from start to finish.

Service: Our waiter was friendly and attentive and check frequently to make sure we are doing well.

Price: A bit higher than most Asian food in the area but it is very reasonable consider the food quality and service.  Another thing regarding price- You would expect a restaurant like this to give you small portions but nope, their portions are HUGE (and we are no small eaters) so you will walk out full and not need to eat instant noodle afterward. 

Overall: Definitely a must try restaurant when you are in SF! Excellent in food quality, service and value. Be sure to make a reservation because the restaurant tends to get pack fast and definitely try to sea bass.
author: Felix S.

description:
Came by for lunch the other day and it was a decent experience, although it was better on prior visits. Restaurant did get quite full around the peak lunch rush so a reservation would be optimal.

The two waiters were quite flamboyant...an undershirt would definitely help with appearances too... The waiter did a good job going over the daily specials.

Complimentary pickled cucumbers were a great way to start the meal.

Started off with the salmon rolls which were good, although the rolls were more of a medium vs medium rare as usual. Flavor was still decent.

Moved on to the tempura green beans which were also tasty, although a few pieces were past their prime and quite stringy...

The kurobata pork chop was decent. Came out medium well and some parts were moister than others, next to the fatty portion. Nopa has a much better rendition of this. ..the mashed potatoes were rather bland though

Restaurant is quite tight...

$32/head after tax and gratuity for lunch.
author: Derek S.

description:
My review is pretty much fluff ( over 4000 reviews and a solid 4.5 star rating).

I first dined at The House when they were on 9th avenue in the Inner Sunset ( this was P.Y...Pre Yelp) and was always knocked out by there unique take on Asian fusion dishes. So they have been in business a long time ( over 20 years!!!) and to do good food consistently that long...Is AMAZING!!!

The food at this location is really good


All the appetizers we ordered were great!!! and uniuqe

Blue lake bean tempura, pickled ginger soy (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=bmvzEsl1HVqCeLlXF0qyHQ&userid=kroQYWSj-BhIEXT4VwLRHA)

Seared Hokkaido scallops, lemon ponzu, micro greens(https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Vt7yHZVFcYILFzvtn9nVYg&userid=kroQYWSj-BhIEXT4VwLRHA)

Deep-fried salmon roll, Chinese hot mustard(https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=sVbBii0c2WbTQPq57ZKABw&userid=kroQYWSj-BhIEXT4VwLRHA)

Grilled shrimp salad, crispy pork skin with red chili vinaigrette (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=eKJp5s5k7gLjniuoEqsinQ&userid=kroQYWSj-BhIEXT4VwLRHA)

The main dishes are also just as sumptuous:

Miso black cod, crab avocado maki(https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Rl4KiY3xhCBCEkvYus5wyw&userid=kroQYWSj-BhIEXT4VwLRHA)

Warm wasabi house noodles, flatiron steak(https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=EIzODVOq4qObwxNYrkbanA&userid=kroQYWSj-BhIEXT4VwLRHA)

If you are visiting San Francisco definitely go for lunch or Dinner. Added bonus of being in the heart of North Beach.

Their space is really tiny and I would highly recommend calling to make a reservation.
author: David G.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in sf!! The food is always good and on point here. Ever single dish is amazing!!!!

The restaurant is very small so it's cramped. The only thing negative I have to say about this place is that, we made reservation for 7:30pm but still had to wait for about 20 mins to be seated. Ugh. Was semi annoyed...i mean what is the point of making reservation if I cannot be seated right away?? 

What we ordered: 
Deep fried salmon roll: cooked perfectly with the middle being a little rare. so fantastic! Dipping sauce was hot mustard, a little too spicy for me 

6 oysters: wish there were more!! So good and fresh!

Mussels: broth was amazing!! Serisouly drank the broth afterwards. Yummm!

Sea bass with garlic noodles and  string  beans. Sea bass was cooked perfectly. Wish it was bigger lol. 

Love this place and cannot wait to come back.
author: Caitlin P.

description:
I was here on Saturday night for dinner with a group of 8. The majority were out of town guests. The House did not disappoint. It's quickly become one of my favorite restaurants. They're pretty consistent with their flavors & service. We ordered two of each of the following: 

-Ahi Tuna
-Grilled Octopus 
-Sea Bass
-Miso Black Cod
-Kale Salad
-Wasabi Noodles & Flatiron Steak

The grilled octopus was served w avocado & potatoes. Definitely my favorite. Everything else was great. I'd recommend making a reservation. It's a very small restaurant & they're always packed. There's no valet but there's a parking garage right up the street.
author: Adrianna J.

description:
My first visit was about 9 years ago and I remember having the 'infamous' sea bass...perfectly prepared - flaky, moist, smoky accompanied with a soy-sesame dipping sauce and those garlic noodles...delicious! 

Came back recently as this is my friend's fave place but over time I've developed an aversion to Asian-fusion restaurants because to me it's just familiar Asian items, given fancy names, on fancy serving ware, smaller portions with larger prices. 

I have to say The House does Asian-fusion well without being pretentious and outrageously priced...the sea bass is still consistently good and decided this visit to get the braised kurobuta pork chop...OH MY! That was some darn good pork and have to say the best I've ever had...then again this type of pork is tender and juicy and was worth every tasty bite....and to have currants, pomegranate reduction...HELLO?!! 

We also ordered dessert but (IMO) not their strongest area...had the creme brûlée with passion fruit...and a lemon tartlet...okay but textures were off for me...didn't have me craving more but a nice to try.

Overall, great place...you can get early reservations at 530 but by 630 the place fills up fast...they hustle you in and out within an hour as the place has limited seating...dishes came out quick, service efficient, and out you go...they didn't rush you per se but there was already a wait of people outside and the server will keep asking if there is anything they can get you.

Definitely come here for the sea bass and the Kurobuta pork!
author: Cheryl M.

description: Best meal while we were in San Fransisco. Be sure to make a reservation well in advance.
author: Roland N.

description:
Celebrated my friends (prettyy late) birthdays here on a weeknight. One of the friends in the group put her name down at around 7 and it was an hour wait for a party of 5

We got super lucky with street parking but the place itself was a touch small. It was an hour until we were finally seated. For appetizers we shared the deep fried salmon roll and the grilled shrimp salad. I actually really liked the salad- nice and tangy and the crispy pork skin was a nice touch.  Opened the handy dandy yelp app to look for suggestions so guesss what i got! The seabass that has greenbeans and some stir fried noodles. It was super filling and the seabass was tender and flaky. Noodles were aightt. A bit saucy haha and the green beans made me feel like i was eating a well balances meal. 

My friends- (ahem all 4) got the ahi tuna and i can confidently say none of them finished their rice. I know its asian fusion but yall aint need to add that much water. I noticed the table to us ordered something with rice and didnt finish that either. 

Aside from that ambiance was casual. Very good service and i was super full from my meal.
author: Linde H.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants! Cozy little underrated spot with AMAZING asian fusion food. I would easily recommend this place to anyone. Have not had one bad thing yet.

Our faves include... 
- the scallop appetizer (which is technically a 'special' but they seem to have it every time I come) Scallops are always cooked perfectly in a nice lemon ponzu - so sad you only get 3 :'(
- the sea bass with garlic ginger soy
The sea bass is flaky and buttery soft, which is a nice contrast to the salty garlic noodles and the green beans. 
- wasabi noodles with steak. 
The wasabi noodles are interesting, and the steak that comes with it is nicely cooked and seasoned well.

I've also tried the deep fried salmon rolls with Chinese mustard & the Pomegranate Pork Chop which are also amazing! 5 stars for sure!!!
author: Caroline K.

description:
Love this place !! recommended by a friend and she was right! Ordered the unagi as appetizer. It's so fresh and the sauce is perfect.  I also love their miso sea bass! Its so soft it melts in your mouth. It's a must try (I can finish two of those. ) Pork chop is also very good and it comes with fried taro chips for both dishes. 

Con- quite small inside and no valet parking
author: Pie P.

description: I went here with my boyfriend for our anniversary and had an amazing experience. Great staff and delicious food i would HIGHLY recommend! :)
author: Marlow S.

description:
This restaurant serves consistently delicious, perfectly cooked food for incredibly reasonable prices, especially for what you get.
For appetizer, I highly recommend the grilled octopus w/ avocado, potatoes & sriracha aioli for $16.
I love the kurobuta pork chop w/ pomegranate currant sauce which is $28. (1 of their most popular dishes)
The grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy noodles is another popular main dish for $31. The garlic ginger soy noodles are a must try!
Prime angus ribeye is good as well for $35.

4.2 stars for this restaurant as they could improve furniture/decor & service as some staff look/act like zombies from time to time. Other than that, I've received & observed great service the past 5x I've been here.
author: Eunjoo P.

description: Good and fresh fish selections. I've been here a few times now and have not been disappointed with my meals. This place has limited seating so if you're planing a visit on the weekends make sure you have reservations. It's lighter during the weekdays.
author: Tuuyen N.

description: Everything was soooo delicious! Highly recommend. The oysters, the poke, the scallops, and the sashimi were amazing! Never have I tasted anything so good! The dessert was amazing as well! Service is great, super friendly and welcoming, always checks up on you. They also have a very clean bathroom as well.
author: Kimberly C.

description: Came here for dinner last night. The poki starter was excellent and delicious. Had fried brown rice kernels throughout with avocados. Yummy. I ordered the sea bass. It was good but not as tender as I would like. It came with garlic noodles and green beans. My girlfriend had a chicken dish. It was a 1/4 Of a chicken with orange gravy over mashed potatoes and had grape tomatoes.  The chicken was very tender although I could not distinguish the sauce. All in all the food was good.
author: Donna L.

description:
The House is this super tight & cramped space that has the best sea bass I've ever had. It literally melts in your mouth. I have dreams about this dish.

Minus one star for how close the quarters are here - a waiter has elbowed me in the head while trying to serve another table (he was really apologetic, and all of the service is always lovely), and one time someone broke a beer bottle and it splattered on my shoe. Because the space is so small and there are so many tables crammed in, it gets really loud. The House is not your dream first date place.
author: Christina S.

description:
A great blend between feeling traditional yet modern at the same time. 

The salmon rolls were not as amazing as I thought they would be. The salmon itself was good quality, with no gristle. The breading was crispy and had almost a tender flakiness. There wasn't much of a wow factor in its flavor. Probably the biggest fault was my overactive imagination, dreaming up something that would blow me away. The Chinese hot mustard came with it, pops spicy like a firecracker. 

The umagi was some of the best eel I've had. It was so soft, I didn't have to use your teeth. Avocado rice on the bottom was equally as delicious. It had a great mixture between creamy avocado and sticky, carby rice. The sauce was the workhorse of the meal, tying everything together beautifully.

The black cod was pure joy. It was one of the few times in life where I couldn't tell whether the meat for the sauce was the best thing about the meal. The card was cooked just right, being tender, juicy, flaky, yet sturdy.  The lemon ponzu sauce was robust, sultry, yet with a light grace to it. The avocado oil surrounding the plate was a really nice touch. It gave the meal not only a more vegetable feel, but I'm more dense profile. The avocado sushi roll on top seemed a bit out of place, was much more 
appreciated than having a straight up scoop of rice.
author: Gill S.

description:
DANK AF. If you havent tried this spot in SF, please do yourself a favor and go. 

Order everything on the special menu. Forget the regular dishes.
author: Dennis H.

description:
It is a small place, basically full every time, but the service is very quick. I made a online reservation. 

The food is very tasty. My wife and me ordered the deep-fried salmon roll for appetizer, the wasabi noodles with flatiron steak (medium was perfect), and the pork chop with potato and asparragus. 

For dessert pineapple cake with vainilla ice cream!
author: Michael M.

description:
One of the better meals I've had in SF! The restaurant is small with limited tables, but it's cozy and peaceful in there -- makes for a good date spot or catch up sesh with a friend.

BE SURE TO MAKE RESERVATIONS. We were seated right away because we had reservations and the walk-ins that had been waiting 10-15min didn't seem too pleased.

Anyways, I'd recommend EVERYTHING that we ordered, which were the deep-fried salmon roll, ahi tuna tartare, grilled shrimp salad, and miso black cod. The salmon roll was unique and delicious - have never had a fried sushi roll before! Everything was better than average, especially the ahi tuna tartare which I wasn't expecting. Ahi tuna tartare is just tartare, but trust me, it's better here.

Also, parking is a nightmare around this area because there are a ton of establishments. Take public transportation, uber/lyft, or just walk.
author: Elvi T.

description:
The House is perfection. I've been here at least 10 times and I just keep coming back for more! The interior is small yet cozy, the reservations require a call-in (which I think makes it do-able to get a reservation) and the food is amazing. 

My favorites have remained the same through the years: 
-Tuna with nori chips
-Sea bass - a MUST! The sauce is amazing and it comes with garlic noodles
-Ribye - HO DAMN. The flavor is on point, cooked perfectly and coated with crunchy bits

The House is good for date night. It's good for parents. It's good for business dinners. It's just DAMN GOOD.
author: Christina L.

description:
The portion size of all their food was great. We started off with the salmon roll. The salmon roll was nicely fried as they were able to keep a pink center. We then order their scallop special with micro greens on top and the sauce finished off the dish with a bright lemony taste.

I order the pork chop and subbed out the mash potatoes with the garlic noodles. When the pork chop came out I was shocked at how massive this one chop was. The pork chop was topped with taro straws which added a great crunch to the dish.
author: Jackie N.

description:
So glad we had a reservation. The place is quite small and simple. The tables are pretty close to each other so if you are looking for an intimate dining experience, this may not be the place for you. The food however, is amazing! 

They have a great wine list and while the menu is limited, they do have some specials as well. The sea bass with the garlic noodles was delicious and fresh. The fish was soft and buttery and perfectly cooked and the garlicky noodles complemented it perfectly. The other dishes we ordered were all really tasty and so was dessert (bittersweet mousse cake)! The House is definitely one of my favorite Asian fusion places and I will be back! 

Don't recommend this place for vegetarians as I didn't notice anything vegetarian on the menu. Might be best to call them and check before you head there.
author: Shriya P.

description: Soooooo good. Came highly recommended by a friend and I'm so glad he did. Bursting with flavor, just the right portion meals, great service.
author: Jackie Q.

description: Haven't been there for years. Tried all 3 dishes and all was very tender n tasty.  I would very much like to go back some day and order the black rod cod.
author: Ms R.

description:
