I would have given it 5 stars if not because of the terrible service. My friend's purse is constantly kicked over due to the incredibly tight space, and my phone as placed on top of the greasy food because our waitress wanted to take back the menu. Surprising contrast to the quality of food.
author: Natalie L.

description:
I came here on 4/20 and the place was starting to get busy for dinner. Me and my boyfriend got a table right away with a reservation, do yourself a favor and make a reservation! 

We ordered quite a lot:
-2/5 salmon fried egg rolls: compared to all the hype about this appetizer, we were quite disappointed. It didn't taste as amazing as all the yelp reviews claimed it to. It was literally just a salmon fried in an egg roll paper.
-5/5 scallops appetizer: this was soooo good!! I would come here just for this again. The scallops were perfectly cooked, the sauce paired so well with the scallops, and everything was just perfect about this dish.
-5/5 sea bass with California maki roll: the sea bass was extremely tender, and I've never had it with this type of sauce it came with. I actually liked this more than my own dish! 
-4/5 pork chop with pomegranate currant: I was so excited to try this as the reviews raved about it! It was really good, probably one of the best pork chops I've ever tried, but it wasn't too special. The sauce seemed similar to the one that came out with the sea bass. 
-5/5 passion fruit creme brûlée: nothing much to say about this dessert, it was a good creme Brûlée with a twist because of the passion fruit flavor. 

Overall, the dishes were nicely presented and extremely flavorful. Will probably come again!
author: Judy K.

description: Seriously. The Sea Bass. Get it. It was the tastiest thing I've ever eaten. There were only two gluten free options, one being the sea bass and the other was the ahi. Both were delicious. But definitely get the sea bass... 10 out of 10! And our waiter was phenomenal!
author: Lee A.

description:
I recently moved to San Francisco not too long ago and a friend suggested this place. I was looking for the top places to eat in San Francisco so I gave it a go. We made reservations because we heard it gets really packed on the weekends. Before I went to The House, I looked it up on yelp to see what kind of food they served. It looked like Asian fusion that looked more upscale.

My thoughts and ratings:

 FIRST IMPRESSION: 2 Stars

The place is kind of hidden. I abruptly stopped walking because our friend knew where the place was. The restaurant looked kinda out of place. The inside was much smaller than I had expected. It looked like a small Pho restaurant (viet noodle restaurant). It was very cramped and claustrophobic. For upscale food, the restaurant itself looked very casual.

SERVICE: 3 Stars

Right when we got into the restaurant, we told the servers that we had reservations. Now, I have worked in various restaurants with reservations. You could immediately tell they did not have us planned to dine with them even though we called and made reservations. So guess what they did? Cleaned up a corner table that recently left and then sat us there. There were 5 of us and it was super cramped. Was not happy about it but hey, we got a table. Rest of the service was average and the food came out quickly. I think they need to train their servers on pouring bottled beer into a glass. The server had no idea how to pour the beer into a glass. It was 70% foam in the glass. We had two beers and she poured both of them like it was wine. Not really impressed.

FOOD: 5 Stars

Oh Em Gee. The food was bomb! We ordered the salmon roll, seabass, salmon, pork chop, and the cod. The food looked so delicious and it tasted even more delicious. My favorite was the cod with slanted sliced sushi rolls. The food was very flavorful and really well presented. I was really happy about the food.

OVERALL THOUGHTS: 4 Stars

The restaurant was cramped and it did not match the upscale look of the food they were serving. The service was average and nothing to really rave about. They had wine bottles by the cash register which was... odd. My view of the restaurant where I was sitting was the cash register and the kitchen right behind it. Not exactly the type of view I would want while eating great food lol I wasn't very far from it either. It didn't have any ambiance. This restaurant is more of a, "eat your food and then go" type of place. I felt like I couldn't really stay and enjoy the company I had. The only thing that saves this place is the food. Nothing more. If you're looking for a place to just have bomb Asian fusion food, this is definitely the place! Definitely coming back for the food only!
author: Tiger Y.

description:
Yo, is the food infused with crack or something? Because I'm addicted! I've enjoyed many memorable dinners at this tiny restaurant over the years and it still remains one of my favorites in the city. 

I typically hate cooked fish with a passion, but will voraciously scarf down the sea bass here. It's THAT good, guys! I'm also a noodle junkie, and the flatiron steak with wasabi noodles make me go crazy! In fact, I don't even talk to my dining companion when I'm eating here - I'm too busy burying my face in the glorious food and munching away. 

If the scallop starter special is available, GET IT! It'll make you go OOOOOOOOFF!!!!! The salmon rolls are delicious as well. Actually, everything is good so just order the entire menu!
author: Suany W.

description: The food here is phenomenal and the atmosphere is so cute and cozy. My only complaint has to be that the service is subpar and the tables are too close to one another, making the place feel too crowded and tight.
author: Cynthia H.

description: Vegans have no fear! They will make a fantastic House Noodle, Vegetable, and Tofu dish upon request.
author: Nick L.

description:
My wife and I came here for our wedding anniversary based on the large number of rave reviews. We both found the food so very mediocre, especially at those prices. 

OUR DISHES:
1. scallops = actually quite good, nice sear, tasty balanced sauce, and cooked just right.
2. grilled octopus = blah; I think it was either poached too long or an old festering cut as it was mushy. The sauce was so bland. 
3. ribeye = tender, grilled to medium rare; cauliflower and mashed potatoes were fine; sauce was overly sweet, almost cloying.
4. chocolate truffle cake = very small sliver, not overly sweet, was pretty mediocre

SERVICE:
It was fine, but it felt very rushed. We were still working on our ribeye when a server came to take our plate while there was still a good amount of food on it. What?? At least they kept our drinks topped off.

AMBIENCE:
Very drab, it felt like sitting in a dentist office waiting room.

TOILET PAPER:
Single ply!? When you charge those prices, at least do us a favor and get 2-ply!

I have zero interest in going back, and I would not recommend. I'm not sure what the enthusiasm is about.
author: Patrick C.

description: The House knows how to deliver. Well, I don't know if they do home deliveries, but the chef sure knows how to deliver on my plate!!!! The flavors used on the Chilean seabass are pleasing to the palate. I especially love the grilled scallops. Crisp on the outside, juicy on the inside. This is a tiny restaurant, so be sure to make reservations. Otherwise you'll be waiting for at least an hour. Parking is also a doozy. Outside of that, The House is a must for anyone visiting SF!!!
author: Ali R.

description:
Oh my god! I don't even know where to start, such a great experience we went 5 min after they open for dinner so we didn't need to wait which was awesome! Service was A 1, new plates and utensils after every new dish came out, love places that does that. The House really makes you feel just like home, it's like at a corner and the place is small and lovely. The outside design of the restaurant has like a Dr.Seuss theme. We ordered the Selected Oysters On The Half Shell served with spicy cilantro mignonette, Grilled Sea Bass served with garlic ginger soy, Warm Wasabi House Noodles served with Angus Flatiron Steak, Seared Hokkaido scallops, lemon ponzu, micro greens.

Seared Hokkaido scallops, lemon ponzu, micro greens: This comes with 3 Hokkaido scallops but it's perfectly made with great flavors, definitely recommended!

Oysters On The Half Shell served with spicy cilantro mignonette: it was good and fresh, love the sauce, it has a bit is spiciness and sweet, but overall it was the best oyster I had!

Warm Wasabi House Noodles served with Angus Flatiron Steak: The steak was so delicious and made perfectly, we requested it to be medium rare and it was so good, the noodles was very good as well, I think they make the noodles fresh themselves there.

Grilled Sea Bass served with garlic ginger soy: The grilled sea bass was made so perfectly that when I took a bite it melts in your mouth with so much flavor and the dipping sauce they made for the sea bass made it extra special!

Overall it was a great experience and great food, definitely coming back again!
author: Christopher G.

description:
One word, fire.
Had the atlantic cod and fried salmon rolls.   Flavors out of this world, would definitely come back for those two.
author: Alexander C.

description: The House was great.  Bustling and lively, it has the feel of a local favorite. We had delicious mushroom soup, killer Korean short ribs w kimchi and a coconut creme brulee w passion puree that had me flippin'.  Seriously the best creme brulee I've ever tasted...but I'm a freak for passion fruit.
author: Mark S.

description: On a quick visit from Denver, my husband and I were told to check out this place. We were absolutely amazed at the food quality and flavors. We both had their sea bass and it was delicious. We  came back the next day for more! We got to meet the owner Angela, and she was kind and personable. Every time visit San Francisco, we are going to be visiting this restaurant again and again.
author: Edie C.

description:
My consistent and favorite local (what used to be a) hole in the wall restaurant serving up Euro-Asian fine dining at affordable pricing.  The simple, family owned boutique restaurant has kept the quality of their meals consistent, with a creative twist I certainly appreciate.  

I recommend the signature dish, the miso-cod topped with California roll.  Some other dishes that I also highly recommended are: kale salad, scallops, king crab toast, clams or mussels with toast, mushroom risotto, and of course, save room for dessert.  The coconut creek brûlée, mango tapioca and decadent chocolate cake with coffee ice cream are to die forrrrrr...
author: Vivienne K.

description:
My son who lives in SF picked this out and made reservations. The place was unassuming and the food was spectacular. We started with 2 apps - the salmon roll and octopus. My wife was sure she want having either when we ordered and even she was amazed by bother the presentation and the flavor. Must try for sure. My wife and daughter split the kale salad and it was good but that it was warm threw them off. We ordered 3 entries and all were amazing- salmon, halibut ahi tuna. Can't recall the various base sauces but OMG, trust the chef and enjoy! Truly a place I'd visit again next trip to visit my son, and he commented that he'd definitely be back to try other menu items. 

Visitor or local, a must try restaurant.
author: Joe A.

description: Excellent food! Everything was really fresh and beautifully arranged on a plate. There are plenty of appetizers to choose from, portions big and can be shared. The sea bass was grilled to perfection: flaky but moist and flaky. Flat iron steak was tender and flavorful.
author: Olga E.

description:
One of the highly recommended places in SF from friends and family,  but I give this place more of a 3.5. If you want Asian fusion in the $24-$40 range per plate, I would recommend this spot..depending on what you order

To start off, this place is notoriously TINY, tiny as in "you can bump elbows with the guest next to you". So tiny that, my boyfriend was inches of getting barfed on by a passing customer (tru story). So it's best to get a reservation, especially if it's a party larger than 2. 
We came around 6:30-7 Sunday night and only waited about 5 minutes for a table.

Muscles appetizer: The broth for this dish was SO flavorful. My boyfriend and I ended up spooning the sauce as if it were soup when we were done. I wish it came with a side of some bread however. 8.5/10

Sea bass with garlic noodles: this is a dish The House is most known for. Admittedly the seabass was flakey and buttery, however it did not WOW me. The garlic noodles were very saucey, different than what you would typically find at Vietnamese/Cajun places. The sauce they provided on the side tasted similar to the sauce they use for the garlic noodles. If you really love grilled fish you may like this, but I think there may be better things offered. 7/10

Angus steak: It was cooked to a medium rare and was quite juicy. It came with a side of mash potatoes that did not wow us, and some cauliflower. 7.5/10

Solely on the food this place is a solid 3.5-4, however I wish they had their daily specials on some sort of board or menu. I'm sure I would have liked something better on that list. You don't get the full description of what's on the dish from the server, and it's confusing when your trying to decide between entrees.
author: Jacqueline N.

description:
For a restaurant as popular as the House, it was surprisingly easy to get a reservation. I think I must have called them on a Tuesday and was able to get a reservation for 5:30pm on Saturday.

We got the pork chop, sea bass, and garlic noodles. There was no part of the meal that disappointed.

The pork chop is the best pork chop that I've ever had in my life. A lot of pork chops that I've had have been dry and tough, but the pork chop here is moist and soft. 

This was my first time ever having sea bass, and I think I'm ruined for life. It was so soft, flakey, and buttery. The garlic noodles was a good pairing, as having the sea bass by itself may not have been enough food. 

Everything had a great flavor, and was not bland or too salty. Perfect balance!

We left a little lighter in our pockets, but full in our bellies. Very reasonably priced. I would definitely come back here and probably order the same thing.
author: Jacqueline V.

description:
Consistently delivers. The food here is so flavorful, so creative, and just sooo good. 

Great wine and sake too and the service is always great. Just wish they would get onboard with one of the reservation apps.
author: Jeff C.

description:
Went mid week around 8:30. It was still pretty full but squeezed in for two. I would not suggest sitting near the door, it's drafty and too distracting in general. Make a reservation if you can.  I have been here twice previously and always enjoyed their food. It embodies the essence of Asian fusion although it seems to have gotten a lot pricier recently. 
The grilled octopus was just tasty. found the meat to be a bit chewy as you'd expect, but I liked the sauce.
My steak over house noodles was ordered cooked medium rare, and came out very rare.The meat was quite fatty too. Noodles were well seasoned and not over done. They do not carry local beer, which is a drag. Interior is crowded, with small tables closely packed. They can't fit more than a couple dishes on the 2 tops at a time. Good for a party feeling, but not romance. Service was prompt and speedy. It seemed a little too much like a mill than a place to really sit back and enjoy.
author: Aaron Z.

description:
4K+ reviews..wow

OK hopefully I can provide some useful tips after going here for about a decade and recently.

I was there on a Saturday Night (made ressie day before) at the first seating (5-5:30) and I believe they were taking walking-ins...so it's probably one of the best options for a last minute decision.

That said come for the appetizers because they look cool and taste even better (foams, gels, towers...yup all the cool stuff you see on Top Chef represented).

The entrees is a mixed bag. Some of the all time greats and favorites have been inconsistent in terms of quality (ie. under-cooked fish)

I dock it a star because we have always felt rushed and it's crowded (the place is tiny and there's no waiting area and the tables are pretty close to each other); far from a fine dining experience in terms of ambiance, but the food and price are the draw.
author: Dank I.

description: Good food, somewhat cold service, and generally long wait (or difficult time finding a reservation) butttt I think the food is good enough to overcome the other two drawbacks.
author: Taline M.

description:
Not really sure why the reviews here are so amazing.  Most nicer restaurants in SF are decent...but it's the price that's the killer.  The House was your average "good food", but not worth the price, and I probably wouldn't come back.

Of course before sitting down, I scoped out everyone's dishes (and I'm the type who's not afraid to ask my neighbor what I should or shouldn't get...what's "personal space"? haha).  None of the main dishes stood out, so my friend and I ordered multiple "smalls".

- Pickled cucumbers.  Bomb. Complimentary starter.  Fantastic zing from the vinegar with a hint of sweetness to balance it out.  Too bad you only get one tiny dish of it and then have to pay $5 for each extra one.
- Unagi on avocado rice.  Let's be real...it's hard to get eel wrong...it will almost always be enjoyable.  Theirs was definitely flavorful, but it came from the dousing of terryaki sauce on the eel as well as the avocado rice below it that was probably more mayo than rice.  Let the eel speak for itself please.
- Scallops.  The most well-done dish.  I'm not a huge scallops fan, but they cooked it extremely well.  Soft, but with a good bite to it.
- Grilled Octopus.  Again...saucy.  I can't even give a review on what I thought because all I tasted was sauce.  Although...the crispy fried potatoes that are part of the dish were EXCELLENT.

If you couldn't tell by my review....it can be summed up in two words: Too Saucy.  Across the board.

Caveat...I didn't try the main dishes, so maybe those are better?
author: Mon T.

description: Hands down one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. I've eaten here for dinner on many occasions and it never disappoints. It is not a fancy restaurant by any means but the food presentation is impressive. Additionally, the prices are reasonable for the quality of the food. My favorite dish is the mushroom rice. If you can get a reservation on a Friday/Saturday night, I'd definitely recommend!
author: Diana R.

description: The House is a small, cramped, and packed restaurant that primarily serves Asian style seafood dishes. Even with 7pm dinner reservations on a Saturday night, I had to wait about 15 minutes for a table to open up for two. The waiter recommended the Grilled Sea Bass with Garlic Ginger Soy so that's what I ordered. The fish was cooked perfectly tender and meaty. The side of Garlic Ginger Soy Sauce was flavorful and the perfect compliment to the fish. However, the sauce was a little on the salty side.
author: Nicolas L.

description:
Easy reservation process. Great service. Food was outstanding!

I got the warm wasabi house noodles with steak. Definitely recommended. It wasn't too spicy and the steak was cooked perfectly. They also gave us a small app plate to start which we really appreciated because we were so hungry at that point. 

Thank you for a great experience for our first time in San Francisco!
author: Jessica L.

description: So this place is good and the servers are super friendly but the food is not as authentic. There's Japanese and American fusion. The dishes are all very saucy. At the end of the meal I felt that my taste buds were saturated with various sauces. The restaurant left me wanting a palate cleanser....something light and refreshing.
author: Logan N.

description: My favorite dish I tried from here was the wasabi noodles with king salmon.  The noodles were really thick but also soft.  The flavor was nice and not too spicy and the salmon was cooked perfectly.  I also tried the ahi tuna poke, which was a special for that day, and it was a large serving mixed with a lot of avocado and crispy rice.  The salad with shrimp and scallop tempura was light and delicious.  The shrimp and chive dumplings were my least favorite of the meal, and I could've done without it.  Overall, it was a tasty meal at a reasonable price for the amount of food.  It was more than enough for two people.  I would come back to try the rest of the menu.
author: Michelle A.

description:
Pretty good, overall I would rate The House as more of a 3.5, but I made reservations about a month in advance for two at 7pm and got seated near the back of the restaurant. I was not happy about that. I also really wanted to try their Miso Black Cod, but then the waiter told me they had just run out. Again, not pleased so 3 stars it is.

My friend and I ordered their 1) Deep-fried salmon roll, chinese hot mustard and 2) One of their special/off the menu small dishes that consisted of Dungeness crab on crackers as appetizers. The Deep-fried salmon roll, chinese hot mustard was probably my favorite dish out of all the things we ordered. I would give 4 stars for that dish alone. The Dungeness crab one was okay.

For my main entree I ordered their Mahi Mahi special (Again, off the menu) and my friend ordered the Grilled ahi tuna, spicy mustard aioli. My Mahi Mahi was on the dry side and a bit bland. I had a taste of my friend's Grilled ahi tuna too, which was good but nothing spectacular.

Extremely small restaurant. Nice service. Overall I was underwhelmed and disappointed with the food, given the high ratings on Yelp. Not sure if I would want to come again.
author: Debra T.

description:
I got to know this place through "Check Please" a KQED restaurant​ show, seventeen years ago. Then I ordered sea bass, there came one square fish on the plate. No garnish or vegetable on the side. I remember every restaurant I went would serve bread and butter, classier would serve olive oil and
 balsamic vinegar to go with your meal. But this place...NADA  ! At that moment, I decided not to order dessert or coffee. I felt like I been ripped off.
author: Abel Y.

description:
One of my favorite places in this area. I've been here for dinner before but this time I came here for lunch. The choices on the menu are excellent and moderately priced. I ordered the House Wasabi Noodles with Pork.  Noodles were perfectly cooked and the pork was juicy, tender. and nicely seared on the outside. The dish had the right balance of sweet and spicy flavors. 
The service was good as one would expect from a upscale restaurant. Definitely worth a try if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Lochan P.

description: Get the Cod and get the sea bass.  After dining on the fried salmon and dungeoness crab  appetizers, which were good, we were treated to a true culinary experience.  The sea bass had a slightly charredl outer crust, which quite frankly made the dish.  The richness of the fish shined through as sea bass normally does, but man, the charred exterior was awesome.  The cod was amazingly just as rich and moist as the sea bass, and it had a very nice blend of flavors to accompany it.   We did wait for 90 minutes on a Friday evening, but it was worth it!
author: Matt W.

description: Late post. Went to San Francisco on March with my boyfriend and we were craving something late night. We started looking for something to eat around in the middle of San Francisco and we were stunned of how many good review this place had Unexpectedly this place is very small but had lots of people the waiters have trouble walking around because there r no space  BUT the food omg the food was so delicious and delightfully well done we were stunned once more haha I just wish they get busier and move out to a bigger place XP
author: Emily K.

description:
For the complete uncensored 411 on dining and the food at THE HOUSE, please see my original review below (it may be helpful- hopefully). And yes, the food here is DELICIOUS! 

If you are going to attempt to order food to go, here is the  deal: they probably won't let you. 

One fateful night, that Seabass was callin' our name and we attempted to phone in an order because we just didn't feel like dressing appropriately, showering, waiting in the cold, waiting in a packed restaurant, dining in a packed restaurant. You get the gist: it was a garlic noodle and Netflix night. 

On the phone, a (bless her heart) airy gal said we can't make a to-go order unless we are on the approved list and if it's our first time ordering to go, it must be in person (which, albeit, unfortunately MOSTLY defeats the purpose of ordering to go for this situation). 

Next, manager hops on the line. To be fair, she was nice and I could tell she cared to an extent. She said if she could pull up an old reservation she "would ALLOW me to order" (Cue imperious tone). Problem is, though we've been there 4-5 times (and recommended this place to others) we've never made reservations. Cue awkward pause. 

Well. Thanks for offering me the favor of giving you my business but I'm not going to beg you to let me give you my money, if the pause was awaiting a plea & bargain. 

To whoever owns this joint: It's 2017. Your food is popular and that's a great thing! We are in the digital age, in San Francisco for crying out loud. I know some very discourteous Donkey's probably order and never pick up- which creates a loss, but I offered to pay over the phone. There are services you can utilize to protect your business and better serve your customer (and not lose either way). 

I'm not going to be dramatic and not come back- heck, no one else in town is serving Sea bass like yours (yet). I just want you to know where your opportunities lie.
author: Amanda A.

description:
Had dinner here on Sunday night and even with reservations, had a little bit of a bit. Based on our experience, here's what you need to know:

- Make a reservation. After you check-in with the hostess, be sure you're there to hear when your name is called. It was super busy that night and I overhead the hostess tell someone waiting that another group had taken their table when their name was called. 

- Look at the menu before sitting down. If you're anything like me, you'll be hungry by then and not want to waste precious time looking at the menu for the first time. 

- Listen to everyone else and order the deep-fried salmon roll, sea bass and wasabi noodles. They are favorites here for a reason. I had the sea bass over wasabi noodles while my bf had the noodles with steak. So good! We also really enjoyed the octopus.
author: Therese M.
Miko B.

description:
I wish I could give more than 5 stars, I would!! 
This restaurant has some of the best food and service I've had in a very long time. I would highly recommend it. Eva,the manager is incredibly accommodating and truly understands what her customers want and need. I will be craving the Ahi, Cod, short ribs, and garlic noodles for a long time to come!! We even got our young teenage daughters to try things that they would never try, and they loved it!! I can't wait to come back!! No they didn't give me a discount and no I was not paid to post this!! Go Go Go!! Bon appetite!! You can thank me later!
author: Kristine F.

description: This was a wonderful meal..the scallops appetizer wad fantastic and the halibut tempura was to die for. The price...120 for two including one glass of sake was fairly pricy...wonderful lunch but very expensive.
author: John Z.

description:
Awesome food! Solid service. Very small venue. The wasabi noodle w steak dish is good. The fish was excellent. Appetizers are amazing. Beer and wine only. Make a reservation - they are usually packed
Highly recommend end
author: robin l.

description:
Fantastic and tasty Asian style cuisine.
The House has amazing atmosphere.
The staff was really great too even though they were busy)
author: Jaycee B.

description: Small little place . Good food and decent service . Menu needs to change more often for what they are trying to pretrade
author: Steven M.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  Good for date night.
author: David K.

description:
Been here twice. First time, ordered 1-2
Appetizers and then a main. I wasn't amazed by the tastes. Maybe it's because I'm Asian and already used to those flavors. 

Fast forward a few years later and we decided to
try again. This time, we ordered only appetizers-including the chef's special miso broth Manila clams. The flavor was so amazing we thought the chef was Japanese..but he's Chinese! 

We also ordered the octopus which was grilled well and not overdone. I was able to taste the nice char grill. 

Minus one star for the crispy pork skin salad. The dressing was bland and the crispy pork skin was unflavored. Needed salt and lime. 

Glad we gave them a second shot!
author: Nikki T.

description: Ate here again. The best sea bass I've ever eaten. And the wasabi noodles was awesome. Didn't enjoy mango tapioca but loved the creme brûlée. Shrimp dumplings were ok.
author: Ashutosh T.

description: Our family enjoyed lunch here.  We had made a reservation for six which was probably a good idea based on the small dining area.  Service was prompt, and the servers were personable and professional. For appetizers, we enjoyed blue lake bean tempura, white shrimp and Chinese chive dumplings, and deep-fried salmon rolls with Chinese hot mustard. We had a variety of entrees all of which were delicious. The desserts were the proverbial icing on the cake. The diet starts Monday (date to be determined).  I would not hesitate to return or recommend The House to a friend.
author: Russ O.

description: Absolute perfection, wow this place is delicious!! We came here for lunch and were seated immediately. The service was amazing. The food is to die for!!! Sea bass was crazy good! And it's pricey but totally worth it!! I'm coming back!!!
author: Lana S.

description:
OVERALL: 
*Recommend making a reservation, though not a must
*Highly recommend the Kurobota Pork Chop and Mushroom Rice w/ Grilled Prawns and Shaved Bonito

I booked a reservation here about 3 weeks ahead of time for a party of 8 for 7:30PM - my family and I got here at 7:30 and the table was all set for us. Definitely recommend making a reservation if you have a larger party, or anything in general, since this place is quite a small establishment and quite popular even on a Monday! We came for my college graduation dinner, and I've got to say, I'm happy I chose this place. There's something for everyone (except I wouldn't recommend this place for vegans / vegetarians) - mostly known for their seafood, their pork chop was also AMAZING. 

[FOOD]
1) Mushroom Rice with Truffle and Prawns (6/5) - This absolutely blew my mind away!! My mom and I were in heaven with this dish and that says something because my mom's taste buds are sooooo picky. The truffle taste wasn't too overwhelming, but perfectly there and the rice wasn't overlooked nor undercooked. I loved the bits of vegetables mixed in, as it added more texture and substance to the dish. 
2) Sea Bass (4/5) - Many fellow Yelpers love this dish, and I could see why. The sea bass was perfectly soft, smooth, and moist. Dip it into the sauce, and it was A+. My only gripe are that the noodles and the beans that came along with it weren't "OMG" but just a "Oh, that's good too". 
3) Pork Chop with Cranberry Sauce (5/5) - My second favorite dish here - the pork Chop was cooked to perfection, so moist! The cranberry sauce added the perfect amount of sweetness to bring this dish to a whole new level. Must get!
4) Salmon Deep Fried Roll (3/5) - It wasn't anything too spectacular; salmon itself tends to be a bit dry. Dipped in the sauce, it was filled with flavor. 

[DESSERT]
5) Blackberry Crumble Pie (5/5) - Yesssss!! My favorite dessert here. I don't know what it is about this; normally, I'm not a fan of Pie, but I think the crumble complemented the mushiness/softness of how a fruit pie usually tastes. I can't say the blackberry taste was very strong as there was also apple or something (I can't remember). 
6) Chocolate Macadamia Tart (3/5) - This was okay.. the chocolate macadamia tart part wasn't anything spectacular. The coffee ice cream went well with the chocolate, and it was definitely very chocolatey. I can't seem to describe the texture though 
7) Coconut Creme Brulee (4/5) - I think the sugar also has some lime, which some people in my family thought was odd since it wasn't exactly mixed into the dessert, but just a "BAM! sour!" The coconut part was very smooth, and not too overwhelmingly coconut if that's a concern 

[PARKING] 
Parking can be a pain, especially in SF. There are plenty of street parking around, although difficult to find an open spot. I did see a parking lot sign right next to the restaurant though. 

[SERVICE]
they have specials of the night, and the waitresses and waiters were all very friendly. They switched out our plates and utensils after appetizers, and were sure to fill up our water cups promptly.
author: Jacqueline T.

description: This place is absolutely amazing!! The food was to die for. I had the Sashimi special with Hamachi, Salmon, and Tuna. The Hamachi was melt in your mouth good. My husband and I also had the crab and avocado toast, Korean short rib special, and the Thai iced tea panna cotta. Everything was decadent! The service was excellent too. 4 different people came to check in on our table. Complete 5 star service and food. Highly recommend!
author: Shay L.

description: So amazingly delicious! Ordered the Seared Yellowtail, one of the specials tonight. Great ambiance and great service.
author: Francesca C.

description:
I've been here about 3 times, all for dinners. I highly recommend calling them to make a reservation. They don't have an OpenTable or anything.

I've ordered:
1. Tuna tartare
2. Shrimp and Chive Dumplings
3. Deep-fried salmon rolls
4. Grilled sea bass
5. Wasabi noodles w/ flatiron steak

I think that you can't go wrong ordering the grilled sea bass or the wasabi noodles. Those seem to be the dishes that people recommend the most, and there is a reason for it. The wasabi flavor in the noodles is not strong. The sea bass is always cooked perfectly. I tried the salmon rolls twice. It is served with a Chinese mustard sauce. I think it is worth trying once, but I don't have a strong urge to order it again. The dumplings are dumplings. Did they taste good? Yes, but I don't think I would order them again. I would want to try something else. The tuna tartare is always good.

This place is pretty small, and there are a ton of tables. Be prepared to basically eat on top of your table neighbors. Given the size of the place, I don't think this place would be good for large parties. The service can be a hit or a miss. There have been times that I have gone and service has been excellent. There have also been other times that I have gone and the service was meh with a lot of attitude. Given everything, I would come back. I think that the prices can be a bit steep for the portion that you get, but the food is always tasty and well executed.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
One of the best and recommended restaurant in SF. Place is small but the staff/crews did their job well.
Foods are not just attractive but really tasty..
author: Mega Team R.

description:
Overall pretty good.

Shrimp dumplings,  scallops, black cod and coconut brulee with passion fruit. 
Cod was a little undercooked for my liking. 

 They should be a little more careful browning things that they don't burn.  The scallops were boarding on having that burnt taste and the creme brulee was way torched and bitter but I scooped the shell off and was still able to enjoy it.
author: Adriana B.

description:
Got 6 items, split amongst me and a friend, for a total of around $80

Appetizer: Seared scallops (7/10)
Entrees: Halibut (9/10), Ahi Tuna (9/10), Angus Ribeye (10/10)
Dessert: Strawberry cheesecake (9/10), Coconut creme brûlée with passion fruit purée (6/10)

For $80, trying out that many dishes wasn't bad at all.

The scallops were good, sauce was a bit too sweet for me but it was a nice start to the meal. 
Halibut and Ahi tuna were great, I love the fried straws of vegetables they put on top of the dishes, it's great way to add to  the texture of the meal. The ribeye was absolutely amazing, and straight up melted in my mouth.
Cheesecake was super tasty, but for the coconut creme brûlée they put too much passion fruit purée on top so overall it was too sour. 

Would definitely come again!
author: Frank W.

description: Undeniably one of the best meals I've had in this city. Thank you #millennials  The stars and reviews speak for themselves. Nothing more I could add. Just go here!
author: Michelle S.

description:
Whenever a chance to dine out for a special occasion comes up, The House is one of the first places that comes to mind. The restaurant is low-key and casual, but the food is absolutely amazing...and it's consistently good! I highly recommend the grilled sea bass with garlic noodles. The sea bass has the perfect texture and the noodles are so flavorful. Other dishes that are worth trying are the clam appetizer and the angus ribeye steak. For dessert, the crime brûlée and mango tapioca pudding are my favorite.

Definitely call in to make a reservation, because space is limited, and this restaurant is often packed.
author: Jennifer X.

description:
We each had the Garlic Ribeye. It was pretty yummy!

The sides with it were pretty simple mashed potatoes and veggies. No soup or salad though comes with the meal. 

Overall it was yummy and I'm glad we went. 

Although my husband was still a little hungry afterwords. 
We may have gotten In n Out After.
author: Sarena C.

description:
I came here on a Tuesday night at 6pm and the place was already packed! Had to wait for 45-60mins just to get a table for 2 but soooo worth the wait. My party and I tried the deep fried salmon roll, sea bass, and the flatiron steak. I've never been a big fan of asian fusion restaurants but The House unexpectedly gave me a great impression!

Deep fried salmon roll: 4.5/5 Did not smell fishy. Great textures: softness from salmon and crunchiness from the seaweed wrap. The Chinese mustard had wasabi in it and it went well with the roll.

Wasabi house noodles w/ flatiron steak: 4/5 I asked for a medium steak and I wish I gotten it a little rarer. I got this dish because I wanted to see what the hype over the wasabi noodles was about... I liked the noodles but without the wasabi it would've just been typical lo mein noodles with a lot of sauce. The noodles were a bit overcooked. Still good but not as impressive as the roll.

Last but not least, the sea bass! 5/5 OMG this was the best dish of the night! I'm not a big fish fan but this sea bass blew my mind. PERFECTLY smoked and buttered up. Every bite was just as good as the first bite. I still cannot believe it. I'm def getting this again the next time I come.
author: Emily L.

description: Expensive but really really good! I ordered salmon rolls and it was so soft like butter in your mouth, the freshness of it is unbelievable. One of my favorites in SF!
author: Kiro W.

description: My favorite restaurant in San Francisco for the food.  I probably eat too much so trust me.  The pomengranate, blueberry pork chop is insanely great.  Like crazy, crazy great.  Tender and a flavor orgasm.  If you haven't gone, you got to go.
author: Rich k.

description:
My favorite restaurant in the city. Love the fusion of cuisine there. Everything we ordered was cooked perfectly and was super tasty. The fish (sea bass) was exquisite, the red meat (Wasabi noodles) was super tender and properly cooked (I can tell they use great products). The jumbo scallops were perfectly sizzled in butter and still soft inside! We loved every single thing in the meal. It was the 2nd time we came here with my wife and this restaurant doesn't disappoint!

My recommendations:
- Jumbo scallops with yuzu sauce
- deep fried salmon rolls 
- sea bass 
- the crème brûlée for dessert!
author: Remy B.

description: After a long anticipated visit to The House for what I heard would an incredible pork chop turned out to be a tremendous disappointment. The pork chop had excessive fat throughout. This was not the center cut I might have expected, but a loin cut that you would find in a lesser type restaurant. It was excessively expensive for what I got at $26. Even worse, I recommended it to two of my friends who dining with me. The service was exceptional, however.
author: Fred S.

description:
My family went out for a day in San Francisco. We shopped and hung out. It was nearing dinner time and we decided to go down to The House. This is a pretty popular restaurant in SF, so we had to wait around 40 minutes. I recommend going there earlier so the lines are shorter. 
However, the lines were most definitely worth it. The food was AMAZING with a capital everything. I love love loved all the dishes my family ordered. The House is on the pricier side, so I recommend going there for a celebration of some kind like a birthday. To start off the meal, we ordered the appetizer, avocado dungess crab cake. It was sosososos good. It had a wonderful medley of flavors. I recommend ordering this. A tip of advice is incorporating everything into one bite. Like get a little of this and a little of that. I'm not really sure how to describe it... but yeah, order it! 
Then for the main courses, we ordered wasabi house noodles with angus flat iron steak, grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy, kurobuta pork chop with pomegranate currant sauce, and prime angus ribeye with house made teriyaki roasted garlic butter. The pork chop was the dish I ordered and I'm so glad I did. I stole little pieces from the other dishes my family ordered and the pork chop was the best, most outstanding dish. The meat was super tender and flavorful and that's not even the best part. The best component of the dish was the pomegranate current sauce. Wow, just wow. It was the perfect combination of sweet and a little acid. The house noodles were a close second though. My favorite type of noodles is thick chewy ones like the ones we got at The House. They were magnificent. They are a tab bit spicy so watch out for that. As for the ribeye and the sea bass, those were super delicious as well. I recommend all four of these main dishes. We didn't order dessert sadly because we were stuffed. The price for these dishes were not cheap, but at least they came with huge portions. All in all, I highly recommend that you give The House a visit for it's out of this world tasting food.
author: Cute Dine R.

description: This is so far one of my favor in SF.  The salmon roll is crunch.  sea bass with noodle and beans are delicious, as well as mushroom shrimp rice.  Finally, the coconut creme brûlée is yummy.  We paired with sake and oolong tea.  We will be back.
author: J L.

description:
I made a reservation. Was told 30 mins when I arrived, ended up waiting 60 mins before leaving.

Worse part is the servers told me they were cleaning tables for me TWICE! 

Both times they said the table was for me they sat Caucasian people who came after me. One group was a bunch of guys with Google tee shirts on. 

Is this what San Francisco has come to?

I don't want to pull the race card BUT this was horrible and obvious racism. 

I won't come here again.
author: Bauble C.

description:
Small cozy asian restaurant with terrific flavors! 
Loved anything we tried , they are very good at sauces and flavors its really hard to go wrong.
Grilled octopus was fresh and tender with a kick of spicy!
Salmon Spring roll was delicious with the wasabi hint sauce!
Steak&Noodles with great spices and delicious veggie&noodle mix!
Honestly we all finished our plates to the last bite! Its totally worth the wait enjoooy!!
author: Merve C.

description:
My bf always likes to challenge me to try and find gems.

We were walking around and wanted a good restaurant.

I found this place and walked over.

The food is solid. Probably one of the best Asian fusion restaurants I've ever dined at.

My bf ordered the steamed clams, I ordered the salmon fried rolls, and we split the octopus.  

The food was amazing.

I also loved the small intimate setting.
author: Aidan V.

description:
It's a pretty nondescript entrance with a yellow neon sign above it and you could walk by multiple times without even noticing it. It's kind of odd that you would find asian fusion in the Russian district, but it's AMAZING asian fusion.

Reservations are a must here, as they can only seat about 30-40 people at a time. Call a week ahead too if you want to get a reasonable time for your party.

They have daily specials in addition to their crazy delicious menu. Came with 3 friends and we got their soft shell crab appetizer special. The presentation was spectacular, and it tasted even better. It was served with some angel hair pasta and the crab had some breadsticks sticking out of it for added effect. The crab was light and airy while still perfectly crunchy and without any of the pungent seafood smell.

For our main dishes, we went with the halibut special, which was served with a cream sauce, the flank steak and wasabi noodles and the lamb special. The halibut was cooked to perfection. It was crispy on the outside, but flaky and succulent inside. Paired with the cream sauce, it was a match made in heaven. The lamb chops were frenched on the rib, a difficult technique to get right, but this place made it look easy and clean. They'll cook the lamb to whatever temperature you request, and they'll nail it. The wasabi noodles and flank steak is their calling card, and it's easy to see why. The noodles are al dente and the wasabi has the right amount of spice to cut through the richness of the steak.

This place is ideal for a casual meet-up with friends, or it can be for a special occasion as well. The staff is really friendly and the service is timely and efficient. Space is definitely a premium here (but that's just SF for you), so you'll probably have to wait outside until your table is ready. Anytime you're in SF, you have to make sure you book a meal here!
author: Khoi T.

description:
Highlights: accept RVSP, REALLY good food.

Good food, good and fast service. We were in town for a wedding so we tried to make the most of it with our little time there. The House accepted reservation so it worked out really well for us. We did not write review until 4 months later so we forgot the dishes we ordered. We had a salad, a deep-fried salmon roll, a fish, and a steak. All were very yummy. I definitely would go back once I get to visit again.
author: Duy N.

description: Incredible. Is all I can say to describe The House. yum. Service incredibly professional and graceful and the food, omg the food is incredible. Flat iron steak, grilled halibut and the persimmon bread pudding. Light and heavenly. Highly recommend.
author: John K.

description: We made reservations for my daughter's graduation luncheon and "the House" was very accommodating to our large party of 23. The food was fantastic and to die for. The atmosphere was great with very very nice wait staff. Parking was not bad. I thought it would be a nightmare but we all found parking within 2 blocks. Taste and order everything. It is so worth it. Order the soft shell crab, poke, salads, mussels, unami burger, sea bass, rib eye, halibut, etc. We had it all and everything was mouth watering delicious.
author: Claire B.

description: Everything was perfectly balanced. We order porkdish, seabass, miso blackcod, and steak dish. Everything was well prepared and service was also shining star. Overall great experience.
author: Brian K.

description: I had the ribeye steak with cauliflower and mashed potatoes. It arrived fairly quick and warm. The mashed potatoes were anything but flavorful but still enjoyable with the cauliflower which had flavor. The ribeye was succulent with great taste and melted in your mouth. The wait staff were very courteous, quick and attentive; my glass was always kept full.
author: Mike A.

description:
Given the plethora of 4 to 5 star reviews, I didn't think it was necessary for me to write another. But damn, after my meal last night, The House has easily become one of my favorite restaurants. 

We called around 7:30 to see if we could make reservations for two, and they told us they could take us at 8. I was pleasantly surprised since it was a Friday night and this restaurant is always packed. We got in a bit late due to the lack of parking around the area but we were still seated within 20 minutes. When we sat down, waters were brought to us almost immediately and our server told us about the specials that they had that weren't on the menu. I settled on the sea bass ($31) while my boyfriend had the wasabi noodles with flat iron steak ($24). O M G the sea bass was the best cooked fish dish I've ever had! It came with mini string beans and noodles - I don't know what kind of noodles they were, but I just know that it was full of flavor. Everything was insanely delicious and the sea bass paired perfectly with the sauce and literally melted in my mouth with every bite. I've had the wasabi noodles in the past and they're also very flavorful while the steak is always cooked to perfection. I wish I could've ordered small dishes/appetizers to try since our main dishes were so good but there's always next time. The entrees are decently priced for the portions given. I noticed they have a huge selection of wines as well - also a plus. Everything was fantastic and I can't wait to go back! 

Tip: Reservations are a must since it's a smaller restaurant. There's also a parking lot in Chinatown not too far from the restaurant if you can't find street parking.
author: Cecille W.

description:
(4.5 stars) The House is freaken awesome, especially for a late lunch when it's not too crowded and the prices are super reasonable. (Under $15 for a filling and great salmon and wasabi noodles dish right in San Francisco, seriously?!) 

Everything we had on the menu was well worth ordering again. The best, hands down, was the sesame soy glazed king salmon. Though a bit pricier than the rest of the lunch options, the intense yet not overbearing teriyaki flavor that they are able to infuse with the salmon is mesmerizing. I usually find that salmon is almost always good, but rarely phenomenal because it's a relatively lackluster fish to start with. But for anyone who enjoys a great fish, this is a must. It's beautifully plated treasure for anyone who orders it.

The warm wasabi house noodles (which I got with chicken instead of salmon and that was a mistake!because the chicken came with the skin on it) was also a great option. It wasn't too spicy and the noodles and flavors were so unique. Next time, which there surely will be, I'm sticking to the salmon.
author: Jason S.

description:
I've come here twice, and both times have been perfect. For starters, we've tried the scallops and the sashimi plate - highly recommend. 

Entree on visit one: the truffled rice with grilled prawns - my mouth waters just thinking about it. The dish was extremely rich with the truffle flavor, topped with what seemed to be living truffles, and infused with a cheese that lightly glued everything together. The prawns were grilled to perfection - and they were huge! I had enough for two servings. 

The second time I came, I had the salmon in a miso type broth, and again - it couldn't have been better. The broth was light, bright, and flavorful, and the salmon was tender, flaky, and dare I say, "moist"? Sorry to those of you who hate that word, but there isn't an appropriate alternative. Juicy is too much - salmon is not "juicy."

Make a reservation if you want to come here, as this place gets pretty crowded on a nightly basis.
author: Jessica C.

description:
The dishes were fantastic. The place was packed by 6pm on a week night. The servers were extremely friendly and accommodating to our peanut allergy. 

The ahi tuna was my fave!
author: Joey J.

description: The warm noodles with chicken, sea bass, poke appetizer, octopus etc delicious and service was great!
author: Debbie L.

description: Follow Zagat grade, great aisan fusion choice, the best dish I highly recommend "Warm Noodle", the best noodle !
author: Faye L.

description:
Been here for lunch several times and never disappoints. The lunch menu has a few, slightly cheaper options than dinner (e.g. several under $20). Service is always attentive and friendly. 

Fave appetizers are salmon roll and tempura green beans. What I love about the salmon roll is that the salmon is cooked medium which keeps it nice and juicy. 

Go to entree is the wasabi noodles with the king salmon. The king salmon is absolute perfection - buttery and juicy - unlike so many other places that just overcook their salmon. The grill adds a smokey flavor. The seabass is another buttery fish option that doesn't disappoint.
author: Judy C.

description:
Consistently AMAZING 
I've been here a handful of times and always get something different (i want to conquer this menu) and the specials
The salmon egg rolls are amazing and the wasabi dipping sauce that comes with it is the perfect compliment.
The soft shell crab appetizer was battered perfectly and just so yummy with the cold noodle salad.
I've ordered the sea bass and garlic noodles and korean short ribs.. so tasty and so many flavors!
My friend ordered once the black cod special and i wanted to steal her whole plate.. wish this was a regular on the menu.
My boyfriend orders the pork chop every time we've been here and is never disappointed.

I LOVE THIS PLACE.. must try in SF
author: Nataliee K.

description:
I love Asian fusion and this place did. not. disappoint.

The House is a small and cozy restaurant - tip: if it's your first time, you might miss it! It's on a slant and it's next to a bunch of pubs so if you go at night be on the lookout for the entrance.

We were seated quite right away even though we didn't have reservation (it was a party of 2). I would say if it becomes more than 2-3 people though, make sure to have reservation. It's packed starting Thursday/Friday night.

We had the salmon roll, wasabi noodles, and ahi tuna. They were all perfect. One personally tip is that if you visit the House, you MUST get the crunchy salmon roll. It is a must. 

As small as the restaurant is, the server is friendly and the food is perfect. Absolute recommend in the big city of San Francisco.
author: Jenny K.

description: Food was just ok. Bad location and parking in the area is a joke. Possible the worst service by grumpy servers I have ever seen. . One star sums it up.
author: Randy W.

description: Called and spoke to Eva, asked if they had availability for 3- they said come in 5 minutes and they can seat us. We show up in 4, get seated, then Eva tells us if a reservation shows up we have to leave after being seated. Waiter brings pickles and water, then picks them up 2 minutes later. We are confused. 3 minutes after that a group of 4 shows up and hostess (Eva) asks us to give up the table. Absolutely ridiculous, poor service and shows complete lack of professionalism. Eva denies telling us to show up to be seated in 5. Eva is "sorry" that we were seated because waiter shouldn't have sat us and given us food / water. When questioned, Eva tells us "she has work to do". Classy joint.
author: Jeremy K.

description:
If you plan on eating here, make reservations a few days in advance. The restaurant is small and super high in demand. We had a party of 8 and they gave us 1.5 hrs to eat. I am not sure if the time is based on your party size or a 1.5 hr is the norm for all customers. The closest parking garage is about 2 blocks down on Columbus & Kearny St. I paid $18 for 2 hours. If u prefer to go the cheaper route (parking on the streets), give yourself 15-20min to find one. It is SF and the area stays busy. 

Now on to the food! The hype is REAL! LOVED the food! I highly recommend the Salmon Rolls for appetizers. I absolutely loved the texture of the Salmon with the crisp of frying the roll. They serve it with a wasabi sauce/salsa. I don't recommend dipping the roll in the sauce unless u absolutely love wasabi. Wasabi has a very particular taste and overdoing it can really ruin the taste of the roll. For dinner, I had the Wild Rice Mushroom Prawns and the Iron Steak with Wasabi Noodles. The Wild Rice Mushroom with Prawns was amazing. If you love comfort food, this would be the dish to get. It was a very unique dish and I've never had anything like it before. Really good though. The Steak w/ Wasabi Noodles I LOVED! The steak was cooked to perfection, so juicy and tasty. I loved the thick noodles mixed with wasabi sauce, sesame and cabbage. The House offers a lot of fresh ingredients mixed with the right amount of spices which compliments every dish. 

On your next trip to SF, bookmark "The House". They will not disappoint.
author: Laila A.

description:
I feel like I'm going to get crucified by other Yelpers for not giving this place a 5-star rating. I'm clearly part of the very small minority that doesn't see what the hype is with this place. I ate here for dinner with friends and none of us were blown away by the food. Now, to be fair, when I read Yelp reviews and see all five stars, I expect the food to knock my socks, pants and shirt off. Unrealistic? Perhaps. But when a restaurant has 4K+ reviews? I'd say it's downright as realistic as a heart attack.

I don't know if one of my 10,000 tastebuds were just off the night I dined here, but I found almost everything I ate to be too salty. Here was our line-up:

- Blue Lake Bean Tempura: Good, but how can you screw this up? It's just a green bean tossed in tempura batter and fried.

- Ahi Tuna Tatare: Great. I wished I wasn't with three others so I wouldn't have had to share.

- Steamed Mussels: So-so, but only after I shook the broth off of it. The broth was very salty.

- Grilled Seabass (with garlic noodles): So here's the part where I think people would likely throw stones or tomatoes at me if I were reading this review aloud given the vast majority of diners come here for this dish alone. Now, let me first preface by saying I fully understand and know seabass is a naturally oily fish, but it's still my favorite type of fish nonetheless. BUT, for some reason, I felt the seabass here was even oilier. It tasted as if I was eating oil with a side of fish. And on top of that, the garlic ginger soy sauce was extremely salty. The garlic noodles ended up getting drenched in the garlic ginger soy sauce since it was all plated together so even that was too salty. It's unfortunate because I don't actually know what their garlic noodles should have tasted like. I wish they would have served it on the side vs. it swimming in the sauce. Two other friends ordered this as well and had the same overall opinion. It was quite disappointing because we all had high hopes for this dish. Another friend ordered the misoyaki fish entree off the specials menu and I wish I ordered that instead. Too bad it was just part of their specials because I would be willing to return for that particular dish. 

Needless to say, I'm glad I tried this restaurant, but I won't be returning. On the plus side, service was great!
author: Lainey C.

description:
RESERVATIONS, FTW!

I've been wanting to dine here for some time now. A few years, at least. Never got the chance until the House was able to squeeze in a dinner reservation for two, which we ALMOST lost thanks to our Lyft driver, but that's another story...

My travel buddy and I shared a bit of each item, so we were able to devour pretty much everything we wanted to try. We ordered the deep fried salmon roll, shrimp and chive dumplings, black cod, and angus ribeye. 

And DAMN! They were delicious. The deep fried salmon roll was quite unique and beautifully presented. Black cod had a nice miso sauce and vertically cut california rolls, and the angus ribeye was perfectly cooked medium rare and the garlic bits were so tasty.

Thank you for a wonderful dinner, the House! I loved every moment of it and can't wait to go back!
author: Bin H.

description: This was a long overdue review for the house. I've been here plenty of times and I just realized I haven't wrote them a review yet! I recommend booking a reservation before you come because it's a tiny restaurant. Also parking can be a pain in this area. My house is in the same area so I would usually just walk here. When we arrived we checked in with the server letting him know all our party member are here and our reservation was at 8:30. Our table wasn't ready yet so we just waited outside. There's not much space in here so usually people just wait outside. I knew exactly what I wanted so we ordered right away after we sat down. Customer service is great here, the staffs are very attentive. We got the ahi tuna tartare, grilled octopus, deep fried salmon roll, kurobuta pork chop, lastly strawberry rhubarb as our dessert. My mom got the famous grilled sea bass, brother got the wasabi noodle with Angus ribeye steak. The bill came out to be $190 not including tips. I would recommend this restaurant to all my friends! :)
author: Tina C.

description:
The food was okay but for such a nicely rated place and overall higher prices, I would expect the service to be above satisfactory. It would have been more helpful if specials were posted instead of recited by the servers. The first server we interacted with was all smiles but spoke so softly that we asked her to repeat twice, gave up and asked a different server. The second server was rude with how she questioned us about our orders and was a bit intense and cold. She was very quick not in an efficient way, but in a way that made us feel rushed and uncomfortable. The host just seemed unfriendly but we managed to get a smile out of her when we paid and left.

The sea bass and scallops were tasty! We ordered the Kobe beef but saw that the flat iron was more popular amongst that night's guests and looked to be a much heartier portion. The fried salmon and unagi were tasty with heavy Japanese influences.The halibut was also very good. I would have enjoyed a different side as both fish dishes came with a heavy portion of mashed potatoes that weren't quite seasoned or flavored. We finished with the creme brûlée which was nice. 

I don't know if I would return because I feel like fine dining needs be good food paired with great service.
author: Jay G.

description: The garlic noodles omg the best I've ever had . Steak was so good too . I'm so picky you guys !
author: Amy L.

description: I love heading over to The House especially for their Udon Noodle Soup and their great Asian fusion atmosphere. I have been here many times and service has been reasonably good with minor flaws. They have a variety of things to try if you're feeling adventurous and when I am looking for that extra bit to satisfy my sweet tooth, I always get their Bittersweet Chocolate Truffle Cake or even the panacotta. Absolutely delicious! Staff is amazing and friendly and I believe that anyone will have a good time here. If you're ever in the area, then I recommend checking out The House.
author: David L.

description: Came for the ribeye, but they were sold out :( However, their sea bass, oysters and crab appetizers were very good. I'm not a fan of pork, but their PORK CHOP w/ pomegranate glaze was AMAZING!!!! Service was also great! They kept our glasses filled with water, and was quick to clear and replenish new plates and utensils.
author: Kimberly D.

description:
I don't usually write a review from just experiencing lunch, but this restaurant blew me away.  It is my new favorite spot, can't wait to go back for dinner, and try more of the menu.  It was so good, innovative, great, fresh ingredients taken to a new level.

We started with the octopus, I am now a major fan of octopus, tender meat, the sauce was siracha based I think, so good.  Similar to abalone.  I decided to have the fresh hamachi poke as my main, it was the best I have ever had.  Hamachi, tuna, avacado, popped rice for texture and an amazing dressing.  My husband had the warm, wasabi noodle bowl with sliced pork.  That was so good as well.  The flavors, textures and fusion twist makes for an exciting foodie experience.  Will be going back soon to try everything.  The dishes I saw coming out of the kitchen were all so delicious looking.  Service was good too.  It is a small restaurant, so when I go back I will make reservations.
author: Carole W.

description: It's tiny so you see the people sitting next to you order something which makes it hard to decide between your choices, Yelp pictures, and what you're seeing but all good. Have had the sea bass and tuna app before which are great. Soft shell crab, tuna main and halibut special today. Finished w the crime brûlée w passion fruit. Need to come back to try all the other beautiful creations!
author: Jesley J.

description:
Bye-bye five-star rating.

Finally taking one star off because of cramp, dark accommodations. Our party of five at table meant for four. End seat inches from next table. Can hear everything they are saying. Hope they are neat eaters. Don't want to find food bits in my hair or on my leather coat. Btw, the adjoining table is a table of three stuffed into table for two. I wish they had stuck to the larger Sunset location and closed this closet instead.

Quality and taste of food not as we remembered either. Sea bass and black cod not taste and texture we've enjoyed in the past. Pork chop much smaller, no longer thick cut and tasted like Chinese style Cha Siu, BBQ pork. Sauces way overdone..too sweet, too salty, etc. Not the umami flavors we used to love about this place.

Another star off for faking us out about coffee. Sold us on coffee being from Caffe Trieste and was French press. Did not mention not fresh French Press, but split leftover coffee from previous customer so my sister and I each got half a cup of lukewarm coffee that tasted watered down. So sad to see decline of this place. Fighting traffic and difficult parking to eat here no longer worth it. We typically spend about $300 for dinner here. We will be looking for new go-to restaurant.
author: Carrie W.

description:
Took our friends visiting in town to the house, only been here once before a couple years ago before we moved to San Francisco. Ordered the tuna tartare to share, small but wasn't bad. Also some other appetizers to share as a table. 

Ordered the seabass main course, that my bf and I ate before realizing it was severely undercooked--let the waitress know. We also told her the udon noodles that accompanied it was extremely salty--I love salty foods btw. She asked if we can put the seabass on the plate and bring it back to the chef to cook it. I didn't eat it when they brought it back but to get to the point, my boyfriend and I both had food poisoning that night. 

He messaged them on fb msger to let them know a couple days ago, no reply though.
author: Alisa L.

description:
My girlfriend and I had a reservation for 7:30 pm and were seated after 30 minutes of waiting.  We had an appetizer (fried salmon roll) sent to our table before we ordered our meals.  I told the manager that the appetizer was sent to the wrong table but she said it was for us because we had to wait.  Wasn't need at all but I appreciated the hospitality and service and it left a great impression on us!

Easily my favorite dish was the grilled octopus.  It was very rich in flavor and had a nice kick.  Go with the server's recommendations you won't be disappointed!  The garlic noodles are bomb as well definitely recommend this restaurant!
author: Jonathan N.

description: Tight space, but great fresh ingredients and inventive menu.
author: Laura D.

description:
I was very excited to try this restaurant, but sadly it didn't live up to the hype.

I love Japanese food -- Izakayas in particular, but none of the food was amazing, memorable or worth the price.  So disappointing.
author: Caroline H.

description: Atmosphere is a two. The taste and ingenuity was a four. Our dishes were very well prepared; the Cod was outstanding and the Kobe ribs were melt in your mouth buttery. Hang on to surprise flavors like a wasabi infused sauces. The downside is that the waiters want to turn tables and rush their customers.
author: Sheila S.

description:
Yesterday was my second time coming here and it confirmed the first time was not a fluke. I went with my girlfriend on a Friday night around opening for dinner and the wait was already 45 minutes. Parking here is always a burden but luckily we were able to find a spot nearby. They send you a text message when your seat is ready so that is extremely convenient when you don't want to wait in SF's cold weather. 

The servers are extremely attentive and know their menu very well. I was bummed that the soft shell crab was not in season because that is the best thing there! We ended up ordering the string bean tempura and those are to die for. The tempura batter is not heavy and there is still a crisp to each bite. Their tempura sauce is not the typical sauce you find at Japanese restaurants. It is more tangy and spicy, which gives the tempura string beans a good kick.

For dinner, my girlfriend and I love the wasabi noodles so much that we both ordered the same thing: Wasabi noodles with the flat iron steak. The steak was cooked perfectly to order and works well with the bed of zuchinni it sits on and red cabbage slaw on top. The ultimate bite is combining all four components of the dish. I would 100% order this again and again.

All in all, my experience at The House has been the best every time. Their food and service is top notch. The only downside is that it is extremely hard to find parking in this neighborhood of SF.
author: Alden C.

description: Really enjoyed the food here. Unique dishes and tasty too. Small size of the restaurant makes it cozy and inviting. Interior is simple but I think the owners are going for a more contemporary style dining so the interior design matches that consept.
author: Jeff M.

description: Amazing Asian cuisine.  The tar tar was a great starter along with my stout beer.  Loved the Japanese Sea Bass and Pan Seared Noodles.  Great place to eat...  Make sure to get reservations.
author: Mike S.

description: I may be the only person in San Francisco that isn't floored. Well, other than my husband. It just didn't live up to the hype for us. We have had much better food for much less. Not a single dish stands out. Everything was just A-ok.
author: Michelle I.

description:
I work where I come into contact with folks from all over the United States and the World. It offers me a great opportunity to network and find new eats. San Franciscans recommended The House and State Bird Provisions. The latter is hoity toity and like 60-90 days for reservations. So I called The House from Hawaii and had no trouble getting in on Sunday, our arrival day.

When we arrived we spent some time in Japantown and worked up an appetite.

When we got to Chinatown and little Italy, we found exceptionally reasonable parking at the Police Station on Velajo. The restaurant was a short five-minute walk from there.

When we got there we were greeted and seated rather promptly. After hearing the appetizers and specials, we decided to try it all along with their famous baked unagi.

Boom! This restaurant rocketed to our Top 3 in the Nation. Up there with Spago Beverly Hills, , California and Mangowood in Woodstock, Vermont.

The lobster tempura was large. The base was light and tasty and the sauce rad incredible. The steamed clams were plentiful and served with bread to mop up the juice. The hamachi sashimi was oily and sweet and melted in our mouths. The seared scallops were lightly crusted on the outside and soft and warm on the inside.

I was thinking if only I had ten thumbs they'd all be up at this point. Glad to say as the night went on they didn't eff up a thing. Except for the first appetizer that got set on our table with no introduction. The water was always filled and never got low.

We had the mushroom risotto with prawns. The sauce was piquant and the shrimps plump sweet and firm. Daughters had the angus steak and miso salmon. I had what I'll call, no blasphemy intended,  The Lamb of God. Tasted like it came off a Mongolian spit. It is was mind blowing.

If we lived here it's where we would go all the time.
author: Terry H.

description: 4 stars for food which was tasty and enjoyable and 2 stars for service which was unmemorable and inattentive. Luckily I was at a business dinner and so the focus was on the conversation and not the food. I got the steak salad ($25) and it was tasty, but I should have gotten the sea bass ($35), according to my friend who goes here often, though it looked line a small dish. Ambience was more upscale than your neighborhood Chinese but not super fancy, so it was just right. Service was rushed, very hard to understand the specials because of the loud noise, our water was not refilled. I wish I could give this place more stars but compared to Hakkasan, I would not go back because the overall food and service quality doesn't justify a $38-48 person price tag. Neighborhood is North Beach, near the old Caffe Trieste, so it's a great location if you're out for the evening.
author: Vik C.

description:
I've been here an additional two times since my first time visiting. It's still amazing and perhaps my favorite restaurant in San Francisco so far! The grilled sea bass with garlic noodles is the best and the wasabi noodles with flatiron steak is still amazing!

It was surprisingly easy to get a reservation at The House given how many fantastic reviews that they have. I will definitely continue visiting this place again in the future. I highly recommend it!
author: Andy T.

description:
Cozy restaurant that was packed when we at there on Sunday evening, so be sure to make a reservation .

Excellent food and service , the salmon skin roll and unagi are amazing. For mains, we had the pork chop and rare ahi tuna with aioli sauce. Delicious and perfect for date night. Highly recommend !!
author: Jonathan C.

description:
High expectations for dinner. 7:00 reservations for 5. I was famished after playing tourist all morning and nothing to eat since lunch. 

We heard the appetizer specials of the day and Terry H said we'll try them all. Yay! But what about my Unagi that everyone is raving about? As you wish Buttercup. Inconceivable! 

So we started off with the lobster tail tempura, hamachi sashimi, seared scallops,steamed clams and of course my baked unagi. We finished it off like it was a feeding frenzy episode of shark week on the Discovery Channel. 

The two of us had the mushroom risotto with grilled prawns. It was so good that I continued to eat even after my stomach said stop! The prawns were big and sweet, and the risotto was creamy and not overly rich with bites of chewy mushrooms. One daughter had the miso soy King salmon, the other had the angus ribeye with cauliflower mash. Terry H. Had the Korean style lamb with Kim Chee.

Service was attentive. Water was filled at half way and plates were taken away almost immediately. 

We will definitely be back here again the next time we're back in San Fran.
author: Darcie I.

description: Great food, very fast service, small location and they pack in the guests.  Sitting by the door can get chilly when the fog rolls in.  Has a family owned feel.  I highly recommend the garlic green beans.
author: Erik J.

description: One of the best meals I've had in a long time. The restaurant is small in size but big in flavor. From the appetizers to the desserts my friends and myself had no complaints. The service was quick and attentive.
author: Lei G.

description:
Excellent restaurant! Great service and really really delicious food!
We had oysters and the sauce was incredible.
Seared Scallops were so good and I don't even like scallops. 
Lamb chops for entree were perfectly cooked and yummy. 
Apple pie and vanilla ice cream for dessert.... I can't say enough about how delicious this place is.
author: Erin H.

description:
Heard about this gem from a cousin of mine and once I yelped it I absolutely had to come check it out. Fast forward to date night with my beautiful lady. 

Nestled in a little corner off North Beach, the HOUSE is a very cozy and intimate dining experience. Reservations are definitely recommended, and I would say you should show up a little earlier to give yourself ample time to find parking around the neighborhood.

We were seated promptly and our server quickly came to us with menus and offered to tell us the SPECIALS menu.  OF course we wanted to hear it! she did speak really fast and all i heard was the New York Steak special so we of course had to get that and us being meat eaters we also got the Masami Rib Eye and we shared a Unagi with Avocado sushi rice. 

Let's just say we are for sure coming back here soon! The food was SOOO good. 
It was spectacular. Let's start with our app, the Unagi.  It was warm sweet Unagi, layered with avocado and sushi rice... I would describe it as deconstructed sushi. 
Next came our steak dishes... my rib eye was perfectly cooked to a medium rare, extremely flavorful and the mashed potatoes it came with, OMG the mashed potatoes. 
The New York special, super tender and cooked to a perfect medium rare as well, all the flavors just had us in a daze.

The service was very attentive but not suffocating, and although we wish we had room for dessert, we will forsure make room our next go around.
author: Kevin D.

description: This is legit my favorite restaurant in SF. The truffle shrimp fried rice and the steak with noodles are to die for. Words can not explain how delectable these two dishes. So much flavor packed, it's irresistible! You must do yourself a favor and come here asap!
author: Bryan N.

description:
Loved this place!

Octopus- omg deliciousness!  I am always on the hunt for great octopus and very few meet live up to the hype- this does.  

Sea bass- delicious!

Mango pudding dessert- very good
author: Rene B.

description:
So delicious! I got the sea bass and garlic noodles cause who doesn't love garlic noodles?

The sea bass was incredible and cooked perfectly. Idk what cooked perfectly means or what it should be described as. All I know is that is how sea bass is meant to be eaten by humans. 

The noodles were ok. Just normal noodles, very yummy, reminded me of Chubby Noodle garlic noodles though which are far cheaper. Maybe less flavorful, actually, so you have to dip in the soy + other sauce they give you. 

Also tried some other food on the table. Wasabi noodles were spicy of course and quite delicious. Everyone was a fan.
author: Ke D.

description:
Wonderful!

Great seat in the window 

Nothing pretentious at all 

Tasty and well presented calamari 

Delicious halibut special with mash and a creamy sauce that was good enough for Jehovah

A keeper
author: Dave H.
