When we walked into this tiny, Asian fusion restaurant for our team lunch, I was a little skeptical, but boy was I wrong. It's not an easy task to get this style of cuisine just right, but The House seems to be a crowd pleaser. 

The sea bass was in-cred-i-ble... seriously. Light, moist, flavorful and just all around perfection. It's served with delicious, fresh green beans and sticky rice with a soy sauce reduction of epic proportions. And you know who recommended it? Fellow yelpers, that's who! Listen to your yelpers, people! I also tried the shrimp and chive dumplings and, well, even though we were sharing them I ended up hoarding three of them for myself. 

The prices are a little high, but you certainly get what you pay for. Besides, there's really something for everyone on the menu. Our group of nine ordered everything from udon noodle soups, tuna BLTs to fried chicken sandwiches. Yep, everything. I was lucky enough to sneak a bite (or two) of the wasabi udon noodles with pork from my colleague. Oh yea, it was tasty. 

If you're looking for something a little different for lunch, you love seafood and Asian tastes, The House is definitely a spot to try.
author: Cara L.

description:
I love food here. I liked small dishes a lot. I had Salmon roll which was very crispy and harmony with sweet sauce was fabulous. Wasabi noodle was good. but, I had Salmon roll and salad was similar from rolls. 

Pork with broth was my favorite. I had to share dishes with my girls. They both liked it a lot and I ordered bowl of rice and they put in broth and It was so yummy. Fast service and many different food options. It is not a big place. No strollers could pass by. It wasn't perfect place to bring kids to eat out. Definitely, I would love to go again.
author: Heeyoung K.

description:
The food was fanTASTEtic.!
bookmark this place since it has 4.5stars in the city & want to give it a try.
We ordered grilled sea bass that came with noodles & green beans.wasabi noodle with strips of steak,ribeye steak with mash potato.
For the appetizer we had fried salmon roll and grilled scallops.I didnt really enjoy the scallops since I'm not a fan of raw foods.but my sister and my friend liked it.the salmon roll was a bit of raw on the inside but just cook on the outside which i really really taste good.though i didnt try the sauce that came with it since they said it was a bit of spicy and tasted like wasabi.
author: Enah N.

description:
My sister loves this restaurant and has raved about it so I finally put in the effort to drive here. A tight little space and parking was a nightmare. But I was ready for that, especially if the food is as good as I've been promised. 

Ordered the oysters starter, popular sea bass, and the flat iron steak. 

Oysters were good, sauce not as good as my sauce but decent. I finished it in about five minutes 

Sea bass undercooked, noodles overly salty and oily, green beans were beans. The soy and ginger sauce I didn't taste any ginger, was just a thicken soy sauce sauce, and with the salty noodles I didn't use the sauce at all. I was really disappointed with this dish considering the hype around it. 

Bf got the flat iron steak, I just tasted the sauce and I don't understand why it's even orange considering it tasted very bland and mostly of butter. He finished it but said it wasn't good. I liked the fried taro it came with.

Overall not worth the drive or money. I had to go buy some pork buns to make up for my meal.

Also service sucked. Waiter never came to check on us, probably because they knew they were disappointing us.
author: Pang X.

description:
3.5 STARS. 
Babe took me here for our anniversary dinner back in November so this review is long overdue. Let's just say the food here was good but I wasn't overly impressed. Couldn't bring myself to the full 4 stars since I'm no a "fan" nor would I crave to come back to this place. 

I got the Kurobuta Pork Chop w/ Pomegranate Currant Sauce. The pork chop was delicious, but I really did not enjoy the pomegranate sauce that topped it off. Warm pomegranate just did not agree with my taste buds. 

Babe got the Sea Bass with Garlic Noodles. Sounds sad but I have the say the garlic noodle portion of the dish was my favorite. Since my dad is a chef, I really have to say that I'm super picky about how my fish is prepared. Once it's overcooked and its no longer soft (melt in your mouth status) I have no interest. Yea, I'm spoiled in the fish department.  This is why I never order fish when I'm eating out. 

Overall, not a bad place, but I would rather eat at a regular Asian restaurant. Sorry The House, but you just didn't spark my tastebuds as I had anticipated.
author: Harriet W.

description:
I've been to The House a few times now, and the food here is always amazing. The grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy is my right hand, my go to. The sea bass here is so moist and buttery, it just melts in your mouth! It comes with green beans and garlic noodles. One of my other favorites here is the kurobuta pork chop with pomegranate currant sauce, which comes with mashed potatoes and asparagus. That sauce is delicious, and it really works well with the pork chop. 

I've also tried the wasabi house noodle with flat iron steak, the deep fried salmon roll with chinese hot mustard, and the spicy miso clams. The house noodle with steak is not bad, but it definitely has no comparison to the sea bass and pork chop. The salmon roll is pretty good, and that sauce gives it a nice kick. The broth of the spicy miso clams is delicious. It also comes with bread for you to dip it in, so you can soak up the broth. The downside of this dish is that they are very stingy with the clams. There was very little clams as it is, and most of them were just empty shells.

The service here is a hit or a miss. I remember the first few times I came here, it was great, however, last night was a different experience. There was a Caucasian lady who was kind of rude throughout the whole night. She also took my plate without asking when there was still noodles left, and my friend was going to finish it for me. Later on, she came back and asked us if we were done, with an attitude, then dropped the check at our table without having a smile or saying thank you. There was also an African American waiter who also seemed like he was unhappy. My co worker asked him if they had any Japanese beers there. He walked away without saying anything (not even a yes or a no), then comes back and puts the beer on our table, then walked away without saying anything again. No "here you go", no name of the beer, couldn't even get a smile out of him. Umm okay....... We still end up giving a little more than 15% in tips though, because the other servers were great. 

Anyways, I've been wanting to write a review about this place for awhile now, and originally, I was going to give it 5 stars! However, I do have to knock 1 star down for last nights service. I hate doing it because The House is one of my favorite restaurants.
author: Esther C.

description: Service was great and food was excellent, but parking was difficult to find. If you can, you should definitely make reservations as this restaurant gets packed really fast. I came here for my bf's birthday and we ordered two appetizers - hamachi with avocado salsa verde, and ahi tuna tartare. We also ordered the sea bass (which was AMAZING with the ginger soy) along with green beans and noodles, and the Kobe short ribs with a side of mashed potatoes. We were so stuffed that we couldn't order dessert. Maybe we'll try it next time!
author: Jamie T.

description:
This place is delicious and i Will start tecommending it more. Their sea bass is the most delicious fish ive ever had, it melts in your mouth. I dont like to repeat restaurants in the city but the House is one of my exceptions. 

Service is great. Ambiance is casual. They serve very fast. 

I would only recommend printing the daily specials because when the waitresses describes so many dishes at the speed of light it gets confussing, or just announce one dish.
author: Cristinita C.

description:
It is not hard to understand why The House received so much love. The food here is a happy Asian American love child. Not pretentious. Not being hard to get. Just really down to earth good food that made excellent use of both Asian and American elements.

You got to give credit to 'fusion' food that is done right. Granted I don't love every single dishes I have tried, most were more than delicious. The Kurobuta Pork Chop was likeable. It was a bit bold and quite showy but definitely made a lasting impression. Deep-Fried Chicken Liver was alright but slightly underwhelming. Seared Scallop with Creamy Crab Meat Pasta, a special of the day, was not as memorable as the dishes on the regular menu. Mango Tapioca was a classic Asian dessert and I am glad they did it well. Key Lime Pie was terrible. I hated that biting bitter sourness. I don't know what happened there. 

Like many restaurants in the area, parking could be hard to come by. Seating is very limited too because the restaurant is quite small. Do plan ahead and make reservations.
author: Mona W.

description:
This has to be one of my favorite meals in San Francisco. It was recommended to me by a co-worker and now I'm preaching it to the world. Even before you finish reading my review, make your reservation NOW!

FOOD - 5 Stars:

- House Pickles: This was simple, but yet so flavorful. It was a nice way to get your taste buds jumping before your meal.

- Deep Fried Salmon Roll: I wasn't sure what to expect with this, but it was so good. It's almost like a salmon egg roll if you want to think of it that way, but the salmon is not dry or anything. It's delicious and moist! This probably surprised me the most.

- Maine Crab Cakes: I'm the biggest crab cake lover in the world. The crab cake had a crispy crusting all around was full of flavor. It was also very moist and not dry at all. It was truly a great way to start the meal. 

- Sea Bass with Noodles and Green Beans: This was insanely delicious. The sea bass was a huge portion, cooked to perfection, and as flakey as can be. It was the best I've ever had! The noodles and green beans were an awesome compliment to the sea bass. The ginger garlic soy sauce was really good with this too. This meal was probably the highlight of my San Francisco trip! I think everyone should order this dish... it's the BEST!

SERVICE - 5 Stars: This place is crazy busy even at 9PM when we were able to get a reservation. The staff did a great job of taking care of us the entire night. There were so friendly and patient especially since we didn't know what to order. It was an amazing night and they did a great job.

ATMOSPHERE - 5 Stars: This is the perfect place to have a date or even a small group together. It's a small spot that is tight with space because everyone wants to be in here. The vibe is awesome with everyone just eating, drinking, and constant socializing.

RECOMMENDATION: I recommend this place to everyone that I talk to because the food was amazing. I seriously would go to San Francisco just to eat here again. This place is so good and I cannot wait to come back and eat here again!
author: Hugh H.

description:
The House is one of my favorite restaurants in the city. It's a small restaurant situated on a small street at North Beach with a packed house most of the time.

This is Asian Fusion dining at its finest. I love coming here both lunch and dinner, with lunch having some of the popular dinner dishes at cheaper prices. Some of my favorite dishes are the wasabi noodles, sea bass, and Kurobuta pork chop with pomegranate currant sauce. I personally do not like eating anything with wasabi unless it's with soy sauce and sashimi, but you do not taste the wasabi in the noodles. The noodles are saucy, but not overly saucy. The sea bass is phenomenal! It's super soft, and it's seasoned very well. The pork chop is also delicious and sweet when paired with the pomegranate sauce.

For appetizers, I really like the steamed mussels with garlic broth. They also had a special of oysters that had their own type of soy sauce that you put on your oysters, and it tasted amazing. I would opt out on the fried calamari; the breading falls off of the calamari, which defeats the purpose of a "fried" calamari. I also tried the deef fried salmon rolls based on the reviews, and they were just ok. Nothing really wowed me about them. 

I also tried the mango tapioca for dessert based on the reviews. If you like mango pudding with small tapioca, this is good for you. I eat this many times at Chinese restaurants, so this was whatever to me.

I would definitely recommend this place for any occasion, special or casual! Make sure to make reservations for dinner because it gets packed. I usually just walk in for lunch, and there are usually open tables. Parking isn't too bad during lunch, but is a hassle during dinner.
author: Vivian L.

description:
I was visiting San Fran due to a work conference and I ended up yelping places to eat.  Based on the reviews I went here.  All I am going to say is wow.  I now have a place I will always visit when I am in San Francisco.  Coincidentally I sat next to a couple that was from Florida that said they always come here when they visit their children. 

I can see why.  This restaurant has great food, great atmosphere, and a friendly and knowledgeable staff (that eat there too so they explain things perfectly pertaining to the menu).  

Our group had the marinated rib eye, skirt steak, seared scallops, tempura salmon, apple crumble desert, seared ahi. 

It was all cooked perfectly with a lot of great flavors.  My ribeye was very tender, and if I had the chance, I would have took 10 of them home with me, and just sat in front of a TV eating them ... they were that good.  Also the scallops, wow ... I am terrible at cooking those things but they got it just right with a light sauce that didn't mar the tender peaks of its flavor.  

FIVE STARS!!!  ... this place is joining my restaurant city book for places that I will definitely always go to when in the area.
author: David L.

description:
I don't get why this place was rated so high and how it was so packed I could only get a 9PM reservation day of. 

I tried the sea bass, pork chop, and salmon roll. They were all good, but not super amazing.

The sea bass was definitely on point. It was cooked well and had a great flavor, I preferred this over the pork chop, which was also good, but why is the menu so small if you can't NAIL the dish? The salmon roll I think is what really kind of just pissed me off about the whole thing. Yelp failed me on this recommendation horribly. I did not think this was a good dish at all. It was just a piece of well cooked salmon in a deep fried roll. I used all of the horseradish sauce to make it actually tasty. 

Bottom line for me: There are a ton of other restaurants in the area you could drop $25-40/person that would be WAY better.
author: Alex K.

description:
I was SO excited to try The House. Out of all the restaurants in SF, I chose to go here for my graduation dinner last year. I made reservations a month in advance. I called the week of to make sure my reservations were still there. I kept gushing to everyone about how I was finally going to try this amazing little restaurant in North Beach. Unfortunately, my evening didn't really go as planned. The poor service really spoiled everything for me and overshadowed the food. No, I didn't have a super rude server, or find a foreign object in my food. It was more about the neglect and failure to meet the standards of their glowing reviews and delicious food.

In the beginning, our server was speaking so fast and it was so loud in the restaurant that we could barely hear the specials for that day. Once we ordered, the food initially came out pretty fast. First the soft shell crab appetizer after about 10 minutes and then the main entrees 15 minutes after that. All 3 entrees...except we ordered 4. We waited another 10 minutes hoping it would arrive, but after no luck I flagged down another server and asked about the missing dish. After a quick kitchen check I could see from my seat that it hadn't been ordered, but he told the chef. He didn't return to our table though to update us and didn't apologize for it either. Another 10 minutes rolled by and the dish finally arrived. Again no apology, no smile. We didn't get checked on throughout the rest of the meal. I had to catch a server's attention to ask for more water when our glasses ran empty and then again for the check at the end.

The food was beautifully presented and well-prepared; moist and flaky fish, tender steak, yummy noodles...but flavor wise, nothing stood out to me and everything was so salty. Maybe I was still annoyed about the missing food from earlier, but I was very unimpressed with everything. And you'd think they would have paid a little more attention to us considering we were all dressed up and I had a giant bouquet of flowers smothering me. I held off on this review for such a long time because I felt like my experience was a fluke. I'm willing to give them one more shot...but until then...The House left me very disappointed on what was suppose to be a joyous and celebratory occasion.
author: Deanna Y.

description:
The House has incredible food. I've tried their chicken and fish, and both are absolutely exceptional. The prices are also beyond reasonable - I think that they could charge quite a bit more, but don't, so you're getting amazing value for the price you pay.

Every appetizer is absolutely delicious as well. Salmon rolls are a must here! 

TIP: Make sure to book reservations early as the venue is VERY small. I think they can only seat 30-40 people, so make one at least 24 hours in advance.

It's a great spot that I will return to every few months for a meal.
author: Albert K.

description:
Outstanding meal, service and experience. We were 20 min late for our reservation (called to let them know we'd be late) and they graciously held our table, despite a line going out the door. Big thumbs up to them for being so accommodating. We did our best to compensate them by having drinks, apps, entrees, desserts and tea (such a hardship for us!). Delicious from top to bottom, especially the grilled octopus appetizer--I could have licked the plate it was so good!

The menu is interesting--Asian fusion, but with some French accents as well. I had the wasabi noodles with beef--perfectly cooked, not spicy (as I requested--you could definitely request heat); hubby had the ribeye and said the spices were a little heavy handed, but very tasty. Dad had the pork chops, and I nearly swapped plates with him, they were so good. I normally never order pork chops as they're ALWAYS dry for me, even when medium rare, but these were just moist and awesome.

We then finished with yummy apple crumble/pie, bittersweet chocolate cake, and my favorite, coconut passionfruit creme brulee--to die for!

Considering all we ate/drank, $240 wasn't too bad, but it's definitely not a cheap night out. Would absolutely return when I'm in the area. Great place to wander around before/after dinner as well, and a perfect location if going to see Beach Blanket Babylon just a few blocks away.
author: Penny S.

description:
YUMMY.

My cousin was in town from the east coast, so all the relatives from the bay wanted to show her around. Our cousin who says he likes to come here often, brought us here for lunch! I didn't really expect much seeming how he described it as "asian fusion" and often times that doesn't sound that great. Most places have just incredibly sweet sauces over their foods. 
buttttt,The House definitely is not like any other asian fusion place i've been to! 
We ordered the wasabi noodles with salmon, and one of us got the sea bass, and an order of the scallops. ALL of the seafood was cooked to PERFECTION. it was delicious! I would say that the noodles were a LITTLE bit too salty, but the flavors were really good. 
The sea bass texture was just so good, and I probably would go for that over the wasabi noodles and salmon next time! 

We came on a wednesday, and around 2pm so it wasn't that crowded but it is a smaller sized restaurant. Pricewise, I would say that it's pretty much what you'd expect it to be in SF. Things could be anywhere from 10-25 of course seafood would be a little more, but the quality does the pricing a bit of justice!
author: Angeline Y.

description: Had dinner here for friends birthday. Made reservations and was seated on time. Very cozy seating arrangements. Food was pure bliss. We got to have Kobe Steaks and each bite was truly heavenly
author: H K.

description:
Never have I been so excited about trying out a restaurant. Coming here had me looking for an excuse to come here a second time. Not only was I extremely full off my three course meal, my mouth was still salivating for more as I was leaving. If this is your first time, I promise that you will be mind blown. 

Where do I even begin? I have to admit that the place is small, but you can already tell by the outside that it's going to be a beautiful experience. My family and I began with 2 appetizers: steamed muscles and scallops. Both appetizers were bursting with flavors that still have me wondering how so many flavors can go so well with each other. I love dissecting ingredients in a dish, and this was one of the few times I couldn't. For my main course, I had the Kurobuta Pork Chop, and it was cooked to perfection. It was a little bit more towards medium well (even though I asked for medium), but nonetheless, the pork was extremely juicy. Finally, for dessert, we had the panna cotta with oranges (special of the day), and it just melts in your mouth like butter. It was the perfect light dessert to follow up with after the heavy main course.

Final thoughts? Service was great, people are nice, reservations are a must, and the food is superb. It is definitely my new favorite place to dine at!
author: Vivian H.

description:
It's been a while since Yelpers have led me this astray, but, for a place that's among the 25 top highest rated restaurants on Yelp, The House turned out to be surprisingly lackluster. Bringing my mom here for a nice dinner before she left the country, our meal consisted primarily of appetizers, where we ordered the:

* Ahi Tuna Tartare - Tuna tartare on nori chips, and highly reminiscent of a similar dish that you could find at the Liholiho Yacht Club popup, but not nearly in the same league. Enjoyable, but not particularly memorable.

* Deep Fried Salmon Roll - Essentially salmon egg rolls, which is hard to completely butcher. That said, while these weren't bad, they were on the salty side of the spectrum, especially when one being too liberal with the accompanying dipping sauce.

* Seared Scallops in Ponzu Sauce - Hands down the best part of the meal, and drastically better than the rest of the dishes, with the scallops cooked just right, and sauced to perfection.

*  Wasabi House Noodles w/ Flat Iron Steak - One of the other stars of the restaurant (the other being the salmon rolls), this turned out to be a bit lacking as well. While decent, we found it lacking in wasabi flavoring, and also found it oddly reminiscent of Taiwanese black bean noodles. So much so, in fact, that every bite ended with the expectation and consequent dissatisfaction that they were not actually black bean noodles, falling just a bit short of that flavoring.

Now, if The House were at a lower price point, and in a place that had easier parking, I'd easily give it 3 stars, because really, the food is pretty average. But, because of the difficulty in parking, and because it IS meant to be a fancy dinner (with prices reflecting that), I can't see myself coming here again.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - A bit on the fence about the accessibility of the place. While there is a large single, angled step to get inside, they do have a ramp they can bring out. And, while the tables are placed close enough that maneuvering around can prove difficult, they can set you up at a table near the front, with enough notice.

Bathroom - I didn't check them out, so I can't say for sure, but even if they were accessible, getting to them could prove a bit troublesome.
author: Johnny W.

description:
- Salad with scallop tempura - this was one of the specials for the day and was pretty good

- Wasabi noodles with pork - not bad, doesn't taste much like wasabi, just a little sweet and a little spicy but more like chili spicy than wasabi spicy

- Curry noodles with chicken - good, same noodles as the wasabi noodles, but curried flavor. the curry taste was light and more like an after taste

- Chocolate truffle cake - they brought out our desserts really quickly like within a minute.. the chocolate cake tasted frozen, wouldn't recommend it
author: Jeanie F.

description:
Love it. All the dishes we ordered were really yummy. Really great noodles and seafood. We enjoyed a scallop appetizer, curry noodles (my favorite), soy glazed salmon (perfectly cooked), shrimp dumplings which were OK but not great, and a Kale salad that was also OK and a upside down pineapple dessert (YUM)

Overall really great restaurant.

Notes:

* Try one of their noodle dishes: Wasabi noodles or Curry, so good
* Salmon is very good, perfectly cooked
* Make reservations, this place gets packed on the weekdays at lunch
* Wines, Sake, beer
author: Christy L.

description:
Good food. Not amazing. Not super flavorful.
Tables are close together.
I was hoping for delicious food that I would crave again and want to come back for.
author: D R.

description: I love the food here and will continue to eat here. It is always consistent and fresh. But for the first time I brought in my own bottle of wine for a special occasion and corkage fee was $30.00!!! Come on now. I know they want to discourage people bringing in their own bottle but seriously? even if you also buy a bottle they don't waive the fee.
author: karen c.

description:
The House is a pretty small restaurant that really has no entryway and no front desk with a greeter. And it's dark inside. And on a not very clean looking street. BUT OH WELL I'd still come here in a heart beat!

I came here for dinner with my girlfriend and arrived a little early. First tip: you will probably have to park a few blocks away since it is a hugely busy street, so arrive early enough to have time to find a spot and walk here. Second tip: make reservations. DEFINITELY MAKE RESERVATIONS. There aren't a lot of tables in here, and wait times can get pretty long, especially since this isn't a place that is great for groups. We made a reservation and actually arrived about a half hour before. I talked to a waitress and she actually had us seated within 10 minutes because a table freed up (and the other groups that showed up were all 3+). Yay for us!

We were seated and explained the specials of the night, all of which sounded really good. Our waitress was extremely attentive and courteous to us especially when I forgot what the specials were twice. 

To start I got a bowl of the truffle mushroom soup which was one of the best I've ever had. It was creamy and rich and had a great aroma where the truffle really came through but was still really well balanced. I'm actually not a big fan of it, but I didn't mind it in this soup because it was made so well and not overpowering. We also got tuna tartare which was some really good raw tuna but served with quite a generous amount of wasabi. If you like the taste and burn, this was an amazing dish, but probably a little overpowering for those who are more sensitive to a wasabi punch to your sinuses. 

Our entrees were the kurobuta pork chop and a grilled swordfish with mussles. They do cook their pork only medium well so that it is a little pink in the middle, but they really know what they are doing because it was one of the best pork chops I've ever had. Great flavors, not dry at all, yet cooked to a melt in your mouth texture that you don't often find with pork. The swordfish was hands down the best swordfish steak I've had in my life - it was super tender and moist and I would definitely order it again. Ugh that piece has put all other fish to shame, I've never even had one that good in Mexico or Hawaii. 

If any review I've done on here deserves a 5 star rating, it is this one. No previous bias, no hype from friends, this was just my own amazing personal experience at an amazing restaurant. I'll definitely be coming back to try something new.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Came here a while back, and wasn't too amazed. I had heard a lot about this place, and was looking forward to it. However, it was slightly underwhelming.

The food was decent, but I personally thought the fried salmon rolls and the wasabi noodles were just too oily. All around, the food used way too much oil, and I just felt a bit gross after.

The space is small, so try to make a reservation or expect a wait. If driving: go early, because street parking may be difficult to find.
author: Cynthia X.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in SF. There warm wasabi noodles with rib eye is a must have. Muscles with garlic shrimp broth and the grilled shrimp salad with chicharrones are delicious!
author: Eva M.

description: All I can say is perfection!!! The seabass just melts in your mouth. You don't even have to chew. One of my favorite restaurants on SF. You need to make reservations to get a seat. Call early!! Small place so not a lot of tables.
author: Erville V.

description: My new favorite place! Went on a spontaneous trip to the bay over the weekend. Wanted to eat somewhere new. I remembered I always wanted to try out The House and thought it would be a perfect place to have dinner. I looked at Yelp and it says it closes at 11pm. We got there around 10:15 and the place was packed. We stood at the door and the owner came up to us and was like 15min wait. I looked at my friend and was like heck yeah not bad of a wait at all. We decided to share the fried calamari and Rib eye steak over wasabi noodles. Steak was cooked to perfection and the wasibi noodles was delicious. We enjoyed every bite. Service was excellent too. They made sure our water was full. Will definitely come back here for sure!
author: Joann P.

description:
This is a pretty overdue review, but The House is a solid restaurant. I had the deep fried salmon roll and the Kurobuta pork chop with pomegranate sauce. 

5 stars for the food, 4 stars for the experience. The wait seemed to be long but thankfully we'd made reservations. The interior is VERY cramped so expect to get cozy with your neighbors. The noise level was too high to make it a comfortable eating experience.
author: Kelly L.

description:
Despite the location- kinda next to a semi-questionable area but  don't let that stop you its safe and its one of the best meals I've had.
  Salmon rolls with hot mustard and the Ribeye was to die for...  expect prices to reflect the amazing food, but so worth it.
I'm sure You'll Enjoy it just as much!!
Small but moderne :)
author: Errry Day J.

description:
Finally came around and gave this Gem a try for my GF's birthday recently.

I had a reservation at 8pm on a Tuesday night and got seated immediately, so that was a great start. The place was pretty packed especially for a Tuesday night, but given the stature of The House, I wouldn't expect less.

Our server was pretty friendly and listed out the "today's specials" for us, but we opted to order from the regular menu. We had the crab cakes to start (oddly shaped crab cakes I might add) but it was delicious nonetheless, for the main dish we had the Wasabi Noodles and the Ahi Tuna. The Ahi Tuna was pretty good, but nothing too special compared to other places, as for the wasabi noodles, I wish there was a stronger wasabi kick but the flat iron steak was extremely tender! A big plus for me!

We also had the double or triple chocolate cake ( I don't remember -.- ) with coffee ice cream for dessert and the server was able to accommodate my request for a candle on top.

Overall, great experience and I will be back to try out the other dishes!
author: Marco M.

description:
This place is unreal! Book ahead though, the seating is EXTREMELY limited.

The variety is great, the drinks are on point, and the wait staff are excellent.

This is a great place to choose for a special occasion! Looking forward to my next visit!
author: Meaghan H.

description:
Who's in The House?

Delicious Asian fusion, that's who. 

Wanted to treat my friend to dinner for letting me crash with them, so I picked a well reviewed spot that was walking distance. 

Many reviews insisted that I make a reservation. Thus I snagged one luckily the day before. Super glad I did. It gave me an opportunity to make a bad joke when I walked in and maybe four people were in the place. 

We did get the awesome window seat though. Great views of the city and some bums stumbling down the block. They're not the most agile and there's lots of hills in the city. 

The food here delivers as advertised. As in it's really good like how everyone says. I have no idea if they deliver, though I would imagine they don't. So don't try to order. 

You get that deep-fried salmon roll as an appetizer if you know whats good for you. Unless you have high cholesterol, nothing deep fried is good for you then. It's large enough to split between two people. Superb!

The ribeye with warm wasabi  house noodles was great. I can't say anything bad about it. Everyone was hyping up the noodles but it was the ribeye itself which was fantastic. Still though, despite how great it was, I feel the best thing to do here is go with the seafood.

The grilled sea bass may have been the best sea bass I ever had. Super tasty and flavorful, paired with some noodles itself which I did not see on the menu. I highly recommend you get it when you come here. Yes, when you come here. Not if! 

They'll be expecting you to make a reservation shortly. 

Just a note, I suppose you don't have to make a reservation if you intend to get there as early as I did, 5:30. No I don't normally eat dinner that early (What am I? 70) but it was the day I landed. Thus, felt like 8:30 to me.
author: Mitch E.

description:
It's rare for me to sit through an entire course of dinner and not have one single complaint, but somehow, The House did just that. If I can give 6 stars, I would. Doing what they do so well, they really do deserve it. 

We made a reservation one week prior due to the fact that reservations usually fills up pretty quickly. When we arrived, we only waited 5 minutes before being seated. The server was friendly and the service throughout the night was great, but it was the food that blew me away.

We started off with the Deep Fried Salmon Roll and the special of the night which was a Hamachi Sashimi with Crispy Nori Chips. SO SO GOOD! For the main courses, we opted for The Wasabi Noodles and the Sake Broth Salmon. These two dishes are probably the best Asian-Fusion dishes that I've ever had in my life. The salmon was so well cooked, and with the hint of sake in the broth, it was a WINNER. On the other hand, the wasabi flavor in the wasabi noodles wasn't too over-powering, even my friend who doesn't like wasabi at all was a big fan! That sure says a lot! 

For dessert, we ordered the persimmon bread pudding and the coconut flan, and WOW, I never had such AMAZING asian-infused dessert. We actually had doubts when we ordered both the desserts, thinking that a persimmon bread pudding may taste weird, or the coconut flan may be too sweet, but we were pleasantly surprised! The persimmon pudding was more like a really tasty piece of spiced cake, while the coconut flan was just heavenly. I would totally lick the dishes if I could. 

Overall, there was not one thing for me to nit-pick at The House, and I walked out of this dinner happier than ever. I HIGHLY recommend anyone around the area to give this a shot, or even for tourists visiting the city to come taste how good food can be in SF!
author: Luby H.

description:
The House is great for both lunch and dinner, but I much prefer to eat here during lunch because it's cheaper for about the same portion and there's fewer people, thus shorter wait time. Main entrees served during lunch and dinner vary. There's always about 3 to 5 specials of the day, with oysters most likely being one of them. Also, depending how late you eat dinner and if you wait outside the restaurant, you may encounter some crazy, drunken panhandlers.

I HIGHLY RECOMMEND the flatiron steak with roasted shitake mushroom sauce (lunch item). HIGHLY HIGHLY RECOMMEND!! Very tender steak, cooked to your desired perfection. Ask for medium, you get medium. The mushroom sauce is AMAZING. It's savory, creamy and so so so delicious that I could lick the plate clean if no one were looking. I also love their oysters, both cooked and raw, and their spicy cilantro mignonette sauce served with them. It's packed with so many flavors, definitely giving your tongue a tickle.

I'm somewhat thankful The House is such a hassle to get to from the other side of the city, or else I'd be eating here weekly.
author: Priscilla W.

description:
Came here on a random Tuesday night. Friends have recommended this place and we were in the area so we decided to stop by. 

We were fortunate enough to find parking about a block down, but I can only imagine how ridiculous parking would have been had we not been so lucky.  

As we walked in, we were greeted and they immediately asked if we had reservations. I can see why. The restaurant is pretty small. We didn't have a reservation, but we were seated right away. The tables are awfully close together so you feel very limited on space. I was practically elbow to elbow with the table next to us. 

On to the food..
I must say, the food was pretty damn good. We ordered the calamari as an appetizer which was delicious. I had the Wasabi Noodles. I do not have any regrets. It was full of flavor and the wasabi wasn't overwhelming as I imagined it might be. My friend ordered the Sea Bass which was cooked perfectly. Very delicious.

I do have plans to return in the new future. There are still many things on the menu that were very eye appealing. I've heard great things about the salmon roll and creme brulee. I was too full to order desert, but I won't make that mistake next time.

All in all, great first experience. One star off due to parking and limited space.
author: Jasmin C.

description:
The House
Overall
3.5 Stars

Gold medal - All that Hype
Silver medal -  Fried Chicken Liver
Bronze medal -  Service

I went to SF for the weekend and was recommended by 2 separate people who didn't even know each other that I had to try The House.  I Yelped The House and what did I find, WOW this place has almost 3000 reviews and is rated a 4.5 star.  Super shocked, I hurried and made a reservation.  The earliest reservation was for 10pm the next night.  WOW.

I ended up in the area that The House was located in and decided that I would put my name down and wait for a table instead of eating at 10pm at night.  I put my name down at 6:50pm on a Saturday.  The manager told us that the wait was over 1 hr. Ok, fine for a 4.5 rated restaurant, no problem.   We went next door for drinks and came back an hour later.  Nope............ still waiting. After another 30 minutes, we were called.  

After waiting 1.5 hours for a table and reading about everyone rave about The House, I was very excited to see what this hype was.

The best thing I had was the fried chicken liver.  It was super tasty and delicious.  Everything else................... hmmmmm it was very mediocre.  The flat iron steak, to the salad, to even the raved about wasabi udon = all mediocre.

The service was great though.  Everyone was genuinely helpful and hospitable.  

I honestly do not know what all the hype is about this place.  The person sitting at the table to the right of me was saying how, his fiance is so upset that he is eating at The House, since it was her favorite restaurant in SF and she not there.   The person sitting to the left of me was saying how they LOVE The House.  I must be the odd weird one here for thinking that the meal was mediocre.

For the price and the hassle of the wait, I definitely am not sure why this place has a 4.5 star and over 3000 reviews.  Seriously,  Touche to The House!

HAPPY HYPING!!!
author: Kelly C.

description:
More like 3.5 stars.

Maybe it's just me, but I think The House is a little overrated. I'll still give it 4 stars because the food was good, but it was not amazing. This place is super tiny so be sure to make reservations. My bf and I spontaneously decided to eat here for dinner and we were one of the lucky ones to get seated without a reservation right when it opened. I don't recommend doing this though because they told us that we could only have the table for one hour, so we felt a little rushed especially because they did not have the fastest service. We decided to share the deep fried salmon rolls, sea bass & garlic noodles, wasabi noodles & flat iron steak, and for dessert we ordered the coconut creme brûlée with passion fruit purée. 

I was a little disappointed with our deep fried salmon rolls because they were overcooked. The sea bass was pretty amazing- best thing we ordered, but the garlic noodles were just OK. I was really excited to try the wasabi noodles, but I actually liked the garlic noodles more and the steak was good, but not amazing either. I really liked the coconut creme brûlée though and all of the food was nicely presented.
author: Stephanie G.

description: Grilled unagi, avocado sushi rice was the best!!!! I wanted seconds!
author: Richard A.

description:
I came here for dinner with my boyfriend last night.  We were a bit earlier than our reservation time but got seated in less than 10 minutes.  Our waitress was really nice and attentive.  She introduced the daily specials but didn't sound pushy at all.

We ended up getting the soup of the day (some mushroom soup with truffle oil?), tuna tartare with nori crisps, the kurobuta pork chop with pomegranate sauce, Hawaiian swordfish and mussels in a curry broth, and coconut creme brûlée with passionfruit sauce.  We also got two glasses of Riesling which was really good but ended up being a bit too fruity with my entree (since the pomegranate sauce was already pretty fruity). 

The soup was really tasty!  It had the perfect velvety texture, smelled amazing, and I'm glad the truffle oil/essence didn't overpower the whole dish.  We only ordered one because I only wanted to try a little bit and because it was the last bowl left. 

Unfortunately, I didn't like the tuna tartare appetizer too much.  I was expecting it to be more similar to a poke salad but it was dressed in a wasabi sauce and my tastebuds are really sensitive to wasabi.  It made me tear up and definitely cleared my nose.  But of course, that's not their fault - I'm just weak sauce :( I did enjoy the nori crisp though!

For my entree, I chose the kurobuta porkchop.  The waitress did warn me that here at The House, they cook the pork chop medium well.  I'm usually pretty squirmish with eating pink pork but I'm sure this establishment knows what they're doing in terms of cooking meat at the correct internal temperatures so I wasn't afraid.  This turned out to be a fantastic entree choice!  The pork was so tender and the sauce paired perfectly!  There is some fat on it so for those who don't like fatty meats, you have been warned.  But, I happen to love some fat on my meat so this was perfect!  I would definitely order this again in the future!

My boyfriend got the Hawaiian swordfish and mussels in curry broth.  I tried some of it and man, it's got to be one of the best pieces of cooked fish I've ever had!  The texture was perfect and the curry broth/sauce was creamy and matched well with the delicate fish.  But I do think that the fish was a bit under seasoned.  Other than that, delicious!

We ended our meal with the coconut creme brûlée with passion fruit sauce.  I was not expecting the passionfruit sauce to be so tart but I like tartness in my dessert so this was good!!  The creme custard part put me to heaven!  Didn't detect any coconut taste/smell though.

All in all, a fabulous place for a date with your significant other or a small group dinner.  It is a small restaurant so expect to make reservations!  Parking is also a bit difficult so account for that as well!
author: Maggi K.

description:
My prior experiences with Asian fusion had made me a non-believer, but man did that change last night. First off, there is a time and place for pretentious, but I don't think Asian cuisine is particularly suitable to be such. I was extremely pleased by the House's down-to-earth dank food that was served up without obsession over how it was plated. Please don't misinterpret my statement: the food looked appetizing, just not immaculate, which to me is a more authentic representation of what Asian cuisine embodies. My mom always told me that a lot of Asian food doesn't look as great as it tastes. 

The restaurant itself is quite small so you should expect to be sitting about a feet away from the next table. Service was fair; though when I first arrived at the restaurant and announced I had a reservation, the waitress looked at me with a blank stare for what seemed like 10 minutes before saying she'd be with me in a second. I'm almost positive I spoke English.   

I adored all the dishes we ordered:
+Manila Clams in a chili broth (on the specials menu)
+Deep-Fried Salmon Roll with hot mustard
+Grilled Sea Bass with garlic ginger soy
+Swordfish with a coconut curry base (on the specials menu)

The chili broth for the clams was just the right amount of spicy and my friend and I loved it so much we asked for extra bread to soak up every last drop. The sea bass was cooked to perfection - flaky and not gelatinous.
author: Charlotte Z.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in SF! The price is actually really reasonable for the quality and portions of the food. If you love Asian Fusion, it will be hard not to love The House.

Make a reservation well in advance if possible because there is very little room for seating inside (also not recommended for big parties). I came on a date with my boyfriend and we had a fantastic time. 

Service was very quick and pleasant and the food was just amazing. We had:

1) Soft Sell Crab - So delicious with the sauce! Tender and decent amounts of crab 
2) Salmon Roll - Great to try (lots of salmon) but not super unique since it just tasted like any baked roll you might find at a sushi place 
3) Sea Bass w/garlic noodles - Oh my GOSH I still think about this sea bass. So soft, perfectly cooked, perfectly seasoned. The garlic noodles were also such a good compliment! I liked them way better than the wasabi noodles. Would get again (and again and again)
4) Steak with wasabi noodles - Huge portion for the price, great steak, but the wasabi noodles just could not compare to the garlic noodles...

Highly recommended for date night! Treat yo'self
author: Jenny M.

description:
What more can be said about The House?  We had early reservations during a weeknight and the place was almost full.  Service was attentive from the three staff members who tended to us. The food was delicious!

Picked cucumbers (complimentary) - Thinly sliced, crunchy and spicy bites to whet your appetite for what was to come!

Grilled octopus - The most tender pieces of octopus I've tasted with just the right amount of flavor.  It has a nice mild spiciness to the grilled pieces which were sliced thin to make me feel like I was eating a soft fish rather than octopus.  I want some more!

Ribeye steak with mashed potatoes and cauliflower - Nicely prepared rare steak with tasty garlic pieces which was tender and flavorful.  This was a generous portion so you could keep enjoying each flavorful bite until you had your fill but you really need to eat the yummy cauliflower that was hidden underneath the steak soaking up all the juices!  The best cauliflower I've ever eaten!

Miso Black cod w/tender greens topped w/crab avocado maki (daily special) - We had the servers repeat the dish to us twice because the black cod was so buttery and smooth that I thought they gave me the sea bass instead but I knew the sea bass was presented differently.  This dish was the winner of the evening!  The crab avocado maki was sliced lengthwise like an open faced sandwich.  The roll was very fresh but after taking a bite and sharing some, I didn't get to eat the rest of it because someone else begged to eat it all.

Atmosphere - Small, cozy, wood themed restaurant that can get loud.

Parking is not the best in the neighborhood so be prepared to circle around if you want to park on the street.  Another option would be to park at the Vallejo St. Parking garage right next to the police station.  It's only a couple of blocks walk to the restaurant if you don't mind paying for parking.  The dining experience is worth the price!
author: Good D.

description:
I have been waiting so long to try this place! I finally got to yesterday!

This is a review for lunch. Contrary to the three $$$ that Yelp says, this place is great for lunch with many dishes in the $10 - 14 range. Not sure how dinner is... It was nice how they let us make a lunch reservation and change it to a later time because we were running late. 

Anyways.. to the food!

Fried Salmon Roll with Chinese Mustard... that mustard really compliments the salmon roll! I saved some for our later dishes because I liked it so much. 

Warm Wasabi House Noodles with Grilled Pork! The pork honestly wasn't my favorite but the wasabi noodles were... as some would say, ON FLEEK! So delicious and honestly I don't think I've ever had anything like that before. 

Curry Noodles with Grilled Chicken... absolutely excellent.  Very generous portion too! 

Rib eye steak special: I think our eyes lit up when our server told us this was one of the specials and again, we devoured this delicious dish.

Usually we skip dessert, but we heard coconut creme brulee and apple pie a la mode and... well.. I would definitely recommend both! 

Service here was great too! Parking obviously sucks but its SF what can you do? I can't wait to come back and try the other items on the menu.
author: Aakash A.

description: So.So.So. GOOD. Make sure to make reservations cause the place gets packed! I always order the Prime Angue Ribeye with garlic butter which is my fav!. I love the garlic flavor and the meat is always tender! Service was prime. Food was a little on the pricier side but well worth it.
author: Aspyn L.

description:
With so many reviews and such a high rating, I expected more from this place.  Had dinner here a couple weeks ago with some friends and was disappointed.  Nothing was really bad, but nothing was really good either.  The service was good and I had a good time, but it was more about the company the the restaurant or food.  Some dishes I remember are..

Beef Salad: Wasn't exactly what I was expecting.  Contained fruit and not really any greens.

BBQ Oysters: I thought there would be more to this dish, but its literally oyster with BBQ sauce.  The BBQ sauce was okay, but I thought the combination of BBQ sauce and oysters left something to be desired.

Mushroom Rice with Grilled Prawns: This was my favorite dish.  The rice was flavorful and creamy.  Delish!

We ordered so many more dishes, but these were the best or most disappointing for me.  Parking is hard to find.  We ended up parking at the garage by the police station on Vallejo.  It's not that far and I believe $3 an hour.
author: Elena N.

description: I was allowed for 30 minutes to finish the dinner cause all tables were reserved There were always a line whenever I came, but the foods were uniquely tasty !
author: Thao D.

description:
We came here on a Monday during lunch assuming we would beat the crowd. Boy were we wrong, this place is constantly hopping! After a short wait, we were seated promptly and greeted by our server soon after. 

Let me just start by saying this, the deep-fried salmon roll is the best I've ever had in my life! You will not regret starting your meal with that appetizer. After coming highly recommended, we ordered the house wasabi noodles and the chicken curry noodles. Both were creamy, rich, and full of flavor! A must try in San Fran.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
3.5 to 4 stars. 

it was good, but not great. 3 of 4 dishes we ordered were specials: hamachi app (good, not wow). scallops (delicious- we could've eaten 5 more portions!). seabass with garlic noodles and green beans- sea bass was good (but it always is) and nothing special on the sides-- overall too salty. lastly, the "kobe domestic ribeye" -- it was NOT kobe... and it was barely a ribeye. the meat was a disappointment and the potato mash it came with was much worse. the only saving grace in the dish was the absolutely delicious cauliflower. it may be the best cauliflower i've ever had, which says a lot... $130 for dinner + tip. value was OK. food overall was good. i'd come back if there weren't so many other places to try in SF... 

side note: restaurant is tiny so tables are WAY TOO CLOSE together! Also, I got that weird seat against the fake wall to the doorway. My impression would have been much better if I was by that window seat the old couple was at! :) also, we seemed to have 2 waitresses. the first was an asian woman who didn't seem very friendly or helpful. she listed the specials like a robot and when she was done i started to ask a question and she was already walking away! the other waitress was super friendly and helpful... sooo, i'd say my feeling on service is mixed as well. 

be warned: the hype is high. i think my review sits closer to a 3.5 in any case, i rounded up a 4.
author: Sau y.

description: Visually artistic creations of skyscraper-like dishes that won't disappoint your taste buds. Beautiful mixture of taste, flavor, colors, and texture of the various ingredients. Very small place in simple casual decor.
author: Andreas K.

description:
First I want to start by saying that I think my expectations were set too high. The food was definitely good, creative and filling. But it just didnt WOW me. 

Salmon Roll ($10/4 stars) - Comes with the spicy chinese mustard sauce and a pickled cabbage underneath. This is probably their most popular appetizer

Grilled Scallops with ponzu sauce ($15/4 stars) - One of their appetizer specials! 3 decently sized scallops with lots of saucy goodness. Not sure what it was but it was good!! We liked this over the salmon. 

Wasabi Noodles with Flat Iron Steak ($20/3 stars) - Hmm. Everyone rants about the noodles. I think they're good.. but nothing you wouldn't expect. Flat Iron steak is pretty basic flat iron steak. Also comes with the same pickled cabbage in the salmon appetizer

Pork Chop ($26/4 stars) Has that awesome unique pomegranate currant sauce. This definitely makes the dish. Its very different and the pork chop is cooked perfectly medium. A great portion.. but again, didnt WOW me. 

Chocolate Truffle Cake with Coffee Ice Cream ($10/4 stars) - i love truffle anything.

Would I be back? Maybe if I lived in SF but I'd choose another $$$ for my next vacation.
author: Jenny F.

description: I came here on a date once. Food is a bit higher in price. When I came my date ordered me wine and suggested what to get. The food is great but it's very small and kind of crowded. Known to be one of the better restaurants in the area. Never ended up on a second date but the food was pretty good. Parking is hard to find!
author: Amy Y.

description: It's as if you went to dinner, and woody Allen, Steve martin and Bill Murray unexpectedly sat at your table and started riffing, but instead of funny witticisms that you laughed at, their words turned into food and went into your mouth.
author: Fletcher I.

description:
Love this place. We've been twice and will definitely return.

The noodles and fish options are amazing.

Great teas too.
author: Captain B.

description:
4 stars for food. 
+ 1 star for my bf

Came here with my lovely bf because he wanted to treat me before I started work. He has such high expectations for food that I know I will not be disappointed by his choice. We made reservations a week in advance for 7.30pm and *WARNING: We took 30 minutes to find parking. Do allocated some time for parking in this very popular area of SF.*

We were seated 15 mins after our reservation. The place is rather normal looking, no cute or fancy decorations to steer you away from the real star - the food. While I was waiting, I was attracted to the large portions of wasabi noodles ($19) because I was so hungry! I decided to order that. There was also a special menu for that night where the main course was short ribs with mashed potatoes and cauliflower ($28).  My bf decided to give that a try. 

Wasabi noodles with beef: Upon first bite, the wasabi flavor spread throughout my mouth. It was not overpowering at all, in fact, it was amazing and I loved how it combined so well with the udon. I immediately made a mental note to try putting wasabi in noodles the next time I cook. I do have to complain about the beef. I got it medium rare, and the beef was medium-medium done at best. I went with it because having the order changed and complaining just takes up so much time and I would rather enjoy my meal. I do wish that the wasabi came in more punctuated flavors throughout the course of the meal, rather than the initial oomph. I could barely taste the wasabi after the first few bites. 

Short ribs: The beef here was 5x better than that of mine. It was soft, juicy, tender, with appropriate amounts of fats that agreed with my palate. I exchanged a few pieces of my meal with my bf's! The mashed potatoes were super special as well, as it was mashed with carrots. There wasn't much seasoning to the mashed potatoes but I guess the star to focus on were the ribs. 

After these two dishes, I was really full and gave the rest of my noodles to my bf who willingly finished it up. I wished I had their dessert as many tables around me had them!
I am not a fan of the noise level but the food made up for it. I will definitely come here again :)
author: Jinyen Y.

description:
Yeah yeah yeah, I know you love it and told your friends & momma about this place, but it's just not really that great. But then again, you probably like PF Chang's, so why should I bother...

- DEEP-FRIED SALMON ROLL with Chinese hot mustard

Pretty fun, but it would have been much much much better if the salmon was raw rather than slightly cooked. Salmon is one of those fish genetically designed to be eaten raw. The roe was a nice touch, and the overall presentation and texture was pleasing.

***WARM WASABI HOUSE NOODLES with angus flatiron steak

Mild wasabi flavor, the noodles were okay, but nothing noteworthy. The steak tasted fresh, but we asked for medium rare and it was closer to well-done. I like a little moo with my cow. Side veggies nice but unmemorable.

***GRILLED SEA BASS with garlic ginger soy

Seared well, the wife liked the consistency (I thought it was slightly tough), but we both felt that it was flavorless. Then they gave us this dipping sauce that was overwhelmingly sweet and inferior to my homemade dumpling dipping sauce (and I'm caucasian, so boom-shakalaka!). Two-buck Chinese restaurant takeaway order side greens.

***BITTERSWEET CHOCOLATE TRUFFLE CAKE--coffee ice cream, coconut caramel

This was quite good even though I was expecting to not like it. The chocolate wasn't too strong, although in my mind something like this that tends to be rich should always be balanced by something fruity.

***COCONUT CREME BRULEE, passionfruit puree

There seemed to be no coconut in this at all. Okay creme brulee. Literally less than a teaspoon of passionfruit puree, which was a major no no.

ALL IN ALL:

Not a bad meal, but considering the reviews & price, it tasted like a slightly upgraded version of PF Chang's. Asian food and fusion food are both difficult to execute stylistically, and The House just wasn't able to pull either off successfully.
author: Elliott D.

description:
If you like Asian Fusion, The House needs to be on your bucket list.  Outstanding food...skirt steak with garlic noodles, sautéed green beans (could have been a little spicier), oysters with BBQ sauce were all excellent and well presented.  

What keeps this from being a 5 star is the venue...North Beach ( where parking is a bear, but there is a hidden paid lot down an alley behind the restaurant); a tightly fit dining area where patrons are nearly sitting in each other's lap; and a noise level that makes it very difficult to have a conversation...maybe I should go with 3  1/2, oh well, food rules!
author: Howard B.

description:
Have I told you I love ASIAN FUSION food? Indeed, I do I do!!!

Must order when coming to THE HOUSE:

1)Deep-fried salmon roll with chinese hot mustard

2)Grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy

3) Black cod special

4) Grilled ahi tuna (rare) with spicy mustard aioli

The best dinner that anyone could ask for. Not to mention their staff is amazing and they accommodate to your every need. Please make reservation if possible because this place is small.
author: Owie N.

description:
Amazing.  I waited 45 minutes on a weeknight.  The wait for this restaurant seemed unbearable but it was worth the wait.

The square footage was insufficient and everything was cramped.  The tables pretty much touch each other so don't expect private conversation.

Despite the small size, the servers were always running around.  They were very polite and didn't really pressure patrons to move quickly.

The food.  Oh goodness, the food.  Everything was amazing.  The mix of ingredients was unique and innovative.   Everything is served at the perfect temperature.  Wasabi Noodles were delicious.
author: Joel L.

description:
House is on FIRE!

The restaurant is located in the Hearth of North Beach a block from the main Bar Street on Grant. The space inside is quite small so definitely make a reservation before coming here! Also, parking can be difficult since it is on a busy street

FOOD: Sea bass with garlic noodles - This is the best sea bass I have tasted so far in my life. The fish is cooked to perfection and melts in your mouth. It comes with garlic noodles which are DELICIOUS if you haven't tried garlic noodles before. The dish is topped with ginger soy which is a great addition to the flavor combination.

Steamed mussels - The highlight of this dish is definitely the broth the mussels are steamed in. The broth has a great seafood flavor but not too fishy. The mussels itself were average sized and great too eat as well.

SERVICE: The service is great. The waiter helped us with selecting appetizers that would go well with our entrees as well as a great wine to pair.

Overall: I've book my next reservation and cant wait to come back! The food is spectacular at a great price. The entire meal was about $100 including drinks and appetizers!
author: Stephen C.

description:
The hostess Angela, needs to really work on her personal skills. There is no sort of order when you come in and are waiting to put your name down. She stood there rudely in front of me, talking to some friends for over 7 minutes and then just walked away. I stood there in utter shock.... What what was I supposed to do to get a table?? I'm thinking, this restaurant must run differently than 99.9% of restaurants in the world.  When my wife finally walked up to the chef wondering how to get a table (if it's even possible at this .01% out-of-the-ordinary-running restaurant), Angela appeared saying she was setting up some table. 

Safe to say, she can set all the tables she wants to. I've been to 2 star restaurants in north beach and they give you attention when you enter... You don't have to chase down a waiter or chef for assistance. I'm writing this while I sit a few doors down at Rose Pistola  ... A true restaurant.... With hostesses that greet you and show you some respect.
author: Harneet G.

description:
I have to admit I was a little skeptical of their 4 and a half star rating with almost 2800 reviews. First thing that came to mind before dining here last Saturday night was "overrated". I thought no way it would be THAT good. Well, I was wrong and it turned out being The House (of Goodness)!

The House is a really tiny so reservations are HIGHLY recommended if you plan on dining here. Don't ask me how many tables they have because I was slightly intoxicated when I showed up around 7:30pm. 

Caesar Salad with Crispy Scallops ~ 4.5 stars ~ $9.00: I have a little secret... I've never been a big fan of scallops. However, now that I've tried this dish at The House, I'm a believer. The scallops were seared perfectly on the outside to lock-in all the flavor of the tender interior. The sauce was delicious and the greens they put on top of each one gives it some freshness. http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=sAugkzJG8H09XwEvSZE-Kg&userid=CZ36wJqV-Xit758UaOr81A

Maine Crab Cake with Pickled Ginger Remoulade ~ 5 stars ~ $11.00: WOW! This pear-shaped crab cake was SO RAD - perfect for sharing. The crab was absolutely the star in this dish, which isn't always the case at other places. The crunchy exterior was the perfect compliment to the moist and intense flavor. http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=wX4ZSuqYidNqDIYkqXqiAA&userid=CZ36wJqV-Xit758UaOr81A

Kurobuta Pork Chop with Pomegranate Currant Sauce ~ 3 stars ~ $24.00: This was one of the few strike outs of the night for The House. I was so underwhelmed by this dish. The main reason is because the pomegranate sauce was way too sweet. Not only that, I didn't think the pork chop and sauce paired well with each other at all. The chop was also a tad dry - GASP! http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=fUJBgGs9qP9gvMTWopcH9A&userid=CZ36wJqV-Xit758UaOr81A

Warm Wasabi House Noodles with Angus Flatiron Steak ~ 4 stars ~ $18.00: Was this dish worth 18 bucks? No, and that's why I knocked down one star. However, it was really good. The noodles were the star and the steak was just playing second fiddle. If they remove the steak and knocked down the price, this would have been a hit. The noodles were cooked perfectly and the wasabi sauce was absolutely amazing. http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=YdoaEwoamZE1hYwqE7Ah8Q&userid=CZ36wJqV-Xit758UaOr81A

Grilled Sea Bass with Garlic Ginger Soy ~ 5 stars ~ $26.00: I'm SO pissed I didn't take a picture of this. It was by far and away our favorite dish of the night. The sea bass was buttery, flaky, moist and just outstanding. The saltiness of the garlic ginger soy took the awesome cut of fish to another level. I HIGHLY recommend this dish. Do not leave this place without trying their sea bass. 

I went with my buddy Josh, my brother and my sister-in-law. We also ordered two large bottles of nigori which led me to get way too tipsy to remember the three other dishes we ordered. I vaguely remember us ordering another fish dish, steak and another app, but I don't want mention them since my memory is absolutely failing me right now. My brother and sister-in-law were in town for her birthday so I paid for dinner. The total bill came out to be around $250 pre-tax which I didn't think was that bad at all considering how much we ordered plus the two bottles of sake. The service was outstanding and the atmosphere was very welcoming. 

The only reason I'm not giving this place five stars is because there were a couple of items I didn't care for at all, especially the pork chop. However, everything else we ordered was BOMB DOT COM. I wouldn't hesitate to go back. In fact, I absolutely plan on going back to try a few other things and devour another order of their sea bass. 

THE House. What a perfect name for this place.
author: Bruce C.

description:
Wowww this place is so good! The family that runs the place is also ridiculously friendly and nice, making the whole experience super enjoyable.

We ordered:

- grilled octopus with spicy mayo sauce - super tender, melt in your mouth amazing octopus slices smothered in spicy chipotle-y mayo. Next time I'll ask for the mayo sauce on the side. 
- fried salmon sashimi rolls - the table next to us got these and we immediately needed to order them too. They are deep fried but the salmon inside is still pink and a bit raw, making it extra juicy and tasty. 
- wasabi noodles with steak - steak was cooked beautifully medium rare, and the wasabi noodles are not too spicy or overwhelming.
- sea bass with garlic noodles - sea bass was juicy, tender, PERFECT. Garlic noodles are absurdly delicious. Only concern is that if you were to take these to go and eat them the next day, they would likely be pretty greasy.

We ate at Liho Liho the night before we came to The House and there is absolutely no question that The House is way, wayyyy better than Liho Liho. If you're looking for the best Asian Fusion in SF, this is it.
author: Amy Y.

description:
This place is absolutely delicious! 

Cute little restaurant tucked away! The wait staff is very attentive and the food comes out quickly! 

When you go, get the salmon roll appetizer! The wasabi sauce is out of this world.

For an entree get wasabi noodles with the salmon. It is the most perfect noodle dish ever!

Chow down and enjoy!
author: Emily K.

description: Everything about this place was great.  Presentation of each and every dish that was delivered to everyone's table was phenomenal.
author: Nancy P.

description:
I first heard of The House by my wife, who..was was introduced to this place on a date by some guy named Carl (Or Karl). 11 plus years have passed since this event and I can now say I am over it.

Especially since I not only 1 up'ed her, I 2 up'ed her and came here on a date with two incredibly hot gentlemen! Neener neener neener!

Yes Yelpers, be jealous...be very jealous as I was in the company of both John Z and Markus N two of the most desired males on the internet.

We stopped in on a Friday evening, John Z had secured an 8:00 reservation which is prime dinner time. As we approached the entry we noticed several diners waiting for tables. My first thought was that would be no way we would be seated on time. No big deal as we were no rush, but to my (most pleasant surprise) our wait is no more than 5 minutes and were seated at a nice table in the center of the dining room.

Let me get the bad stuff out of way. What did I not like about The House?

Nothing.

Ok, now on to the good stuff.

The food. Awesome.

Here are the details.

We started off by sharing the string bean appetizer. They were lightly breaded and served with a delicious dipping sauce. We each had a glass of sauvignon blanc, which priced at just $8.00 a glass was the perfect pairing.

We then shared a salad that was lightly (and perfectly dressed) and accompanied with deep fried chicken livers. Again, delicious.

Next up, the cod. I really can't comment too much on this as I just don't do the seafood thing but my friends commented on loving it, which is good enough for me.

What's next? How about the pork chop. YES! Scored a big 5 stars all around the table. It was served with mashed potatoes (perfectly mashed by the way) and asparagus. It was perfectly cooked to medium and was mouth watering. This dish belongs on any pork chop lovers radar.

Finally the flatiron steak, served over noodles this dish did not disappoint. Again, perfectly cooked to medium rare. The steak and noodles were the perfect combination. 

Our wine for the evening was a bottle of Carignan from Mendocino County. A medium (to almost full bodied wine) that I thought for the $45 dollar price was an absolute bargain.

The House is one of those places that I completely fell in love with. Not expensive, service excellent and food that is out of this world. I cannot wait to get back here again.
author: Rene C.

description:
Friday night - full house at The House.  But our table was ready as per our reservation.
Seating is cozy.  
Seabass was nice.  A little more seasoning would have made it better.
Shrimp and chive dumplings were very tasty.
Wasabi noodles with flatiron steak was outstanding. Medium rare was the right call.
But the star of the show was the plate of Blue Lake beans Tempura style.  The dipping sauce was ... addictive.  
Great dinner overall.  Many more items on the menu we will have to try next time.
Hopefully we will get a server who's attitude is not quite so elitist / dismissive. Everyone was a first timer to the restaurant at some point, right?

To her credit, she did act a little friendly when she presented the bill ... (sic)
author: Lewis C.

description:
The House is definitely one of my favorite restaurants in the city! My boyfriend grew up in the city, so he introduced me to this cozy little spot, and I've been dying to go back since! 

We made a reservation around 6:30 p.m for dinner, and when we arrived 15 minutes early or so, they seated us promptly on time. The staff is very polite, and was very patient with everyone despite all the chaos happening in such a small restaurant. 

We ordered a couple things:

For starters, we ordered the MAINE CRAB CAKE with a pickled ginger remoulade, which was absolutely delicious. It's a great starter because it's light and fluffy, with a generous amount of crab meat in it as well. 

For our entrees, we had the...
-Warm Wasabi House Noodles with Angus Flatiron Steak: the Angus steak was very well seasoned, & cooked to a perfect medium rare.  It's sliced up already, so if you prefer a whole piece of meat, don't hesitate to order the rib-eye steak instead (just as delicious). The steak was placed on top a bed of sweet & savory wasabi noodles, which packed a nice punch, and was a nice balance to the flavors of the meat. 

-Grilled Seabass with Garlic Ginger Soy- Honestly the best piece of fish I have ever had. It will literally melt in your mouth with such a soft texture, and the garlic ginger soy is subtle enough for it not to over-power the taste of the fish. All the reviews rave about it, but you have to taste the dish to understand...it's that serious!!
author: Krystal O.

description:
Ive been here for lunch and dinner, and both times were impressive.  The food is always very nicely presented, and tastes great.  The pork chop is by far the best item on the menu, but dont pass on their signature curry or wasabi noodles.  Theyre interesting flavors, and not something you'll find many other places.  If youre coming here for dinner, make a reservation.  If you dont, know whats nearby that you could walk to while you wait.  Lunchtime isnt as crowded and you might be able to get in with no wait. 

I would also recommend that you try the specials that they offer.  I have ordered a few of them and they have been good.  

Overall, good food and good service.  Prices are pretty standard for this type of food and this type of location.  Expect to spend around $40 for lunch for 2 people and around $75 for dinner.
author: Mike R.

description:
A few co-workers and I stopped in here, upon recommendation from a friend (who said it is her favorite place in the city), for lunch while in town for a business trip and we had a wonderful lunch.

The place itself is neither here nor there, it's a hole in the wall but it doesn't matter. The staff accommodated our last-minute reservation and was nothing but pleasant the entire time we ate - friendly, speedy, and always smiling. And the food was nothing short of amazing. To start, i had the sashimi and it was some of the best I've ever had. Seriously, the soy sauce + wasabi it came with was absolutely PERFECTLY mixed. For lunch I had the Udon, which was wonderful, and my co-workers had a salad and chicken curry. They, too, agreed that the food was spot-on.

I will come back here without question next time I am in San Francisco.
author: Mark B.

description:
After hearing about this place about 3 years ago, I finally had a chance to try this place.
I was a little disappointed because after reading all the great reviews about this place,  I was not impressed with this restaurant at all.
Don't get me wrong the food was good, but nothing exceptional.  It is an asian fusion place but I think it caters more to American Asian Fusion.
We ordered a bunch of things ( deep fried salmon roll, octopus salad, mussels , ribeye, flat iron steak, wasabi noodles, chicken liver salad, creme brulee , flourless chocolate cake , mango pudding) and nothing was outstanding that would make me come back to this place.
The ribeye needed more seasoning and the octopus salad was too sweet.

This place is always busy because its right  by Grant where the tourist place is.
It is also very small so I don't think they can take any reservations more than 6.

Coming back.... I don't think so...

Off to the next best thing...
author: Claudine V.

description: The dishes were very impressive and tasty. The service is good enough. Reservation is recommended because when I was there, I waited 45 minutes outdoor. Also, the catering person won't give you even one minute more than 5 minutes for you to walk back for your reservation.
author: Rhoda S.

description: Food is amazing here! Portions are huge and price is very decent. Totally worth it! You have to order their deep fried salmon rolls! They are the house special. Highly recommend to make reservations ahead of time as it gets packed for dinner. Lunch time is better chance to avoid lines but I would still recommend making a reservation. This is our second time at this restaurant and it never disappoints !
author: Melissa C.

description:
Make a reservation! Small restaurant and gets crowded. 

We really enjoyed the tuna tartare and shrimp dumplings as appetizers.

For mains:
Sea bass: delicious! Hands down. We heard it was widely recommended and agree completely. 

Lamb special: disappointing. The lamb was cooked well and was fine but I expected Asian influenced flavor. Instead this tasted like lamb I make at home but without any spices.l or marinade. Not on the menu, not worthwhile to order as a "special"

dessert: bread pudding special was delicious. Again not on menu but I liked this choice better than what I saw offered on the menu
author: Anon V.

description:
A long time ago, The House used to have a second location on Irving. 
That location was not very good from what I remember. You can't survive charging $20+ for Asian fusion in an area highly populated by Asian restaurants.

So anyway.

My friend made a reservation for a belated birthday dinner for herself / early birthday dinner for me. We were told we would have to give them back the table by 8:30pm. 
While I understand that this is a small restaurant, I do not like being rushed. I'm one of those people who eats, notices a crowd and says to my group "hey we should get going, there's people waiting." 
Since I anticipated The House rushing us, we went ahead and decided we wouldn't bother with dessert at this restaurant. Good thing because the dessert menu wasn't impressive anyhow.

Well.. What can be said about The House that everyone else hasn't said? It's pretty good and worth the money.
I had the sea bass and it was delicious. Although it comes with a ginger soy dipping sauce, I barely used it. The fish was tasty on its own, how I believe fish should be.
