Flat iron steak w/ wasabi noodles was good also.
My friend ordered the rib eye w/ garlic butter and that was super good. 

If you want to eat here, a reservation is HIGHLY recommended.. but don't be shocked if they tell you what time you need to be done eating. A little off putting and pretentious isn't it?
author: Susy C.

description:
I came here for Christmas Eve dinner without a reservation and waited about 30 minutes if not less. I am guessing we didn't have reservation because my date said so but he was tricking me that night so don't count on it.

The owner was walking around checking in with everyone. I think this is the first time I ever seen this happen at a restaurant. Its a nice touch to a quaint place. 

This place is tiny. 
It gets packed fast. 
Lights are dimmed for dinner. 
I'd suggest dressing up a little bit for dinner. 
White cloth napkins. 
     I wonder if there was something alive on mine because later that night I noticed a little bump on my lip where I distinctly remember wiping. But no worries it was gone the next day. 

I had the salmon dish. It's a slice of salmon on a green veggie island in a bowl of broth with rice on the side. The salmon was delicious. It is nicely seasoned and cooked to perfection (not under or over cooked). 

I'd love to come again to try the salmon wrap and the pork chops. They were out of pork chops by 8pm.
author: Jess W.

description:
Small place off the busy streets of SF.  Food and beer here is awesome.  It gets extremely busy so make a reservation or be prepared to wait.  Ordered the steak, pork chops, salmon, chilean seabass and they were all delicious.

You must stop by this place.
author: Douglas K.

description: Another amazing meal. Had the salmon roll and sea bass. Everything was so fresh and delicious.
author: Isaac R.

description:
My friend raved and raved about this place and then I saw the $$$ and got a little worried; I didnt want it to be a stuffy expensive place.

But then we came in for lunch and the atmosphere was pretty casual and breezy. The lunch menu is actually pretty well priced. I got the most expensive item on the menu which was the seabass and it was for ($24). The rest of the items are all under 20. Seriously though, the seabass did not disappoint. It was sooo freakin buttery and delisssshhhh. Would come back in a heartbeat!
author: Dominique F.

description:
Don't get me wrong, I thought the food was prepared well and executed flawlessly.   It's just that I've seen better at some of the asian fusion restaurants (that are in more ghetto areas).       

I enjoyed the meal but was expecting a bit more on an interesting technique or spin on food.     I didn't get that.   I got really solid, well executed food.    Maybe to me, that's just not enough.
author: Albert W.

description:
Came for Lunch. I had the Pomegranate Pork chop which was very very good. The combination of the sweet sauce and the charred edges of the pork chop make a great flavor. Someone else had the Pork sandwich and they said it was amazing.

Pretty safe to say this place is going to be good at whatever they make.
author: Joseph Rebelo R.

description: Just wanted to update.  I bring all out of town friends to The House.  It is easily one of my favorite restaurants.  The food is always spot on and the service is great.  It is a bit pricey ($40/person with tax and tip), but worth a splurge every once in a while.   The miso black cod special is maybe my favorite meal.  If it is on the menu please get it.
author: Paul W.

description:
Came here this past Saturday and was not able to get a table since the wait was 2.5 hours... goodness! I'm thinking what can be so great about this place? My bf was adamant on eating here so we came back the next day and after almost 2 hours of waiting, we finally got seated!

I started with a Lychee black ice tea which i thought was disappointing, because I couldn't taste the lychee in it.. so i ate the ONE lychee at the bottom of the cup. The good thing is that it came with free refills.

We started with the deep fried salmon rolls with the hot mustard dipping sauce. It was actually pretty tasty, considering how i was a little hesitant on ordering it. I feel like I can make this dish at home.

For the entrees, I had the Rib eye steak and the bf got Chilean sea bass. My steak was HUGE! it took over the whole plate and sat on a bed of mashed potatoes and broccolini. My steak was cooked to my perfection! I ordered it medium rare. It was well seasoned with soy sauce and fried garlic. I couldn't finished the whole thing, so I took it home and ate it the next day and it was just as good.

My bf's chilean sea bass was another story.. he didn't like it very much and said it was too salty. He did like the garlic noodles that his dish came with.

For dessert, we had the coconut creme brulee with the passion fruit puree on top of it. The brulee was good, but I felt the passion fruit overpowered the whole dish. 

Will probably come back, but definitely have to make reservations. I cant stand the wait, 
Also, parking is a pain the butt in that area. The whole two hours we were waiting was time spent trying to find parking.
author: Jenn L.

description:
Make sure you make reservations beforehand! My boyfriend made reservations about a week and a half in advance and the only opening left on a Friday night was 5:30pm. The restaurant is pretty small and is located near SF Chinatown. Because of how packed the small restaurant is, you're only abut a foot away from the next table which gets pretty cramped. We tried the following dishes:

Deep Fried Salmon Roll - This appetizer was pretty unique. But, I was a little disappointed that the sauce that came with it was a little watered down and the salmon inside was a little overcooked. My boyfriend had tried this dish before and said it was better the last time he was there. I thought this dish was good but could've been better. 

Wasabi Noodles with Salmon (substituted Salmon instead of the Flatiron Steak) - The staff was pretty accommodating about letting us substitute the dishes with any type of protein we wanted. After hearing all the great reviews about their wasabi noodles, I was hoping that they would be more flavorful. Again, my boyfriend said that they were better the last time he was there. I was surprised by how generous their salmon portion was. I thought the dish was good but I wasn't amazed. 

Pork Chop - ORDER THIS DISH! This dish was why I thought this restaurant deserves 5 stars. I normally am not a huge fan of pork chop but once I saw that it came with a pomegranate sauce, I was sold (I love pomegranates)! I loved loved loved this dish! I swapped this dish with my boyfriend's for him to try and immediately wanted it back. The pork chop was perfectly seasoned and really tender. It's great on its own but even better swirled with some of their pomegranate sauce. Sad part was that I thought their mashed potatoes were a little bland and just tasted like potatoes with no seasoning. 

The House is a great place for a quick meal. You probably won't stay for long considering how cramped it is inside. Their food is a great twist on Asian Fusion. I can't wait to try some of their other items next time!

TL;DR:
small restaurant
make a reservation at least a week ahead of time
order the pork chop!!
author: Charlene L.

description:
Minimal service.

Arrive early, & be sure to try the sea bass. They come with some bomb green beans.

You'll hear a lot of your neighboring diner's conversations. It is called The House, after all.
author: Jenny Q.

description:
While I love Yelp for finding new restaurants in new cities, I also decided to enlist the help of Facebook for my first trip to San Francisco. Well, I got one measly response: My friend told me that I MUST try The House in the North Beach section of the city. He is correct, and Yelp is correct. The House is great.

My friend and I made a reservation for either 7:00 or 8:00 on Friday night because we were sure we'd need it. Shockingly, tiny as it was, the restaurant was accepting walk-ins when we arrived. 

Upon being seated, we started out with a glass of Echigo Stout, a little-known Japanese beer that we both enjoyed. For my main dish, I tried the chilean sea bass with ginger soy sauce served on the side. The fish was cooked perfectly and was palatable on its own, but the ginger soy really made the dish stand out. I will say that it was a bit on the salty side, especially toward the end, but I wouldn't fret about it too much unless you really don't like salt. The bass was served with sides of tasty noodles, which I dipped in the remaining sauce, and some greens.

My friend had the steak, which was served with mashed potatoes, which he very much enjoyed. I don't eat cow so I had to take his word for it.

I was a little concerned about the three $s, but the prices were actually quite reasonable. I think we paid around $30 per person, not including tip. So what's not to love about The House?

Edit: Just realized this was review number 200!
author: Laura O.

description: Every single bite we had in this place was great. Highly recommended - Just come in and eat everything if you can!
author: Monster L.

description:
Who knew cod could be exciting?  I took a gamble when ordering the entrée and it was a fantastic decision.  The House really knows how to make a mouth-watering dish.

Everything I sampled was delicious.  Service was also excellent.

I wish they had a larger space.  My only complaint is that the seating is a little uncomfortable due to the close proximity to your dining neighbors.  However uncomfortable, it won't keep me from coming back when visiting the city.
author: Chelle T.

description: I will start by saying this is one of the best meals i've had in SF, if it was just based on food alone it would be an easy five stars.  The service, mainly the hostess and one of the waiters, i'd give a three star.  This was my second time coming here so my girlfriend and I knew exactly what we were going to order.  My girlfriend made a reservation weeks in advance and we arrived at the location on time.  We walked in with a smile, expecting to be greeted in a similar manner.  The female asian hostess walked towards us giving us a quick glance over in a mundane manner and greet a lady who walked in behind us like she was her long lost friend.  I am a firm believer in customer service so i tried not to let that bother me.  After her reunion with her friend she looked at us with the same mundane look and directed us to our table.  So i also have to mention how small and tight the restaurant.  As we ordered our food the restaurant started to fill up.  The waiter i mentioned before continued to bump into me as he was attending to the table next to ours.  Not even a sorry or excuse me after about 7 consecutive bumps.  We ordered the calamari, flat iron steak with wasabi noodles and the sea bass with garlic noodles.  As I started eating, I was not disappointed, i was so glad the first time i ate here wasn't a fluke and a smile came to my face.  I quickly forgot about the crap service from the hostess and the clumsy waiter.   I would definitely come back but i hope the two aren't working.
author: D S.

description:
For the four years that I've been coming here, The House has never failed me. 

I think Anthony Bourdain should definitely come here for the Layover episode of San Francisco (I haven't seen that episode yet but if he doesn't want to miss out, The House is the place to go).

If you haven't already done so, please try the pomegranate pork dish. You won't consider that a mistake in your life--so do it!

Sad to say, the pork chop is so good, that for the four (maybe five) times I've been to The House, I've always ordered the pork dish. I will for sure order something else next time though.

My date ordered the curry udon noodles with chicken (not sure if this is only on the lunch menu). But I couldn't help myself from drooling over his noodle over my plate of pork chop. This does not mean that you shouldn't try the pork chop or that the curry udon noodle is better, they are both equally as good--it just means I need to not order the pork chop next time. 

Anyway, you leave feeling really content. My favorite hole-in-the-wall place in SF. :)
author: Denise L.

description:
What an amazing under-the-radar restaurant. 

Checked it out last night and wanted to relive the meal the second it was over. We tried the shrimp/chicken/chive dumplings (some of the best I've ever had), the garlic noodles with flat iron steak (both perfectly cooked and seasoned), swordfish with green beans and noodles (also perfectly cooked), a cod special (perhaps the winner of the night - buttery fish, amazing sauce) and the deep-fried salmon rolls. I really don't think you can go wrong at this place. 

My only complaints are that they don't serve cocktails and the manager was a bit rude to us because part of our party showed up late. It happens. But the magical dumplings, fish, noodles and more made us forget all about that. Highly recommend.
author: Elena K.

description:
This is my cousin's favoeite restaurant and now I know why. The food was very food. From the very beginning we were happy with what we tasted.

To start we had: thesea scallops, salmon egg rolls and grilled octopus. The grill octopus was so good; not over cooked and not rubbery. The sea scallops were so tasty we ordered a second plate. The salmon was good. For the main course we  had the chilean sea bass and steak. It was so flavorful.  Absolutely delightful. We've heard not every dish is good but these two were The House's best dishes and it definitely was amazing.
author: Nam V.

description: The octopus!! So de-lish!! Everything on the menu is amazing!! Never been disappointed!
author: Nora J.

description:
Food: the clams appetizer is to die for! That sauce, orgasmic! lol no joke. Oysters were fresh, wasn't so keen on the sauce there, it was chill. I ordered the wasabi noodles as my main dish, it was really good. Nice undertone of wasabi, so it wasn't too intrusive. Balanced flavor. My sister ordered the Kobe steak dish, not to bash, but it was more like a filet mignon cut. But, again the sauce was bomb! 

Atmosphere: nice little date place, can be a bit loud because it is a small location. 

Suggestion: MAKE RESERVATIONS!!! Took us 1.25hr to get in... 

Verdict: price v. quality, worth it. Food, bomb! Would I go back? Yes, I will make reservations next time. Would I recommend this place to my foodie friends? Absolutely.
author: Kim D.

description:
Had the garlic noodles (was ok) and sea bass.  DO NOT leave here without trying the sea bass, it's cooked perfectly and is one of the best fish dishes I've ever had.  Be prepared for a long wait for a weekend dinner during "dinner rush hour" as the place is small and quite popular.

As many others have mentioned, don't forget the sea bass.
author: Joseph C.

description:
I ordered two things:
Shrimp & Chive dumplings
Sea bass with udon and green beans.

The first: I was underwhelmed by the shrimp and chive dumplings. Perhaps I am more used to the traditional overwhelming garlic-chive taste in other dumplings I've had, but the taste did not have any brightness. Moreover, the skin of the dumplings was not quite thick enough.

The second: The sea bass was cooked to perfection. The beans were also a highlight in the dish. Very much recommended.

The space itself is a bit small. I knock off one star for that and mediocritizing a classic.
author: J G.

description:
I came here a while ago and have been meaning to write a review, but haven't had time for it. I am usually indifferent to service. As long as my food comes out and someone can be flagged down to fill my water, I'm a pretty happy camper. Customer care here was really quite exceptional though. My boyfriend and I had been meaning to try The House for a while. I managed to call and make a reservation for a Saturday night. Due to work related things and traffic, we ended up not making our reservation time. I called ahead and told them I wasn't going to make it, and they said they would see what they could do for me. When I arrived, they still seated me right away even though I was half an hour late and there was another party ahead of me in line. Hooray!  

Now onto the food. I tried the fried calamari. Perhaps I should've been more adventurous, but I love calamari. It was possibly the best fried calamari I've ever had. I also had the wasabi noodles and the pork chop. The wasabi noodles were tasty, but the the pork chop was downright magical. It was cooked to perfection. I've never had such a well executed piece of pork in my life. Every part of it was tender and juicy. The House really does bring pork to a whole new level. To this day, that pork chop is still the epitome of everything a pork chop should be. Ok, I'll stop raving now.  For dessert, we had the panna cotta. It was good enough that I spent several minutes scraping the sides of the empty bowl in the hopes of getting enough for one more taste. Entrees here will cost you somewhere between $18-$30. Appetizers average around $10.  

Parking in the area is tough, but I will definitely be back someday. Apparently I still need to try the sea bass.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
The house is something out of a dream. Moving artwork, friendly staff, and a courteous atmosphere soothes the soul while inspiring for more. Their intimate sushi roll was a delight to eat and I absolutely loved their dessert options. 

Get here, now.
author: Navid B.

description: Try to get a reservation beforehand. As for the food, can't go wrong w/ the specials (appetizer specials and mains are always good)
author: Tom P.

description:
A lot of Asian-fusion type restaurants are hit-or-miss, but so far, everything I've had here was delicious! Reservations are highly recommended, and try your very best not to be late because they will give away your table. I mean, I can see why, this place is super tiny.

From my recent visits, I've tried:
Caesar salad with crispy scallops- This was great to share, very fresh and light.

Scallops a la carte (this was from the specials menu)- So good! The scallops were perfectly seared and the sauce was amazing.

Kale and pistachio salad (also from the specials menu)-  This was absolutely delicious! The kale are shredded into thin slices and seasoned with just the right amount of dressing and topped with pistachio. The flavors and textures of this dish went together so well. Two thumbs up!

Kurobuta pork chop with pomegranate currant sauce- The presentation for this dish was on point. I loved the color of the pomegranate sauce and it created a nice balance for the pork chop. The flavor was aromatic and tasty.

Sesame soy glazed salmon- This was probably the most Asian-looking dish. It was good to try but not something I'd order again. 

Grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy- This is a must try! The fish literally just melts in your mouth, and I didn't even know fish could do that! It has this nice, buttery texture that's so easy to eat and before you realize it, you've already eaten the entire dish. If you order this (which you should), do not order any other type of fish for the table (which we did) because this dish would make you not want to eat anything else.

Oh, and I also ordered the lychee iced tea. Yum.
author: Dung N.

description:
With almost 3000 reviews, and an overall rating of 4.5 stars, nothing else really needs to be implied.. this asian fusion restaurant is delicious!  They take reservations, so don't be silly and risk having to wait for a seat, just make the reservation!!

The low lighting in the restaurant really makes for an intimate meal, but a date or SMALL group of friends will work great here.  The portions are quite large for  this "fine dining" type of restaurant.  I had the grilled sea bass and it was AMAZING.  I got to a pick a side of garlic noodles or rice, & UH DUH, going with the garlic noodles.  My boyf had the steak and loved it.  He MADE us order 2 desserts on top of the appetizer/entree we already ordered, and he promised it would be delicious, even if it meant we would wobble around the hilly streets of SF afterwards stuffed beyond belief...

Can't wait until I come back! *drool*
author: Kristie F.

description:
It was a chilly Sunday night and I suggested that the boyfriend and I go to Brixton for dinner. He said sure, made reservations and we were off. We walked a couple of blocks until I thought to myself, this doesn't look like the place...

"SURPRISE! We're at The House!' "WTF YO! YEW LIED TU ME!" Oh well... we were seated quickly and everything on the menu sounded delicious. I ordered the chicken breast and honey ordered the steak with wasabi noodles. I wanted to order the wasabi noodles but I thought that the wasabi would overwhelm my food. Definitely not the case. There was just enough wasabi for a kick in the noodles and the steak was fairly fresh, except for one bite. My chicken breast was delicious and had beautiful garnishing and even yummy mashed potatoes underneath! We also had some chocolate dessert? Don't remember what its called.

Definitely will be back with a group of friends. :)
author: Mabel Y.

description:
This place is so incredibly good. 
I had some rice with saffron and some other amazing stuff on it. 
It tasted incredible. Everything is fresh and flavorful . I feel like 
Americas top chefs are in their kitchen. I will come back !
author: Mariangeles C.

description: This place is amazing! First of all my wife and I walked in last minute Christmas Eve! There was a wait and the hostess took us in no problem which was awesome. We were seated in no time and ordered the amazing ribeye (smothered with garlic) and the BBQ ribs :) My wife wanted some noodles but hates wasabi which again was no problem, our waitress offered garlic noodles which were freakn' awesome! We also ordered the tuna tartar and it was made with wasabi and my wife ordered not knowing and again no problem, they removed it from the bill no questions. Overall this place was amazing. Great staff, great food and amazing service. Thank you guys and Merry Xmas!
author: Shane K.

description: Great vibe!  Great sake!  Awesome food!  I had the ahi tuna. Best ever...very fresh and the sauces are perfect!  Don't forget to start with the poke and salmon rolls!  Sake is a nice addition!
author: Jackie G.

description:
Wow, amazing food.  Wait was a bit long but worth it.  I'm usually not that much of a fan of fusion because I think it's sometimes used as a copout from getting to the bottom of things and simply making good tasting food.  

I got the deep fried salmon roll as an appetizer and sea bass with noodles and green beans as the entree.  Both were awesome.  The salmon rolls are crispy on the outside but rare on the inside (I'm from Minnesota where we eat a lot of steaks and this is the way I grew up eating steak).  The sea bass was similarly well cooked.

We'll be back.
author: Daniel Y.

description:
What happened to this place? It makes me sad to say that I no longer have a favorite restaurant in SF due to my recent dining experience here. My usual, the sea bass, didn't melt in my mouth like it did the previous times--it tasted like sea bass I can buy and cook at home. The accompaniments also left a lot to be desired--the green beans were so skinny and the noodles tasted a bit soggy. My husband ordered the ribeye, which was mostly fat and lacking flavor. The worst was my mom's wasabi noodles and skirt steak. Why would they give us a knife if the steak is so tough that you can't even cut through it? I thought my mom was being picky, so we all tried to cut the steak, which was nearly impossible. Eating it was even more impossible. I couldn't even chew through it, so I swallowed it. When we asked our server, she said it was supposed to be like that since it's a lean cut of meat. I don't know anyone who would pay $22 to eat that--I wouldn't even accept $22 to eat it. The wasabi noodles were also very greasy. Needless to say, most of that dish was left untouched. I was so sad that this was the last meal on my mom's visit here and she even picked up the tab. Imagine spending a hefty amount on a sucky meal--definitely not a good way to go out. 

I recommended this place to so many visitors, raving about how great it was. Now I'm embarrassed for recommending such a place. I definitely won't be back and will tell others to steer clear.
author: Grace L.

description:
Fantastic Asian fusion food in North Beach.

I've heard friends rave about this place, so I decided to try it out on my most recent trip to San Francisco. I came here with a few of my friends, so I was ale to try a little of each dish.

We ordered a couple plates of the tuna tartare, calamari & the salmon roll to start. Tuna tartare had a bit too much wasabi for my liking (I strongly dislike wasabi). Calamari was good, nothing special. The salmon roll was also good.  Of these three appetizers, I would probably order the salmon roll again.

For drinks, most of my friends ordered alcohol, except me. I ordered green tea & my tea came in its own little pot.

On to the food:

I had the Grilled Sea Bass w/garlic ginger soy. Came w/snow peas & noodles. The Sea Bass was perfectly grilled & moist. Buttery. The way fish is supposed to taste.

I also had an opportunity to taste the mahi mahi, grilled salmon, pork chop w/pomegranate sauce & the rib eye steak. Everything was delish.  I don't think you can go wrong with any dish at The House.

We all shared the creme brulee & tapioca for dessert. I found the caramelized passion fruit topping on the creme brulee a little tart, but the mango tapioca was a hit with everyone.

Came out to about $50 per person.
author: Grace C.

description:
Probably the best soft shell crab I've ever had! The halibut was also great, although I wish there was no mash beneath it. The sauce was amazing though. The Kobe was great (their sauces are beyond perfect! ). Highly recommend.

Their staff was also wonderful- friendly,  helpful and always there for water and quick to bring our dishes out
author: Rebecca P.

description:
Acoustics - not for 50s set!
Deliciousnes - Yum!!!
Wine - great!
Service - C'est Bon!

Salmon roll
Sea bass-warm wasabi noodles and green beans
Radicchio Salad w Shiitake mushroom
Pecan pie-Kabocha 
Sake 
S. blanc
Caffe Trieste Coffee
author: Kevin F.

description:
I brought my parents here after a cold day on a boat and was EXTREMELY satisfied with myself for having made reservations a couple weeks before.

This place is kind of on the border of North Beach and Chinatown on a small intersection.  We fell out of the cab and immediately realized there was a little crowd outside.  We walked in, fully expecting to still have to wait in spite of having reservations.  However, they were immediately ready for us and seated us right away.

It became very apparent very quickly that the place is tiny and every single bit of space is maximized, probably not to the best of ways.  We felt like giants in the little area we were given.  Between dad and I, we felt like linebackers trying to squeeze in around a small kid's tea party.  However, after we took off our coats, it felt a little less constrictive in there.

The food was fantastic.  The plating was beautiful and after mom's 3 months stay here in the U.S., she says this place was her favorite above all the other places we'd taken her to.

We ended up sharing everything.  I don't remember exact descriptions but mom got a scallop dish with wasabi noodles, dad and I got a steak dish (rib-eyes I believe) and aunt got a fish dish.  

Service was polite and nice but understandably, they didn't have time to stand around and chat with us.  There was barely any place for them to lounge anyway.  

When we left, the crowd had gotten bigger and the weather deteriorated.  So glad that wasn't us.  We'll go back another time as well but will definitely be with a reservation in hand!
author: Tammy L.

description: I love the House although I have had a bad meal here before. The pork chops are to die for. The currant sauce pairs perfectly with the meat. Request the noodles instead of the mashed potatoes they give you. The wasabi noodles are so good. I had the chilean sea bass here and it was overcooked and too dry. The salmon rolls and Caesar salad with fried scallops are excellent to start your meal off with. Reservations are not super hard to get but totally necessary.
author: Chi N.

description:
The House should be a legit contender for a Michelin star. Their asian-fusion preparation of seafood is unmatched. In particular, the king salmon and sea bass are a joy to eat - although it is hard to miss in any order here. They are a dependable SF staple that no serious foodie should miss. 

Pro Tip: Order the cookies for take-away dessert for your inevitable walk around North Beach.
author: Chris P.

description:
Mmmm.. the food.

But uh.  Is this supposed to be decor?  Can they at least try?  I can't imagine what would happen if there was a fire.  Or an earthquake.  (Knock on wood.)  I could easily hear the conversations of the party next to me, and the one next to them, and I wasn't even trying.

Regardless, yes.  The food.  Their black cod with miso reduction was amazing, the california roll type thing that came along with was not.  Their wasabi noodles with steak was something I could get at a good mall food court and their medium-rare was more of a medium plus.  The ahi poke appetizer (3 wonton pieces) was cute and acceptable but it was their scallops (3) that were amazzzzing.

I didn't understand why there was such a wait.  It was so crammed and while our waitress was curt, the man who took our dishes/refilled our waters were so unfriendly, I briefly wondered if he was deaf or just blatantly ignoring us (it was the latter).  Their wine selection was okay.

I can think of many other places you can go for this kind of food, at this price, but with a better environment.  But if you absolutely must come here, I'd say stick to the seafood.
author: Janet L.

description:
Decided to try this place in my visit to San Francisco. This restaurant is really small and it's located really close to Little Italy. I would recommend making reservations because the restaurant is small. We decided to walk here from out hotel in Union Square and was not bad of a walk. We were seated and presented with pickled cucumbers. Our server gave us the specials of the night and they all sounded amazing. 

We decided to start off with the Ahi Tuna tartare with Nori chips. I went ahead and ordered the Black Cod with Salmon Roll and miso glaze. The Ahi Tuna was really good and had a kick to it because it was mixed with wasabi. The Black Cod was super good. It was like a deconstructed sushi roll which was super cool. The fish was really well cooked and the roll was a perfect compliment.

I don't live in San Francisco, but I would recommend trying this place if you live in the area or visiting like me. The House is delicious and will definitely come back on my next visit.
author: Henry O.

description:
I took my Brazilian bf here for lunch and he looked around and said, "this place is popular? For dates?? It looks ugly.." I agreed and laughed, then ordered, hoping the food would make up for the questionable decor. 

Our meals came out and EVERYTHING WAS DELICIOUS!.. and well-priced! Maybe I've been away too long but The House just proves how fusion food is done right in SF. A meal like this would have cost twice the price in London!

THE SEA BASS WAS PERFECT - flaky, slightly buttery yet soy-sauce flavored, cooked exactly right. The garlic noodles and veggies paired so well with the fish. The bf was shocked and said, "Wow, everything really is good!"

Thank you, The House! You left a great impression on a foreigner foodie!
author: Jenny T.

description:
I guess I'm opposed to my fellow yelpers, but this place just didn't do it for me.

It's so crammed here - nearly elbow to elbow. I know its the city and all, but I felt like everyone just knew your business.

The food was okay. I got about three dishes, all containing fish. I just remember tasting salt, fish, and oil. In addition, it was crazy expensive. It's in a great and lively neighborhood, but does that make my half fist sized fish $30?

1 extra star because they do take reservations so your wait can be minimized.
author: Chase L.

description:
We had not eaten here in years and I was happy to see that the quality of their food remains the same.  We ordered the grilled unagi on avocado sushi rice and it was perfect.  We also shared the grilled shrimp salad - on the lighter side, but still tasty with lots of crunchy textures and a slight kick from the sweet chili vinaigrette.  

For the main course, we ended up getting the ribeye, short rib special and the wasabi noodles with flat iron steak.  The meats were cooked to order (we asked for medium) and they were perfection - tender, juicy, and full of flavor.  The short ribs and ribeye came with mashed potatoes, which were ok, but I guess they were toned down to allow the meat to be the star.  The wasabi noodles were wonderful too, but they are on the spicy side.  Don't order those unless you like spicy stuff!    

For dessert, we shared several.  We tried the apple cobbler (?), which was fine, but it didn't stand out.  The bittersweet chocolate dessert with coffee ice cream was our clear favorite.  It was very rich and deserved a cup of tea to go along with it.  We asked for the coconut caramel sauce on the side and actually enjoyed the dessert better without it.  We also tried out the housemade almond cookies, but I wasn't a fan of those.  

If you can, call several days in advance and make a reservation because the place is always packed.  Space is at a premium in the restaurant, so you are almost sitting family style next to your neighbors, but the food is worth it!
author: Leigh Ann F.

description:
Definitely worth the wait! Get there early before they open to shorten the wait time or call to make reservations. 

Ordered the wasabi house noodle with angus flatiron steak! Super flavorful and delicious - definitely recommend it! Also, ordered their mahi mahi special, which was great. 

Overall great dining experience
author: Ephraim B.

description:
My new favorite restaurant in the city. This place is absolutely delicious! I don't want to write a long detailing description of everything I ate because I don't want to ruin the surprise you're in for. I had a taste of Wasabi Noodles, Pork chop, Soft-shell crab, Pork Belly, and the Sea Bass; they were ALL fantastic. I really was shocked at how everything came out and was both visually appealing and extremely flavorful. 

This place is a MUST try and the hype is for real. It's usually very very busy so come early, put your name down, and then go down the street to one of the 50 million bars and enhance your pallet with some beer. If I could wipe my memory so that I could try this place for the first time again, I would.
author: William L.

description: I'm going to update my review to a 5 star now 6 years later. Was I crazy? Perhaps. That sea bass.... I'm sorry I ever doubted you.
author: Sally C.

description:
Everything about my dining experience at The House was brilliant. 

Had a reservation for two on Valentine's Day after two failed attempts (on my part) to dine there months ago. My man went to find parking and I was promptly greeted by the hostess. Had to wait about 10 minutes for a table even with a reservation, but it was an especially busy night, so no big deal. The wait gave me a chance to scope out other diner's dishes and evesdrop on Valentine's Day conversations, because I'm creepy like that. 

Once seated far from the front door at a four-top  (!) (which I loved: more room is always a plus for me when there are people literally everywhere) I ordered the sparkling Shiraz and studied the menu. Honestly, everything sounded and looked amazing on other people's tables; we ordered the scallops for an appetizer and they were delicious and tender. 

He had the pork chop with pomegranate sauce and mashed potatoes, I had the Chilean sea bass with green beans and noodles with a ginger-soy(?) dipping sauce. Yum on all counts! The sea bass was flakey and buttery; I ate the whole thing. His pork chop tasted like steak, it was so tender, I'm guessing they brine their meat. 

We shared the strawberry rhubarb pie a la mode for dessert, which was tart and sweet, I had never had this pie before and it was very good. Fast, friendly service, a real treat.
author: Crystal C.

description:
We got there early enough to beat the dinner rush and we were seated within 10 minutes!

The service was friendly and cordial the food was delicious. 
An intimate environment with dim lights and candle lit tables. 
Asian fusion food with a bit of a fancy in a good way attitude.
A great and trendy little restaurant.
author: Alex N.

description:
What a wonderful dining experience in San Francisco. We came on a friday night at 6:30 with reservations for 6. The restaurant was cozy and full of people with a line out the door (impressive since it was raining as well). The meal was spectacular from beginning  to end, the deep fried salmon rolls were gone in seconds and the shitake mushroom soup hit the spot on a cold rainy night. The highlights of the meal were the ever popular sea bass and the kobe ribs (i believe this was a special of the night). I wanted to take home a gallon of the sauce that comes with the sea bass!

We ended the night ordering every single one of the desserts on the menu since they all looked great. The apple crumble dessert was my personal favorite. 

I highly recommend this restaurant if you are in the area. I will definitely be back.
author: Emily C.

description:
I love the presentation of their food and they are amazingly delicious! The restaurant is quite small and tables are close to each other but it definitely lives up to the great reviews on help.

Deep fried Salmon rolls- the salmon was soft and perfectly deep fried with chinese mustard dipping sauce. It is a must.

Warm wasabi house noodles with angus flatiron steak- cooked to a perfect medium rare. Oh so good.

 Grilled seabass with garlic ginger soy- hands down the best dish of the night. It was so soft, buttery and moist. It literally melted in my mouth.


Pork chop- so tender and delicious. The pomegranate sauce was sweet but perfect with the pork chop. Super love this. Sauce was on point.

 Chocolate truffle cake- Perfect way to end the meal. Bittersweet but so delicious. My fave here.

 I would highly recommend this place if you're in the city.
author: Arielle D.

description: Love the noodles, hate the lines and lines. Even after all these years. But I keep coming back for the house noodles.
author: Jacky S.

description:
Did NOT like:
- salmon fried rolls: salmon stinks
- octopus salad: nothing special and not 
                            much of octopus
- scallop dish: nothing special taste
- pork skin salad: so so
- dumpling: nothing special. Tastes like where u can get them at the super market. 

Did LIKE:
- Wasabi noodles with seabass: noodles taste amazing. Seabass was good too. 
- caesar salad: taste different from any other restaurants. Right amount of dressing and fresh. 

Overall: staffs were nice. I would probably come back for Wasabi noodles but nothing else made me to feel come back to this place.
author: Yoona S.

description:
I'm very confused by the exceptional ratings. Confused enough that I came here 3 years ago and found it mediocre, but then wandered in again to give it another try. Yep. Still confused. 

Maybe we're just ordering the wrong things:
* Tuna poke (special of the night): Tuna, rice cake crumbles, and avocado. Good but could have made it at home. Also, the tuna was a bit on the over-soyed side.
* Unagi and avocado: Good. Very creamy. A bit too much soft stuff texturally and not enough crunch or bite to offset it. Also, a heavy dose of mayo. Should have gotten the salmon roll instead - the pictures look incredible and the texture looks awesome.
* Wasabi noodles with skirt steak: Good. I liked the crunchy (mildly) spicy topping. The steak was cooked beautifully. The noodles were good. But it wasn't like I wanted to slurp the entire bowl down. In fact, I think we even had a few strands of noodle left when we were done. 

I guess my expectations are always set really high and I end up being shot down from my pie-in-the-sky vision, so I end up always disappointed.
author: Sylvia L.

description:
Came here for the first time after my co-worker raved about the sea bass, and I have to agree! The sea bass at The House is by far one of my all time favorite preparations of fish. Served alongside noodles and vegetables, The House gets the protein-vegetable-starch combo down perfectly. The dish is seasoned well, portioned well, and you leave feeling full but not stuffed.

Today, my coworkers and I ventured up to North beach again. We were lucky to grab a noon reservation for 3 after calling in at just 9:30am today. I wanted to try a new dish, and though I was tempted to order their yellowtail special for the day, I went with my gut and ordered the Kurobuta pork chop with a pomegranate currant sauce. I was immediately awed by the generous cut served. As I cut in to the perfectly cooked pork, I became an instant fan. The sweet and slightly tart sauce complemented the pork so well, cutting the fattiness of the meat. If I could bottle that sauce, I would serve it on practically anything. Though I considered devouring the entire pork chop, I set aside about 1/3 to take to go so as not to food coma for the rest of my day at work.

I have yet to be disappointed by anything ordered at The House, and I can't wait to go back to try my next dish!
author: Nancy T.

description: One word to describe the food here- WOW! Everything was amazing!  When you walk in the House it looks like an unassuming little hole in the wall, this is why you don't judge a book by its cover.. the food was fantastic.  We ordered several apps, the Ahi Tuna was very good but the scallops were amazing! Some of the best I have ever tasted!  For entrees we ordered the Sea Bass and sashimi which was delicious and the Kobe ribeye was fantastic!  Both dishes came served over wasabi noodles which were so good!  Overall, this was one of the best food experiences I have had in some time.  The restaurant is small and cramped, we were literally eating with the people at the table next to us, in this case they turned out to be very nice but I can see how this could be a turnoff.  The service was average.  Overall I can't wait for my next trip to SF to go back for the amazing food!
author: Brian S.

description:
I came here on a date.  We made reservations for 9pm and it was super duper packed.  We probably got seated around 9:30, but let me tell you.. the wait was well worth it!

The place is really small, so it gets a little loud.  I wouldn't recommend this place as an intimate & romantic place, but it's definitely a nice place to take someone on a date that you're comfortable with already.

I ordered the Angus Ribeye steak.  This steak was so juicy it just melted in my mouth.  It almost made me want to cry it was so delicious.  It came with some mashed potatoes and some grilled cauliflower.  The whole thing was perfect and complimented each other perfectly.  I ate the entire dish.  I would recommend getting medium rare because it makes it so much better and so much softer.  My mouth is watering just thinking about this darn steak!

My handsome date ordered a special that they were having, which was a scallop dish.  He really enjoyed it too and finished every last piece.  I had a little taste of his and it was very creamy and savory.

They have a small selection of entrees, but honestly... I love places that can perfect their main dishes.  Basically you order anything on their menu and you cannot fail.  It'll all be delicious.  I'm so glad he took me here because i'd be missing out on this delicious place.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Woot Woot! 
This place is hoppin! Good thing we made reservations! We got to skip the line :D
We ran like 10 minutes late but when we called them to let them know, they said they give a 15 minute window before giving the table up, so that's good to know.

The food is overall really good. We started with the calamari for an appetizer (just meh, not a lot of flavor, and too much breading), then I had the sesame soy glazed salmon in a bonito sake broth - ya, it's as good as it sounds. Go look up the pictures. My friend had the curry noodles with shrimp, also good from the bite I had, but we both agreed that mine was the winner, this one didn't have as many unique flavors-more standard. 

Both dinner portions were really good sized so we were glad we passed on a salad/light side and also passed on dessert so I can't comment. 

Customer service was very good as well. We ordered drinks but my friend drank a lot of water as well, and they were constantly over refilling it. 

Only downside is that the tables are super squished next to each other so you really don't have any privacy. I was like, "man I wasn't expecting to have dinner with 30 other people tonight!" Okay, it was quite that bad, but we both talked a lot quieter in hopes our conversation wasn't also a part of our neighbor's conversation :P
author: Mandi W.

description:
Came here to celebrate and heard good reviews about this place. 

Ambiance - the house is quite small...so the turnover rate CAN BE quick. 

Service - excellent! Our waitress was very sweet. She described the specials clearly and on point. 

Food - YUM!!! Everything we ordered was delicious! We got the seared scallops, soft shell crab with cold noodles that had a hint of spice in it, pork chops with pomegranate sauce and sea bass with green beans, noodles and ginger soy sauce and lemon pudding with fresh berries. Everything was good and juicy and flavorful! I'd Def come back for more! 

It definitely deserves the hype that everyone says. But again, you might have to wait for a table!
author: Hey Y.

description: This place takes the customers for fools and serve watered down wine...when confronted, the caliber of service quickly comes to a screeching halt and you are left there feeling uncomfortable doubting the decision you've made to come to this place. If there is a such a thing as zero star, this place wins it.
author: Jojo E.

description:
Don't even get me started -- my recent dinner at The House was arguably THE best meal I've ever had. Remember to make a reservation a few days prior because the restaurant is pretty small. I had to change my reservation from 8 to 8:30 the night of and the staff was gracious despite how busy it was so that was nice. When we arrived, we were seated right away. The place is loud and the seats are soclose to each other you can pretty much join your neighbors' conversations but regardless, the food was A+MAZING.

Per recommendation (and Yelp reviews), we started with salmon rolls, which were deep fried to perfection and came with this wasabi mustard sauce that had a unique kick to it. For entrees, I ordered the sea bass and my BF ordered the pork chop. Let's start with mine. I had to refrain myself from swallowing my sea bass whole just because it was so freaking delicious. The fish melted in your mouth and the garlic ginger sauce it came with was magical (confession: we dipped everything we could into it). I was pleasantly surprised by the pork chop because I was a bit hesitant about the pomegranate sauce but everything came together perfectly. The sauce wasn't too sweet and the pork chop via the words of my BF was "the best pork chop he's ever had." He was literally crying tears of joy with every bite. For dessert, we went with the coconut creme brulee. Again, a little unsure about it at first but man, were we wrong (again). Personally not a big fan of the passionfruit puree on top but the creme brulee itself was everything a dessert freak like me could've ever dreamed of. 

Overall, I've never eaten a meal so slowly just because I wanted to try and savor every bite. The House was everything I've hoped for and more on this trip to SF from LA and you know 110% I'll be coming back whenever I'm in the Bay Area. Hands down, the best $90 ever spent. Trust me -- if you haven't cried over food, you're missing out.
author: Shannon W.

description:
I'm usually not a huge fan of Asian fusion, but The House is the ultimate exception. We tried the Warm Wasabi House Noodles with Angus Flatiron Steak and the Miso Black Cod w/ an Avocado roll special. For both entrées, the presentation and combination of ingredients was so impressive and unique because you wouldn't expect it to work. I have to mention that the quality of the cod in specific was extremely fresh and tasty. I usually dislike eating the skin on fish, but the skin on this cod tasted amazing as well. 

Like others mentioned, the restaurant is small so I wouldn't risk not calling in for reservations ahead of time. I was able to get reservations on the same day for two. The only con about The House is parking. Parking is pretty difficult since they don't have valet or private parking. You have to pretty much either drive in circles for 20 minutes to find street parking or pay $10-20 at private parking lot that's within walking distance. Aside from this challenge, I would definitely recommend The House if you're ever in North Beach.
author: Caitlin M.

description:
The House is definitely one of my favorite restaurants in the City. Everytime I think about The House, I think about the delicious food (esp the seabass!) I had that night. I had made reservations one week in advance on a Monday night. We easily found street parking about two blocks away so I think we got really lucky that night. Plus, it was free after 6pm. :) When we arrived, we were seated immediately. The House is pretty small on the inside, so it's best not to come here in a big group. I actually think The House would be perfect for a date night! Anyways, we shared the following: 

Classic Fried Calamari - Started with the calamari as an appetizer. The calamari was not too heavy and it tasted pretty good. Nothing too special about it. 

Warm Wasabi House Noodles with Angus Flatiron Steak - I thought this dish was just alright.. I felt that I have had way better flatiron steak elsewhere and I did not really taste the wasabi in the noodles. I was pretty disappointed. :(

Black Cod with California Roll - Second best dish after the grilled seabass! This was one of the specials that was not listed on their menu. The black cod was soft and moist. It was pretty flavorful; however, I definitely liked the flavor in the seabass more than the black cod. I thought it was pretty interesting that it came with the California Roll. California Roll was just any other California Roll except bigger. 

Grilled Seabass with Garlic Ginger Soy - AMAZINGLY DELICIOUS!!!! We had ordered the seabass with mashed potatoes. The seabass was grilled perfectly. It was so soft, moist, and buttery. Each bite melted in my mouth. This dish was definitely my favorite of the night. Everything about this dish was just perfect!

Chocolate Truffle Cake with Coffee Ice Cream - YUMMY! Perfect way to end the meal. The dessert was chocolately and rich. It was not too sweet. The coffee ice cream complemented the truffle cake just perfectly!

Overall, service was good that night and I had a really delicious and tasty dinner. Thus, the reason why I gave them five stars. I would definitely recommend The House to others. :)
author: Philana C.

description: Amazing food each and every time we come. Photos don't do their food justice. You must come in and experience their food. Fresh, wonderful flavor combinations, every bite with every dish is just amazing!I know I keep using that word, amazing, but it is just...well, AMAZING!  Best darn food in the city!
author: Julie G.

description: Tiny restaurant so definitely make a reservation. I liked that the menu was simple and that there were specials for the day. Ordered the deep fried salmon roll and scallops (special) as appetizers and loved it. The Sea Bass is cooked perfectly and there's also a light charred taste to it. The boyfriend ordered wasabi noodles with Angus Beef and it also came out fantastically.  The portions were a good size and we were very full by the end of our meal. This place is awesome- definitely must try.
author: Grace L.

description:
I can't believe I haven't tried this place before!  I came here for a date not too long ago and was blown away by the food quality.  When we arrived, I was a bit bummed that they had already given away our table after a short ten minute delay.  I'm glad we decided to wait, because the food was to die for.  We had four dishes in total.  

Caesar Sald with Crispy Scallops:  A
Their caesar dressing is really something else.  It has a nice tart flavor to it, and isn't too creamy.  The scallops are fried, and were a nice golden brown served right out of the frier.  They just melted in your mouth with a rich seafood flavor.

Deep-fried chicken liver with baby greens:  A
I thought the crispy scallop salad was good, but this was another level.  The chicken liver was fried as well, and had the perfect consistency and richness with every bite.  It was tossed in a vinagrette dressing that really let the creaminess of the chicken liver shine.

Warm wasabi house noodles with angus flatiron steak:  A
Cooked to a perfect medium rare, the flatiron had the perfect texture.  Flatiron is not known to be a soft cut of beef, but is instead known for its very beefy flavor.  Even though it was a little rough, it exceeded my expectations for a flatiron.  The wasabi noodles were simply delicious.  They were udon style and pan fried with a wasabi sauce.

Grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy:  A+
The sea bass was grilled and was also served over a bed of noodles in a sweet soy sauce.  The sea bass was cooked perfectly, and juices melted out of it when I first cut it.  It was right at the point where it was almost rare, so it was not dry at all.  I was very impressed that it wasn't mushy, but actually had some give to the texture.

Overall, a great place.  I can see why this place was so full even on a weeknight.  Please come try this place!  I will continue recommending it to my friends.  They don't have to many covers, so be sure to make reservations.

PROTIP:  They have a great wine list that can easily be paired with many menu items.
author: David C.

description:
3.5 solid stars

I've been wanting to try this place for a long time, ever since they first opened! I finally had the pleasure dining here.

Service: 3.5/5
Food: 3/5
Ambiance: 3/5

Bottom line: Order their fish--that's their specialty. All the other dishes were just mediocre. 

Ordered: Generous portion-sized
Fried salmon: 3/5
Ribs: 3.5/5
Black cod: 5/5
Sea bass: 5/5
Pork chop: 3/5
Wasabi steak noodle: 4/5

Yes, make reservations if you don't want to wait. Very small venue--probably seats about 45-55ppl max.
author: Jen H.

description:
Really good food for a pretty reasonable price.  
- Scallops (4.5/5) - well cooked, with a great sauce
- BBQ oysters (4/5) - these oysters were absolutely massive, and they were really good, but not remarkable
- Pork chop (4.5/5) - absolutely delicious, one of the best pork chops I've ever had
author: Simon L.

description:
Came here a few months ago and it was amazing!!! My boyfriend and I ordered their deep fried salmon rolls, the flatiron steak with wasabi noodles, and their sea bass with garlic noodles.

The salmon rolls were divine, it just melts in your mouth. Its the perfect portion and balance; its not heavy nor oily. The flatiron steak was good, but the wasabi noodles were amazing; very different. My boyfriend also really enjoyed his sea bass, but he wished his garlic noodles were wasabi noodles instead. 

The restaurant itself is really small and cramped, so there's not much privacy between patrons. It is also recommended to make reservations since they can only accommodate so little people at a time. Service was pretty good; can't complain.
author: Samantha C.

description: If you aren't already convinced by the other 3k reviews to give this place a shot then...I'm not expecting to perform any miracles with my review. This place gets enough business as it is and I definitely see why! My recent visit was enjoyable and I left in good spirits. My food tasted as delicious as it looked, the portion size was perfect, and the prices reasonable. I'd advise going for lunch and making reservations in advance (full disclosure, we were late and there was a line...but the hostess was gracious and understanding). The customer service we experienced during dining also did not suffer even though it was a packed house and there were only 2-3 waiters working. Overall, this place is small and is in a gps-unfriendly location but certainly worth making the trek out to try.
author: Katherine N.

description:
This place is awesome!! I was in San Francisco this past weekend and The House was recommended by a friend.  My bf and I went for dinner Friday night and wow, the meal was amazing! We had a reservation so we didn't wait and got seated right away.  The lady who seated us was a little unfriendly but our waitress was terrific!  

We sat down and looked over the menu and everything sounded fabulous but we settled on:

-Softshell crab tempura:  This was one of the special starters not on the regular menu. It was served with some  sweet chili noodles that had a bit of kick to it. The softshell crab was not overfried, it was perfect.

-Seared scallops with some citrus ponzu sauce:  Another special starter not on the menu. Seared just the way I like it! The sauce complemented the flavor of the scallops really well. 

-Wasabi noodles with steak: I ordered this based on all of the great reviews.  I'm so glad I went with this!! The noodles had so much flavor without it being too salty. I ordered the steak medium rare and it was more on the rare side, which is exactly the way I prefer my steaks.  

-Kobe beef with black truffle sauce: My boyfriend ordered this which h was one of the special entrees that night. He loved and ate every single bite. Like my steak, he ordered his medium rare and it came just the way he likes his steaks. 

Yes, we did order like fatties but no regrets.  We loved everything we tried and the whole dining experience was great. I'll definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for a good meal in SF!
author: Miko S.

description: Amazing food. Only had to wait 20 minutes for a table. Can't go wrong with anything on the menu. I had the tuna and my gf had the sea bass. We also had the soft shell crab and unagi small plates. The unagi was the best.
author: Charles H.

description:
This place was overrated for me. I was very excited to try it, but after the dishes, I was a bit disappointed. 

I started off with the White Shrimp Tempura Appetizer. This I liked. It came with a mountain of tender greens and a light tangy sauce with avocado and thin apple slices on the bottom. It was quite delicate and nice. Expectations up.

I ordered the grilled salmon on a bed of bok choy in a bonito sake broth, topped with a thin slice of daikon and a side of rice. The salmon was a bit overcooked- it wasn't dry, but it was very firm and heading there. The daikon was just hard and chewy, but at least the broth was good. 

My friend had the sea bass and it was overcooked. It was dry, but the sauce was a nice complement to the sea bass.

My other friend had the roasted chicken, which she liked until she got to the wing/drumstick portion and found pink pieces and stopped eating it.

All in all, we left silently and didn't ask how we liked the meal and instead, trekked to find ice cream, hoping it would save us.
author: Emily C.

description:
Great food, great service, the only thing was the actual physical location was very small and packed, paying this kind of prices for that kind of ambiance felt a little off.

Wasabi noodles hit the spot, a lot of flavor...the crab cakes appetizer was also amazing, especially with the wasabi flavors infused in it.  Dumplings were good, the food here is spot on!!
author: Alvin H.

description: Didn't realize I have not reviewed this place.  This has been one of my favorite restaurants in the city since I moved here in 2012.  Food is always amazing and you know what you're getting every time. Love the Scallops, Seabass, and ribeye.
author: Jay H.

description:
This place is a diamond in the rough.  Ah, yes the Broadway scene.  The restaurant is very close to the bars and strip clubs.  Next door had an interesting costume shop.  This area has a lot of tourists and night owls.  Therefore, parking can be a nightmare sometimes.  I've been here for both lunch and dinner and this place is always packed.  MAKE RESERVATIONS!!!

My favorite appetizer was the deep fried salmon roll, which had a delicious wasabi dipping sauce.  I love The House because their fish is amazing.  This is coming from a person who normally don't like fish.  I've tried the Sea Bass, Black Cod, and Halibut (yummiest, yummier, and yum).  I really like the Sea Bass dish because it comes with a choice of rice or noodles and green beans.  I always order the wasabi noodles with it!

This place is jam packed, but the waiters are always attentive.
author: Lynn L.

description:
Asian fusion in the a gorgeous and delicious form.

We had a huge party of people and this small, intimate location accommodated us. The wine was flowing, delicious Riesling, and the glorious, tasty food was getting passed around.  We went ahead and ordered various plates and just shared.  

The staff gets huge props for dealing with a large group and keeping our glasses full and taking various orders and being so lovely about it. 

The most memorable dish, the flaky, deliciously, light Sea Bass. WOW! It literally melted in my mouth and the teriyaki type sauce was a perfect match. The green beans and mashed potatoes were a great addition. The scallops were glorious in all their flavor and texture. The shrimp and orzo pasta dish, I literally wanted to lick the bowl clean, it was so savory. The desserts, WOW! I was so full from all the amazing dishes that I didn't think I had room until I laid eyes on the flan and chocolate deliciousness that was placed in front of me. Do NOT skip dessert! Save room!
author: Colleen B.

description:
My husband who lives in SF in the past has been talking about this place since we met; I finally got to try it. Amazing!
We had reservations at 5:00 (right when they opened). The place was packed in minutes. Service was polite and helpful. Food just so good. 
The scallops were cooked amazingly. The cod fish came with a sushi roll on top that was creamy and delicious. Warm kale salad was so good and the dumplings were great. I wish we can stay in SF more to try all the menu. The end was with delicious coconut creme Brûlée. Yummy!
author: Hana S.

description: Went there last week for the first time. The service was excellent and the food came so fast. Like most of the people posted here, I tried the salmon rolls, wasabi steak noodle and their famous grilled sea bass. I love all of them; however, I feel that the wasabi taste was a little bit too strong in the noodle. But overall it's great! Would definitely come again and try more foods.
author: Alicia A.

description: Situated in Chinatown....loved the wasabi noodles... reservations is a must... best time is for lunch to avoid the crowd
author: JAN I.

description:
Not sure how I never discovered this place before, but wow is pretty much the summary: 

Quick hits: 
Asian Fusion
Small Place
Black Cod
Flat Iron Steak
Long Waits
Get Your Reservation On
Greatness.
author: Andrew C.

description:
My wife and I had a very nice dinner last night at The House. We started with green bean tempura and the barbeque oysters, both very good. We had the special cod entree and steak on warm soba noodles. Again, both terrific. Desert was panecotta with strawberries and apple crumb cake- very good as well.

Great dinner, very good food. If it was local to our restaurant wasteland in Ventura County, we'd come back regularly. 

BUT, it's in San Francisco, where there are so many great "knock your socks off" choices and very good isn't good enough to put up with no parking, the (typical SF) tables right on top of each other, the high noise level and busy distracted wait staff.

Did we enjoy the food?- unequivocally yes. Would we come back- unequivocally no. Not in San Francisco. Too many places to have food this caliber or better where they valet park and you can actually have a conversation over dinner.
author: Fred M.

description:
We had a spectacular meal and exceptional service.  This owner run restaurant did not disappoint.  The food was absolutely amazing!  Fresh, clean, seasonal and delicious.  Those in our party had the wasabi noodles, chicken, sea bass and a special of marinated cod.  Everything was exquisite! 
The desserts were so scrumptious!  We had their special persimmon pudding which was light and delicious.  
Some helpful hints to patrons, make reservations and if you can't try to go anyway it's definitely worth the wait.
The only draw back was the location and difficulty finding parking.

Thanks Angela for making us feel so welcome!  Cheers to your success and wishing you continued blessings to you and yours in the New Year!
author: Lori T.

description: All of the dishes here is to die for! Everything is so good. The clams, mussels, scallops, pork chips and Lambs. Delicious! I will definitely coming back soon!
author: Stephanie N.

description: We got their Poke, Wasabi noodles, shiitake  Truffle soup, mushroom rice with prawns, and the salmon roll. The poke was pretty good, not as flavorful as I'm used to from cheaper places that include ponzu sauce or wasabi. The wasabi noodles were the best thing we had. They claimed they were spicy, but they were not too hot at all. I really enjoyed the shiitake soup, the truffle oil added a nice kick. The mushroom rice prawns were also a hit--very creamy risotto-like rice. The salmon rolls were pretty good, they're cooked, so don't order them if you're expecting sushi. The service was prompt, but they messed up in our check a few times and they wanted to charge us for extra pickles.
author: Kevin C.

description:
While you might be tempted by the flatiron steak (if only because you want to try the wasabi house noodles) or even the teriyaki ribeye, don't do it. This is not to say that these dishes aren't delectable, but fish is the move at The House. 

I opted for the (masterfully cooked medium rare) ribeye myself, and after asking for a bit if the lusciously thick homemade teriyaki sauce on the side, I was quite pleased. However, after trying all sorts of other options from around the table, I feel confident reporting that the sea is where their menu shines.

The Caesar salad was solid, the dumplings were whatever; the garlic noodles and the wasabi noodles were both worth re-visiting. However...

The deep-fried salmon roll was ridiculously good. The tuna was beautiful. The sea bass was perfect. The crab pasta was Wal-Mart heir rich, and I fucking loved it. 

Go to The House, go seafood, and don't look back.
author: Peter D.

description:
My friend suggested this place as we drove to SF from Berkeley for a day trip. A native from Hong Kong, I have always been a huge skeptic of Asian fusion food, of what I believe to be "overpriced, nonauthentic Asian cuisine". This place defies the stereotype.

We were worried that we won't get a table since we did not make a reservation and the place is small. Luckily, we came at an earlier time and snagged a table right away. The placed filled up as we paid our bill.

I followed my friends' suggestions as we ordered the items below:

Deep Fried Salmon Roll: Yum! Crispy on the outside and deliciously moist inside. It is generously sized for a starter. The sauce that came with it was tasty, but too spicy for the Cantonese me.

Wasabi House Noodles: I am not a huge fan of wasabi and still enjoyed this dish.

Sea Bass: Deliciously flaky and flavourful. The string beans that came with it was also well-cooked and a good accompaniment.

Pork Chop: Delicious! The pork chip was thick and tender. Had many let-downs with pork chop dishes at other places and this place cooks it really well.

Apple Pie: Average. Would not order this again.

The only negative I can think about this place is its high price, few tables that can easily get crowded at night, and relatively slow service as there seems to be a low number of waiter to customers ratio. Come and enjoy!
author: Genny C.

description: I absolutely love The House. Been here a few times now and they do not disappoint. The sea bass with the garlic noodles is my favorite. The ahi tuna is a must try as well!
author: Hovik A.

description:
This place never disappoint. My mouth is watering thinking about the food i had!! I tried this place two years ago and i'm still rave about this place!!

We ordered:

Appetizer: softshell crab and salmon roll
Main course: Halibut and Pork chop

The soft-shell crab is deep fried and flavorful with noodles on side. It's delicious but it wasn't memorable. On the other hand the salmon roll is a MUST TRY with crispy egg roll skin wrapped with juicy tender salmon in the middle. I can have 10 rolls myself (maybe a bit exaggerating) 

The Halibut was grilled to perfection! The well grilled fish is sitting on top of the mashed potato which is flavored with some asian green union, the sources is creamy/buttery with corn in it. On top of the halibut there is this finely chopped carrots strips which was deep-fried. This plate has the texture, the sources (flavor), and the color altogether. My friend who usually complains about food has nothing negative to say about this dish. Hands down!! 

The pork chop dish did not disappoint as well, flavor is good, plating is pretty and the texture is in the dish as well, but i think you get this idea.

I'll definitely come back for more. Oh one last note, remember to make reservation or else expect an hour wait for sure.
author: Jumy C.

description:
Crap...where has this place been the past however long that the house has been open???  

All the searches on yelp...and the restaurants we've been to...the house has never showed up on the search page...until about a week ago when I was searching for a bday venue for my mom.  I can't remember what I searched for...something along the lines of seafood, rice, and prime rib.  Anyhoo, I'm glad the house finally showed up!

I made reservations immediately for lunch...parking sucks around here but who cares???  Wait til you try the food!  Haha.  

We started off with a special...hamachi appetizer.  The fish was super fresh and buttery...the avocado and seaweed with the sauce just made it the perfect starter.  

Wifey ordered the curry noodles with chicken...yum!!!  Reminded me of pepper lunch in milpitas...but the chicken was cooked absolutely perfect...the right amount of seasoning...and a heaping plate of noodles.  Super addicting.  

And then my dish...the winner winner.  I had the wasabi noodles and pork.  The server told me the pork is cooked medium.  I heard my mom's voice in my head saying that you have to cook the crap out of pork in order to prevent any foodborne illness...I wasn't about to say no to the recommendation of the chef.  I said sure, why not?  

That had to be some of the best pork I have EVER had...it was juicy...seasoned well...gosh I'm salivating just thinking about it.  The noodles weren't overpowering with the wasabi...it was done so well that it just accented the dish. So freakin good!!!  

And then dessert...we ordered the coconut creme brûlée with passion fruit...the first bite was like a huge palate explosion.  Really good stuff.  

The service was fantastic...she had personality and was right on point.  I think they mostly get shirts and ties that frequent the restaurant...and also foreigners?  I tried to crack a joke when she asked how our dessert was.  I said it was disgusting...even though it was obvious that I licked the plate.  Haha.  Her face dropped for a moment and she looked really confused...wondering how I could say such a thing when there wasn't a drop left on the dish.  I had to hurry up and say I was just kidding!  She was great though...definitely knew what she was doing and how to take care of the guests.  Awesomeness!  oh, and the prices were extremely reasonable!

5 stars...one of my new fave restaurants...can't wait to come back again and try out dinner this time!
author: Jen W.

description: I love the sea bass! It is one of the best sea bass I have ever had. The place isn't too big and it fills up very quickly. If you don't have a reservation, then I suggest coming a little before they open. If you're in the city, this place is definitely worth a try!
author: Cynthia J.

description: The food was great but I'm deducting one star because of the service. Our server seemed too busy to listen to our orders carefully...
author: Jae P.

description:
Pretty good. I loved the pork in pomegranate and the flat iron steak on wasabi noodles good. I was surprised that the seabass had a strong fishy taste but the sauce was really good so when I ate it together it overpowered the fishiness. 
This place was good but not great and I didn't really care for the ambiance. The waitress had no humor.  She was very informative but not memorable. She didn't even ask us for our beverage. As we walked in we didn't feel welcome.  t think for price and location. They definitely need a waitress with an outgoing personality and if the ambiance isn't great atleast the food should exceed our expectations which it didn't.  Won't be coming back!
author: Deepika S.

description:
Absolutely delicious! This place is a hole in the wall, but their menu makes it hard to pick from because of all the great choices. The food is special. They use the same ingredients you will find at most Japanese restaurants, but with a twist. 

Must try! Add to your bucket list!
author: Abed A.

description:
Great meal: the Kobe beef ribeye with truffle sauce deep fried salmon egg rolls were perfect! 

I would highly recommend The House to EVERYBODY!

The House, please tell your story on r3lish: https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/relish-bite-sized-video-stories/id844759887?mt=8

This is where I would want to hear from you.
author: Wayne W.

description:
I was afraid The House would not live up to the hype, but after eating here this past weekend, I'm with the rest of the 2000+ reviewers that gave this place 4 or 5 stars. Despite its popularity, we were able to easily get a lunch reservation for 4 on a Saturday at 12:30. Parking in the area is extremely difficult to find, so I'd recommend planning to arrive a good 20-30 minutes before your reservation.

APPETIZERS
- Deep-fried Salmon Roll: As one of the most popular starters here, this one did not disappoint. Warning: The wasabi dipping sauce is really spicy, so dip at your own risk!
- Ahi Tuna: This was one of their specials and not on the menu. The portion size was kind of small, and it was probably more aesthetically than gustatorily pleasing, but delightful nonetheless.

MAIN ENTREES
- Wasabi Noodles: This one didn't contain as much wasabi flavor as I envisioned, which is a good thing. It's actually so discreet that even a child could enjoy. I'd recommend this dish because it's not only delicious but also very unique.
- Curry Noodles: Though not as popular as its wasabi counterpart, I think the curry noodles are slightly better. Plus it comes with corn!
- Swordfish in coconut milk curry sauce: This was also one of their specials not on the menu. I think the presentation of this dish also wows more than the taste. Overall it was still a great dish, but it doesn't live up to the others.
- Grilled Sea Bass: The hype for this dish is right-on. This entree looks the plainest, but it's definitely the stand-out one in terms of flavor. Maybe I'm biased because sea bass is my absolute favorite type of fish, but this was so good that it might even be a candidate for my last meal on Earth. :)

I will have to make one complaint, although it's not big enough of a deal to take a star away from my rating. For a restaurant with a continuous flow of customers coming in and out, a lot of their ceramic plates are chipped and extremely dirty (with grey/black marks from excessive use over the years). They're noticeably dirty enough for my friends and I to all look at one another with raised eyebrows as the waiter set them down in front of us.

Regardless, I'm very pleased with my experience at The House. Since I found both of the special non-menu items that we ordered to be subpar to the others, my recommendation would be to stick to the regular menu items and to TRY THE GRILLED SEA BASS!
author: Celia K.

description: The house is awesome! Never get disappointed in this place. The food is fantastic. We usually come here for dinner, but my fs me came herr on their lunch hours , not too crowded and the price is reasonable!
author: Mark A.

description:
I ate so much that I barfed that night.
Does that make you want to go or avoid it? My bad.

We came early hoping to sit at the bar, but there was no bar. The waiter/host looks overwhelmed. I get the feeling he was used to dealing with assholes because he was preemptively asshole-y to start. The place is TEENY-TINY. Like the size of a studio apartment so prepare yourself for that claustrophobia. Also, because it's so tiny, anytime someone walks in to their non-existent entrance, the entire place gets the night cold air thrown in their face. It sounds like I'm complaining, right? Ugh, I want to but the food is so good, I cannot decrease their rating.

There was a couple that's been waiting for 2.5 hours because she was dumb and didn't make reservations - and stayed for the 2.5 hours! Now I know why.

This is amazing Asian fusion on the verge of Michelin worthy. To top it off, I got out of there for like $50 with my own appetizer and entrée and sharing a dessert. The portions are huge. If you are hungry, don't over-order *ahem* and barf afterwards. Calm the eff down and take it slow. All portions are meant to be shared. And for that price, I consider this place 'cheap'. 

Crab cakes + Seared Ahi Tuna + Coconut Crème Brulee made my heart sing. 

Please be forewarned that you are in between a dive bar that reeks of weed + skank lingerie shop + strip club. Yeah, it's that kind of area.

ENJOY.
author: Tania P.

description:
You'll be surprised at how small this restaurant is.
It's got very cozy ambiance that suits its name just right.
All of the food we ordered (tuna tartare, salmon rolls, wasabi noodles w/ flat skirt iron, and grilled seabass) were delicious. I especially had the best seabass here. The taste of every dishes we had were not of just ordinary taste you can easily predict. Definitely one of the BEST restaurants in SF!
author: Hyemin J.

description:
Nice little restaurant with outstanding food. Only wish the place was more spacious so I could get in and out of my chair without smacking the next patron with my purse. 

We had raw oysters and salmon rolls for appetizer. Raw oysters from hog island were good, as always. Salmon rolls could pass. My entree- wasabi noodles with flat iron steak medium rare- was delicious!
