Pork Chops - 5/5 Sooo good (I don't usually eat pork.)

Pretty small space, around 30 seatings? 

Good date location. 

Good service.
author: Yen N.

description:
I don't understand why this place has a such high ratings, unfortunately, my experience was just not so so great. Service was attentive and they gave me a dessert under house for my birthday, that's the best part. The Thai tea penna cotta that they gave me was absolutely delicious. On to the food, I was disappointed. From the appetizers to the entrees were just medicore. The pork chop that I always want to try and I heard how well it was prepared from my friends was so bland, lacked enough seasoning, may be they did not marinate the pork chop enough before they cook, the sause was too sour I think. My husband ordered the Angus Rib Eye steak was so bland either and lacked of sauce. Both entrees had too little sauce.
I will give this place a second chance when I am free.
author: Edwin Q.

description: Could not be more excited to be here. Second time here and again everything was delish! There is nothing I would improve. Soooo good! Loved the dumplings, loved the pork chop, loved the sea bass. Can't wait to try more!!
author: Karen V.

description:
Suchhhhh a delicious dinner!  We went without reservations on a Saturday night  and we well aware of the long wait that we were going to have to endure, so we put our name down and went down the street to King of Thai for some drinks and sports in the meantime.  It ended up being around 2 hours, so if you call and there is an available reservation at 10 PM, take it since you will likely wait that long anyway! 

That being said, the food and service was incredible!  Very friendly and efficient even though we were clearly there at the end of a very long rainy night.  We ordered the salmon rolls (holy amazing-I could eat them with every meal!).  For the entrees, we ordered the Sea Bass and the Wasabi Noodle Steak.  The fist was cooked to perfection and the noodles were perfect.  I opted to get rice as a side for the Sea Bass but will 100% be getting noodles in the future.  So so good!
author: Raina D.

description: The food is satisfying and I usually enjoy my meal here. I will say that every time I come here, I always feel a bit rushed to finish and leave. The space is very small, so if you plan to come with a bigger party be prepared to squeeze in. Because of this, i generally don't plan to come here with more than four. As a party of five, we were squeezed into a table clearly only meant for 4. The person who sat at the "head" of the table was constantly scooting in and out to let people pass behind him, which is fairly unpleasant when you're trying to relax and enjoy dinner.  I get there are a lot of people waiting but for five people I think 3 two-tops instead of 2 two-tops is much more reasonable if the fifth person can't sit at the end of the table comfortably with enough space behind him.
author: whatever I.

description:
This place lived up to the hype. I got a reservation 2 days in advance, was seated right away and service was great. Had a nice red wine (can't recall the vineyard) along with the salmon rolls to start with. That mustard is to die for!

Flank steak and wasabi noodles were a home run and prices were very reasonable considering this is the most unreasonable city in the country. 

Hope I get to come back sometime. Highly recommend.
author: Eric S.

description: I took off a star for the lack of decor. For the pricing I wish it was a little nicer in here. However the miso black cod was unbelievable. I think I could eat it for the rest of my life. Such amazing flavor and so fresh! The seared tuna dinner was delicious as well!
author: Michelle G.

description:
The fish dishes are definitley the best. I got the Wasabi Noodles with Pork. Should've gone with Salmon on my noodles. Everyone here is right, Sea Bass; it looks simple but taste fantastico. And those Salmon Rolls with Chinese Mustard are divine! 

Customers kept leaving the door open after exiting the restaurant, so I had to keep getting up to close the door; can't let the ladies freeze now can we?!?!? Especially with one being sick. 

~ Not born on a farm.
author: Ken L.

description:
Very impressive for Asian Fusion. 

Deep fried salmon roll - Amazing. Crunchy outside and the salmon is cooked to perfection, getting a bit more raw as you reach the center. 10/10
Steamed mussels with garlic infused shrimp broth - First impression: wow, all the mussels that I had before this were...wrong. Definitely the best mussels I have ever had. The broth is amaze. 9/10
Unagi Roll - 7/10
Kobe Steak - Came out less cooked than we expected. 8/10

The customer service was... decent. We felt a bit uncomfortable asking questions even though we were confused about the specials--which customers should never feel. It was my friend's first time ordering steak at a fancy restaurant and the waiter wasn't super kind or trying to help her out with how cooked she wanted it. It was also pretty difficult to get our waiter's attention. 

Overall, would def come back just for that salmon roll though.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
Dinner at The House was delicious!!! Came here for my mom's birthday, so it was a chance to sample a lot of the dishes. I made reservations the day of, but it's easier to get a table and time that you want if you call to reserve days ahead, since it is a small place.

For starters, we had the scallops, which is a special there, steamed mussels, and deep fried salmon rolls. The scallops were beautifully seared, with a lemon ponzu sauce. The mussels had a yummy broth, but the mussels were kind of small. I don't eat fish, but my family enjoyed the salmon rolls. 

For the entrees, I had the wasabi noodles with flank steak and there was just a hint of wasabi that did not over power the whole dish. My family got the sea bass, pork chop, and ribeye steak. The pork chop was so juicy and tasted great with the pomegranate sauce, the seasoning for the ribeye was soo good, the sea bass was a hit for my fam. All the entrees were pretty generous in size. 

For desserts, I got to try coconut creme brulee and the chocolate truffle cake with coffee ice cream. They both tasted great. I couldn't taste the coconut in the creme brulee, but I tasted the passion fruit and the sugar on the top was the best part for me. The truffle cake definitely had the chocolate taste to it and I loved the coffee ice cream, who doesn't love ice cream. 

I had a great dinner here and it is definitely worth the price for the food and service.
author: Susie N.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here on a whim one night.  We decided that we wanted something good for dinner and we drove from our office in Cupertino to SF for The House.  The wait was about half an hour, which wasnt too bad. We ordered the special of the day appetizer, which was ribs and the baby octopus salad. The ribs were a bit tough, but the flavor was okay. The salad was pretty good. For dinner, the boyfriend ordered the steak over the wasabi noodles.  It was different, and not what I expected.  I ordered the pork chop, and it was DELICIOUS.  We both agreed that if we come back, we will both order the pork chop. 
Overall, a good dinner.  Service was good too.  The minus one star is for the appetizers just being so-so.
author: Kristin K.

description:
This is a nice spot.  I came with a relatively large party for the space, and we tried quite a few of the items on the menu.

My favorites:
- Mussels in curry.  Fresh, plump, cooked well.
- Octopus salad.  Light balance of flavors, with a nice crunch component.
- Black cod.  Cooked well, though I thought it was a little funny that there was a California roll on top.
- Mango tapioca pudding.  This was excellent; thick, smooth, creamy and not too sweet.

The other party hits were the pork chop and crab cake.  I was not as big a fan of the steak with wasabi noodles - for me, the noodles didn't have much flavor. 

All in all, a fun place for dinner.
author: Connie T.

description:
So so so crowded! Which means everyone is trying to get the great food they offer.

This place definitely didn't disappoint. We got the salmon, and the mussels for our appetizers. Both were tasty and my friends loved the wasabi sauce that the salmon came with. 

We then go the sea bass and the scallops for our entrees which were both a-mazing. The sea bass was seasoned very well and had the melt in your mouth goodness. The garlic noodles it came with were sinfully tasty, as well as the green beans. The scallops were on point...and the bed of rice it came with was D-lish! 

Definitely go here. Make sure you make reservations because I don't think there were any more slots available when we got there that night. So give this place a try! You will not be disappointed!
author: Maria M.

description:
I have had several dining experience here, most have been excellent.  But last night I had the worst experience ever, the oysters came and had an awful fishy smell which indicated that it might have expired.   The waiter took it back and told me he too had smell it and will give me another order. 

But when I get the supposedly new order, I noticed there are no fishy smell. But there are also no smell of any other sort, and it tasted blended with no oyster not any other taste. 

Then my order of the special of Kobe style beef short rib, the presentation is nice as always.  But I noticed that it was very difficult to cut and I could not chew the meat, and had to spit out what I could chew.  This goes for the whole order, so I end up with a pile of it on the side of my plate.  

I suspect that they have running water over the original order of the oyster they took back, and even as I have told the waitress that the beef was not chewable. She did not suggest anything, instead she walked away without even an apology.  

This will be my last patronage of this restaurant, and wish you all the best of luck.
author: DAVID T.

description: So I was blown away by this place...soft shell crab was amazing and is the best ive had on the west coast. I had the Salmon noodle and it was really good!!! The rose here was amazing as well!!! Would come back here!!!
author: John A.

description:
I have been here 3 times since 2007 and it just as I remember every single time - consistency counts!!

I love the intimate ambience and the food is always delicious

Salmon Roll - MUST TRY. I love how it's still raw in the very center and there is SO much salmon. I've never had anything like it, it's so buttery

Sea Bass - I've gotten this all 3 times and it is just as good every time. THICK piece of fish so perfectly cooked. Delicious udon noodles (my fav!) and green beans!

This last trip we also tried 2 off menu specials

Scallop appetizer - very well cooked, nothing unique about it but very tasty
Mahi Mahi w. curry sauce - also amazingly well cooked with a really tasty curry

All of the dishes are super reasonably priced. My only small complaint is that because of the small venue and busy crowd you can't have a super leisurely meal, but we still had our taste buds rocked. Love this place and will try to visit every time I'm in SF!
author: Jessica N.

description:
This place blew me away. 

The atmosphere is very cozy, and I highly recommend making reservations in advance. If I could give 4.5 stars, I would, and it's the forced intimacy that would dock my rating the half-star. Hope for good table neighbors. That's all. 

Prices are reasonable, especially for a fantastic meal in the city. 

Attire ranged from super casual to very dressy. Anything goes. 

Staff were friendly, helpful, and prompt. 

The food is delicious. It is Asian fusion, but the menu doesn't require you to be an adventurous diner to enjoy it and find plenty of things to try. 

It is hard to describe a truly amazing meal, because what makes it amazing is the feeling you are left with at the end. I left satisfied, yet eager to go back for more. 

And after writing this review, thinking about that meal, now I'm hungry.
author: Stephanie J.

description: Whenever I'm in the city this is one of my go to restaurants. In the past I have always had to make reservations at least a week in advance to get a table and i'm never disappointed. Recently a group of six came around 8:45 and we were able to get a table within 20 minutes. I have eaten almost everything on the menu and I've never eaten anything I didn't like. My favorite is the Sea Bass.
author: Jared R.

description: This restaurant was recommended to me by multiple friends so it was a must try before I left SF. The restaurant itself is very small but the food is delicious. There was already a line outside and we got there a little early to try to beat the rush at 5:30. Everything we ate was good and the service was on point. I'm sure the menu is seasonal so I would like to come back and taste more of their offerings. The seabass and garlic noodles is a must, the kobe short ribs with truffle reduction was delicious, and the mushroom soup was so good I almost licked my bowl clean. A+
author: Hieu T.

description:
Came here for lunch the other day. 

Shared the deep fried salmon roll, the wasabi noodles with pork, and the udon soup with my boyfriend. 

I thought all the food was good, but nothing spectacular. It was good in a sense that it was nothing I expected. The dipping sauce with the salmon roll was super strong and burned your nose from the horseradish but nonetheless tasty. The wasabi noodles were good, but maybe we should have gotten the steak instead. The udon was also good, but the broth was a bit bland and oily. 

I expected a lot more from reading other reviews, but it was okay. This place deserves more than 3 stars just because it's creative.
author: Kelly T.

description: AMAZINGLY GOOD to say the least. So hidden that we passed it twice looking for it - walking!  We came around lunch time and there was less than a five min wait. I'm not a fan of a lot of curry, but I'm always willing to try everything. The curry noodles with grilled chicken was simply mouth-watering. So good that I truly needed a bib; it splashed all over my shirt, but I wasn't going to let it hinder my taste bud's high. OH. SO. GOOD!!
author: Linda D.

description:
Food and service is great!!!!! We had the today's special appetizer clams on miso spicy broth and regular menu- deep fried salmon roll were awesome.
Dinner: flank steak with wasabi noodles, shrimp with risotto and short ribs with mashed potatoes. TASTY !!! Desserts were all good!!!!
Commendedvery friendly ....
But you need to make reservation to get in.
author: Tita M.

description:
I have been here a few times by now, and I have had the following things: kurobuta pork chop, grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy, warm wasabi house noodles with angus flatiron steak, as well as a variety of appetizers. Without exception, everything I have ever had from The House has been delicious, and I would recommend them all (perhaps the kurbota pork chop a smidgen more than the others, only because I am a gigantic pork lover).

My biggest and most fervent recommendation though--and the reason I come back to The House so often--is the chocolate cake. Jesus Christ. I could sing hymns about this cake. It is SO GOOD! If you like dense, rich, delicious chocolate cakes even half as much as I do, you will thank me once you order this. In fact, I'm thinking about it right now, and will therefore probably be at The House tonight. You're welcome.
author: Clarisse V.

description:
What can I say that the previous 3200 reviewers haven't already? 

I'll keep it simple: the food is amazing, every dish we tried tasted great. 

Our strategy: We ordered a single entree and maybe 4 appetizers, a lot of food for two people but we didn't leave a single bite behind.

We went on a Sunday night and presumably it was easier to get reservations.

Note that they don't serve any cocktails so you're limited to beer / wine, but thats not a deal breaker.
author: Farid H.

description:
Wow, I really like this place We came when they opened for their dinner service you have to make a reservation or come quickly they filled up the instant they opened the door The food is amazing we like everything we got except for the oysters we thought  they were going to be baked , they actually took them back and took them off the check so they get a star for that
We ordered some type of shrimp risotto ,octopus salad and the steak wasabi noodles 

The reason I deducted one star is because we actually called to make a reservation they told us we did not need to because they didn't open till 530 for dinner then we got there the lady told us we needed a reservation But she would go ahead and seat us but we would have to eat quickly in less than hour because they have too many reservations I thought that was super tacky we were only there for about 45 minutes the food came out  super fast .
author: Alice B.

description:
Tried all their popular dishes.  Wasabi noodles, sea bass, and salmon roll.

This place is TINY! Not for the claustrophobic.  Reservations are in-house only.  They  try their best to keep to it, but if people don't leave, you will be waiting beyond your scheduled time.

I would  come back and get to go order of the salmon rolls.  My favorite!!!
author: David W.

description:
I dream about this place sometimes. 
 It's a little crammed and if you have a large table you're rushed for time, but the food is soo good! Every time I come back to SF, I always make it a priority to eat here. The pomegranate pork chop is so delicious! And for a three dollar sign restaurant, it's not even THAT pricey. 

Parking is difficult. There's a wait, but they take reservations. In my experience you can call the morning of and get a reservation so I would recommend calling so you can avoid the wait. Would recommend!
author: Vy T.

description:
Came here for a belated birthday dinner with the boyfriend! On a Tuesday night around 6pm it wasn't too crowded and we were able to find seats immediately without reservation. Seating is cramped so not recommended for large parties if you don't want to wait (2-4 optimal).

Ordered the sea bass, BBQ pork chops, and crab cakes with some wine. Some of the best crab cakes I've had (don't quote me on this because I haven't tried too many, but it was still fresh and delicious!!). The sea bass came with soy sauce glaze, rice, and green beans while the pork chops with mashed potatoes and asparagus.

Presentation was fantastic and food was cooked to a yummy tender quality.

Minus a star because the ambiance wasn't as appealing because waitresses were scurrying around almost as if in a panic bringing food plates to and fro the kitchen. It might have seen this way because the interior is so small though. Coming back again to try their specials!
author: Audrey C.

description: The food and service is top notch at this tiny little restaurant. I came with picky people and foodies, but everyone was very satisfied with the food that they ordered. I personally got the glazed king salmon filet in sake shoyu broth which was mind blowing. I can't wait to come back and try the other entrées!
author: Dylan F.

description: This place is fantastic!  Great food, great service.  My wife and I shared 3 small plates and our daughter had the shrimp dumplings.  More than enough food.  The quality and presentation of the food is that of a much more expensive restaurant.
author: Chris W.

description:
I love this place. 
I take all the girls I meet here for our first date. Instant pantie dropper. Salmond rolls are on point and the Kobe is amazing. 
The staff is wonderful and genuine. If anybody ask me where is a good place to eat. The House automatically comes out my mouth without second thought. 
#teamangela #teamchris
author: Europe N.

description:
Loved this place!

For starters we had their special, the ribs, which were delicious. We also had the shrimp dumplings which were pretty good. For our entrees I had the ribeye. Yummm, delish. My boyfriend had pork chops, which he also loved. A little pricey, but that's how it is for good food. Lots of interesting beer and wine choices.

My only complaint is the service was spotty. We were kind of just left there once our meals were brought. Didn't really see our server again til the end
author: Addy L.

description: When someone asks me what's my favorite restaurant in SF I tell them it's the MF'ING HOUSSSEEE. the end....jk  pork chop, wasabi noodles, and scallops were amazing...scallops were the best evar
author: Vince L.

description:
I would have probably rated The House a bit lower, it was a holiday weekend, the place was packed and we had no reservation, however our 45 min wait ended up only being 10 minutes

We had Pickled Cucumbers and and appetizer I can't think of, but both were good.

For our mains, we did Warm Wasabi Noodles with Angus Flat Iron Steak and Grilled Sea Bass with Garlic Noodles, both were pretty good, but from a highly rated place in SF I expected much more.
author: Sergey S.

description: Not a first date recommendation. It's way too loud and the staff (possibly the owner) were not friendly. Our waitress had trash breath. The food is excellent but the canned cokes brought the "class" down a notch.
author: Carlos V.

description:
ALWAYS a great meal here. Everything on their menu is bomb. You won't be disappointed about any choices on their Asian-fusion menu. I can't even list and name any of them specifically because they are all so good!

One thing you might get disappointed over is the no reservation policy and the small dining area. Go on a weeknight to save you a LITTLE more on wait time. Pricing is GREAT for the caliber of food they're serving by the way. One of the best restaurants in SF IMO...and seems like everyone else's opinions based on the reviews here on Yelp.

A must go if you are visiting SF.
author: Justin L.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Seabass & Wasabi Noodle
2.) Ribeye

Food was good, but nothing super amazing as most ppl have hyped.


SERVICE:
good

ATMOSPHERE:
Small nice not too fancy, in the heart of North Beach so the surrounding area is cute.


9.10.13
author: Angela L.

description:
I didn't have a reservation so was placed on a waiting list. They called me in 35 minutes, as promised. It was definitely worth the wait.
Their famous sea bass was absolutely delicious. The service was courteous and prompt. 
This is definitely a place to come back!
The noise level is high, so this might not be the best place for a meaningful conversation.
author: Anna S.

description:
I'm not sure why everyone is so obsessed with this place. I thought I must've been missing something the first time I came here but it's been upwards of 6 times now and in this case, first impressions were accurate.

Food: I strongly dislike Asian fusion which is probably my biggest problem here. Still, I always leave feeling like I haven't eaten no matter what dish I got. I've tried the yellow curry dish, steak sandwich (pretty good), chicken, and seafood and always feel the same. They're all fine but not 4.5 stars-worthy. 

Service: Fairly slow even if not busy.

Atmosphere: Casual and on the quieter side but still background noise and conversation.

Overall, it's a good place to try but I don't think it lives up to the hype.
author: Salma R.

description: This is one of the best restaurant in SF. I highly recommend it. You will not be disappointed. Everything is excellent on the menu and the presentation is impressive.
author: Sandy S.

description: I don't know how to describe this place and the mostly I can't even talk about the food. Let me say this place has the best tasting and most delicious food ever I tasted and I have been all over the world. I'm from Los Angeles and every time i come San Francisco I have to eat here. Only been here 5 times and I wanna eat everything on the menu including the deserts but I just can't manage to do that yet lol. The chef Larry is the GOD of food. This guy is the MAN. IF you want fireworks in your mouth and foodgasm just come here and try it out. It's worth every penny. Another words are yuuumm, goooood, fantastico, deliciousio and AWESOME .....until next time. I can't wait to come back.
author: Hovik B.

description:
The House is one of my favorite restaurants in the city because their food is consistently good. Unlike some restaurants, I haven't experienced an "off day".  I took my mom and nephew there last month for a 7 pm dinner on a Sunday night.  We had to wait 15 minutes for our table even with a reservation - no big deal as we weren't in a hurry.  The three of us were starving so we ordered 3 appetizers - the salmon roll, barbeque ribs and the day's special, dayboat scallops.  All three were delicious!  For entrees, we ordered the rib eye, the sea bass and the miso black rod.  The sea bass and the black cod were so fresh and melted in our mouths.  My nephew loved the ribeye - the portion was big even for him and he couldn't finish it.  We ordered the chocolate cake for dessert.  
Considering the quality of their food, I think this is one of best deals in the city.
author: Rica G.

description:
We're visiting from Portland, OR, and The House came highly recommended by a co-worker who spends a lot of time in San Francisco. We arrived on time for our reservation, and were barely acknowledged by the staff. 

We were seated at what was clearly the worst table in the house- right next to the kitchen door and the restrooms. From then on, not a single staff member said a word to us. An appetizer and some water were brought to us by someone who neither smiled nor acknowledged our existence. 

The table was so dark it was impossible to read the menu without a flashlight. The most frustrating part of the experience was that a couple who arrive after us with no reservation were seated at a much better table.

After surveying the situation, my partner and I left. As she put it, "Why would we spend in the neighborhood of $100 to be treated so poorly?" We walked out and found a place with much better service and many more smiles...and I would not consider going back.
author: Jack C.

description:
Besides for the servers who were nice, the other two females working there were definitely not friendly! They're probably the managers? Owners? I've never been so upset before even getting seated at a restaurant before! I made reservations the day before and the lady I spoke with was really nice on the phone. Asked for my credit card because it was for a party of 8, that's fine since I did not plan to cancel. This was a restaurant I've been wanting to try for over 2 years now! So, I was really excited especially because I get to bring my mom and my aunt for an early Mother's Day meal. I got there 10 minutes before 5, which I made reservations for. The door was held opened by a door, so I assumed I can walk in? I did and the lady just stared at me and I said, hi I made reservations at 5. She looked at me and responded with "ok" and just continue to stare at me. Uh? So I said ok... And she goes well we're not opened yet. That alone made me upset ! She could have said it nicely and at least let me know what time they'll opened, or better yet, just have seated me. I walked back out and she closed the door right away. It's that serious, huh? The door finally opened and we were finally seated. Throughout dinner, our server was nice and the other servers were as well. None of them likes saying thank you apparently. Or you're welcome. Even when we were helping one of the unfriendly woman with the table and dishes, she did not even bother saying thank you.

Besides for the bad service, the food was alright. It's nothing special where I would want to come back and eat here again, though. If you guys don't mind the service, it's a restaurant that's worth trying.
author: S M.

description:
What can I say to bring down The House? Nothing. Like a baby bird, I would close my eyes and eat anything they feed me.

Flat iron stake is a beefy example. At other restaurants, the chef pulls out his chewiest piece of meat and autoclaves the beef until it resembles a leather belt your dad used to beat you. The chef then camouflages it with sauces of subterfuge to hoodwink you into believing that you're eating food. The menu says steak, but you think mis-steak!

The flat iron steak at The House, in contrast, is rendered tender and subtly spiced, before shacking up with the wasabi noodles--thick-cut signature noodles touch you with a fabled "green flash" of wasabi heat at the final brush with the tongue. This dish recalls the aspirations of metallurgy: aluminum is whisked into gold. 

Their seafood dishes, priced  in the mid-20s, are creations you will dream of. The sea bass has a shell of soy-glazed crispiness that makes you wonder if they are raising sea bass in a tank of soy. Once you break through the sub-millimeter of crispiness, the supple middle makes you wonder: is having a mouth full of teeth a little overrated?

This food isn't fusion--it's evolution.

--

PS, Make a reservation or you'll be standing in their 9 cubic foot doorway with 10 other hungry, sad customers for an hour smelling sea bass and contemplating 

PPS, they give away your reservation after 20 minutes late, so need to plan on 30 minutes looking for parking, before you give up and park your car in the middle of Washington Square Park. It's called a "park" for a reason, right?
author: Lou S.

description:
All week I was looking forward to my experience at "The House" with my wife, how can a place with over 3200 reviews and four and a half stars be anything less than stellar?

Upon arrival the host was very cold and uninviting, made it seem like a bother for her to help us.

However looking past all these minute details, it came down to the food and I will tell you this is the place to come for an eclectic spin on Asian food. 

Just order the pomegranate pork chop, salmon roll, and manila clams. Trust me, stop reading this and come here immediately. Just be prepared for horrible service.
author: Valentin R.

description:
This was my second time eating here, this time with my hubby for an early anniversary.

The food was still good; I got the grilled sea bass with ginger soy and garlic noodles and the hubby got the pork chop in pomegranate sauce, with both dishes being delicious. I think I enjoyed his pork chop more as it was very tender, juicy and not over cooked. We also split the fried salmon appetizer, which was delicious, except for the wasabi dipping sauce it came with. It was just too strong and neither of us can really stand wasabi.

For dessert we decided to split the mango tapioca and the coconut creme brule with passion fruit sauce. I have to say I was under-impressed this time with the latter, as the first time I had it you could taste the coconut in the creme brule more as well as more passionfruit puree. The mango tapioca was cold, creamy and refreshing though.

I was just a little disappointed though that after stating we were celebrating our anniversary, other than a candle glued onto the plate of our dessert, nothing was really said to us or written out on the plate. I am wondering how they would even acknowledge someone's special occasion if they didn't order dessert..stick a candle on your check? Otherwise, if nothing is complimentary, there is really no point in leaving a note when making reservations.

I'm sorry, The House, while serving really delicious and upscale food for reasonable prices, has missed it's mark this time around with the service being a little inattentive (we came right at 11:30am when they opened and only 2 other tables were there) and not really putting in much effort in the anniversary presentation, given that we were charged for both desserts, even writing out happy birthday in chocolate syrup in addition to an awkwardly placed candle would have been a nice gesture for choosing to celebrate with them.

Overall, I would still come back for the food but perhaps not for something like an anniversary. Definitely get the pork chop if you can't decide and the Tuna Ahi Tartar, which wasn't on the menu this time or a special, but something I enjoyed a great deal with first time I dined here.

Driving around this area is probably the worst, so try to take public transit or stick with a weekday during lunch. There is parking in the North Beach garage a few blocks away for $3.00 an hour.
author: Petra S.

description:
Made a reservation for 7 within a week's notice and got a time for 5oclock on a Saturday. Def recommend making reservations for this place as it is small and always crowded (with good reason!)

TLDR; quant busy place with great service and AWESOME food in big portions - at reasonable prices.

Appetizers:
Crab cake: Pretty big crab cake for an appetizer! Usually I expect 2 dinky round pieces but they shaped it into something like a big pear. It was big enough for all 7 of us to have a good bite out of it. Lots of crab and not filled with batter. The "Asian fusion" part of it here was a hint of wasabi which was pretty good!
Soft shell crab tempura (special for the day):

Entrees:
Kurobuta pork chop: TENDERRR. It had like a sweet BBQ sauce which was pretty good but I wanted something super savory. This is awesome if you like BBQ,

Wasabi noodles with flank steak: I've been hearing so much about this! I actually didn't taste the wasabi in the wasabi noodle? I kind of expected a plain or green noodle but it was more of like.. a  red-brown colored sauce. It looked "cheap" but was pretty damn good. HELLLA flank steak too. And it was cooked perfectly!

Rib eye steak: MY FAVORITE!!!!!!!!!!! I ordered the wasabi noodles and my BF got this. THIS ended up being my fav, while my BF liked my dish more. OMG this rib eye was sooooo damn tender and such a big portion. Again, perfectly cooked and LOADS of fried garlic on top. YUM!

Sea bass: I don't usually like fish, but this was soooooo good. Perfectly flaky fish with good flavoring. Slightly crisp, and also a big portion.

Dessert:
Rhubarb and strawberry pie (or something? it was a special): The pie was good.. nothing like AMAZING but def above average pie. To be honest, the mango pudding stole my heart away!

Mango pudding: Iuno, this is pretty standard for most Asian places. But OMG this mango pudding is so good and prob one of the best I've had. It's so creamy and smooth, alot of places have this all hard, thick or powdery tasting but not here!! There was also enough of the condensed milk (many places don't have enough) and it was diluted a bit for the perfect texture. I also tasted some ginger or coconut in there. Yummy!
author: Emily C.

description: Outstanding food, experience and service. Best restaurant we have been to in San Francisco in a long time.
author: Jean A.

description: I got the lamb. Was amazing! I ordered it well-done and it was still full of flavor. The kimchi sauce was different and excellent along with the rice. It is a little crowded, but it is San Fransisco! Maybe in the future they could expand. Out waiter was very hospitable as well. He very enthusiastic about sharing the specials, and he and the staff kept checking on us for refills and anything else we needed.
author: Krizia Kaye B.

description:
Came for lunch as a friend recommended it. Even though we made a reservation, we saw plenty of people who came and got a table without reservations. 

The food was pretty delicious. The popular deep fried salmon roll was really yummy. It was salmon wrapped in nori sheet with a spring roll warp on the outside. It came with a hot mustard sauce which pairs perfectly with the rolls. The pork chop was a pretty good portion, and the pomegranate currant sauce gave it some sweetness. The play between the sweet and savory was nice. The fried Alaskan halibut from the daily special menu came with the roasted cauliflower, which I enjoyed. We finished the meal with chai panna cotta, topped with strawberries and mangos. It was good, but nothing memorable.

All in all, we liked the meal. I'm not sure if I would go out of my way for it again. I don't think the food was worth our effort of making the reservation and planning our day around it. I wouldn't mind grabbing a bite if I happen to be in the area without having to make a reservation.
author: Lynn C.

description:
I came to this restaurant because of a friends recommendation.  I was excited to visit this restaurant.  Yes the parking does suck, we had to park a few blocks away.  We had to stand in a cramped entrance with others waiting to be seated.  The host could be a bit more welcoming.  We were seated at a small table our waitress was friendly and knew the menu well (kind of hard to understand her though).  We ordered the salmon roll, which was deep fried.  Im not a fan of deep fried sushi type things but this was actually really good and light flavored.  I like how they keep the salmon still a little raw in the center of the meat.

I ordered the bass dish with garlic noodles.  The fish was a good size and super flaky.  The sauce is a bit over powering and the garlic noodles are not great compared to other garlic noodles that I've had.  My gf ordered the pork chop dish and that was the winner!  She really isnt a huge fan of pork chops but she ordered it cause I wanted to try it.  She liked it!  But I think I liked it even more!  We ended up trading out plates half way through.  We finished our meal with the strawberry rhubarb pie with vanilla ice cream.

The meal was overall delicious and the price was under $100.  I would definitely come back but the location and size of the restaurant makes me not want to come back for quite some time though.
author: David K.

description:
This place is so tiny and cute! I came here with my mom, grandma, sister and aunt and we got seated immediately for lunch with no wait.

We started off with the calamari and softshell crab. I have to say they were pretty flavorful and just the right amount of spice. That kept us full for a while and then our main entrees came. I got the curry noodles with shrimp, sister and mom got the wasabi noodles with salmon and my grandma and aunt got the udon (i know.. we all got noodle-y things :3). It was also very, very good and filling!!! I thought the portions were a good size for roughly $10 and it wasn't spicy at all. I was glad the wasabi and curry noodles had the right amount of flavor and didn't burn my taste buds off. 

We all decided to try their chocolate ganache cake dessert with coffee ice cream. Not bad, but pretty small. 

Oh yeah and I got their lichee black iced tea and honestly it tasted like water :/ oh well. The lichee they dropped in my drink was good though. 

They had good service and the waiter was nice. The little dish they serve you when they give you water (cucumber?) is free the first time but requesting more is an extra $2 to your bill.
author: Kathleen S.

description:
Spectacular.  Absolutely stellar food.  So much flavor in amazingly light (though I am sure they are not in reality "light") dishes.

I really do not have too many other insightful things to write, aside from: this place is spectacular.  Go here.  Be blissfully happy.
author: Maureen C.

description:
It's 4.5 stars. The food is outstanding - steak and noodles dish was delicious, as was absolutely everything else. It's the perfect place for something not so, "We always go there," unless, well, you always go there. It's also a great spot to take out-of-towners, as it combines the best SF has to offer - cool neighborhood and originality rather unlike what you'll find most places. 

My one and only not-the-best feedback regards the service. Our waitress was friendy enough through the arrival of our food, and after that, she didn't really check in with us and switched with someone else halfway through. The second waitress could not have been more interested in anything other than us finishing and getting the hell out of there for the next table. So if you're hoping to linger and chat...you won't.

Note: You won't find them on OpenTable, but they take reservations the old school way (gasp!), which I highly recommend. It was very busy with a wait out the door on a Sunday evening.
author: Kiesha R.

description:
One of the best meals I've ever had! Such unique flavors and everything was perfectly cooked! Knowing how good the food was, DD made a reservation weeks in advance and we were seated right away when we arrived. Score!

--Ahi Tuna Tartare ($10)--
To start we started off with something light. Tuna was delicious, fresh, well seasoned and beautifully presented. My only complaint was the extremely small portion!

--Chilean Sea Bass with Garlic Noodles ($26)--
I LOVE sea bass! And this one was melt-in-your-mouth delicious! Soft, flaky, flavorful, buttery - just perfect! Comes with a nice portion of sauteed green beans and a choice of rice or garlic noodles. GET THE GARLIC NOODLES - chewy and flavorful!

--Braised Pork Shoulder ($28)--
DD loves braised, slow-cooked meat and ordered this pork shoulder dish - a special that night. He was presented with a big bowl filled with a spicy cream sauce. In the middle of the bowl was a nicely sized piece of braised pork shoulder topped with a fried pork brine. The soup just by itself I could have drank! The flavors in this dish were unique and delicious - the perfect balance between spicy and creamy. The meat was fall-apart soft and we devoured it completely. DD said it was one of the best dishes he's ever had - I totally agree. Even better than the Sea Bass!

All in all, we left blown away by our meal! Servers were prompt and well informed about the food. Only thing sort of UNDERwhelming was our Ahi Tuna appetizer. Next time we'll try the fried calamari - which looked awesome! EASY 5 stars!
author: Eunice K.

description: My wife and I had an awesome experience at this restaurant. We had the ribeye, soft-shell crab, salmon rolls, and tempura green beans. The food was unbelievable, the service was just as good. Food was also very reasonably priced considering the quality, and portions (especially of the ribeye).
author: Brett B.

description:
Two words: Miso cod. 

The most delicious melt in your mouth fish that I've had in a very long time. The California rolls served on top of the cod and the accompanying sauces were unnecessary. 

Bf ordered the mushroom rice which he enjoyed. It was a hearty, well-balanced dish.

The service was great as well but the space was just way too cramped. Really didn't want to hear the couple next to me talk about their relationship (awkward...) while trying to have a nice dinner with my sweetie...I couldn't tune them out!

All in all a solid restaurant.
author: Susie O.

description: Hands down some of the best food in SF however I will never be returning with all due respect to the chefs. Sat with a group of friends and family and my relative dos not like his food he asked for it to be changed out and was denied due to a he kitchen being closed. Understandingly we asked them to just take the food back so they did and still charged us for it.. Our bill was 480$ and she still charged us for a plate that had a bite taken out of it then when we confronted her she offered to take half of the meal off. This kind of customer service is disgusting and is a main reason business fail. The waiters were being very short and salty as well throughout the dinner bad energy from this place.
author: Daniel E.

description:
Starter hamachi sashimi, avocado, seaweed and radish with citrus shallots dressing. Entrees seared ahi tuna with wasabi aioli on top of rice, and sea bass with ginger soy with green beans and udon noodles. Dessert was chocolate truffle cake with coffee ice cream. 

Everything was delicious. Huge portions. I can understand why this restaurant is so popular. The sea bass is the star of the show. Taste like a mix of Chilean sea bass and butter fish. Super moist and flavorful. The only thing I didn't care for were the noodles that came with it. Kinda like udon stir fried with hoisin sauce. Service was prompt and efficient. It's a very busy and tiny restaurant.
author: Sunny C.

description:
Two things that I am always and forever hesitant to try in a restaurant and usually never experience at perfection: cooked fish, and Asian fusion.

Two things that The House excels in. To perfection and beyond: cooked fish. And Asian fusion. What?! 

I was impressed by everything, and this almost never happens to the Yelper in me. 

Not only were all the fish dishes we ordered cooked wonderfully just right, but the combinations of Asian inspired flavors with New American style plates were served up in surprisingly decent portions at surprisingly very affordable prices, given that The House is a special occasion type of restaurant and all (but of course it's still perfectly appropriate to show up in shorts and flipflops. Except if you're wearing shorts and flipflops in SF, you're probably a really lucky tourist who accidentally wandered in here . . . anyway, I digress) 

Combinations like wasabi with noodles, perfectly cooked flat-iron steak, miso with flaky butterfish, curry with rich seabass, delicious berry compotes with tender pork all come out beautifully and creatively executed. Start off with some deep fried salmon rolls. Order something different for everyone and then pass the plates around. True, you won't want to even dive into your food because it's so beautiful, let alone have your entire table pick at it, but you'll also thank me later for being able to try more combinations of some of the most flavorful, delicious dishes ever in this unassuming little (but not hidden - as evidenced by the thousands of other rave reviews already) gem in North Beach.
author: Betty W.

description:
It's been over 10 years since I've been here and the place is still packed to the gills. 

On a good Friday, my sister and niece flew in from Vegas and she wanted..no, she must eat at The House again. Last time when she was in SF 2yrs. ago, she enjoyed it so much so I couldn't say no to her. 

We had reservations at 9pm and still had to wait about 20mins. When we did get seated, the kind waiter came and was very attentive. He was telling us the special for the evening but I really didn't understand him clearly. No matter, I knew what I was having. I went for 3 small dishes: octopus, Caesar salad with I believe deep fried scallops and the dumplings. My favorite was the octopus. It was cooked perfectly, the sauce was a small amount of mayo and some tangy chili sauce. The salad was okay, nothing to write home about, same for the dumpling. 

 My sister has the salad with the pork skin and another item I am forgetting now and the deep fried green beans. The salad was interesting. It was a sweet vinaigrette dressing but what made the dish fun were the deep fried pork skins. Green beans were okay...just okay. The sauce that accompanied it was this soya sauce with lots of green onion. 

My niece had their famous sea bass entree. That was very good and fresh! It was served with some noodles that resembled Dan Dan mein and stir fried green beans. 

The ambiance is cramped, on the dark side and loud. But everyone is having a grand time. Since the place is small, the tables are very close to each other. If you are on an intimate date, there's not much talking without raising your voice.

Prices are high. Our meal for 3 of us came to be about 150.00. I am not a huge fan but I know The House has a wonderful reputation for consistency. Better to go for lunch if the pocketbook is tight. I feel this restaurant is placed too high on the pedestal. The hype from the younger generation has made The House to seem like it is one of the best of the best. It's not even Zagat rated....I don't believe. I could be wrong. 

Shalamar on Polk Street is Zagat rated over and over every year. It's one of the best Indian restaurants I have even eaten it. And that place is a hole in the wall with no frills. But the best Tiki chicken Marsala!! I know I'm comparing apples and oranges but I'm just sayin'
author: Jessica L.

description:
At 3050+ reviews, this place really does not selling.  I'm amazed at how they can repeat perfection.  Every. Single. Time.  

Their scallops appetizers (sometimes not on the menu) has haunted my palate for days...buttery, delicate, flavorful.  Delicious sake to complement amazing food.  The venue is pretty small, and the tables are packed.  I personally prefer the intimate environment it offers ... just don't wear a heavy sweater or jacket - it gets warm!
author: Nikki G.

description:
Inflated bubble.

Overpriced: http://sf.curbed.com/archives/2014/06/06/san_francisco_median_house_sale_price_this_spring_was_11m.php

Overrated: Average of 4.5 stars from over 3,000 reviews. An impressive feat. But also a confusing one. 

There were absolutely some standout dishes. Ginger noodles, shrimp and chive dumplings and grilled calamari in a spicy tomato sauce were all excellent.

But the pork shop with pomegranate sauce was a fattening disappointment and served with barely any of the much anticipated sauce. Miso cod was forgotten a day later.

Service was nice but felt scripted, indifferent and rushed. Space didn't have any signature architectural details and even felt a bit cramped. One bathroom?

At $120/pair expectations were high. Some dishes more than exceeded expectations but it wasn't an overwhelming positive story.

Much like the current state of San Francisco itself.
author: Jason B.

description:
definitely one of my top 5 restaurants in sf. been coming here for YEARS and the food stays super consistent and comforting. the place is tiny, so make reservations. unfortunately, parking sucks in north beach, so plan accordingly.

i absolutely love this place. my favorite is the sea bass plate with garlic noodles and the california  roll. super simple, but great food nonetheless.
author: Vanessa D.

description: We sure lucked out finding this place when we got to San Francisco. We were going to eat at a Chinese restaurant but the wait was really long so we walked around and found The House! My husband ordered a noodle dish that was spicy but delicious and I ordered the unagi avocado sandwich which was AMAZING!  The eel was cooked perfectly, all tender and mouthwatering. The bread seemed to be sourdough that had been buttered and seasoned with herbs before grilling it and the avocado, tomato and lettuce were so fresh. The wasabi mayo was the perfect touch. Definitely would recommend.
author: Angelique N.

description:
Loved it - easy to find and fast to sit down when we went, even though we didn't have a reservation.  Excellent flavor - we got a hamachi appetizer along with the Kurobata (sp?) pork, which was extremely tender and tasty with their BBQ-like sauce.  Eat the hamachi first as it's a much more delicate flavor.

Main dish was prime rib (medium) and their special noodle dish.  Both were very flavorful without being overdone.  Nice easy ambiance and friendly servers, highly recommended. 

The other appetizers were also quite visually appealing - something to come back for!
author: Art H.

description: Great great food for the price and I think this is true asian fusion compared to when people add miso to anything and call it fushion food. I always get the salmon rolls (raw salmon with spicy wasabi sauce in a roll that is deep fried) and the sea bass with green beans and the garlic noodles. The desserts are pretty good too. Everything else was pretty decent when it came to tuna tartare, porkchops, or the cod. The place isn't too hard to get RSVP if you have a small group and call a few days earlier. I've been 3 times since fall and would definitely go again anytime.
author: Lily P.

description:
Waitress put a family of 5 into a dark corner. Lighting is dim overall but I guess that's just the typical ambiance of expensive restaurants.
We ordered 2 appetizers, 3 entrees, 2 desserts.
 
Appetizers:
-Steamed mussels in shrimp infused broth: Mussels were nicely cooked and not rubbery. Broth was whatever. 
-Fresh Oysters: The best oysters I've ever eaten. So plump and creamy. Sauce was some kind of vinegar and soy sauce but all you needed was a nice spritz of lemon over these babies.

Entrees:
-Angus ribeye steak: Best dish out of the entrees. Nice flavor. The grilled cauliflowers had a smoky flavor and were delicious. 
-Wasabi noodles with Angus flatiron steak: forgettable. This cut of steak wasn't as flavorful as its ribeye counterpart. You could taste the wasabi in the noodles. The fat noodles has a pleasing chewy texture but were too greasy.   
-Grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy sauce: Fish was fine but forgettable. Sauce didn't really do anything for me. This dish was also served with the housemade noodles in a greasy sauce that I don't remember. The green beans served alongside the fish was so oily. What's the point of covering vegetables in so much oil if it's not the good kind of fat (i.e. animal fat)?

Desserts:
-Chocolate cake with coffee ice cream: Cake was nicely dense and had a dark chocolate flavor. Overall, dish was decent but definitely not worth over $8.
-Coconut creme brulée with passion fruit sauce: Texture of the creme brulee was firm and silky smooth. I couldn't really taste coconut but the consistency and texture of the creme brulee made up for it. And it was fun to crack the shell of sugar on top.

Overall, I was not impressed. Service was fine. Our waitress was attentive and our water was always refilled. But for the prices, the dishes should be more creative or just taste like something else beside grease.
author: Julia T.

description: We went for lunch and ordered the kobe rib eye steak  (not on the menu), soooo worth the $40 was amazing...
author: C C.

description: By far one of my favorite restaurants in the Bay Area. I always have to order the pork chop but the sea bass is very good too. Actually, I tried almost everything on the menu and it's always very good. The service is always on point. I have been here many times for over 15 years and never had a bad experience.
author: Lauren V.

description:
So yummy and interesting ! The menu simply makes your mouth water :) 
Friendly cosy environment. Nice eclectic crowd. 
But mostly the food is super delicious! 
Enjoy!
author: Karin C.

description:
Was here on the eve of my last b'day (Saturday). I am surprised what all the rave is about. We had a two hour wait time. The place is quite cramped for space. The four of us were pretty uncomfortable all the time. The food is not too great.

Not worth it for the price paid (expensive).
author: Sundeep R.

description: Never celebrate your birthday here! They'll charge you $3 PER CUT of your own birthday cake after you ordered over $200 for dinner and all you asked for is a knife! And they say this fee is the universal policy for ALL the restaurants?!?! This sounds like a joke but it's real! Worst service I've ever had. I have to ask for water and silverware for several times. Waited long time to order food. Totally ruined my birthday mood. Never come back again!
author: Yi C.

description: Absolutely Delicious! This is the best Asian fusion food I've ever had! Cute, quaint atmosphere, friendly staff - every dish was superb, and I'm usually a tough critic. Felt like I was getting a casual, home-cooked meal with Michelin star rated flavor and presentation.
author: Melissa D.

description: The House has top notch Asian Fusion. Best salmon I've ever had. Incredibly savory beef house noodles with steak cooked to perfection. The food was balanced and tasty. Nice romantic ambiance and location in North Beach. I recommend trying to make reservations to avoid a long wait. It can get pretty loud and crowded, but is worth it for the amazing food!
author: Steven V.

description:
The most appropriate rating for me would be 3.5 stars. My meal was just ok, while my fiance's was fantastic.

My fiance ordered the warm wasabi house noodles with angus flat iron steak, which was absolutely delicious. Definitely get the house noodles if you come here. I ordered the Kobe beef special, which was tough and chewy. The flavor was good, but I could barely eat the steak. 

This is a TINY restaurant, and where you sit really determines your experience. We made a reservation, and ended up getting sat at the very back of the restaurant, on the same small path to the kitchen and in between a table full of loud teenagers and a table with unruly screaming children. That definitely made the experience a bit worse in my book, my fiance and I couldn't hear each other throughout the entire meal. Having a little more space would be nice.
author: Michele F.

description:
Last dinner in San Fran & the best one ever!

Not sure about the parking!  We lucked out and were able to park right out front so I knew it was meant to be!  We had the cutest little server! She was so kind & sweet!  We even had a water boi!  lol.  

My friend & I had the friend salmon roll & drooled for a while.  The crunch, the flavor, the sauce... hot damn!  We also split the green bean tempura- come on!  So damn good! I got the sea bass which put things over the top for me!  It was so rich and perfectly prepared.  I think I moaned a little when I ate it!  

I never get dessert and was considering the creme brulee.  I opted not to, and regretted it all night!  Seriously, the whole dining experience left me wanting more.

I think it is perfectly priced, too. Oh, I also loved their placemats with the little house punched out of them!  I am, after all,  a details girl!
author: Kim K.

description: Incredible food, flavorful, beautifully served! Friendly and very knowledgable service. The Asian fusion on highest level. Must try while in San Francisco!
author: Kasia B.

description:
Pretty much been a loyal patron of House for over a decade.  I even used to go to the location on 9th Ave & Irving up until it sadly closed.  Fortunately there's still the original North Beach location.

The restaurant is always super busy and the seating is definitely on the cozier side.  But all this is worth it once you get your meal.  Everything on the menu is good...but I rarely ever diverge off course from getting my all-time fave dish at House...the Kurobuta Pork Chop with pomegranate sauce.  Even if you don't normally like pork, get the pork chop!...yes, it's that good!
author: Justin L.

description: Ate here three nights ago and it was to die for. The sea bass was superb. The poke was excellent and the hangar steak and wasabi noodles as everyone reported as the best was truly the case. I wanted to return the next night, that's huge for a weekend trip for me!
author: Jenny M.

description:
I gotta do a shoutout--my bf and I ate at here last weekend, and I'm still dreaming of the ahi tuna tartare on toasted nori chips.  Those chips were so flavorful!  

This place has been open since 1994 and still has 4.5 stars, and yet I'd never heard of it!  We go out to eat A LOT, and I don't think we've ever had a meal where EVERY DISH was so amazing.  (Including at $$$$ places.)  The only minus was that it's SO LOUD, we had to yell at each other the whole time.  Could barely understand the server above the din.

The other amazingly delicious things we had were: deep fried salmon rolls, wasabi noodles with flatiron steak, and chocolate macadamia tart with toffee ice cream. Doing a couple extra small plates and sharing 1 entrée was great for 2 people--the portion was generous for the entrée, and we got to try more things. Will definitely come back to try a fish entrée because they looked awesome, and the friendly folks at the table next to us also raved about their pork chop.
author: Dany C.

description:
Pleasant neat lil place ...!!
Came here for lunch with coworkers and was intrigued by the interesting menu...
Basically your western food prepared with Asian flare~~
My sesame salmon came with traditional Chinese greens and flavored with dark soy sauces (what I gather to be..?!)....
The deserts were also nicely done with interesting flavors...
Love to come back and check out their wine list...!
author: YC L.

description:
Great little restaurant...We enjoyed the pork chop the best, along with the mussels which was an appetizer. It was tasty, but would've been even better with some bread for dipping. The pork chit came with a pomegranate sauce, mashed potatoes, and asparagus. 
We also had the sea bass, which everyone raves over, but it was a little saltier than we've had before. 
I would definitely recommend either going right when they open, and having an early dinner, or making a reservation, which is only over the phone! 
Overall, the food was tasty and it does get crowded so make sure to have reservations!
author: Stephanie F.

description:
The House was amazing.... We ordered 4 main entries. 3 different fish dishes (Cod, Halibut and Sea Bass) and they were melting in our mouths...  A dish of Kobe beef with spicy noodles, which were very tasty all the way! I think I will dream about their dishes.... Appetizers, ahi tuna tartare and deep-fried salmon roll, were ok but not great like main entries. 
Wonderful service and good atmosphere, maybe a little noisy with voices echoed... Will go back again!
author: Katsumi N.

description:
I just had a fabulous lunch here today. We started out with the seared scallops appetizer, which was cooked to perfection and adorned with black caviar and a delicious sauce. Then, we had some fried calamari, which was also tasty and crispy. After that, we got an order of the tuna and yellowtail sashimi, which was very fresh and good.

For our main entree, we all got the wasabi noodles. I had mine with salmon, which was soft and juicy. Perfect. I wouldn't have changed anything. I already made reservations to come here again in 2 weeks! Look forward to having dinner here.
author: Joan S.

description:
BEST RESTAURANT EVER. Go here yesterday. Then again today!!!

Black cod
Sea bass
Unagi appetizer
Pork chop
Hamachi
Wasabi noodle

Everything is amazing. Period.
author: Jason T.

description:
First dates are always weird. What do you talk about? How much do you eat? Do you kiss the other person at the end of the date? 

Regardless, I came here for a first date and the date didn't end so well, but the food was good. I had a great experience at the restaurant. We ordered the deep fried salmon rolls as the appetizer to share. The dipping sauce that came with the rolls were not as great as I thought it was going to be, but the roll itself was definitely good. 

I ordered one of the specials they had that night - the halibut with truffle cream and mashed potatoes. Who doesn't love truffle right? The halibut was flaky and amazingly cooked and the cream and potatoes went so well with it. Thinking about it makes my mouth water! 

We also got dessert (chocolate anyone?). We ordered the truffle cake that came with coffee ice cream. The truffle cake was so dense and so chocolatey. The coffee ice cream was a great complement to all of that. Would definitely order that again. 

The place is kind of small, but a great place. Not enough seats, but it is North Beach. It's just a cute restaurant definitely up for a second try.
author: Nina Y.

description:
Get your monocle out if you're ordering the Caesar salad. You will need it to find the micro scallops. 

With that minor bummer aside, I enjoyed just about everything about The House and their Asian-fusion fare. Sure there is limited seating, but it feels cozy. Not old and broken-in cozy...more like comfortably close.

Everything the group ordered looked delicious and everyone left satisfied overall. Just keep in mind that if you're remotely hungry, you'll need to order something else supplemental if you're eyeing up the Caesar Salad.
author: Tara L.

description:
I am just another wowed customer writing nothing but good things about this place. 

A friend of mine was visiting so I made reservations for 7PM on a Saturday, and the day of, at around 3:30PM, I asked to move it up to 5PM when the restaurant opened and they were fine with it. Wherever you're coming from, I'd recommend allotting time for traffic/looking for parking. We got to our reservation on time, and 10 minutes later, the entire restaurant was packed. Avg. wait was 45min-1hr after that point. Moral of the story, DEFINITELY make reservations or get there exactly at opening!

I ordered one of their specials, and if I remember correctly, it was a ribeye steak with mushrooms and truffle reduction. WHAT!? Yeah, just typing that out made me salivate. It was ... divine. My friend was so jealous. He ordered the wasabi noodles with steak -- the noodles were tasty, but he wish he had my steak to go with it; his was kind of bland. Sry, you gots to get your own. 

**Side note: Since we got there at opening, we got to choose where we wanted to sit, and we opted for the table right in front of the window. People who passed by literally stopped and looked at our food, ooohing and ahhhing. I interacted with them a couple of times, demonstrating my steak-cutting skills or giving them a thumbs up and mouthing out "sooooo good." They were very entertained (I think). I should get a star for positive advertisement of this restaurant. Or not, depending on if I was either entertaining or creepy.

It was a pretty pricey meal, but I didn't care. The restaurant itself isn't fancy/bougie or, let's be a little more real, PRETENTIOUS. Decor was simple and clean, so you know that what your paying for is the quality of the food, and this was top-notch quality. Respect.
author: Christine C.

description: Recommend making reservation as they are a small restaurant and they get pretty busy! Food was awesome and the service was great despite us having a big party of 8. The House is not that big so a party of 8 requires you to make a reservation. I think it helped that we were not a rowdy group so we had pretty good service. There were so many choices that I had a hard time deciding but in the end I had their Miso Glazed Cod. It was delicious! I also tried their angus steak with the wasabi noodles and pork chop that my other friends had. I really wanted to try their sea bass too.  Will definitely come back to try the other dishes!
author: J C.

description:
Took a tip from my cousin and came at 5:30 at opening and there was no line. We got a few specials of the night which was a Kobe beef and Halibut dish. The Kobe beef was great, moist and flavorful. The halibut was average but had a nice light Thai curry. 

We also had the wasabi noodles which. Had enough kick and was equally tasty. All dishes were presented fairly well and was a good place for a good time
author: Joey L.

description:
When I think about SEA BASS, I think about THE HOUSE!
This restaurant is a bit small so make sure you make a reservation before dining here. Everything on the menu is absolutely delicious. Service is good.
Overall I find myself dining here at least 2-3x/year.
Only con is that parking can be difficult.
author: Virginia L.

description: We had the pork chop and it was really good.   The service was efficient.
author: Edgar C.

description: This hole in the wall Asian Fusion restaurant tucked into San Francisco's North Beach neighborhood is absolutely delicious from start to finish. This small restaurants has very few tables but the food is served in a timely manner and the wait staff is very kind and conscious   of the customers waiting. For appetizers (small plates), we started with the deep-fried salmon roll and steamed mussels. The salmon rolls were tasty but the mussels were mouth watering. The rolls were served with a spicy mustard so gauge your tolerance before you smother your roll in it like I did. The mussels were served in a great sauce with garlic bread slices; I could have eaten this whole appetizer myself. For main dishes, we ordered the ribeye and alaskan cod special. The ribeye was cooked to a tee and the cod was marinated in a delicious sauce plus the sushi rolls on top were key. For dessert, we ordered the apple crumb pie and chocolate truffle cake. The pie was served warm with a hint of cinnamon cooked into the apple slices. The chocolate cake was totally worth every single rich and gooey bite. I would highly recommend this restaurant for a date night or a dinner spot for a small group of friends worth impressing.
author: Meredith R.

description:
Very good food. Tried 3 different dishes all of them were super good and delicious. I would highly recommend this place. This place is usually busy on weekends so I would recommend make a reservation in advance. Also try their Japanese beer, it's good.
Less on ambiance more on food for this place.
author: Rahul C.

description:
Dined here on a sunday night (7/27).

I wanted to take a break from the usual french/new american cuisines in the city (SF has great standards for food, and many tend to skew toward french cuisines - not complaining of course!).  

Started with the ahi tuna tartare - an almost outdated dish, but welcomed.  Presentation was done well, with three large taro chips stacked with ahi, one resting on top of another.  Seasoned with nori & sea salt, nothing really stood out about the flavor.

 We moved onto the crispy salmon skin rolls, which was also presented beautifully.  It consisted of two traditional salmon skin rolls, fried on the outside, then cut diagonally (for 4 pieces).  It was good, but I felt like I could order this at any sushi restaurant.

As for the entree, we had the black cod dish, with a side of garlic noodles.  The dish itself consisted of a small piece of miso marinated black cod, 3 pieces of sashimi, and two long california rolls (stretched out).  It wasn't anything new - I've tasted similar miso marinated black cod (for cheaper) at izakaya restaurants in the peninsula, and the sushi I could have gotten at any sushi place.  The wasabi garlic noodles tasted like the ones I ordered from ben tre in SSF, with a slight wasabi aftertaste (but it was so subtle, I almost didn't taste it).

Overall, I thought the food was good.  The tastes aren't unique; you can likely order similar dishes at any japanese restaurant.  There's always a long line out the door (even on a sunday evening), but if you're around the north beach area and feeling like  asian cuisine - this would be the place.
author: Hsin L.

description:
This review is longggg overdue! 

The food here is pretty good and I haven't been here for awhile since they moved from the sunset district. 

The Chilean seabass is mouthwatering good and reasonably priced around $23! It also comes with a side of garlic noodles and green beans. The fried salmon rolls for appetizers are also SUPER good and highly recommended! The calamari was also decent.  I love the way they plate their food and make it look really presentable and delicious.

I would also recommend making reservations because it's superrr small inside and the wait could be long! Parking is also really hard but it is free after 5 or 6 pm so take advantage of that as well.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
I don't get all the rave reviews?? Don't get me wrong we enjoyed our meal, but with my limited culinary skills, some fresh ginger and garlic and some Momofuku sauce I was able to re-create my flank steak with noodles at home. If I can make something at a highly raved about restaurant than something is clearly amiss..

As promised the restaurant is small, but by Philly standards (what we've come to know and love), this place is cavernous. The service is fine. Professional yet not overly friendly. We both enjoyed the food, but it lacked any refinement and my flank steak was tough and chewy. Seems like flank should be lean- no??? As expected parking is a bitch in this area and the wait is super long without a reservation.. All that added together-its hard to give The House more than a 3.
author: Ritu K.

description:
I was definitely impressed. The food is good and I only remember the Ahi Tuna Tartare and the Seabass with the wasabi noodles.  We ordered two more dishes but this one stood out the most. The Seabasss was cooked perfectly, I can't believe how soft, tender, moist, and delicious this piece of fish was and to add to the greatness were the wasabi noodles. The noodles were such a nice touch, it had a hint of wasabi and that was that. It wasn't overpowering which made it a great complement to the whole dish. 

The place was super crowded and small, why must all successful places always be so small? What is up with that? Lol. That means RESERVATIONS RESERVATIONS! 

I highly recommend this place and who can forget the name of this place?
author: Mia L.

description:
The bae surprised me and brought me here for my birthday. I've been meaning to try this place and I was thoroughly happy with my experience there. He had made reservations  prior to going. We waited about 10 minutes to get seated after he checked in. So it wasn't too bad. 

It's a tiny restaurant with small tables. It might be harder to set up for a big party but its definitely perfect for a date night.

The wasabi house noodles was my favorite dish of the night! We ordered other dishes to go along with it. And everything was delicious. But I would definitely go back for the noodles. :)
author: Michelle F.

description:
Come here and get happy. 

The food, service, and ambience is great here. The place is small but the food is worth the wait. Make reservations if you have a large party or it will be impossible to get a table. I have tried both their sea bass and flank steak plates are they are both really good. 

A must try!
author: Michael L.

description:
Restaurant was a great visit to San Fransico, I ordered the Wasabi noodles with salmon and my lady ordered the grilled chicken. It was amazing. Everything had such great flavor. And the prices were great....less then 30 for both :) 

We shall be coming here again.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
It's been over 10 years since we've been here! Visited tonight to celebrate our Wedding Anniversary. Food still very delicious and expertly executed. We ordered a great deal of food:

* soft shell crab special appetizer (excellent)
* crab cake appetizer (excellent)
* ahi tuna tartare with nori chips appetizer (very good)
* wasabi noodles with medium-rare flatiron steak (excellent)
* Kurobata pork chop in pomegranate sauce cooked medium (excellent)
* grilled sea bass (wowww)
* coconut creme brûlée with passion fruit sauce (very good)
* mango tapioca (wowww)

Why not 5 stars? With its huge success and following, they need to find a larger location, have 2 bathrooms, and spiff it up a notch? It would be worth their investment. Service was good but not memorable! They were thoughtful enough to place a candle on our dessert commemorating our special event! They are responsive when asked for things. Like them to be more perceptive and proactive. What could have made it a 5 star experience were the small but impactful details. They did not inquire about how our food was, fill water in timely manner, or ask if we wanted to order more drinks. The busboy did not smile, utter a word, fill water promptly, or seem like he wanted to be there. He's a downer on a staff of energetic people. Get rid of him.

Food experience was excellent. Service experience needs a little work! Will be back cuz our taste buds gave thumbs up!
author: H E.

description:
Ever since we discovered this place 7 years ago,  we have been going back at least a couple of times each year. We live in south bay so the trip out to the city isn't very frequent. 

We always order the scallops (seasonal), wasabi noodles and steak,  and the seabass. They are all so delicious! 

Without a reservation it will be almost impossible to eat here.. So make sure you call ahead at least a week in advance.
author: Sera P.

description: I love their steak and salad. I will go back to try other dishes and steak again. I think they have the best Steak.
author: Meichelle L.

description:
ABSOLUTELY LOVED THIS PLACE!!!

My man and I found this place on a whim and decided to come here for our anniversary dinner -- we'd rather have amazing food than too much of a fine dining experience. Everything we tried was amazing!

- Wasabi Noodies w/ Flat Iron Angus Steak - SO flavorful! noodles were tender and not overdone or underdone. Meat was cooked perfectly and the seasoning was on hit. i also didn't mind the amount of veggies either, it was just the right amount. sometimes i feel like there's too much or not enough or it's like rabbit food or too much garnish, etc. i would come back JUST for this.
- Deep Fried Salmon Rolls - not what i expected based on what the initial name says. the seaweed wasn't overpowering at all and the cook on the salmon was just right. dipping sauce was a nice touch and the overall taste was just yummy!
- Grilled Sea Bass - OMG .. so yummy! I was told this was one of their best dishes and i have to agree it's probably one of my favorite dishes they have.

Service was meh. They're lucky the food is bomb, otherwise i wouldn't come back for the service alone. It was so-so, nothing special.

Overall - Wait time and parking are the worst parts about this place ... but it's totally worth the wait!
author: Rachael D.

description:
Winner winner Asian fusion dinner! Mad props to Alex S for using his mad Yelp skills (makes sense - he's a CM) to find this little gem. It's not cheap, but it's not that expensive either, especially since I'm used to DC prices, and the food was both unique and excellent.

The restaurant itself is small and unpretentious, with only a handful of tables, clean lines and minimalist decor. The feel was upscale enough for a work lunch, with professional service and trendy aesthetic touches like adorable all-white placemats with one little house shape hole-punched out of it (no Chinese zodiac calendar here). 

Our calamari and shrimp dumplings were good enough to order a second round, and ALL of our different entrees looked, smelled, and then tasted so enticing, the one would-be healthy-choicer who'd ordered a salad threw in the towel and ordered another entree.

My entree, the udon noodle soup with chicken, was excellent. Flavorful broth, tender strips of lightly grilled chicken, and a delightful surprise - my favorite element, floating cherry tomatoes that popped when bitten, releasing hot, zesty tomato juice in your mouth. Memorably tasty and fun. This little spot is worth cabbing to even if you're not in the neighborhood - the menu's locked and loaded with winners and unexpected treats!
author: Kristin M.

description:
Aside the fact that this place is TINY, everything else is FANTASTIC!!! Their food, service are really superb.

Food's a fusion of Asian and American, with an emphasis on fresh, local ingredients. Oh, and organic and tons of creativity! Personally I love the wasabi noodle, nom nom nom! And the pickled veggies appetizer are great to munch on!

Their wait staff are attentive and fast. I don't recall ever having to really ask for water, they always seem to be on the look out on these types of little things so you've a great dinning experience.

There isn't much an ambiance so you could feel very rushed come busy dining time. Maybe half a star off for that. But the quality of food and service make up for it!
author: May W.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in SF. Portions are good and reasonable for the price offered. Definitely try their crispy salmon rolls, so good with their wasabi sauce. Sea bass is also good, though it can be a bit oily.
