I came here recently and had their house special, cod with some teriyaki type glaze with fresh crab avocado rolls on top. It was sooooo good! Their mushroom rice was good as well, my cousin said that it was better than risotto!
author: Christina C.

description: Surprisingly dissatisfied. The sea bass was over rated. I was looking forward to a buttery texture but ended up having to cut every bite with a knife. The fish didn't taste fresh, instead it tasted as if it was previously frozen. The only reason I would give this place three stars is because of the flavor of the sauce.
author: Marlene T.

description:
"Asian Fusion" conjures up mixed feelings depending on who you talk to.  For those having extensive experience with serious traditional Asian fare, one can't help but cringe a bit in apprehension on the inside.

The House, however, will dash that thought right out of your head with just one (epic) meal.

Even before my friends and I had a chance to peruse the menu, we were intrigued by the presentation and intoxicating aroma of the ginormous entrees being served to neighboring tables.  As a result, we were torn about only ordering a couple shared small plates and a main dish for everyone with so many great options in front of us.  The solution?  Get nearly every small plate and go for broke on the main =D

We hit nearly every point on the spectrum with the top offerings being the much raved about Deep Fried Salmon Roll as well as the American Wagyu Beef Tartare & Uni sashimi special.  The salmon's great texture transitioned from fully-cooked flaky meat on the outer edges towards a raw core, all wrapped up in delightfully thin and crispy batter.  The horseradish in the accompanying mustard matched superbly and made each bite a pleasure.  On the cooler side, the sashimi was beautifully presented and included components such as paper-thin apple slices and bits of toast that complemented the creamy tartare and uni both in texture and flavor range.

Our Steamed Mussels and Coconut Curry Clams special were also huge hits and outshone all the iterations I've had in Boston.  The mussels had a lovely brininess and the curry makes you want to sop every last bit up with grilled bread.  While we're doing a little comparison to Beantown, the Maine Crab Cake here came out on top as well with light, creamy texture and not a hint of excess grease.

The others including Deep Fried Soft Shell Crab, White Shrimp and Chinese Chive Dumplings and Grilled Octopus.  The freshness of the ingredients made their presence known right away, but they didn't stand out nearly as much in general.  Go for them if you have the appetite, otherwise they can be skipped for the mains.

...Which leads me to the Warm Wasabi House Noodles.  Every one of us agreed that the angus flatiron steak was tender to the next level.  Ridonkulously tender?  Yeah, that sounds about right.  The noodles underneath brought back memories of Dan Dan noodles with awesomely spicy flavor.  Suffice it to say, I could've inhaled the entire thing in minutes and left with a glorious food coma.

If you're still reading this, thanks for bearing with me ;)  We couldn't finish without nabbing a dessert...or three in the form of Coconut Creme Brulee, Dark Chocolate Cake and the Blueberry Tart special.  Not a single one lasted much longer than 60 seconds as evidenced by the clashing of spoons left and right.  If you had to pick one though, get on that creme brulee - flawless execution rounded out by lovely passionfruit puree on top.

Lastly, the logistics.  The House is indeed on the smaller side with cozy seating arrangements and surprisingly moderate noise levels...always a big plus in my book!  Service was very helpful with ordering and consistently timely throughout the meal.  And the damage?  A mere $50/person with tax & tip included for what was essentially a DELICIOUS and filling 12-course meal.  Aim for about a week in advance to place reservations and come ready for excellent food that really lives up to every last bit of the hype.
author: Eric F.

description: Been going here for a few years now and it's consistent. Food is American- Asian fusion deliciousness. Always fresh and never disappoints. Small and intimate setting. Perfect for date nights. Make reservations don't show up ha!
author: Aubrey K.

description:
Oh wow.  A hidden gem in SF indeed. This place is hard to find, because of its modest entrance and cozy layout. But the size of the restaurant can't hide its trendy decor and absolutely gourmet food.
Living in Berkeley means exposure to countless Asian fusion food. Comparing to The House, those places pale, or even look cheap. The House gives Asian food am interesting twist out of your imagination, and in decent portion too. Both your palate and stomach will be satisfied. Try it out!
author: Tiffany Q.

description:
If you like Asian Fusion food like I do, The House is definitely up your alley! I had an excellent dinner here for my 3 year anniversary. The staff was very nice and all of our dishes was excellent! And if you're like my boyfriend and I, go crazy on the appetizers because they are ALL delicious. 

Recommendations: 
- Caesar Salad w Deep Fried Scallops : perfectly dressed and the scallops were tender and juicy with a light batter.
- Maine Crab Cake : Excellent plating, cooked perfectly with a delicious sauce to compliment. 
- Blue Lake Bean Tempura : Awesome crisscross tower of lightly battered green beans with a great soy dipping sauce. (This was my favorite!) 
- Grilled Sea Bass w Garlic Noodles : MUST GET! Perfectly cooked sea bass that went well with the green beans and garlic noodles. And I loved that the sauce was on the side to not over flavor the plate. 
- Mushroom Rice w Grilled Prawns : Just yum yum yummy! Perfectly grilled prawns that go great with the mushroom rice. Only downside is that I found it to be a bit oily.
- Crumb Apple Pie a-la-mode : You can definitely make room for this scrumptious dessert because it is THE perfect end to a delectable dinner. 

Tips: Parking is difficult in the area and the restaurant is small, so make a reservation.
author: Sharon L.

description:
I came here a few years ago after my friends raved about it.  I was disappointed with the "Asian Fusion food" and haven't been back.  Last week, I happened to come here b/c the original dining choice I had was actually closed for renovation.  Coming in as a walk-in, I expected to wait, and was told it would be around 20 mins - not bad for a walk-in.  20 mins had gone by, then another 20 mins and another 20 mins, and finally after 1+hr, me/friend got our table.   Well, I am not complaining.. but I am just stating the fact.

Appetizers: 
- Seared Scallops: one of the specials of the night.  For some people this might have been on the raw side, but for me it was perfect.  
- Deep Fried Salmon Roll was goood!!! 

Main Course: 
- Sea Bass with Wasabi Noodle was perfectly done
- Seared White Tuna (one of the specials of the night again), it was decent but not the best.  The California (?) roll that came with it was good though.  

I would say this time around, I have changed my mind about the food at this restaurant.  I am a little torn between giving it a 3 or a 4 stars.  The food is good, but the restaurant is small, the plates are a little lacking, and parking sucks in that neighborhood!  

Oh, almost forgot.. they actually have a few interesting Japanese Beer choices.  Ok, that did it to boost my rating to 4 stars.
author: Lillian T.

description:
So I had this project about a month ago that was just an absolute nightmare. Constant fire drills and just difficulty at every major milestone. So to boost our morale I decide to have a team dinner and to get us out of the office earlier than 6 for once. Searched around on yelp and The House seemed to be the perfect venue for a nice low key dinner with great food. 
Definitely make reservations for this joint because even when we showed up right at 5:30, there were people already waiting outside. Once the doors opened, we were greeted by the host and they quickly sat our group down at a table. The restaurant is definitely on the smaller side and has a nice cozy feel to it. We started to peruse the dinner and drinks menu and I was pretty pumped to try out the contemporary Asian American fusion food. For some reason our group was under the impression that the main dishes would be small so we decided to order three appetizers including the tuna tartare, crab cake, and the sashimi. I would say the crab cakes were a bit dry for my taste and the sashimi just seemed standard to me adding nothing creative. The Tuna tartare was solid but again nothing that really made me feel it was creative. 
For the entrée I ordered the Warm Wasabi house noodles with angus flatiron steak and my co workers ordered the Angus ribeye steak. Honestly when the plates came out I was pretty jealous of the ribeye my coworkers received but with one bit of my warm wasabi house noodles I was blown away. The steak was ordered medium rare and it came out perfectly cooked with the right level of pink. The noodles were just bomb. Great flavor and texture to them. I ate everything and was probably ended up licking the plate hoping that more would fall magically onto it.  My co workers devoured their ribeye as well saying it was really well cooked and just melt in your mouth good. I wish I had the chance to take a bite but I was way too busy with my dish to even notice the other plates. The portions were actually very generous as well which I was surprised about. 
The entrees were definitely the star of the show and I could see the creativity coming through. Although the appetizers were a bit disappointing, the main dishes had me leaving very content and happy. Hoping to be back to get more of those wasabi noodles.
author: Dan M.

description:
Came in without a reservation and the wait was about 20 min. They called us and we got a great seat. Our waitress was a serious, no-nonsense, no small talk sort of gal,  she could have been a bit more welcoming. 

I had the pork chop which was huge, juicy and covered in some glazed sauce which my sis hated, but I liked. (I hate teriyaki sauce). My bf had the shrimp with bonito flakes which he thought was decent. My sis had the seared ribeye and noodles which she liked. The creme brulee was very good (my opinion, since I loved the fruit sauce on top) and my sis thought the sauce was weird, but the underlying cream was very good. Can't please everyone. Parking lot was close by which was GREAT (unlike Clement St). I know this place gets great reviews, but my review is on the "it was good, but not great" part of the rating scale.
author: Thalia F.

description:
This restaurant doesn't need another review, but here goes.  The complaints about lack of authenticity baffle me.  This is Asian fusion.  It doesn't adhere to one particular style of Asian cuisine, which is partly why I like fusion food.  It's interesting and unexpected but familiar all at the same time.  I mean, unagi sandwich?  Heck yes, sign me up!

Unfortunately the sandwich wasn't on the menu when I went in March.  As much as I wanted to love The House, only one of the dishes we ordered was worth the trip, and that was the wasabi garlic noodles.  A little oily, mildly spicy, but full of strong garlic flavor.  It killed my breath, but my tastebuds didn't care.  The other dishes were less interesting in comparison but still good.  The pork that came with the noodles was a little dry.  Kurobuta pork chop with pomegranate sauce was slightly sweet and a nice pairing of flavors, but the meat was also dry.  The flank steak was well-cooked but not a stand-out dish.

The restaurant space is modern and rather minimalistic but charming.  It's a little cramped but creates a cozy atmosphere.  Service can be a little brusque, probably because they're busy.  Do make a reservation.       

A note to the out-of-towners: If you go during the day, the area is totally safe and walkable.  We didn't want to attempt street parking and found a structure only a couple of blocks away.  It was a cool structure (each parking space has a fortune cookie-style aphorism printed on the ground), but for what we paid ($9 for 2 hrs), it would have been more worth it to try the street.  Apparently parking used to be free on weekends, but it isn't anymore.
author: Tiffany W.

description: Everything is amazing.  The poke, sashimi, salmon and steak was so delicious.  Service was attentive, friendly, and memorable.
author: Anna C.

description: Best wasabi noodles I have ever had! This place is not cheap, but they definitely have good food. Had the unagi appetizer as well and that was pretty tasty. Good service. Good food.
author: Sam B.

description: Such a beautiful little spot on Grant Ave. I had the vegetarian curry noodle, it was super delicious! My boyfriend had one of the today's specials and was very pleased with it. Then we shared chocolate truffle cake for dessert. It was heaven. Highly recommend this place.
author: Hande D.

description: Wow Perfect portion sizes. Fresh clean food. Enjoyed some time here with close friends. Every dish I ordered was tasty and satisfied with the wait time and service. Plan on returning again.
author: Renity A.

description: The House opened on Sunday at approximately 5:15 and was packed by 5:30. They don't take reservations so if you don't want to wait get there when they open. The food was excellent. We enjoyed our meal. I ordered the lobster tempura as an appetizer. We ordered the special cod with the crab and avocado roll on top and the prawns. The portions are small so if you are watching you waist line this is your place. I had four prawns on my plate. Not a meal to fill up on but on the upside it leaves room for desert. Since it's located in San Francisco's north side probably a walk to place. The place was clean and the service was great as well. The staff was very attentive. It doesn't look like much from the outside but when I left at around 6:20ish the wait was one hour. Get there early if you don't want to wait. Just yelping out.
author: Kirk I.

description: The House was so good. The Sea Bass was incredible. The service was super attentive. Some people complained here about the decor. It must have recently changed because this place is really cool inside. The salmon rolls were super good. This place is totally worth a visit.
author: Jack M.

description:
Boy oh boy is this place good. The wasabi noodles with angus steak is unreal. I would get this every time if there weren't a bunch of other delicious-sounding dishes on the menu that I want to try... Also got the ahi tuna dish. The dish was put together nicely and the spicy mustard aioli was perfect. Though I'd recommend getting these two dishes on separate visits (similar tones of flavor in wasabi and spicy mustard).

The venue is pretty small and cozy, with some bare decor. It got a bit loud at times, making it hard to hear each other, but probably because it was a Fri night in a pretty lively bar area. Our party of 4 went at around 10pm without a reservation and only waited for about 10 min before a table cleared up. However I've heard the wait can get pretty long during more regular meal times so I'd make a reservation to be safe.
author: Will Z.

description:
omg pomegranate porkchooopppp. DROOOOOOLLLL. 

a MUST order. if you don't, you're crazy!
author: Dominique L.

description:
I've been here twice, once for dinner and once for lunch.  It's the best Asian fusion food in the Bay Area.  The place is really small, so make a reservation for dinner and go early for lunch.

My favorites are the salmon rolls and the sea bass, but I have to say that everything I had was awesome!  The food is perfectly seasoned and for the price and quality, great value!
author: Stephanie K.

description:
I had to write this review so I wouldn't forget how amazing it was. I visited some time back (winter) but still remember the food! I had the fried salmon appetizer and cod entree. Everyone at our table liked their food. 

The place is quite crowded and the wait was out the door. Luckily we made reservations the day before. I've read numerous complaints about the dark lit, crowded room with somewhat biased seating service. I think when you go to a place like this, you're here for the food not plenty elbow room. I wouldn't let that get in the way.
author: Alina T.

description:
Pros: 
Big portion
Tastes excellent
Cozy space

Cons:
Long wait
Staff was not very friendly
Hard to park nearby

I'd definitely come back again for the amazing food!
author: MsGood F.

description:
This place was awesome. My beau and I are often skeptical of places dubbed as "fusion," particularly "Asian fusion," so we went in with no expectations. We made a reservation a week in advance for a large party, and because of the small restaurant, we were asked that we finish in 1.5 hours because of the demand (which would later be confirmed, because near the end of our time it was already 10pm and another party was waiting to eat). The restaurant was PACKED. There's only a small bathroom in the back (and there's a very narrow pass to the kitchen, so be a wall--a very tall wall). 

TIP: A friend called in to special request their miso black cod...which would later be like a total clouds-parting moment.

Our waitress was very nice, We ordered several appetizers, such as their mussels and salad, which were all very tasty. It's good to buy several with a group and just pass it around the table. As for the entrees, my special ordered cod was EXCEPTIONAL. Instead of it coming with its sushi (which is made interestingly flat and long), I opted for their udon noodles. They brought this out on a separate plate, which made my meal of excellent value. The noodles are very good, remniscient of zha jiang mian (Chinese/Koreans, you knows it!). 

The sirloin and wasabi noodles were really good, which have a nice kick to it without giving you a nasal flare. Someone in the group also got the fish with squid ink risotto, which I was really jealous of. 

There was one staffer who seemed to be the manager, who wasn't a chipper girl when she came to our table or just in general around the restaurant. But, we had a good waitress, so this was easily pardoned. Great food, do your research on fan favorites, and enjoy!
author: Jen C.

description:
If they had a 100 star review this ave would get it ... Not only the best food in San Francisco, but quite possibly the best food in the world. 

Parking is impossible and the 1-2 hour wait seams like a lot for any restaurant.... But trust me it's not! This place is amazing.

I live in Encino but honestly would consider driving 6-7 hours just to eat here everyday. The food is that good. 

Please open a location in Los Angeles :)
author: Paul S.

description:
The two stars is for the treatment we received.  
I don't mind waiting for a table if I really want to eat somewhere, but the way these people run their business is ridiculous.  First, they tell me 30 -40 mins. Then that was up and they say another 30 mins.  Okay, then that was up and then they said I don't know might be a while.
Thanks assholes, instead of being upfront and honest with us, we wasted our time waiting here instead of just making a decision on our own to go elsewhere.
I won't be coming back here.
author: S G.

description:
Great place. Seafood is solid here. There's a reason why they've been around so long and never had to change their menu.

My wife always gets the seabass with garlic noodles and green beans

I almost ALWAYS get the pork dish, usually some form of kurobata miso pork. Its DELICIOUS. It like concentrated ramen gravey with a pork and a huge crackling. its delicious and a stunner.

Deep salmon rolls good. All the apps here are good.

This is one of the few restaurants we go back to in san francisco despite all the trendy new places.
author: jeff l.

description: This is one of my all-time favorite restaurants in San Francisco. I now live outside the city and return just to eat there. The food is unbelievably fresh, with wonderful mixtures of tastes & textures. The service is always perfect. I would just recommend that you sit towards the back on chilly nights because the front can be quite cold.
author: Dairsey L.

description:
Uhh, dengit San Francisco for having so many great food options!!! Why can't San Diego match up to your culinary caliber?! So not fair...

Anyway, The House has Asian fusion cuisine with a modern flair. The dishes come out and look like they could be the winner of a Top Chef/Iron Chef TV show. Portions are perfectly sized for single serving but if you come with friends, I suggest sharing to get the most out of this place. Sharing is caring!!

I've ordered the Steamed Mussels, Kurobuta Pork Chop, and Swordfish Curry, but I've TASTED the warm wasabi noodles, grilled sea bass, angus ribeye steak, and sesame soy glazed salmon (thanks friends!). What I recommend above all those dishes is the KUROBUTA PORK CHOP. It's served medium with a warm pink center so be aware for those who are squeamish about anything-less-than-well-done pork. And it comes on top of a mashed potato serving with grilled asparagus and pomegranate currant sauce. SO GOOD.

FRIENDLY TIP: Reservations are recommended but we were able to get a table as a walk-in. They'll jot down your number and call you when your table is ready so you can walk around Chinatown to kill some time, but you have to be back within 10 minutes from when they call you so don't wander off too far!
author: Jessica T.

description: Absolutely amazing! In my opinion, it's pretty tough to mess up fried chicken, but when you know what you're doing and add other amazing flavors on top of that in order to form a sandwich of awesome, you get the fried sandwich from The House. Side salad was adjust a hair too warm, but alas was not the centerpiece of this dish. The ambiance is small, but still enough to be a social atmosphere. Amazing and I will be back to see the other dishes that this place has to offer!
author: Alejandro C.

description:
All I can say is, "WOW". This place, is no doubt one of the most creative and unique places I've eaten in SF for a great Asian American fusion restaurant.

First tip: MAKE RESERVATIONS! This place is a small little hole on the wall (I think next to a sex shop) with not too many tables and fills up FAST! 

I came here for a nice date with my BF and believe me, it's definitely a GREAT place to go for a small two person birthday date or anniversary! 

We ended up getting the grilled garlic sea bass and a wasabi cod dish that I believe was one of the specials for the night. Our food came out RIDICULOUSLY fast for the quality and the presentation was PHENOMENAL! So professional and beautiful.
The fish was cooked to perfection and the small sides that came with it complemented the dishes well, The garlic sea bass came with garlic noodles, a side sauce of garlic, and green beans. All a great Asian American fusion combination. I definitely preferred the sea bass over the cod dish, but the cod dish was good too. The cod dish came served over some broccoli and very uniquely rolled California rolls. The wasabi sauce wasn't my favorite but not bad.

For a classic dish, definitely order the grilled garlic sea bass! You can't go wrong! But no doubt, if you're ever craving some quality seafood with an Asian twist, this is your go-to place!
author: Vicki L.

description:
Having grown up on largely Asian cuisine I used to shudder at the words "Asian fusion." Ever since my first time eating at The House I knew I couldn't have been more wrong. 

The wasabi steak noodles are a delicious signature dish. The sea bass entree was PERFECTLY cooked. So soft...the best sea bass I have ever had.
author: Andrew K.

description: I have been to many countries and tried steaks everywhere. So the ribeye didn't surprise me. It's the average taste you expected from this kind of restaurants. I don't think it worth the price but the location might explain why~
author: Nancy H.

description:
Went with a friend who is a regular here, had to be there early before they opened on Saturday night waiting to get in, but well worth it. 
Fabulous shrimp, salmon rolls for apps and a steak with noodles 
Would come back here anytime.
author: Kevin K.

description:
I used to eat there a lot . But not anymore. Any restaurant should listen the customer a little bit . I came there at 2:30 , and i wanted to order 5 fried chicken sandwiches . Restaurant was full and kitchen was working. But the manager women reject me with very rude way that kitchen is closed... 
I bet that any restaurant takes order in this kind of situation. Especially when they know u that u come there every 2-3days .
author: Jay M.

description:
You know the satisfying feeling you get after going through a lot of trouble for something? 

September 2012: My girlfriends and I wanted to eat here but failed to find parking after driving around like crazy for 1/2 hr! We gave up and I was pretty upset. 
October 2012: This time I RSVP for the earliest slot at 6 PM. My BF and I parked on the street near Union Square and took the bus to The House. It took longer than it would driving but it wasn't too bad. 

Finally I'm in! We shared the Ribeye Steak (OMG so succulent & juicy) and the Wasabi Noodles with Flat Iron Angus Steak (not a fan of Wasabi but was pleasantly surprised!). 

Parking sucks and the place is very small. However, you would pay at least 20% more at other upscale joints for food that isn't as delicious as The House.
author: Tessa H.

description:
My first time here. Got a table walking in. The service was good.  

The food was decent but not as good as I hoped reading all the reviews on here. Maybe I just didn't order the right did.

We started out with the tuna tartare and creamy scallop appetizers. Both were pretty good and reasonably priced.

For the main entree, we ordered the salmon in miso soup and the wasabi noodle with steak flank. The salmon was really good and we liked that a lot. The wasabi noodle was pretty bad. Too many mixed flavors and very greasy. The flank steak was good but we didn't like it with the wasabi noodle.

Overall the place was pretty good but not spectacular in our opinion.
author: Jason Y.

description:
Wasabi house noodle with steak on top- sooooo good!! The steak option was not available, but if you ask for it, they can substitute it. Also, the fried salmon appetizer was very delicious with the dipping sauce. 

I want to go back for the sea bass-heard from many people it was their favorite.

Small restaurant with a wait so I'd suggest making a reservation or going early. Parking of course is always difficult.
author: Sarah C.

description: I came here from a recommendation from my brother and I must say everything was absolutely amazing the food was so delicious we had to wait three hours but it was totally worth it I came in extremely full but I had a couple clients to take out but the food was so good I savored every bite and kept eating regardless I will definitely be back
author: Andy N.

description:
I'm a little confused how this place has so many reviews and so little "hype." I don't have to call months in advance to get a reservation, people aren't talking about it all around me all the time, but by golly, there's a delectable Asian fusion restaurant smack dab in the middle of North Beach. 

The House should probably be called something more like "The Apartment," since I think square-footage wise it's smaller than my apartment.

Grilled sea bass is definitely a must. Flaky, moist and just down-right delicious, you've got to try it. I've also sampled the specials (a crab/scallop risotto and kobe beef steak, plus the wasabi noodles are very unique).

Unsung hero of the night was the tapioca dessert. Normally I dislike Asian tapioca-desserts but this cool, vanilla-ice-cream-like product coupled with fresh mango is absolutely to-die-for.  (Yes, it earns all those hyphens)

As others say, don't dare showing up without a reservation and it's a 4 people or fewer kind of place.
author: Stephanie T.

description: Excellent and unique Asian fusion cuisine. We had a salmon roll, Caesar salad with scallops, sautéed cod, and Japanese wine. All were delicious.
author: P S.

description:
I've wanted to experience The House for a very long time but ex'ed it out because parking in this area is such a hassle.  The guy was taking me to a "surprise place", which just happened to be that focacccia bakery in North Beach (Liguria Bakery?) that I had been to many many times, so it wasn't like a new place for me.  We couldn't find parking but , no big deal because this was a perfect time to TRY to find parking and go to The House.  We found parking, very close to the place.

Well, it really was fantastic.  We walked right in without a reservation.  It was around 1:00 on a weekday.

We started with the famous deep fried crispy salmon roll.  The portion is generous and 2 can share. It is served with a delicious cabbage slaw and a wasabi dipping sauce. The sauce was a perfect accompaniment to the roll. The guy had clams in spicy broth.  This was a fantastically yum dish.  The broth was so good that he asked the wait person to leave the bowl on the table so he could anoint his udon soap (the next dish ) with the broth,  She wasn't even grossed out!

The grilled Chilean sea bass was the best piece of fish  I've had in a long time.  The ginger ,soy and garlic were in perfect proportions and the fish was grilled to perfection.  I would order this again.

We would go back to The House.  It is now on the rotation list.....
author: Bleep S.

description:
HmMm, Asian Fusion at it's best!

We had dinner reservations for a party of four, but we still waited approximately 30 minutes for our table. I am not too sure whether they are punctual with their reservations, because there were a few other parties with reservations that had to wait as well. I guess it doesn't hurt to make reservations anyway though, because the restaurant is tiny and it can get really crowded and cramped.

The menu was very brief with one dish that really stood out to me, the warm wasabi house noodles with Angus flatiron steak--so naturally I went with that! We also ordered two appetizers to share: deep-fried salmon roll with Chinese hot mustard (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZoZjbOYR-apY8XvommlNUA?select=msgiohj2b-V_lBcpOR2Ylw) and the blue lake bean tempura (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZoZjbOYR-apY8XvommlNUA?select=rNqngEvu6IK8pTsO6ENafw). The appetizers were beautifully presented and tasted wonderful. The deep-fried salmon roll was warm and buttery. The blue lake bean tempura was lightly battered and deep-fried to perfection. 

The main course, the warm wasabi house noodles with steak (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZoZjbOYR-apY8XvommlNUA?select=z6j2IuQYn5c3XrkRm_NwJA) was bursting with flavor. The warm wasabi noodles left a brief and subtle burning sensation in my mouth that was quickly neutralized with the steak and slaw. The steak was a little on the chewier side, but edible. I sneaked in a taste of my girlfriend's grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZoZjbOYR-apY8XvommlNUA?select=meORaV5F01gLsACwVapEeg) and it was heavenly! The sea bass was so crispy and blackened on the exterior, but still very flaky inside.

The staff was very knowledgeable and attentive. I am usually skeptical of Asian Fusion places, because their food is always lacking. The House is far form lacking; I was very impressed. I do recommend giving them a try!
author: Lien T.

description:
The short walk up to the restaurant was probably more interesting than anything I actually ate here.  Topless clubs, sex toy shops (one next door), and what looked to be hookers puffing on very pungent smelling weed. That said, it's also right next to Chinatown and lots of small Italian cafes, which really captures the bustling, eclectic essence of San Francisco in my opinion. 

The restaurant itself was easy to find though, in spite of being so small (probably the size of someone's walk-in-closet), due to the logo being so large and legible. Walking in, I was a bit shocked by how many people they were able to cram into such a small space, and, jumping ahead, was even more shocked later when a chubbier lady almost knocked my plate down with her bottom when trying to scoot in between the 8 inch space between tables, to get to her seat. So, I really can't say this is  a place with much ambiance, when you can also hear the word for word conversations of the tables on either side of you. 

To start the dinner, they provided us with a complimentary pickled cucumber side dish, which was way too sour and acidic. Then the server went through the specials and menu, and we settled on 3 entrees: 


"Warm Wasabi House Noodles with Angus Flatiron steak" ($19)- Okay, tasty enough, but pretty standard stuff. Tasted like  stir-fry, teriyaki noodles flavored with wasabi then topped with a layer of cucumbers, a layer of cabbage/red pepper (best part), and a layer of sliced steak. The steak was particularly awful, I got it in medium rare, and it was so chewy. It was hard to cut even with the steak knife that they provided.  Would never get again.. 

 "Kurobuta Pork Chop with Pomegranate Currant Sauce" ($25)- This is a  one inch thick and 5 inch in diameter slice of bone-in pork sitting in a sweet pomegranate sauce, with a side of mashed potatoes, 2 asparagus, and 2 slices of deep fried taro. The pork was tender, fatty and purposely under-cooked (we questioned the server about that but the server replied that it's "high quality pork", thus is okay?). The sweet, fruity sauce really overwhelmed the flavor of the pork though, so it just tasted like some kind of grilled meat covered in sugar/fruit. The best part of this dish was the steamed asparagus (so tender and fresh), and the mashed potatoes. The secret to the mashed potatoes was probably the infusion of kombu and bonito, a mixture I've had before.

 "Sesame Soy Glazed Salmon in Bonito Sake Broth" ($23)- This was a lady hand- sized slice of very tender, fresh, sesame, soy glazed grilled salmon sitting on a bed of slightly bitter, Chinese mustard greens called Jie Cai, topped with a sheet of seaweed, pretty slice of turnip?(didn't taste like anything, literally there for the prettiness factor), and a bit of fish roe. All this was sitting in a dashi broth and served with a plate of rice. The salmon tasted amazing, but everything else was pretty standard. 

Overall, I don't feel like the price of any of these dishes is all that justified. The portions are pretty large, but I would have prefer more amazing-ness over quantity. The best part of eating here was the night that followed. After leaving the restaurant, we strolled down Grant ave. for what was left of the China town parade,  and within 30 minutes my stomach started feeling queasy and heavy. Then, within three hours, I threw up $70 from my stomach and within nine hours, I lost the $18 that had made it's way into my intestines. 

Food poisoning aside, the 3 stars is really just for their food, just because I cannot 100% conclude that the food poisoning derived from here, and not from the milk and Cheerios that I had earlier in the day.
author: Patty C.

description: a great little treasure tucked away in between north beach and china town.
author: Susan L.

description: The sea bass is awwsome!!!!!!! Also the souce on the ribeye steak is amazing!!!!! Five star to the food and four star to the place. Except several tables by te window, other places are so dark. Maybe add more lights?
author: Ruisi G.

description:
Can I have their scallops FOREVER???????????

 We had reservations for 10pm on a Saturday evening and we arrived at 9:50 or so.  We got seated at 10:10pm and on to our table we went.   We got our waters immediately and some pickled cucumber dish.  It may have been because I was a little inebriated ( I had a beer before coming) but the pickled cucumbers they give you were delicious.  I saw people not eating them and I could not fathom why!  I was ready to just ask everyone if they wanted to donate theirs to me, but I held myself together.   Another tiny plate is $3 ...so don't eat them too fast haha (...I think I'm the only one that really liked them lol).

A few minutes later, a waitress came over and told us about the specials!  I don't remember anything she said except Halibut and mashed potatoes and I decided that was what I was going to get.  My boyfriend ordered the Angus Ribeye Steak.  And for starters, we got the scallops.  I'm sure you already know how I felt about the scallops...they were divine in all their buttery glory.  So tender and flavorful.  They only give you 3 so savor them while you can.  I really do wish I could have these everyday...if not once a week...basically more often than I'm having them now.  They are delicious.  Try them. 

Probably 10-15 minutes later the food was out already (mind you, it was late -1030 pm or so haha)! My halibut was in some creme sauce.  I'm not a fan of creme sauce but for that halibut, I'll eat anything.  The halibut was like butter.  Perfectly cooked and was a wonderful combination with the creme sauce.  The mashed potatoes weren't anything special, but it was fine because the halibut was obviously the star of this dish.  My boyfriend's steak was medium cooked.  It was really good and also tender.   I'm having a hard time articulating the deliciousness of it all, so you're probably just gonna have to try it if you haven't already.

I was already full after finishing my plate, which I pretty much vacuumed up, but I figured that it was a good decision to get dessert.  We ordered the strawberry rhubarb crumb.  Aghhhhhhhhh it was so gooooooood.  It came with a scoop of ice cream. It was lightly sweet and tart at the same time, both of which complimented nicely with the ice cream.  

The only issues I had with this place are : (1) that it's tiny, which is not bad...but seating could take a while without reservation; and (2) it's kind of pricey.  But I mean, for a special occasion or something, it's perfect.  

Also, the staff is nice.  The hostess was a small Asian woman.  She was very nice, patient and welcoming, despite the restaurant being very busy.   The waitresses were the same.  It just made the overall dining experience that much better. 

Do it do it do it go go go. Treat yo'self! It's worth it.
author: Vivian L.

description: Great meal this evening!  Zoey was our waitress and we had great service and she was very enthusiastic with her recommendations.  Our appetizers were yummy!  Dungeness crab and avocado toast plus shrimp dumplings.  Entrees were Chilean sea bass with udon noodles and green beans and the second one was udon noodles with flat iron steak.  One other item was warmed kale salad with blue cheese, avocado and toasted pistachios.  Each item was perfectly prepared.  It was hard to pass up their delicious list of desserts but we had no room!  We highly recommend The House!!
author: Dianne W.

description:
Celebratory dinner with old roomies in a dimly lit restaurant packed with people. We shared a salad and the two orders of the udon noodles (rumored to be the best meal on the menu). The salad had a little too much bleu cheese but it was good, nonetheless. We all agreed that the steak on top of the wasabi noodles was cooked really well. The noodles actually tasted a lot like a version of a popular korean noodle dish so it wasnt anything worth gaga-ing over BUT the meal was thoroughly enjoyed. 
+1 star added for allowing us to bring our own bottle of wine!
author: Katie C.

description: Long overdue review. I ate here about a month ago with my boyfriend and it was amazing! We had the mussels, ahi tuna, and ribs for starters. Everything has tons of flavor and was prepared perfectly! All of the entrees were delicious. It's a very small restaurant so a reservation is highly recommended. Great place to check out in SF!
author: Serina W.

description:
A friend recommended me to try to place and The House has definitely become one of my top 5 favorite restaurants in SF!  I got a reservation a week in advanced because my friend told me it gets really busy even on a Tuesday night.  Since it is in North Beach, parking as usual is pretty horrible so you should probably factor in that time too.  

The service was amazing and the staff were all really friendly and professional.  They had a lot of very unique drinks and food so I basically wanted to try everything.  We got the soft shell crab appetizer, Sea Bass and the porkchop entree, and ended with sago pudding and creme brulee for dessert.

ALL super worth it.  The bill wasn't surprising too which is always nice.

I definitely recommend this place for dinner for a special occasion!
author: Alister L.

description: Amazing food! Very small but worth the wait. The dumplings excellent. Had the special which was lamb cooked perfect.
author: Marianne G.

description: Food and service was excellent. We started off with the shrimp tempura and baby greens salad ($11). It also had a bit of avocados and apple slices which complimented the flavors very well. Just wish they would put a little more avocado in it. I had the kurobota pork chop ($25) and it was delicious. It was grilled perfectly and the sauce had a sweet savory taste that was absolutely mouthwatering. I usually don't finish my food but I ate the whole thing. My husband was also taking a few bites from my plate. He had the Kobe beef which I didn't try since it was too rare for me to eat, but he said it was good but not as great as my pork chop. Definitely a memorable place that I would come back to.
author: Karen L.

description:
RESERVATIONS A MUST!
They only hold the reservations up to 15 minutes and then they will try to accommodate you as needed.  Parking in the area is tough so come early.

This is a very small restaurant in the north beach area, which can get pretty crowded so beware if you are claustraphobic!  The decor is very simple and clean but the food makes up for its simplicity.  Asian fusion has always made me skeptic but this place proved me wrong.  The dishes are plentiful and very well plated.  I must emphasize very WELL plated for a little restaurant like this.  It would make you feel like you are in a fine dining dinner but in a smaller scale venue.  

What we ordered:

1. Deep Fried Salmon roll with chinese hot mustard- I loved this!  It felt like I was eating an eggroll with medium rare cooked salmon in the middle, which is hard to master.  The chinese mustard sauce, take it a bit at a time. It definitely is strong!

2. Warm wasabi house noodles with angus flatiron steak- I was scared for the challenge of eating wasabi noodles but this was nothing to be feared!  Green noodles with a hint of wasabi, which went well with the steak.  It wasn't overpowering at all!  Definitely unique in its combination!

3. Chicken breast with roasted portabella white truffle oil sauce- the meat was so moist and tender.  it went perfectly well with the mashed truffle sauce potatoes that came with it. my boyfriend was absolutely in love with it

We didn't get to try their desserts but we will definitely next time when we are in the city!  Definite must to try in SF!
author: Kathy D.

description:
I am conflicted about this place.

The food was EXCELLENT with quite an artistic twist on asian fusion. That part I enjoyed immensely.

However, I would like to point out that I had a reservation and STILL had to wait 40 minutes to be seated. It was almost as if it didn't matter that I had a reservation, I still had to wait in line with all the walk-ins. 

The service was impeccable and my waitress was very pleasant and attentive despite being extremely busy.

My biggest issue: while waiting for the bathroom, I saw a small cockroach. It wasn't huge and it was only a lone one but it was still a disgusting sight. I don't doubt that every single restaurants has some amount of vermin, it'd be impossible not to. But they should consider investing on a few roach motels.

Would I recommend this place? With a wait this long, it is almost not worth it but I would recommend it for someone who seriously wants to eat good Asian fusion.
author: John W.

description: Very nice ambiance.  Clean and bistro-like.  Good food.  Turn offs were the abrupt, short tempered head waitress.  Then there it was learning the curry is laden with Heavy Cream.   Doesn't mention that on the menu!  Would have liked to know that before ordering.  All that Heavy Dairy Cream and still not flavorful like a coconut based curry!   A nice head waitress and a more transparent menu of the ingredients would have made this 4.5 stars for our group of 6 last week.  The 2 friends who udon thought there was way too much oil.  The folks who ordered sandwich and wasabi noodles seemed happy with food.
author: Dna h.

description: This is our favorite restaurant for a night out in San Francisco.
author: Sara T.

description: The House never disappoints! My hubby & I usually get the melt in your mouth "sea bass" & the juicy tasteful "rib eye steak". The price is worth every penny! The workers are super friendly.
author: Cassy T.

description: I'm not sure about half the items that my friend ordered, but everything I ate was the most delicious thing I've ever tasted. I don't think you could go wrong ordering from their menu. It's usually very busy so I'd recommend getting yourself a reservation. A must eat restaurant in North Beach.
author: Samara C.

description:
This was the second time I've been to this establishment and again, was not disappointed. Service was great... a cheery Thai waitress was our server and was very friendly and attentive. 

We enjoyed...
Steamed mussels (we literally drank the broth after consuming all the mussels)

Pork Chop with pomegranate - currant sauce and mashed potatoes. This was mine and the presentation and taste was fabulous. A little more fat than I'd normally like, but the sauce was so good and the pork so tender and juicy, I barely noticed. Came with some beautiful flamboyant plaintain chips. 

Grilled Seabass with garlic ginger soy sauce, garlic noodles and grilled asparagus. I stole a few bites of this and the sauce was amazing. The fish very light and buttery. 

Steak. Also stole a few bites of this...no complaints. Super flavorful. 

Chicken Breast. Did not try.. but my picky 13 year old sister absolutely devoured it.


Dessert selection seemed average. Decided to venture elsewhere.

Only con... parking in North Beach. 

Was it worth it? 
Without a doubt.
author: Nicha K.

description:
Yay, one of my favorite restaurants in SF! 

This place is ALWAYS packed, and there's a reason why. I usually don't like asian fusion restaurants because they tend to muddle too many different flavors from different asian cultures and therefore loses authenticity of certain tastes, but this place seems to focus more specifically on Japanese fusion. Anyways, I've been here 3 times before, and it's always consistently blew me away in every aspect. 

I've had: 
- Mushroom Risotto with Shrimp: When the dish first came out, I was worried because I saw a plate of risotto topped with bonito flakes, and that's not the first thing you think of in terms of flavor combination. But, it was amazing! the risotto was creamy, but not heavy and the bonito flakes ended up being a great complement to the dish.  The dish came with 4 large pieces of grilled shrimps that seemed fresh, were cooked to perfection, and bonus: they were all peeled and cleaned. 
- Green bean Tempura: light, crispy but not greasy, and surprisingly flavorful. Though it was a really good dish, it wasn't anything extremely unique in terms of flavors, but definitely a good starter dish!
- Scallops with Ponzu sauce (special): Love this dish! This dish comes with 3-4 scallops on top of a ponzu sauce and topped with some greens. The scallops are cooked PERFECTLY and the sauce + greens add a very bright note to the dish. 
- Tuna Tartare with Nori Chips: pretty good! the nori chips are really good on this dish and the tuna is fresh and marinated well, but nothing too spectacular compared to some of the other starters they offer 
- Wasabi Noodles with Steak: YUM. This is one of the most popular dishes here. the noodles are stir-fried udon noodles, and it packs in some amazing flavors! It has a little bit of spice, but nothing too spicy. I think the steak can be a bit chewy but, nothing that can't be overlooked. 
- Grilled Seabass with Green beans: This is probably my favorite dish here. You get a choice of rice or garlic noodles- I would recommend the garlic noodles! They use udon noodles instead of the traditional egg noodles that are commonly used for garlic noodles, but the flavors are still great, if not better! The seabass is cooked perfectly and the sauce that comes on the side with it only  enhances the flavors. The green beans may LOOK bland at first, but they're also packed with a garlicky flavor without too much oil or grease and with a nice crunch! 

The prices might seem a little high at first, but for the quality AND the quantity of all the dishes, it's worth every penny! Will definitely be back again.
author: Judy B.

description:
Hands Down Awesome!

Not often you go to a place and you say "I will be back tomorrow"

Had:
Sea Bass
Ribeye Steak 
Mussels
Wasabi Noodles with Salmon 

All was amazing!!!

The place would get six stars, too bad you can only give 5...
author: misha f.

description:
I've been here 3 separate times now, and I've always left a little poorer but a lotta fuller and happier. 

The wasabi noodles are always good, but I've found that the steak quality can vary. It's ranged from medium-rare to well, so really emphasize how cooked you want your steak.

The reservations can also be a bit wonky, I'll make rez 3-4 days in advance and still end up waiting 10-15 minutes when I get there because they haven't managed tables properly.

The food is bomb though, so I'm really just looking for excuses not to rate them higher.

Oh! The name. The House isn't the most descriptive. Maybe something more along the lines of "The Awesome Ass Asian House of Mothaf*ckin Mouthwatering Dishes Replete with FlavorSplosions and Little Cute Houses Cut Out At the Bottom of the Paper Things They Put Under Your Dishes But I'm Not Fancy Enough to Know What They're Called."

Yeah.
author: Alex L.

description:
Yay yelp didn't fail me!

My fiancé and I came here for dinner from sacramento. It was definitely a challenge to find parking close to the restaurant so be prepared to walk quite of a distance.

The area seems a bit sketchy since there are strips clubs down the street, the restaurant is next to a sex store and there are many homeless near the restaurant. My fiancé was a bit bothered that this may be some kind of hole in a wall restaurant. Especially since we want a good experience.

Luckily it wasn't so bad when we walked in; it had decent interior. So once we have arrived to the restaurant, we were the first few that came in and we were offered a window seat. Of course I said yes bc I thought it was a bit more roomier than the rest of the tables.

Next we got our menus. We already knew what to order (thanks to yelp) so we started off with fried salmon roll with Chinese mustard, wasabi house noodles with flatiron steak and the sea bass with garlic noodles.

The fried salmon roll was a hit for my fiancé and I was quite surprised. To me the roll was delicious but the sauce was a bit strong tasting to me. However I have gotten used to the taste after a few bites. :)

Fiancé got the Wasabi House Noodles with steak. There were lots of flavors in this dish and some strong ones when you run into a little chunk of wasabi. The steak was cooked perfectly; juicy and tender.

I got the Sea bass with garlic noodles. Apparently they serve this dish with green beans so I have replaced it with cauliflowers instead. Not a fan of green beans. Ick! Well my first bite of the sea bass was quite amazing. As I sink my fork into the fish it just slides off. Then as I take a bite, it simply melts into my mouth. I was so in awe I immediately told my fiancé to try. He isn't much of a fish guy but he was willing to try and he actually liked it. Mmm... The garlic noodles were very flavorful however I thought the noodles were a bit greasy. I got tired of it half way through.



Overall, yum. Good one time experience.
author: Cee K.

description:
This was one of the best dining experiences I've ever had. My husband made reservations at The House for our anniversary dinner and it was amazing. 
The Deep Fried Salmon Roll with hot mustard was killer. I could have poured that mustard over everything, it was so good. We also had the Lobster Salad - really good but the Salmon Roll was the star of the first course. 
We took other reviewers advice and had the Sea Bass. I'm ruined for all other Sea Bass. Ever. It was AMAZING. We also had a side of Wasabi Noodles. My husband really liked them. I thought they were pretty good, as well. If you're not a huge fan of Udon noodles then you may not find them as fantastic as others did. I usually don't care for them but these were good. I just didn't waste too much room on them because of that Sea Bass. Did I mention it was amazing? 
We also order a special of the night, Short Ribs but as good as they were, they still paled in comparison to the Sea Bass. 
I cannot remember the name of our dessert but it was something with Strawberry and Rhubarb. It was so delicious. I'm not sure it's on the menu every day. Worth a try if it happens to be served when you visit. 
Like many others have suggested, I suggest making reservations in advance especially on the weekend because it's a popular place. 
I really do think this was one of the best meals of my life. When we are back in San Fransisco I will definitely make sure to go back to The House.
author: Jaclyn W.

description:
All I wanted on BirthdAy was Ahi Tuna Steak, and it looks like I came to the right place.  It was the best Ahi I've had, considering both SF and San Diego. They didn't over do the sauce and let the Tuna speak for itself. My girlfriend had the Sea Bass, and my buddy had the Tri Tip. All were amazing.
     The only thing issue was trying to get a reservation. I had to call about 10 times to get through, and they only had one spot available the next day. But hey, small place + incredibly good food = limited space. If your feeling like perfectly cooked meat, definitely go here.
author: Michael F.

description: This is the best Asian fusion restaurant I've ever been to. The menu is so creative and the flavor combinations are incredible.  The prices are quite reasonable given the good quality of food and service. The decor is unassuming, which I guess let's the food shine! Total hidden gem.
author: Sarah K.

description:
If the food in my own house was as good as San Francisco's The House, I'd never leave home! I'd also be 400 pounds but it would be worth it!

Located in North Beach, The House is one of the few non Italian joints in the area. This tiny place has very limited seating; I would say it can hold a max of 40 people. I think reservations are a must. The décor inside The House is simple and elegant.

The menu here isn't too large but everything they serve is beautifully presented and tastes amazing. My wife and I were so torn on what we wanted to order as our main entrees we decided to order three and split them, along with an appetizer and a dessert. This is all we ordered from The House;

Kobe beef papaya salad with tomatoes, cucumbers, pickled radish, fried crispy rice and a light vinaigrette http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZoZjbOYR-apY8XvommlNUA?select=hhhyCUWJzngXcB0wAvzzUw
Grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy sauce w/ garlic noodles and grilled green beans http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZoZjbOYR-apY8XvommlNUA?select=J5ine_2tytYXutJGQUE8QA
Kurobuta pork chop with pomegranate currant sauce w/ mashed potatoes and grilled asparagus http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZoZjbOYR-apY8XvommlNUA?select=cnmnDSGogP8ih3GfXG8N9w
Warm wasabi house noodles w/ angus flatiron steak and Kimchee http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZoZjbOYR-apY8XvommlNUA?select=_BUtkXfGpOXnElTod3woGQ
Chocolate truffle cake w/ vanilla ice cream http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZoZjbOYR-apY8XvommlNUA?select=k1VI2bW48YFwSlN7X4PvPQ

Every dish we had was exploding with bold flavors. Out of all the dishes I had, my favorite was the Grilled sea bass. It was perfectly cooked and melted like butter in my mouth. Actually, every meat here is perfectly cooked, super tender and extremely flavorful. The pork chop dish was great, especially the pomegranate currant sauce it was sitting in. The wasabi noodles with steak, which was recommended to me by my buddy Kent D,  was great too. The noodles had such a great flavor. I could have eaten bowls and bowls of those noodles alone. The chocolate cake was so rich and decedent. It was a great way to end a phenomenal meal.

The prices here aren't bad considering how fantastic the food is and how large the portions are. The service was top notch as well.

Honestly, I have dined at many restaurants in SF and The House could be my favorite thus far. My entire experience at The House was flawless. I can't wait to go back again.
author: Craig R.

description: We went here for my boyfriends birthday after it was recommended by a friend that lives in SF. We absolutely loved this restaurant and the romantic environment. Very small restaurant so I would call for a reservation but I can't promise it's worth the wait! The Unagi was INCREDIBLE and the steak was cooked perfectly! We will definitely go back the next time we make it to Cali!
author: Anna H.

description: The food is excellent we came in around 5 pm on a Tuesday and it was a great experience love the food here.
author: Alex C.

description:
It's a shame because they serve the type of food that is deserving of at least 4 stars but the ambience is that of a 2 star Japanese sushi joint you would typically find scattering the streets of NYC.  First, let me give the props. The pork chops were delicious. The pomegranate sauce had a nice balance of tangy and sweet and worked very well with the pork chop which was cooked to perfection.  It's a hefty size so you won't be aching for more when you are done. The wasabi noodles fell a bit short though. The wasabi flavor should have been more center stage but it wasn't and it just felt like we were eating plain udon noodles with slices of beef. Not bad but for all the hype, it fell short.

Now, what they could do better.  Look, I think if you're going to charge upscale prices for the food you serve, then you owe it to your guests to create the atmosphere to go with the price. And it doesn't take much - a table cloth of some sort, maybe some candles, flowers, little potted plants, or anything on the table would've been nice to create a soft and intimate mood which the layout of the space easily lends itself to be. Also, so much can be done with lighting. It was so bright in there, I think an investment in some softer lighting by the owner would help.  

So, to summarize imagine the contrast - tasty, creative well-cooked food served on naked, cracking, chipped yellow wooden table with bright cafeteria lighting.  Really, I think the space could do so much more and is screaming for a makeover.
author: Syddie P.

description: We had an excellent dinner and excellent experience at the House. The salmon was amazing, the short rib was incredible. They were accommodating of my 3 children and it was truly an amazing experience. If having a hard time choosing from high end restaurants in SF, give the House a shot , you will be pleased
author: Oink A.

description: I love their sea bass and grilled pork chop.  Just had their jumbo scallops on specials, which was amazing.  These all have the right flavored and have never been disappointed.  However, it is quite salty. Always get extremely thirsty after eating their sea bass.. If they could change that it would be perfect.  I know they are a small restaurant and very busy but I always feel very rushed when I dine there which doesn't feel good, fine dining is about the experience. They don't charge SF mandate fee here, which was a pleasant surprise. Parking is a nightmare.
author: Ree'Ay I.

description: This review is almost 1 year late but I still had to post. My husband and I were driving the coast this past summer and we spent a few days in San Fran seeing the sights and catching up with some amazing friends. It happened to be our 1 year wedding anniversary and we were looking for somewhere delicious and cozy to go. The House fit that description and more. It was so long ago that I can't even remember what we ate (and looking at the menu currently is making my mouth water so I have to stop). Here's what I remember- appetizers were AMAZING, entrees were even better and we just had to have dessert. Go here. You won't be disappointed.
author: Ashley M.

description: I got the curry noodles and it was really good. The vibe of this place is really sexy and it's just a really cute place. There's a really small menu though.
author: Ann T.

description:
This is a must try restaurant.  Sea bass and Cod are definitely my favorites.  It's hard to describe.  The flavors are so subtle and extreme at the same time.  The fish is beautifully seared, and very moist and flaky inside.  

Made reservations and was seated right when we walked in.  I told the waitress to bring out the dishes as soon as they were ready.  Big mistake on my part, I had no idea the kitchen staff was so efficient.  Minutes after ordering, our table was covered with the 6 dishes we ordered.  We couldn't eat fast enough.  I help going back between the sea bass, cod, and skirt steak.

Advice: avoid the scallop salad.  It's made with the small fried baby scallops.
author: Edward N.

description:
What can I say that hasn't already been said? The House ROCKS. We were sat within 5 minutes for our 8:00 p.m. reservation. We took some Yelpers' recommendations and ordered the scallops appetizers - sooo delicious and perfectly cooked, they almost melted in our mouths. 

For entrees, I had the seabass and my date had the flat iron steak. Both were amazing. The only downside of the meal was the Pinot Noir from Oregon($65) that the waitress recommended. But we both thought the price-to-quality ratio was not great.

Overall, this place is HOT right now, and rightly so. Can't wait to go back!!
author: Wendy N.

description:
It's not the most romantic setting, but The House definitely delivers some awesome food.

The Ambiance:

This place is pretty small and loud. It's not the best place to have an easy conversation without raising your voice a few times. The decor is pretty simple and sparse, and doesn't quite match the caliber of the food (but being Asian, and used to Asian places, I didn't really care too much). 

One unusual aspect of this place was that they seemed to give you time limits on your table. As patrons were walking into the door, the hostess would say "We can seat you as long as we have to table back by __ o'clock". Even though we made a reservation, we were still told that we had an hour and a half limit at our table. I understand that this system allows for more efficient seating and maximizes the number of diners per night, but it feels odd to be pressured to finish by a certain time. 

The Food:

Fried Salmon Rolls ($9): Each serving came with four "pieces" (two long and two short) of the roll. The rolls were cooked just enough for the salmon to remain slightly raw on the inside, which was awesome. Dipped in the hot mustard, it was a flavor explosion in your mouth.

Grilled Sea bass ($26): Following a personal craving for sea bass recently, I had to try it out, and it was very good. Generous portion of fish with a nice grilled flavor. It wasn't the absolute best melt-in-yo'-mouth sea bass I've had, but it was pretty damn close. The garlic ginger soy was tasty, but salty, so be careful and don't just douse your fish in it. The noodles and snow peas that complemented the fish were done well, and comprised a filling and satisfying meal. 

One friend got the Angus Ribeye ($25), and as a bonafide steak lover, definitely enjoyed his generous cut of meat. another friend got the Pork Chop ($23) and was also satisfied with his meal, particularly the pomegranate sauce that came with it.  

Service:

They allowed us to sit at our table while two of our friends went to find parking (parking blows around here), so that was cool. The waitress was brisk, and waters were refilled on several occasions. The food came out at a pretty good pace, which supports their notion of turning tables over in a timely manner. Overall, no real complaints here.

Although I get suspicious when a place boasts "Asian Fusion", The House will not disappoint in treating you to some awesome food without superfluous frills.
author: Greg L.

description: The House is a little restaurant in downtown San Francisco. Upon walking it, it seems very small and up-scale. It is really quiet inside, and the lights are pretty dim. We came here several times on special occasions. Since I am allergic to seafood, I always get the skirt steak with mashed potatoes. The meat is very tender and almost melts in your mouth. I believe you have to make reservations in advance because it tends to get pretty crowded here often.
author: Jordan W.

description:
Best meal I've ever had. Ever. It was absolutely amazing!

Mussles to start - they were incredible. 

Like all of the reviews I went with the Sea bass. I would give it 500 stars.
author: Rachel B.

description:
We ate the wasabi noodles an beef tenderloin, bean tempura with ginger sauce (sauce was ON POINT), BBQ oysters, octopus salad, grilled ahi tuna, mushroom rice, coconut creme brulee, mango tapioca and key lime pie!!

The flavors were refreshing and balanced - a little sweet, a little spicy. I especially enjoyed the mango tapioca and the creme brulee. The coconut in the creme brulee wasn't too overpowering, and created an interesting, yet subtle spin to a standard dessert.

As for the mains, I loved the mushroom rice - it was a a fusion of risotto and asian fried rice. The grilled ahi tuna was seared to perfection.

The servers were efficient, friendly and very nice! Great spot for a small group of friends/family.
author: Riana L.

description:
Have recently been back to the House. and all I have to say is you cannot go wrong with:

- the Scallops appetizer if they mention it on their "specials of the day"

- Seabass (with fried udon noodles) & Kurobuta pork chop for mains. Share if you need to.

You will leave Happy and satisfied. I promise.

Also do not forget Dessert and the Housemade almond cookies to go!
author: Amber S.

description:
After many years of coming here, The House by far is STILL my favorite restaurant in the city. 

Up to today, I still recommend the Angus ribeye steak that is on their permanent menu. Don't get me wrong, every other dish you get from their menu... I can almost guarantee you'll enjoy it. You'll want to lick your plate clean.

They have daily specials so definitely chime in on listening and order something. 

Remember to make reservations before coming here. I recommend 2 days in advance to possibly get your desired time. I do not recommend large parties more than 6 people here. Without reservations, expect at least an hour wait. Don't fret if you forgot to make reservations and you just have that moment of wanting to come here because it's North Beach, there's a lot of bars, cafes, shops, and even a park nearby to past time. They'll call you when your table is ready. But go an hour before you're actually hungry. 

I can't stress how good this place is any more, you just have to go try and see for yourself.
author: Nancy N.

description:
After so many years, I finally made it out to The House.

Appetizers:
I can't remember the exact names, but we had the tempura green beans and salmon fried egg roll. Both were great.

Entrees:
I had the blackened cod special that was awesome. My friend had their only vegetarian option, the wasabi noodles with sauteed vegetables.

Verdict
Call in early for a reservation, food is good and well priced, be prepared to spend a lot of time parking or pay $25 to park in the lot in the alley behind the restaurant, and be prepared for very limited options if you're vegetarian.

Note to The House: Please, please, please offer more vegetarian options.
author: James T.

description:
The place was tiny and very crowded, but the food was delicious!

We ordered some skinny fries as a side (they were a side for the steak which was the special of the day), and they tasted great.
We also ordered the deep-fried salmon roll and that tasted delicious. The spicy mustard sauce it came with burned, but it gave the rolls a good kick.

I ordered the sea bass with noodles. The food was well-presented and full of flavor. My friend ordered the udon noodle soup, which was a little bit spicy but still tasty.

This place is by far the best Asian Fusion food I've ever tried. Even though I didn't get a chance to try everything, I will definitely be coming back because the food was so yummy and worth the money.
author: Helen S.

description:
"Oh me oh my!"

It's hard to figure out what this place should be considered as since it's pretty much a tiny hole in the wall, going up a slight hill, nestled a block away from China Town.  It's pretty much almost impossible to spot the place out unless you know you're going there.  Either way, this place has to be one of the best dining experiences I've had so far in my life!

The first time we came here, my friend's relative that lives in NorCal introduced us to, THE HOUSE.  It was closed LOL. We didn't get a chance that day since it was full of exploring and sight seeing and such.  I believe we came back the next day and finally stepped foot into this fine establishment.  Yet being so tiny and confined since the seating was limited to about 10 or so, the ambiance of the place completely nullifies that.  It's really nice being in there and the staff is good. Moving on-

The dishes were very interesting as I've never had Asian fusion before of this quality.  My friend's relative mentioned a Pork Chop dish, that seemingly wasn't on the menu, at all.  So I guess it was a seasonal dish maybe?  But they were able to make it anyways.  We all order different dishes and had some appetizers but I don't remember the names of them since well its about a few years since I was there (this review is years behind LOL but I have pictures!  Just check them out and salivate)

So I'm going to be talking about the pork chop a lot, gonna tell you right now haha.  IT WAS DELICIOUS.  The currant reduction sauce was out of this world.  The presentation was amazing.  The Chop itself was juicy and the flavor was jizz in my pants.  I just couldn't believe how good it really was.  We told the workers there we're from Long Beach and we drove all the way here just to eat here, which is pretty much a half truth. :D

Fast forward another year or two, we're all back again here at the house and the guess what?  The Pork Chop is now on the menu haha.  It was a Kurobuta Pork Chop with pomegranate and currant reduction sauce.  We had it again (of course) and it was still delicious.  I honestly couldn't stop thinking about it for about a week after consuming it haha.  I honestly can't wait to come back and have it again, along with any other new specials or items.

(The chop!)
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=3V6n8hmTxwbM0Og7wzE4yQ&userid=Z4d49-dnAja73lufAlIORw

THE HOUSE!
author: Johnie H.

description: Yup!  Had the Seabass!  You should too!  Good food /  friendly staff!  Garlic noodles- awesome!
author: Vishal C.

description:
Small place but augh-mazing food. The wait was a bit much and God knows how I love to wait for anything. The staff was great and ensured we had a nice experience. I got to meet the chief after I sent a tip back to the kitchen staff.  Did I mention that the food was awesome!?

If you looking for a nice restaurant for a dinner for two that has great food - this is your spot. 

Avoid big parties, its a small place and be sure to book ahead - even then expect a wait. The wait is worth it though. 

d.
author: Donald H.

description:
Oh I've been craving for the house for the longest time. Its finally time to satisfy my craving and so I decided to do so today. I ordered the wasabi noodle while the Wifey ordered the pork chop. 

Wasabi noodle and the pork chop were made perfectly. It tasted very delicious and we couldn't stop eating it. The pork chop was juicy and tender. It wasn't tough like how some  restaurants made it. Its not dried either. The wasabi noodle is one of my all time favorite. It always delivers the right amount of flavor while the wasabi doesn't overpower everything else. 5 stars for the food for sure. 

The service today was very mediocre. Only one of the waitress actually smiled and helped us. They constantly refill the water but overall their facial expressions gave me and the Wifey the impression that they don't want to be there. It really soured our mood a bit in terms of enjoying the food. 3 stars for their service today.  

Parking is also another issue for this place. There's no private lot or parking lot so its all street parking. If you're familiar with this area, then you would know that parking is scarce. I was lucky today and found parking within 5 minutes and a block away. 

Overall the quality of the food trumps the parking and the service so therefore I will give it a 4 star.
author: Stephen W.

description:
The House is OFF THE HOOK. Each dish sings with layers and layers of familiar flavors and memorable textures with a twist - this is Asian Fusion done right!

A great place for a nice dinner out on the town - just remember to make a reso!

When I knew a foodie friend was going to be in town, I called a few days in advance for a 7pm reservation on Saturday night (they had only 6 or 9pm slots available so just as a heads up, this small space fills up fast!)

Every square inch in The House is occupied by either tables and chairs or the kitchen. Seating is tight but that also means you get to lean in closer to your dinner date's plate of utter deliciousness! Portions are generous and while I was stuffed in the end, there was no way anything was going to be left on the plate!

Our party of 2 was seated 5-10 minutes after check-in. We scanned the single-sided menu, which contained just enough starters and entrees to choose from (any more and we would've really had to flip a 4-sided coin to help us finalize). From the Warm Wasabi House Noodles with Angus Flatiron Steak to Grilled Sea Bass with Garlic Ginger Soy...really, everything on the menu sounded just exquisite -  no need for pictures!

Then, there were the daily specials. I'd heard the specials are always a good way to go here, so we went with our gut!

FOOD
I should've taken notes on the ingredients, but here's what I remember before my taste buds took over:

* BLACK COD MISO over mustard greens in a sweet soy sauce reduction (with wasabi-infused oil possibly?), topped off with 2 length-wise slices of lobster avocado roll. This should really be called "Oh My Cod" because surely you'll repeat an "omg" expression of some sort throughout consumption.

The cod itself is a perfect white fish that picks up flavor well. The chef cooks it to tender perfection: buttery, moist and subtly sweet meat, the thin layer of fish fat left attached, and skin that holds a slight crisp.

It sits on greens that are cooked as is, providing that refreshing bit between the buttery fish, sweet savory miso and reduction, and sushi roll.

Then, there are long slices of lobster avocado roll draped on top of the fish, creating a unique aesthetic and contributes a lightness to the Asian flavors from the rest of the dish. Also, that bit of rice is just great with the protein.

* HAWAIIAN HALIBUT over grilled mussels in a coconut curry with corn, okra and potatoes is truly a hearty dish. The smokiness from the lightly charred fish, grilled mussels, and vegetable components in the curry goes hand in hand with the super savory, creamy, nutty curry itself. A dish with more weight and body!

Yup, I came with high expectations and left with the anticipation to come back soon.

Dishes to order next time:
* Fried Salmon Rolls with spicy mustard sauce
* Warm Wasabi House Noodles
* Sea Bass

PARKING
Street if you're lucky or a parking lot. 
Portsmouth Square Garage in Chinatown is a 5-minute stroll away. Saturdays, 2-3 hours: 9$.
author: Karen W.

description:
I don't easily give 5 stars rating to a restaurant. The place is too small and too packed, it is also extremely hard to get a parking space here, but the food here is definitely worth everything. I am always cynical about asian fusion restaurant, but this one rocks.

Eeverything here is superb, I would say that you can find something like this nowhere else. The price is extremely reasonable for such quality and quantity. The kurobuta pork chop with pomegranate is out of this world, the pomegranate sauce is perfectly balanced, not too tangy, and not too plain. The wasabi noodle is great, it goes along with anything, but I would recommend the steak on top of the fish.
author: Hendo L.

description:
I give this place a solid 3.5 stars.  In grade school they tell you to round up if it's 0.5 or more, so here I am rounding it up to 4 stars (the things we learn in elementary school. LOL!)  It's really a 3.5 IMO though.  

I don't get why this place is rated so highly on Yelp.  Everything was good, yes, but it wasn't OMGIWANTTOCOMEBACKRIGHTAWAY good.  

Got the Caesar Salad with Crispy Scallops to share between two people for the appetizer.  Portion was perfect for two as a starter.  Scallops were sweet, but I wish they weren't deep fried.  Salad itself was pretty plain.  

We ordered the garlic ginger sea bass which was cooked to perfection.  It came with a side of green beans and yakisoba noodles.  Both sides were mediocre.  

The ribeye steak was perfectly medium rare.  It was a pretty big portion and the meat was tender.  It came with a small side of mashed potatoes and some broccolini.  Again, sides were ok...  

Ended the meal with chocolate truffle cake w/ coffee ice cream.  Dessert was pretty amazing.  Rich, but not too sweet.  Definitely check it out if you're here.

I feel that all the food was delicately flavored.  Presentation of the food is like artwork.  Very pretty.  

It's pretty tough to find parking in the streets here.  Supposedly there's a parking lot somewhere around there, but I didn't find it.  I got lucky and parked 2 blocks up...after circling around 3-4 times.

Oh...if you come here, make reservations.  Place is pretty small and without reservations, you'd probably have to wait outside in the sidewalk.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Sorry to say for the bucks you pay its just ok. Its good creative Asian comfort food. When we ate there there were a lot 3/4 of the restaurant was full of young Asian couples professional type.
Its a small restaurant so make reservation, there was a waiting line when I left. It's very tight close seating.

The food: its fresh, creative, and loaded with flavors of soy ginger wasabi and more. My favorite was the Wasabi noodles. I saw beautiful  rib eye steaks and huge pork chops at table next to us that looked REALLY good.
