We Had grilled salmon over wasabi noodles, asparagus with ginger and garlic, sea bass with garlic noodles, shrimp dumplings.

We had 1 app. 1 vegi, 2 entrees, 2 glasses of wine each, and 2 desserts and coffee. $186.00.
A little pricy I thought but the secret is like people around us were doing ... Share an appetizer and an entree. Or just get 1 entrees each. Portions are big from what we saw.
I'd go back for a causal lunch but not dinner, just because there are so many other better dinner places too choose from in the city.
author: Tropical T.

description:
This is probably one of the only asian fusion spots i've tried and actually had flavor beyond basic "sweet and/or sour": A lot of fusion restaurants have the misconception that they need to put a lot of sugar in their dishes. The House was an exception. Their use of spices, flavoring, etc, was perfect and not too heavy.

The pickled cucumber was alright; it is a very traditional and authentic asian cold dish. Complimentary though, neither adds or minus stars.

The gf and I shared two mains because we were DYING to try the coco creme brûlée with passion fruit puree. There was no way we would risk being too full to have dessert so we skipped having an appetizer.

The two dishes we went with were the flat ironed steak & noodles, and the sea bass (substituted noodles with mashed potatoes because we already had noodles.) The noodles were amazing, portion was pretty good. If you get the sea bass, get the noodles with it because the mashed potatoes were just ok. The beans were okay.

Service was professional. The place was packed and very busy but luckily we only had to wait ten minutes for our walk-in.

The place is good but space is tight and compact. Wouldn't recommend it for a romantic occasion but definitely try the food here!
author: Vicky H.

description:
I ate here a few months ago and had a great time. It was a little confusing at first being so small, and nobody really around to greet you at the door. You're kind of left standing there like an idiot for a few minutes, but oh well! 

We waited about 30 minutes for a table but just got a drink at the bar next door in the meantime. I had the roasted chicken dish and my date had ahi tuna and we were both very impressed with our meals. Super delicious! I am not a fan of seafood at all but I even tried the tuna and liked it. That never happens! It's a good spot to go on a date too, small and cozy. Just plan on waiting a bit, and its probably not a great place for larger groups.
author: Mandy A.

description:
CAVEAT: Maybe my experience was poor, but it I always give the restaurant the benefit of the doubt, however you won't be seeing me returning for mediocre expensive oily food. I'm not lying when I say, I have had some better experiences at most fast food joints. I usually don't write bad reviews, but we drove 30 mins to this restaurant to find a staff that really didn't care much about what they were doing... At least it seemed that way. Don't get me wrong our server was nice, but cold as ice. 

25 bucks a person for a greasy chicken sandwich with grizzle inside the fried thigh, I was grossed out. The noodles were sub par and far too oily and that is their signature dish. 

Wow,  I  must be the only person on Yelp that thought the food was mediocre, service staff disinterested, and nothing made me want to try more = appetite lost. Best part with food preparation. 

I didn't hate the meal just was extremely disappointed and wonder if it was just a bad day we went. Sorry to write a bummer review.  Yelp Onward
author: Sharif B.

description: I was told to visit this place when in sanfran, so we were walming on the area and gave a try, saturday. 2 pm...not busy bu fee people on the place, got a table/ booth. So listen to the 4 people next to us conversation... Not bad. Order  grilled calamari. Flavors were good,  it was a little undercooked. Had a plum wine( pretty sweet, tiny bottle)sevice was good
author: Larry L.

description: Have mercy this was some GOOD ass food.... I came here with my awesome co-workers for the first time last week and I was NOT disappointed one bit. I ordered the wasabi noodles with pork and may as well have licked the plate. It's a really small, but super cute and very clean little restaurant. Service was also very good. I will be back soon to try more from the menu!
author: T A.

description:
i came here a few months ago the last time i visited san fran and i still think of this place. SO FREAKIN GOOD.

i try to avoid asian fusion places but i couldn't pass up a friend's recommendation. i knew whatever dish i ordered had to have the wasabi noodles. think i ended up ordering the special of the night which was some sort of fish (seabass?) and i substituted for the wasabi noodles. i was not disappointed.. pretty sure i wanted to lick my plate! can't wait for the next time i'm back to san fran.

p.s. 
we also ordered the deep fried salmon rolls. they were good but did not leave a lasting impression like these damn wasabi noodles had on me...
author: Mimi T.

description:
Dude. After eating here, my stomach was hurting....in a good way. 

I ate so much because everything was so delicious. My SO and I came here the day after valentines. We had:

Small plates: fried salmon roll, the Maine crab cake (must have!) and the mussels. 
Entrees: sea bass (must have) and wasabi noodles with the angus flat iron steak. 
Dessert: bittersweet chocolate cake and the Thai tea panacotta. 
With a glass of wine and a glass of beer, our bill came out to $120. 

We cleaned our plates off. The couple next to us said "Wow, you guys killed ALL that?" I wasn't sure if I should be proud or offended so I'm proud. 

Anyway, this has easily become one of my top ten restaurants because the food was excellent and the price was fair. A very enjoyable dinner!
author: Louis N.

description: Even the lunch menu was great. Must try the fried salmon rolls and grilled sea bass with garlic noodles. Overall most of the food is highly contained with sodium I guess.
author: Tae Eun K.

description:
The wife has been trying to take me here since she went with her girlfriends, and i was hesitant when the term fusion was used to describe it but glad i went. 
Food was good, and i really liked the mussels, and the soft shell crab apps.

Very cool little spot near little italy and good place for date night. Not so great for parties but they seem to accomodate them. No rsvp on a saturday night, but only had to wait for like 20 minutes and they took our number to text us when it was ready so we could grab a beer at the thai place next door.
author: Johnny C.

description:
This place is small and parking sucks, because well, it is SF. Make reservations ahead of time. 

Appetizers: 
Deep Fried Salmon roll - just ok, almost dim sum like, wasabi  sauce was strong.
Steamed mussels - I'm not a fan of mussels but my friends liked the dish.
Special appetizer of the day: pan fried scallops, this was really good, they should add this to the regular menu. 

Entree:
Flank Steak with Wasabi Noodles - Noodles had good flavor with wasabi, so if you don't wasabi I do not recommend this. Flank steak was good. 
Grilled Sea Bass with garlic noodles - Good flavor on both, would recommend it.
Ribeye Steak - Just like any other steak but with pan fried garlic on top, yum!
Kurobuta Pork Chop - the best dish of the night, highly recommend this. Thick cut of pork chop, juicy. The sauce was sweet and complimented the savory pork chops.

Dessert menu did not look appealing so we skipped it. 

Service, they were all really nice, service was quick, especially the appetizers. Came on a Sunday night at 8:30, it was full, waited not too long but we made reservations. 

My friend had to drive around for 30 mins to find parking.
author: Shirlene N.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants if I am feeling down and I wanted food that was good and a place that is up lifting.

I love their appetizer where they wrap salmon around nori and fry it.

I know I'm not suppose to, but their black cod is alway good.  I'm not a huge fan of their noodles.  Short ribs are great, dessert is always good.
author: Tony T.

description: Wasabi noodles is what I dream of.....
author: serina c.

description: I started my meal with plum wine. It came with an actual plum in the wine. In all my years of ordering plum wine, I have never experienced such a treat! Then our scallop appetizer arrived. They were very good. The sauce was superb and they were cooked perfectly. Unfortunately, there were only three scallops on the plate. I wanted more! My husband and I both ordered the steak on the flat noodles. They were very tasty. We finished the meal with tea and creme brûlée. The creme brûlée melted in my mouth. I would recommend everything!
author: Lisa O.

description: Compare to the majority of other places which mostly cooking just "food" this place offering something what I can call  "the restaurant food". The place maybe a bit more expensive then other places but offering definitely more.
author: Dmitry G.

description:
Returned for a second visit near 6 months after the first. What took me so long anyway? Brought my wife's friend who was visiting from Korea so that she could enjoy the delectable goodies that they serve up at The House.

In order to multiply our enjoyment, we had the ingenious idea of sharing all our dishes. Thus we proceeded in devouring each dish one by one.

To start we had the tuna tartare with nori chips and a half dozen raw oysters. I enjoy trying different types of tartare at the many restaurants that I visit. I must say that The House has one of the best. It's the perfect blend of tangy, spicy, and fresh tuna taste along with the unpretentious chips that melt away easily into the background. The oysters were good, I enjoyed the spicy sauce that accompanied the oysters. It seemed to be their own blend that precluded the need of tobasco or cocktail sauce. Although I think I prefer tobasco.

We had the sea bass and pork chops again and they were excellent, AGAIN! I just love biting into that sea bass. The sudden charcoal grill taste combined with the seared outer skin and soft inner sea bass is to die for. I don't understand how they cook the fish like this and not dry it out. Tricky tricky asian fusion cooks... :)  The pork chops were soft and inviting and paired well with the pomegranate sauce. I still like the sea bass better and my wifey liked the pork of course. I swear she just likes to choose the opposite of whatever I choose...

Since we had a third person with us we had the opportunity to order a third and NEW dish this time. (The real reason for coming to The House with a third person comes through.) We had the chicken with white truffle oil. The name of this dish does it no justice, neither does the real name on the menu. The chicken is cooked to perfection, nice and juicy on the inside and definitely not dry. The sauces surrounding the chicken were the kicker. This is truly what fusion is about. There was some combination of curry and other sauces that were just absolutely KILLER. None of us could stop eating the chicken, we all wanted the last piece.

Another great dinner at The House. How can I not give this place 5 stars when I always walk away pleased? The prices are also pretty reasonable for a nice restaurant. We had 3 appetizers, 3 main dishes, and 1 dessert for $120 not including tip. I'd say that's a pretty reasonable price for what we had.
author: Tommy B.

description:
This is a small place, so I recommend reservations! It fills up quickly, so even if you get there early like we did and it feels empty, don't worry. The menu is fairly extensive with lots of yummy-sounding dishes (there were yummy specials that night, too!). The whole feel of the place is super different from the food. The food is a little fancy and so good, but it feels like a dressed-up hole in the wall joint.

There are steak, seafood, and chicken (but no vegetarian) dishes to choose from. I can be a bit picky in food I like, but there were multiple dishes I would have liked. I ended up getting a mushroom dish that was really tasty. We were absolutely stuffed when we left, but enjoyed the natural light flowing it the big window, the simply-decorated tables and the courteous service.
author: Aly M.

description:
Wandered in here for lunch around 1 PM on a Saturday.  We were able to sit down just about right away despite the fact that this place is TINY.

The service here was generally prompt and attentive.  Bonus points for making sure water glasses were topped off.  My glass never got below half full the whole time I was there.

I had the curry noodles with veggies and tofu, which was delicious.  I thought maybe it could use just a little extra heat, perhaps.  I didn't really notice any heat while eating the noodles/tofu/veggies together.  I did notice it when drinking the curry broth on its own, which I thought was especially good.  I ate it all, though it was a fairly hearty portion.  $10 for the noodles, so I thought it was a great value.

I'd be happy to pop in here again if I'm nearby.
author: Brent T.

description: If you are a foodie & don't care about ambiance or decor then this is the place for you. The food is just delicious!  The Sea Bass, the salmon roll, the wasabi noodles & the mussels were fantastic. Definitely a must if you are visiting Frisco.
author: Sean H.

description:
It was my first time trying "The House" and I was with a friend just to treat him out to a nice birthday dinner. The restaurant is rather small and tight. Because it gets so much business, it's packed tight in there. The wait (depending when you come) can be painstakingly long. I believe we arrived at 6PM for dinner, but the wait was roughly 1.5 hours. Honestly, we didn't mind. There's plenty to do in the area to kill time. Walk around the streets of the area and grab a cup of coffee or something.

SERVICE: Once we were seated, our waiter was pleasantly polite and informative of the specials and filled with recommendations for us first-timers. Service was decent. Very polite, courteous, and well-informed. Given that it was a busy time, the servers could not get to us as quick as they possibly could have wanted to. Which is perfectly understandable. 

APPETIZER: Raw Oysters
It was my first time trying raw oysters. And for my first time, I fell in love. I think I love eating raw oysters now. The oysters were fresh and did not have that overpowering fishy smell. The sauce with the squirt of lemon on it was utterly delicious. Luckily, my friend did not prefer oysters. More for me! 

ENTREE: Rib-Eye Steak
I haven't had steak in a while, so I was pretty excited to finally have some. First off, the plating looked beautiful. It looked like it tasted amazing! The steak was cooked to perfection. I ordered it medium-rare. And it was cooked just the way I wanted. Not too difficult to cut into or chew. Every bite was filled with tender juices and sweet Jesus have mercy... I love meat. Surprisingly wolfed down the whole thing as ladylike as I possibly could. The mashed potatoes that accompanied the dish were pretty good, but obviously did not overpower the taste of the steak.

DRINKS: Tea
I cannot clearly remember what tea I had ordered, but I believe it was some sort of black tea. It was relatively strong and heavy in taste. Slightly bitter, but I didn't mind. As a tea connoisseur, I've developed a taste for tea and I thought it was quite aromatic. However, probably would prefer it if the taste was a little lighter and not so strong. I would assume most would find it a bit too strong or bitter.

However, keep in mind that you are in San Francisco and it is notorious for it's lack of parking spaces. We got ourselves valet parking nearby, so it was no big deal for us. 

Regardless of the inevitable horrors of city parking, I highly recommend giving this restaurant a try! The wait is a bit long, but if you've got time, it's worth it. The portions are more-than-enough; maybe even generous. Definitely swing by and try it out!
author: Jessica X.

description: This is such a quaint little restaurant located in Little Italy. I highly recommend making reservations as the wait time is long. However, if you did not make reservations, there is a dive bar right next door that you could wait and have a drink. All in all, I highly recommend this restaurant. The salmon roll with hot mustard sauce is a must order appetizer. There Seabass was cooked to perfection which was paired with Wasabi noodles. The service was great, they were prompt and very knowledgeable of their menu.
author: Myrene M.

description: The food is excellent. As all of the other yelpers have stated, the sea bass is mouth-watering delicious. I'm a huge sea bass aficionado, and this is one of the best I've had (even compared to high-end east coast restaurants, NYC etc.). The service was polite and quick - can't complain. Will definitely return again.
author: Dewan F.

description:
Made reservations for my girlfriends birthday dinner a week early so getting seated was no problem! We have heard good things about this place so our expectations were high. Our waitress was really polite and patient with us and the service was overall excellent but we weren't really acknowledged at the door. We started with the Deep Fried Salmon roll and the the calamari. A perfectly seared piece of salmon wrapped in a crispy exterior, the salmon roll was freakin' amazing. The calamari on the other hand was just as good. I ordered the wasabi noodles with steak and my girl friend got the Sea Bass! The wasabi noodles tasted really unique and the steak was cooked just the way I liked it, medium rare. The Sea Bass was hands down the best dish of the night, the meat was heavenly when combined with the sauce they serve it with SO PLEASE ORDER IT! I was very satisfied with the meal.

The House does Asian Fusion right.
Pro tip! The lychee iced tea is not sweet.
author: Andy C.

description:
Wonderfully great experience, it's worth every minute.  

Tucked away, in a slightly non-descript is a special little place.  It's Asian food, sure; and one can proclaim to the high heavens; with the might of Joey Laurence "WHOA" once you take your first bite.  The food service and quality was that mind shatteringly-smack_your_cousin-kick_him_in_the-shin-good.  

I dare say, with a place that has over 2000 reviews on Yelp, there has to be something that works.  I took my Seattle taste buds here, and armed with a more than attractive girl to help keep me honest, decided to find "The House."  The décor is simple and homely; the tables and chairs close, everyone her is cozy, without being cramp.  The first detail you might notice after being seated is the little house cutout in the table placement.  If you know the finer details like that are taken care of, you have to expect the food will have a focus on detail.  

Looking at the menu, it's simple, one page of goodness.  They seem to understand that a good kitchen with a focus, should stick with that focus, with only maybe 15 small places, and 10 main items.  We did the following; two small, and two main plates. 

Steamed Mussels 
Tempura Shrimp on Greens
Sea Bass with Vegetables
Seared Ahi Tuna. 

Here we go... 

Steamed Mussels were cooked wonderfully, full of flavor, extremely soft and tender. The sauce was light and just enhanced the texture of these sea found delights.  The Tempura Shrimp was a visual sight, a mountain of greens, with shrimp and avocado.  What makes or breaks a dish like this was the cooking of the shrimp.  It was a delicious lightly fried masterpiece.  The shrimp were tender, and juicy.   The greens balanced it out perfectly.

Sea Bass, is an animal that is fatty, full of love fish.  it makes the world feel better; and in this case, it does make the world feel better.  It's blacken, just slightly on the top and bottom, a crust that balances the juicy flesh in the middle.  It was soft, fall apart goodness-that-would-make-you-scream-in-joy-with-new-found-salvation. Yes the clouds parted for this meal.  Mine on this night was Seared Ahi Tuna.  A towering piece with three richly cut pieces of tuna, on the slopes of a rice and vegetable hillside; with rivers of what I recall, a spicy aioli.  The fish superb, the flavor textures were perfect, and if you didn't know it, eyes closed, you might imagine yourself in pure Zen.  

So "The House" proves to be good-amazing-loving-warm-from_the_heart food, but what is that feeling you have when you are done?  Pure Satisfaction.
author: Andrew L.

description: Went with a group of 6, only two of us vegan and, unlike some hotspots where you can be treated to something "with the meat left off", The House really stepped it up and made us feel like they cared. The food and presentation is really remarkable. Everyone at our table was thrilled and beyond. Wasabi noodles with tofu and vegetables are in my dreams! Great, small, excellent wine list. You may get contact high from the street scene outside but, you'll probably enjoy your dinner even more. One bit of silliness, only two credit cards per table. When you have 6 or 8 people, that just doesn't work and we saw others who were challenged by it. They should rethink this. Otherwise, a solid "HELL YES, we'll be back!!!".
author: Michael N.

description: The food was delicious but it was quite pricey for the serving size that we got. Otherwise, the service was great and the atmosphere was fantastic.
author: Serena L.

description:
Have you ever fallen in love? When I first took a bite of what I order, it was like I fallen in love. There are no words to describe how much I love this place. 

I absolutely love this place. It's a place you wouldn't expect to be so mind-blowing in your mouth because the restaurant is so small. It's not even noticeable to the naked eye because you could so easily just walk past this restaurant when there are so many many other restaurants that are in that area. 

Anyway the first time I came here I ordered the steak. OMG...it was so delicious. There is no steak in my library that compares to this steak. I mean it's not even a restaurant made to eat steak but its just so flavorful and it even has the look. They chopped garlic into little pieces and roasted it and put it on top of the beautiful steak. I took a bite and I just fallen in love. I usually hate eating the fat on a steak...but the fat in the steak was so wonderful that the whole steak was devour by me in a matter of minutes.

WELL I also tried the appetizers which was pretty good. It wasn't anything I clearly remembered so it doesn't really matter if you get it or not. Anyway my other two friend got fish. Not only was my steak absolutely mind blowing but the seafood they got was astonishing. They paired up with the fish so well that you just don't want to stop eating it and just lick everything off the plate. The fish is so smooth and tender that GAH I really wanted to go back to SF right now to eat it. 

This asian fusion restaurant is small and have a small menu but everything on the menu is just wonderful. If you live in SF and you haven't tried this place out yet then you are absolutely missing out on one of the best place ever. Go now and try it I tell you because if i live in SF you would see me day and night. :)
author: Ernest Y.

description:
This is my FAVORITE restaurant. I've been coming to The House since I was 10. (Yes, I was a spoiled baby!) I still remember their location on Irving St, which was just blocks away from my house. 

Anyway, here are the must haves:

Appetizers:
Deep fried salmon Rolls - The Spicy Mustard sauce has a nice kick! 
Deep Fried String Beans - Nicely battered with tasty dipping sauce

Main Dish:
Chicken Curry Noodles - MY ABSOLUTE favorite!  
Seabass - Another childhood favorite! This will literally melt in your mouth! 
Flat Iron Steak - So tender and juicy 
Wasabi Noodles with Salmon - The wasabi taste is light but it's soooo good!

Dessert:
Mango Tapioca
Chocolate Cake
Bread pudding 

I basically love everything they have! 

Warning: Parking is hard to find so come early and make a reservation because it's always crowded!
author: Daniel S.

description: First time here tonight. Waited an hour and a half because this spot was fuckin crackin. Food was hella good, waitress was really nice but... I don't think I can justify waiting an hour and a half for this food. Don't get me wrong... it was absolutely delicious and I will be coming back here to try more food but waiting for an hour and a half, the food better make me cream my pants if I gotta wait that long. Highly recommend people at least try it! Everything I tried was dericious!
author: Kevin J.

description:
Brought a date here - I noticed that this was a top yelp restaurant, and i wanted to try it out. 
 
I had a reservation, and was sat immediately, there was quite a long line outside - def recommend getting a reservation booked!

The server told us about quite a few interesting specials, so we ordered a mix - the scallop app special and the unagi app - the grilled scallops were the highlight of the meal - unagi was AMAZING! 

Date ordered the seabass and garlic noodles, which he loved.  I had the ribeye.  It was cooked perfectly, but had a weird teriyaki sauce on it, which i thought was not very delicious - it almost felt kinda wrong on a ribeye.  I think its just my personal taste, because my date finished my plate and was enthralled.

To finish things off, i had a fun dessert wine (i can't remember what it was - sorry - but it had a pickled plum in the sweet wine) and date had a lovely coconut creme brûlée.

While I am not a fish enthusiast, I can appreciate a restaurant who does asian fusion well, thoughtfully and perfectly served.  I had a great experience, as did my company.  Service and food was excellently executed.   

Bravo, House!   Thank you for a great date night!
author: CC C.

description:
Q: How do you know you really like a place?

A: When you make a reservation for your next visit during your current one.

Yep, I am smitten with The House and grateful that I made it a last minute addition to my "to eat" trip hit list. The place is small and a not-so-hidden gem, so you're best served making reservations.

On both visits, my dining companions and I opted to skip the specials and focus on the regular menu items. The menu consists of an assortment of starters and mains, by sharing we were able to try a nice cross-section of the menu:

*Ahi Tuna Tartare - excellent, one of the most flavorful tuna tartares I've ever eaten
*Deep fried salmon roll - delicious and the chinese hot mustard will do wonders for any congestion!
*Maine crab cake - inventive presentation and teeming with crab. This was the one dish I would've passed on, but only because it was too rich for me.
*Steamed mussels - good, but average compared to the other items I tried. 
*Grilled sea bass - OMFG, how do they make this fish so moist and juicy?! The fish practically melts in your mouth Served with udon noodles and green beans, it's a can't miss dish. Did I say OMFG?
*Grilled ahi - not as amazing as the sea bass, but still an excellent dish. Generous amounts of ahi are presented over sticky rice and spinach.

We capped off each dinner with a slice of chocolate cake. Dense and rich, almost fudge-like, and served with coffee ice cream it was amazing and a perfectly decadent way to cap off an already decadent meal.

Service was friendly and prices seemed reasonable for the quality and quantity of food delivered. The House is definitely on my short list of places I would love to return when I get back to San Francisco.
author: Mary T.

description: Absolutely phenomenal meal here on a Wednesday night. Do yourself a favor and choose from the daily specials: we enjoyed fresh, crisp oysters; perfect scallops; savory, tomato-y mussels; and the best black cod (sablefish) that I have ever had. Crispy on the outside, tender in the center, and accompanied by a flavorful, yet not overwhelming, ponzu sauce. We finished with a smooth and creamy coconut creme brulee, cut with a tangy passionfruit drizzle. The space was small but not cramped, busy without being noisy, and warm in ambience. Our service was friendly and efficient. I look forward to returning!
author: Katherine M.

description:
I'm a huge fan of the house.  I live and work nearby, and I come here often for lunch meetings and dinners.  

Service has always been warm & friendly, even though they are always packed.  

I love the food.  It's described as asian fusion, but I'd say less asian and more american-style fusion.  The scallops are amazing every time.  The angus steak on the noodles is always worth an order.  I'm trying to think of a main entree that I haven't enjoyed and I'm coming up blank.    

Just go in, tell them to surprise you, and you can't lose.
author: Rob N.

description:
My wife and I went to The House for my birthday dinner last Thursday, and had a great time.  There were a few drawbacks such as the service and noise levels / seating arrangement, but all in all, we had a great experience.

We started with a beverage (beer and wine), and 2 appetizers:  Scallops in a Ponzu sauce (on special) and the Crab Cake.  We enjoyed both, but were more impressed with the scallops which were prepared perfectly.  The sauce and veg complimented and made them quite delicious.  The crab cake was large and felt like it had a lot of filling (non crab) inside, but it was still tasty, and the sauce was good.

I had the famed Sea Bass with garlic noodles.  The bass was cooked perfectly and was very delicious.  I kind of liked it simply grilled rather than dipping it in the accompanying sauce, but that's just my preference.  The sauce actually tasted great on the noodles and the green beans that came with the bass.  My wife had the mushroom rice with grilled prawns.  She and I both thought this was OK.  

We waited forever for our 2nd drink, and in fact, had to ask a server who was not our server if we could order a drink after about 10 minutes of sitting there with an empty glass.  Also, in the section in which we sat, the tables were maybe 6 inches apart from each other.  Therefore, it's as if you're dining with the people on either side of you which makes any conversation (if you can hold one given the volume in the restaurant) awkward.  I would go back, but would try to go for lunch or sometime when it wasn't super crowded (which would be hard because the food is delicious).
author: Nick T.

description:
This is the snootiest, most self-satisfied restaurant I've ever been to. That includes all Michelin star places in San Francisco, LA and Vegas I've dined at. This place's nose is so far up its own ass, a team of Sherlock Holmes and Batman would need a week to find it.

I'm willing to forgive the typical San Francisco-ness of having to make reservations over a month in advance. *But* with the North Beach parking craziness, I was literally 11 minutes late. I called in advance saying I was having parking issues and would be 15 mins late. They said they give up tables after 10 minutes and there was a "mob" outside. And we'd probably have to wait the full two hours for a table.

When we got to the restaurant, there were 3 people outside. If that counts a mob, these guys probably shit themselves at Bay to Breakers.

Fortunately we *were* seated relatively quickly...after an excessively rude waitress snapped at us and told us to wait outside.

From the moment we sat down, to the moment we were out the door, we were rushed and made to feel most unwelcome. A waiter wanted to bring out our entrees 5 mins after we'd been served appetizers. This is *after* I already bought a $70 bottle of wine off these people, so it was going to be a good size tab. When I told him to wait for us to finish our appetizers, they looked super offended. Please.

Entrees were brought out the instant I took the last bite of appetizer, and we were rushed through those as well by the staff.

To be quite honest, the food was average for the price. It was decent, but for a $80 food tab (two apps, two entrees) I would expect adequate food. Total bill was $150, so I'd expect better service considering we're giving them a decent amount of money for two people.

All in all, this is the *last* place I would come for a nice meal given the abhorrent service. For a special occasion in San Francisco, go to Alexander's, Acquerello, La Folie or Boulevard. The House is just awful from start to finish.
author: Rishi G.

description: This place was really good. The dishes are daily priced. The only downside to this place was that it's so small. The waiter are walking around near you, over you, around so much the experience becomes chaotic. The food was awesome, everything we had was delicious
author: Elba A.

description: Went in, it was packed; left, then the hostess found us in front and recommended we come back in... so we did. Glad we did!  I had the halibut. Loved it!
author: Rob H.

description:
This is by far one of the best restaurants I've been to. I am stunned by the deliciousness and awesomeness of the food. I came here with my sister and some friends and man oh man did it not disappoint. 

My sister recommended that I get the sea bass. So I did. In the 30 minutes of waiting, I was engulfed in the most delicious piece of fish and garlic noodles that I have ever consumed. I was very impressed by the other dishes as well and the lined seemed super packed.

Decor of the place was super interesting as well. Simple and to the point. I highly recommend this place. It's like a super big orgasmic explosion in your mouth.
author: Nathan L.

description: Love the wild salmon.  Even their rice is good.  Veggies, presentation, everything is awesome!  The space is nothing to speak of but the food is EXCELLENT!
author: Susan B.

description: The House... I wish it was my house.  The food is really good.  The staff are very friendly and attentive.  Always greet you with a smile.  But again the food is real, REALLY good.  My favorite being the grilled salmon on top of the wasabi noodle which is on the lunch menu.  A must try.
author: Christian H.

description:
My boyfriend and I were here on a date night, and we chose this place because of their delicious steak and wasabi noodles (pictures are posted!!). 

I wanted to give 3 stars, but I'm giving an additional star to the two servers (not our waitress) that gave us our check, cleaned our table, and poured water for us.  When we first sat down, water, a mini plate of sliced cucumbers with vinegar and sesame seeds, and menus were given out by a tall nice gentleman.  It was pretty dark in there, so it was kind of hard to see the menus.  I don't remember it being that dark, but it was probably because the light was flickering above us.  It was kind of annoying, but I wasn't going to ask them to fix it.  They couldn't have fixed it right then and there because dust would have been everywhere and people would have to move.  I am not that kind of person that would make everybody stop what they're doing just to fix the light.  The flickering of the lights didn't seem to bother other guests, so maybe their eyesight is better than mine. haha lol  The waitress came to our table about 5 minutes later asking if we wanted to hear the specials.  Even though we heard the specials, we were still sticking to the original choices we made (the wasabi noodles and steak).  In addition to our entrees, we ordered the tuna tartare as our appetizer.  As for the drinks, my boyfriend ordered champagne, and I wanted to try something different, so I ordered the Rose (not the sparkling one).  Overall, the champagne and the Rose was ok (nothing too special).  The table next to us was seated 5 minutes later than us, ordered right after us, and had the same waitress as us, but they had their appetizer before us.  I understand that different appetizers have different waiting times.  But it was after they finished eating their appetizer that our waitress came to our table and asked, "You guys didn't get the appetizer yet, right?  I'll go check."  When our appetizer finally came, it came in 3 pieces.  I would have taken a picture of it, but my boyfriend was too hungry and ate it. lol  The tuna tartare dish came with three long triangular chips, each chip having tuna tartare stacked on top of it.  The presentation was really amazing (WELL DONE CHEFS!!), but 3 chips for 2 people (NO CHEFS!! =/)?  I would suggest making 4 small chips, so we each can have 2.  Even though my boyfriend was hungry, he still offered the last chip for me because he knew I love tuna tartare.  Such a nice boyfriend. lol Anyways, after finishing the appetizer, our entrees came.  The wasabi noodles weren't super spicy, just how we love it, and the angus flatiron steak was DELICIOUS!!! (SUPER WELL DONE CHEFS!!)  We wanted the meat to be cooked medium, and it was just perfect.  So much flavor and the portions were just right!  While we were eating our entrees, our waitress asked if everything was ok, and we said yes.  We then realized, we actually didn't even know the name of our waitress; a table that was 2 tables down was asking for her name and that's how we knew. lol  Hearing our waitress' name from 2 tables down, you know that the restaurant is small and you can hear other people's conversation.  When we were done with our entrees, the same woman that poured water for us cleared our tables and asked if we wanted dessert.  We looked at the menus, but we didn't feel like eating dessert.  We decided to look at the other side of the menu to see if anything else was written there, and my boyfriend spotted some green sauce stuff stuck to the back of the menus.  Again, the light was very dark, so we couldn't even see what that stuff was.  Our waitress asked if we wanted any dessert, we said no and wanted the check.  She said ok and collected the dessert menus.  8 minutes later, the check has not come yet.  We had to ask the nice lady who refilled our waters for us to get the check for us and she gave it right away.  I guess our waitress was too busy to give us the check.  It's weird to have 3 different people serve us, but I felt like the nice lady who refilled our water cups and gave us the check was our waitress. lol  

Will I come back?  Probably because the chefs did an oustanding job on our entrees, and because of the service from the nice lady.  I hope our waitress provided great service to her other tables, since we didn't get it. =/
author: Diana H.

description: My boyfriend and I wanted to explore North Beach and ended up stumbling upon The House after 10pm for a late dinner. They seated us right away and were very attentive to customer service. The wine was great but the food even better. We started with their sashimi special that was some of the freshest and most flavorful fish I've had. The deep fried salmon roles were incredible also paired with a miso infused dipping sauce. We then split the sea bass with soba noodles and green beans and the flavor a perfectly complimented each other. Completely satisfied and will return again soon!
author: Janet B.

description:
Unforgettable experience.

We were seated swiftly, greeted by the wonderful waitstaff.  After ordering we waited minutes before our meal was before us.  The meal was great.  Fantastic.  We ordered the grilled chicken and mashed potatoes and the curry chicken.  Both were on point.
author: Samuel S.

description: Octopus was amazing, you have to get there on time otherwise you will be waiting for a bit. Very small and cute place but gets packed real quick.
author: Iris M.

description: This is such a cute place! Absolutely loved the food and atmosphere! The space is very small and although we had a reservation, we still had a bit of a wait. The only reason I'm giving this place 4 stars - the price. The portions are pretty small for what you are being charged. Expect a high bill but if you're OK with that, you will not be disappointed.
author: Shaun M.

description:
My husband and I ventured to The House after reading all the amazing reviews.   It was a Saturday night at about 8:30pm and we had a 45 minute wait.  During the wait we hung out at the salon next door which has live music.

What we ordered:
Deep fried salmon roll - my husband liked the roll and I thought it was ok however we both agreed that the wasabi dipping sauce was excellent.
Wasabi noodles with flat iron steak - both my husband and I thought this dish was delicious! 
Sea bass with garlic noodles -  the Sea bass was delicious!  I liked the combo of Sea bass with the garlic noodles but the noodles eaten on their own did not stand out to me.
Apple pie crumble - we both thought this was a good dessert to end the night with.

The couple next to us ordered the calamari and it comes with dried fish flakes on top that move due to the steam of the dish and this gives the illusion that the calamari is still alive.  It is pretty cool and freaky if you are not expecting it!

Note - both are entrees came with garlic noodles.  They were burning hot, no joke, so be careful or you will not be able to taste the rest of your meal:-)

Food: 4 stars
Service: 4 stars
Noise: Loud
Drink menu: wine, sake and beer
Wait: average
Parking: street only, it's the city:-). 
Tips and Tricks:  Make reservations or expect to have a wait! The House is a small and very loud restaraunt. I think the experience would be more positive if you keep your group to a maximum of four people.

We will definitely return to The House!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Food was good and ambiance too with awesome service, but little crowded for a dinner date. Appetizers are awesome specially the Salmon rolls and Lamb chops for the main course. Cold Sake are special and premium. Should like to visit once in a while for a change in palate....!!!
author: Nikhil N.

description:
You know, SF is a city of foodies but one thing I know many will not deal with (unlike NY) is RUDE service. I called to make reservations and the woman that answered the phone was the rudest woman I have EVER dealt with in the the food industry. YOU ARE IN CUSTOMER SERVICE, have a better attitude!

My advice to The House: BE NICER and not so stuck up.  Or else people will stop frequenting no matter how good your food is.
author: Olivia H.

description:
Shockingly, on the Saturday of Labor Day weekend - we found parking on Grant, just a few stores up from The House for our 12:30pm reservations.  After reading hundreds of reviews about wait times, etc, I was amazed at how quickly we were seated, and the fact that half of the restaurant was empty upon arrival.  

We went for 3 of the starter specials:  Toro Nigiri, Scallops, and Kobe Beef Tartare on Crostini.   FYI, all of the starters we had came in 3's.  So if you're dining w/just 1 other person, you'll have to Ro-Sham-Bo for the 3rd and last piece, or if you're dining w/2 other people, you're fu6ked- because you'll definitely want more than 1 bite of the creative deliciousness that The House gives you.  And the presentation!  The presentation of the food was absolutely beautiful.  The Toro was fresh and fatty.  The Scallops were seasoned with what I think must've been called Hella Slammin Yummy Seasoning Packets.  And the Crostini that the Kobe Beef Tartare was placed on?  Cannnnnnnnn I marry you.

After realizing how small (but wonderfully tasting) the starter specials were, we were still hungry.  So we went ahead and ordered the Unagi Avocado Sandwich.  OH. MY. GAH.  It's been repeated in hundreds of reviews on here already.  As simple as the sandwich may sound, it's mouth watering good.  Do NOT doubt me on this one.  Is the Pope Catholic?  What'd I say.

It's a small spot, but do yourself a favor and make reservations.  They don't have pricing on their online menu, but everything we ordered ranged from $11-14 each.  It's pretty reasonable for a place that serves tasty food prettier than some of the higher end restaurants I've dined at.  I told my friend, if I was ever mad at someone- they could redeem themselves by bringing me an Unagi Avocado Sandwich from The House.  Future boyfriends:  Take note.
author: Rho T.

description:
All that hype and 1-hr wait for my walk-in! Finally I made it and had a great meal. 
Following the popular recommendation, I ordered the sea bass with garlic noodles and it came with stir fried beans on the side. Delish and very well made! The fish was cooked to perfection and came with some additional dipping sauce on the side. I love it when sauce is on the side and my food isn't dipped in it! Garlic noodles and beans were amazing too. 
MUST ORDER - the tapioca-mango pudding. I am a big tapioca fan and this is one of the best I have ever had. 
Can't wait to be back to try more yummy-ness. 
On the downside, everything is excellent, but the wait and prices may not be 100% justified. For the same price, you could probably get more gourmet stuff. But this place is still worth a try.
author: Neha M.

description:
Unobtrusive, all quiet on the western front, 
Cement, pantone grey, this is modern, 
Yellow neon sign, hint of life at night,
this is The House, perfect hang for a party of four, 
have reservation, or wait patiently by the door,
The dream of the fisherman's Wife, 
This that sea bass, seduction like Chuck Bass,
rich and smooth,  
This that black cod, been trill and back, 
curry, garlic, wasabi, three's company, 
textures, righteous, 
flavors, gorgeous, 
dive in, that good vibe, yellow submarine,  
let the tastebud bask in the yellow hues, 
espresso ice cream, essence of a sweet dream,
petite, intimate, let the light dim some, 
this is the subtle hollow cutout of a house on paper, 
I let the taste dwell just a bit longer, 
beginning of a perfect night, stepped outside, 
charming housewarming, my sensations linger
author: Roy C.

description:
The stars are a reflection of the poor service. We called earlier in the day and were told they don't take reservations. We arrived at 545pm and were told it would be 45 minutes before we were seated. We walked to Calzones, had a couple rounds, an hour later, I realized they still had not called my cell phone regarding our table. So I called them. They told me we were next. So we walked back to the restaurant only to find four parties with reservations being seated. I guess they do take them. At 740 pm we still weren't seated and everyone else in my party started to leave. I told the hostess to cross our name and suddenly the table being set was for us. So we got sat 2 hours later. The servers were unorganized as well, we weren't greeted for 10 minutes, them three people approached/pressed for our order. The food arrived quickly and it was very good, exactly "Asian fusion" as I would imagine. I enjoyed the grilled squid and the black cod was yummy. 

It is unfortunate that the service ruined our experience. I have worked at similar restaurants so I understand turning tables, sharing tables, etc, but there was no communication amongst the staff. The hostess had not properly planned for the rush nor set aside tables efficiently for reservations. Maybe two hostesses would benefit. Though the food was good, not worth the price given the Front staff. :/
author: Zara S.

description:
The two of us didn't make reservations and instead waited outside for 15 minutes before it opened at 5:30pm. We were second in line and were seated right away.  

Service = super friendly. Quick and efficient, no complaint there.

We had the ribs for appetizers. Falling off the bone good. I don't think I need to say more. For the main course, I got the Chilean Sea Bass. Honestly, the sauce was okay (it tasted like commercial sweet soy sauce with some chili pepper). The sea bass, however, was well-cooked, moist, and was not overly fishy. The garlic noodles on the side was the best part! Very rich in flavor. I kind of wanted the noodles just on its own.  My boyfriend got the duck.  It was cooked well. It also came with some crunchy noodles or something similar and was very presentable.

Parking in the area is a. I recommend parking in the Chinatown parking lot (for $3 an hour), which is a block or two away. 

Also, the place was a little cramped. We were seated very closely to another table for two next to us, and all of us were clearly (unintentionally) eaves-dropping on each other's conversations. It is still a great place for a fun date, just not a great place for an intimate date. With that said, I don't know if going in a big group would be a good idea.
author: Vivi S.

description: The House just wow. Absolutely superb. My family of 4 came in for dinner we notice that this small cozy restaurant was in the center of little Italy. We were skeptical at first but once we got in the nice lady who served us was very kind and helpful. The food we ate blew all expectations and completely surprised me and my family. We have been to many restaurants in the Bay Area but this restaurant is the one restaurant that we will never forget!
author: Ashwin C.

description: I liked this place! It's not street Thai food, which I prefer,  it a really good spot to take someone that is not super adventurous.
author: O H.

description:
I went here with friends for my birthday.  I don't eat a lot of fish and am otherwise vegetarian.  So when I arrived and saw almost no strict vegetarian options, I was a little nervous.  However, I was able to find many delicious options that fit my pescatarian tastes.

As a table we shared three small dishes for appetizers: Asparagus with roasted sesame dressing; Classic fried calamari; and a Lobster Tempura special.  Each was incredible!  The lobster was delicious!

I then had the Sesame soy glazed salmon in a bonito sake broth and my boyfriend had the Mushroom rice with grilled prawns.  We were both extremely happy with our choices.  This place is definitely a place to try!  Even though I do not frequently eat seafood, I have found myself craving these dishes in the days since my visit!

The restaurant is small, so make reservations.  Otherwise I'm not sure how successful you will be in finding a place.  Also our server was everything I want in a server.  She was attentive but not overbearing.  She was very understanding of us having to continually ask her to come back and give us a little more time to review the menu.  And she made sure our water glasses were always full and that we had everything we needed.
author: Christine B.

description:
Having lived in Shanghai for 4 years, I'm somewhat resigned to perhaps not finding any great Chinese in town.  But this place is excellent fusion and I will definitely come back/bring friends.

We had:
- BBQ pork ribs
- Caesar salad with scallops
- grilled Salmon
- mushroom rice
- cod (daily special)
- almond cookies

Caesar salad was predictably unspectacular (but still fine, I was feeling like a salad) but the ribs, salmon, and mushroom rice were all just so delicious. Almond cookies are good but not sure they deserve the yelp hype.
author: Kathryn C.

description:
Called to make a reservation. The receptionist was COMPLETELY RUDE! I don't appreciate a side of attitude with anything I order, especially before I even order my entree. If a restaurant does not know how to train their staff any etiquette, no matter how amazing the food, I would prefer to eat else where. 

Food taste like shit if the service gives you shit
author: Jesse H.

description:
The absolute best asian fusion we have had. Great service and incredible food. The restaurant could use some air conditioning though, I was sweating in the back of the packed dining room. 

But the important thing is the food. We had the sea bass and steak, both great! And the tuna tartar and salmon rolls were out of this world. 

Paired that with a nice oolong tea pot. Best meal we have had in a while!
author: Sean G.

description: The space is tiny. If you are with a group larger than 4, you will be cramped. Make a reservation or be prepared to wait. The food was ok, nothing extraordinary. The portions are huge, and nothing was bad, but nothing was especially great.
author: Diane Z.

description:
As a single girl, I sometimes think about what I'd like in a potential boyfriend.

He should be nice, smart, funny, sweet, and arm candy material.  Oh, and if he can make me wasabi noodles with grilled chicken just like how they make it at The House, I'm sold.

Mike C. suggested meeting up here for lunch on a Friday, and I was torn between the three noodle dishes: udon noodle soup, curry noodles, or the warm wasabi noodles.  After asking the waitress what she thought, I went for the wasabi ones, but swapped out the pork for chicken instead.

We split the fried salmon rolls, which is basically salmon wrapped in nori, deep-fried, and served with a spicy mustard sauce and a slaw on the side.  The salmon was juicy and tender (and not by any means overcooked), and the seaweed skin was fried to a perfect crisp.  I only put on a thin strip of the mustard sauce (which was kind of runny), and it tasted great because it wasn't too hot, but gave it a great kick.

The wasabi noodles had a very faint hint of wasabi (not very strong wasabi flavor if you're worried), but it was basically pan-fried noodles (like a yakisoba) with pieces of grilled chicken.  So. Freaking. Good.  Not too greasy, no flavor was overpowering, everything just worked.

For a lunch place, the prices are steeper than your usual sub-$10 salad or sandwich, but it's so worth it if you want to step out of the Financial District and onto a quieter corner of North Beach.

Single guys, get your woks ready.
author: Tori S.

description:
The House is one of my top favorite restaurants in the city. No one should pass up the sea bass. It's fresh and cooked to perfection. The steak with wasabi noodles might be my favorite steak dish to date. Also cooked perfectly and the noodles are a nice compliment.

Make reservations if you can. It is small and fills up very quickly. But it is worth the wait!
author: Ryann M.

description:
The food here is great! I love coming here, although it is a bit heavy on the wallet... I usually have a reservation when I come here to eat since this place is really small and has very limited seating. So either get there early before the rush or make a reservation ahead of time. 

I've been here twice, and both times I have had a pleasant experience. Both times I have ordered the Wasabi Noodles and the Sea Bass. So good. I can't even describe how good the sea bass is. Once it's in your mouth, it's like heaven! And the wasabi noodles. Amazing! I'll always order these two here. I recommend it!

It's been a while since I've been here so my review isn't as recent as I would like it to be. But from the recent reviews, it seems that the wasabi noodles and sea bass is still the popular items!!

Food is a bit pricey, but well worth it. Yum!
author: Joan T.

description: Great food. Very exquisite burst of flavors. The chef does a great job at fusing different textures and flavors. I had the grilled sea bass that was grilled to perfection. Wasnt a fan of the garlic noodles on the side. My friend had the mahi special with wasabi sauce and two avocado rolls which was great too. Must try the umeshu wine !
author: Priyanka P.

description:
Just called to make a reservation. The girl who answered was not friendly. She was short and barely let me finish my sentence before she asked, NAME? WHEN? WHAT TIME? 

Haven't eaten here yet and i'm sure the food will be great...but for a small restaurant with tons of great reviews, you need to get rid of this girl and replace her with someone who has better phone demeanor. Just some advice.
author: Zara H.

description:
All the raves are correct! This place is soooo good.

We got two dishes, which were the two most expensive on the menu. One was the Sea bass, which I will never ever forget about, and the other one I think was the pork chop dish.

I have nothing to say about the pork chop dish, it was okay. But that sea bass was to die for. I think I would put that dish up as one of the top 10 best things I've ate in my life. I don't know what it was, the garlic noodles, the veggies, or the combination of those two with the Sea bass, but it was amazing. There are not enough positive adjectives in the dictionary to describe that dish. 

Okay, I don't want to hype it up too much so go try it for yourself. Other than those two dishes, everything else was priced very decently. And this is a place I am definitely going to go back to whenever I get the opportunity. I feel like the other dishes they serve must be really good as well. Can't wait try them.
author: Ronny L.

description:
Yes, you are a great restaurant, but you don't need to treat us as being lucky to get a table. 

My wife and I dropped by just now to see if we could get a table. The hostess said it would be about 30 minutes. But before we could respond, she abruptly (and rudely) moved on to a table to take their order. She could have at least waited for us to tell her if we wanted to wait for a table. I should note that there were 2 unoccupied tables - one for 4 and another for 2 or 3.

So right now we're at Restaurant Ideale across the street having a wonderful dinner.  And if you're looking for Asian fusion without the 'tude, go to HRD Smokin' Grill, also across the street.

(Note: we've been to the House plenty of times over the past few years since we live in the neighborhood.  I even remember going to their location in the Sunset before it closed.)
author: howie f.

description: Came here on a Friday night with reservations and still had to wait about half an hour. I didn't mind since it was an extremely small restaurant and supposedly really good. We started off with the calamari for appetizer. It was pretty darn good. For the main course, I ordered the Wasabi Noodles with Flatiron Steak. I can see why people enjoy it so much, but I didn't really like it. Maybe because the yelp reviews hyped it up for me. My boyfriend ordered the Sea Bass with Garlic noodles. I liked his dish a lot more than I liked mine. My favorite part about the meal was the dessert! We ordered the Apple Crumble  a la Mode. It was SO good in everyway! Makes up for the rest of my dinner.
author: Lina C.

description:
This place was very crowded at lunch, best to get a reservation. Some co-workers and I had the special which was deep fried halibut. The fish was moist and fresh and the batter was not at all greasy. With a non-alcoholic drink plus tip it came out to be about $30. Others had the flatiron steak, but the grilled salmon with wasabi noodles looked like the best bet.

The waitress was very friendly and took her time with us even during the hectic lunch hour rush. We had a party of 10 and I was impressed that we were all served at the same time (perhaps it helped that most of us ordered the same things). The dining room is very very small and moving around can be difficult, especially if the waiters and other patrons are moving about. I'd advise you not to take the table by the window because it's near impossible to leave your seat without disrupting your neighbors. 

The bathroom was actually a welcomed refuge from all the noise. It's single occupancy so it wasn't very clean, but not the worst I've seen. 

For the price, you can certainly get more bang for your buck elsewhere, but it's worth trying at least once. The food tasted very good with the fresh ingredients and the service was attentive. Even for a cheapskate like me who doesn't believe in spending more than $10 for a work day lunch, I'd go back to try out some of the other dishes.

Food: A.....everyone at the table was happy, no complaints
Service: A....staff was awesome, always kept our glasses full
Atmosphere: B+....a little cramped, but the room was buzzing
Price: B+.....fair for the quality, about $30 per person with non-alcholic drink
author: Stevey K.

description: I really enjoyed it. Reminds me how useful Yelp is. Great meal with good service. I thought the salmon rolls, which I ordered cooked medium well, we're the most tasty thing our table had. Really very good.
author: Michael D.

description:
My favorite restaurant in the city!

Although The House should actually be called TheTinyCrampedRoom, the food is totally worth it! DON'T FORGET TO MAKE A RESERVATION, especially for dinner..or else you'll be waiting an hour for a table!

Although everyone raves about the Sea Bass, which is definitely extremely tender and mouth-melting, I would have to say that my favorite here is the Pork Chop http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-house-san-francisco?select=9J5rzgMkGETaeQstZ-SOFQ#2pv8tcE_eKWvrSXzdTX6pg. It's slightly sweet (pomegranate flavored), but this is the most delicately cooked pork chop I've EVER had in my entire life. And it comes with some really good mashed potatoes and asparagus. :)

As for appetizer, my favorite so far is the beef tartar (it was a special one time for lunch http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-house-san-francisco?select=9J5rzgMkGETaeQstZ-SOFQ#9J5rzgMkGETaeQstZ-SOFQ). Also, the steamed garlic mussels are great too!
author: Liz W.

description: I rarely give five star reviews. I grew up in North Beach (not too far from this place) and I am a traveler. I am a foodie and possibly a food snob (is that redundant?). Anyway, I have eaten a lot of fine food in great restaurants all over the place. I almost went with 4 stars, but then I thought, why? This place deserves 5 stars. I could not think of one thing that could have been better. All of our food was phenomenal, and the service was spot on. We made a reservation, which I recommend, for any day, let alone a Friday night. We did have to wait 15 minutes, but the restaurant is small, so I don't knock them for that. It was well worth it. I had the miso sea bass. It was amazing and the portion was the perfect size. I almost could not finish it.
author: Valerie F.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Tuesday night with my sister and two friends. I was able to make a reservation earlier that day for 7:30PM the same night (although everyone says it's so hard to get a reservation, was quite easy!).

We tried the soft shell crab as an appetizer which was good. It was served with noodles and the crab was yummy. I ordered the ribeye medium rare -- it was quite delicious (big enough to share). My friend ordered the sea bass which she loved. 

Overall, everything was yummy. A bit on the expensive side, but very good. Service however was just okay. 

Would come again!
author: Siv L.

description:
I have nothing bad to say about this restaurant - it was just OK.

1) Our server was great, very helpful with all my questions.
2) It was me and a friend and we were seated at a 4 person table - nice!

3) For appetizers, we ordered the crab cake and 2 special apps -- hamachi sashimi and scallops.  The crab cake was good.  I should have just had this for my main course.  The hamachi sashimi was fresh with plenty of avocado on top.  The scallops were a disappointment only because there were 3 and they were the size of a quarter.

4) For entrees, we had the special kobe beef and the sea bass with garlic noodles.
Again, nothing bad about these dishes, just nothing spectacular.  The garlic noodles were a bit salty so they could have lightened up on the NaCl. :)

I thinks its a decent place in North Beach, something different from all the Italian restaurants around.  I won't be poo-pooing the place but its not a 4 or 5 star in my book.  Its just OK.
author: S K.

description:
I have always adored House for its great food - the fish, the prawns, the ribeyes. 

As usual, the food itself did not disappoint - I had the prawns with rice, and it was cooked to perfection. My friends had the salmon dish and they ate up every bite. We then had the chocolate cake desserts, and again, they were divine. However we were a bit disappointed with the service this time around - our server seated us and got us water for the first time and then just disappeared entirely. It wasn't until I got the hostess's attention again did she assign another server for our table. As a result, our food arrived a bit cold.

We could also tell that they were rushing us out to make room for other guests, because they served us the bill at the same time they served us dessert. 

I really hate to give House less than a 5-star review because it still remains one of my favorite spots. However, I think they need to up their service game.
author: Nancy L.

description:
amazing food. After a week I'm still in awe of how much I loved the food. walking in I noticed how small this restaurant was. they were so busy we werent able to get a reservation for two and decided to just go and wait the 45 mins. well worth the wait. 

we ordered the crab cakes, the pork chops and the sea bass. everything was delicious and I especially loved the presentation and ingredients used. thin fried plantains and  taro chips were used in the presentation, very creative.  pomegranate seeds were used with the pork chops. pomegranate seeds, out of all things. I thought it was pretty stunning and offered just the right amount of sweetness. the sea bass melted like butter. grilled to perfection with a side of garlic noodles and string beans. everything was amazing. a bit on the oily side but I didnt mind since the food was just that good. 

excellent food, highly recommended.
author: Serena L.

description: Absolutely like butter! Sea bass and black cod are a must! The seared scallops and creme brulee with passion fruit were delicious!
author: Quang V.

description:
Finally got to try this place! Definitely worth the wait and the price, which was justified. 

I had the wasabi noodles with angus skillet steak. The noodles were very good with enough of a wasabi flavor to it, which was just right. The salmon tasted normal to me, but I'm not a connoisseur of seafood. Their special menu included kobe beef and an appetizer with pork belly, but that was beyond my budget that night. 

The portions were just right too - not bulky yet fulfilling. 

For a restaurant that I've been eager to try after seeing it on Episode 13 of Check Please! but never got to go, this place fulfilled my expectations! 

It also had a very cozy feeling to it as again meeting expectations. The tables were close together, the pictures on the wall made it feel like home, and the soft colors set the mood inside and out. It was a place I wanted to go, a house, like home.
author: Michael Y.

description: I met a group here and we let the waitress order for us.  The place was packed and our group barely fit at the table.  Everything we tried was outstanding.  We had Scallops with arugula and roe, Lamb Chops w/ noodles, sea bass, fillet mignon and kimchi.  Every dish was distinct.  They also served a Japanese IPA that was crisp and hoppy. Service was good, the decor/ambiance was lacking.
author: Bryan H.

description:
Yum!

I been to The House for the first after hearing many friends rave about it this past week.  We came here for my boyfriend's actual birthday dinner.  The location itself is difficult to find parking and the place is relatively small, probably not ideal for a large group and it's slightly dim.

We had the Ahi Tuna Tartare and crabcakes as starters, I had the infamous grilled sea bass and my bf had the domestic Kobe steak special of the night, and we ended with creme brulee and the apple pie for dessert.

Ahi tuna tartare = I did not like this dish at all. I hate wasubi!! I absolutely hate it.  I wished they would had listed a litte more detail of this dish on their menu because if i knew it was mixed with a wasubi sauce, I would have gotten something else.  (This is the factor of the 4-stars rating)

Crabcakes - these are not your traditional patty-shaped crabcakes, it's more like a pear-shaped. The crabcake was a good size for two and had some sort of tartar sauce on the bottom.

Seabass - OMG is all I can really say when the sea bass entered my mouth.  It was juicy and good and went well with the garlic ginger soy sauce, which I was a little skeptical at first because I was worried the ginger would be too overpowering.  And the noodles it came with was... well let's say this, thinking about it is making my mouth salivate.  YES, its that good.

Steak - well it tasted a little too fatty for me but maybe I just gotten a bad end of it but my bf enjoyed it.

Creme brulee - This was listed as a Coconut creme brulee with passionfruit puree but I didn't really taste any coconut. The passionfruit puree was really light on top but contrast will with the creme brulee.  I love creme brulee and this was good creme brulee

Apple pie - I had a small bite of it and it was actually warm, which is how apple pie should be and it's not the usual pie but it had those crumbs on top. This was good apple pie and I usually don't like applie pies.

Service was attentive and dishes were nicely made.
author: Mimi P.

description: Excellent food - great service!  A great gem just tucked away on the edge of mainstream  north beach .  The wine list was well thought out and the manager did a fantastic job at pairing selections with dishes
author: Aaron C.

description: I looked at some of the reviews before I went, and everyone was recommending the deep fried salmon roll. Oh my goodness. It was so full of flavor - I barely had to dip any of the mustard sauce to enjoy it. We had the wasabi noodles as well as a fish special that they suggested. All of them tasted delicious... We were considering ordering dessert but decided not to because we were full. Kind of happy we didn't because it doesn't look worthy of its hefty price tag.... Hopefully will go back to try some other food!
author: Shera K.

description:
Love and warmth always seem to be oozing out of the kitchen! We always enjoy our meals thoroughly here because it's clear everyone is enjoying their job! 
For New Years they switched up the menu but still delivered originality and deliciousness on every plate! 
A true gem of north beach!
author: devorah h.

description:
starter is a picked cucumber - sweet and sour.
it's casual wear here. the waitress is nice but flustered. most popular : salmon starter which is medium rare; main dishes: pork cooked medium and the sea bass. 


get your rsvp. I found parking about 3 blocks down.
author: Jeff K.

description:
Great place for a special occasions.
Reservation is recommended and parking on a street is difficult, 
but there are 2 parking lots right around the corner. 
Yesterday (Chinese New Year) I take my wife for her BD and Valentines day celebration. 
Because of the traffic (Chinese New Year Parade - big deal in SF) we were 20 mins. late for our 9 PM reservation (I call 5 days earlier for reservation and the earliest time was 9 PM) & we had to wait a little.
But it was worth it.
Kobe beef steak on special,  Shrimp dumplings with Chinese chives  Pork chop, Blackberry dessert and bottle of Australian Shiraz - everything was very good.
author: Johnny J.

description:
Very disappointing food and way overpriced. The owners are clearly all about stretching their margins. Our dinner started badly with a trip to the bathroom to wash my hands, and boy, was that place filthy! Never a good sign.

We then ordered wine by the glass, the most expensive red on the menu, $14 pinot noir, and it was disgusting, completely undrinkable. It wasn't corked or anything, but the taste was so bad you could just tell it was a very, very cheap wine. We sent it back, but they still charged us for it.

Then the food was very disappointing too, and extremely overpriced. The fried salmon roll was bland and greasy, the shiitake salad was ok, I guess, except there was maybe half a shiitake in there, and the rest was just lettuce. The kale salad was good, I'll grant them that. 

On to entrees and our disappointment continued, with a sea bass that was obviously not fresh, just like the side of overcooked mushy noodles that came with it. The sashimi was just ok, but small, and nothing to remember. Overall the best dish was probably the kobe beef and mashed potatoes, except it wasn't kobe beef at all, just regular beef. Again, a trick to charge double the value.

All in all our experience there was completely forgettable, except for the price tag, which was anything but! $170 without tip for a party of 3, way too much for such mediocre food.
author: Juliette R.

description: I used to come here growing up and continue to visit as often as possible.  Perfect blend of flavors both then and now with some consistent favorites and other new items.  Amazing consistency and great staff.  Favorites are the garlic noodles and wasabi noodles topped with either salmon or chicken.  It's amazing to find an intimate restaurant like The House that meets / exceeds expectations time and again.  Thank you!
author: Michael M.

description:
I was so excited to FINALLY check out this place after wanting to eat here for so long!  Bf told me to pick the restaurant he'd be treating me to to congratulate me on my new job, and he must really love me because he let me pick The House despite the horrible location!  The only time we were able to get a reservation Saturday morning for later that night was at 9.  It was late, I was hungry, but it worked out after all.  Was it worth the wait & hassle for parking?  NO!  There's so many good reviews for this place & so many of my Yelp buddies have praised them, but bf & I just thought it was "okay" & not worth the trip out.  And mind you I am no way a fusion hater..I love it when it's executed right!

We ordered:
*Shrimp & Chinese Chive Dumplings ($9):  They were okay nothing really popped out & I definitely prefer authentic Chinese ones over these.  Kimchi was served on the plate too.
*Warm Wasabi House Noodles with Flat Iron Steak ($18): Nicely made noodles with a hot but not way too overwhelming wasabi flavor.  Nicely grilled flat iron steak cooked perfectly medium rare (per requested) and topped with cucumbers and more of their rendition of kimchi....so much kimchi!!  Again just okay, not very impressive.  (My dish)
*Chicken Breast with Roasted Portabella White Truffle Oil Sauce (under $20?):  I love truffles/truffle oil!  I semi-secretly wished to switch with him as this was his dish.  The chicken was cooked nicely as it was moist.  The truffle oil sauce was yummy and the mashed potatoes had a smooth consistency.  
*(special of the day) Red Velvet Cake ($8):  Not very sweet which could be a good thing but it just fell flat.  I prefer by a longshot That Takes The Cake's red velvet cupcakes over the cake here.

Service was pretty attentive and prices are affordable for a fancyish fusion menu.  As others mentioned this place is tiny and you are seated so close to the next table.  I've always found that almost every time I am in a tiny restaurant like The House, I end up sitting next to a really annoying lady!!

It wasn't bad but it wasn't great.  It is what Yelp says, "A-Ok."
author: Cat C.

description:
This is my favorite spot in North Beach. It's an Asian fusion place but where as most places are Asian food being Americanized, this place is American food being Asianized. 

The best thing is the grilled seabass with garlic noodles (it's basically asian noodles) and green beans. I've never had anything quite like it. 

Sometimes they have American kobe beef which is done quite well here.

For appetizers, the tuna tartare is fantastic and the soft shell crab when it is available.

Service is impecable. The spot is quite small though so try to make a reservation or else expect to wait a hour or so.
author: Victor W.

description:
The House is a great place to dine when you're feeling like eating something extra special for dinner. I've been here twice for dinner and left both times with a happy stomach. Make sure you call in and make a reservation before you dine because I can guarantee you that the wait for the next available table won't be a short one.

My all time favorite dish that I will never fail to order is the grilled sea bass. It's incredibly moist, buttery, and tender. The texture of the fish is to die for, not very flaky at all and quite meaty. There's a nice grilled char on the sea bass that gives it a nice, subtle smokey flavor and visual appeal. The dipping soy sauce that comes with it is just as wonderful. My friend and I couldn't stop bathing everything we had ordered for dinner in it. 

One thing to keep in mind though, both times I ordered the sea bass, I had the udon noodles to go with it and both times halfway through the meal I kept thinking to myself that it was a tad way too oily for me. Don't get me wrong, the noodles were yumsies but I think next time I'll try the rice instead. 

The service is superb and the atmosphere, pleasant. I can't wait to go back and try more things on their menu...and order more grilled sea bass of course.
author: Jasmine L.

description:
This meal was probably the highlight of my SF trip, as far as my stomach is concerned. We stood in the doorway waiting for 30 minutes for a 10pm table (who the hell is eating dinner at 10pm?! Oh yeah, US.), but I didn't mind a bit. To my left were a bunch of hippie 20-somethings smoking some reefer outside, to my right was the scent of Asian fusion goodness. Strange combo, but it kept me both hungry and uh, relaxed.

The hostess, a Lucy Liu doppelganger, kept us updated on the status of our table, and seated us as soon as she could. As soon as I sat down, downed some plum wine, and got my food, I was in culinary heaven. 

Sure, the restaurant is about the size of some Real Housewife of Orange County's walk-in shoe closet, but the food is well worth eating ass cheek-to-ass cheek with a stranger and overhearing someone's fascinating conversation about burritos. In fact, you might learn something.
author: Ellie W.

description:
Amazing! Even my mom liked it and she only likes Chinese food. I love how innovative they are with the whole east meets west thing. Everything on the plate had a purpose. Even the California roll on top of my miso glazed black cod somehow made sense. All of their seafood is to die for because it's fresh fresh fresh. You can't go wrong with the favorites such as the fried salmon roll or the ginger sea bass with garlic noodles. If you are so lucky to have the black cod as a special of the night, order that, you can thank me later. 

Also heard the ribs with cherry glaze is amazing. Will be back to try that!
author: Nan H.

description:
This place lives up to its epic Yelp reviews. I called at around noon on a Thursday and was able to get 8:30 reservations (last ones available) for two people for that night. Thank god. 

We arrived and we seated immediately and greeted by a very friendly waitress. I ordered red wine which was very tasty and a heavy pour. 

My meal was the Sea Bass which was the best sea bass I've ever had. So very good. My friend ordered a pork chop meal which was good but nothing crazy. The pork was just not as flavorful compared to my amazing sea bass. 

For dessert, we ordered the apple crumb and ice cream which was very good. 

Food was stellar as was the service. Best food I've had in SF. Hands down.
author: Matt O.

description: Top choice to dine in SF! Order the infamously flavorful wasabi noodles with angus flat iron steak. Trust me - it will get your tastebuds dancing! Replace the steak with their seabass if you don't do beef. Service was very attentive. They take reservations on Fri & Sat nights too!
author: Vikki L.

description:
