Arrived a few minutes early and almost the entire front section was taken up by a very large party.  At least 25+ people.  But once they left they reset and got us seated quickly.

We had to try the salmon egg rolls.  Very good.  Lots of heat from the wasabi dipping sauce.  The sea bass was literally like butter.  Smooth and flavorful.  The beans were crisp and in perfect bite size pieces.  Had to have the chocolate torte for dessert.  Also very good.  Service was QUICK (but not rushed) and friendly.

Yes, the place was packed.  Yes it was loud.  Yes we were next to the door (but at the window).  Yes I would go back.
author: Teri X.

description: Looked up on yelp and reviewing this restaurant so that I can find it next time I'm in sf. Great food and ambience. Casual. Took off one star because I called in for reservation two weeks in advance but by the time I showed up they forgot about my reservation and I had to insist them looking back to their notes or whatever. They are super busy afterall.
author: Aoying Z.

description: Food was outstanding. My waitress must have had a terrible day. Never have I met a person and just didn't jive with them right off the bat. This woman was a an asshole. The entire time. Food was fantastic, she might have spit in it but still tasted fine.
author: Mike B.

description:
Amazing food, probably the best fusion restaurant we have ever tried

Blue lake bean tempura: Amazing
Deep fried Salmon Roll: Amazing
Cease salad crispy Scallop:  Good
White shrimp chive Dumplings: Very Good

Unagi avocado Sandwich: Out of this world
Wasabi house noodle with frank Steak: Amazing
Curry noodles grilled Chicken: Amazing
Grilled Seabass: Amazing

Apple Crumb: Amazing
Chocolate truffle cake: Excellent 

Good and effective Service
author: Thien B.

description: Great Little place that delivers every time. The good reviews are earned every day and i commend the owners for running a tight ship. great service compliments all the good food. Shitake mushroom soup was amazing followed by Wasabi noodle and salmon - who can ask for anything more? :) I have tried 90% of the menu and never thought - "I won't order that again!" be ready to share your dish with friends as you have to try everything.
author: andrew c.

description:
This place definitely deserves the 'as good as it gets' designation. The price is just right, the dishes are delicious and extremely creative, and I like the somewhat secretive or down to earth version of their website. 

Plus, I found out when I spoke to the hostess last Satruday that this is a family owned and operated establishment. The hostess' husband is the chef! This is so cool. It always makes me feel good to be in a position to support small local business. 

Definitely recommend this spot.
author: Herman R.

description: Wow!!  Ended up here after strolling around Chinatown and looking for a place we could sit and have wine with our lunch.  Passed on lots of great looking Dim Sums and other places with appetizing food but not much in way of seating much less wine.  Super glad we stuck to our search walking right past this nearly almost invisible storefront on the outer edge of Chinatown.  It's categorized as "Asian fusion" which sums up a great selection of really fresh and deliciously prepared dishes.  We tried the popular salmon rolls which didn't disappoint and also enjoyed fresh oysters, a beautifully balanced cold noodle dish with perfectly cooked thin sliced skirt steak and finally a white shrimp dumpling.  Really nice variety on the wine list.  The service was also friendly and well done.
author: Grace H.

description: Reservations are recommended but we saw plenty of walk-ins get seated w/o much of a wait.  Food lived up to expectations.  Both the deep-fried salmon roll and the crab cakes were superb.  My seabass w/ udon and green beans was pretty much perfect.  Great crust and seasoning on the outside of the fish and perfectly cooked.  The sauce it's served with is bold and the presentation was very simple on it unlike some of the other dishes which also made it easier for me to eat.  Wasabi noodles a little overhyped for me.  Last, there was no letdown from the dessert of a bittersweet chocolate cake w/ the coffee ice cream. The only weird thing I noticed was they would keep filling our water glasses to 3/4 rather than all the way...seems like that guy knows the art of pretending to look busy.
author: Derrick C.

description:
Inconvenient parking but outstanding food? Yep, we must be in North Beach.

Let me preface this by saying I'm seriously not a fan of fish aside from salmon or tuna. My personal experience with fish at home and restaurants has been that the fish comes out either horribly dry and flaky or bland or both. THIS IS NOT THE CASE HERE. The House makes an incredible, buttery and tender sea bass that is quite unrivaled. I have never realized that fish (again, other than salmon or tuna) could taste so amazing and have such depth of flavor! I can't say enough good things about this dish - I ordered it to share with my friend but I secretly could have eaten the whole thing myself if she wasn't watching it with an eagle eye just as closely :0

To summarize, get the sea bass and come here for lunch! You won't regret it!
author: Tiffany C.

description: Really. really good grub. I followed what all yelpers did and ordered the salmon rolls (yummy - sauce was a little much for me tho), wasabi noodles and the sea bass - everything was spectacular.  The kimchee coleslaw on all dishes was a nice touch to the meal. I would have ordered more items but I was a lone diner  this time round. The menu looks amazing! Try the sparkling Shiraz with your meal - it was nice and refreshing. This is one house I definitely will come home to the next time im in SF. Note: make a reservation as this place is real small - more sized like an apartment than a HOUSE!!
author: Lor B.

description:
Big time fisherman. Have tasted fish 5 minutes after being caught. This place probably has the best and freshest fish dish i have ever had in a restaurant. I ordered the white sea bass and was not disappointed. Very skeptical in the beginning because i dont like eating fish in any restaurants. Sushi yes, but not cooked fish. This place rocked it. Also had the scallops as a appetizer and a glass of chardonay.  


This is a must try place. I wonder where they get their fish from. I hope not the infected bay waters..... The fish taste so fresh they just might......
author: Robin H.

description:
LOVE this place! Come here for a booshie, romantic night out with your partner! 

Finding a sophisticated, delicious, non-Italian restaurant in North Beach isn't the easiest task. Thankfully, the House is here to save the day! While the decor is pretty plain and the service isn't anything to brag about, I'm convinced that absolutely anything you order here will be incredible. Just to give you an idea, we got: 

Appetizers: 
Fried Salmon (savory, sweet fried goodness. Yes please)

Entrees:
Wasabi Noodles and Steak 
Pork Shoulder (that week's special)

Each dish was unique, artfully presented, and bursting with flavor. I was almost sad to have to leave, but realizing that I have a new place to bring friends before heading to Grant street bars was a wonderful revelation.
author: Nicole G.

description:
Call me crazy but I thought the House was decent, meaning - not horrible but not something that makes me salivate the instant I hear "The House." It was our first dinner destination in SF, but I do not have dreams of what the food would taste like again... 

In all fair honestly, we tried majority of the plates, family style. 
Miso seabass with wasabi noodles.
Neiman pork chops in a pomegranate currant sauce
Seared ahi tuna
Angus ribeye
Wasabi noodles with flat iron steak

Presentation is beautiful. Service was okay, but I can't blame them because we came in when they were doing last call on a Monday night. 

Maybe, I'll give it a second shot the next time I'm in SF but for now, my cravings for "The House" are satisfied.
author: Chris D.

description:
I've had my fair share of Asian fusion restaurants and The House did not meet my usual high expectations of what Asian fusion food is supposed to taste like.  If I could describe the House's food in 4 words, I'd describe it as: "expensive 'fancy' Chinese food". 

My friend and I ordered for appetizers:
Ahi tuna tartare with roasted nori chips
Deep-fried salmon roll with chinese hot mustard

For entrees:
Warm wasabi house noodles with angus flatiron steak
Grilled ahi tuna (rare) with spicy mustard aioli

We had gone with the recommendations as was recommended per yelp, and for the most part, the appetizers were pretty tasty, light, and quite good.  The ahi tuna tartare was cool and crisp and created an interesting conflicting texture with the crunch of the nori chips.  It was an almost surprisingly pleasant place.  The fried salmon roll was basically a piece of salmon wrapped in seaweed and deep-fried.  When I saw "roll" I thought it was a deep fried sushi roll, but it was a whole hunk of salmon.  Once again, there was a conflict of textures between the crunch of the deep-fried outer layer with the squishiness of the salmon--which was a surprising but interesting mix.  It was accompanied with a spicy mustard sauce (typical Chinese hot mustard) which gave it a nice kick--so spicy that it cleared my sinuses.

Now onto the entrees, which were not as good as I had hoped.  The food was cooked in an exorbitant amount of the oil, that it felt like my tongue was swimming in a pool of oil.  My chin literally was sopping with oil, and no, I'm not a messy eater.  My pores were exuding the excess oil that I had consumed from my oily entrees.

The sea bass was soft and tender, but besides that it was DRENCHED in oil.  My cholesterol probably went sky rocket high after eating that sea bass.  I always thought eating fish was supposed to be healthy, but based on this experience, it was not.  Similarly, the sea bass was a little bit on the salty side.  There was some soy sauce that accompanied the sea bass which basically was deemed unusable since the sea bass was already salty.  As a side, the sea bass came with garlic noodles, which was topped off with an extreme number of onions, so that eating these garlic noodles tasted like I was eating onion noodles.  The onion flavor overpowered any taste of garlic in these noodles.  Like the sea bass, the noodles were drenched in oil.  I managed to finish my dish, and at the bottom of my plate...was a pool of oil.  Quite frankly, that is not very pleasing to see.  

My friend's wasabi house noodles with steak was similarly just as oily and salty.  When he had finished his dish, he was extremely full due to all the oil that caused such a satiating effect.  He had told me his flavors were nothing novel, special, or worth writing home about--and was something he could cook himself.

Chinese food is traditionally oily, and the House follows this "model"-- oily!  In my opinion, the food here is "glorified" Chinese food--just more expensive, smaller portions, and slightly better presentation.  

Talking about other aspects of the restaurant, the service is good--they keep on filling your water and keep on checking on how the food tastes, etc.  However, they had placed us right by the bathroom, as I had predicted, just because my friend and I look young.  A lot of restaurants think that younger people will not tip well, so they will place them right by the bathroom, despite having many other tables available for sitting at that time.

Parking can be a nightmare too since parking in down town SF can be horrendous.  But if you come around 6pm, you can park in the metered spaces for free.

Overall, I give the restaurant a *2* star review based on the following reasons::
- 4* stars for good appetizers and good service
- minus 2* stars for unhealthy amount of oil and salt used to cook their entrees, lack of novel concepts in their food, difficulty for finding parking, and seating us right adjacent to the bathroom despite having other available tables nearby.

I understand my review might be viewed as a little harsh as compared to what other yelpers have said about this place, but I feel my rating is honest and fair.  I've had my share of Asian/Asian fusion food to know that Asian fusion *typically* is tasty, novel, and healthy -- and the House did not meet my high standards.  I had expected a lot more from this restaurant due to the excellent ratings here on Yelp, but it really didn't cut it.  I truly am not impressed by dousing everything in soy sauce, salt, and oil.  That is *NOT* in any way Asian fusion.
author: Matthew L.

description: I bookmarked this on yelp a long long time ago, well not really maybe like 3 years ago. So I was excited that I finally go to try it, especially with friends that were just visiting. I was also lucky because I made a reservation and didn't have to wait in the bullshit of a line.  BUT The food turned out to be just okay. I can't even remember exactly what we ordered, because it all just wasn't memorable enough. That makes me sad. I think I just built up so much in my head, that when it actually came time, it just couldn't meet expectation. Quite a big bill too. Not really happy about that.
author: April D.

description:
The house is, hands-down, my favorite restaurant in the city.

If you're looking for a place that never disappoints on the food/service and doesn't break the bank, this is your answer!

Recommendations:

Appetizer:
I generally always get whatever is on special. I'd recommend their scallops (AMAZING), and their eel/dragon role (I've only had it once, and ALWAYS ask if they have it available...but no luck. I hope they bring this one back!)

Entree:
Get the sea bass with garlic noodles. It's their best dish. I've tried most of the dishes on the specials/menu, and anytime I don't order the sea bass, I regret it. 

Dessert:
Apple crumb a lad mode. yum!


Definitely make a reservation WAY in advance (especially if you're trying to go on a Friday/Saturday night).
author: Valerie Y.

description:
Haven't found a place in the city where I left with an amazement on how inventive and mind-blowing the food was... until I found The House. Using Yelp, I was on a search for the best Asian-fusion joint (or at least one with the highest Yelp ratings) in the city. Low and behold, with 1,757 reviews and still maintaining a 4 1/2 star rating definitely warranted a visit from my partner and I. After eating here, it definitely hits the mark on the 4 1/2... and I shall explain why....

We made a reservation over the phone and was surprised to able to snag a table for two for the next day at 7pm. On a Thursday night in the city, I didn't expect this place (with it's small dining area size and popularity) to have one. Nonetheless, we got lucky. Finding the place isn't too hard. Parking is a different story, especially in the middle of the dinner rush on a Thurs night. We circled Columbus, Grant and every alley at least three times for an empty (aka free after 6pm) spot, to no avail. We eventually settled for the North Beach Garage on Vallejo St ($3/hr isn't too shabby). 

Walking in, I was surprised as to how small the actual dining space was. By scanning the room, I could see why the fire marshal would have given the eye if more than 35 people (including waiters) had been seated in that space. I was happily surprised to with diversity of the people in the place. I overheard from the group of two couples, seated beside us, in their mid-50s talking about how they found this gem on Yelp. Each new dish that we'd ordered, sharply caught their eyes as they followed the traveling dish onto our table. Immediately they'd talk about the dish and decide whether to order it or not.

The menu read like a standard asian fusion restaurant with the typical meats: oysters, ahi tuna, shrimp, salmon, steak, prawns, sea bass, ribeye. How it was cooked AND presented was a different story. We  ordered:

H'ordeuvres (from the small plate section):

Deep-fried salmon roll with chinese hot mustard
Blue lake bean tempura with pickled ginger soy

Entrees: 

Grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy
Miso-glazed black cod

From the starters to the main meals, the presentation was eye-catching and delightfully interesting. I especially loved the fried salmon roll. Crunchy on the outside and so tender on the inside. The flavors were amazing (imagine 4th of July fireworks in your mouth) and had a fine dining type of presentation. The true highlight, however, was the sea bass. My partner had described it so perfectly, "grilled perfectly like a steak." One bite and I knew that it had to be marinated in butter because sea bass CANNOT be that ridiculously juicy and oh so tender in the mouth! 

Because we'd eaten enough fried food that day (and week) to be admitted in the ER for chest pains, we opted out of dessert. All in all, it was a fantastic meal. They would have gotten a 5-star rating, had it not been for their 3-star service. We had to waive for the waitress' attention not once, twice, or three... but FOUR times. And when I got her attention, she replied with the very stern, "just wait." That had cost her at least 5% minus off the gratuity. The service, overall, rivaled that of In-N-Out Burger or another fast food joint. I blame it on the high popularity of the place, coupled with the very limited seating. 

We left with a 10% tip and the total cost was still $86. Anything less than $100 is decently priced in our book. DEFINITELY coming back... as early as tomorrow.
author: Carloalexi M.

description:
The House was wonderful, and very crowded even on a Monday night.  To start, we shared the shrimp and chive dumplings, which were good, but not too exciting.  For the main course, I had the halibut and mussels entree.  It was delicious and full of intense flavors and gorgeous colors.  My friend got the sea bass, his go-to dish, and it was great, but, again, not too exciting.  Our third guest had the noodles and steak, also good but nothing special.  Every dish that I saw come out was beautifully presented, and I'm dying to try the special scallops (seems like they have these often), and the ahi tuni with nori chips appetizer.  

The service was ok - we felt like we had been forgotten about several times and had to hunt down the waitress to request the check - but everyone was nice and the restaurant has a relaxed atmosphere in spite of being so busy.  Overall, this was an excellent meal at a fun restaurant with great flavors.
author: Rachel A.

description:
I love the food, the presentation, and the taste... the size of the place not so much. 
Try the wasabi noodle, but then I love the spicy kick. Also, the sea bass was perfectly cooked. Am a repeat customer.
author: Taz S.

description:
Make sure you have reservations before coming here. Place is small and super busy!
Parking in this particular area is horrible. I recommend praying to the parking angel and hopefully find free street parking or going to the parking garage off of Vallejo with cute little notes in your parking space! 

Had reservations with my cousin at 7:30pm on a Sunday night, we were right on time and got seated right away. The tables are very close together so be careful when you squeeze into your seat and not knock down anyones drink or accidentally put your butt in anyones food!

It took awhile for someone to serve us water or even come to our table to greet us. Eventually after looking at the menu for about a good solid 10 minutes someone finally came over to tell us the specials that were happening that night. 

For appetizers we ordered the ahi tuna tartare and caesar salad w/ scallops. Both presented very well and delicious. 

For our main meal we both ordered the grilled sea bass. Mmmm it was melt in your mouth perfection. On the side were regular green beans and a side of garlic noodles which tasted like chow mein to me. Either way it was very satisfying. 

Dessert we ordered the mango tapioca and the bittersweet chocolate truffle cake. 
The tapioca was good but didn't really satisfy my sweet tooth after a meal. The truffle cake was a nice and rich, came with ice cream and sauce on the side. 

We also got a pot of peppermint tea to sit and settle our food. We paid a reasonable bill and left very full and happy! 

Service was fast, food was awesome, bellies were happy. All you need, and will be coming back!
author: Jenn T.

description:
PORK CHOP.
I've had almost every appetizer/entree at the house and the final verdict is always the same, get the PORK CHOP. The rest of their menu is pretty good too but the pork chop is by far the best item on the menu. The restaurant itself is crowded, noisy, and the service is sub par, but it still manages a 5 solely for the Pork Chop. 

Q: What if I wan't to get something els...
A: NO! Get the pork chop.
author: Eddie K.

description:
My favorite fish is Black Cod/Sablefish so I just had to try the Black Cod special. I'm not trying to be a hater or anything, but I don't think I enjoyed it as much as everyone else does. There's way too much going on with the plate. The fish was sandwiched between an ocean of sauce and a California roll cut at a really sharp angle with two long antennae things sticking out of it. I don't mind fancy plating, but this left me baffled. I wasn't sure how to approach the dish. How do I start eating it? 

The fish itself was cooked well. I personally think the best way to prepare Black Cod is steaming it, but they did a good job pan frying it while keeping the interior soft, rich, and buttery. It's actually pretty hard to overcook Black Cod since it's inherently so oily. However, all the other elements didn't really add to or enhance the fish in any way. It didn't seem like the dish was very focused. The puddle of sauce was a bit excessive and too heavy to compliment the fish. I also couldn't figure out what the California roll was for. Why was it there? I have no idea. I didn't think it paired well with the fish, and it seemed tacked on top for no reason but to look ridiculous. I ended up using the California roll to mop up the sauce, which worked pretty well, but I didn't think they really belong on the same plate as Black Cod. Despite making a nicely cooked fillet of Black Cod, the other distracting components conflicted with the fish.
author: Nei N.

description: Wow. The food here is amazing! They start you out with pickles. Which are perfectly crunchy. I got the fresh scallop appetizer, the black cod with California roll, and the famous wasabi noodles with pork. They waiter probably thinks I'm a pig, but when the food is this good, who cares! :) the black cod is one of the best I've had ever.
author: Tim C.

description:
FYI: you might not gain anything new from reading this review. It's purely entertainment as they 2442 reviews are more informative. 

I'm not usually a big fan of fancy restaurants because it's a waste and I think people are paying for the service and ambiance, but hot hell this house is on FIYAH! 

We booked a reservation a couple of weeks beforehand and I'm so glad we did. We walked in and we were immediately seated. The place was tight but that made conversation with the other table that much more enjoyable. More soon to be mentioned. 

The hostess was very sweet, and by sweet she didn't nag us to take our order so she could rush us out. We ordered the ribeye steak, and salmon swimming in some mysterious broth. Don't kill me for the lack of a complete description. And that's because any food you order will be good. The ribeye steak was tender and juicy, an....d perfect! Every bite was satisfying down to the core! Now I know why people come to fancy places. For the steak! My friend's salmon was pretty good too. I might be biased. How does one transition taste buds from steak to salmon? Don't answer that. I'll just have to come back to find my own answer. 

Here's the best part that I had to include in my review. There was this couple in their mid-fifties. They were adorable. We people watched "them," actually more like couple watched them the whole night. The woman was in charge and calling all of the shots while the man was just doing what he was told. I hope my marriage isn't like that. But they were cool because they took our picture and they poured a quarter of their wine when we ran out! WHAAAA!? How sweet. I don't come to the city often, but if this is how people are like in SF, I'm coming back every night. 

P.S. I didn't pay attention to the decor besides one minor detail. There's a little punchout of a house in the paper mat under your dishes. How lovely!
author: Bobby N.

description: The food was AWESOME! My boyfriend and I started out with some fried calamari and deep-fried salmon rolls. The salmon rolls were delicious, but beware of the cheese hot mustard dipping sauce, it's pretty spicy. For our main course, he ordered the angus ribeye steak and I got the grilled sea bass with garlic noodles. Both of the entrees were cooked to perfection, and the ribeye literally melted in my mouth. I highly recommend checking this place out, just make a reservation beforehand.
author: Ali C.

description:
I came here for a birthday dinner and the food was PHENOMENAL. Everything looked so good that it was difficult to choose from, and enough people have mentioned how delicious the food is (yes, definitely get the bass. It is everything that Yelpers have raved about AND MORE), I'm going to mention some of the less than awesome things about this place:

1) It is TEENY. Like, elbows jammed up against the next table type teeny. The layout and decor is functional but not particularly inspiring. Not the nicest place to go to for a very special occasion decor-wise.

2) Because of said teeniness, reservations are a definite must - we came a little early for ours and got seated immediately, but there was an extremely long line out the door starting from around 7pm.

In general though, fantastic food. Definite must-try.
author: Genevieve A.

description: Friday night, on a whim with friends: this place is tiny and was packed but we got seated within 5 minutes. Excellent food. We decided to share appetizers only: deep fried salmon roll: amazingly good, crab dumplings: yummy, scallops: to die for, crab cakes: interesting. All dishes were incredible and I want to go back to try the noodles. Services was attentive. I will be back!
author: Conny F.

description:
Perhaps it was an off night, and it didn't bode well when they weren't serving their famous pork chop. But here are the details of my dissent...

1. Appetizers: calamari was tiny and soggy, fried salmon roll had a LOT of salmon... but was a bit overcooked.
2. Grilled sea bass with garlic noodles: fish also was a bit overcooked, noodles were greasy.
3. Chicken with truffle oil: meh, I've experienced better. It was really something that I could've made at home.
4. Hamachi (special of the day): decent, but a bit lean so it was not the smooth, buttery texture you'd expect from this fish.
5. Logistics: parking in this area is a pain, the wait to be seated was long, and the staff was obnoxious and pushy. (We were there for less than an hour total for drinks, appetizers, and entrees...  and we were being rushed CONSTANTLY to order, eat, and leave. I mean, I get that you want to seat as many people as possible in this busy spot... but there's no need to skimp on the hospitality.)


Bottom line: for its price range and rave reviews... I expected MUCH more. I personally think that there are PLENTY of better Asian fusion spots in the City, and that your excess time/money would be better served elsewhere.
author: Erin O.

description:
Put your arm around me now
Only got a few more hours
So let's try to make it count
While the sun is shining bright at...THE HOUSE! - Megan Nicole (summer forever)

I made reservations for this place two weeks in advance for me and my family, which was completely necessary considering how small the place is and how popular the restaurant/area is. I can't emphasize how packed the tables are together so when they were able to accompany a larger group like mines, I was pleased. 

Seared scallops, fried salmon rolls, sea bass, ribeye steak w/ wasabi noodles, porkchops, halibut w/ garlic noodles...everything was good but the seafood was exceptional. Portions are a good size too so everyone was able to try everything.

One SF restaurant I can cross off my list. Very happy we came.
author: Danny H.

description: If you love Asian seafood, this is a must-try. It is a small, cramped restaurant in North Beach, but the food is amazing. Flavorful fresh dishes with a Japanese-Asian twist. The fresh sashimi with Asian beets was outstanding, as was the spicy soft shell crab with angel hair noodles. For main courses, the wasabi noodles with seabass were out of this world, as was the Yellowtail with crab rolls.
author: Larry P.

description: I remember the first time I came here for dinner was back in year 2000. The food were tasty, small portion, and expensive. thus i left with a half full stomach. I came back here for dinner recently, The food is still tasty, the portion is now bigger, and the price remained the SAME! More importantly, I left with a full stomach! I would definitely come back again as long as the wait is not too long.
author: Raymond L.

description:
Man.. where has this place been all my life?
Why am I the last person to ever find this place...

Better late than never. You could try o find parking around the area or go down to the park or anywhere else in between within walking distance. But if you're tried of trying so hard for parking you can go around the corner to the parking lot and call it a night and eat already. 

Its a small venue which probably handles about 50 odd people  at its best but its cozy and quaint and doesnt really matter as long as you try not to get seated by the bathroom or the door. Those locations aside the food is amazing! I could comment on all the dishes I had there but theres only two that I truly fell in love with. The sea bass is perfect! And the mango pudding is unlike anything i've ever had before. Anything else I can say to any effect will only serve to diminish their quality in your minds palate. 

Just thinking about those two dishes makes me drool....
;D
author: John-Michael C.

description: Well what can I can I say, I visited my favorite restaurant in San Francisco a few days ago and just like each and every previous time I had eaten there it was delicious. Both my girlfriend and I got the sea bass with garlic noodles. The fish was cooked perfectly and the noodles I could probably eat each and everyday! No matter what time your reservation is be prepared to wait at least 15 minutes but thats understandable because the place is small, good thing I had my beautiful girlfriend to help allow the time to fly right by. For apps I had two items that were specials that day and they didn't disappoint just like the entrees didn't. If you are a foodie such as myself THE HOUSE is a must try! Enjoy fellow yelpers and foodies!
author: Dmitriy G.

description:
Sensational. Food was delicious (tried the wasabi noodles and flank steak). Service was also phenomenal; even my water was constantly being refilled right away without me having to ask.

I will absolutely be back.
author: Orien W.

description:
Sigh. As much as I love this place, I have to knock it down a couple stars for my last visit here. Something just wasn't right. The mussels tasted a bit on the fishy side. The sea bass was still good, but the pork chop wasn't as good as I remembered. Worst of all, though, was the hurried service. You can tell they were trying to rush us out. They even brought out our entrees while we were still working on appetizers! The "rush" was so blatantly obvious, that I had to call them out on it.

I do plan on coming back here again, eventually, so I hope my next experience will be good again so they can redeem their 2 stars.
author: Kazu O.

description: We visited the House after almost a year of trying to making last minute reservations. I must say the food lived up to its expectation. The appetizers- dumpling and tempura green beans- were excellent. We also had the special for the day-Kobe steak- which was delicious with the mushroom sauce. My wife had the wasabi noodles which were delicious. We concluded with the chocolate truffle cake. Overall an amazing meal, we enjoyed our time at the House!
author: Ninad S.

description:
Unbelievable every time- and super accommodating to gluten free/dairy free! 
So the food is delicious and always cooked perfectly.
The staff is super friendly and attentive.
It's a great place to take a date or the parents- or anyone who wants mouthwatering food.
author: Colleen F.

description:
My bf and I decided to come here for our anniversary dinner since we have heard good things about this place and its in our neighborhood.  
 
It definitely helps to make reservation since they do get packed and the place is generally small and cozy. I made reservations the day of on a Saturday and was able to get the time I wanted.  
 
After arriving 15 minutes early for our reservation, we were seated 15 minutes later at the time of our reservation.  The waitress is caring and seems like she cared about our needs as apart of their restaurant experience.  
 
We ordered raw oysters which consist of what I believe to be Kumamoto which is more of the grimier ones with a strong aftertaste. 
  
We ordered the kobe beef skirt steak that came with mash potatoes and the recommended sea bass dish from yelp reviews. Wow, I am so glad we did. The sea bass's texture is perfect. I would recommend to dip only a tiny bit of the black sauce that resembles sweet soy sauce as it will be too salty. The sea bass came with stir-fry udon. It was a bit salty.  
 
 I was really pleased with their wine selection. We each ordered a glass of Piesporter Riesling, Reuscher-haart, Mosel, Germany 2008-very sweet and a glass of pinot noir, Country Line, Anderson Valley,  California 2009- buttery and not dry. 
 
Our bill came out to be about 100 dollars. Entrees ranged from 18-28 dollars. Wine came out to be 12-14 dollars a glass. I dont recall what the pricing was for the oysters.
author: Becky Q.

description:
Probably one of my favorite restaurants in SF!

The restaurant is small and hard to accommodate big groups but they do take reservations! 

Best appetizer dish is their deep-fried salmon roll... it is still raw in the middle, and served with a mustard sauce

For entree items, I definitely recommend their ea bass and/or ribeye!! I am drooling just thinking about it... YES it is that good!!!
author: Loni L.

description:
I met a friend here for dinner because he could not stop raving about the food. I've read good reviews but never thought to make the trek to north beach for it. We made a reservation for 6:30pm for two and when we arrived it was already packed! If you do not have a reservation, don't plan on getting a table. The place is small and compact. You are literally going to be sitting next to the other person from the other table. 

We ordered the usual that most Yelpers seem to get, the sea bass and the wasabi noodles w/ flank steak. The noodles with flank steak was superb. The sea bass was cooked to perfection. I have never had it prepared in that way. It was delicious. For dessert, fellow yelper Fancy Pants, suggested the tapioca. Pretty darn good. I'll come back for sure. Service is attentive as it can be for a busy small restaurant. Reservations are a must. Try the dishes that other Yelpers suggest. They know what they are eating.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
Is the restaurant small? Yes.   (You'll get over it!)
Are the tables close together?  Yep. (So what?)
Is it difficult to find parking? You can bet on it.  (Easy solution: Walk or cab it.)

Honestly, all of the above won't matter when you taste their food.  The starters we had were the Maine crab cakes and blue lake bean tempura. Both were delicious but the tempura wins out!  By far, their best dish is the grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy.  It's amazingly simple, but it's packed with flavor.  Even if you don't like fish all that much, this is the dish that might just get you to change your mind. 

Try it!  You won't be disappointed!!!
author: Khristine A.

description: What's to say that hasn't already been said, It's great! Every dish.... Surprisingly I never have difficulty getting a reservation. It's small but I like it that way.
author: Coco C.

description:
We came here on a Saturday night with reservations at 5pm.  As we arrived right at 5pm, there were already people waiting at the door.  The hostess seated the parties with no reservations first letting them know that they were allowed an hour to dine (before the next party arrives). When we mentioned we had reservations, rather than seating us, the hostess made us wait at the door eventhough our table was ready and proceeded to seat the no reservations behind us.  I thought this was a bit rude, she could have seated us and left us with menus at least.  

On to the food:
Calamari - tiny pieces of calamari, we've had better
Fried Salmon Roll - generous with the salmon but it was pretty well cooked, I expected it to be some what raw in the center
Seabass with Garlic Noodles - the seabass was delicious, butter goodness!  the garlic noodles were really greasy and not garlicky, reminded me of chow mein from the Chinese deli
Flat Iron Steak with Wasabi Noodles - Steak was good, nothing special, the wasabi noodles were really greasy and again, reminded me of chow mein from the Chinese deli
Passionfruit coconut creme brulee - yummy but the passion fruit sauce wasn't spread out on top but rather just a small spoonful poured on top, just enough to cover the center spot

They brought us our check as we were starting on our dessert.  While we were still enjoying our dessert, the waitress came by and flipped open the check holder to see if we were ready to pay.  When she didn't see anything in there, she slammed it shut and walked away.  We thought this was really rude and unprofessional, most places I've been to would ask if you were ready rather than flipping open the check holder to see if there was payment inside.  We were only halfway through our dessert!  

Overall, food ranged from okay to good.  Service definitely needs work.

3-stars
author: Veronica N.

description: As a SF resident, this is a spot I always recommend to anyone from out of town (even though many locals don't always know about it!). Great food, great atmosphere. You might have to wait a little even with a reservation but it's only because it's so small. Worth it!
author: Roya P.

description:
I love this place!  It's consistently good.  

We started with the salmon rolls as our appetizer.  
The seabass is fantastic - a big meaty piece of fish that's never overcooked and just melts in your mouth.   The wasabi noodles are delicious too.  Perfectly cooked noodles with just the right amount of chewiness to offset the crunch and saltiness from the sauteed long beans that are served alongside. 



The only con is that street parking is tough to find.  But you can generally park 4-5 blocks away at the Vallejo garage.
author: C l.

description:
Sea scallops were flabbergasting. 

Sea bass was flaky and, well, orgasmic. (Mom's words not mine, which was a little awkward.)

Warm wasabi noodles with ribeye steak (they ran out of flatiron steak) was a hot orgy of gorgeous nubile women and olympian men in my mouth.


Service: don't remember, I was in a gastro-trance.



Not sure how I'm going to top this review.
author: Nick And Mavy M.

description: Stopped in for lunch our first day in San Fran, based on Yelp review and we were not disappointed! The food was absolutely delicious and very reasonably priced. I ordered the shrimp and endive dumplings - which were great. The shrimp was fresh and had the right texture, and the flavor was delicious. For an entree I ordered the wasabi noodles with king salmon - it was amazing! My friends also ordered the bean tempura - FYI it's green bean stalks fried - but it's really good and so is the sauce it brings!.
author: Cary V.

description:
Since my initial review, I've been back 3 more times.  That averages out to be once every 1.5 weeks.

Whether I go for something new or stick with the dishes that I love, I never leave this place disappointed. There's never been a dish that I didn't like.  Maybe just thought it was "okay" but never a "meh, never again".

** Note: THERE ARE ONLY TWO UNPLEASANT/"MEH" THINGS I'VE COME ACROSS AT THIS RESTAURANT**
 #1 - They do not give you plain white bread with the mussel dish.  The is SO BOMB that you need bread to pair it with!  I mean, when there's no bread I'll drink the damn sauce, but some bread would be AMAZING.  Well, all they can do for you is put in an "order" for bread which is just 4 slithers of garlic bread.  This annoys me because a) they charge for this and b) I want PLAIN bread to taste the amazing sauce damn it!

#2 - I usually go for dinner, but earlier this week I went for lunch.  The waitress had a STINK FACE on the entire time.  No smiles, no manners, just flat out RUDE.  My cousins go all the time for lunch when the are in town from NYC and Shanghai, and they said they've always had her as a waitress and she just never smiles.  I don't really want to call her out, but seriously.. PLEASE PUT ON A SMILE.  Stacy, you're a great waitress, but it sucks that you aren't very friendly and never seem to smile unless you're serving a table of friends.

Anyways, back to the food. Those 2 things are my only complaints...and after some debate, I'm not touching my 5-star review.  Yelp should be focused on the food.. so let's keep it that way.

New dishes that I've tried...

1. Mussels in shrimp, garlicy sauce - the sauce is SO good.  I'm not a fan of mussels, but the sauce is too good to pass on.  Works out well that the company I'm with love to eat mussels.  They can have the seafood and just give me the bread to dip..-- BRING YOUR OWN BREAD.

2. Grilled Prawns + Mushroom rice/risotto - YUM!  Not usually a huge fan of mushrooms, but this rice was sooooo good. Had a hard time keeping my fork out of the boy's dish.

3. Sea Bass - the noodles weren't so salty this past time, so this dish has grown on me... except I don't LOVE the ginger soy sauce.. would prefer going for the meat or something else.

4. Halibut special - sauce isn't actually very spicy (not that I like spicy) and nothing to write home about. Pass...(unless you LOVE halibut)

5. Sesame Salmon - YUM!  But I'd still prefer meat over fish.  I'll always take an animal with 4 legs over seafood.  The sesame flavor was delish - my tiny little cousin liked this so much so finished the whole damn thing..which is pretty impressive for her.

Okay this review is already too long.  Let me just say this.  I don't give a lot of 5 star reviews..but this place and Chez Maman in Potrero Hlil are currently my 2 favorite restaurants. I never leave either place unsatisfied.
author: Melody T.

description:
This place is AMAZING! 

The layout's a little packed and it gets cosy on dinner service, so be prepared to inadvertently share conversations with your fellow hungry diners. If you really focus on what's important, you'll realize the bulk of conversations will be along the lines of "wow this is amazing, I can worship this food". 

Plus, the elderly chinese folks from the nearby Grant street would actually spill over to here and it's a nice fusion of the young hipsters and the old timers. 

Pork chop - 5 stars
Halibut - 5 stars (this is a chef special, might be seasonal)
Scallops - 5,000 stars
Steak - 5 stars
Risotto - 5 stars
Clams - 5 stars
Crab cakes - 5 stars (very good presentation as well)

I'm pretty sure that the rest of the menu will be 5 stars.
author: Kevin N.

description:
The Dish: My parents and I ate here for my birthday dinner. We were thrilled to get a reservation as the first time we tried coming here a couple months prior, we were unable to get seated. It was totally worth the wait. We ordered the Maine crab cakes for appetizer and man, it was GOOD. When I went to the east coast, the crab cake wasn't even that great. The sauce paired with the freshness of these crab cakes is seriously incredible. My dad got the steak special; my mom ordered the wasabi noodles with steak; and I got the sea bass. Every single dish was incredible. The steak - both medium and medium-rare were tender and flavorful. I normally don't enjoy fish (at all...ever), but something made me order the sea bass and I don't regret it at all. It melts in your mouth!!! It's the best I've ever had! 

Ambiance: It gets crowded around 7pm - but regardless of the time you eat, I would make a reservation. The service is not the best I've had, but it wasn't horrible either. Doesn't matter - the food makes up for everything. It's awwwwwwwwwwwesome!
author: Gina T.

description:
Nice casual place with really good food. 

The House is great - its not at all pretentious or over the top. the decor is simple and clean and though you don't have a huge amount of space, you don't feel too cramped in there. 

The food is great - its high end with awesome flavors, creative dishes and quality ingredients. We had a chicken dish and a wasabi noodle dish - both were really good.  The dumpling appetizer was super delicious.
author: Stephanie M.

description: Wow!  Get the house miso noodles with flat iron steak!  Absolutely amazing, with such a a unique taste.  The chicken breast with potatoes was amazing too, but the house noodles with steak is a delightful assault of flavors, you have to try.  Highly recommended.
author: Brian L.

description:
little tiny place with amazingggggg food!!!
i thought the Deep Fried Salmon roll was good but it wasn't my favorite since the salmon in my friends entree (it was a special that day) tasted a lot softer, therefore, better ahahha
wasabi noodles were good but a little too heavy for my taste.
my fav was the dessert!!! mango tapioca!!!!! i still miss it now :(
author: Ru C.

description: Met up with with some friends in the city to try this place. Service was on point. Everything looked so good on everybody else's table we decided to each order a main dish and share. It was a great idea and we loved everything. My only complaint was how close the tables are to each other but that's city living I guess.
author: Tracy B.

description:
If you go early enough, you can beat the dinner rush and be seated within 10 minutes!

The service was good and the food was delicious. This place had a very intimate environment with dim lights and candle lit tables. The food is Asian fusion and is plated with a lot of finesse. 

I had a prawn risotto topped with bonito flakes and my boyfriend had the half chicken. Both dishes were full of flavor and were very hearty!

We also had the long bean tempura and that was like typical tempura, nothing special. 

Overall The House was a youthful, trendy, and great little restaurant.
author: Monica T.

description:
This is by far my favorite go-to restaurant in the city. I always have a fantastic meal here...always!

The one thing that I think brings me back to a restaurant is consistency. The House definitely gets that done!

My favorite dishes are: 
1) Sea Bass with warm Wasabi noodles
2) Warm Wasabi noodles with flat iron steak
3) Ahi tuna tartare with Nori chips

Have a glass of Banshee Mordecai wine. Yes, they serve that and it's one of my favorites. 

Major tips:
make reservations
Cab or bus it. It's in North Beach. So good luck with finding parking.
author: Molly T.

description:
It's nearly impossible to find parking here and there wait can be ridiculous. So my tip to you is plan ahead and make reservations.

The food is pretty good with a nice presentation. This isn't a place that I crave to revisit often, but once in a while is okay to splurge my money at. I enjoyed my wasabi noodles and kurobuta pork chops, but I probably hyped it up to be something more.\

Overall, my friend and I had a wonderful experience.
author: Amimee D.

description:
Couple of my foodie friends highly recommended taking my folks to this place during our short visit to San Fran this past weekend. 

**PLEASE NOTE**
MAKE RESERVATIONS!! 
You need to make reservations before you go...unless you like to wait a long time. There was an error when I was making a reservation but when I called to confirm, the workers were very accommodating and took care of our party of three. 

We ordered the Crab cake for our appetizer- AMAZING! ... 
I've tried all sorts of crab cakes ... this one was good specifically due to the nice pairing with the sauces! YUM! 

For the main entrees... 
Wasabi noodles with steak- our reservation was at 9:30pm on a Sunday night. By the time we ordered this menu, they did not have the cut of meat they normally use...instead, they gave us T-bone... WE WERE A-OKAY with that! :) Nothing to describe...it was GOOD, PERIOD.  

Sea Bass with garlic noodles- The sea bass was so fresh, and was well complimented with the garlic soy noodles and greens! 'yum... 

Mushroom rice with grilled prawns!- This dish can be a little overwhelming if you just get it by itself. But the parents and I shared all three dishes so we were able to get the best of all three! The flavor infused in this dish was unbelievable!

I cannot wait to go back!! I'm actually craving all 4 dishes as I'm writing this review right now. 

Just trust all 3000 + reviews and go! 
it's yummy!
author: Oleevia W.

description: In summary: unbelievable. I tried the fried salmon roll and the wasabi noodle with steak. Both items were really tasty, a new combination of tastes to me. The steak with the noodle plate was soooo juicy and tender. Both dishes had a nice spicy kick from wasabi. The service was great and professional. It was a little small, so the tables are too close to each other.
author: Sasan A.

description:
My co-workers rave about this place and it is their GO TO spot for a group lunch. 

I had the Wasabi Noodles and found them a little sweet but yummy. The place was small and kinda out of the way but worth going.

Service was good, no complaints really other than the walk from the office (Fidi)
author: J-nine I.

description:
The House might be my new favorite restaurant in SF - definitely top three. The overall experience was awesome; the food was delicious and the atmosphere was nice. 

We started with the White Shrimp And Chinese Chive Dumplings which tasted fresh and melted in your mouth. 

Then, we split the Baked cod with crab and avocado sushi (a daily special) and the Grilled Ahi Tuna with spicy mustard aioli. In both dishes, the fish was cooked absolutely to perfection. The cod was unbelievable. The ahi tuna was perfectly grilled. Both were simply delicious. The crab sushi with the cod dish was also superb. I don't think you can go wrong here with fish - they clearly know how to cook it. 

We also had the Apple pie and chocolate cake for dessert. I know they are not very Asian-sounding deserts, but thats what we were in the mood for after some delicious fish. The chocolate cake with espresso ice cream was unreal. 

If you are looking for a dinner that is sure to be amazing, go to The House.
author: Alden Q.

description:
Their only fault, if you can call it a fault, is that the food is so good they've become overcrowded.  I see a new, larger location in their future!

Had the salmon spring rolls (cooked perfectly, served with a delicious Chinese hot mustard sauce) and the sashimi special plate.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
The place is small... but i loved everything we had. 

Came here with some girl friends and ordered the Mussles, Taretare, some kind of roll thing for appitizer. For the entre I ordered the sea bass...It was so very yummy.
author: Sheenie L.

description: This place is fantastic! Everytime I visit SF, I make sure to have a meal here.
author: Stefanie L.

description:
Ridiculously long wait. Came with two people on a weekday. Originally arrived at 630 told wait 40 min with possible early advancement. Told by hostess will call cellphone if earlier time available. Returned at 710 told 730. Waiting now it is 810 still not seated. No apologies from hostess. Very poor service. Unable to justify for the food. 
Also tried to call phone to reserve but phone did not work and unable to make reservation
There are other fusion choices around. Seriously if you respect your time, do NOT come here. Avoid at all cost.
author: Moon C.

description: I enjoy the food but when it comes to customer service certain staff members have no initiative to go above and beyond. Called to make a reservation to get a party of 7/6 people was told I couldn't and can only make a reservation for 5. Understandable given they are a small place. So I proceeded to ask if I could possibly get two table close to each other where I can seat 3 on one and 4 at the other but to no surprise the lady on the phone wasn't very accommodating. Not asking for the moon just wanting to take my family and friends to enjoy the food you serve but gotta say now that won't happen.
author: Jayson D.

description:
Great food !!! The place itself is small but the food is totally worth it. I ordered the Wasabi Noodles with pork. They were spicy , full of flavor and it was just the right amount.
Will be trying out the Sea Bass next time
author: Anshul N Eypsa T.

description:
Someone told me this was the best meal they've ever had so I had to give it a go. Though I cannot agree with my friend, I had a lovely meal here it just wasn't incredible.

All the seafood was cooked very well y there were interesting combinations of flavors. I enjoyed the sea bass y the shrimp y chive dumplings were actually very good. The salmon rolls were ok as well as the mussels, but surprisingly my favorite parts of the meal were the side vegetables y coleslaws.

Be aware that the portions for the appetizers are quite small and you need to make a reservation in advance because its a small place y it sells out. Worth a try but I don't know that I'd make it a point to go again.
author: Maya-Luisa G.

description:
Pretty much my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. When it comes to amazing seafood, The House is it. Yes, it's tiny. Make a reservation or the wait can be an hour plus.

But once you're inside, ask for the specials. And if scallops are on there, GET THEM!! We had their scallop special before and it was pretty much the most amazing thing EVER. Melt in your mouth. Alas there were only four...we could have eaten 40!

And of course for the main course, you have to get the sea bass. You just do. They fish specials are usually really good, but if you have never had the sea bass, that's the way to go. Enjoy!
author: Grace T.

description: The House tops the list of the best meals that I have ever had in SF. My bf and I both ordered their warm wasabi noodles with flat iron steak. The meal was fantastic and we both agreed that this was the one place that we would have to return to when we make another trip out here. They do get crowded during their dinner rush so make sure to make reservations beforehand.
author: Tammy C.

description:
The bf and I decided to try The House after a good friend recommended. Since it was last min, the only rsvp was at 10pm. We got there at 8pm. Was told 1 hour wait...LUCKILY someone called and canceled their rsvp. SCORED.

I had their delicious, tender, and flaky sea bass with noodles and string beans. Freaking awesome! it was perfect. The bf had their steak. A little on the fat side but the heavenly mash potatoes made for it. 


Decor: very cozy.
Service: awesome

Tip: make reservation in advance and I would recommend take a cab to avoid parking.

Oh, make sure you save room for dessert..the mango tapioca hit the spot.
author: Meems P.

description:
BELIEVE THE HYPE. It is TRUE. The House is one of the best restaurants in the city! This is one of the best meals I've ever had in San Francisco.

1. The location is AWESOME. North Beach is filled with tons of bars and crowds of people who really light up the city. If you don't have a reservation, be ready to wait.In the meantime, you can go to a nearby bar for cheap drinks and the latest game on TV! (wish there were more bars like these in SoCal)

2. The decor of the restaurant is simple, modern, and sultry. It is dimly lit and the walls are accompanied by black/white portraits.

3) Food= BOMB.

For the appetizer, we ordered the Seared Scallops (which was one of the specials). It was A-M-A-Z-I-N-G. The scallops were a bit raw which gave it a nice buttery texture. The flavoring of it (I don't know what it is) was SO good. It melts in your mouth and is paired with little sprouts on top. omgG so good...... they're to die for. Do keep in consideration that this is a pretty upscale restaurant, so you'll only get 3 scallops!

For my main course, I ordered the Sea Bass with Garlic noodles and Green Beans. Divine as well. The Sea Bass was soft and flaky, cooked to perfection. The Garlic noodles were well-seasoned and full of flavor with chunks of onions and garlic. The green beans had a similar taste as the scallops. It's a blast of flavor, then the flavor slowly simmers away as you enjoy the main ingredient.

My boyfriend got the Angus Ribeye Steak. He claims it's better than Houston's! I had a few bites of it and boy, it was good. There were toasted garlic (or almond??) pieces on it, making it rich with flavor.

4) Alcohol= delicious. I had the chardonnay while my boyfriend had the red wine (started with an M). My  chardonnay was refreshing, light, and fruity. Definitely, a good pair with my sea bass. Additionally, the red wine had a very soft wood undertone (which I definitely appreciated).

I loved loved this place. I would definitely come back here. I highly recommend you to make reservations, as it is seemingly impossible to get a table during peak hours.
author: Joyce M.

description:
Love this gem of Asian Fusion place. 

Everything we had was awesome.  Tofu curry noodles, garlic noodles with chicken,  tempura beans, shrimp dumplings, fried calamari and grilled cod. 

There is public parking around the corner. 

Service is quick and not pretentious. Its good place for kids and large groups ( we were 10).
author: Rutuja K.

description:
Been here 2 times and it's a 5-star experience every time!  Nice little hole in the wall type place in North Beach.  The House is Asian Fusion at its best and won't disappoint once you get past the crowd of people standing in line.  Ambience is pretty classy and upscale, but at the same time pretty casual.  

Made reservations beforehand for prime time spot during 6-8 pm and once we got there they sat us at our reserved time.  For the main entry, me and my friend ordered the Deep-Fried Salmon Roll with Chinese hot mustard and Grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy.  The Sea Bass melted in my mouth with every bite I took!  This isn't your ordinary Sea Bass, it's Chilean Sea Bass!  The salmon perfectly complements the sea bass with that kick of mustard.    

For dessert we got the Coconut Crème Brulee with passion fruit sauce and Deep Fried Bananas.  The crème brulee is sweet and creamy.

Highly recommend the House for it's exquisite taste and ambiance.
author: Andrew P.

description: Came here again for dinner (a friend planned it and made reservations). Food was again Very good and the service is acceptable. Will definitely continue coming here if I don't have to do the reservation.
author: Precious K.

description:
The House is one of those elite eating establishments that should be on every San Franciscan 'top 10 places to try'. The food is scrumptious and beautifully presented. If you're looking for the perfect chic dinning experience for a birthday or just date night look no further. 

The staff is impossibly sweet, which makes each visit all the more enjoyable. The place itself is pretty small and it's not uncommon for them to be packed, so reservations are a must; especially on Fridays and Saturdays.
author: Janine J.

description:
Need a semi-casual night out with the significant other? Craving asian but not TOO asian so it can still be considered a "nice-dinner"? Then, look no further! The House is absolutely divine. 

Salmon roll: Delicious twist of your normal "dynamite" roll at sushi restaurants.They use this magic-sauce on it as well (that's actually not sirracha) which adds the perfect amount of tastiness to this dish. 

Sea bass- buttery-melts-in-your-mouth-i'm-not-even-big-on-fish person-will love! Perfect texture and richness in flavor. A must try from this restaurant! 5 out of 5 

Flat iron steak (medium-rare) with wasabi noodles- yes, please! noodles were a bit drenched in oil but I guess that helped with locking in the flavor(?); overall, 4 out of 5 stars

Now all you'll need to complement this fine meal is a few glasses of wine and dessert. We've always opted to walk around Little Italy for dessert options so can't speak on the House's selection. 

Service: Hostess was nice but your waiter/waitress may vary. They're so efficient that i almost felt like my dinner was super rushed. During my last visit, the waitress reached for my plate to take away while my fork was still in my hand and I was in mid-chew- hence, minus one star. 

Make sure you make reservations! This place is always crowded- don't get denied at the door because you didn't call ahead! ENJOY!
author: Patricia K.

description:
This is why Yelp was invented!

Its a small, understated restaurant that you could easily walk past if it were not for Yelp.  It seems like this place gets packed quick but we got lucky cause we came just as they were opening.  A lot of people walked in after us with reservations so I would suggest making one.  The food is amazing.  Very unique flavors, well prepared, and extremely tasty.  We tried the ahi tuna appetizer and the wasabi noodles and steak.  The appetizer was fine and good but the wasabi noodles and steak were the real stars.  I could eat a bucket of that stuff.  Load it up, send it to my table, and I'll be a happy camper.  Too bad I dont live near this restaurant because I would be a regular for sure.
author: Sam P.

description: I love the menu here.  I had the mixed green salad w grilled bass fillet.  Parking could be difficult though.
author: Eva L.

description: The pork chops are a killer, best ever.  Had the Hamachi starter and the slices were cut thick and big very well worth it.
author: Tommy P.

description:
The House was half empty on a beautiful October Saturday just before the end of the lunch shift, so that may be a good time to beat the line. I'm glad I didn't wait because I thought this place was totally just okay. I normally steer clear of Asian fusion, but was excited to try The House because of its reputation, and hey, I live in California now and fusion here is actually a good thing, right?

The good:

- The amazing fried salmon roll with hot Chinese mustard. They wrap raw salmon up in nori and flash-fry it until the outside is crackling and the inside still meltingly raw, then serve it up with some pickled cabbage and carrots and nasal passage-assaulting mustard sauce. Genius.
- The rainbow of fresh vegetables that comes on every dish
- The mashed potatoes

The not great:

- Maybe my brain's horseradish center was just tapped out after that Chinese mustard, but I found the house wasabi noodles cloying and one-note - surprising to me because I normally love this kind of thing.
- Shrimp curry noodles were hugely disappointing - watery and not spicy or flavorful, with small, bland shrimp. This dish actually did taste like some sort of dulled Americanized version of a more interesting dish, rather than a new spin on a classic.

That fantastic salmon roll could bring me back, but after the main courses I couldn't help feeling like fusion had let me down again.
author: Cecilia L.

description:
Recently my favorite Washingtonian and I were treated to dinner at The House. While the mathematician of our lot translated the numerous conversations carrying on in Mandarin around us, we ordered the Blue Lake green bean tempura, the asparagus with roasted sesame dressing and the Maine crab cake to start. 

I should begin by saying that "Asian fusion" isn't really my thing. Far too many folks slap wasabi or ginger or soy on something and call it "Asian fusion." And don't even get me started on the kimchi imposters (it should be a crime to call these awful cabbage slaws KIMCHI!) 

That said The House is in a league all its own when it comes to "Asian fusion." One look around the restaurant and that becomes clear. After all, when was the last time you saw Asian families packing the tables at places like Betelnut or Roy's? They, along with diners of every hue, pack The House because the food is immaculate! Our entire table was impressed at every turn from the appetizers I mentioned above to the main courses (flat iron steak served over wasabi noodles, grilled sea bass and sashimi) to the desserts (where the mango tapioca was a surprising stand-out.)

NOTES: 
Make reservations, this place is tiny and was completely packed on a Tuesday night

Service can be brusque but is always efficient

Do NOT skip dessert

While waiting do not remove the menu that is taped to the window to look at it - this really irritates the woman who runs the front of the house. Instead ask her for a copy of the menu.

CONCLUSION:
The House is no flash in the pan - the restaurant's been around since 1993 and remains at the top of its game.
author: Miriam W.

description:
I had really high expectations for this place, but it fell just a tad short.

I heard raves about the wasabi noodles, but they were just so so so salty! It was pretty ridiculous. My bf's 75 year old grandma spit it out! I don't know if this is just a one-time fluke, but darn it was salty! While the noodles were too salty, the pork was SO sweet! The sea bass was excellent though.  

It was a very cramped location and parking was such a pain. Be sure to make a reservation. Due to the noise, tight spaces, and long waits, t's not exactly the most comfortable and happy experience eating here, which is why I'm taking one star off.
author: Farrah N.

description: Service was truly terrible. We felt on edge every time we asked a question or when we weren't quite ready to order. It made our dinning experience unpleasant. While the food is good, it is far too salty.
author: Karina S.

description:
Summary: Why pay to get treated like pooh on someone's finger, when there are a gazillion great restaurants with much better food and amazing service? We were seated at 8:45 for an 8:00 pm reservation. No apologies, just plenty of entitled attitude. And the food was just ok, as was the service. Depressing! 

Details: My boyfriend took me there for my birthday. Our reservation was for 8 pm, and we were pretty close by 7:45. I was worried that we might be a bit late due to downtown/north beach traffic being so unpredictable, so I called to let them know we *might* be no more than 10 mins late. That got me a mean, impolite lecture, the sort you give a second grader for lighting fire to a cat's tail! - basically if we weren't there by 8:15, our table would be given away. 

We were inside the restaurant at 8:02 (yes, 2 mins late!) but it took 10 minutes for the hostess to acknowledge us. There were no apologies for our table not being ready, no indication as to when it would be ready and no updates for close to 30 more minutes.  Folks who walked after us were being seated, which really pissed me off, but we were starving by then and decided to wait. We were finally seated at 8:45, with no apologies. Apparently, the 15 minute limit just applies to the customers, not the restaurant! 

The House used to be my favourite restaurant, but NEVER going there again.
author: Sam B.

description: Truly, absolutely loved every part of our meal here. The two of us shared two appetizers, two entrees and a bottle of wine. The food is fresh and bursting with flavor. The only real downside is that the restaurant is pretty small, so the tables are super close - but it's a small price to pay for such a good meal!
author: Lauren C.

description:
I've eaten here at least 3 times before writing this review. The food has been very consistent over the years although the menu doesn't change much. Miso black cod with sushi rolls is always a popular dish here (one of the 3 daily specials). Their specialty is seafood with Asian influence and you can't go wrong here.

For entrees, I went for the swordfish with coconut curry sauce this time. The fish is perfectly cooked while the curry soup is so tasty that I drank the last bit of it. The server was nice enough to swap the potatoes (side dish) for wasabi noodles which are a much better choice for the curry.

Great service. Reservation is a must. Save some room for desserts at the end (Passion Fruit creme brulee and mango tapioca). 

There're parking lots nearby on Vallejo St between Stockton and Powell.
author: Saran R.

description:
Tasty, tasty, tasty. We've been coming to The House for years--and they have never failed us. When visitors come up to Northern California, The House is usually my top 5 restaurants that I refer them too. The place is a little on the smaller side but offers a very cozy feel to it. The staff is especially friendly and quite funny. 

You also cannot beat the price for the high quality food and presentation. Your average dinner plate is around $20 and worth every penny!

The Sea Bass is a MUST! Extremely well seasoned and melts in your mouth. The garlic noodles that they pair them with are exquisite! Other tasty favs include the flatiron steak and any of the specials of the day. As for appetizers, you have to try the deep fried salmon rolls! Don't confuse them with the Cheesecake Factory's "Firecracker Rolls" because they will quickly correct you on that!  :)

Another tip is that you really need to make reservations for this place as they are always packed but extremely worth the wait!! It's too bad that I live in the South Bay or I would be a weekly regular!
author: Nam N.

description: Make a reservation!  Order the Kurobuta Pork Chop with pomegranate currant sauce.    It's amazing!
author: Minna T.

description: Stood in the front for 10 mins. All the waiters were walking around, no one greeting. Just looked at you and kept doing their own things. I asked one of the Africa American waiter "should we just wait here? He kept doing his own thing and said "yes". How about "Hi, I'll be right with you." I don't mind waiting, but getting ignored like that is very disrespectful. It's not even that busy.
author: Jim C.

description:
I had read the good reviews, so I decided to get take out for dinner on a Monday. LOVED IT!!! And keep in mind my 5-star review is based on take-out service and food, so I know that the dining-in experience would be even better.

The location is super convenient at the corner of Grant and Columbus. The place is little and seemed crowded, so I would definitely make a reservation ahead of time. However, a party of 5 came in after me, and the hostess was kind enough to seat them as long as they would be finished before the reservation at 8pm. Most places would just say no. 

I quickly placed my order and waited at the front. Within 5 minutes I had my food and was on my way. She even asked how far I was going to ensure that the food would travel well. Very thoughtful.

I ordered the crab cake and the tempura green beans (I guess I was craving fried foods), and they were both stellar! The crab cake was moist yet crispy, and the sauce had a kick to it. Very nice. The green beans were great. I was hesitant about the sauce at first, but after the first bite the flavors totally made sense together. I love when I am surprised by flavor combos like that!!

Because I was carrying out I didn't want to get something fancy that would be a better experience there, so I didn't get the amazing sea bass that I saw coming out. Will definitely be back to try out the fish and other amazing things on the menu. YUM!
author: Kristen G.

description:
We had a reservation for 8 pm.  After a quick drink at Vesuvio, we walked over to the House.   We arrived pretty much right on time.  We were quickly greeted and quickly seated.  This is a small restaurant and the tables are pretty packed in.

Our menus were brought to the table soon after.   Our server came over and covered the specials (one of which they were out of).  

After a bit of discussion, we were ready to order.  

Starters:

We selected the scallops special.

After discussion, and some narrowing down, I selected  the fried calamari.

Mains:

She selected the grilled  sea bass with garlic ginger soy.

I selected the Niman ranch pork chop with pomegranate currant sauce.

Dessert:

We selected a chocolate cake with espresso ice cream.   I can not remember the actual name of the dessert.

We shared all of the food.

Scallops - These were very good scallops.  They had just that  slight taste of the sea without having an overbearing flavor.  They were well cooked.  There was no hint of being rubbery.   The greens worked well with the scallops.   The lemon sauce was fresh and bright.

http://tinyurl.com/6dlfdjn

Calamari - This was decent calamari.  I did not think it was outstanding.  Like the scallops, it was not rubbery.  The breading could have used some more flavor.  The small bitter salad served as a side was delicious.

http://tinyurl.com/44hjoqg

Sea Bass - This was very good.  It was flaky.  It had just a touch of the flavor of being grilled.   And once again, it had just a nice delicate flavor of the sea. I did not try the sides.

http://tinyurl.com/43wqhsx

Pork Chop - This was one amazing pork chop.  It  was succulent and  meaty.  The pomegranate sauce was very good.  Some might think it a touch too sweet but I did not.  The asparagus and whipped potatoes made for nice sides.

http://tinyurl.com/3nrtbkt

Chocolate Cake - This was wonderful chocolate dessert.  I enjoyed every bite.   She liked it too.

http://tinyurl.com/6gpue5e

As usual, we shared a bottle of red.  I get 2/3rds and she gets 1/3.  Lol, she is the driver.  If I recall, this was a bottle of Anderson Valley.

Ambiance - This is a simple, small, and well kept room.  Even with it's small size, it is still a comfortable space full of people enjoying their meals.

Service - I would say the service is professional and helpful.   It is not robust or what I would call friendly.  I did not find it rude, just focused.  I think it is a small restaurant and they need to turn tables over quickly.  They focus on precision.  There wasn't a lot of "are you enjoying your meal?" or "can we get something else?".  But they are there at the key moments and they keep the meal flowing.

Overall - I was impressed.  I think the food is the focus of the restaurant.  It is not a flashy restaurant and the service is functional.  I would not hesitate to return.
author: Mark D.

description:
5 stars for the food! 

For starters we had: 
- Seared Scallops
- Ahi Tuna Tartare
- Deep-fried salmon roll with chinese hot mustard
* Scallops were my favorite, but were also the special and not listed in the menu 

Entree 
- Warm wasabi house noodles with angus flatiron steak
- Mushroom rice with grilled prawns
- Grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy
* All three dishes were amazing. Well prepared and presented 

Dessert 
- Warm Apple pie a la mode 

Drink
- Riesling 

I agree with the other reviews that the place is small and very cramped. You have to make reservations in advance and parking is a nightmare. However, I wouldn't let those contributing factors take away from the fact that the food was delicious and decently priced.
author: Maggie Y.

description: Everything was absolutely DELISH!!!!  The prime rib... Pork chop... Sea bass... Flat iron... Can't go wrong with either. Their ahi tuna tartare appetizer was the BOMB!  Next time I come back to SF.... I'll definitely have to come back to THE HOUSE!
author: Tammy H.

description:
Fantastic!  We came here the day before Thanksgiving Day, and was pleasantly surprised at how delicious all of the dishes were.

I'm always skeptical of "Asian Fusion" cuisine, but this place knocked it out of the park.

We started with deep fried salmon rolls, which melted in your mouth.. it was just amazing!  

Main entrees we ordered: Pork Chops, Black Cod, Sea bass with Garlic Noodles..  Oh so good!  

I skipped out on dessert, but from what I hear it was wonderful.  :)

5 stars all the way!
author: Leanne T.

description:
This restaurant has really slide down the last few years. Went to get dinner with a group of four at nine pm. The service was terrible,  and the food was a shadow of its former creativity and original  flavors. 

We started our dinner by waiting 20 min to place our order. Our crab cake appetizer was tossed onto the table and to no surprise it toppled over with the artistic taro chip flourishes falling onto the table. The waiter didn't even notice. After the next three dishes were tossed in the similar manner, with glasses being knocked we mentioned it to our waitress who said that she hoped the food still tasted "okay despite how the dishes look." House used to prior it self on its presentation. 

The dishes were very salty with little of the robust oriental spices we are used to.  I almost wonder if the restaurant has changed ownership. 

So disappointed to see an old favourite in such disarray.
author: Jen C.

description:
Did I come on an off-night?  Not really sure what happened but I was highly disappointed given the amazing Yelp ratings.  While the appetizers were unique and pretty good, the rest of the food didn't stand out at all, and for the price tag, I feel we could have gotten a better meal elsewhere.  All the food seemed to be missing that unique all-star "wow" factor that you'd normally expect from an SF place with a yelp rating so high.

I might give it another chance just to see if my experience was a fluke, but it probably won't be anytime soon.

And yes, the place is in North Beach, so don't expect to find parking anywhere, ever.

Funny story, we saw the hostess the next morning at Turtle Tower.  Chicken pho FTW!
author: Cynthia G.

description:
Maybe I was able to unhype the hype about this place, or maybe this place was just pretty damn good, but for whatever reason I really enjoyed this place.

Appetizer:
I started with a small but very fresh tuna tartare, and the unagi with avocado sushi rice (read: dragonroll with high quality eel). Have fun trying to share the unagi because its not pre-cut. I attempted to cut it into pieces with a butter knife, which was as good as trying to cut it with the handle of my fork.

Entree:
Predictably, they had a miso sea bass, but for my entree I ordered the other white fish, a Black Cod special topped with a sushi roll. Holy bujezus, so good. The pomegranate currant porkchop, which I was highly skeptical of since the menu was primarily seafood, was SO moist and flavorful! The currant-pomegranate sauce was tastefully incorporated into the dish - just enough to add to, but not overpower the flavor.

Dessert:
The truffle cake tasted like every other flourless chocolate cake, cept with really good coffee ice cream. The mango tapioca was like the stuff you get at chinese restaurants, except it was DELICIOUS. 

Keep your expectations realistic, the servers are nice and food is fresh, pretty, and tasty.
