Pro Move: Don't dawdle with your drink orders or you'll get lapped by your food! The House brings out dishes VERY quickly. Of course, their huge pours emptied a bottle of wine into our four glasses in no time.

The halibut special was a strong choice as well. My pork chop wasn't a great cut but it certainly was flavorful. The pomegranate sauce exceeded expectations too.

The yellowtail sushimi starter came in very generous portions, presented nicely with seaweed paper, avocado and what I recall to be a mild pico de wasabi. 

The octopus salad was fine, and healthy, but not something we'd order again. The octopus leg is cut and breaded for Western tastebuds and thus loses its impact in the salad.

Pro Move: Don't bring a large bag if you're coming from work. The House doesn't have much room between/under tables, especially for tall people.
author: Mike H.

description: A truly terrific meal; everything was so flavorful and on point. You must try the octopus salad which had an amazing sauce and the sea bass their known for was so perfectly cooked. Great, attentive service despite it being a busy Friday night. The crowded and tightly spaces tabled only added to the intimate atmosphere. Highly recommended and for good reason. Can't wait to go back!
author: Lauren C.

description:
Went here for the first time yesterday and I loved it!! We didn't have a reservation so we had to wait 1.5 hours, but it was definitely worth it. In the future I will be sure to make a reservation...

The place is really small and cute, but the food is delicious!!

We had the crab cake for starters which was the best crab cake I had ever tasted...and it was super cute...shaped in a pear. I had the ever so famous seabass with wasabi noodles and green beans. Oh my my it was sooo good. Noodles were great and sea bass was cooked perfectly. My bf had the ribeye and he is sure it is the best ribeye he has ever had. Everything was good and relatively priced. Will be going  back again for sure
author: Krista B.

description:
Ordered: Deep Fried Salmon roll, Wasabi House Noodles, Chipotle BBQ Pork Loin Sandwich. 

All very good. It would be great if the Deep Fried Salmon Roll comes in smaller sizes, as in rather than 4 large rolls, maybe 8 smaller rolls. 

The restaurant is not very big and it might get crowded at peak hours. 

I'd like to come back to try their Kurobota Pork Chop.
author: Jonathan N.

description:
I came to this place with my girlfriend. She brought me here for my birthday. She made reservations and we waited about 5-10 mins before we were seated.

Note: This place is very small. Tables are next to eachother.

Other than the place being very small, the food was delicious! I had the Rib Eye Steak which I fell in love with. The steak was very juicy and tender. The way I like it. My girlfriend ordered the Sea Bass with noodles. The sea bass melted in your mouth as you eat it. It was that good. The noodles were also good. The sauce that came with the sea bass was good. Some may think the sauce may be too much for the fish, but I enjoyed it. For dessert, we had the Creme Brulee. It was delicious and had the right sweetness to it. No complaints there. I wish this place was bigger and in a better location. The parking is all bad especially if you go during Friday through Sunday. I can imagine parking being bad during the weekday anyway since this place is so close to Broadway. Can't wait to come back and eat here again. Make sure you make reservations if you plan on eating here. If you don't make reservations, be prepared to wait a long time.
author: Steven O.

description: Kudos to Angela's  staff; all performed exceptionally well on your night off. As a business owner u should feel comfort in the service, quality and employee buy-in for your mission statement. Nice job Doreen and Kudos to the Chefs for serving hot, prompt food....you have set the  bar high for quick, hot awesome food in the Bay area.
author: Kirk D.

description:
The wait: On a Saturday night at 6pm, my guy and I decided to try "walking-in" for The House.  I Know, we've made better decisions but hey...spontaneity is the spice of life.  Overall, we waited an hour and 20 minutes.  Not TOO bad.  Just walked around and found an awesome bar nearby.  

The service: We came back a little earlier than the estimated time but the hostess was on point with her timing.  She was patient and really took care of people coming through that door.

The food: ...speechless
-The scallops on the special's menu was recommended to us and UghhhH. SO GOOD. Comparable or better than, dare I say... _ _ _.
-Pork chops--flavorful, fresh, elegantly presented and just DELICIOUS. 
- Steak with wasabi noodles was tasty. I wasn't blown away by it although it was aesthetically pleasing upon arrival.
-Chicken liver salad was mediocre.

Overall, fun dinner with great food.  The limited seating and cramped space added to the atmosphere and made this dinner memorable.  Although 2 of the 4 dishes we had weren't exceptional, the quality of the food and thought behind each dish was commendable.
author: Julie P.

description:
I always feel like I'm gambling when I'm coming here.  Not even gambling in a sense where you win sometimes.  This place is called The House.  Well of course The House wins... every time.

I don't get the hype at this restaurant with all the 5 star reviews like I don't get why Kanye is such a prick but still have so many followers.  Ok well, at least Kanye can deliver the goods.  Can't deny the lyrical genius in him even though I could care less about the self absorbed person that he is.  House though... I don't get it whatsoever. Is there something wrong with me? Maybe my palate is going through changes? Maybe everything I know about flavor is something like that of color blindness where a color might not be the way as I saw but was something entirely different. While everyone is 5 star trigger happy for this place, I've been here a handful of times, and I have not had a dish that was not way too salty.  At first I thought I was alone as though apocalypse just happened and there is no one to be found... but then it happened.  One after another, and soon a handful of people showed up around me with the same thought about "The House". I was not alone. So freakin relieved I'm not crazy.  

The steamed mussels always seem to have a stench to them. I don't believe it's rocket science but the equation: Mussels + musty death decaying stench = not fresh.  It happens I guess but the smell is so foul I think I'd be able to smell it if I was the chef/cook.  Why would you still serve it?  I stopped ordering those after the 3rd time.  4th time's the charm perhaps? Uh... I'd rather not.  Gambling isn't my forte.  Hey, but if you have been on a hot streak at the blackjack tables over at Lucky Chances Casino, it's probably worth a shot to grab the mussels.  I let the lady at the front of the house know but she insisted that it was fresh so I didn't want to make a fuss on someone's birthday and took it as a loss.  You win some you lose some... wait what am I talking about?  This isn't the casino... I paid for a bad product.  You should gladly take back your smelly mussels.  The House wins.

The ribeye steak. Salty. I really thought it was from an ocean cow breed of some sort with scaly fins and all, naturally brined from the ocean before it was filleted and prepped for dinner. Maybe it wasn't the steak... maybe it was the teriyaki sauce.  Asian fusion in The House... to eat here you gotta be BALLIN' for the night so you square up n shoot for it... nothing but SOY SAUCE! BOOM! Asian Fusion! I mean can anyone else tell that this spot is Asian fusion with all that soy sauce?  Let's put more just to make sure they know we are Asian fusion up in The HIZZZOOOOUSSSEEE!!!!!!!! (with two arms up n all like a field goal was good)

The wasabi noodles with flat iron steak.  Ok guys, a quick guessing game... Place your bets... bet on Player or bet on The House.  Everyone done betting? Ok here's the question.  What is the most common ingredient you can think of that goes with wasabi? Besides fish of course.  WINNER WINNER CHICKEN DINNER!!!  I couldn't hear what you said on the other side of my computer but yes you got it!  SOY SAUCE!!! Hahahaha!  Winner!  Too salty.  I mentioned it to the lady and once again got some resistance.  I ended up packing this one to go and remade it at home toning down the brilliant soy sauce effect.

Grilled Sea Bass... take a wild guess folks.  You win... again (in the most unenthusiastic tone of voice).  Grilled Sea Bass in garlic ginger SOY.  Use your imagination on this one.  I'm skipping it.

My friends loved it.  I told you in the beginning... I don't get it.  They are also friends who tell me how great their dining experience was even if there were cockroaches running around.  As long as they are happy for the birthday party that's all that really matters in my book.  Instead of disrespectfully complaining about everything like Kanye would have at the restaurant and ruining a great birthday outing I get to talk about my experience here on yelp.  While I enjoyed the presence of great friends, the food was just additional to the QT spent with them.

Unless you love soy sauce or salt as much as you love your secret vices...
It's a gamble coming here where The House wins every time. 

2 stars didn't seem fair so 3 is the best I could do.
3 stars for service.  Food came out in a timely manner however if a guest says they don't like something just change it.
2.5 stars for food.  I can see the concept but it lacks finesse.
3 for vibe. Always busy and bustling for the cozy touch of commotion.

I won't be going back unless I absolutely have to.
author: Colin M.

description:
The menu was pricey. The restaurant was cramped & noisy. You really had to talk louder if you wanted dinner and conversation with your date.  The ahi tuna tartare and the kobe beef salad were ok.  
The salmon roll appetizer was really yummy. I really loved the wasabe noodles.  The pork chop with pomegranate sauce was so tender and perfectly cooked! I would definitely go back for more.
author: Shirleyanne A.

description:
It is the 3rd time I'm going there and I've always been delighted. The food is super good, and the price are reasonable regarding the quality! (30$/person). Main meals are quite big so unless you are a bit eater don't plan starter+main meal (and I am quite a big eater).

Important note: you really have to book in advance. We came at 6:30 and had to wait for 1.5 hours. When you start eating you understand why :)
author: Philippe R.

description:
Small little place but the food was SOOO good.  I will admit that I ended up with food envy here.  While my salmon was delish, my friends chilean sea bass was even better!  When we do go back, I will be sure to order that.  The three of us had:  

Yellowtail sashimi app
Bottle of Resiling
Chilean Sea Bass
Seared Salmon with broth (can't recall which)
Tuna Steak
Creme Brulee

If I needed to fuss I would say that the custard in the creme bruless needed to be a little firmer but other than that, I have no complaints.  I am glad we made a reservation as the line waiting by the door was a little ugly during certain times.
author: Vonnie S.

description:
They will skip your reservation (without calling you) if you are over 20 minutes late. Sucked for us because we missed our reservation and waited about 45 minutes for a table. Yeah I know it was our fault, but it sucked. Haha. Plus, the little lady wasn't very nice about it. Meh.

The food, however, was pretty awesome and came out in a super timely manner. I particularly enjoyed the fried salmon roll, it is probably my favorite, even though it was just an appetizer. I had the steak with the wasabi noodles, the steak was great as expected but the noodles were a tad bit salty for my taste. Still good though.

I am an iced tea addict but was very disappointed in the "lychee" black iced tea, which was pretty much watered down iced tea with a single lychee in it. Boooo.

Service was eh. I don't believe you should compromise service regardless how great the food is. HOWEVER, I would most definitely come back here again. Haha.
author: Danny P.

description:
I'll give this place a 3.5 
The Deep-fried salmon roll not bad, pretty good with the chinese hot mustard. 
I had the seabass with ginger soy, Wasabi noodles with steak. 
The taste wasn't bad but nothing much special.
1 starter, 2 entree $60 for 2 people. 
All I could say is, the food is not bad but nothing too special and a little bit over price.
The restaurant is pretty small so it gets loud which you can't really talk.
author: Niko L.

description:
YUM YUM YUM YUM YUM!!!

I didn't have the pork chop, but it looked amazing!!!!!!  I want to go again for that pork chop!

The MISO wasabi noodles were also spectacular!!!  I'll get a side of that too...
author: Janet L.

description:
Love The House! 

I've been lucky every time I come here because they always have my favorite specials. 

Miso black cod with california rolls - cooked to perfection every time.

Seared scallop appetizer - I love scallops, so I love this dish.

Pomegranate porkchop - on their regular menu, but equally delicious if your special favorites are not being served that night.

Kobe beef skirt steak w/ mashed potatoes - I substitute out the mashed potatoes with the house noodles which are very good. The kobe beef has a good marble of fat, but make sure you eat it fresh, because that marble looks extremely unappetizing when you open up the to-go box the next day. 

The dessert menu never looks super appealing to me so I've never ordered it here. 

I would definitely make a reservation, because the space is extremely limited. If you want, you can also call around 5:15 or 5:30 when they open for dinner to ask what their specials are before you head over. 

On weekdays you can normally find metered parking, but if not there's a decent parking garage between Stockton and Vallejo that is within walking distance.
author: Melissa M.

description: Favorite. Must try. Been here many times and am never disappointed with the food. Place is extremely clean but a bit small. Also had reservations twice here before but for some reason I was nit placed on the list even after they have confirmed the reservation. Food makes up for all those small things.
author: Raymond T.

description:
I went with a group of friends to have dinner here; there were 5 of us, and unfortunately any group over 4 people is just too much for this tiny place.  We made it work, but it was tight.

The food here is great, as noted by the other hundreds of reviews.  For starters we ordered the scallops.  We each got to eat only one, but damn it was good!  I ordered the Angus Rib-eye Steak - thoroughly enjoyed it!  The mashed potatoes were lacking in flavor, but the side sauces helped to kick it up.  All 4 of my fellow diners got the pork chop, which they raved and raved about pre-meal and post-meal, since a few of them had eaten here before.  We also shared the coconut creme brulee.  It wasn't that good; couldn't even taste the coconut.

Now, here's the bad stuff.  When you are seated, they give you a small plate of pickled cucumbers to munch on while you wait.  There were five of us, and they gave us one plate.  We promptly devoured it, and asked if we could have another.  One of the waiters told us it would be an extra dollar.  An extra dollar?  Really?  This is such a simple thing to do.  We look over at a party of 2 next to us, and they also got one plate of the cucumbers.  But we were a party of 5.  Doesn't that constitute 2 plates?  I don't know...really lame on their part.

Secondly, the wait staff here is really bad.  Our waitress couldn't even pour a beer right; she just dumped it in a glass, leaving my friend with more foam than beer in his glass.  I mean, come on.  Her attempt at pouring a bottle of wine was no better...spilled wine on one of the plates, and just wiped it off instead of getting a clean one.

Really good food, but don't expect much from the staff.  And if you want an intimate meal, this is not the place.  Be ready to share every conversation with the diners around you.
author: Greg S.

description:
Don't you guys hate how cramped this restaurant is!?

We had reservations for 2 at 6:30pm, and we were just 8 minutes late. So they didn't seat us right away. We ended up waiting an extra 10 minutes. There was however one table open, but it was a bigger table, most likely meant for a party of 3 or 4. All the two people tables are so effing small! So I guess they felt bad for making us wait, so SCORE! We got the big table. 

The OYSTERS never fail. 

We tried one of their special appetizers for the day, it was some kind of kobe beef salad. It was delicious. I believe that was my first time eating beef in my salad. If thats one of the specials on their menu that day, ORDER IT!

My entree was the sea bass. It came with these fat noodles. Fat noodles over skinny noodles all day any day. I LOVE FAT NOODLES. I think it's because everytime I eat skinny noodles, I eat it so fast (because they're so thin!), that I forget to chew, and then it gets stuck in my chest. And it hurts. So yes I was a happy camper with my fat noodles and sea bass. 

And while everyone was being super classy with their wine, we ordered a pot of tea! I forgot the name of the tea, so let me check it real quick on their website! ....ok NVM! It's not on the website. But it was the first selection in the tea section. You must try! Tea is good for you.
author: Amy X.

description: I've never EVER had a bad meal here! The Sea Bass is a can't miss, but I opted for the Black Cod special, and was not disappointed! We also started with the scallop special, and that was on point as well.
author: Brian L.

description:
I've heard a lot about The House and was super excited to try it out. The House is a small restaurant and sitting is tight. The décor' is not memorable but the place is really clean and has a casual feel to it. It is conveniently located in the heart of North Beach and easy to get to by public transportation. 

We ordered a bunch of food to share:
-       Deep fried salmon roll: 4 stars but watch out for that Wasabi sauce
-       Wasabi House Noodle: 3 stars, I should have not ordered it because I think it is made with the same sauce base as the sauce for the Fried Salmon Roll
-       Swordfish in coconut milk curry sauce: 4 stars.  It's yummy but I think a lot of places can replicate this dish
-       Grilled Sea Bass: 5 stars, I get the hype about this dish. It's a MUST TRY!
 
We were so full that I can't really eat any dessert but the desserts looked great and I can't wait to go back.  This is a great place to take visitors if you want to take them for a good meal without over splurging.
author: Eugenia C.

description:
My friends and I were lucky and came right before the lunch rush, so we were seated right away even though we were a party of 6. 

What we ordered:
Deep Fried Salmon Rolls - so tasty!!! I was a little scared to eat it because the salmon itself isn't cooked all the way and there's a little bit of pink in the center. It tasted way better than I expected. I'm not a fan of the hot mustard dipping sauce though. But that's just because I hate Chinese hot mustard/horseradish/wasabi. 

Chipotle Pork Sandwich - this was very flavorful and kinda tasted like korean bbq pork. My only gripe with this dish was the fact that there were some nice chunks of fat that I had to spit out. The salad that accompanies the sandwich was dressed very lightly with a sesame dressing that was really good. 

Curry noodles - the few bites that I had from my friend's dish was very tasty. However, eating a whole dish of curry noodles can be overwhelming and you'll get sick of it fast. Definitely a sharing dish just to try.

Korean short rips - omg the marinaded short ribs were so good! Cooked perfectly with potatoes and sauteed green beans. This is definitely a safe dish to try for the unadventurous. 

Sea Bass - I didn't try the sea bass personally, but everyone else at the table raved about it and said it was the best dish that we ordered at the table. I'm not huge on fish so I didn't try it. The noodles that came with it was VERY good. 

Mango tapioca - very creamy and not too sweet or rich. I liked this a lot and we scraped the bowl clean

Pecan pumpkin pie - eh. I can pass on this one. 

Overall, the service was attentive and friendly. I really enjoyed my time here and was glad to try it. I'll definitely be back here again!
author: Kathy T.

description:
WOW.

i've been bug'n my bf to take me here for the longest..!

This restaurant gets packed! RSVP strongly suggested!

It is a very intimate & cozy spot to have a nice dinner with a significant other.

I had Grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy---melts in your mouth! I've never had fish this good!

He had Angus ribeye steak, housemade teriyaki, toasted garlic butter--and his dinner was cooked to perfection! He ate it all and left me with a few bites =( lol

Service was ok--since we were having dinner within closing time.

Overall, I'd so go back again!
author: Sarah F.

description:
Came here during a weekend trip to San Francisco. The service here is really nice and flexible; we had to adjust our reservations twice for the same night and they were super accommodating. The place was packed for dinner, but our server was really nice and never kept us waiting. 
We got the scallops with ponzu butter sauce as an appetizer which I loved (probably my favorite part of the meal). My Girlfriend got the steak and wasabi noodles, and the steak was cooked perfectly. Neither of us were a huge fan of the wasabi noodles, but I got the sea bass with noodles and those were very tasty! The noodles are kind of sweet and we both preferred those to the wasabi ones.
For dessert, we got the coconut Creme brûlée with passion fruit sauce, and it was surprisingly not too sweet and really well balanced.

I probably wouldn't come here again because while everything was good, nothing was spectacular or really stood out, and it is kind of expensive. But still a fun night out, and would definitely be a great date spot! :)
author: Sophia D.

description:
We came here around 12:30 pm on Saturday, beat the lunch crowd, and got seated immediately. Our host and waitress were attentive and friendly.

The daily specials were a little overwhelming since there were so many options and I wanted to try everything. After mulling over the menu, we eventually ended up choosing the the deep friend salmon rolls, albacore (daily special), and sea bass. I settled for sea bass since a) that's what Yelpers highly suggested and b) because they didn't have the black cod that my friend raved about. I will be back for you next time, black cod. 

When our orders came, I whipped out my camera to take a photo. The plates were well presented and deserved a picture. The food was combined with the ideal sauces, but I wish the garlic noodles paired with my sea bass were less oily. The portions were plentiful and worth the $$$. It was a hardy feast - I wish I had more stomach space to check out their dessert menu.
author: Judy H.

description: Had the yellowtail sashimi appetizer--one of the best I've ever had. The curry noodles with grilled chicken was really good. Even the pickles were good. The Hitachino red rice beer made it one of the best lunches ever. It's just a tad spendy, but good food has a price I guess.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Thank you Christine C., thank you Marc A., thank you Jason G...thank you for recommending this great spot.

There is no point arguing with the sea bass.  Just give in.  Amazingly good.  Of course, I followed the advice of my most trusted yelpers and went with the grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy.  The worst part of the sea bass was swallowing it, because it meant each unbelievably awesome bite was gone.  It was smooth as butter.  Ugh, I'm going to be thinking sea bass tonight.  Actually, I didn't appreciate the garlic soy as much.  I thought it was unnecessary and just masked the flavor of the fresh fish.  As an aside, it's the same problem I have with putting ketchup on a great burger.  Don't mess with it.  The veggies were also cooked perfectly.  The noodles?  Well, they were fine.  My wife had the Grilled blue fin tuna with spicy mustard aioli.  That was also very good, although it was a little too salty than I would otherwise prefer.  The calamari appetizer was okay.  Admittedly, it was a safe choice and I should have picked something more creative.  Extra points for great presentation.

I wasn't crazy about the lack of elbow room.  Then again, I don't think it's their fault that they have a fairly small place.  It was a little awkward to have a cozy conversation when you have a couple on either side.  Noise level was a little high.  We liked our server, but we were not too happy with the lady who got us our seats.  Whatev, maybe she was having a tough day.

Thanks to yelp, I found out about awesome places like these.  Seriously, try the sea bass.
author: Angel S.

description: This use to be my favorite restaurant. I guess I came here too often! Hah. Jk. it's still one of my favorite places to go but I probably won't come here for awhile. When I first came here, I was in love with everything. From the sea bass-to the rib eye steak. It's all delicious. Down side is the area where it's located, which is in North beach where parking is kind've hard and traffic is a bit busy at times. Don't get me wrong, the food is still worth the drive. I guess it's cause I've dined here one to many times. The fried salmon avocado rolls make a really good appetizer.
author: Laura T.

description:
This restaurant lived up its expectations. They lost our reservation, which was weird because it was made in person. But they seated us anyway, even though they were busy that night. 

The restaurant is small, so they turn the tables pretty fast, and it is hard to get a reservation, but when you do it is wonderful!!

The Seabass is phenomenal. One of the best meals I've had in a long time. They had a black cod as one of the specials this night, which is a recurring special apparently. It was also delicious. The appetizers were wonderful as well.

Someone in my party spilled his beer after he only had a few sips. They did not bring him another one, which I thought was not the right thing to do. Especially at a nice restaurant where we were spending a lot of money. 

Overall, it was a delicious dinner and thoroughly enjoyed! I would go back every month if I could!
author: Marci L.

description:
Amazing.  Sometimes the restaurants with the near perfect ratings are totally a let down (*ahem* ramen house in downtown LA).  But this one is true to it's ratings.

Came for lunch last Sunday and the mile long trek from downtown was totally worth it. There was no wait.  The tables are close together so be prepared to get intimate with the strangers dining next to you.  Luckily we had a nice family next to us and they enjoyed their meals just as much as we did.

I had the sea bass with garlic noodles.  I cannot describe how delicious this was.  Everything was perfectly seasoned and cooked.  Iggy had the pork with wasabi noodles.  This was also surprisingly delicious.  And for $10 a plate, his dish was the better value.

I could have easily had a second helping of my dish.  I really considered it.  But the thought of being called a fat greedy pig by the kitchen staff swayed my decision.  

I MUST have this again.  Next time I'm in SF for sure.
author: Hoa T.

description:
Despite the long wait on a Tuesday night, the food was pretty amazing! I actually had reservations for 7:30pm, but was running late. Tried to call The House multiple times, but no one picked up. Got there at 7:50pm and our table was given to someone else. Thus, we had to wait 45 minutes for a table....

1. Wasabi Noodles with Flatiron Steak
Yummy wasabi noodles! I can eat a bowl of that every day. Don't be turned off by wasabi, because it's not the go-up-your-nose type of wasabi. It was just the right amount of wasabi - not too much that it overwhelmed the other components of the dish, but just enough to bring out the wasabi flavor. I'm pretty sure that someone who doesn't like spicy food will enjoy this dish. As for the steak, it was a bit on the tougher side since I asked for medium well (my fault), so next time, I'll probably go with medium. There were way too many veggies in the dish, and wished it was replaced with more noodles! Priced at $18, it's pretty reasonable!

2. Creme Brulee
This was okay.. not great, but not bad. The passion fruit puree and the coconut creme brulee didn't really mesh well with each other. When you take a bite of this, you first encounter the sourness of the passion fruit puree. Then, you taste the bitterness of the caramelized sugar. Lastly, you taste the sweetness of the coconut creme brulee. The sourness really took away from the dessert as it was too much of a contrast to the sweetness. I think it would have been better off without the passion fruit puree, or with another type of puree. 

Will definitely come back. I will try to remember to arrive on time for my reservation next time!
author: Michelle L.

description: Rich flavors, unforgettable food. Get the salmon and wasabi noodles with extra veggies.
author: Laura L.

description:
BLACK COD OMG. okay, just had to get that out of my system to start with.

So I came here with no reservation (they don't take reservations by phone, I was told? hm...ok...) expecting pretty much to get turned away but they had a 30 minute window for a table for 2. Despite their wanting to rush us out, the waitresses were very nice and attentive. Brownie points for the house!

We tried the black cod and the sea bass, both suggestions from fellow yelpers, and mango tapioca for dessert. The sea bass was tender as everyone has said, but it didn't knock my socks off. The chinese veggies it was served on were very salty, but the avocado sushi rolls that came on top were interesting decoration and provided a nice (blander) flavor to complement the black garlic sauce on the plate. The black cod was the better dish by far, with crispy slightly burnt outer edges and juicy melt-in-your-mouth type meat underneath. It kind of reminded me of a similar dish at Mantra down in downtown palo alto, except the dish at the house was even juicier. If this is a special that is on the menu when you visit, order it!

Dessert was mango tapioca, which I actually really liked. The mango sauce on top provided a nice sour flavor to offset the sweetness of the tapioca and the whole thing was light and not too syrupy sweet. Next time I'd like to try the coconut creme brulee with passionfruit puree.

Lychee iced teas were delicious too, with free refills that our waitresses kindly supplied whenever our glasses were drained.

Our bill came out to around $70 for two people, not too bad for a delicious meal. Reasons why it didn't get 5 stars: parking was a bit hard to find, the place was small and even though the waitresses didn't rush me, I felt obligated to chew faster, and the sea bass was good but not amazing. If I am in the North Beach area I will definitely try to stop by again, and probably make reservations in advance next time!
author: Joyce H.

description:
Reliably delicious Asian fusion, with a nice ambiance.  

I've been twice, once for a weekday lunch (no wait) and once for a weeknight dinner (10 minute wait.) The menu seems to change up a bit and they have quite a few daily specials.
author: Cynthia M.

description: Came today for lunch with friends who've been here many times.  Wow!!  The appetizers were fabulous - salmon roll, clams, Ceasar salad with scallops, fried green beans, and the best dumplings!!  I had the Sea Bass for my main entree, and was not disappointed!  Fabulous flavor, and the sauces!  Everything was excellent.  I couldn't finish the fish, so it will be my dinner tonight.  We ordered several desserts, and all were wonderful.  I'm ready to come back to this jewel!  What a wonderful place.  Top notch food, and service!!
author: Caroline C.

description:
Beware of the Rat! 
We had a reservation here on our anniversary and told the "host" who is a Chinese woman that we plan to bring in our kids. She  sat me and my children at our table and then a few minutes later returned to ask us to get up. She did not explain except said "I can't take you now".  
I told her we had reservation and we have kids who are hungry. Was it because I brought my children?
This so call "host" did  not apologize for asking us to leave.
She is prejudice against children and did not welcome them. 

I had to file a discrimination to the Bureau of Consumer Rights.

Please do not bring children to this "black hole in the wall". It's dark and kid unfriendly.  Reservation is not honored or respect given.
author: Little Me T.

description:
I'm usually leery of fusion cuisine because mixing different flavor profiles from different cultures doesn't always work. Fusing needs a chef who is both a skilled technician with a deft hand and an artist with a discerning palate. A few weeks ago at the House, I found such a chef. I had dinner there with 3 friends & almost everything was a winner.

The restaurant is small, long and narrow. Expect to eavesdrop on other tables' conversations. Also, those conversations combined with a semi-open kitchen & all the hard surfaces made for a very noisy space. Ask to be seated near the big picture window that lets in lots of light. Any further back & it feels cramped & claustrophobic. Tables were set with white paper place mats with a tiny house punched out of the paper. Service was aloof but efficient and unobtrusive. Water glasses were promptly filled without having to flag down wait staff. 

Our server gave us some pickled cucumbers to start. The pickles could have been crunchier but they had a good balance of sweet, salty & sour. 

All the appetizers we ordered except one were hits. We had the shrimp/chive dumplings & asparagus with toasted sesame dressing. Both were good, very simple. The kitchen's restraint allowed the freshness of the ingredients to shine through.

The tempura Blue Lake green beans were absolutely yummy. While other restaurants also have this on their menus, this version was very well done. The batter was light and not greasy at all. The beans were tender but still had snap when you bit into one. The presentation was fun. The beans were arranged on the plate like a log cabin with the ramekin of dipping sauce corralled in the center. 

The uni and steak tartare on toast was my least favorite & I think the only strike of the meal. The base was 4 squares of bread fried in butter. I think the bread was pre-fried and sat around until an app needed to be assembled. This made the bread cold and way too greasy. Half the bread was topped with uni and caviar. The other half was topped with tartare. The tartare had way too much mayo. There were also thin slices of Asian pear to add a bit of sweetness and crunch to the dish. The whole appetizer needed some acid to cut all the fat. 

The entrees were all home runs. The sea bass was the most visually striking. It was an architectual pile of edible wonder. The fish was perfectly cooked with crispy skin and flaky meat. A California roll was sliced in half at an angle and propped up against the fish. Long strips of turnip chips balanced on top like rabbit ears. The dark miso and garlic sauce that pooled on the bottom of the plate had the right amount of salty/sweet. Another entree was the halibut. A different type of fish, leaner than the sea bass but still cooked to perfection. The cream corn orzo & vegetables that came with it embodied summer. 

The Angus flatiron steak came with a mountain of wasabi noodles. The steak was tender. The noodles had that great chewy texture. The heat from the wasabi was negligible in the beginning but gradually built up the more you ate. This dish was addictive. I kept on stealing bites and cleaned off the plate when my friend couldn't finish it. 

Another friend had the mushroom rice with grilled shrimp. It was an Asian version of risotto. It was lush with an earthiness from the mushrooms and truffles. The shaved bonito ribbons on top were fascinating. They were curling & wiggling, reacting to the heat of the rice. It looked like an underwater garden of kelp swaying and undulating with the waves.  

I loved all the desserts. The panna cotta was silky smooth and not rubbery at all. The nectarines and peaches on top were perfectly ripe. The creme brulee had a perfect burnt sugar crust that shattered with a tap of the spoon. Yummmm! The strawberry rhubarb cobbler was good, not too sweet with a pleasing tartness from the rhubarb. The mango tapioca pudding was delicious. I would have liked the bigger tapioca pearls but that's a minor quibble.

Also another minor quibble, they had what looked to be pen and ink drawings with watercolor on the wall. While very nicely executed, I didn't really like looking at feet and tushies while eating. 

The kitchen staff have mad skills. While not really avant garde, the flavor combinations were skillfully executed. The food was delicious and just about perfect. Another plus, you could taste the quality and freshness of the food. No frozen food and no shortcuts makes for a very happy tummy. A great "go to" neighborhood restaurant.
author: Cece E.

description:
I wanted to see what the rave is all about here, so made a reservation and still waited almost 25 minutes to be seated. We didn't mind because we were not that terribly hungry and of course I expected the wait time. I heard the seafood is good, but I chose the wasabi noodles with steak for the sake of her, since she's not a seafood person. The menu perfectly defines the "Asian Fusion" and is all properly done, great selection, very original, very unique. So really if this review was for the food only, I'd give it 5 stars!!

However, this place feels like it's perfect for a speed dating game. I don't care much for personal space, but somehow I feel like a cattle cow sitting here. Yes, the restaurant is small because they want to keep the exclusivity going. However, trying to crowd that many people in one small room is not cute at all, unless maybe it's your first date and you are scared your date may be a wierdo. Lol. 

So a 3 course meal comes up to ~$80, so expensive, yeah, but not to the moon. Their service is very upbeat, they are all hardworkers and positive in manners, lively in personality. A++ for their outstanding service and efficiency. I might come back here another time, if I'm in the right mood for it. However, for now there are thousands of other places which may still live up to the proper Asian Fusion name, but with more space and a calmer feel of eating.
author: Andrew I.

description:
I am in love.
Dinner. Lunch. I will always try to go to house.

Dinner:
Sea Bass- So amazing
Tuna - Delish
You have to try the House Noodles. 

Lunch:
Tuna BLT - I dream about the next time I can get this. SO good.
Everything is delicious and the service is great.
author: Francesca F.

description:
TL;DR: Great food, no frills atmosphere and service, and you should plan to call advance for a reso. Not a whole lot of places that are going to give you more bang for your culinary buck than The House.

Actually, that's about all you need to know. That, and order the salmon roll and the sea bass. Do this, and I can't see leaving disappointed.
author: Alex H.

description: Great asian fusion restaurant in North Beach. Small place that doesn't take reservations, so be ready for a long wait... but its worth it!
author: Scott S.

description:
I've been waiting so long to come visit The House and I finally made it! The House has all the little details figured out, so you'll definitely enjoy your experience here. The space is really small, so don't bring a large group of friends here. The service was super fast--each dish was quickly proceeded by the next. I think this place definitely tops the list of places to bring a date -- cozy, intimate, but not pretentious (unless you were going for that?). Be sure to make a reservation because I saw someone get turned away at 6:30pm on a Sunday night.

Onto the food: it was amazing! We ordered the lychee iced tea (they actually refilled it!), raw oysters, tempura soft-shell crab (see picture), the sea bass, and the special (black cod). Our appetizers came with the same sauce--an amazing blend of vinegar, garlic, cilantro, and siracha. It was great for dipping the soft-shell crab in as well as slurping together with the oysters. Even though I'm typically a spicy food eater, the spicy vinaigrette had me gasping for air!

As for the entrees, I had the sea bass while the boyfriend had the black cod special. Both fishes tasted fresh and silky and the accompanying sauces didn't overpower the fish. My dish came with Shanghai style noodles as well as string beans. I really enjoyed the noodles as they were well made and not greasy tasting. 

Overall, a great night out. The setting of The House made me feel like I was on a third date (even though I've been with the BF for nearly 3 years). In total, our dinner came out to around $100 (tax + tip). If you're trying to impress someone, make a reservation at The House!
author: Angela L.

description: Sorry to say that when a restaurant has killer food but terrible service, the experience becomes a bad one.  First, the food...tempura beans, grilled octopus appetizers were as advertised.  Innovative, tasty, leaving you wanting more.  The pork chop was moist and marinated in a Char Siu sauce that would make any Chinese gourmet jealous.  And the grilled sea bass was melt in your mouth good.  Now the down side...the specials are read to you before the menus arrive.  The waitress asked to take our entree orders before anyone had taken our drink orders.  All in all, it felt like they were trying to rush us so that they could turn the table as quickly as possible.  Okay for a fast food place, but not cool when you're trying to enjoy a great meal.  Kudos to the chef and the kitchen staff.  Too bad front of house let you down.
author: Roy K.

description: Solid Asian fusion food that caters to Americans' love for ultra sweet and savory soy flavored things. Black cod special was great, cooked just right and set in a delicious sauce that I don't remember the details of. The popular fried salmon roll appetizer was great, too. Good, fun atmosphere too. Wouldn't expect to find a restaurant like this hiding between all the strip clubs and dive bars in the area.
author: Wilson C.

description:
Amazing dinner last night! First time there! I cannot wait to go back and try the other items on the menu! Service was great! Food is amazing!!!!!! 

I had the special soup of the day. Potato soup with toasted cauliflower and truffle oil! It was divine! The dumplings and asparagus that came next were simply delicious! Ordered the sea bass and wasabi noodles with flat iron steak! All I can say is that I cannot wait to go back! 

Truly one of the best dining experiences I have had!!!!
author: raquel t.

description:
The best fusion food I've had in a while. I went for the sesame king salmon in a broth, it was amazing, cooked to perfection (still raw inside, yummy). 
We expected over an hour wait when we walked in at 7.30pm on a Saturday evening, but we must have been very lucky as we got a table straight away. 
Service was friendly yet a bit rushed, probably because of the crowd - the restaurant is overall super busy.
To get a 5th star, I'd say that it needs a nicer (less rushed) service and maybe a quieter atmosphere - also a tad less garlic in the food!

Overall strongly recommend the place, especially in this neighborhood where you're never quite sure what you're gonna get!
author: Emilie G.

description:
Not the best first impressions. The place was packed and we had arrived on time for our 7:30pm reservation yet we still had to wait another fifteen minutes to get a table. The interior is tight with dim lighting, a bit like a sardine can. The staff has to squeeze through the madness to provide their hospitality.

But as soon as we got a table our waitress somehow managed to list off the many specials of the day from memory. The specials and menu sounded unique and tasty. For appetizers we ordered the beef tartare, mussels, and tempura fried soft shell crab. The soft shell crab was predictably delicious although it's adorned with these very long bread sticks that come out of its body like petrified dreadlocks. The beef tartare could have been anything although it was still tasty. While the mussels were good the broth was absurdly rewarding. Good thing nobody at my table was interested in it because I slurped it all down with my trusty mussel shell.

I had ordered the pork chop with pomegranate currant sauce served over mashed potatoes and vegetables. Whenever there are pork chops on a menu I get them. The House certainly delivered. It was so friggin' good. The currant sauce isn't too sweet but it's robust and savory enough to elevate the juicy pork chop. I had a hell of a time cleaning the bone.

I tried a couple of bites from my party's dishes and they all tasted good. I remember the wasabi noodles being tasty. All the meat was properly cooked. For dessert we were thinking of saving ourselves for a spot later in the evening so we only ordered the tapioca pudding. It was delectable. The consistency is a bit runny yet this makes it refreshing and not too heavy. In hindsight I wish we had just had dessert here.

____

If you can get past the London Underground interior with bombastic noise level, you'll be eating some tasty tasty food. Not recommended for large parties.
author: Michael H.

description: Came out on a trip to San Fran and my bf was looking for a good place to eat and we found The House. Appetizer was amazing, we had the sashimi sampler. The Ahi Tuna and pork chop were great! Overall experience was remarkable.
author: Denice C.

description:
I missed House on my last trip to SF, so I made it my mission to eat here as soon as I got here.  As recommended by other yelpers, I made the reservation, Monday May 7 at 8:00 p.m.  

Seating:
No one at the door to greet us.  I assumed this was normal here.  A server came by and asked to wait while table became available.  I waited a year to experience the House so had no problem waiting little longer.  Server gave our table to another patron who came after us, made us wait 20 minutes, and then presented two tables which was available the whole time we were waiting.  No apologies, just sat us, like this is the normal presentation at the House.

Food:
I came here for food after all so I decided to let it go and try to enjoy the food aspect of it.
Had hamachi (?) appetizer, it was blend.  I had skirt steak and my husband had the sea bass.  Honestly, it was not that great.  I really wanted to like it but the steak was tough and the noodle had no flavor.  I tried the sea bass, cooked perfectly, but again no flavor.  

Service:
Our server, same woman who gave our table away, had absolutely no personality nor sense of service.  To make matters even worse, she dropped used oily fork on my husband's shirt.  I almost never care about services when I eat out but this woman just made me want to leave this place as fast as possible.

I soooo wanted to like this place......
author: S B.

description:
Clearly this place needs no introduction, nor probably a 2321st review but here I go anyways. I met up for dinner with a friend and her boyfriend from a year abroad after college. Silly me coming from Dallas and assuming that last minute reservations were easy to get in SF, if even necessary at all. We had a 9:30 dinner seating on a Friday night and only had about a 5 minute wait upon arrival. Started with one of the cold sakes on the menu (right around $40) and some Singha beers for the classy combo of Sake bombs and shots versus sipping our slightly pricey Sake.

HITS:

Deep fried Salmon Roll - this is one of the best appetizers I've had in awhile. Salmon was still perfectly raw yet not fishy but with a warm crispy outer layer. Truly delicious. Our group bypassed the niceties (no, you have the last one... no....heh..nervous laughter because I want it...you) and rock paper scissored for the final tantalizing piece like children.

Boyfriend's Kobe Beef Steak with mashed potats was TO DIE for. I ate maybe more than half.

BY NO MEANS A MISS, BUT NOT QUITE A HIT:

Mussels - not bad, I'm just a mussels freak and have had a lot better at many other places. Yes, even in Dallas not by the bay.

Sea Bass - I hope I'm not crucified for this. The Sea Bass was decent and certainly a plentiful portion (I should have split it with my friend who got the same), but I think I was expecting heaven in my mouth. I actually preferred the noodles and the green beans (which were scrumptious) to the sea bass, and trust me I love fish.

If we just would have had the fried salmon roll app and the Kobe beef special - which would definitely have been enough to split between two (what I'm saying is do this if you are on a date or just have a party of two :) this would have been a 5 start experience. We had SO much of the seabass meals leftover that we tried to take with us, but were going on to a bar next and ended up having to leave our extras on a stoop and hoping a kind hobo would wander into our bag. Nonetheless, still really great I just selfishly prefer to hope for 5 stars for a $150 pre tip meal.
author: Merlinda I.

description:
Called The House today to inquire about reservations for two for tonight.   The response, "We have reservations for 5:30 and 9:00, goodbye, *CLICK*".  

Uh, what just happened here?  Did this moron think I was calling simply out of curiosity?   Doesn't one typically offer available reservations to customers calling for reservations?  Not so at The House, it seems.  these f***tards don't deserve your business.  They won't be getting mine, *CLICK*!
author: Alex L.

description:
I'm usually hesitant to try new-fangled fusion places that are hyped up but The House definitely exceeded my expectations. The salmon rolls were delicious and my favorite out of the appetizers that we ordered. The center is still slightly raw so it doesn't have that overcooked salmon flavor. The outside is crispy and the sauce is pleasantly tingly with wasabi. The ahi tartare however was fresh but forgettable and served in a tiny portion. The asparagus appetizer was light and crunchy. Everything was perfectly seasoned with an Asian flair.

For my entree I went with the kobe special of the day which was friggin AMAZING. I'm still not over it and it's been practically a month now. The beef was thinly sliced and cooked perfectly medium. It was topped with mushrooms and cherry tomatoes on a bed of cauliflower and mashed potatoes. The cauliflower soaked up the amazing sauce and was surprisingly a huge highlight of the dish. I also tried my friend's sea bass which was flaky and buttery and came with a tangy sauce. But I'm more of a turf than surf person so the kobe still wins in my eyes.

The portions are perfectly filling. The litchi iced tea was quite refreshing as well. The tea comes unsweetened and though they give you sugar on the side it's really not needed. 

I can't wait to come back!
author: Jacqueline C.

description: Amazing! The wait is definitely worth it. Made reservations a few days in advance. They don't use opentable, so u have to call in. Arrived for reservation early and were seated close to our reserve time. The restaurant is quite small and you're sitting in very close proximity with your neighbors. We ordered fried salmon and dumplings for apps, both good. The real stars were the entrees: shrimp risotto and sea bass! Bursting with flavors, it was like a party in my mouth. Would definitely return! But make sure to make reservations if you plan to go on a Friday or sat, or else plan to wait 1.5 hr or so.
author: Christie B.

description:
I'm a fan of The House but I'm giving this place only 4 stars on account of the fact that we made a reservation for two well in advanced we still ended up waiting, also the host seemed annoyed and who knows maybe she was having a bad night but we were not welcomed with a friendly smile of any sort--kind of a turn off in my book. 

We were then crammed in between two extremely loud large parties and could barely hold a conversation of our own on account of competing with our neighbors. Nevertheless, our waitress was extremely attentive and constantly checking up on us-- which I appreciate greatly. The food we ate was absolutely mouth watering and the presentation was beautiful. As a SF newbie I felt I had to give this place a try considering the amount of people on yelp telling me to go here and I'm happy with the over all experience. But will I go back? Ehhh probably not.
author: Dani A.

description: I've heard of this place from friends for a while but never went because I didn't want to buy-in to the hype but it was so worth it!  Went with my girls on a Thursday night and dang it was worth it! Hate the parking situation but the garlic noodles, the appetizers and company was worth the long walk and fighting traffic. Definitely recommend making a reservation so that you don't have to wait in line. As we were eating, there was a long wait that was just going out the door.
author: Tori K.

description:
I'm going to make this short and simple.  Came here for dinner once. Delicious, but overpriced food with small portions. Will not return because you totally do not get your bang for your buck here.

Plus, when I dined here, all the staff members seemed like they hate their jobs. No one smiled.
author: Pudgy G.

description:
Absolutely lives up to the hype and so worth the wait. I'm not a huge fan of Asian fusion and I'm always skeptical of places where so many people rave about it but this one DEFINITELY is well deserved.

Uni with avocado and beef tartar --their special appetizer of the day. SO amazing. Both the uni with avocado and the beef tartar came on a lightly crisp wafer that left it feeling light yet flavorful. My gosh, I'm craving this as I type this.
Sea bass with garlic noodles - The dish everyone raves about (so of course we had to order it). Fish is cooked to be light and juicy. The flavor is absolutely amazing. The garlic noodles were such a nice complement to the fish
Wasabi garlic noodles with steak - Steak cooked perfect with just the right amount of tenderness

Man, such a win on all levels. Also, such a small restaurant so definitely make a reservation or be prepared to wait.
author: Diana Y.

description:
*droooooooooooool*  

I came here for lunch with my boyfriend & it was worth every penny (that..we didn't pay). Our close friends kidnapped us & dropped us off outside The House with an envelope of money & reservations already made. They're so sweet. (: They knew I was dying to try this place & they made it happen!

I ordered the Kurobuta Pork Chop while my boy ordered the Sea Bass. Both were...to die for. The first bite I took...I can't even describe. :X 

The Pork was tender & the pomegranate sauce that it came with was absolutely divine. Everything about this entree was AMAZING.

My boyfriend's sea bass was super buttery & flaky & extremely well prepared. 

Lunch is much lighter on the wallet than their dinner, but I would pay their prices for dinner any day. 

The ambiance is small, but it adds to the cuteness. (: Make sure you make a reservation!
author: Priscilla O.

description: the food here was excellent but above all the service was amazing. Our waitress was unbelievably sweet and honest about the food she liked and disliked. We ordered the ribeye 3.5/5, the sea bass 4/5, the salmon appetizer 4/5 and the poke 4/5.
author: S E.

description:
It's pretty unfortunate that The House neighbors a purveyor of neon a*s-high cut-out dresses and pleather, because that's never going out of business and therefore this tiny little restaurant has zero hope of ever expanding and we are going to be stuck with long waits and having to learn to really like the people eating next to us because we are basically sitting on top of them. 

The  service is friendly and fast (because they are praying to get you the hell outta there asap to accommodate the teeming masses hovering for your table).

The food here is clean, fresh, perfectly cooked, beautifully plated and probably the best Asian Fusion I've had in SF: 

- OK: Dumplings
- Good but not memorable: Scallops, Prawns, House wasabi noodles and steak, Chocolate cake, Apple crisp.
- Very good: Pumpkin cheesecake, Sea bass, Miso Cod (may not be on menu but you might be able to get it if you ask)
- Awesome: Halibut with cream sauce

For ~$35-45/person including T+T, enjoy it all while getting "cozy" with your fellow diners.
author: Snuffles B.

description: I have been here a few times already and each visit was awesome. My favorite dish has to be the pomegranate pork chop. The  steak noodles, rib eye, and sea bass are great, but I will be constantly ordering the pork from now on.
author: Huey N.

description:
I love this place!  This is the kind of food I could have everyday.  Came here for lunch with a friend.  A humble Asian-fusion find in the middle of pasta and stromboli.  

I opted for the Grilled ahi tuna (seared) with spicy mustard aioli and their house udon noodles with a crisp and delicate junmai sake.  Most delightful lunch experience!  I believe my friend had the seared salmon over wasabi noodles.  Whatever it was, it looked delicious.

Nice wine selection and service was warm and down to earth.  Ambiance nice enough and not too fancy.  The little-kitchen-that-could pumps out dishes fast despite incredibly cramp quarters.

Already miss SFO and wish I were here having lunch instead of my uninspired PB&J.
author: Kalani C.

description:
Normally when a restaurant has a rating this high, its tough to get reservations day of, but I made them for 630 pm on a Tuesday and we were seated no problem. I really cant say enough good things about this place- food was awesome and the service was fantastic. Our waitress staggered the dishes in a well thought out manner and never rushed us (we took a while to eat too...)

There was a little snafu with one of our plates and again, our waitress handled it beautifully. She comped us two free desserts and a bag of home-made cookies-- much appreciated and kind gesture. 

Coming back? Definitely.
author: Jamie C.

description:
This review is long overdue- I came here some time back after my sisters graduation. We wanted to go to some place that had great food but wasn't stuff - and so we came upon the house. 

I must say, everything we had here was delicious. The wasabi noodles were amazing. And then I remember having some kind of rock shrimp app that my bro-in-law went nuts over.

All in all I need to go back- only problem is theres way too many great places to try in SF!
author: Komal B.

description:
What a bland unassuming name for a place that packs so much.

So much flavor. So many people. So much noise?

True, the acoustics are no good in this small space, but unless someone in your party has a hearing impairment or doesn't operate above 10 dB, then, game on.

Decibel levels aside, the food is loud. Portions are quite generous, yet licking the plate is irresistible. Dishes are well plated, but not too artistic that you don't feel bad attacking it. Flavors are intense, savory, sweet, balanced. For a place that specializes in Asian Fusion seafood, they do non-fish quite well. 

Vegetarians need not apply.
author: Alissa A.

description:
Excellent food, crowded, but great service!

Recommended: MAKE A RESERVATION!
WARNING: Even if you make a reservation, prepare to WAIT!

The party that I was with had about 8-9 people. Unfortunately we had to wait a big even though we had a reservation. Be prepared to be squished by the doorway because there is absolutely no room! Many waited outside, but it was too cold to. While waiting to be seated I was impressed by all the dishes that I saw coming out. My eyes were watering and I wish I could order the WHOLE MENU!

Unfortunately due to the small space, plan on being seated very close to the table next to you and watch your back when your trying to get out of your seat. This place needs to find an upgrade to the space because it has excellent service, food and ambiance. 

Service:
If you bring your own wine be prepared for a $30 cork fee!
Water was always filled and never made it passed half way. We were always checked up upon which makes for excellent service. 

Dish: Pom prime rib
EXCELLENT!!! SOOOOO GOOOD!!!! I would recommend this one for sure!!! excellent taste, very flavorful and JUICY. The pom def added to the taste, not over powering either! In other words YUMMY YUMMY IN MY TUMMY !
author: Kristina L.

description:
KUROBUTA PORK CHOP WITH POMEGRANATE CURRANT SAUCE - This is the best pork chop I've ever had, and quite possibly the best dish I've ever had at any restaurant, period. The pork chop from Nopa is delicious and very high on my list, but it doesn't come close to this one. That's how good it is. I literally smile after every bite I take of it. Which probably adds an extra 30 minutes to my dinner. I CAN'T HELP IT!!!

This restaurant is a must visit. FACT: one of the best Asian restaurants in the city is right in the heart of North Beach, aka Italian food central. I also just realized I'm using a lot of caps in this review. Again, I CAN'T HELP IT!!

Make reservations; I can't stress that enough. It's a small place, and you'll need to get there on time. They almost gave away my reservation once because I was late (I would've cried if they did). Finally, they have specials that change all the time, so pay close attention when your waiter announces them, because there are usually some amazing dishes waiting to be had.

It's been a long time, but I can happily say that I'll be having dinner there this weekend for my cousin's birthday, and I think it's pretty clear what I'll be ordering...
author: Stan A.

description:
Okay.
Hostess and waitress weren't stand-outs. I had miso fish with sushi roll on top and I was not blown away. 
Place was cozy but tables are on top of each other and I felt like I put my butt on the table next to me when I was getting in and out. 
Glad I tried it.
author: Sherry C.

description:
I love this place! I'm a business traveller and always look out for good restaurants where I can enjoy my evening with a nice experience, reasonably priced that the boss doesn't complain about the expense report.
Every time I'm back in SF, this place is a MUST!
I love this kind of American-Asian fusion and all their dishes I had so far were excellent, with no exception. Be it the dumplings or the angus steak. I LOVED the salmon roll, try that!!!
Portions are ok for my expectations, not kind of these overloaded plates you sometimes get when you go on quantity oriented restos.
Athmosphere is ok some; the room is quite small, for maybe 50 people I'd say.
You definitely need to make a reservation, at any day of the week.
author: Alex M.

description:
2000 some odd reviews, what can I say, except get a reservation.  We did, and sat right down.  But, there was a line down the block, and many of those folks never did get in.  

The food is definitely unusual.  We had the obligatory fried salmon roll, and it was grand.  We also shared a noodle special, made with strips of kobe beef, and the sea bass.  Everything was stellar, except one thing.  Its a small thing, and my only gripe.  The noodles that accompanied the beef and sea bass had too much sauce.  It was slightly overwhelming, but overall it was sooooo good, we really didn't mind.  

Its SMALL but great atmosphere, the food is familiar, yet unique, the service was stellar, and it was all in all a very nice dining experience.  Highly recommend.
author: Rob B.

description:
Being from the Midwest, I've had a lot of good pork chops in my life. The one served at The House tops them all.

The dining area is really tiny and crowded, and the service is hectic, but the food (everything we had was delicious, not just the pork chop) is worth it.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Let me make it clear before I start to get hate messages from lovers of The House-- the issue with my review is not the food whatsoever. I thought the taste, portions, value, presentation, etc was great. We had the salmon roll, the tartar, and the asparagus for the appetizer. We also had the wasabi noodles and the sea bass for our entrees. All that we ordered was good and did not disappoint. If I were to give a review just on the food alone, it would get 4 stars. 

The service, however, was VERY disappointing.

I have never written a yelp review (that I can recall) in regards to service. I am not a stickler for service. Give me my food, be nice, refill my water, and everything is kosher in my mind. But the service I experienced yesterday was probably the worst I have ever encountered. I have never been so rushed during a meal.

We got to the restaurant and were so pressured to order something quick, I felt like I was going to get yelled at if I didn't order something soon. The point of a restaurant is for a dining experience. If I wanted to get Chinese take-out, I would expect the rude, short service. But somehow, they apparently didn't know where they were, because I felt like I was at Panda Express! When we were done with our meal, our plates were shuffled away, and before I could blink, the dessert menu was in front of my face. Oh, and did I mention, they already took away all our place mats, and crumple them in front of us? 

Before I could even read the first words of the dessert menu, they asked what we wanted. We ordered something random, and it was good, but I never got to enjoy it, because again, the plates were taken away as soon as I took my last bite. The bill was immediately "plopped" on the table, followed up with an obviously fake, "whenever you're ready." Well, my mom wanted to finish her pot of tea, and the five of us were all talking, ya know, basic dinner conversation. There were two dirty spoons left over from our dessert at the far end of the table. The waitress made a point to reach over (no regard that she's interrupting) and snatch the spoons and take them to the kitchen as if she was disgusted that we were there for (heaven forbid) an hour. Oh and while she took the spoons, she made a point to open the check the bill, and ask if it was ready. I thought you said "whenever you're ready?" 

Well, we had 5 people in our party. With appetizers, entrees, dessert, and an after dinner tea, we were in and out in an hour max. They're lucky we're fast eaters.

Food is good, but if you want to have the experience similar to the Panda Express, then here's your place.
author: Victoria B.

description:
The House lived up to the massive Yelp reputation.  To be honest I was going to hit a nearby ramen place but found it closed, so I double backed and returned to The House.  Good thing, because I really enjoyed my lunch.

The House is small and staffed with friendly waitresses.  I tried the shrimp dumplings and loved the dipping sauce.  My main entree was the wasabi and pork noodles - not too spicy because I asked for mild.  I love wasabi but it makes me cry like a kid who just skinned their knee.  The pork was cooked perfectly.

I recommend The House if you're in the area and looking for some well made Asian fusion entrees.
author: Phil B.

description:
Wow...easily the best scallops I have ever had.  It started with the appetizer and went all the way through the dessert. 

From the scallops to the sea bass for the entree. Like the scallops the sea bass was expertly cooked.  It made me take smaller bites to enjoy it even longer.  It tasted like it was poached in butter than crisply grilled to perfection.
Onto the dessert.  Mango tapioca was terrific.  In fact I could have eaten a few more bowls of it.  It was creamy with a hint of mango.
If you haven't eaten here do it today.
author: Shannon P.

description: Wow this place was amazing. One of the best meals I had If not the best we had in SF. Ordered the sashimi appetizer which was great and the sea bass with garlic noodles. We loved it so much we considered going back the same day for dinner.
author: Irfaan L.

description:
Went for lunch and decided on the flank steak entree. 

Delicious! The meat was very tender, the sauce was scumptious and the mushrooms they put on top were full of flavor.

The price also wasn't as bad as I was expecting. My dish was $15 but there were many that were less than that. The most expensive entree was $23 for the sea bass (which my friend said was also very good).

This restaurant is the closet I've come to wanting to give 5 stars. If the quality is still amazing after another visit I will definitely have to elevate it.
author: Rachel R.

description:
I was up there for a trip and my friend took me here for lunch.

Note - I wanted to try the pork chop bu they were sold out of it when I got there for lunch that, I def want to try it next time.

We had a seared scallop with a lemon vinaigrette type of sauce, which was the special that day. These were delicious, perfectly grilled with some char on it, and the sauce complemented it perfectly.

We had the grilled sea bass, again it was perfectly grilled and seasoned, both the seasoning and the char brought out the flavor of the fish. The peas and noodles that came with it were ok, nothing special. Like one of the other review said, the special soy sauce that came with it was too strong and would have covered up the fish' flavor. I ended up putting this sauce on the noodle.

We also had the Korea style short rib, it was good, but nothing to write home about.

We then had the coconut creme brulee for dessert, there was only hint of coconut which came through on the first couple of bites. However, they have a lemon/tangerine type glaze over it which overpowered the coconut flavor.

Overall, I definitely recommend this place and I will be going back whenever I come visit SF again
author: Reggie L.

description: The food is good, but the customer is not terrible. My first time went to SF, I came here and spent 2 hours waiting for the table. Wow, that is amazing. It is not a good place for dating with your significant one, not romantic.
author: Eunice L.

description:
This is a long overdue post that has been sitting on my "to do" reviews half written.  Just a warning, it's going to sound odd since I wrote the first half almost a year ago and the bottom half just now.  Nevertheless, here you go:

Things that turn me off during the early stages of dating:

1.  When a guy overuses the saying "lol" or "LOL" when texting.  Something about that makes me cringe.  It reminds me of a 12 year old girl.  It just makes you less masculine for me and just completely turns me off.  

2.  When a guy uses the restroom more than once when dining together in a restaurant, especially if there isn't any alcohol involved. Is there something wrong with you?  Do you have a bladder problem?  Do you need to make a quick phone call to your boys for advice?

3.  When a guy gets his order before me and rather than waiting for my order to come, he consumes his plate.  By the time my plate arrives, he's pretty much a halfway done with his food and now I'm left to eat alone while he stares at me.  Did a pack of wolves raise you?

For the record, this was my first and last date with that person.  I've been wanting to try this place for such a long time so I was super excited that my date picked this place.  

Here's the deal, I would probably like it more if my friends did not hype this place up.  I wanted to love this place, I really did.  But the truth is, it was way too oily for my liking.  This is coming from a person that adores fried chicken and chicharron.  Granted, it is Asian fusion but my plate was so greasy that the oil was almost soupy.

I ordered the Seabass with garlic ginger soy noodles and the oil was overwhelming.  My date, however, told me that they were "off" that day and that it normally is a lot better.  I was able to try his, Kurobuta Pork Chop W/ Pomegranate Currant Sauce.  (even though he was almost done with it before I started eating) I definitely was in love with it and I was jealous of his order.   The sauce blended very well with the tender meat.  The presentation was beautiful on both dishes, I can give them that.  The dessert was amazing, we ordered the mango tapioca dessert.  It was just the right amount of sweet.

As for now, they get 3 stars only because like I was told that the chef was off that day and that the place is normally much better.  I'll be back soon and I'm hoping to give them a much better review.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description:
Asian fusion food is a difficult style to get right, and at The House they definitely succeed at the genre by turning out hearty, feel-good dishes turned up with a kick. 

After spying the Asian Wasabi noodles with steak in the photos I knew that that was the dish for me. And I was not disappointed. The udon noodles had a fab tooth feel and were spicy without overwhelming the rest of the flavors on the plate; the steak was perfectly cook and tender as could be. 

My only regret about the meal was that while the space and service were fine, there was nothing particularly spectacular or special about either.

If only someone would bring this style of cooking to Paris where I'm based!
author: Zeva B.

description:
It's always good to be observant when trying out fusion cuisine. My friends visiting from the East Coast had really positive things to say about this place, so after a day of exploring in the city, we made our way over. I heard beforehand our friends had placed a reservation for a party 8 (us) since this place gets crowded really quickly. To my surprise, we only waited for 20 minutes before being seated. 

A first impression of the decor: small, cozy, and definitely intimate. Great for large parties or for a date night. It's got a rustic yet modern twist on the inside. 

On to the food:

Our group ordered two appetizers: the salmon roll and squid salad. Both were amazing, although my favorite hands down was the salmon roll because it was essentially deep-fried sushi-like rolls with really tender salmon, served with this amazing wasabi. On a side note, our friend's aunt was friends with the owner, so we got a free appetizer on the house. Can't beat service like that :)

For the main dish, all my friends ordered the steak served over wasabi house noodles, but I went a little adventurous and ordered the pork chop served with pomegranate sauce. DEFINITELY had some sort of food-gasm when I ate it. I think this place is also known for their sea bass dish, but I would skip that to get the pork chop. Portion sizes are definitely okay for the price they charge you. 

Desserts: They have a kick ass chocolate lava cake and an assortment of house-brewed teas to help you digest. Pretty standard.

All in all, for everything I ate (3 appetizers, 1 entree, dessert and tea) I only dropped 35 bucks. Pretty worth it for a once-in-a-while foodie excursion :)

Tip? Get the pork chop dish and make sure to make reservations well in advance. You won't be disappointed. It's a good place for Asian fusion.
author: Samuel H.

description:
I don't understand why this place is SO popular with over 1400 reviews just like I don't understand Slanted Door with over 2100 reviews!  Yes, the food is  more tasty and more innovative than your order by number Chinese restaurant down the block.  Yes, the presentation is nice and individualized unlike family-sized troughs elsewhere.  Yes, the desserts are much better than orange slices secretly sweetened with sugar water.  So compared to traditional Asian restaurants I can see the allure, but compared to all restaurants in San Francisco I don't see it being THAT outstanding for all this buzz.

Pickles: Sure beats deli pickles!  Little slices of pickled cucumbers with sesame seed ground on top.  Had that subtle vinegar taste that is common in Korean pickles.

Deep Fried Salmon Roll with Chinese Hot Mustard:  Take raw sashimi grade salmon, wrap it in a spring roll then deep fry it!  Hmm!  Loved how there were varying degrees of doneness with the center being raw.  The crispy dough gave a good crunch texture.  The mustard dipping sauce was like Chinese mustard + soy sauce + some other stuff, a nice departure from what comes in those little plastic packets.

Caesar Salad with Crispy Scallops: Tiny seared scallops and romaine lettuce.  No croutons, maybe the mini scallops were supposed to replace them?  Also, not very generous with the cheese (...if there was any).  Probably the least satisfying dish here for me.

Scallops: Much larger scallops than the ones in the Caesar salad.  Perfectly cooked with a seared exterior and flan like interior.  The sauce it was floating in was perfect.

Kurobuta Pork Chop with Pomegranate Currant Sauce: Tender pork chop with such a nice tangy sauce.  A few simple vegetables underneath, that would be quite boring if not for the sauce.  There was some deep fried root chip (taro?) that was tasty too.

Mahi Mahi with PEI Mussels: Sadly there were only three mussels, which is quite a change from those huge vats at Belgian places.  The star, the mahi mahi, was plentiful and did a great job absorbing flavor from the broth base.  I'm normally not a huge fish fan because fillets can tend towards bland, but I sure scarfed this one up by the spoonful with the amazing broth! 

Garlic Noodles: We tried to get a side of wasabi house noodles since a friend of ours doesn't eat beef (for religious reasons, not for stupid self-important diet preference reasons) so the steak was out.  We were politely, but firmly denied, but were offered this off-the-menu option.  Huge udon noodles stir fried with some garlic.  Tasty, but not as out of control garlicky as a Filipino version.

Japanese Pumpkin Pie with Macadamia Nuts: Macadamia nuts in the pumpkin pie, why hadn't I thought of this?  Loved the crunch in the creamy pie.  Two awesome ingredients making one great dessert.

Coconut Crème Brûlée with Passionfruit Puree: Not overly coconutty.  Passionfruit is always appreciated in my book, though I think this came from concentrate rather than fresh out of the fruit.  A perfect way to Asianify a Western favorite.
author: Adam B.

description:
I've been here only twice, once about a year ago and the second time just yesterday.

The interior of the place is slightly understated, small, and the tables are little close together. For the slightly high prices and delicious food, the interior is slightly understated and plain, which is surprising, but not a bad thing. It's simple and clean inside, without any distracting or frou frou decor having to compensate for anything. They don't try to be stupidly trendy, which is refreshing. (Also it's a little dimmed, probably to give tables some more privacy because tables are pretty close).

When I went with my bf, we ordered:

- The octopus salad with pork rinds. So yummy. A bit pricey for a small salad appetizer ($10), but I was really surprised at how soft and actually chewable the octopus was. The pork rinds were tasty too, without being tooo greasy and gave the salad a nice crunch. It was light and fresh and perfect if you want a light but savory app.
