- The black cod. The fish itself was just perfect, definitely the best fish dish I've ever had, anywhere. The sauces went really well with it and it practically melted in my mouth every time I had a bite of it. It came with two long pieces of california rolls on top which wasn't anything spectacular, but I loved it anyway. The greens that came under the piece of fish was good, but nothing amazing, it's something my mom can whip up at home in 5 min. But the main star of the dish, the cod, was amazing.

- The grilled sea bass. It was a meatier fish, but still really yummy can came with a sort of soy-saucey dip. I don't think that this dish was as good, because the sides were just green beans and some asian noodles that are pretty mundane and unoriginal. Tasty, but not groundbreaking. 

- Coconut creme brulee. This was awesome. :D I love creme brulee in general AND coconut. But if you don't like coconut, the flavor is really, really subtle. It also came with passionfruit puree on top, which made some bites sort of tangy and delicious. :))


Favorite things:
- The food.
- The service. This server came by with the water jug literally as I was just taking the last sip as if he'd been waiting and watching for me to finish. o.O I also had this lychee black tea and I had drunken half way, and there was a moment when I looked back at it AND IT WAS REFILLED. I did not even notice. I asked my bf, "did you see that?" and he didn't know what I was talking about. Phantom waiters? Servers are really friendly and eager to repeat specials, and make recommendations. This guy recommended me a great wine that I had to write down the name of. :)

Not so awesome things:
- The price. I love the food, but it was just too painful to pay 20+ for an entree that was tasty, but had more more mediocre sides.
- The parking. Yeah.
- Possible waits. Make reservations ahead of time. The service is going to be better around non-busy times. Make reservations for earlier, like around 6pm or so. It gets pretty crowded around 7 or 8.
author: Susie Z.

description:
I have been here more than five times in the last half a year. Need I say more?
Hands down, THE best Asian fusion in the city. 

This place only sits about 50 people, so reservations are not easy to get, your best bet is to reserve a couple of weeks in advance or have a early/late dinner (they open at 5pm). 

The last time I was here, we ordered the seared scallops as an appetizer along with sea bass and garlic steak. The scallops were cooked a little too well but the sea bass, in my opinion, makes up for everything. It was extremely tender and flavorful. Our waitress was extremely attentive and brought us everything we ask for.

Definitely a SF gem if you ask me.
author: Ximeng W.

description:
Five stars just for the fried chicken liver with greens!

I can live on that.

The caviar in the seared scallops though, left a weird taste in my mouth but everything else was great!!

Asian fusion in its finest :)
author: Pam K.

description: This was an amazing experience. A small place with fantastic food and service. After the first course you feel like ordering the entire menu.
author: Sorin F.

description: First time here, except the weird reservation due to high demand of this lovely small fusion restaurant, everything is perfect. Nice atmosphere, great food and excellent service. Fried salmon roll and Kobarota pork chop is must try.
author: Kwok Y.

description: I love this place. Very small 'though. Reservations is a MUST! My fave is the Warm Wasabi House Noodles - DELISH! Highly recommend it. I'll definitely be back!
author: Jingle A.

description:
Even if it's just lunch, you should make reservations.  Our group of 6 people ate here around noon and it was still mellow, with a couple tables open.  But as soon as it hit 12:45-1pm, the place was packed and people were waiting.

I tried 3 things: 1. Fried calamari, 2. Deep fried salmon rolls with Chinese hot mustard, 3. Grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy.  For #3, I had to go against my nature and get this purely based on Yelpers' recommendations.  I wanted the Unagi Avocado Sandwich SO BAD!  And in many ways, I still regret my decision.  The reason being that I've had really amazing sea bass before so the silkiness of the fish wasn't a surprise, it was a requirement.   Along with that, there was some stir fried udon and Chinese green beans and the type they used was something I rarely eat at restaurants and more at home.  That gave me some comfort.  And with your typical fusion dish, there's always a lot of sweet glaze/sauce but at least this was on the side.

The one thing that I liked was the Chinese hot mustard that came with the salmon rolls.  This tasted slightly different from the kind you get at dim sum restaurants but I liked their interpretation.  The salmon wasn't so bad either - everyone enjoyed this.  The calamari, well, is calamari.

You should really come here to see the hostess - she looks disheveled in that apathetic, secretively hippy way.  To sum it up, it's like the Cheesecake Factory type Asian dishes with a Canto touch.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Lunch review:

Ordered the chive and white shrimp dumpling, seared tuna with sushi and salmon with wasabi noodles.  Everything was delicious!  the appetizer was a really good start and the noodles were delish.  A little ibt on the heavier side but I was hungry so it was perfect.  My friend and I were both so full at the end but I ended up cleaning house and finishing both our dishes.

We each paid $27 (tip included) which seems decent to me for what we got.
author: Christine B.

description:
Let's just get to the point.

For appetizers, we had the mussels, deep fried salmon roll, and shrimp dumplings.  I enjoyed the mussels and especially the tomato butter broth, however, the mussels were quite small.  The deep fried salmon roll was perfectly cooked and not dry at all.  The shrimp dumplings was my least favorite appetizer because they just tasted like any other dumplings.  Yes, it was good but there is really nothing special about it that you can't find elsewhere.

Our entrees included the sea bass and miso cod.  The sea bass was definitely the better of the two.  Flavor-wise, it was pretty simple, but what made it stood out was how it was cooked perfectly.  The accompaniments, however, were less than impressive.  The chinese green beans and garlic noodles were overdressed with soy sauce/oyster sauce.  It was heavy, greasy, and really just a bad attempt at asian fusion.  The miso cod was super soft and moist, but that entire dish was ruined by the soy/miso sauce that it came with.  The cod sat on top of cauliflower that was completely drowned in this sauce.  It was difficult to eat because the sauce was just too overwhelming.

I really hate it when asian dishes are drowned in a teriyaki-ish sauce.  The appetizers were great, the piece of sea bass was delicious, but everything else... I would not care to have again.
author: Kat E.

description:
I came here with my family on a Sunday night. It was still packed and they were only seating people with reservations. We were a party of 6 and were told that we had an hour and a half window to finish dinner. That's plenty of time for us.  

The waiters/waitress can be a little emotionless, or maybe snobby because they know how good their food is and they don't really care about customer service. They are attentative and they do their part, but with a straight face.

The flavors were amazing but some dishes can be a little overly salty, but it might just be me. They always have a few items/specials that are not on the menu which are always amazing as well.

Tips:
-Make reservations ahead of time, especially if you have a party of 3 or more.
-Don't expect the waiters/waitresses to smile. (serious face)
author: Junia L.

description:
Asian fusion?? Yes! SOOOO GOOD! We came here on a Friday night and it was packed! It's a really small place though, around 20 tables. 

Dishes Ordered:
Ahi tuna tartare with roasted nori chips
Roasted unagi (eel) with avocado sushi rice
Warm wasabi house noodles with angus flatiron steak
Mushroom rice with grilled prawns
Apple Pie Crumble with Vanilla Ice Cream
Blueberry Pudding and Ice Cream

TARTARE --- Never heard of it before, never tried it before, IT WAS INSANE IN THE MEMBRANE. The Ahi Tuna Tartare was delicious, the tuna was fresh sashimi. The roasted unagi was also one of the best appetizers I've tried in SF thus far. It had a real smokey taste with the unagi taste and the coolness of the wasabi. The wasabi noodles and steak was pretty good but had a little too much of a sweet tinge for me. The mushroom rice and prawns were so delicious. It had a strong taste of mushrooms (maybe a little too strong for some), but it went really well with the grilled taste of the prawns. 

The dessert was probably the best part of the night. The apple pie crumble was pretty average. The blueberry pudding was AMAZING, FREAKIN AMAZING! Seriously though, this blueberry pudding was like a cake almost, it was pretty thick and tasted so rich and wonderful. 

Pros:
- Wonderful Food
- Unique Menu
- Great Service
- FANTASTIC DESSERT

Cons:
- Kind of Pricey
author: Kevin L.

description: I like the location and ambiance of The House although I could see how it could feel cramped if you sat at certain tables.  I got the salmon rolls that came with a mustard sauce.  It was perfect and could not have been better.  I ordered the pork chop for dinner, which was very solid.  There was a Japanese IPA on the menu that satisfied my IPA craving.   I believe the hype is justified.
author: Bob B.

description:
Easily the best meal we had on our vacation to SF.  The dumplings for our appetizers were excellent, but the main meals were what really made our dinner so enjoyable. I had the wasabi noodles and they were terrific. My wife had the special with featured yellowtail tuna which was terrific also.  

The service was excellent and all the waitresses were prompt and very helpful.  

I highly recommend The House for an excellent dinner.
author: John W.

description:
This place is really awesome! I was lucky enough to sample everything on their menu the first time I came because my family is friends with the owner, and I have to say I liked everything. My very favorite thing I always get when I come here for dinner is the pork chop! It is so delicious! And you can never go wrong with the apple pie for dessert. I am not much of a pie fan, but that pie is a loss for words!

The only down side is that this place is pretty small, so if you have a big group it's going to be a tight fit, but other than that the food and service is awesome!
author: Helen C.

description:
The bf took me here for my birthday. What a treat! Looks like the Yelp community has spoken for me already, but may I repeat, get the sea bass. You will not regret it. I skipped the garlic noodles and opted for steamed rice on the side. The snap peas were a nice pairing with the bass. So delicious! While the ambience is nothing to write home about and the space is really crammed, you kind of forget that when you immerse yourself in their delicious food. Skip the salmon rolls. Try the truffle cake, mmm. I'd like to go back and try some of their other small plates, they all sounded intriguing. They have an eclectic alcohol list too! Treat yourself!

Note: parking sucks really badly around here, so allot yourself 15-20 min before your reservation. But, there is a decently priced structure nearby on Vallejo, http://www.yelp.com/biz/north-beach-parking-garage-san-francisco. Good luck!
author: Lisa H.

description:
I have been here a year ago, the food was good, but not impressive.

we were in the area a few weeks ago on a Saturday, stopped by around 5pm for an early dinner.  The restaurant was only about half full, but the manager/owner (she) said there was going to be a 20 minutes wait - with an attitude, unkind and almost very mean as if this is a 5 star hotel and we must wait.

I am ok to wait, but NOT OK WITH ATTITUDES.  I have gone into restaurants much crowded and the servers had excellent attitudes.  

Service is a big part of dining out.  I would NEVER DINE in a restaurant with terrible service.  No matter how good the food may be, if service is bad, its not worth it.
author: Kathy C.

description:
There is no way around it. This place serves up some yummy food. The highlight here is the sauces: they are so generous and forward that they become a partner of the meat/veg, not just an accompaniment.

I am not a sea bass fan, but I adore theirs. Rib-eye is a favorite cut of mine and theirs took it to a new, enjoyable place. Even the desserts were a hit, so yes. This place is for real.

When I'm old, forgotten most of my techniques and too weak to cook, I would be happy eating every night at 'The Home'
author: Richard B.

description:
Let me start by saying, my friends set the expectations bar for The House super high for me.  I've heard about this place multiple times from multiple friends as early as last year, and yet did not get a chance to go until this past Saturday...which I regret now, since I've been missing out!

One super plus - the food came out suuuuuuper quickly.  We ordered appetizers, which came probably within ten minutes or so, and when we were done with those, the main courses came out only minutes later.

Second super plus - the food was not only delicious, but also gorgeous.  All the dishes were visually attractive and creatively presented!

We ordered the pan-seared scallops appetizer, a platter of three sea scallops topped with fresh pea sprouts(?) and a delicious horseradish sauce.  The texture of the scallops was perfect, not at all rubbery, and the sauce augmented the flavor of the scallops without overpowering it.

Then, for dinner, I ordered the sea bass, and I was blown away by the tender flakiness of the fish.  The dark soy sauce was served on the side, which was good since it was really salty/strongly flavored.  I was not super impressed by the garlic noodles it came with (you can choose to get rice instead), but the fish and the green beans more than made up for it.

Luckily for me, I sat amidst a table full of friends who all ordered the pork chops, so I got to steal a few bites.  The meat was deliciously juicy, and even though I was not a huge fan of the sweet berry sauce it was served with, it still outclassed all other pork chops I've ever eaten.

Now that you've read the rave reviews yourself, don't be like me and put off your visit until a year later.  It is just as delicious as everyone says!
author: Cindy X.

description:
I briefly thought about giving this spot four stars, but one look back on the price and this is definitely a five star place for so many reasons.

The number one reason I would say this is a five star restaurant is because you essentially get huge portions and very Gary Danko like inspirations for 1/4 the price per dish. The service is great, the restaurant is small and intimate and the atmosphere is very warm and inviting (if you had a reservation ... not so much if you wanted to stand around and wait).

The menu is small but delightfully packed with delicious choices that made it hard for me to pick just one. I had two appetizers and two entrees and the whole bill came out to be less than $60 or so. Wow!?!?! This is amazing just because it's San Francisco!

Their choices are fusion, and yes as much as I'm not the biggest fan of most fusion places, this place is downright delicious and rightfully reviewed as one of the better restaurants in SF. I can't wait to come back!
author: Lorrie M.

description:
It was weird.  I didn't like the sea bass.  

Yes, I walked in dreaming of my cod, light, succulent and satisfying, but it was not on special, so I was content to try something else.  Everyone loves the sea bass, so I did not hesitate to venture into new fishdom that evening.  

It was thick and very rich.  I wouldn't say it was tough, but it was not even close to the delicate-barely-touched-with-heat cod or tuna I am used to.  That, and the side of noodles was so thick and salty, I felt like something was off.  Also, there was no shortage of green beans in my plate and they were pretty oily and also very salty.  It just took me by surprise.  Truth is - it was good, but it was MAN-good, meaning it was thick and robust.  ...Not what I expect from a House fish dish and definitely not what I wanted that night.

Weird.

However, the salmon appetizer was spot on, as was the tuna (I snagged a bite from another).  Our friend, a-meat-and-potatoes-ONLY kind of a guy, had the steak and ate every last morsel. There was love in his eyes.  We might have opened a new door for him that night.

I took half my dish to go, which is odd for me, and skipped out on dessert, which is even odder for me; especially because I love The House's passion fruit creme brulee (it is one of my favorite combinations).  But I didn't even have space for that.

I wonder if it is okay to make reservations and then call that same day to make sure they have the special I want.  Is that wrong? 

I feel like it is wrong, but I am going to do it anyway.
author: Hayley W.

description: So my friends and I wanted to go to another place but was packed so we decided to walk around to look for another place to dine.  We walked around and ended up deciding to try this place out.  What did we conclude? The food is awesome! I tried the teriyaki steak which was the best steak I've had! Juicy and tasty!  Totally worth the 26 dollars.   The dessert was great as well!  Will comeback in the future for sure!  Fast service too!
author: Don P.

description: Never disappoints.  It's all about the sauce!  Every dish always has decadent sauces dripping that just oozes with flavor.  This is one of my favorite restaurants.  Tasty, down to earth, good service, and what eating out should be about.  I have tried a number of dishes as the menu often changes and everything has been fantastic.
author: Christina K.

description: A small restaurant, you may pass it if you aren't looking for it. I must say it is definitely a must stop in and try. Even my picky eater kiddos were impressed.
author: Reba M.

description:
Overated

We has a reservation but yet had to wait 30 minutes. Restaurant was crowded on a Monday night and waitress not very welcoming as she greeted us. No apology or anything as she seated us.

Starving, we sat and ordered appetizers. We had the salmon rolls and mussels. Very delicious along with a decent priced white wine. Appetizers are pretty generous  in sized.

This is when it went down hill... I had the sea bass with garlic noodles. Cooked well with flavor but so oily. Same with the noodles, such shame.

My brother had the ribeye...he enjoyed it though I would have preferred a thicker cut. It was loaded with fat and barely 1/2 an inch thick. Also very oily, drenched.

My mom ordered shrimp tempura. It was pretty soggy and covered with salad. 

Service was horrible. They never once poured our wine other than the initial glass. Came back just once to ask how we were doing. Staff was busy drinking beer behind the counter and eating their own meal. We asked to see the dessert menu and she never brought it. I finally waved her down with my card asking for the check.

She's like...no dessert?? Ugh after waiting 20 minutes for you to bring the menu, no thank you.

What a shame. Only a few days in San Fran to celebrate my Mom's birthday and first trip here. It was wasted by this restaurant.
author: Miss Lei S.

description:
We decided to go because of all the reviews.  I had actually came on an earlier flight and thought that we would stop here on the way.  They originally told us it would be an hour wait at 8:30 without reservations, it was really more of a 1 3/4 hour wait.  And I don't think it mattered too much if you had reservations because a couple in front of us had reservations at 9, and weren't really seated until 9:45.  Parking isn't easy; we had to park in one of those parking lots, and a lot of them seem to charge outrageous prices.  

Finally it was our turn to sit down in this rather small and crowded claustrophobic restaurant.  We ordered their sashimi special and the pig skin octopus salad.  The salad was nice, the sashimi wasn't anything special.  My boyfriend got the flat iron steak on wasabi flavored noodles.  He didn't really like it at all.  I got their halibut on a creamy sauce.  The fish felt a little on the dry side and it came with this mash potato side which was good in itself, but really did not go with the fish.  And the sauce made it too heavy and rich, which only brought down the fish even further.  So the food was rather disappointing.  Especially for the hype and the wait.  I wish I'd known.  I think I would've rather tried one of the pizza or burger places around that area.  I would've saved 3 hours and quite a bit of money and probably enjoyed the food more than what I experienced.  

It's okay.  It's nothing wonderful, nothing to rave about, and nothing to wait in line for.  I felt like the couple that passed on the restaurant when they realized the wait for it would be at least an hour lucked out.  I wished I hadn't been so stubborn sometimes.  It really didn't pay off in this situation.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Food: 5, Atmosphere: 5, Service: 5

What can I say other than we ate and almost licked our plate clean!  The food was truly amazing - perhaps some of the best food I've had happened here tonight!  The steak was done just right.  The sea bass was flaky and yummy.  The pork chop was totally moist and the most amazing dish was the coconut curry yellow tail - the perfect blend of flavor is to die for!  Love the small atmosphere and the cozy feeling to this place.  Only warning is do make reservation and come early.  Without reservation, don't bother showing up.
author: Yi N.

description:
This restaurant is so cute! It's like a small little house right in the middle of Little Italy. Not suitable for a big party, 2-6 people is OK. Cute date night place :)

Get the sea bass - its delicious! Melts in your mouth. Absolutely love the sauce that goes with it. Their garlic noodles are also good, small portion, but tasty.

Parking is going to be nuts. If I were you, I wouldn't even try looking for street parking. There are two parking lots on Vallejo street, between Stockton and Powell - just 2 blocks away. Have fun!
author: Rosie W.

description:
Contemporary fusion Asian American rated extremely highly by a friend certainly lived up to its star-studded reviews.

Thursday dinner reservation and The House was already steaming up the windows with people dining and queuing at the door alike. Simple ambience in an intimate layout (tables are quite close together) our table of four was seated promptly.

We started with steamed mussels with garlic infused shrimp, deep fried salmon roll with Chinese hot mustard and baby octopus with pig skin salad. Each dish was delicately flavoured and beautifully presented - I would ask for bread with the mussels to make the most of the broth. Personally, the salad was a little too pungent (or strongly flavored) for me but the rest of the group enjoyed it.

Having heard the sea bass was a signature dish I was slightly disappointed with The House concept of grilled sea bass with garlic ginger sauce - it was no better or worse than I've tasted elsewhere I was expecting a twist or a surprise with my bites but nothing. The sauce tasted slightly burnt rather than leaving a silky taste. The pork chop with pomegranate sauce was a colorful in taste and appearance, a fresh combination and worth a try if you're feeling adventurous. The warm house noodles with flatiron steak arrived with perfectly cooked steak, beautiful crunchy salad served with garlic noodles.

Best thing about having dinner with a group? You get to try a good selection of desserts! Mango tapioca, coconut and passion fruit creme brulé, chocolate truffle cake with vanilla ice cream - the mango tapioca reminded me a little of a lighter creamed rice pudding presented with a pretty mango jus flower, light and pleasantly scented. My friends loved the rich truffle cake and ice cream but the crème brulé - booooo. Sorely disappointed. Burnt not caramelised. Mousse-like not dense. We did have to send it back but a thank you to the staff for taking it off the bill, they explained it was not crème brulé as we know it but The House creation of the classic. Not for moi.

Overall, a charming place, pleasing food for the eyes and the stomach. Oh, and your paper place mat has a tiny cut out house, very cool.
author: Sahara B.

description: Great Asian fusion food! It's a small-ish restaurant so make a reservation. We enjoyed the fried salmon rolls for appetizers. Everyone loved their meal - steak, pork or seafood. Great presentation with lots of flavor.
author: Jessica L.

description: Great food and great service.  The best Sea Bass ever!  We have been back a few times by or selves and with friends and family.  If you get the chance this is one place you won't regret trying...
author: John W.

description:
Despite the seats being a bit squished and you can totally hear what your neighbors are saying and feeling what they're doing... the food is great and the service is excellent. 

First time order for 2 -- 3 appetizers (half dozen of oysters, hamachi salad, salmon roll) and their off the menu entrees -- black cod with sushi and some kind of beef dish.... and dessert (creme brulee with passionfruit juice) Must come back again and try everything on the menu!!! (:
author: Kady S.

description:
Asian Fusion:

Chicken curry noodles are very good. It's a lot to eat and can be shared between two people for lunch

Calamari -- not fried is simply amazing

Creme Brulee with passion fruit puree - DAMN! This is a must try!

This place is pretty small so reservations are an absolute must.


Will repeat!
author: Jase O.

description:
I gave this place a 3 star because it is overrated.

Ordered:
Calamari - tasted like calamari from a haply hour menu. Nothing special.
Wasabi noodles with steak - Tasted like chow fun from chinatown. The steak was cold and chewey. My work has better flank steak.
Sea bass - The only item that was worth the price.

If you want to dine at an upgraded version of pf chiangs this place is perfect. Otherwise not worth the wait or reservation.
author: David S.

description: I love this place! My boyfriend and I went for our anniversary and we both fell in love with it. Their deep fried salmon roll is a must have as well as their seabass. Their seabass buttery goodness totally melts in your mouth! Everything was so good that we had to try their dessert as well. Pie a la mode.. On point! The only down side is that it is a small restaurant and definitely make reservations before coming. Other than that, definitely worth adding this place to your must-eat-when-in-SF!
author: Yliana C.

description:
Wed Night Dinner:

Octopus Salad - has crispy pork skin, nice
Scallop - on par with other fancy places that serve the scallop
Kobe New York - good portion, but was $40
Halibut - good broth, curry base
Bitter Sweet Choco Cake - nice finish
Coconut Creme brulee  - original and good

All great, the place is a little small but we had reservations. Was suppose to have the Wasabi Noodles with flat iron steak and Pork chops from reviews on Yelp. But decided to try the specials. Saw the pork chops coming out while we order and definitely going to try that next type. My money was worth it at this place.
author: Phillip K.

description:
I don't know how to say this without sounding dramatic, but this restaurant has the best food I've ever had. I've been twice now and it's amazing how consistently good they are. The menu is simple, yet flavors are complex. Though I haven't had everything on the menu, I'm convinced it's all gotta be good.

We ordered the salmon, the wasabi noodles, and the seabass and EVERYTHING was delicious and so different. 

The salmon roll app was so tasty and perfectly cooked/fried and the sauce that came with it was so good I wanted to save it for my entree later. Of course, I didnt need it because the broth that came with the salmon was heavenly. It was savory but mild and clean, maybe some fancy food peeps would describe it as "umami"? Whatever it was, it was delicious. 

We ordered dessert (even though we were full) and the apple pie was warm, sweet, and the crumble on top was the perfect crunch with the soft apples. 
I was stuffed, but I couldn't stop cause the flavors are so good. 
If my wallet was big enough, I'd eat here every week!
author: Megan B.

description:
The house has amazing food. They have Asian fusion food and all their dishes are completely delicious and inventive. My absolute favorite dish is their ahi tuna main entree. The tuna is seared perfectly and the combination of the rice and sauces is so good. 

From their appetizers, I love their tempura green beans and I also love their fried salmon roll. This place has really fresh fish and ingredients and their sauces make each dish unique. 

The place is rather small and it's hard to get in if you don't make reservations in advance. Strongly recommend calling them ahead, a week or so, and getting reservations.
author: Armina A.

description:
This is probably one of my top 3 restaurants in San Francisco. When I lived there, this was an easy go-to with people who came into town to visit. The wait to get a table is pretty ridiculous, but I had the opportunity to get to know the hostess who would seat us pretty quickly.. i loved that about this place! 

The menu is always changing and they do an excellent job with American/Asian fusion and a great wine selection to compliment the food! 

If you've never been, you need to go into this place at least once - you wont be sorry!
author: Ameesh M.

description: Having lived in SF for 2 years, I have now eaten at quite a few restaurants. The House remains one of my absolute favorites. The service is prompt and the food is phenomenal. This is fusion done right. Definitely get the sea bass. I also enjoyed the pomegranate pork chop and I don't even like pork chops! The noodles are also awesome. Basically, you can't go wrong; this is one of those rare restaurants where nothing is a "miss," and I want to keep coming back to try the whole menu. I've been here 3 times and I already am craving more. The House is very busy though, so make sure to secure reservations. For dinner on the weekend i would recommend calling at least 1.5 weeks in advance. Also, it's pretty pricey, but definitely worth it.
author: Anna J.

description: My husband and I read how great this place was in yelp, and so we decided to try the place on our first night in San Francisco. And boy, were we glad we did. We walked about a mile from our hotel to The house and it was so worth it.  The place is small but really nice. We got seated right by the window and so we got to enjoy observing the people outside.  We had the calamari for appetizer. My husband had the pork chop while I had their dinner black cod special. It was delish!  The mango tapioca for dessert was awesome.  The service was great. Their staff are really nice and our food was served right away.  Definitely recommend the place.
author: J L.

description:
one of the BEST restaurants in SF for sure / HANDS DOWN!!

These people know what they are doing. They keep their reservations really organized and it is a must to have a reservation here, otherwise the waiting list could take forever... this is a tiny gem in the middle of North Beach.

Cannot say enough about their plates execution, every sauce, every texture kinda melts in your mouth... it is just delicious and flavorful. 

Gotta try the Ahi Tuna, or mussels, and the salmon roll to start off.

On the entree side my faves are the sea bass, the pomegranate pork chop.... They also have Kobe Steak as part of their specials. They cook the beef to perfection medium rare, omg! DAMN, everything here is to die for.

I am not the biggest fan of tapioca, and gosh.... the mango tapioca was outstanding at The House.

I highly recommend this restaurant, wont disappoint, especially locals.
author: Anaheli D.

description: In my 23 years of living, I can't believe I've only been here TWICE :( I've ate here several dishes here from those two visits and I have nothing but great things to say about this restaurant. Well first off - this place is kinda small so the wait could be a while but totally worth it. I want to say everything you try would probably be great. It'll be like a dance party in your mouth moving to your belly. I mean everyone else described everything perfectly but you'll never know how heaven really tastes likes until you sit down and eat it... now i want some .... OH LEMME MENTION THIS... parking here? ahahah good luck!
author: Kristina L.

description:
We tried the old "The House" close to UCSF few years ago. The foods and services were great.  On the recent trip to SF we called to make a reservation for dinner at this new place. We got a 8:30 pm reservation on Fri Oct. 19 and went there at 8:20pm. The place was packed. After waiting for few minutes at the door, a woman came to us and we told about our reservation at 8:30pm. We gave her our phone number and she said that our reservation was at 9:30pm. I didn't  think it was 9:30pm since "nine" and "eight" pronunciations do not sound close. I ask if she remembered if I made the reservation in the morning or afternoon. She said that she couldn't remember while being very sully and didn't even offer an apology. Hmm... I said to myself: "Is today the Halloween?". So we left and went to another restaurant nearby rather than waiting for  an hour.

I think they took our reservation just as bogus and definitely lied to us when the place was full. That is a really dishonest practice. We are aware of the good foods. But for us having good foods without good services is like meeting somebody who is pretty outside but ugly inside. So shame on you The House. The management should take a closer look at your staff. I guess you don't care much about customers since it sounds like more people need your foods than you need customers. Your business is quite lucky these days but one day you might learn a lesson though.
author: Kevin T.

description:
Very expensive, but still a fan. The sea bass was very good, service was excellent.  Worth the occasional splurge, but I'm in the demographic where I strongly prefer hole-in-the-walls to fancy upscale Asian fusion, so won't be coming here regularly.

Not sure where I'd prefer to spend a comparable amount of money.  Definitely tastier here than Slanted Door.  Maybe Tamarine in Palo Alto is preferred and comparable.
author: Lisa S.

description:
DEFREAKENLICIOUS. I was so obsessed with my meal it was insane. I had the steak and everyone else in group got the noodles and there wasnt a bad thing we had to say about the flavor. Everything was amazing. 

The restaurant is pretty tiny and the service was slow last time i went but definitely worth the wait. Make a reservation! 

Its slightly hidden and the street area isn't a busy one in the evening but CHECK IT OUT. Yummm
author: Jillan B.

description:
Finally, a highly-rated place in SF that takes reservations. Definitely a plus. 

I'm usually not sure how I feel about Asian fusion foods, and that's how I feel about The House as well. Perhaps my friend hyped it up too much, or perhaps we didn't order the sea bass, which was the most popular dish (sorry, had too much good fish in Hong Kong). We did try the deep fried salmon rolls, which were pretty much salmon egg rolls. Too fried in my opinion, and salmon was ok. 

My favorite was the flank steak atop a bed of wasabi noodles. Sounded like a sinus-clearing entree to me, but was surprisingly not too overwhelming. Noodles could have been a bit more al dente, but were flavorful with a small kick of wasabi in each bite. Steak was cooked perfectly, well-seasoned and tender. My favorite part of the meal.

Good place to try. Solid fusion food with fresh ingredients.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
I'm going to add to hype and say that this is place is pretty awesome!

We made a reservation for 5pm on a Saturday (which is when it opens), arrived 15 minutes late because we couldn't find parking, and found that the place was already 3/4 full. I would say the entire place could probably seat around 50 people - it's small, but not a hole in the wall.

At the recommendation of all the reviews, we order the pork chop and  the sea bass. Both were very satisfying, but different, and therefore need equal attention. 
- The sea bass was soft, almost like it was steamed, but crispy on the outside from the grill. It was accompanied by garlic noodles, which I didn't not find very interesting, but still the overall dish was inspiring. (~$26)

- The pork chop was accompanied by a pomegranate sauce, fried taro/yam chips that towered over the mash potatoes, and a few pieces of asparagus. I enjoyed all of it to the bone. (~$22)

Even though I did sneak off 1/4 of my bf's sea bass, I think I enjoyed the pork chop more because it really isn't too hard to cook soft fish. It's all about timing and steaming. And my momma taught me right!

We ended the dinner with the chocolate cake that was topped with a scoop of coffee ice-cream (to test these yelp reviews), and it was great! the consistency of the cake was soft and almost brownie-like. (~$8)

For the romantics: Mood-lighting happens after 5:45 pm (when the sun sets).
author: Lucia C.

description:
came here for dinner while visiting my brother out in San Francisco. Cool place serving East meets West cuisine! Among our group, we ordered the ribeye steak (my pick - DELICIOUS!), cod, salmon, tuna, and flatiron steak with udon noodles. Everything came out very quickly and was piping hot! The steak was just so tender and well seasoned with the housemase teriyaki glaze. The fried garlic bits on top were a great compliment to the creamy mashed potatoes!

Everything was well presented (and very photogenic!) Surrounding us were a lot of other Asians who were equally in awe of the beautiful presentation of all the dishes! Service was great too! Suggestion-carpool! It was rough trying to find parking around here for dinner!
author: Lisa W.

description: Great service!!  Sea bass, ahi tuna, house noodles and dessert were delicious.  We had persimmon pudding pie, coconut creme brûlée and chocolate cake?  Demon slayer sake was well recommended.  I would like larger portions of mussels/octopus per dish and less salt on the veggies.  I thoroughly savored the mussel broth with their garlic bread.  Yum!!  Less memorable were the steak and pork chop but my friends loved their dish.
author: amee m.

description:
Wow so many reviews.  I think my review gives new meaning to take it with a grain of salt....

Anyways, The House is actually pretty good.  The food is simple asian fusion.  Nothing cutting edge or out of the box, but it is solid nonetheless.  I made reservations for lunch to avoid the wait.  When we arrived the place was fully packed with the only empty table being ours.  Hence, we were quickly seated.  

We ordered
Blue lake green beans which were very good.  They are served in a tempura batter over blanched thinly sliced beats with a fish/soy dipping sauce.  The string beans were very big and pre-blanched before they were quick fried in tempura batter.  The texture grean been was crunchy and fresh.  

Black Cod which reminded me of an asian fusion version of fish and chips without the chips.  The Cod was extremely moist and very tasty.  Dipping sauce was vinagear, soy, fish sauce, and ginger based.

Grilled Sea Bass.  One of the best Sea Bass's I have ever had.  Extremely moist with an excellent texture.  Came with a side of noodles.  Excellent dish!

Wasabi Noodles and Pork.  My favorite of them all.  Very flavorful noodles with a nice finish of wasabi.  The wasabi adds that kick without spice to balance the sweetness of the noodles.  The thinly sliced grilled pork and pickled cabbage that top the noodles were perfect as well.  Crunchy pickled cabbage rounded out the whole dish.

The House is a very good restaurant with a lot of hype.  Do I think it is deserving of the mass hype, not really, but the meal was good.
author: Rhett S.

description:
This was one of the first Asian fusion restaurants in the City. The sea bass entree was the most memorable, and it's still on the menu. 

Five of us came for lunch today. We came specifically for the unagi sandwich. A fillet of unagai on grilled buttered bread with avocado, lettuce and tomato. Served with mixed green salad. I'm going to try to duplicate the unagi sandwich at home. 

We started with the deep fried calamari. Although it appeared burnt, it didn't taste burnt. Served with shredded slaw and a nice dipping sauce. 

The restaurant was packed during the lunch hour, but our food arrived within reasonable time. 

Major con - the noise level because the spacing is very tight. You don't have to try very hard to hear other people's conversations.
author: Shirley N.

description:
I must start off this review by saying they serve THE BEST grilled sea bass hands down. Without. A. Doubt. Okay. Onto my review.

This place is surprisingly small. Tables are tucked very close together. I was able to listen to my neighbors' entire conversation. You get these white paper place mats with a tiny cut out of a house. It's a simple touch but it gave quite the impression. There wasn't much decor to this place. Very simple and plain. The food must be good because the place was never empty and there was always a group of people waiting for a table. The House attracts a pretty diverse crowd. I was really impressed. 

Don't let the website fool you. It may look cheap as hell but the food more than makes up for it. They have specials that are not on the menu and I remember every darn thing the waitress was reading off sounding really tempting. I was getting overwhelmed by all the choices I had which I surprisingly all liked. My friend had mentioned they make the best sea bass so I decided to go with that. Hopefully the next time I come back they'll still have the black miso cod. The sea bass was really thick and juicy. Just judging by it first glance, it would look like it was grilled so black that the fish was probably hard. The second that first bite hit my mouth it was as if I was in heaven. The fish literally melted in my mouth. It was really juicy and buttery. It was cooked perfectly. I don't have one bad thing to say about it except there should've been more of it! It was served with green beans and the warm wasabi house noodles. It also came with this sweet garlic soy sauce that I poured over the green beans. It tasted like something you order at a Chinese restaurant. Don't get too happy with the sauce or it'll get salty.

For dessert, we got the red velvet cake. Oh dear my. The presentation was awesome. The cake was very soft and moist but the cream cheese is what got me. It had just a small hint of sourness but it was mostly sweet. Sometimes the cheese and the cake can be a little too sweet but The House made it perfect so it would complement eachother. Neither component overpowered the other. 

The House definitely did not disappoint one person in our party. Each dish had their own specific flavor. Not one of them tasted the same. Make sure you make reservations a few days before. We called the day before and the only earliest time they had available was 9:30PM. The service was very friendly and efficient. Prices were surprisingly lower than what we were expecting which makes this place even better! We couldn't have asked for anything better at The House.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Let me start off by saying the sea bass was amazing. The bf and I got the ahi tuna tartare with nori chips and the Kobe beef with truffle sauce. Service was decent. Finished off with a coconut cream brûlée topped with passion fruit purée. Will definitely be back soon!
author: Mary M.

description:
I LOVE sea bass.

I will go to any restaurant that is known for their sea bass, and this is one of them.  Is it worth the hype?  Totally!  The serving of sea bass is bigger than what I expected (no complaints on my part!), seasoned beautifully and cooked to perfection.  The garlic noodles and green beans that came along with it are also delicious!  I did try the deep fried salmon roll appetizer, and while it was good, it wasn't amazing, so 1 less star because of that.

The place is definitely small and not good for large groups because of that.  But, they do take reservations, so no matter how many people you have in your party, just make the call and you will be glad you did!
author: Tanya P.

description:
One of the most innovative restaurants I've been to. 

The House is the only true Asian fusion place I've ever been to. Plenty of places with that label use the moniker to pawn off upscale versions of Panda Express. It's almost as if the label is made for places who want to to make authentic Asian food but can't.

The House is different. Everything on the menu seems to be something American but is hiding the soul of an Asian dish inside. The tartare is served on top of a seaweed cracker to mimic sushi, and the wasabi noodles bring together the slight spiciness and fresh taste of a Korean dish known as Bi Bim Bap. Each component and flavor profile seems to have been both innovative and well thought out. 

The result of their efforts is an assortment of food that seems less Asian than other Asian fusion places in the U.S. but has a flavor profile that is far more authentic than other Asian fusion restaurants. 

Taste aside, this restaurant is a marvel of both innovation and concept.
author: Eugene P.

description:
NOTE: it is open on Sunday even though it says on the yelp iphone app it's not.

What we got:
Seabass (comes with same noodles as the wasabi noodles, different sauce) - the noodles were a bit salty, it's the lo mein nooodles though yum. Seabass was tasty, and grilled to perfection, wish it came with a different dipping sauce though.

Wasabi noodles- comes with cut steak on it, it's really good! Dash of wasabi taste on it, but I would say this was the best thing we ordered.

Deep fried Salmon Roll - eggroll looking thing. warning: use dipping sauce sparingly, it has a strong wasabi taste that might make you cry like a little girl. 

Chicken Liver & Salad - not that great, deep fried chicken liver, nothing spectacular, normal tasting salad with no special dressing, get something else on the menu.

It's a quaint little place, they told us we had an hour before they needed the table back since we didn't have a reservation. They didn't rush us though, everything just moves at a fast pace there as they clear out your huge plates on their tiny table. One detail i thought was really cute, was their placemats. They punched little house stamps into them. Clever! Overall, it was good, a bit too saucy for me, but a nice place to try while you're in North Beach and want to get non-italian food!
author: Joanna S.

description: I make sure to frequent this restaurant whenever I visit San Francisco. I was blown away the first time I dined here, and it has yet to disappoint. The sea bass is simply the best. I have yet to find another restaurant that can do it better. It is actually because of this restaurant that I decided to become a Yelp member and write a review.
author: Samuel Y.

description:
Over 3k reviews and 4.5 stars is as legit as it gets. One of my favorite restaurants in the city that is actually sorta kinda reasonably priced (for SF anyway).

Must try apps:
Crab cake
Scallops (special)

Must try entrees:
Wasabi noodles
Grilled sea bass (get it with noodles!)
Pork chop
Kobe ribeye with truffle reduction

Everything on the menu is good, so don't be afraid to try new things but the above are my favorites. Make a reservation, this place gets crowded.
author: EJ Y.

description:
we went in on a Saturday afternoon with no reservations, we were sat in about 5 minutes,no wait,we has the with shrimp dumplings for an appetizer , they were amazing.
For lunch we had the special noodle bowl wonderful, chipolte bbq pork sandwich, also amazing, and the crispy chicken sandwich, every bit of the food was beyond good, you get good portions, none of us could finish our whole meal. even the side salad was really good.I cant say enough about how good the food was.
now the service, not so great, they were all in a super rush and we had to have our server repeat everything because she talked way too fast, we only saw her to take our order and bring our bill, but the food made up for the service.
All i can say is AWESOME!!!
author: s s.

description:
So, I would call it 4 stars, but I have never had such amazing sea bass before.

Don't come with reservations. Leave your phone number - call comes from a blocked number, so answer it! Your table is ready!

Got the ahi tartare with wasabi small plate: 5 stars, amazing flavor

Salmon roll: eh, I would say 3 stars

House wasabi noodles: 3.5, my steak was cooked well, but this was not the stand out entree

Pork chop: 5 stars, thick and super super tender. I'm getting this next time

Sea bass: 5 stars! Heaven! So juicy!!! The hubby is getting this next time!! And we r splitting it :)

Going back for sure! Making reservations this time
author: Hazel J.

description:
SO DELICIOUS!! GET ANYTHING AND EVERYTHING! I was very impressed from appetizers to desserts!

The black cod with california roll and grilled pork chop with pomegranate sauce were excellent! The juiciest pork chop that I've ever eaten!

The dishes are innovative and fuse asian cuisine with new american in a sophisticated and harmonious way. Just thinking about 'The House' makes me want to eat there right now!
author: Christine Y.

description:
Overall: Slightly disappointed, but leaving as 4 stars because the food IS good. Does it live up to the hype, though? No.

I really wanted to love The House (I spent a good amount of time online beforehand researching what dishes to order and salivating over the beautiful yelp pictures of the food), however I left slightly disappointed. Don't get me wrong, the food IS good - I just don't think it merits the 2,000 person 4.5 star average. It's the same kind of disappointment I felt after Aziza (except there, the entrees didn't actually taste good).

We tried:
- The hamachi sashimi appetizer - 3.5 stars (the fish quality was good but the salsa-like topping was more bland than I'd hoped)
- The deep fried salmon roll appetizer - 3.5 stars (good, but I likely wouldn't order them again (IMHO the wasabi way overpowered the otherwise tasty salmon).)
- The sea bass with garlic noodles - 4 stars (the main reason we came) (the fish was cooked well, the ginger / soy sauce actually made the fish slightly sweeter (which I wasn't expecting).. and I might order it again.. but.. somehow.. I expected more!)

May go back again sometime, but will likely cross a few more off my to-try list first :)
author: Helen D.

description: Great find the food was excellent. Real crowded for a small place but I judge off the food. Everything was perfect for what it was. Will defiantly be going back when I go back. Creme Brule was amazing no question always a must. Met some life long friends in there just starting up a conversation about our food. Will go back anytime possible. Def. make reservations.
author: Jordan F.

description: Wonderful food, high quality ingredients, great staff, but long wait.
author: Hamid M.

description:
WOW! I'd say I just missed the commotion. Judging from all the raves and five solid stars given away to this restaurant, I must've missed something. Perhaps it wasn't my night, but my experience here was slightly off the chart. We had a reservation at 9 pm (yes, horribly late because we couldn't get an earlier reservation as every citizen wanted to dine here that night), but arrived at 8.30pm to hope for an open table. Having no luck, we decided to wait till 9 pm after all. We told them we would walk around the North Beach neighborhood and would come back around 8.50pm, so please remember that we're here. Apparently not. They gave away our table to another party and so we had to wait for another half hour for the next table. 

Ugh, bad start.

Service is somewhat decent, the waitresses are smart about their food and everything seemed timely and food was not overly delayed. But the food per se, forgive me for saying this, were not as good as what I thought it would be. Geez I waited 8 years to try this place and all I got was a basic standard sort of food. They could do better if the cut down on the saltiness on their wasabi noodles. Nonetheless, I had a favorite dish; the risotto with grilled wild shrimp (or something like that in the name) Risotto was cooked perfectly, creamy and everything. Shrimp was good and fresh too. 

I might come back, perhaps in the next 8 years.
author: Rika P.

description:
YUM!  

this place is tiny, and they will not seat you until the whole party is there. 

this is what we had 
appetizer:  
-raw oysters --- very fresh 
-Steam Mussels --- tasty!
-Deep fried chicken liver with baby greens --- the deep fried liver was soooo good!             

Entree:

-Angus ribeye steak -- very tender and juicy. but the veggie that came with it was so bitter. the mash potato was a little dry, i prefer some gravy
-Grilled Sea Bass -- forget the ginger soy it comes with, i think its too salty. sea bass alone is really good, and the green beans too!
-Grilled Ahi Tuna -- not enough sauce? decent
-"Special" Kobe beef. very tender. but it only came with some fries, a lot of them

Dessert:

-creme brulee - kinda sour but i like it ;)
-chocolate warm cake with coffee ice cream - pretty good ;)

i remember glancing at the bill... it was $180 (before tips) for 4  not bad considering we had a fest + i didnt include drinks and 1 or 2 other stuff
author: Anna W.

description:
Wow.  Yes it's that good.

Came here with my family after hearing our neighbors raving about how scrumptious this place is.  Well, it is that good.

Where to begin...oh yes.  We started with an appetizer special that was served tonight: perfectly-seared scallops with microgreens and herbs on top, complemented with a delicious mustard sauce.  I've never had scallops that were so perfectly cooked: seared well on the outside, but so buttery inside...

That was just the appetizer.  After having the great appetizer, our entrees came:
"Warm wasabi house noodles with angus flatiron steak"
"Grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy"
"Grilled ahi tuna with spicy mustard aioli"
A special that showcased halibut with some great curry (don't remember the exact name...)

Well where to start!  The steak was cooked perfectly and the wasabi noodles were definitely one of a kind.  The sea bass literally melted upon eating, and the garlic ginger soy perfectly accented the delicacy of the fish.  The tuna was delicious and the mustard aioli tasted almost like a wasabi sauce, so the taste perfectly accompanied the rare ahi tuna.  The halibut was delicious, and the curry had a great earthy taste to it.

Upon completion, we had to have a go with the dessert menu.  We ordered the apple crumb pie a la mode, mango tapioca, and the creme brulee.  I'm not necessarily a very experienced dessert taster, but the tapioca and the creme brulee were pretty good.  The apple crumb however...was pretty much the best apple pie I ever had.  It managed to taste naturally sweet, with no noticeable additional sugar that plagues many other pies.  Then the crumb atop was so crisp and had a great texture.  

Overall, it was a great family experience to eat at such a high quality restaurant such as "The House".  This place definitely deserves a definite-must-return!
author: Brian S.

description: I ve tryied to reserve they answer you cant when i got the place people went ahead me because they had reservation by web , ok i choose for one to go, while i was waiting i saw every cookers touch every kind of food with the hands, i asked wasaby noodles with medium steak , never had noodles so dry and the steak was rer not medium
author: Stefano G.

description:
After I got over the whole "my life is filled with doom & gloom, I'm so ancient" melodrama, I let the best friend kidnap me & force me to have a happy freakin' birthday instead of boo-hooing into my morning cup of coffee. 

I swear, nothing says you are loved like a birthday lunch at The House.

I had my favorite thing on the menu: the seabass with garlic ginger soy sauce, green beans & noodles (just *reading* about it makes you drool, don't it?) And ended the meal with their mango tapioca. 

In the past year, we've been to The House many times to celebrate many things. I love their minimalistic decor, leaving nothing to distract you from your gorgeous plate of incredible food. Their flavors are consistently amazing palate pleasers & service is attentive/friendly.

*sigh* I'm a year older (probably not any wiser), but the end of my 20's started out in a really delicious way this year, thanks to the BFF.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
They literally have the best pork chop one can possibly makes. Juicy, tender, and just amazing!!!

Tuna was good too. i'll definitely try the sea bass next time! 

Always make a reservation before you go, cuz the line can easily be two hours.
author: Jacob Y.

description:
Great restaurant! The steak and wasabe house noodles was an amazing dish. Also had the fried salmon rolls and ahi tuna appetizers to start which were both incredible. The salmon rolls are a must - i've never had salmon done this way! I definitely would recommend this for a family dinner or dinner with a few friends - not much room for big groups and eating in close quarters.

My only complaint was that they seemed to rush our meal along a bit since it's a small and in demand restaurant. Also, they could use a little more space for all the people waiting for tables at the door who were literally watching us eat.
author: Rebecca G.

description: SO good.  I've been here several times over the last eight years, and it's delicious every time.  The miso black cod was delicious tonight.  I usually love the ribeye as well.  The mains are way more delicious than the appetizers.  Do it.
author: Melinda C.

description: For a 4.5 star place expected more.  Firstly I made a 8pm reservation. Did not get seated till 8.30pm! Was seated right beside an open door so was freezing cold.  The starters were really delicious!! Scallop in ponzu sauce (daily special), salmon roll, oysters. Salmon roll was by far the best - medium rare in the middle and fillet not mashed salmon. Scallop slightly overcooked but flavours were very good. The main meal - him this was really weird. The pork chop tasted like sweet sour pork with the pomegranate sauce and noodles way too salty and steak too chewy. Overall - flavours tasted too much like chinese food - for fusion expected some more interesting flavours. Desert - persimmon pudding pie really good. Overall, they need to step up service and main dishes to earn their 4.5 stars.
author: I L.

description:
The House is one of the best restaurants I have visited.  
The place is small, so you need to make reservation in advance.

The table is small and very close to each other.

We ordered the Fried Salmon Roll and Scallop appetizers we loved them.  Our main courses were Clams Curry,  Grilled Sea Bass, and the special Raspberry Duck and we enjoyed all of them.

We will go back for sure!
author: Cholada C.

description:
YUM! went here for my anniversary. delicious food but the service wasnt that great. the servers are overworked and express that in their service. even if you have a reservation, expect a 15 minute wait if you go on the weekend (the restaurant is veryyy small so there isnt much space to wait either.) make a reservation.

we got the shrimp salad (only came with 3 pieces of shrimp, could have had more,) the grilled ginger garlic sea bass with and garlic noodes (one of the best fish plates that ive ever had,) the rib eye (melts like butter) and finally the chocolate cake with coffee ice cream and coconut (i didnt like it that much. very thick chocolate, didnt care for the ice cream flavor. we should have gotten the creme brulee). overall the food was very good and presented well.
author: Brianna N.

description:
I am so glad that my friend and I decided to wait 30 minutes to get seated here even though we were starving. Definitely listen to the Yelpers and make a reservation, this is a small restaurant and they are extremely timely with reservations. 

Now onto the food, I ordered the Wasabi Noodles with Angus Flatiron Steak. My mouth is watering right now as I remember what it was like, soooo delicious. The noodles had the kick of wasabi but not overpowering to the point where you need to be drinking water, the steak was tender. 

For dessert we had the Mango Tapioca and Coconut Creme Brulee with Passionfruit. Both were probably the best desserts that I've had in SF by far. That creme brulee is to die for and was probably the best I ever had. 

Definitely putting this on my list of restaurants to come back to!
author: Shannon W.

description:
Optimally I would give The House a 3.5, 3 seems a little too harsh but a 4 is over-complimenting. 

I got the Kurobuta pork chop, calamari ahi tuna tartare, tried some of the sea bass and had the chocolate cake. Everything was delicious, but nothing was particularly memorable. The ahi tuna and chocolate cake were probably the only two dishes that were worth their prices. I also had some of the lychee iced tea, which was literally  just a single lychee in a glass of iced tea. Nothing special. 

All in all, I wouldn't say that The House is a must-try. It's good for groups (make sure you make a reservation though!) and a pretty casual restaurant with decent food for exorbitant prices. I'd probably go again, but not often.
author: Alice W.

description:
OMG....the food here is Outstanding!  I went here with my girlfriend on a whim and with no reservations.  They originally told us about a 45 minute wait so they took my number and we went to a bar next door.  Before I could even finish 1 beer they call me and tell me they have a table ready!  Awesome!  We started off with the ahi tuna tare tare and the charred octopus salad with fried pork skin.  The tuna was good and had a nice spice to it, but the real hitter was the charred octopus salad!  That thing was amazing!  It's basically a lot of finely sliced veggies thrown together with octopus and chicharron in a light vinaigrette - everything complemented everything else so well - the tanginess, the textures, the slight hint of spice - soooo good.  It's probably the only other salad (next to my mom's chinese chicken salad) that I would completely fill my belly on and be totally satisfied.  

So, naturally with a good start like that, I was extremely excited for main course.  I ordered the flank steak over wasabi noodles.  Sounded a little odd at first and like it wouldn't go together, but boy was I surprised.   I had ordered it medium rare, and it came out that way!  I hate the places that ask you how you want it, just to get a dry, overcooked, tasteless waste of meat.  Anyway, the two just went together beautifully - the meat was tender and the noodles were tasty, slightly spicy and complemented the meat well.  I'd say this is probably the only dish I've ever had that incorporated noodles and steak on the same plate and it blew me away.  

My girlfriend ordered the pork chop - not as good as what I had, but still awesome.  The chop was cooked medium (chef's recommendation) and I don't think I've ever tried a juicier pork chop.  There wasn't a single millimeter of meat that wasn't tender and juicy.  

The House has certainly jumped to the top of my list as one of the best restaurants in the Bay Area and possibly the world!
author: Karl D.

description:
I've been going to House for years (even back when they had their spot on 9th and Irving) and it remains one of my favorite spots in the City. The food is well presented, always tastes good, and priced reasonably. I'm never disappointed. Here are some of my favorites:

Tempura lake beans - I always order this to start; a mound of crispy friend beans with a tasty ginger soy dipping sauce.

Warm wasabi house noodles with angus flatiron steak - I like this dish just for the noodles more so than the sliced steak.

Grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy - Buttery, moist fish that melts in my mouth (it comes with rice, but the waitstaff usually lets me substitute their garlic noodles in its place).

Kurobuta pork chop with pomegranate currant sauce - One of the best pork chop dishes I've had; meat was very tender and juicy, but the sauce was a delicious surprise.

Angus ribeye steak, housemade teriyaki sauce, toasted garlic butter - Super flavorful with the teri sauce; meat is tender but can sometimes be a bit on the fatty side (but I like that).

The place is rather small so I'd recommend always making reservations. Parking can be tricky because of its location in the heart of North Beach, but I always find a spot in the parking lot on Vallejo and Stockton.
author: Rick T.

description: Came here for a belated Valentines celebration with the gent. It was the best Valentines dinner! Also my 1st Valentines Day dinner ever. But that's beside the point. The House is sooooo yummy. Everything was just so perfect. The fried artichoke hearts were tasty. The scallops were divine! The gent ordered the Sea Bass with ginger soy-- Amazing. I ordered the Ahi Tuna, wonderfully seared! We were so lucky to have gotten there near closing, at our time of reservation, after finding thee most awesome parking spot. Everything fell into place this day. I think the fact that things went so smoothly, the food tasted even better. And the waitress was very sweet and honest when it came to what to order.
author: Krystal A.

description: i was incredibly underwhelmed by the quality of the food.  the dishes lacked of any unique flavors.
author: Mike M.

description:
Hip little spot in North Beach. 

The staff was able to change our reservation last minute, so that was pleasing. It's true - it's a fusion spot - not traditional by any means. 

It's a great place to share lots of dishes. The decor is somewhat simple, not too overwhelming aesthetically. 

Note: Super hard to find parking!
author: Drea B.

description:
My favorite restaurant in San Francisco currently. 

I have never had anything I didn't like here.  I never do, but I would even order fish here, that is how well they do everything they prepare.  If I want a knockout meal when I have guests in town I take them here.  Consistently great, not just good.  

I've come for lunch and dinner many times, quality is always there.  Lunch is a better value and usually less of a wait, if any, so if you are rushed for time do lunch during the week. 

My personal favorites: scallops, kobe beef mango salad, curry noodle chicken, sea bass.  

Go to this place now. 

I love you House.  xoxo.
author: Mike I.

description:
Food: 
-scallops were damn good 
-Filet was great
-Chilean seabass not bad at all (I'm typically not a huge seafood fan anyways)
-Chocolate cake was rich and delicious 

Overall, food would be a 4/5 stars 

Location was is kind of busy, but that's fine. You'll probably need to taxi.  That's what we had done. 

Service was good.

Make reservations. We got seating next to the window and there was a line of people outside and people starring in at what we're eating. I kind of hate this and would want more intimacy and privacy at a restaurant as nice as The House. If I'm going to dinner or on a date with someone I want to feel like it's just us not us + everyone else waiting in line watching my every bite.
author: Suzie B.

description: This place!!  I keep ordering fish dishes at places that have no idea how to cook fish, but THIS place!  They are masters at cooking their fish.  Got the sea bass, and it was so juicy, perfectly flaky, and MELTED in your mouth.  PERFECT.  The dish also came with some tasty garlic noodles and garlic green beans!  To be honest, the sauce was a littttle too salty on the garlic noodles, but the fish more than made up for it.  Really decent proportions.
author: Lily N.

description:
I came here for a friend's birthday last night.  Now, it's not that this place is bad, but I don't really understand the hype everyone's said about it.  It's ok, but it's nothing special.  And I dunno, I don't know if $26 for a pork chop is really "reasonably" priced.  I was expecting something more imaginative, more...infusiony.  I got a porkchop, some mashed potatoes, and 2 asparagus spears.  Really?  That's it?  Sure, the sauce was ok, but it was a little too buttery for my taste....and nothing super inventive (i.e. I've had this before years ago).  The boyfriend got the sea bass since everyone seemed to be raving about it.  It's sea bass, you can't really mess it up...but that was about it.  They had sauteed green beans.  Really?  Because we can't do that at home ourselves.

Additionally, we had brought a cake for our friend.  I'm totally cool with a cake cutting fee.  We had brought a candle and had wanted our friend to make the first cut.  Apparently we're required to use THEIR candle and they won't let us cut it ourselves.  They had to cut it.  Ok...kind of weird, but whatever.  I mean, less mess for me, but I thought it was weird that the waitress went off about how we couldn't bring our own candles.  Just tell me that once and don't make a big deal about it.

Overall, not impressed and will not be making my way here again.
author: Quynh-An P.

description: We started going to our office holiday dinner here 3 years ago and now I am no longer aloud to change where we plan to go. The food here is always excellent. The scallops that are typically on the special are a favorite and even though there are only 6 of us we have to order enough for every one to have lots of this appetizer. Everything we have tried on the menu has been wonderful. I personally had the black cod with miso this last time around and I am still thinking about it. For dessert the creme brûlée  is always my favorite. Your really cannot go wrong here unless you want to be able to hang out at your table all night since they have a 90 minute limit on tables at dinner time.
author: Denise L.

description: I don't know what else I can say that would be different to the other 2300 reviews, but thanks Yelp. I think I ordered some of the tastiest dishes on the menu because of the reviews and recommendations here. The Sea Bass was amazing and the scallops special was easily the best prepared scallop dish I've ever had.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Pros: 
- Great food, excellent service (were really accommodating in being able to change my reservation because of a delayed flight)
- Sea Bass: best i've ever had
- Deep fried Salmon Rolls
- Decent price 

Cons:
- Parking was a bit of an issue (I ended up parking in a lot across from a police station) 
- The restaurant is a little cramped but nbd (you're there to eat after all)
author: Andrew S.

description: We came by on a Friday night with high expectations. We ordered the fried salmon roll and tuna tartare for appetizer, and the sea bass as well as steak with wasabi noodle for entree. Overall, the best item was the salmon roll. Everything else was good but not spectacular. The wasabi noodle was a bit salty, and the sea bass (even with the sauce) was nothing inspiring. We have had better food in other places. 3.5 stars overall.
author: Jeff N.

description: How to start, no clue but how to end is a must go! So go after u read this review. Haha.. anyways my sister first took me here a few years back and I can't stop coming. We go here for all sorts of occasion. Yes, its that good. My favorite dishes are fried calamari, deep fried salmon roll and grilled sea bass, oh and an extra 1-2 side of the house noodle for my son. He can have two plates to himself, I know. Everything else is great as well but those are my mains :)
author: Jeanette L.

description:
Best meal ever last night! We did a walk in and got lucky but I would definitely make a reservation as this place is small and they fill up fast. Here's what we had and seriously I was so happy the entire time we we're eating.
Wine: 
A bottle of Sparkling Rosé 
Appetizers:
-2 orders of the salmon spring rolls with a Chinese spicy mustard sauce (super crisp yet a light bite and the spice from the Chinese mustard was the perfect combo, the roll was literally filled with salmon!)
-mushroom soup with a drizzle of truffle oil (mellow but bright earthy flavor, all around really good soup.)
Mains:
-bbq pork shoulder in a miso kimchi broth served with a crispy pork skin chip and small bowl of rice (what I had, mind blowingly good, complex sweet flavor from the pork shoulder mixed in with the perfectly salted miso broth. I could eat that every day. EVERY DAY!) 
-Wasabi noodles with strips of beef (excellent amount of spicy-umami-bomb dot com flavor added with the perfectly cooked medrare beef.) 
-pork chop with a currant-pomegranate sauce served with mashed potatoes and 2 plantain chips (that sauce was like if you thought currants' and pomegranates' we're 2 separate fruits you're sadly mistaken because it marries these 2 flavors into 1 of the all time godly sauces of the world category. And then the pork chop...oh man can't even compare.)
Dessert:
-Chocolate Truffle cake with coffee ice cream topped with a caramel drizzle and cream sauce (what can I say, a chocolate diety has uttered a whisper and it made this. Maybe not like AMAZING so definitely a whisper rather than a loud roar. Still good though.)
-Coconut Creme Brulee with a passion fruit sauce (passion fruit sauce perfectly complimented the creamy taste and burnt sugary layer.) 
All in all I was smiling the whole time I was eating and the service was excellent! Definitely coming back.
author: Johnny L.

description: Most deliciously memorable steak! A small, quaint and romantic setting in North Beach. If you want to take someone special somewhere special where the food does not dissapoint and the meal is hearty then I recommend House. My only comment is that the servers can be a little less intimidating!
author: N J.

description:
If you walked right past it, don't be surprised. Very small place with big flavors.

We had Tuna BLT, tasted all the items, all flavors worked perfectly. Friends also had Salmon with rice and another with noodles. both plates were clean so they must have been great. Finished off with the chocolate cake, delish!

Great service, very attentive but not over board.
author: Amy J.

description: Second time coming here, I remember the food being good from the first time I came but coming here a second time made this a 4 star place for me. I had the porkchop this time and loved it. I love sweet and savory and that def made this dish. The sauce is fantastic and I am a sucker of flavorful food. The chop was cooked perfectly at med rare and came w/asparagus and mashed potatoes... Would def come back for that dish alone... Everyone else at dinner was impressed with their meals as well
author: Candice B.

description: Our first time here, we ordered the octopus salad, the ahi tuna tar tar, sea bass with wasabi noodles, and the mushroom rice with grilled prawns. The tuna was really good and flavorful! The octopus salad was so-so, I think we could' have done with a different appetizer. The sea bass was VERY tender and moist, and the wasabi noodles were bomb! The mushroom rice was interesting, although I was not a fan of the flakes on the rice and prawns. At first I thought there was something moving on my plate... totally creeped me out.. But other than that, this place was pretty good! I definitely would have to come back and try other dishes!
author: Stephen G.

description: The salmon rolls are a great appetizer. I always get the seabass that comes with noodles. Their mango tapioca is sweet and has a nice consistency different from pudding.
author: Jessica W.

description: Was never open to Asian Fusion places but this place has opened up my eyes/belly EVERY dish we tried was awesome. Scallops good, pork chops good, salmon good, octopus salad good, beer good. Yummy!!!!!!!!
author: Mad M.

description:
I celebrated my friend Sarabeth's birthday and I finally got to check out one of the restaurants on my list, The House. The House is a small restaurant nestled in North Beach. In a district full of cheesy and over-the-top Italian restaurants, it's a little funny to find a Asian fusion restaurant tucked in the corner of Grant Avenue and Broadway Street. But, it was absolutely delicious and I would highly recommend it to anyone.

I started the meal with the hamachi sashimi special of the day and the deep-fried chicken liver with greens. The hamachi was so fresh and literally melted in my mouth. The deep-fried chicken liver is a pass. I thought the breading was a little too thick and masked the taste of the chicken liver. I also got to try the crab cake and I loved it. The breading wasn't too thick and the crab filling was plentiful and fresh-tasting.

The House cooks fish perfectly. My favorite dish was the miso cod; second favorite was the salmon; and third favorite was the sea bass. I don't think I've ever had fish cooked so well in my life. The miso cod was one of the specials of the night and served with two uncut sushi rolls on top. The cod was almost buttery and the sauce complemented it perfectly. If you see the miso cod on the menu, order it! The salmon was a nice-sized fillet and very moist, served on top of bok choy. My sea bass was soft and came with a ginger soy sauce. While the sea bass was also very good, the cod and salmon were even better.

My friends raved about the pomegranate pork chop and it had a nice honey glaze on it. While tasty, the flavor reminded me of a piece of BBQ pork (char siu) that you can buy at Cantonese restaurants. I feel like I could eat a piece of char siu and be just as satisfied. The fish is better and I would definitely choose any of their fish dishes over the pork chop.

For dessert we ordered the chocolate cake, apple crumb pie and mango tapioca. All of the desserts were solid. I liked that the chocolate cake wasn't too heavy, but it still had a rich chocolate taste. I love that the apple crumb pie had big pieces of baked apples and the crumb topping was yum. The mango tapioca reminded me of a classic Asian dessert and I think it's my favorite out of the three. Honestly, we were all a little full (because the portions at The House are so generous) and couldn't even finish all of our desserts.

If you do go to The House, be sure to make reservations. The restaurant is really small and I saw tables being turned away at 8 p.m. on a Monday night! Don't let that deter you because I guarantee you'll love it!

Read more reviews and see photos on my blog: http://rbjello.wordpress.com/2012/03/12/asian-fusion-goodness-at-the-house/
author: Jackie T.

description:
This place was jumping so do everyone a favor and make reservations. The couple who came in behind us waited 45 mins.

Next, get the deep fried salmon roll with hot mustard app. One of the best things I have eaten in the city and Yes I have been to the Burger King on Market Street. So there.
