The flavors, texture, and colors just combined perfectly!

Mid way through the dinner, we decided to also order the tuna tartar. This would be the only dish we could've done without. I personally felt that it was under-seasoned and kind of bland. This is the only item I would not order again.

But back to the fabulous dinner! Everything else was truly amazing and of very high quality. We did not have too much room for dessert after 3 appetizers and 2 entrees between us 2. I would love to try some next time though!

I saw a mix of people here, with many Asians included. I'm gonna be real here. Most times when you read up on a place that is Asian, or Asian fusion, you arrive to find many many customers (but without an Asian in sight). The House is different. I saw Asian people here! The Chinese family that sat next to us spoke the language too, and appeared to have been here before. So no, this is not just good Asian/Asian fusion for white people. It's good for Asian people too. ABCs! Take your families here! They will be impressed!

Super excited to come back. Will definitely call in to make the reservation. And although I'm usually the type of try different dishes on a different visit, I will definitely order the sea bass again. The food was soooo amazing that I decided not to take off any points from the first phone encounter I had.
author: Elaine H.

description: My co-worker told me about this place. I was surprised how small it was and noticed the bad location. The food was good, but nothing to rave about. I was taken back by the rude waiter. She is the older asian lady with grey hair. I wanted to pay with a gift card that I won at work. She automatically said it didn't go thru, which was a lie. I had $150 on it and it had never been used. It annoyed her that I wanted to pay with an amex gift card. She wasn't helpful or accommodating.
author: Lisa S.

description:
The food was worth 5 stars, the quality that makes you close your eyes with each bite to better experience it. Scallops, mango beef salad, asparagus with sesame sauce, hamachi sashimi with avocado and a mix of baby capers, finely shredded cucumber and some other magic stuff on top. Amazing. Our waitress (tall, pleasant, young Asian) was fantastic. 

The missing star is for a reservation snafu,  or more precisely, how it was handled.  When I arrived I said my name and the small Asian woman went off, came back and then said, sorry no reservation for Robert. I never mentioned a Robert. I told her my name again: Pxxxxx Rxxxxx. She came back and said yes, she had found Rxxxxx. She showed me to the table. After we had ordered and received our appetizers she came to our table, clearly very stressed and stood over us asking in a somewhat accusatory tone whether there had been a mistake because the real Rxxxxx had arrived.  I told her that I had called the day earlier, that someone had returned my call and confirmed me that very morning. She was doubtful in a knitted-eyebrow, intense unwavering gaze manner and then blurted that it didn't make sense because they usually fill up a week in advance. 

I'm not even sure what she was thinking. That we had snuck in under a false name and fooled them? I told her my cell number and asked her to check the phone record so she could see that they had called me. She didn't take me up on it, but spent the next 15 minutes fussing nearby and being generally odd. That and the fact that it is a very small crowded restaurant and somewhat loud made it a little distracting. The food however was so amazing and quick that we ended up laughing the whole situation away with our waitress (tall, pleasant, young) who was embarrassed by the whole thing, particularly because as she pointed out, there were several open 2-tops around us. 

As we left the other woman glared at us again. It's hard to imagine what was going on for her. 

I'd go again, because everyone else was great and the food is incredible, but I'd wear my sphere of magical white light to protect me and ask to be seated far, far from the small, high-strung, shrewish woman.

Yes, of course I'm kidding about the magical sphere.
author: Kate G.

description:
almost 2,000 reviews with an average of 4.5 stars? that makes my review almost objective and not subjective, right?

this is my number 1 restaurant to eat at whenever i visit SF. i never order anything else except for the seabass. that perfectly cooked piece of fish and THAT sauce. i want to bottle it up and take it home! i tried to replicate it a home but have always failed miserably. the veggies (whether snap peas or chinese string beans) were perfectly cooked and still retained a crunch but had great flavor. you can order rice instead of noodles but the noodles are delicious. 

the servers and owner were amazing, as usual.

note: make reservations!!! you won't regret it. : P
author: Cat B.

description: I was blown away by just how good their food was. I came here with a group of girls for a bachelorette and the place is small. And, since I don't love fish/Japanes food usually, I was a little weary. However, I needn't fear because this place was awesome. We had steamed calamari, scallops, sea bass, mushroom rice with prawns, and fried green beans - and oh-my-gawd was everything amazing. I seriously didn't know I could like fish so much! I am still dreaming of the scallops, which were perfectly cooked. I would definitely come back here again - it's probably good I live 6 hours away, otherwise I'd be here all the time!
author: Melissa H.

description:
Wow!  Talk about exceeding expectations!  I had never heard of this place and it's not in a trendy spot like the Mission or Hayes Valley, but this is easily one of the most delicious and flawlessly executed meal I've had in months.  

(1) Charred baby octopus and crispy pork skin salad.  Very tasty.  The salad is kind of like a cole slaw style cabbage and carrot salad, but the baby octopus was cooked perfectly tender with a nice char that added extra flavor.  

(2) Pork chop with pomegranate currant sauce.  HOLY @#$!#.  I could eat this every night for the rest of the year.  Everyone knows how hard it is to make a good pork chop, but this was absolutely 100% perfectly cooked.  Meat was tender and juicy and well seasoned.  If it weren't for the sticky sauce, I would have picked it up and gnawed the meat off the bone.  

(3) Sea bass with noodles.  PERFECT.  We Asians tend to prefer our fish on the rare side, so I'm always grumpy when "Western" restaurants overcook the fish.  Not here.  Fish was soft and tender and melted in your mouth.  Noodles were thick and delicious and slightly chewy.  

This place is tiny, so be sure to have reservations.  But holy crap, if I'm going to get obese, I want to get obese on this food.
author: Matt Y.

description:
The eternal question: sea bass or black cod?

I vote for the cod. You'd expect the sea bass to be a fattier fish, but the cod is by far more buttery and flaky. If you really can't stand California rolls, though, either find someone at your table who does, or else pick something else because -- to its credit -- the restaurant doesn't shirk on the sushi portion.

The sea bass comes with more distinctive sides, and it's a meatier, more robust filet. Still good, but if you're expecting the sort of fluffy, lightly-grilled whitefish you sometimes get at other restaurants when you order sea bass, go with the cod.

Everything else on the menu -- and I really to mean everything -- is terrific, and the restaurant's high rating is absolutely deserved. I especially like the chicken livers and the calamari.
author: Albert L.

description: Over hyped, I really expected a much better quality food. We went there during the week, they weren't that busy so we were seated instantly. The waitress was OK with a hint of attitude, she tried her best though. The food wasn't as tasty as it should be, and extra greasy. On a side note, and what really turned me  off not being kids friendly, No kids menu whatsoever, I order the simple chicken breast but got charges for it as a while entree even though we didn't get the side or the sauce. Please reconsider having a simple kids menu as we understand that you vast majority of patrons are adults.
author: Shadi K.

description: Wow, I'm not a foodie but the food here was delicious! I was blown away. Parking may be a challenge!
author: Michael J.

description:
birthday dinner #3
3.5

we were pretty much set on ordering from the menu but as we were about to order they said the specials and everything went out the window.. they had so many specials offered it was hard to decide

everything ordered were specials except dessert:
-tempura soft shell crab w spicy cold bibim (thin wheat flour) noodles: i liked this a lot and the cold noodles were refreshing

-seared scallops topped w microgreens: i haven't had scallops in a long time and thought these were pretty good

-miso black cod topped w crab avocado rolls and fried plantain: there was bok choy under cod.. i liked the fish and it was cooked perfectly but the rest of the dish was ok, i wouldn't order this special again

-halibut w mashed potato and cauliflower topped w julienned fried yams: my friend said their halibut was overcooked and compared it to a rock. they like the mashed potato though

-coconut creme brulee w passionfruit puree: this was good but i like a thicker sugar crust so you can hear it breaking w the spoon

-mango tapioca: nice and light, i'd get this again

.. and I washed my dish down w lychee black tea which was good.

i'd come back to try their reg menu
author: Raquel T.

description:
Happened to end up in Chinatown/Little Italy while we were sight-seeing and totally relied on Yelp's app to find a place to eat near where we were standing.  Based on the reviews, we headed toward The House and were not disappointed!  

Salmon Rolls, Wasabi Noodles, and the Chicken Salad were all highlights.  Food was all extremely fresh and delicious and prices were very reasonable.   We were also impressed with how friendly and quick the service was.  Would totally recommend The House if you are anywhere near it!
author: Valerie M.

description:
The atmosphere and service was meh but the kitchen is on. point.

I heeded Yelpers' advice and ordered the sea bass entree and it was perfect.  The filet is soft and thick with a salty, buttery charred crust.   When I had the first bite my head tilted back, my eyes closed, and I almost fell out of my chair.

For appetizers we had the deep fried salmon rolls and the oysters.  Both were also stupid delicious.
author: Benjamin K.

description: Been here since 1999...I love their Chilean Sea Bass and Garlic noodles and Filet dish.  The have great selections of appetizers, wine and cocktails. Its a small venue, so reservation is a must.
author: JOY R.

description:
Like many other great eateries here in the city, The House is literally like eating at someone's house. There isn't much seating available so make sure to make your reservations ahead of time.

We came here for a friend's birthday on a Sunday night and yes, it was a full house. Everything we ordered was fairly good if not delicious. For starters we had the salmon rolls which were fried in wonton wrappers and served with a hot chinese mustard. I'm not a big fan of hot mustard so I thought this dish was ok. The calamari and tuna tartare were both good.

For our main courses, most got the sea bass, but I got the cod which was an excellent decision on my part. I tasted the sea bass and definitely liked the melt in your mouth cod better. Sea bass has a tougher meat. The cod came with a bed of greens and sliced california rolls.

I would like to come back to try the halibut with mushroom orzo. This restaurant is definitely on the higher-end fusion side, so do expect to pay $30+ per person. Worth it though!
author: Stine H.

description:
Not as good as I remembered it when I went way back when but it was familiarly good. I liked the wasabi noodles with the flank steak. I had my steak medium rare and it was tasty, although I would have preferred to have it sliced thinner. I tasted the pork belly and it too was pretty good with a good helping of meat and vegetables. The flavors melded in pretty well and there was a good balance between sweet and savory. The tuna tartare was delish. It was fresh and the wonton chips added good crunch and flavor to the entire dish. The place was filled up at 6 pm (an hour too early for me to eat) but due to a concert at 9, we had to get reservations way early. 

Perhaps my palatte had changed a bit- I did like the meal but I did not find it superb. Maybe another dish another time? There were many other dishes that seemed appealing such as the sea bass and crab cakes. 

Definitely reserve seats in advance, the place is very popular and seating is sparse-it's a teeny place. Parking is a pain so get there way early to have sufficient time to park. Prices are on the higher end and portions run on the larger scale. Our waitress was nice and helpful.
author: Laurel P.

description: I came here expecting a lot out of the food. Parking sucks so bad here, you should come 40minutes to an hour earlier to find parking, especially around dinner time. My boyfriend had made reservations at 8pm but we weren't seated until 15-20 minutes later, which is surprising since we already made a reservation. The place is a bit small and cramped, but the seabass lives up to its hype. the seabass was flavorful and the sauce to dip it in was my ultimate favorite. The noodles were chewy and flavorful as well as the string beans. I liked every part of my dish. My boyfriend had the warm wasabi noodles with the flatiron angus steak, which was a bit on the spicier end, but the noodles were a larger portion than mine and just as chewy. The medium rare steak was cooked perfectly, but I definitely enjoyed my dish more. We ordered oysters as a starter, but it wasn't fresh and let me down. The sauce to dip the oysters with was too spicy for me so I didn't enjoy that either. We ended our meal with the coconut creme brulee with mango puree. I didn't like the sourness of the mango puree mixed with the sweet coconut creme brulee, but the custard part was delicious and just the right sweetness. The only thing I didn't like about it was that the sugary part was just a tad bit burnt compared to what I would have liked. I definitely want to return and try the other dishes.
author: Amanda C.

description: Across the street from the oldest bar in San Francisco is a small restaurant with people waiting for hours to weeks to eat there. The menu changes often, ingredients are fresh and the combinations interesting, wines are by the glass, and the beer selection is small but select. We had lobster tempura salad, clams in spicy broth with grilled bread, grilled prawns with spicy mushroom rice, dumplings, seared ahi tuna with rice and bok choy, and a perfect grilled octopus salad (so tender). The decor is simple, the white paper placemats had a little house punched out of them in the bottom center. Great Asian fusion food.
author: Greg M.

description:
What can I say about a fantastic restaurant that nearly 1000 other people haven't already said?  Nonetheless, I loved this place enough that I had to write a review. I am not a fan of Asian fusion at all, but even I highly recommend The House!  Loved the unique food -- they didn't try too hard to try to stretch an asian dish to make it crazy fancy and call it "fusion."  Instead, they has a great balance between East and West styles of cooking and ingredients, creating dishes the way fusion should be done.  Every single menu item our party had was delicious, and the staff is incredibly personable.  

Easy to miss and hard to find... don't trust your GPS when trying to find it.  Definitely go, soon!
author: Carol L.

description:
The House is good... I just don't think it is super amazing great.

We got the soft shell crab, tuna tartar, and the miso cod special. Everything was cooked really well and the food was delicious. Service was ok, they seemed a bit off but it was fine. Prices are what you expect for this type of food but I found it a bit pricey   (we ended up paying around 25-30 per person in the end--keep in mind we got 2 apps and a main).

All in all, a good place to go for a nice meal but be prepared to wait (restaurant quite small--they don't take reservation for small groups) and to pay a bit more.
author: Jennifer W.

description: We were really looking forward to experiencing The House based on Yelp reviews.  While the food was good, the atmosphere was crowded, bland and simplistic.  The service was good but we felt VERY rushed through the entire experience.  No relaxing and enjoying a meal here!  Boom, Zip, Bam!  Get in, get served, get the heck out!  Disappointing.
author: Gregory C.

description:
If they have their roasted truffle cauliflower as a special. GET IT. 

Delicious. Mouth. Explosion.
author: Beverly T.

description: Make reservations days in advance, we called the morning of and the first avail was 930pm! But the food was great! The wasabi noodles and crab cakes were fantastic and service was great. Vegetarians be warned - only 1 option was available and tasted ok until I added the sriracha sauce, then it tasted much better! Enjoy!
author: Mansi S.

description:
Thanks Dru C.  You did not steer me wrong w/ your review about The House.  I'm so jelly of SF folk that you can dine here whenever you want.  I loved our dinner so much!  The friends I brought here also were big fans. It was a perfect dinner.  

We had the deep fried salmon roll - amazing.  That spicy mustard sauce was perfect to cut the richness of the deep fried goodness. 

Scallop appetizer special - who can go wrong w/ scallops.  We had 3 on a plate and it was perfect. 

I ordered the rib eye.  Wow.   This thing gets the attention of men.  Literally.   A table of 4 guys turned and stared at my plate and asked what I ordered.  It was juicy and cooked perfectly.  I loved the roasted cauliflower it came with too.  

My friends had seabass and the pork chop.  I'm so glad we all shared in all of our bites.  Amazing food.  Can't wait to go back. 

TIP: Be prompt with your reservation as we were 5 minutes late as we were having a drink down the street at 15 Romolo and they gave up our table.  We ended up having to wait about 40 minutes - which they comped us an appetizer.  Very nice gesture.
author: Lisa V.

description:
This is very good asian fusion, and good value.  There are a lot of restaurants that cost more and don't taste as good.  

I like the scallops for an appetizer, which is usually one of the specials and not on the menu.  A very good way to start the meal. 

I'm only okay with the deep fried salmon rolls.  Sometimes the salmon is overcooked, and also salmon tends to taste a lil fishy. 

The ribeye is delicious!!  Very tender and flavorful.  So satisfying. This is my #1 choice.

The sea bass is YUM.  Melts in your mouth, and goes well with the noodles.  I also like the veggies too.  This is my #2 choice.  

I tried the cod as well, which was the special of the day.  That was okay, I'd still prefer the sea bass over the cod.  

For dessert, the mango tapioca pudding is my favorite!! We ordered 2!!  It is light and refreshing, great way to end a great meal.   We ordered the 2nd after we also had the creme brulee (that was just okay it was too soft for my taste), the chocolate brownie, and the apple pie.  Yup, that good. 

I can't wait to go to The House again!!!
author: Julie Y.

description:
Took my wife here for our anniversary dinner and without any exaggeration...the dinner was the best I have had in San Francisco in a very long time.  Everything is great and the service is incredible!  Don't believe me...go and find out for yourself!
I going back again and again!
author: Dan Z.

description:
Worth the wait!  Food is excellent.  I had the sea bass - cooked to perfection.

The restaurant is small and, of course, parking is a bit of a challenge in this neighborhood.  The service was on the slow side (not sure if they normally are short on staff or if maybe someone had called in sick that night?).  In any case, management apologized and appys were on them.
author: Clara S.

description: Wow! What a quaint little spot! Friendly servers... Brisk service. From the ahi Tartar small plate to the Kobe Ribeye to the Coconut Creme Brule... Next time I will bring friends to share this place with
author: Matthew K.

description: Best kept secret in sf. Make reservations and go. You don't want that line. Get sea bass.
author: Brad T.

description: Came here for the first time a few weeks ago.  I was really impressed.  There were 3 of us, so we got a variety of appetizers and entrees, all of which were delicious and unique.  I highly recommend the sea bass!  The prices were reasonable for the quality of the food.  The service was also great.  My biggest complaint is the wait time (even with a reservation) and the fact that the inside of the restaurant is so small and cramped.  While we were waiting, there was nowhere for us to stand without getting in the way.  Overall, I'd highly recommend this place and would come back!
author: Katy R.

description:
Came with my mom and boyfriend at the recommendation of my sister. I've always been wary of fusion food. But this does a great job at bringing asian flavors into dishes without being overly forced or gimmicky.

FOOD: Started with chicken livers/baby greens and mussels. Entrees had pork chop with pomegranate/currant sauce, sea bass, and lamb chop special. The mussels I could pass on next time. The chicken liver with salad was great. All the entrees were delicious - the winner being the pork chop (and I don't even like sweet sauces with meat usually). And the boyfriend liked the sea bass even though he's usually not into fish.

ENVIRONMENT: Tiny! Gotta make those reservations. And because of the coziness, it gets a little bit loud. But nicely decorated with photographs.

SERVICE: Friendly and prompt. They also had a lot of specials, so props to the waitress for remembering all of it.
author: Kailyn G.

description:
Hard to find bc of the scaffolding blocking the sign. Pretty small, but decent seating arrangements. MAKE A RESERVATION, that places fills up fast. Went last week for a early v-day present, thank goodness we came on 2/13 instead of the day/weekend of. I'm sure we wouldn't have got a table. Super happy to get our own table and not have to share it. 

Dress attire is pretty trendy, guys: slacks, button-up; gals: dinner dressy, not clubbing/lounge.

Parking is hard around that area in general. And all of the side streets are on hills, so try to take public transit. There are lots of bus stops, plus its always packed with people around that area, late into the night. 

What we ordered: 

Drinks: Ordered the wrong beer, meant to order Echigo beer, but ended up with a different beer that was dark but tasted light, not heavy. Name??

Appetizers: Oysters with thai chili salsa, the sauce was perfectly spicy. I think there may have been mango in it?? I don't recall the exact title, but it was great!

Entree 1: Warm wasabi house noodles with flat iron steak. Noodles were soooo flavorful! The wasabit was not overpowering at all.

Entree 2: Kurobuta pork chops with pomegranate currant sauce. The sauce was delicious! 

Would definitely come here again to try all of the other seafood dishes, and specials! Wish we could have stayed longer
author: Jay C.

description:
Believe the reviews and all the hype about it. Asian Fusion here is about as good as it gets in San Francisco! I've been to The House about three times throughout the past few years. I have to say, this place is truly a great place to eat. I came here on a Sunday and calling in for a reservation about 3 hours before dinner and they only had two slots available; 5:00PM and 9:30PM! 

Food: The most recent meal I had here included their Sea Bass (with Garlic Ginger Noodles), Halibut (with Coconut Curry), Deep Fried Salmon Rolls, and Wasabi Noodles (with Flat Iron Steak)!!! Oh my goodness, every single dish was so fresh and amazing. All of them are worthy of being repeatedly ordered during every visit but my absolute favorite was the Sea Bass along with the flavorful noodles. The Sea Bass was superior in freshness, flavor, and display. That specific dish costed about (~$28) and was well worth it! 

Atmosphere: The place is a bit small and gets loud when it starts getting packed. Nonetheless I like the atmosphere very much because it was very easy to hold conversations and enjoy the food. Lighting was good and made the gourmet food look even better! 

Service: As always, they always announce the specials before you get to look into the menu itself! The service was overall good as they came constantly to refill water and ensure that everything is going well! 

In conclusion, The House is an absolute favorite and a great place to eat with up to four of your favorite people! I will definitely come back when time permits! Cheers to consistently doing a good job, House!
author: Jonathan L.

description:
3 Stars SOLELY based on today's lunch experience.  Otherwise, it's a freaking 4-5 Stars place in my book.

Service was good as usual.  Today I decided to FINALLY try the sea bass with HIGH anticipation.  $20 sea bass is not a bad deal at all for lunch!  Presentation was beautiful as usual.  Pretty good portion of sea bass.  Nice crunchy greenbeans, and flavorful noodles on the side.  Sea bass was cooked with slight crunch on the surface, flakey in the middle, LOOKS GREAT! 

HOWEVER, the dish was EXTREMELY oily.  Sea bass wasn't seasoned enough because I'm supposed to dip it in the sauce that it came with.  However, the sauce was overly salty.  Even a very light dip was pretty overwhelming.  The fish was probably seared with lots of oil, and remember, sea bass is an oily fish.  Everything came out to be super oily.  

Pretty disappointed this time.  I guess I'll just stay away from the sea bass....  WHAT?!  Yep, sounds like non sense, but I like the flank steak WAY better.
author: Gigi T.

description:
THE #1 Asian fusion restaurant in SF. Trust me I'm a lawyer. Hah. Ok no really, I first tried this place in 2007, and most recently New Years 2011, and it's been able to retain its quality through the years. 

RECOMMENDATIONS/TIPS
1. Any seafood appetizer really, but especially the Maine Crab Cake or their specials. 

2. If you're on a date with a girl (or guy) who aren't planning on testing their waist elasticity for the night, try 2 appetizers and split the entree. More flavor exploration and diversity for a little less dinero.  

3. Grilled Sea Bass. F*@% yes. This dish generates serious word of mouth. And while it's in there, it just literally melts away in these perfect flakes that disappear much too quickly. I never knew fish could be this tender outside of the raw variety. 

4. A Riesling to go with that Sea Bass. 

5. Don't count on trying to walk in for a seat. Make reservations at least 2 days beforehand if you want a decent time

CONS
- Don't expect anything service-wise past semi-attentive inquiries about your enjoyment of the food and making sure your water is filled.
- Desserts don't quite match up to the quality of the main courses  
- Good luck trying to find decent parking in North Beach. I usually end up at the garage @ Vallejo & Powell.

PROS
- Generally amazing quality for only $$ prices
- Ambience is perfectly tuned for what kind of meal you'd expect there. Not too dark so you don't have to squint to see your buddies, but also dim enough for romance. 
- Speaking of romance, I saw McDreamy here once. I think he helped get my GF in the mood. Thanks McDreamy...I think.
author: Jing X.

description:
When I was at working looking for a new place to eat for lunch, The House was one of the first on the Yelp search.  I said to myself, 4.5 stars out of 2,400+ review?  Challenge accepted.

Before showing up we had thought that it would be hard to find seating since the venue is relatively small.  Upon arriving however at 12:30 we were able to get a seat almost immediately and handed menus.  The waiter mentioned the specials for the day and gave us sometime to think it over.

The menu is simple but would definitely like to try everything on there.  I ordered the Curry Chicken Noodle and the Fried Calamari.  The Calamari obviously came first and was good, nothing too special about it.  That all changed when the actual food came.  It looked just like the pictures and the portion size was large.  Not only was the presentation great, the food was also very flavorful without being overbearing or too oily.  By the end of the meal we were all very full but kept eating until we finished every bite because it was that good.

Although this place is listed with "$$$" each noodle plate is only about $11-$15 which is completely affordable given their portion sizes.

In the end I would highly recommend you to try this place as I will definitely be back until I've tried everything on their menu.  Service was good, venue was nicely appointed and very intimate.  I try not to give 5 stars but this place definitely lived up to the reviews and deserve the full 5 stars.

A must try!
author: Zhen C.

description:
I very scarcely give out 1 star reviews and dislike reading/writing rant-y reviews. I especially hate giving well-acclaimed businesses such a poor review. However, The House has truly earned this rating in my books. 

Disclaimer: This review is based purely on the SERVICE, not the food. I've never, in my years and years of foodie dining, experienced such disrespectful and insolent service. 

In a city filled with a plethora of highly calibered restaurants competing neck-to-neck with each other, it's of the utmost importance to differentiate your restaurant not only based on the food but also on the service. 

Here's the story in a nutshell: 

It was my bf's and my 5 yr anniversary dinner celebration and we had chosen The House as our celebratory dinner for the night. We made reservations for a party of 2 at 7pm. We were driving to SF from a business conference in Palo Alto that day and got stuck in quite a bit of traffic. At 7pm, we had arrived in the North Beach hood but were looking for parking (btw - insanely hard to find one here!). I called the restaurant at precisely 7pm to let them know that we will be ~10-15 min late and are currently searching for parking/if they have any parking recommendations. The waiter replied simply with an insolent "Your reservation will be given up if you do not arrive in 10 minutes." When I hung up the phone, it was 7:03pm. We scrambled for parking in the meantime and arrived into the restaurant at 7:11pm. There was a long line in front of us that the maitre'd was tending to so by the time it was our turn, the time was 7:15pm. Please note, the exact timing is being highlighted to prove the utter ridiculousness of the service. The matre'd had a brusque and ridiculously rude attitude while telling us that she cannot seat us as we are more than 30 minutes late to our reservation. At this point, I whipped out my phone and showed her the exact time of "7:15pm" and mentioned if anything, we are ONLY 15 min late and we were waiting in the line for almost 5 min, so we still technically made it in 10 min. Without getting into any more excruciating detail, she asked us to wait 2 hours for a table or "get out" (yes, "get out" is quoted verbatim). 

There wasn't an apology or a sincere "We're sorry. We're just so booked and had to give away your reservation but we do hope you can dine with us in the future." That would still be hard to stomach given that it's our anniversary dinner and we called ahead to notify them that we'll be there. However, it's INFINITELY better than how we were treated. 

When we're prepared to spend $100+ for a romantic dining experience at your restaurant, the least you can do is provide us with some basic respect. 

So of course, after we were asked to get out on that busy Saturday night, we panicked for a bit and then managed to score a reservation at Jardiniere in Hayes Valley at 7:30pm. Given that we had to get from North Beach to Hayes Valley in less than 15 min amidst the traffic from the ballet and opera performances, we were a bit late again. And when I called Jardiniere to inform them (obviously panicking after the crazy House experience that had just ensued), they were so accommodating, friendly and held our reservation for us (feel free to reference my review of Jardiniere). And yes, they were equally busy as the House that night. 

So moral of the story - there are numerous great restaurants in this city that have fabulous service and fabulous food. Please head to one of them instead of The House.
author: Priya S.

description:
Hands down the easiest restaurant to review - Every single dish ordered was delicious and left us wanting more!

We were a group of 7 - had to wait for a table, but the waitress will give you a buzz  on your cell phone a few minutes before your table is ready (how cool :))...so we walked over to Steps of Rome to get a drink.  I'd definitely recommend making reservations if you're heading over for dinner on a weekend....the restaurant isn't very big so space is limited - ambiance is cozy - good for both date nights and a night out with friends!

We ordered all the Starter Specials our waitress mentioned (sorry none of this is on their menu):
-Toro Nigiri - totally melts in your mouth
-Grilled Octopus - the octopus was the perfect texture (not chewy) and I wanted to lick the plate cuz the sauce was to die for
-Scallops - heavenly, I seriously could have had a plate of these succulent scallops all by myself - sux I had to share :P
-Beef tartar - super interesting presentation - the tartar nestled on a perfectly crisp toast and a gorgeous radish, the taste matched the presentation.

For our main courses:
-I had the Halibut with clams (Special that night) - omg perfection on a plate - don't know how they incorporated okra in the dish, but yaaay for that! 

What others had and of course I had to sample a bite of every dish:
-Sesame soy glazed salmon in a bonito sake broth: since I definitely plan on going back there - this will be the dish I order, the sake broth was flavorful and the salmon was done just right and they serve the salmon on a bed of greans which makes it a perfectly balanced meal...
-Grilled ahi tuna with spicy mustard aioli - the best presentation ever - deserved all the oooooohs and aaaaahs cuz it was freaking tasty on top of that...
-Niman ranch pork chop - the pork was so tender; it had this amazing caramalized glaze and was so good 

Desserts:
Mango Tapioca - refreshing 
Chocolate cake with coffee icecream on the side - I was stuffed and still couldn't get enough of it :)

We devoured all this with 2 bottles of their Nigori.  

Overall - blown away and beyond satisfied! Worth every $$$ spent there! 

***side note:  they allow the use of only 2 credit cards for a group...so carry cash if you're splitting the bill and don't want to run to the ATM.
author: Bhavnak K.

description:
Date night with the significant other... the occasion? payday of course!

Came here because it was recommended by kat c., a fellow foodie who lives in SF, and I wanted to explore the food in SF more since I've exhausted the restaurants in the East Bay. 

TIP: Called in and got Reservations for 8pm, but was told if I tried to come earlier they would try to accommodate me. Came at 6pm and was seated almost immediately!

We order the Salmon Rolls for appetizer, split both the Sea Bass and Kobe Beef for entree, and had Fresh Peaches and Vanilla ice cream for dessert. 

The Salmon Rolls were SOOOOOO good. It's a must try! I could eat 10 more orders of those. I'm salivating just thinking about it...

The Sea Bass is so good, buttery, and melts in your mouth. The S.O. doesn't generally like fish, but thought it was really good as well. 

The Kobe Beef was a special, it was a perfect medium rare. Soft and delicate, but with full flavor. You can taste the quality in it!

The dessert was alright, but it was the perfect way to end the meal. 

I got the Lychee Black Tea to drink with my meal, but I should have just gotten wine. It was mediocre. 

Despite the fact that the Tea and the dessert doesn't deserve a 5 star rating, all the other elements really gives those stars back!

I can't wait to come back here!
author: Tien P.

description:
Double-ply toilet paper? You have my attention, House.

And my being impressed didn't stop there. Our team of 10 did a family-style meal, so I had the opportunity to try (hog?) lots of tapas and entrees. The tiny venue could be intimate -- or could be incredibly loud ... when you have a big, rowdy group like ours! But the careful presentation and solid wine list make it a place that would be appropriate for a date.

Highlights of the evening for me: the tuna app, rare sliced steak, and kobe steak. Everyone swears by the sea bass. But that was more like 4 stars for me. Overall, it's Asian Fusion at its best -- a great mix of influences, strong flavor, and some spice. Of the desserts, the fudge-y chocolate cake was amazing (when is chocolate not?). The blueberry cheesecake was a bit tart for my taste. The creme brulee had some salt topping it, which added a nice dimension to the dessert.
author: Christina G.

description:
I can't believe it's taken me so long to write a review of this place.  It's a special place for my wife and I, dating back to times even before we were married.  We've been there off and on for the past decade-and-a-half, and it's always been a delight.

The biggest compliment I can say is that they understand fusion food both conceptually and in practice.  Their menu isn't huge, but the stuff on there (with varying specials) is always well thought-out and fun to eat.  The pork chop is the king (if you have not tried it, this should be the first thing you order).  But their black cod, sea bass, and steak are all good.  My wife likes their risotto with shrimp, too.

The small plates are good, but honestly, I think it's the entrees that steal the show and keep us coming back again and again.

Don't forget to get the passionfruit creme brulee.  It's a good end-note to the meal...  think classic creme brulee but with a passionfruit shot to it that adds a tartness to balance out the sweetness of the carmelized sugar and custard.  I should mention that we've been there where it's been a little bit off (temperature issues / uneveness), but it's still something we can't help but order every time we're there.
author: Jeff L.

description:
Please take the Sea Bass off of your menu. And you need to do a better job of tasting the food before it leaves the kitchen, especially when it's being made before hand, referring to the mashed potatoes served with the rib eye. 

First off all, we were late to our dinner reservation and there were already three people ahead of us waiting for tables. But thankfully because we had reservations we were seated first before some others. BUT i had to go to the cashier and let the hostess know that i was late for me reservation and that we have arrived. BUT the hostess, had a rude attitude like "uh, ok." and looked at me with almost an annoyed look. 

oysters I recommend. the asparagus was served cold, and i do not think that was mentioned on the menu. they like to put SESAME SEEDS ON EVERYTHING! it's ok on a couple of signature dishes, but it can be overkill. 

the sea bass, don't get this. everything was super oily on that plate. the noodles and the green beans. oily doesn't mean seasoned. and the sea bass, i'm not sure it was fully fully cooked. it wasn't as flaky as i was expecting it to be, no real exciting reason to be savory. and the ginger soy sauce was so-so.

not a date place, especially when you're so close and be a part of your neighbors conversation. parking sucks. the food arrived pretty fast. we didn't have dessert because we couldn't even hear ourselves think.
author: Maureen M.

description: My favorite place in San Francisco. For sure take the scallops if those are on a special menu, and follow with wasabi noodles and grilled sea bass. Amazing!
author: Mitya V.

description:
They are unafraid of separating you from your dead presidents at The House, but these are happy transactions: we ambled in here with a group of twelve, keen on sharing family-style goodies of the Asian Fusion and New American persuasions, and though The House is aptly characterized as boutique sized, they made plenty of room for our hearty party and kept the good bites coming. 

Highlights included a light and tasty sea bass, delectable Kobe beef, Ahi tuna tartare with roasted nori chips, asparagus with roasted sesame dressing for some of our veggie diners, steamed mussels with garlic infused shrimp broth, and creative craft brews and summery wines on the flow. Fortunately, we managed to stick the landing with a creme brulee (featuring sea salt, a fair juxtaposition for creme brulee's typical exploits). In all, The House was a warm and delicious way to spend an evening. Frankly, that we found food as good as the company within said something to me. And that's enough to extend smiles beyond a transcendent meal itself.
author: Kevin N.

description: Love the food. The steak is to die for. The wait and space is not as desirable, but any place good is worth waiting for and cramming into.
author: Chloe L.

description: This is among the best restaurants in the us hands down. Can you say pork chop? Or even the swordfish is awesome
author: M C.

description: Best food and service in SF. Just make sure to make a reservation or you might not get in.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I've been to some high-end Asian fusion restaurants, but I think The House may top them all - and judging from the packed house that my fiancee and I arrived to on a Friday night, it's a pretty popular place to eat. Definitely call ahead of time (it doesn't have to be weeks in advance), or  you'll end up waiting for a bit - and there's not really a lot of space to stand if you're waiting. Service here is very quick, and the waitresses are on the ball with knowing the specials.

The food, for lack of a better word, was breathtakingly delicious. For appetizers, we had the oysters - of which I'm usually not a big fan, but the cilantro sauce added a dose of spice that really added another dimension to them. The kobe beef tartare and uni flatbreads were delicious as well. The beef was delicious on its own merits, but I really liked the uni on top of a piece of avocado - both are foods with smooth textures, and the flavors blend really well together. The entrees were great as well. I had the kurobuta pork chop; I'm usually not a huge fan of pork, but this was cooked to the right tenderness and wasn't overly fatty. It also came with a pomegranate currant, which was less fruity than anticipated (which was good) but added a slight twinge of sweetness to the dish. My fiancee had the miso grilled cod, which was perfectly cooked - the cod fell apart so quickly and was extremely tender. Lastly, the desserts - the Japanese-style pumpkin pie was fantastic. I can't pinpoint the main difference, but the natural sweetness of the pumpkin vs. the somewhat artificial canned pumpkin that is sold in the store was the main difference. The chocolate truffle cake was also delicious as well, particularly with caramel drizzled on top.

This is definitely one of my all-time favorites that I've been to. There are a lot of other interesting items on the menu that I'd like to try out sometime as well, and I do hope to come back when I'm in SF again.
author: Asuka N.

description:
We went here last night for a date. It was extremely busy and despite having a reservation (and arriving 10 minutes after the scheduled time) we waited about 15 minutes for a table. The service here is very attentive and professional, taking their time to answer all of our questions about the specials for that night. I had the Kobe special, which was somehow had a little too much fat for me, and my date got the pork chops that were DIVINE. These were juicy and moist and it melted in my mouth.

I'm definitely a fan and will be coming here again in the future.
author: Le D.

description:
The Grilled Sea Bass with Garlic Ginger Soy is a *MUST HAVE*. If you only go to this restaurant once, you need to order this dish.

Be sure to pay close attention to the server when they announce the specials of the day. I've been pretty impressed with every dish here and I typically order something off of the specials menu to share with the table.

Be sure to call ahead early to make reservations. If you don't have a reservations and you are a walk in, they will call your cell phone when your table is ready.
author: Lester W.

description:
We've lived in the neighborhood for 5+ years, but never bothered because of what it looks like with a crammed setting, a slightly average menu and long lines at the door.

Stopped by today since there weren't any people outside scoping out a table. We left our number for a reservation that was to be in "30 minutes" (more like 40 minutes). We walked down Columbus for a quick drink at Devil's Acre to kill some time.

-40 minutes later, we received a call.  The hostess said that our table for two was ready.  We said that we would be there in 7-10 minutes.  She said, "we can only hold the table for 5 minutes."  What? Most restaurants give a 10-15 minutes buffer for having a party wait 30+ minutes.
-We rushed up the hill to the restaurant, walked in and were seated to our table.

Food: -Good.  

-Octopus salad was good.
-Crab Cake was almost all filling and no crab (hello, it's crab season).  For the price, one would expect some crab inside what was basically a corn muffin.
-Sea bass was perfectly cooked.  No complaints.
-Steak with garlic noodles was fine.  Great temp on the steak.  Noodles no different than most in Chinatown or at Chubby Noodle.

Wine Selection: Poor.
Sake Selection:  OK
Beer Selection: Poor

Service: Awful

-No specials ever offered until we heard one of the many servers share with the table next to ours (after we finished our starters).
-RUSHED.  We felt like we were pressed to eat for the next customers that were hovering at the front door.  If I'm paying top price for average Chinese fusion, I shouldn't feel like I'm just a number.
-NOT ONE server asked how we liked any of our courses, sakes, wines or anything. No personality, since the clients are just numbers in a factory.

Ambiance: Horrible

-Bad acoustics.
-Bathroom needs an upgrade.

How does this place have a high rating?  Please tell me it's from those that haven't been exposed to what a dining experience  should be (low, average or high priced)! BTW, we paid $140+ for our meal. 

I suspect the high ratings are because it WAS a good option for Chinese "fusion" cuisine over a decade ago when there weren't any options for decent food in Chinatown.
author: Lana K.

description:
Tiny place that can accommodate large parties. Gotta love that. 

The staff are real pros who are not only efficient in serving our party of twelve family-style helpings of Asian goodness but who were also very helpful with respecting my vegan diet amongst a sea of carnivores. Bravo!

I am smitten with the tasty asparagus that had the best sesame dressing that I have tasted in a long time! They also whipped up the warm wasabi house noodles entree with tofu in lieu of angus flatiron steak as shown on the menu. Yum in the tum! 

The wine list had a nice roster of varietals that paired wonderfully with the menu. I must point out that my glass was never allowed to be empty as the staff were ready to top it off at all times. Yes, my heart is bursting with mad love right about now!

I would definitely have another feast here when I am in San Fran again.
author: Marcia M.

description:
Apparently they don't really understand the definition of a "reservation".  It means to reserve a table for you do you don't have to wait when you get there.  I made a reservation 4 days ahead of time, but when we arrived exactly on time, we had to wait another 30-40 minutes to get a table! I don't care how good your food is.  If you don't know how to manage simple reservations you don't know how to run a restaurant.  So even if you make a reservation prepare to wait anyway.  completely ridiculous.

Furthermore, the host did not even so much as apologize for the wait.  In fact, she simply asked for our name and didn't tell us anything for 40 minutes. 

The waitress also came out too early with our entrees, and literally took our appetizers away while we were still eating it.  

And the Wasabi noodles are WAY over-rated.  They aren't that good at all.  I could hardly taste what was "wasabi" about it.
author: David N.

description: Parking here is a beast, but worth the hassle. Each dish is made to perfection. Portion size is small, but that's how fancy restaurants serve their dishes. It's hard to get a seat, due to small restaurant, so go on an off peak day.
author: Tish A.

description: I Was so blown away by this place. Everything is unique and amazing (and I tried nearly everything on the menu). It's seriously top notch chef stuff here. I've traveled around the world and I really think I'd say this is the best restaurant I've ever been to.
author: David W.

description:
Wow! I'm so glad a friend recommended me to come here! I have to say that the service is pristine, the food delicious and the ambiance, well, given its small size, was fabulous.

The meals are well presented, definitely high quality food. 

I would suggest coming here if you have 4 or fewer people in the group.It's not suitable for large groups since space is limited.
author: Sophia S.

description: EAT HERE. you must get a reservation early though because its a really small place. cozy atmosphere with modern decor. the food and service was great. the halibut is my recommendation. their wasabi noodles were a dish that i'd never had before and really enjoyed!
author: Megan F.

description:
Slight negative: We had to wait about 25 to 30 mins past our reservation time.  This is likely simply a byproduct of their insane popularity and very small space. 

Funny:  For some reason, the door is locked on the outside.  The only way I could get in is if some nice person on the inside felt bad for me and opened the door.  I kept looking around for a camera that would be sending footage to a bloopers type show. 

Positives:  For our wait, they immediately brought over salmon rolls (amazing and on the house!). The wait staff was incredible and very helpful with suggestions on the menu.  I was torn between wasabi noodles/steak or sea bass. The waitress suggested I do the sea bass with the wasabi noodles, which is her go to meal there.  Awesome!  And they brought over the sauce that typically goes with the sea bass- suggesting that I dip instead of poor it over, so as not to mess up the taste of the wasabi noodles. Small detail, but definitely indicates that they know their food well and care about preserving it's integrity.

A must try!  I'm still salivating over the sea bass!
author: Amanda B.

description: The greatest Asian fusion food in the city!!! The rack of lamb is a special I had today and it was in my top 5 greatest lamb I have ever had. The steak and noodles was amazing as well. I will recommend this place to any Asian food lover. The line is worth the wait!
author: J Y.

description:
Wonderful date night spot. My husband and I arrived for dinner Thursday night at about 7pm without reservations. The wait was less than 10 min. The tables are really close but the setting is intimate.

About the food..... I had the highly recommended blackened cod which was cooked to perfection. My husband had the pork chop that was succulent and tender.

The staff was attentive, friendly and accommodating. We found the prices reasonable. We plan on returning again in the near future, plus I want to turn my friends on to this spot!
author: Taurus R.

description:
The value for the quality of the food and taste is seriously unbeatable.  My GF and I walked there for lunch after we toured Alcatraz...and the reviews are right, The House is simply the best. We arrived around 2pm on a Saturday and were seated right away.

We shared:
The Chinese Chicken salad...it wasn't the salad we saw as walked in with greens, but  it was so good.  The Chicken was the perfect temperature and the vegetables were very fresh.

The Shrimp and white bean dumplings were flavorful...but they were just steamed, believe they would have been better if they were pan fried with a slightly crunchy noodle.

The Wasabi noodles with Salmon...so flavorful...a very subtle wasabi flavor with a large perfectly cooked filet of Salmon.  Can't believe it was only $11.

I wish they would open "The House" in Seattle!
author: Brian A.

description: Cute little date place that has a great atmosphere and vibe. Simple no fuss place with tasty food. Call early to reserve the miso cod which is good. Its not amazing food but overall rates well in everything: food, atmosphere, location (though hard to find parking), service.
author: Debbie Y.

description:
This rating, without even setting foot in the door? Well, I *would've* included a food review if I could...

I called two weeks ago and made reservations for last night (Saturday) at 9pm. Called ahead about 8:40pm to let them know we were running late, and the woman who answered the phone revealed that she had no reservation for me at all. In the middle of the process of her making me repeatedly spell out my first and last name *and* give her my phone number twice, she kept saying, "Nope, can't find you!" (I mean, wouldn't it be obvious on first check of just two of those three details?) She sounded really annoyed, like she was doing me a favour, and said I couldn't dine there at all that night as they had no free tables. 

At this point I told her that that was fine, that we could obviously find something else, but that I would be putting on my Yelp! review that they'd "lost" my reservation. (Good thing we didn't actually get over there only to find we were outta luck!) Then she got quite rude -- "Miss, I *told* you, I don't *have* anything here for you! Do you want to eat here, or NOT?" 

Of course, her having just told me that there was no way for me to dine at the restaurant that night, I wondered aloud how I could possibly eat there if there were no tables... (I also mentioned that I'd be adding her rudeness on to the review.) At this point she got flustered, denied telling me they were full, and told me she was going to pass me on to the hostess (... but... but... if she wasn't the hostess, then why was she answering customer phone calls?) -- who told me I could come in at 10:15 if I wanted. That was a nice possible resolution, but we decided not to accept the offer, and went elsewhere instead. As a previous reviewer has said, there are too many great places to eat in this city without having to deal with this kind of pricey behaviour. 

Perhaps my mind will be changed when I eat the food -- but maybe even not, since I'm vegetarian: When I called to check about possible off-menu options (tons of places will rustle something up for you if you ask them nicely!), they said it would depend on what the chef had in that day; and when I responded that maybe I could call in on the day of or the day before, I was told (literally) "Oh, I wouldn't bother". 

Thanks, House. Thanks.
author: Simran T.

description:
Just a word for the wise, this place opens for dinner at 5:30. Don't show up earlier or you'll be greeted with a boot back out the other way. But I was in a rush to catch a flight out from SFO that night, so I figured I'd try to pull an early bird.

When ever I'm in the bay I try to make it here. This time, I had the usual, the pomogranate Porkchop. My friend the wasabi noodle and steak. And to start it off, the Eel rice where instead of being like sushi before, is more like a cream risotto now. In my opinion, it's a bit too rich now, with eel and cream sauce. 

But still same great place. No complaints as ever. And made my flight out with plenty of time.
author: Vince E.

description:
If you can deal with the claustrophobic space, which often has the frustrated waitstaff dipping and dodging to avoid colliding with seated customers, you are in for an incredible treat. This is the best seafood/asian fusion restaurant in the city. The cuisine is simply sublime. 

We started with the fried salmon rolls, which are far from what you would expect - not ground salmon, but big, bold strips glistening inside a wonton wrapper. 

Then the seared scallops swimming in a rich lemon sauce, topped with fresh watercress, presented beautifully with a dollop of caviar on a cucmber in the center. It was an array of colors worthy of Van Gogh, almost too beautiful to eat. 

Followed by the ahi tuna tartare served in what tasted like a wasabi glaze, presented on wontons for ease of operation, and the octopus salad, which is a blend of textures, from crunch pork rinds to crisp vegetables to chewy cephalopod. And finally, the soft shelled crab which is presented like something out of science fiction, but extremely tasty and fresh. 

Main entrees were the steak, sea bass, and the mushroom rice with bonito flakes. The mushroom rice was easily the standout dish - delicate, flaky, fishy bonito on rice with the texture of risotto. The steak was extremely tender, and the sea bass was moist, flavorful and delicious. Each of these one dishes could have been "the best dish" at any other restaurant. All the deserts, equally good. The upside down cake and chocolate cake in particular.
author: Neal P.

description:
Ever since my boyfriend and I discovered The House, we've been dining here at least once or every other week. We've tried almost everything on the menu, including the specials, but my favorite dishes are the Grilled Sea Bass and Scallops (appetizer). I also LOVE their caramelized cauliflower, which is a side entrée dish. I love the texture, sweetness, spices, and the flavor of it. But pretty much everything on their menu is delicious, so I can't help but order 3-4 appetizers on top of my main entrée and my boyfriend's entrée. Oh! We also order dessert too : ) I prefer American or European cuisine over Asian (except Korean food), but they elevated the traditional Asian dishes by adding a hint of American spices, which I must say, they perfected the taste. 

I would love to give The House 5 stars, BUT I must subtract 1 star for their lack of friendliness and attentiveness. Although they remember us, I don't feel a sense of connection or rapport with the waitresses, which I hope we had since we visit so often. Although I am quite critical when it comes to service, their food is wayyyy too delicious. Therefore, they are an exception to the rule : )

One thing to note: make reservations, or be prepared to wait. Luckily, we always made reservations so our wait time has been 2 minutes or less, however, I've seen patrons wait out the door to be seated!
author: Lilac R.

description: I've been here several times now and have yet to be disappointed....except in myself because I keep ordering the same dish - the house made wasabi noodles are AMAZING.  It's not that I don't think the other dishes are delicious, I just want to enjoy the noodles and perfectly cooked steak over and over again.  Service is always satisfactory and, frankly, I wouldn't care if the server was rude.  Just give me my noodles.
author: Christina C.

description: So delicious! One of the smallest restaurants I've ever been. I got the noodles all the reviews mention. I'll be back the next time I visit San Francisco.
author: Andy F.

description:
I have no qualms with the food...it was excellent. In fact, I didn't find it particularly overpriced either, it seemed fair based on the high quality ingredients and presentation.

It's the service and the general feel of the place that was a let down. Nothing wrong with the ambiance, but the place was always a bit overcrowded. Also, the host was rather inconsiderate and told us the wait was 30 minutes when it was nearly 1 hour, without giving us an update unless we asked. Also, our server was very cold and impersonal, just placing the food on the table and leaving. 

For future reference, a reservation online is a must. Second, you must try the Pork Chop, it has the most incredible pomegranate glaze! The salmon roll was a tasty appetizer, and the Kobe Salad special was light and flavorful. Lastly, the dessert was a chocolate "cream pie" though it was basically just a mousse...very decadent nonetheless. Again, no problems with the food, only with the people involved.
author: Sid A.

description:
4.5ish after 1787 reviews...they must be doing something right.

I'll keep this succinct since I'm sure I can cannot say anything original after 1787 reviews...

I fucking love this place.
author: Chris D.

description:
I was a bit skeptical since this Asian Fusion restaurant is located in North Beach...although I'm not familiar with the area, isn't North Beach Italian?  But a few of my co-workers recommended this and I'm so glad I went.

Appetizer:  Ahi tuna tartare with roasted nori chips.  
It was good, but I've had better.  The presentation of the dish was nice and the nori chips were good.  But the sauce or lack-of, made the dish mediocre.  
Entree:  Chicken breast with roasted portabella white truffle oil sauce
This dish is SOOOOOO GOOD.  The chicken was served with mashed potato.  The sauce was AHHHH-MAZING, so good that i wanted to lick the plate.


I Love The House.  One of the best meals I had in SF.
author: Terry C.

description: The best cooked food I've ever eaten.  The sea bass flaked apart, buttery as all hell.  Coupled with delectable noodles and green beans with a perfect amount of kick the course was incredible.  Sampled the pork chop and the salmon off friends' plates and can say that it was also the best cooked pork chop I've ever had the pleasure of eating.  Started off with an evening's special that consisted of tuna poke with avocado which was simple and sublime.  The nature of the place is unassuming and allowed us to make friends with the neighbors just to the right of us and split some excellent sake.  All in all The House is a win.  In North Beach, fantastic food, great people and service all make for a restaurant to return to again and again.  Calling ahead is nearly a must if you don't want to be waiting out the door as this little place fills up quick.
author: Chloe B.

description:
This place just radiates positive vibes as you walk in. So maybe we made reservations for 10 pm and didn't get seated till 1040...who cares.  It was well worth it. The ambiance was warm and intimate in this small, nearly shack-like restaurant. That coupled with some fantastic food definitely redeemed every one of those 40 minutes I waited.  

The roasted unagi with avocado rice stole the show. It was a meaty portion of eel with just a light coat of eel sauce. The rice was moist, brightened up by some avocado.  We split the seabass for an entree which turned out to be the perfect complement to the unagi. It was light and fresh compared to the heavier tastes we started with. I totally recommend both fish!

We also had a couple sidekicks like kobe beef tartare and shrimp and chives dumpling. It was hard to taste the beef in the tartare, cause it was heavily mixed with aioli. The crostini and apple gave it good texture but the flavors just weren't gelling all that well to me. And the dumplings were probably playing it safe- they turned out tasty but ordinary.

They play the Asian fusion menu really well and while some of the apps were nothing special, the unagi and seabass were just amazing. If you're looking for sophisticated comfort, The House knows best.
author: Eva O.

description: Get a reservation if you can, but on a moderate night walking in may work for a small party.  Intimate atmosphere, and really terrific service and food.  Very happy.  Had skirt steak and noodles, with scallops for a starter.
author: Scott W.

description:
I've been going to The House for over 10 years, ever since they still had their larger (and more comfy) location near Irving.  It is consistent and delicious and really is my favorite restaurant in the world.  I don't love Asian Fusion but they do it right.  

I never get to go out much to the city with two young kids, but I would choose House for any birthday or anniversary celebration if I could.  They don't disappoint, unlike other higher priced places.

My musts are the salmon roll (love the spicy sauce), Rib-eye and Sea Bass (so tender and tasty!).  Other items were good but less memorable. I have tried their pork chops when I was pregnant, asked for it well-done and it was still amazing and tender.  I love their Mango Tapioca and Chocolate cake too.  I also love that their presentation is nice, they include crispy/crunch elements into their dishes, have interesting sides and use different types of greens.  Most recently tried their scallop special and they were so delicious.  They take great care with their garnishes and sauces - they all work together beautifully.

I do wish their beer and wine was served colder, and that they would buy some newer plates, but I appreciate their prices are relatively low.  Their portions have definitely shrunk but their prices are still so low I can't complain.  I used to be so stuffed I couldn't enjoy my dessert without being uncomfortable but now I can easily polish off my desserts and not feel regretful.  If they ever open a larger, more elegant location, I would pay higher prices to eat there for sure.

They once had a terrible waitress that we actually left no tip for (she was THAT BAD), but now all their servers seem nice and friendly.  

Sometimes I try their specials and they underwhelm, but nothing has ever been bad there, just not as good as my usual favorites, and I end up wishing I ordered something else.  

Yes, get an early reservation, arrive with plenty of time to circle and find parking and enjoy a good table not squished in between others.  I would not suggest going with a party of more than 2 actually.  Enjoy some delicious, inventive food without breaking the bank!  If they were closer to me I would probably go every week and if they were more spacious I would drag the kids there!
author: Lisa T.

description:
THE MOST AMAZING MEAL IVE EVER HAD. 

We came here for my birthday and its was just like I had it the first time. Its so flavorful, tasty, mind-blowing delicious. I was them to be my chef when I get rich one day! The pork  chop was good, salmon soup was good. There special that night, the spicy pork miso or something like that was amazing. It's a bit pricey, but totally worth your money! We got the asparagus appetizer and it was so good like last time. I would literally not mind eating here everyday!
author: Mo W.

description:
My wife and I ate at The House on a Monday night.  We split the octopus salad and shrimp dumplings.  I liked them both pretty well, but my wife tasted something in the octopus salad that she didn't like (so I got to eat most of that one).  For dinner, I had the wasabi noodles with steak.  The wasabi noodles had a nice bite and it went really well with the steak; I would definitely order this one again.  My wife had black cod, which was a special for the evening.  It was really good.  No room for dessert, unfortunately.

I would probably give The House 3.5 stars if that was possible.  I wouldn't mind going back and trying some different dishes, but I left thinking that I had eaten some better meals at the Out the Door (the one in the Westfield Mall, currently closed), which I gave 4 stars.
author: Richard M.

description:
This restaurant is a rare gem.  The space is noisy and crowded, but lively and a great place to take friends and enjoy conversation.  Your voices will mix with the happy boisterous atmosphere as you enjoy American fusion style cuisine cooked to perfection.  My wife enjoyed "damn good" cod, and my pork in pomegranate curry was perfection.  Paired with a glass of high quality pinot, I couldn't have asked for a better degustation.  The quality of this food far exceeds the casual atmosphere or price tag, which is substantial, but not upsetting.  My friend also had the pork and was similarly impressed.

The menu options range from traditional American, such as chicken breast in roasted portabello mushroom sauce, to asian-styled fish dishes.  

The deserts are excellent as well.  My wife enjoyed strawberry rhubarb crisp and I had mango tapioca pudding.

Portion sizes are generous, but not obscene.
author: Alexander W.

description: This place isn't as good as I remembered. Things are more expensive but food quality definitely has worsened. I ordered the mushroom rice with tiger shrimp--was given four shrimps and a scoop full of mushroom rice that was buttery, but not flavorful. I got sick of the dish after a few bites. My husband had the sea bass that was overcooked (the sea bass use to be our favorite)-- the sides of strings beans and garlic noodles were yummy though--but we paid 26$ for the sea bass, not the sides....I use to dream about the creme brulee--it use to be so tangy and tarty--this time, it was just overly sweet. No one ever came by to ask us how we were doing. Had to ask three different people for the bill. The quality of the food and the lacklustered service definitely made the price of the entire experience a total waste. Well, that's one less restaurant we HAVE to go to when we're in SF.
author: jane m.

description:
Overrated.  I had the sea bass with wasabi noodles and greens.  Everything was too oily and salty but the sea bass was cooked very well.  Nothing special about the wasabi noodles and I couldn't detect the wasabi.  The greens were drenched in oil, bit salty, and tough to chew.  Partner's kobe beef was practically raw, dumped on mashed potatoes.  This fusion needs improvement.
Appetizer yellowtail sashimi was pretty good, hence 3 stars.
author: Carol K.

description:
I've been going to this place for years and it has not failed me yet.  Food is always great and consistent!  My favorites on the menu:  oysters on the half shell (always fresh) with their special spicy vinaigrette, Salmon rolls, Deep fried liver salad for starter. Must have entree: Sea bass with garlic noodles. Droool!!! End it with the mango tapioca pudding.

I highly reccommend it!!!!
author: Megan W.

description:
Anytime I have friends come into town and ask me "where should we go to eat in the city?" I always recommend The House. Seriously one of my favorite restaurants in the city, hands down. Not one complaint.

Wasabi noodles, fried salmon roll, that's whats up!
author: Lindsey N.

description: i love finding good new restaurants to dine at! didn't find this one actually. my gf took me here. it's rare that i'm ever in the area, but i had plenty of time to be adventurous and cross town. a bit pricey for lunch and dinner, but i can't complain anymore. food in this city is expensive, period. this place is definitely worth a lunch. not so sure about dinner. meat and fish are grilled to perfection and of course, the noodles were amazing. i'm never a big fan of fusion asian food, but the flavors here are on point.
author: Thao T.

description:
Food = Great. Everything on the menu has a unique flavor.

Staff = Not great. This place is a 5-star in terms of food but their pompous attitude knocks them down to a 3-star in terms of overall experience.

We get that your food is tasty. We get that your popular. Don't act like you're doing charity work for your customers who are forking over hundreds of dollars and keeping your ass in business.
author: James M.

description:
Food is great, but the attitude of the servers is another story. Called to RSVP for a party of 6 and I felt the person on the line was annoyed that I was called. They request you to leave your credit card # in order to RSVP a spot. Apparently it's somewhat for their security in case you do not show  up, they would charge your card for $10 per person unless you call in advance to cancel.

I understand the restaurant is small and it hurts them if people do not show up. I'm sure they get it all the time so I wouldn't blame them for having such an attitude. Still, they should improve on their customer service.
author: Jason N.

description:
Food.. Absolutely terrific. Off the charts for me. It's Chinese-American Fusion like my parents used to make sorta =), but well, add in a few decades of culinary evolution, and you'll have what they have here.  The food is very consistent in quality over the YEARS that I've been coming here.
Service: Great this time! (more details below..)

My wife and I usually try to avoid North Beach on the weekends, but since we had a special occasion to celebrate, we braved the partying crowds of Halloween and the nearly impossible parking situation to make it to our restaurant of choice for the evening - The House.

Once there, we had to wriggle our way in through the door to get our names on the waiting list.  Yes, it helps to have reservations, but after about 35-45 minutes of standing near the door, enjoying the scene and studying the menu by the window, we earned our table.  So you CAN do it without reservations, but ya just have to wait a little.

For appetizers, I ordered the Mixed green salad with Avocados, Apple and with White Shrimp Tempura.  It was delivered without delay.. only about five or six minutes after ordering. I rarely say "WOW.. that was good" involuntarily about any appetizer, but here.. I did!  It's THAT good.

My wife ordered one of the specials for the week - a hothouse Tomato Soup served with a fried clam on top of a small dollop of mashed potatoes.  No disappointment here. Soup was light, and the fried clam seem to have been fried in their same batter as their calamari.  It was a delectable beginning to a terrific dinner.

I had been pining for a decent steak over the last week or so, and while The House is probably known best for it's seafood and pork entrees, I ordered the Angus Rib-Eye in a garlic-butter sauce as my main course.  This red meat offering is usually served over a bed of mashed potatoes with Chinese Mustard Greens.  As for my preferences, I had them substitute rice instead of the mash, which they were glad to do.  The entree arrived medium-well just as I had hoped, seared and caramelized beautifully both aromatically and visually.  YUM!  Each careful bite was incredible and savored with much care.
 
Service?  Hmm. this time, it was actually pretty friendly for once. Our waitress was attentive, not obtrusive, and water service was right-on. No waiting, no issues with "throwing menus" in front of the customer. Much better than my prior visit back in 2009.

After this latest visit, I am happy to reinstate "The House" to my list of all-time favorite places to enjoy a high quality meal.
author: Harry W.

description:
I had to come back again for the sea bass. YUMMY!!!!

I also tried their apple pie a la mode. Definitely sweet and I like the gramcracker or whatever topping. Mmmm...Now I'm craving it again.. lol
author: Helen V.

description:
Its New Years Eve.  

RSVP at 7:30pm, seated at 8pm.  But I will still give them 5 stars for their service and food!

We waited half an hour long, but the hostess was thoughtful and comped us a Salmon roll with this Asian style coleslaw.  And yes, it was yummies!

For dinner:
Fried pork belly - It was a bun with a slice of fried pork belly tucked in the middle with a hoison sauce.  You can then add veggies to it.  "Soft" on the outside and "crunchy" on the inside.  Its almost like a Pekin Duck Bun. Very flavorful.  - Like

Duck entree - Now this was super duper yummies! I can still remember the flavor that burst in my mouth.  I thought the mash, asparagus, blackberry, and the sauce worked really well with the Duck.  It was cooked to medium rare; just perfect for me!  Ahhh- phenomenal.  If you are a "duck" kind-a-person, definitely recommend trying this.

Pork entree - It was flavorful, but not enough for me.  It still tasted a bit bland towards the inside and a bit dry. (But that's pork for you.)  Not too crazy about this one.

Finished off with a glass of Pinot and I'm good for the night!
author: Jessica P.

description:
As humans we tend to remember things better than they really were. So, in my mind, the true test of a good restaurant is whether or not it's as good the 2nd time as it was the first. I've been to plenty of restaurants a 2nd time only to walk out a bit disappointed.

I went to The House the first time several years ago with my family. I don't remember many details other than that I had lamb and we all thought the meal was spectacular.

When I returned to the House a few weeks ago with my husband an in-laws, I was worried it might not live up to my memory. But boy was I wrong! This place was just as good as I remembered.

My husband and I split the Ahi Tuna Tartare appetizer -- it was absolutely amazing; I'd highly recommend it. My in-laws got the fried salmon roll which was also good but definitely would take 2nd place in my book.

For an entree I had the "Sesame soy glazed salmon in a bonito sake broth" and the fish was cooked to perfection.

We almost didn't get dessert, but I'm glad we did! We had a chocolate truffle cake which was absolutely UNREAL. I've never had any kind of cake that tasted like that. My husband and I are still talking about it.

The House is some of the best food you can find in the city for the price and the service is excellent as well. Just don't expect to walk-in without a reservation!
author: Sydney L.

description: There's a reason this place has 4.5 stars on the hit parade. Truly a gem in North Beach. You won't be disappointed.
author: Anthony W.

description:
Went here yesteday for the hubbys 37th birthday on a Thurs night.  It wasnt crowded at all, as we were seated right away.

The place is much smaller than expected, and the decor was simple and light.  Definately a nice place to take a first date or so... but nothing fancy.  The lighting could be a little brighter, it was dimly lit, or maybe our seat just missed the drop lighting they had inbetween tables, but... being that the food was AMAZING, i would have liked to see it a little more.

On to the good stuff...

We ordered for appetizers:

Seared scalops 
Hamachi sushi topped with some mango salsa and avocado
Soft shell crab with vermacelli noddles with a kick of Sarracha.

I honestly dont think Ive had such an amazing infusion of foods in my palette.  I absolutely wanted more, and was looking forward to our entrees.  

Entrees:

Garlic Ribeye with Garlic noodles
Miso Seabass with Garlic noodles

Not your typical garlic noodles, they were more of the thick egg garlic noodles you find in the chow mein, but tasty nonetheless.  the garlic was not overpowering, and it was flavorfull, and as a matter of fact, I almost wanted some rice just to sweep along the residual sauces from the meal.

The meat was tender (honestly, how can you ruin rib-eye), with all the juicy fat drippings, with thin slices of carmelized garlic on top, below a bed of chinese green leafy vegi (dont know the name of them, but do recognize them when I go to Ranch99).  

The seabass was grilled to perfection.  I know with seabass being such a light white fish, if it isnt made right, it can taste funny.  It was savory, AND tasty.
