I honestly didnt have one bad remark about the food.  If this review is solely for food, it would be 5 stars.

Held back a star because it was indeed my husbands birthday.  Asked them to do a little something for acknowledgement, and the waiter said they would.  At the end, they forgot ... and came by when we already paid the bill with a lit candle.  Really?  $160 tab and you couldnt even remember to put a candle on cookie, whip cream, anything?!  Oh well... sign of the times.  OH, of course because of the dim lit restaurant, it wasnt as appealing as the food could have been.

Overalll a GOOD experience (could be GREAT), but.... we would come back.
author: Barb B.

description: The food here is awesome I suggest the salmon roll and the wasabi noodles with flank steak. Great atmosphere, awesome location. It is a small restaurant and does get very busy though so make a reservation!
author: Madie H.

description: They did not honor our reservation time. Had to wait 45 minutes over the confirmed time I booked for a table for 2. Poor wine selection and just so-so food with bad service. And the location is deplorable ....urine on the sidewalk out front. Not sure what the hype is all about.
author: Hungryin H.

description:
I finally made it to The House and actually got parking right in front on a Saturday night. You definitely need a reservation, as it's a tight space with no real waiting area.  

You start with house made pickles that get the appetite going.  We went for the calamari appetizer, which literally came out in like 2 minutes.  It was a little tough to enjoy as people waiting by the door kept bumping into our chair, and there was a huge chilly draft every time the door opened.  The calamari itself is nice and crisped and not overdone, with a pretty standard cocktail sauce, garnished with shredded kimchee.

They had a lot of specials on the menu that night, but as everyone had recommended the sea bass, I had to get it. It was tender but had a nice sear on one side, and it was flaky but not too rich.  It had a good amount of flavor for something not drowned in sauce, although a small drizzle of the reduced soy glaze helps it out a lot.  I got it with rice, which ended up being plain white rice, so I think noodles would have been a better option.  The stir fried green beans were thin and flavorful but very oily.

Then we were debating between the pork chop and the steak, and the wasabi noodles for the flat iron steak helped it get chosen.  The steak was pretty tender, but it lacked the flavor I expected.  The beef was fresh, but maybe it just needed some more salt and pepper?  On the other hand, the noodles underneath are well seasoned, with a little kick from the wasabi, which was not overpowering.  

Portion sizes are pretty good and left us a little too full for dessert.  

Am I the only one not giving them 5 stars??  It wasn't bad, but I think it was just too hyped up.  Prices are very reasonable for what you get, but I tend to be pretty critical with fusion style restaurants.   It's a cute little family owned place with lots of regulars.  Service is very friendly and prompt (water is refilled quickly), and they keep coming by to check if you're done.  I understand the need for quick turnover in a small space,  but you almost feel guilty for eating slowly.  However, if you like fusion, it's worth checking out.
author: Marilyn T.

description:
Came here for date night with the boyfriend and we had a great time! We had reservations for 7PM and were seated right away. 

For starters, we ordered the deep-fried salmon roll with Chinese mustard. The rolls were garnished with a heaping amount of green caviar. Each salmon roll is wrapped with seaweed and then deep-fried. I loved the contrast of textures between the chewy salmon and crunchy exterior. Go easy with the Chinese mustard - it has a strong kick and definitely cleared up my sinuses  :D

For entrees, my boyfriend and I decided to share the special - a halibut with clams in coconut curry and the infamous seabass with wasabi house noodles instead of the garlic noodles. I was blown away by the presentation! The seabass was AMAZING! The texture is so smooth, soft, and perfectly chewy. The seasoning was a touch too salty, but other than that it was perfect! The wasabi noodles were a little on the oily side and I didn't taste any wasabi in the noodles. The halibut and curry was good, but the seabass stole the show that night!

We shared the coconut creme brulee for dessert which was good, but nothing amazing. I ordered the lychee iced tea which is unsweetened (but you can request for sugar on the side) - it had the perfect hint of lychee flavor - delicious! 

The ambiance of the restaurant is simple and cozy. The tables are crammed a little too close together. The table next to ours was clearly fit for two people maximum, but they still tried to cram three (big) people to one small table. The service was not bad, but felt rushed. The food came out so fast, as soon as we were done with our appetizers (literally 2 minutes later) they came out with the entrees. We were seated at 7PM and were finished with dinner by 7:45PM. Also, the restaurant is pretty loud, so the waitresses need to speak up! I could barely hear them when they were introducing the specials... 

Parking in North Beach area is hard to find, but we got really lucky and parked around Washington Square Park. Be prepared to spend a good 20 minutes circling for a spot or pay for parking in the garages. 

The food is creative, packed with lots of flavor, and beautifully presented. Prices are very reasonable as well. I definitely recommend checking out The House!!
author: Eva W.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  We have been going here for 10 years and it is outstanding every single time.  We always make reservations as it is a very small restaurant which is packed with locals and usually has a line out the door.  

The food is to put it simply - perfect.  We usually eat seafood when we dine here and I highly recommend the salmon, sea bass and black cod.  It is always cooked to perfection and each has its own unique flavor. No trip to The House is complete without an order of the tempura stringbeans.  They are one of the best appetizers I have ever had and are truly addictive. Even when we say we aren't going to have them, a table nearby will be eating them and we immediately fold and place an order. 

Because the restaurant is small and the tables are close together, everyone ends up carrying on conversations with their neighbors. The last time we ate here we sat next to a young couple on their honeymoon from Georgia.  The bride told me that she did hours of research before their trip and discovered that The House was one of the most recommended restaurants in San Francisco (quite the accomplishment for a city with such great restaurants). She said it was the best salmon that she had ever had and couldn't figure out why - it was like magic.  Indeed.
author: Brad M.

description:
This is the exact opposite of my kind of restaurant. It's Asian fusion. It's a sardine can. And it's in North Beach, which is half nasty nightclubs and half tourist traps. This restaurant also doesn't need another review, but I'm compelled to write one because the food is not only great, it's a great value for San Francisco.

I came here for my birthday dinner last year and for a double date last month, and I've eaten just about everything. Your birthday is a good time to be obnoxious by sampling your guests' food at will. I enjoyed my second visit more, though, because I could don a t-shirt with jeans and eat like a T-Rex. A few of the dishes are of dinosaur proportions (e.g., wasabi house noodles with angus flatiron steak)!

The menu is short and simple, yet diverse and thoughtful. My favorite appetizers were the deep-fried salmon roll and roasted unagi. I don't generally care for the texture of either, but wow--these were winners. The only appetizer I didn't like was the deep-fried chicken liver because there were just too few gems in that haystack of a salad. I already eat slowly, I don't need to waste time hunting and gathering the good stuff.

As for the entrees my favorite was the butterfish special with crab sushi. The butterfish rivaled that of Roy's (http://www.yelp.com/bi...) and the crab sushi put it over the top--this is one to not share, even with a birthday girl. The wasabi house hoodles, grilled sea bass, and Niman Ranch pork chop are all great as well but simply incomparable.

Dinner for two could range from $50 to $100. This is a lot for Asian but reasonable for fusion. I highly recommend reservations unless you're a native Italian and ok with having dinner at 10pm--but if you're a real Italian, North Beach is definitely not your scene.
author: Liz T.

description:
Came here with friends last night thinking that on a random Tuesday night this usually super crowded little place would be more available.  So wrong.  It was brimming with people.  Thank god we had a reservation or else I don't think we would have been able to sit down until close to 9 p.m.  Super recommend the wasabi house noodles with angus flatiron steak, grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy, and the grilled calamari with fish flakes (special menu item).  I didn't like the deep-fried salmon roll at all even though it was Yelp recommended.  I thought the salmon was too dry and the sauce was way too wasabi-y.  I probably wouldn't ever get it again.  

Parking is insane.  There's a garage a few block down near Stockton that I would check out as a last resort.  I would ALWAYS make a reservation.  Disappointed that this place doesn't take reservations on OpenTable.com.  Calling to make a reservation is so outdated. 

Definitely would come back to try other Yelp recommended!

Date of dining: July 7, 2011
author: Kimberly C.

description:
If you ever crave for Asian fusion cuisine, The House is the place to be.  

Parking was a pain but you could valet park in the back.  Service was fast.  Food came out shortly after putting in the order.  

I took Connie C's recommendations and ordered the miso black cod and seared scallops.  Spot on.  Both dishes were amazing.  Fish was flaky and moist with a sweet reduction, just melted in my mouth.  Scallops were warm, soft and seared perfectly.   Get both dishes if you dine there.  

Definitely will go back for more.
author: Hannah C.

description:
Again...not sure how I've never reviewed this place?? I've been going here since they first opened their doors last 90s, and amazingly they are still producing the same great quality food as they did from day 1. The only reason why they don't get 5 stars is because of the size of their location...you definitely can't be afraid to be cozy in this place...especially with strangers. Our table for 2 was mashed between a table of 2 and a table of 4....definitely cozy. It sometimes feels as though you're eating off of your neighbors plate :) but that's what brings people back here perhaps...very cozy...hence the name i guess..."the house"

Things to never miss: 

- Oysters 
- Grilled Sea Bass (the noodles are always perfect)
- Seasoned Rib Eye
- House Salad (the dressing is light while the citrus isn't overwhelming) - every bite of the salad is very refreshing. 
- Wines by the glass can use some help...and overall selection....but for SF, the selection is well priced.
author: Master B.

description:
This place isn't Asian-Fusion, but more of a New American style with Asian flavoring.  The dishes are beautifully presented and rich (but not overwhelming) in flavor, but most on the menu try to imitate any trademark dishes.  (I really find it necessary to clarify since I hate Asian Fusion places normally.)

My date and I both ordered steaks (2 different types), an appetizer, and lychee black teas.  Everything was delicious.  Serving sizes were generous.  The service was great.  

My only possible qualm is how small the place is, so remember to make a reservation!
author: Jeanne L.

description:
My mom and I are crazy for the bone in pork chop with pomegranate sauce. I usually don't like sauce with my meat dishes but I always ask for more pomegranate sauce on the side with this pork chop dish,
The blue lake bean tempura is always perfectly fried and the tempura batter is light and crispy,  One time they had a special of the day appetizer which was just fresh hamachi and blue fin tuna, but it was so fresh and delicious. I saw the delivery guy from Royal Hawaiin deliver their seafood so they definitely are getting quality.
I would say service is attentive and they are polite.  Definitely love coming here for lunch.
author: natalie y.

description:
Despite all the good things that I've heard about The House, going to North Beach, with its clusterf$$k traffic and parking situation is just never appealing to me.  So after calling and canceling a few times, I finally managed to keep the reservation and went there on a Sunday evening.

The decision on the timing was a conscious one.  I've experienced enough of North Beach traffic at its finest and didn't feel like dealing with it in my old age.  

Sure enough, we got there in about 15 minutes from the *other* end of town (SCORE) and were able to find a spot right outside the restaurant (DOUBLE SCORE).   

What we didn't anticipate was that our table was still occupied by the earlier party, so we had to wait for a good 15 minutes before we were allowed in (the entrance to the restaurant was definitely not designed to hold a large amount of hopeful diners).  Thankfully, though, the food came out relatively fast because all of us were starving at that point. 

Our appetizers were out within 10 minutes of ordering: Roasted unagi (eel) with avocado sushi rice (Phenomenal with a capital P), ahi tuna tartare with nori chips http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZoZjbOYR-apY8XvommlNUA?select=9vRf8qmVTlGJeR6hCGFiKw (good), and the deep-fried salmon roll http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZoZjbOYR-apY8XvommlNUA?select=FyXnTNDxPk6xKT6O64OsyQ (disappointingly underwhelming).  

Then along came the entree - as soon as our plates of appetizer were cleared - and again they were a bit of a hit-and-miss.  Everyone loved, loved, loved the creamy melt-in-your-mouth grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy and noodles http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZoZjbOYR-apY8XvommlNUA?select=t_zbZ3Z2VIUWZAoF8pMfMw, as well as the mushroom rice (which was almost like a risotto, only a little drier) with prawns.  The rest of the entree were just okay - the ribeye steak was a bit on the chewy side http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZoZjbOYR-apY8XvommlNUA?select=cFJk2o__xsa-ThdrBy4nzA and the flatiron steak was just so-so http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZoZjbOYR-apY8XvommlNUA?select=V8-AgPhd0LrF6O4yjdegCQ (I now know better not to order steak in a non-steakhouse).  

All in all, it was a good dinner - I'll just pass on the steaks next time (and recommend others to do so).
author: Ange L.

description: I'm currently typing and chowing down on the Wasabi Noodles with Salmon! I couldn't even wait to finish the dish before posting this review.  The thick noodles are perfectly cooked and tender but not too soft. They ring with the essence of wasabi, much more subtle than I've experienced with sushi : ) salmon is perfect. The dish is beautifully plated, and accompanied by the house pickles.
author: Thomas A.

description: This spot is great! I work next store and always wanted to try it, there's always people waiting outside during lunch, it's pretty small inside. I just ordered to go and came back to get it in ten minutes. I ordered warm wasabi noodles w chicken, it was solo good! Not super spicy or wasabi tasting but just enough to taste the wasabi a bit. The staff wasn't the warmest but they are working hard and busy so I didn't take offense. I will certainly be coming back to try those salmon rolls!! Also the prices were good. I'd rather spend 12$ on a delish dish than 10$ on something not very good at other places around the neighborhood
author: Brittni Z.

description:
Usually not a huge fan of asian fusion restaurants but The House may have change my mind. We went to The House as it was heavily endorsed by some co-workers particularly the miso black cod which they described to be mind-blowing and indeed it was.

Between the 5 of us we essentially turned our dining experience family style, so we got to try a bit of everything. We split several small dishes and ordered up an entree each. Everything we had that evening was excellent, particularly the black cod. The black cod was served up with a delicious sauce and a roll cut into two pieces. The fish was brilliantly marinated/prepared, and it was so tender and buttery, I'd kill for a bite right now.

The restaurant is pretty small and the air conditioning system didn't work particularly well that evening so it got a little irritating eating sweaty. Their sake selection could be kicked up a notch, but other than that, it was a great experience! 

Tip: Make a reservation. Second tip: Do not miss the chance to eat here ever. Third tip: Look at our food pics and other reviews here: http://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=230607147045281&set=a.230606447045351.43110.215645868541409&type=3&theater
author: Margie S.

description:
Amazing food. Don't even attempt street parking -- there are two nice garages a couple blocks up Vallejo on the other side of Columbus -- easy parking, easy walking. Absolutely get a reservation. It's small and crowded, and without a reservation you'll either wait a long time or not eat at all.

Only negative is that it's such a small space that if you have a "loud talker" nearby their voice will echo throughout the restaurant. If you are such a loud talker, do your fellow diners a favor and go somewhere else.
author: R. A. F.

description:
Fusion cuisine is difficult to cook without being a terrible fail. However, The House is able to capture the best of both worlds of Asian and American. The flavor of all the dishes were beyond belief! 

Overall the ambiance of the restaurant was intimate and romantic (mood lighting ;} ) Service, food, and ambiance was wonderful. Definitely, will be coming back again!
author: Sara N.

description:
Came here during my trip to San Francisco under the recommendation of  the high marks on Yelp. The reviews were pretty much spot on in both pros/cons.   

It seems the two most mentioned items here are the Steak with Wasabi Noodles, & the Sea Bass.  My girlfriend and I ordered each of those, and both the Bass and the Steak were cooked perfectly, (I don't know how they get the Sea bass so light and fluffy).  The wasabi noodles were also very good, and while not the most amazing thing I've ever eaten, I think they get special points out of  their uniqueness. 

We ordered the Chocolate cake for desert, which has no Asian twist to it but was also very good. I'd say it was actually closer in consistency to fudge than actual cake.

The service & the atmosphere were decent, though as mentioned by others not to the "5 star" caliber of the food.  They took my final tip/receipt copy while we were still sitting there, which I found a bit odd coming from DC.  Not a big deal, and it may be a San Fran thing as another asian restaurant I went to in Chinatown also did the same thing.
author: Eddie D.

description: 2nd time dining here, and did not disappoint. I opted for the specials of the day, which I'm so glad I did. Delicious fish in a Thai inspired sauce almost. Just delicious.  I hear the noodles are out of this world, but I have yet to try them!
author: Meredith M.

description:
Tiny and cozy ... a bit too cozy.  I wish they had a bar.  It was awkward standing/waiting in the doorway not up in someone else's face or in the lap of someone eating dinner.  Luckily they seated us pretty quickly.  The place was packed on a Monday night ... but cleared out by 9:00.

Having glanced at Yelp, I knew to order the sea bass.  It was worth it.  Generous portion of fish with sides of green bean and noodles.  It was a lot of food and I didn't need to eat it all ... but I did.  We also shared the scallop appetizer which was incredible.  I would order 3 plates of those for my meal next time.

The meal was good and left me with a good impression of the restaurant but it was the delightful company that made it a great night.  Nothing like catching up with girlfriends, swapping naughty stories and trading moves.
author: Kathleen W.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in SF! You have to make reservations or else you're be waiting for about an hour! Try the flat iron steak & noodles, ribeye steak and cod specials. 

For appetizers we got fried calamari, salmon rolls and crab cake. Yummy! Everything on there menu is really good! =)
author: V N.

description:
So The House has 4.5 stars, so obviously the food is good.  2000+ reviews, so what can I add?  The Bay Area has the best asian fusion in the US.  New York has Tao, The Bay has Tamarine, Slanted Door, Crustacean, The House is better than them all!  Yes, it's better than Tao!

We went for a late lunch on a Saturday, no problem getting parking or a table.  The lunch is great, some of the favorites are on the menu and they had great specials.  This area is busy at night, so I recommend trying The House for lunch.
author: Shen J.

description:
This place is great! The food is excellent from the taste to the presentation. Only gripe is that this place is so packed all the time that I don't get to enjoy the setting. The chairs and tables are packed so close to each other that I could practically reach over and steal my neighbor's wine glass. 

I've been here twice. The second time, the waitress was a bit rude. She read off the specials like she hated her job without even a crack of a smile. Other than that, I would come here again.
author: Jenny T.

description:
Why are there so many good food establishments in SF?  I'm missing the city even more as I'm catching up on reviews. 

We came here on the first night of my visit to SF.   
Just about everything on the menu caught my eye but I stuck with the highly recommended Wasabi Noodles & Flat Iron Steak.  
Like everything I had in SF, I dream about it.
The wasabi noodles sounded like they'd be overpowering with the wasabi flavor but no, they were so good & well-balanced the steak. 

I don't really care much for the service.  The waitress had the "it's all serious business" attitude but whatever, as long as the food was spectacular it really didn't matter.
author: Carol L.

description: Last night's dinner was great!  Again, don't bother if you don't have a rezi.  The service was fast and our table for four was waiting and ready for us at 7 pm.
author: Cassie P.

description:
I am not sure if it is my European taste-buds that are the issue here but in my opinion, there was nothing 'special' or 'great' about this place or the food (ok, there was one, but I'll come back to it later).

I had the Mushroom rice with king prawns and if I am brutally honest, it was stodgy, bland and tasteless enough for me to only eat half of it. Putting that into context, I lick plates clean after almost every meal and often get forked in the elbow from table neighbours as I lean across to help finish their plates.

Yeah the decor was clean and simple, and the service was good, but based upon what I ate I am not sure I'd want to go back...sorry.

Now, to the one 'great' thing that was also a bit freaky: on top of my dish was this really fine papery stuff that when it got warm (from the food it was sprinkled on), it started waving and moving around making the dish look like it was still alive. It freaked one of my friends out but I found that pretty cool.
author: Elliot A.

description: This place is amazing. We came here for lunch and had the sea bass with garlic noodles, pork chop with wasabi noodles, mussels in shrimp infused broth and the homemade cheesecake with fruit. Being pasta snobs we have high standards for pasta and this place met them. My husband is also a fried chicken and pork chop snob and he's never able to find a place that can cook either without it being too dry. The pork chop was amazing!  Very juicy!  Service was excellent and the prices for the quality of food extremely reasonable.
author: wendy w.

description: Lunch today was excellent. Scallops, salmon all great. Service very nice. One of the best in Chinatown
author: Dan S.

description:
Came in after seeing glowing reviews on Yelp.  Definitely did not live up to the 5 star reviews.  I don't think there is 3 star Michelin restaurant in the world with more 5 star reviews than The House, which seems is a little fishy to me.  Here is review of what we ordered:

Salmon Rolls:
Salmon wrapped around sea weed then deep fried.  Super hot mustard dipping sauce.  Wasn't very good.   

Wasabi noodles with steak:
Steak was cooked properly but was chewy and flavorless, which tells me they use low quality meat.  Noodles were soggy and too salty. 

Halibut (special):
Was fine, nothing special.  A little under seasoned but was fine otherwise. 

Overall the food was just OK. Again, nothing special.  I would give this place 3 stars, but had to take one star away after factoring in the price ($100 for two people)   The House does have a great vibe and a good wine list.  I will not be coming back.
author: David K.

description: Well prepared dishes with excellent presentation and sizable portions. I came here for lunch with 4 other coworkers. There were no complaints about anything that was ordered. The fried salmon roll was a great way to kick off the meal. The wasabi noodles with grilled salmon was flavorful and full of wasabi goodness. If you like fish this is the place to go. Two of my coworkers got the butterfish special, another got the sea bass and the other got the sol. Everyone left with their tummies happy. Desserts were nothing to rave about but definitely hit the spot. The apple crumble ala mode is pretty classic and tasty. I was a bit disappointed they didn't have desserts with more of an asian flare like something with green tea or red bean in it.
author: Debbie C.

description: Made a same day reservation on Tuesday for 7:30 PM.  We got there at 7:29 PM and the nasty waiter first told us we were late and then, later, that reservations they didn't have reservations at 7:30.  I decided to call the restaurant before writing this review.  The owner knows who the offensive server is but insisted there must be some misunderstanding.  There is no misunderstanding that I was treated very rudely by a nasty waiter person.
author: Mary B.

description:
The House that the food Gods built (if food Gods exist).

My friend and I snagged the earliest table they could reserve on a Sunday evening - the 5 p.m. slot. Oh me oh my, this place was a hit, as it was packed even at this hour.

As we looked around our fellow foodie neighbors, we began raving about the immaculate presentation of their appetizers - the fried soft shell crab, the deep fried salmon rolls, and the oysters - just to name a few.

We opted for the fried salmon rolls - a solid start. Our only regret was failing to order "tapas style," as we were salivating, just eyeing the appetizers around The House.

My friend opted for the sea bass, and I, the pork tenderloin.

These portions were certainly hearty - but we couldn't put our forks and knives down.

The sea bass was accompanied by garlic noodles (with the other options being rice or potatoes), and the noodles had the perfect blend of sweet & salty. This is a must-get for your side selection, unless you simply naturally gravitate to rice and potatoes. (If that's the case, though, you're better off at an American joint!)

One word for the pork. Juicy. I wouldn't have been surprised if this pig was on steroids - in a good way, of course. I haven't had kahlua pork, lechon, or bacon this good. And the fried yam placed perfectly on the mashed potatoes were a perfect addition to this foodie masterpiece.

The desserts looked enticing, and unique for an Asian fusion place. But the portions were just too much to handle - any more food and we would have brought (and weighed) The House down.
author: Jamie L.

description:
Has become one of my faves in and out of the hood! 

Has high end food quality with the tuck away vibe that is so SF! Had the sea bass on a previous visit and it's prepared perfectly but the sauce is very typical to asian fusion. Good for those that do not like to explore their culinary taste buds. 

Last visit, Waitress verbalized a loooooong list of specials that my date and I were testing our memory banks to remember them all.
So we had the scallop app special and Hamachi entree special! Still thinking about both dishes! Scallops were 3 or 4 on a plate (can't remember)! Doesn't matter because I just may order anything scallop at House moving forward! Fabulosity!

Hamachi was really beautifully presented and fabulously prepared! My date liked my dish better than his (maybe because he ordered steak!), so I was nice enough to share:-) Good thing he was cute!
author: Gina H.

description: Not a big fan of chinese food generally but thought the food was quite good and their wine was also excellent. Enjoyed the experience there - it's unpretentious and clearly about the food.
author: Aadil M.

description: Took my fiancé for her birthday.  Made reservation, but still had to wait 30 min for a table.  We both order the Seabass with garlic noodles.  I found a piece if hair in mine.  We both had diherra 1 hour after we left.
author: Jimmy P.

description:
If your waitress mentions the black cod special, do yourself a favor and order this shit. It's amazing.

This past weekend, I took some friends here, totally building the place up. I got a bit nervous because, well, what if The House didn't live up to their expectations? 

But this dinner pretty much blew them away. And me, again. I was able to sample more dishes, and all were outstanding: the scallops appetizer, the mussels, the sea bass and noodles, the steak and noodles, the short ribs special, and the salmon. Again, the bean tempura, deep-fried salmon roll (and its sauce), and the tuna tartare were what I remember them to be.

Presentation of food here is very thoughtful. The space is small, and weekend nights are busy and can be loud, although from my experience the table at the front near the window isn't too bad -- perhaps the loudness intensifies further inside the restaurant. Decor is minimal, but who the eff cares. The food is the star here, nothing else.
author: Cheri R.

description:
I've been here 4 times now and have been impressed every time. Every time my girlfriend makes the long trip over from Madrid, this is the first place she wants to go eat. She's even called this her "favorite restaurant in the world, I think". Big words, I know. But believe me that even if it can't quite live up to that claim in your book you will most certainly be impressed with the extremely high quality seafood and creative of Asian fusion menu. 

This is one of the only restaurants where I pay very close attention to the specials because the Pork shoulder with foie gras and the Cod special are absolutely amazing (no hyperbole here). Another tip is the Japanese Rice beer, both of which are very good. Oh, and of course you must never skip the fried salmon appetizer, even if you're on a budget.

Even if The House wasn't around the corner from my place I would still endure the endless wait, the annoying door that doesn't close by itself (you'll know what I mean), and the lack of parking, just to enjoy this fantastic and unique food. 

Try it, or go back if you haven't had the pork shoulder!
author: Christopher N.

description: Seriously one of the better meals I've had. Started with tuna tartar and scallops special. Ah-mazing. Entrees were sea bass and wasabi noodles. Again both delicious but think the noodles didn't live up to the hype all over the other reviews IMO. Finished with coconut creme brûlée. Wish we had this place in DC!
author: Carrie D.

description:
I spent a week in SF, and wound up at The House twice. The reason being as follows: the seafood-centric menu is fantastic, the prices are very reasonable and they can accomodate large-ish groups (just be sure to make reservations ahead of time, and try to arrive together, as they won't seat you unless your whole party is there). 

Save for some less-than-palatable oysters that were taken away without question, my meals at The House were perfect. The space is small and somewhat plain in terms of decor, but the service it excellent and the food even better. I had an amazing tuna tartare app that was beautifully balanced and super-fresh - the crispy wontons it sat atop were light and fun to eat. We also shared a plate of dumplings that, while not so exciting on their own, were drizzled in a delicious ponzu sauce  - the perfect balance of salty and sweet with a citrusy note that sang. I went with a Chilean sea bass entree that was a special that evening, and I hope for your sake they bring it back for permanent placement on the menu - this thing had an outstanding sear and flavor to it that kept me eating long after I was full, and a side of garlic noodles with some sesame-soy dressing that was beyond compare. This dish was so good, I went ahead and got it for round 2 later that week. Yup. 

The wine and beer list are decent here, but not outstanding by any means. I had a Banshee Mordacai that, while a little bold, was a great accompaniment to the fish, and the table ordered a white and a rose that no one seemed that crazy about. Lesson: order the Mordacai. Order the fish (except for the oysters). Make reservations. Enjoy.
author: Hilary H.

description: Wasabi noodles with grilled salmon, I found my last meal on earth, well one of three...I'm going out on a three course meal! Ok, so first of all this place is slightly hidden so if It's your first time here make sure you have enough time to find it, and parking too. With reservations we were seated right away, small place but trust me it packs a big punch of flavorful dishes. Staff is super attentive and nice. Food is always consistent( been here a lot) and wait time for food is good. This is a gem in San Francisco, don't miss out and try it for yourself!
author: Prih C.

description:
Delicious.  I came here with a friend after hearing all the hype.  The place is cozy, a little too cozy.  Very small, should be renamed to "The Room".  Other than that, everything was great.  Service was attentive and they take reservations.  We got the calamari to start, which I must say, was the best calamari I've ever had.  She got the wasabi noodles with steak and I got the sea bass.  The noodles had a zest to it but wasn't overwhelming.  The sea bass was cooked perfectly and was complimented well by the greens and the sauce.  I was actually surprised the prices weren't that bad, considering it's in North Beach.  

I recommend this place!
author: Alex G.

description: This is one of our favorite restaurants in SF.  Every dish is excellent, we have tried everything in the menu and the flavors are outstanding.  Our only wish is if it weren't so difficult to get in.
author: Sandhya K.

description:
Grilled Sea Bass lives up to the hype! I'm an avid rice guy - but definitely get the Garlic Ginger Soy Noodles with this one instead.. 

Black Cod Special topped with California Rolls was just as delicious.. both had melt-in-your-mouth goodness! Fresh + cooked and tasted just right..

Deep-fried Salmon Roll was so-so.. probably wouldn't get it again..

I was hesitant to go with the Mango Tapioca for dessert.. I grew up with heavenly tasting ripe mangoes from the Philippines and can't help but compare every time.. but this one actually reminded me of the staple dessert they'd serve after your meal at Chinese restaurants back there.. still not as good.. but a solid effort! If you want dessert - go with this one.. otherwise, not a huge loss if you skip it (unlike the two fish dish must-haves!)..

Expect cramped spaces and a loud atmosphere (guys couple tables down had the most obnoxious ear-piercing voices ever.. if my fork wasn't too busy with the yummy food I probably would've hurled it at his face Brad-Pitt-with-spear-Troy style!) 

Definitely make reservations.. Otherwise, no biggie.. leave your number, walk around, and they'll call when your table's ready..
author: Ram L.

description:
I have no idea why this restaurant is getting the high marks that it is.  My dining experience here the other night will go down as one of the worst, and I'll never go back.  Our server didn't get to our table to greet us for at least 15 minutes, by then she tells us the specials but says we probably already decided on something else.  Our starter caesar salad we split came with one serving spoon left on the table with two side plates that were warm (not chilled) and so old they looked like they belonged on the buffet line at sizzler.  My ribeye was so grizzly, the only way it was even edible was because they pounded the hell out of it before they cooked it.  The server never once came by to check on us.  I can go on and on, but I won't.

This restaurant was recommended to us by a previous employee that opened a Thai restaurant in the north shore of oahu.  He did an amazing job serving us so we thought we'd get similar service here. Not!!!

As a person with over 15 years of fine dining experience, I know what a high class restaurant should be, and this is not one.  Thomas Keller would throw up if he ever ate here.  There are too many better places to dine.  Don't spend your money here.  It's not worth it.
author: Mark M.

description: Ate here on a Friday night without a reservation. We got very lucky! They took our name and said they would seat us in half an hour, which they did! The place is tiny but that makes for a cozy environment and it's got a good vibe, with people buzzing all around you. The food is absolutely delicious. This placed completely lived up to the hype! The flavors were exotic, flavorsome and spot on. I got the wasabi noodles with flank steak, can't recommend that enough. We ordered the salmon rolls for an appetizer, which were ok. Probably wouldn't order those again. They have a decent wine list and its a great place for small groups or a date. I plan on going back several times, but will make a reservation next time.
author: Mita P.

description:
Our last meal in San Fran during our 5 day visit.... no regrets.
The decor was simple and unpretentious, the service was stellar and the food delicious. I would definitely visit again on my next trip!

I was impressed with their beer selection (not a large list, but great choices) and had a Chimay red. The SO had a lychee iced tea that he wasn't as impressed with - I suspect he was supposed to mash up the one lychee to get the lychee taste, but he didn't want one mashed up lychee. Would have been better if had 2 or 3.

For appetizers, we ordered the scallops and the salmon roll. Both were tasty and we were quite pleased with them! As for mains, he got the sea bass (which lives up to all the reviews on yelp) and I got the wasabi noodles.

MY BIG ADVICE: DO NOT order the salmon roll AND the wasabi noodles. Firstly, the salmon roll comes with a wasabi-based dipping sauce, so I couldn't even taste the wasabi in the wasabi noodles (until I cleared my palate with some of his white rice). Secondly, the slaw that comes with the salmon roll is the same slaw that comes on top of the steak on the wasabi noodles. This was actually pretty disappointing - as good as the slaw was, I was ready for something a bit different and I felt like this was an opportunity for the chef to present something new. 

I guess there was one regret ... I should have gone with the pork chop =/ But all in all, it was great fusion food (and I'm pretty picky when it comes to Asian fusion)
author: Stephanie W.

description: The salmon rolls were overrated. There wasn't anything special about that particular appetizer. I loved the sea bass dish with the garlic noodles. It was delicious! The scallop appetizer would be something I would come back for because they cooked to perfection.
author: Monica L.

description:
I was never a big fan of Asian Fusion cuisine. My friends and I heard good things about this placed and I gave it a tried.  Making a reservation is the best thing that you can do for yourself. This place is always packed. Our reservation was for 8pm and we were seated around that time.  I expected a little bit more out of the ambiance.  The tables were very close to one another and I felt like I was have dinner with the table right next to me the whole time. 

Appetizer: The friend calamari was very dry and tasteless.  I had better calamari at the Cheesecake Factory

Entrée: I had the flank steak with wasabi noodles. My steak was medium rare and it tasted really rubbery.  The wasabi noodles were drench in oil and were not very pleasant.  On the other hand, my friend's grilled sea bass was seasoned and cooked perfectly.  My sister had the lamb chops and she thought that I was ok. 

Ambiance: The place is very small with a bunch of tables right next to each other.  

Service: The service was horrible. I had to ask to ask to get my water refill every single time.  And every time, the waitress forgets and I had to go get it myself.

Our biggest mistake was coming in here expecting a WOW factored.  We merely walked out with disappointment.
author: Christina T.

description: Great food.Service was really good. Order the steak and noodles. We also order the scallops for an app, and they were out of this world. It's also great that you can order delicious teas with dinner.
author: Trilla D.

description: Went for lunch, had a reservation.  The space is small, but they don't rush you.  The food was  amazing.  I had the wasabi noodles with pork, with a hamachi sashimi appetizer.  I will definitely be back.
author: Alexandra M.

description:
This place lives up to all the reviews.  Everything was great to awesome!  I'm sure I'm not contributing anything new so I'll keep it short.  

The sea bass was cooked perfectly.  I have never had a sea bass that was cooked to perfection like that.  It was like butter.   Hands down the best dish of the night.  Just pure awesomeness!

On any other night the flank steak with wasabi noodles would have been the star but against the sea bass it takes a distant second.  

mmmm....sea bass.....mmmmmm
author: henry h.

description: It lives up to its ratings, great food and service.  The black cod special was outstanding, as was the salmon.  The crab cake small dish is also very unique with a little wasabit sauce.  The service and knowledge of the servers was also excellent.
author: David J.

description: I will just start by saying this was one of the best meals I ever had the pleasure of eating:) The House is a one of a kind, asian fusion restaurant that is a must try when in the city. Every dish comes out looking beautiful and has the taste to match! We took our friends from out of town here so got four appetizers to share: the deep fried salmon rolls, Maine crab cake, asparagus, and the barbecued pork rib special. They were all amazing but I have to say the salmon roll was probably my favorite. For our entrées I had the ahi tuna and it was absolutely delectable! My boyfriend had the warm wasabi house noodles and he loved it. Everything we ordered was so good and flavorful! And our waitress was so sweet, the service was great. Just make sure you make a reservation, it's a smaller restaurant.
author: April C.

description: Delicious.  I ate there alone and had a wonderful warm kale salad and then a braised pork shoulder in a spicy sauce.  Staff were friendly and attentive. Highly recommended.
author: Michael U.

description:
The House has Very Good Food. Small place but worth stopping in to eat.
They have a Nice way of putting dishes together for Great Flavors. I'll be back.
author: Woody W.

description:
I've heard so many good things about The House for the longest time (mostly the 4.5 stars averaged over 1700 reviews) and finally got to come try it a couple nights ago. The venue is indeed pretty small, but gives you a more intimate and cozy feeling....kinda like your house! Perfect for small parties or a date, Definitely make reservations!

The food was amazing. I've always enjoyed asian fusion but this place definitely highlights how great it can be. We got the ahi tuna tartare and seared scallops with caviar that were both amazing. Entree wise, we got the wasabi noodles w/flat iron steak cooked medium rare to perfection, and also the black cod as their special. Debated on whether to try the seabass or the cod and I'm definitely glad that I chose the cod. It was so soft and buttery, just amazing! I also loved the veggies and the longest ever california roll that went with it. Everything was cooked to perfection. The cold sake was also a great accompaniment to the seafood meal, and the service was also fantastic throughout.

Of course, can't forget the dessert! Got the dark chocolate truffle cake with coffee ice cream, which was great but I must admit dessert isn't their highlight. Definitely would come back again in the future =)
author: Louisa L.

description:
OBSESSED - This place is amazing. I've been three times and have never been let down. When they make something with truffle - DAMN. I would recommend ordering whatever they recommend. This place is delicious and not to be missed. 

Perfect place for a date. Great service. Good vibes and amazing food. Love the fish and the chicken dishes. Highly recommend!
author: Danielle G.

description:
I'm not sure what everyone's raving about. Sure, the deep fried Salmon rolls were tasty and the Apple Pie was the "best thing in the meal," but that's not really a complement.

The clam chowder tasted OK but the main course seabass had none of the signature butteriness due to overcooking. The flank steak, between being under cooked and gristly, made the table jump whenever we tried to cut through it. The pile of garlic and wasabi noodles lacked flavor and felt a bit greasy.

Maybe it was was an off night, but three of five dishes missed the mark, including the two mains. I won't be back unless someone else is paying.
author: Alexander J.

description: The House is one of the best restaurant that I have tried in the bay area.  I rarely choose pork chop at a restaurant cause usually it is not good.  Well, I  had my pork chop at the house... 5 stars!  It was delicious... well worth the money.  The wasabi house noodle was awesome... overall everything is 4.5 - 5 stars for this place. The restaurant  is very small so remember to make reservation or else it would be a loooong  wait (1 to 2 hrs).
author: Evelyn W.

description: Excellent asian fusion food. Love their decoration!
author: Gong L.

description:
The House may very well be the upset winner of our recent San Francisco trip. Asian fusion can really be a question mark of a category, but this place nailed it.

We came here for lunch, and just to be safe, called ahead to get a reservation. We were seated promptly, and were given some delicious cucumber pickles (hint: save half of these to clear your palate at the end of your meal).

We ordered the warm wasabi noodles with salmon. The noodles had a nice kick, and the veggies tossed in gave the bed a nice crunch. The salmon was seasoned and cooked perfectly--really moist. 

We also tried the grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy. It came with a side of flash-fried green beans which were amazingly flavorful. The noodles were similar to our other dish in form, but had a sweeter flavor, instead of spicy. As for the sea bass itself: wow. Again, it was cooked to perfection with a nice crust on the outside, and a firm, yet juicy center. We didn't really use the black bean sauce on the side, as the meal had enough flavor without it, and could really stand on its own.

The House really knows how to cook a piece of fish. We were really impressed, and definitely recommend it!
author: Safford B.

description:
Pros:
Amazing food, fresh fish cooked in delightful and novel presentations, and great service. 

Cons:
It is hard to get a table many times but at least you can make reservations!

Fun:
There was a super-waiter there, I don't know if he is still there, but his name is Ozzy and he is amazing.  Somehow he can serve the whole restaurant and not get stressed for a moment, remaining friendly and attentive and I ran into him on the bus and found out he also goes to school.  Impressive.
author: Mike G.

description:
This place is outstanding! The only reason I'm giving a 4 is because I just reviewed Gary Danko and gave it a 5 and they are not exactly the same experience. I think for the type of food you're going for here and restaurants at the same level this place deserves 5 stars. 
Reservations are highly recommended. 

My husband and I went here for a birthday dinner. I had called ahead and they had a little candle placed in the dessert for him at the end of the dinner. 
Very reasonably priced for excellent food and service. Our waitress was fantastic!
The ahi tuna app was good. 
The kobe beef app was a special and was out of this world. 
Like other reviews the sea bass was perfection. I got it with the garlic noodles and LOVED it. 
The ribeye was excellent, nice cut of beef and very flavorful. 

Dessert: what I also love about this place is that they had phenomenal dessert options! We got the key lime pie...delish! 

I can't wait to go back!!
author: Anne D.

description: Wow, what a great little find. The House is a gem. It's a super small space packed with lots of cool, young sophisticated people. Lots of young asian 20 somethings who look like they all have macs at home and who are super critical about their food. The House has extremely flavorful, seasoned entrees, many served with what seems to be their trademark, thick homemade round noodles. I had a stellar chicken breast over curry noodles... rich and comforting. My partner had ribeye over round noodles with kind of a rich, wasbi-ish sauce. Decadent and awesome. You will not be disappointed.
author: Ari R.

description:
This is definitely a must go to place in San Francisco. Quality food at a decent price. Although the parking situation is horrendous (took me 40 minutes to parking on a Friday night), I will definite book another reservation in the near future (I'd probably muni next time). Lunch selections didn't seem that bad either...

Appetizers:
Salmon roll-probably the best appetizer they have available. Seasoned well and jammed pack with flavor. The skin was toasted well-thick enough for the crunch but thin enough to not overpower the meat.
Crab cake-not very notable. But wasn't bad either.
Clam-delicious sauce that can be used to for the bread. The mussels were huge too.

Entree:
Wasabi noodles and flat iron steak-one of the cheaper entree items and is definitely worth to try. Portion is decent and the quality isn't half bad.
Sea bass- probably the best sea bass I've ever had. Moist, buttery, and cooked to perfection.

Be sure to make reservations to avoid lines!
author: Jason K.

description:
My friend and I went on a Tuesday night without a reservation and after 20-25 minutes, we were seated. It was kind of crowded inside but the setting is definitely very cozy and intimate.

Drinks:
+Lychee Black Iced Tea
You need to add a lottttt of sugar in it to get some sweetness in this. The lychee itself was okay and my friend questioned the freshness of it but I think next time, I'll just stick to water.

Appetizers:
+The Scallop Special
I CAN NOT stop raving about the scallops!!! They were literally the BEST SCALLOPS I have ever had! The texture was amazing and the sauce was divine. I'd order this every time, no hesitations. 

+The Baby Octopus Salad 
I thought there weren't enough octopi? and too much crispy pork rinds. It was good, but i think I'll pass on this next time.

Entrees:
+Wasabi Noodles with Flatiron Steak
This was AMAZINGGG. I loveeee spicy foods and this dish definitely hit the spot. It wasn't too greasy and the wasabi wasn't overwhelming at all! We ordered the flatiron steak medium and it was perfectly cooked, still intact with that gorgeous red in the center. Delicious!

Dessert:
+Chocolate Cake with Coffee Ice cream and a Coconut Caramel Sauce
The chocolate cake was very rich but the coffee ice cream complimented it nicely.

+Mango Tapioca
The mango tapioca was not my thing at all. It looked gorgeous but I was just not a fan. My friend, however, loved it.

Service was on point! Will definitely come back but definitely would try making a reservation next time since it seems we got lucky with getting a table that fast.
author: Eileen Z.

description:
We ate there on Christmas eve and it was packed even for our 5pm reservation. I liked everything about The House! They opened on time, seated us, and gave us a list of numerous daily specials (would be nice if they printed it or put on a board) as well as the menu. There are so many dishes there I would like to try, it will require multiple visits.  The wait staff is friendly and efficient and they didn't blink when we asked to substitute salmon for flatiron steak in the noodles dish. The barbecued oysters special was out of this world, and the salads were crisp and dressed just right. The entree was excellent, salmon cooked perfectly!  We had a special desert too - a pumpkin pie with macadamia nuts and it was fantastic.

I just wish they'd lease the empty space next door to make it a little bigger, but then again, I'd hate to disturb the operation of this perfect little restaurant.
author: Jake J.

description:
Who needs another review with 2000+ right? But after I read the first few, I disagreed and thought I'd put my 2 cents in. 

Tuna tartare: good but very wasabi intense.
Salmon roll: delicious & cooked well (super soft in middle) wrapped in seaweed and deep fried, ... but pricey. Maybe not worth it. 
Pork chop: WINNER!!! My dish and SO GOOD. Huge portion and with sweet pom sauce.. Dine mate agreed was also the most aesthetically pleasing of all the dishes. 
Ribeye: Good. standard. 
Sea Bass: overrated. Don't understand the hype. Noodles were salty, green beans limp and lifeless. 
Halibut with orzo (special): okay as well. Creamy orzo. 

No cod special tonight. 

Wait is long-ish (45 minutes @ 730p on wed night, no ressies) but food comes out SUPER fast. Waitress are fast and efficient, if not sugary friendly.
author: Christine Y.

description:
I totally forgot but THE HOUSE was where I dined at for Senior Prom back in 2003! Back then it was located on 9th between Irving St. and Lincoln Way. Now the place is called Kiki's (Japanese Restaurant, same owner as Kitaro's on Geary). 

In any case, I was able to visit THE HOUSE this past Friday night and I can't believe I forgot about this restaurant! And I also can't believe it took me 6 years to come back to devour their awesome food. Mmm...

The place is a lot smaller than their 9th Ave location. There are about 10-15 tables in here and it's really narrow. Yes, I know what you're thinking -- MAKE RESERVATIONS!! We sat back near the kitchen so every time the door open, I saw flames go up. Way cool...but does anyone else notice the weird smell that comes breezing through? I'm not sure if its from the kitchen, the bathroom, or the servers? Shrug.

I read some reviews about the House before and I have to disagree with what everyone is saying about their not-so-great service. Either you guys are real snobs and beezies and want impeccable service or their service really sucked when you went, and got better the day I came. The server started off ranting off a bunch of their specials, and I was quite proud that she remember them all. Water was constantly refilled and our plates were constantly changed. This was awesome. Service was attentive. 5 stars for that.

COMPLIMENTARY VINEGAR CUCUMBER SLICES
Beware: VERY vinegar-ey. I choked on a piece since it was soooooo tangy but nonetheless it was very refreshing.

OYSTERS
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/I4eMNfxLsI5BMvysFiRhUQ/l
Not as good as Foreign Cinema's oysters but still AOK in my book. The sauce it came with was a mix of...you know what I have no clue. All I know it was spicy as F!! 6 raw oysters came on a plate.

SHRIMP DUMPLINGS
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/q4YbAsSRgKnXEvBA_RnvcQ/l
7 dumplings for $9? Sure, I guess. Kinda pricey for pretty well made dumplings but this is a must get dish for all you dumpling lovers. The shrimp wasn't mashed up into small pieces but it was a good sized chunk of shrimp in the dumpling. The chives in it were fresh. The skin was rolled thin and it was absolutely delicious. The sauce it came in was a mix of soy sauce, green onions, and a ton of vinegar. Yum.

SALMON ROLLS
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/-ccvyPaJI-lEb5PHM2Lm5g/l
o m gee. The House just put a new meaning to egg rolls. Screw egg rolls -- bring on the salmon rolls!! There are two pieces on this plate, perfect to eat by yourself or share with someone else. The salmon is fried to the point where it's half cooked -- PERFECT. The skin was fried crispy and you could barely taste the seaweed for all you non-seaweed fans. However, this dish did come with a Chinese mustard dipping sauce. It pretty much was a blend of spicy mustard and horseradish. Don't put too much on, it really gets you in the nose!!

Before I go onto the entrees that we ordered, I have to say that yes, 2 people did eat 3 appetizers, haha. Mmm after we finished these 3 dishes, we realized that The House is big on...
1. Horseradish
2. Vinegar

WASABI NOODLES & FLAT IRON STEAK
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/-nEQyBWDxUv4deRk4RYLUw/l
The steak was ok. It was steak. Meat. Cow. Steak. Yeah, nothing to rave about. But the wasabi noodles were off the hook! The noodles were chewy and of a good consistency. I was a bit turned off by the wasabi because I'm not a big fan of it but the amount of wasabi in this dish was just perfect. It didn't kick my ass nor did it completely leave me alone. I loved it. I picked out every piece of noodle until it was completely gone. Yum Yum Yum. 

BLACKENED COD WITH SUSHI (special for the night)
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/vN_cg1RyrpQkeUaF9GXncQ/l
The infamous Sushi. This was made long just like the salmon rolls and cut in a weird way, just like the salmon rolls. The sushi was really tasty. I dipped it in the sauce that the cod came in and it was good. The sauce was similar to unagi (eel) sauce but something was different. But OMG, the cod. OMG. OMG. OMG. OMG. Melted in my mouth like butter. It was so soft, cooked to perfection. I don't even think my mom can cook fish that good. Damn, the house threw it down as far as the cod goes.

Damage done: $76.50 pre-tip
(Oh and the bill here is handwritten. On it, our waitress denoted our Shrimp Dumplings as "DUMPY." I laughed for a good minute or two. Cute!)

SUMMARY:
Service was attentive. No complaints.
Food was orgasmic...I mean delightful.
Salmon Rolls are a MUST order.
Reservations needed and highly recommended!!
The House is newly dubbed as one of my favorite restaurants in SF.
The House deserves to be my 300th review on Yelp. Woop!

(More pictures uploaded)
author: Heidi C.

description:
Love. Love. LOVE !

Everything was phenomenal ! The wine, the appetizers, the entrees, the service -- it was all exceptional. 

We ordered a special they had as one of our appetizers. It was a grilled calamari with something on top that made the dish look like it was movinggg ! It was a pretty exciting experience ! You must try it. Plus, the dish was full of smokey goodness ! The other starter we got was the deep fried salmon. GET IT. End of story.

For my main dish, I got the Wasabi Noodles with a Flatiron Steak, cooked medium-rare. The noodles were just the right texture and flavor, and the steak was cooked to perfection ! No condiments necessary because everything was seasoned so well.

The bf's entree was the Rib-eye steak cooked medium rare. It was total M&M's status. The steak literally melted in your mouth ! SO yummy. 

The portions were also gigantic. We could have shared and topped it off with dessert at the end, but of course we didn't think things through until it was too late. Oh well.

We'll be back, we promise ! We're determined to try every plate at least once. (:
author: Paulina N.

description: We were happy to be able to eat here, pretty difficult to get in. Service was great. Loved the scallops. Maybe the most delicious I have ever had. The tempura green beans were good and plentiful but nothing crazy amazing. The shrimp dumplings a bit fishy. Loved my halibut and black cod (though a bit too much wasabi flavor on the cod). All in all a very delicious meal. Be sure to get the garlic noodles. Super yummy.
author: Jack S.

description:
Uninspired. 

Perhaps I ordered the wrong thing. Friend had the hamachi which was the special of the day. Wife had the chicken dish with truffle oil. I had the grilled sea bass with noodles. 

Men. I've experienced better. 

And they sat us at 6:10 and said we needed to go by 7 pm.
author: Joe O.

description: So this was a special post dinner for us and the wait was expected to be 45mins to an hour without reservations. We didn't mind of course. We ordered a bottle of champange rose to quench our thirst. For appetizers, we ordered raw oysters on the half shells, fried calamari, seared scallops, and the unagi roll. For the main dish, we shared the wasabi noodle. We didn't order dessert because we were too full. The food was AMAZING... Every single bite i had was so delish and it all just made me say mhmmmmmm!!! LoL
author: Anji W.

description: I LOVE LOVE LOVE THEIR SEARED SCALLOPS!!!!! They are very flavorful and it just melts in your mouth. Small cute restaurant that gets full fast. Best to make reservations. If you dont have reservations, the wait is usually 45min to an hour. I also had their seabass with the noodles and the portions are generous and it's so good. Can't wait to go back!
author: Ella A.

description:
At first, I thought that The House was a little bit out of place in the Italian district, but it definitely holds it down when it comes to taste!

I went with a group of friends who suggested this place over E & O Trading Company. There was a bit of a wait on a Friday night, but I found it completely worth it!

The deep-fried salmon roll was a delicious appetizer! I'm definitely ordering it again when I'm back in SF. The sauce that came with it was the perfect pairing, just be prepared for a little heat! 

The crab cakes were perfect, but a little hard to share. 

I ordered the Angus Steak with Wasabi Noodles, and to say that it did not disappoint would be a wild understatement. The texture of the meat was exactly what I wanted for a medium rare cook. I picked little bites off of my friends' plates, and the Sea Bass and the Pomegranate Pork Chops, were both amazingly delicious. I really don't think it's possible to go wrong with the choices at this place!
author: Lesley-Anne L.

description:
Oh man, this place is dinky!  So make sure to place a reservation before you come. 
Other than that, the food is awesome.  

My girlfriend and I started out with the deep fried salmon rolls.  I can see why it's a popular item, since the crispiness was just right, and the salmon was of good size.  Interestingly, the mustard dipping sauce that accompanied the rolls was probably my favorite part.  It had a great tangy but spicy taste to it as well (probably had wasabi).

For the main course, I ordered the Kurobuta Pork Chop W/ Pomegranate Currant Sauce.  The Pomegrante sauce was heavenly.  It was savory, but had a citrus and meaty taste.  Unfortunately the Pork Chop was a bit overcooked and a bit too chewy, but the sauce made up for it.  My girlfriend ordered the duck with a blackberry reduction.  Her duck was cooked a lot better than my pork chop, but the blackberry reduction wasn't as great as the pomegrante sauce.  

Whoever the Saucier is at The House, is really talented.
author: John S.

description: There was a line out the door 15 minutes before they opened! It was worth it though - great food and service. It was a bit loud but manage-able.
author: Rita C.

description:
We walked in at ~6:30pm without a reservation and were seated in a matter of minutes - spare table in the back in the midst of a full house, YAY!

The House really is a pleasant little surprise; located in an area full of late night drunk food and strip clubs, The House sits idly. Its a very small restaurant (like all SF restaurants), and has very limited seating - they suggest you make a reservation a month in advance in order to avoid waiting, but thankfully we got there at the time that we did since a line did start to form once we were seated.

The House's specialty is seafood, with an Asian Fusion flair. The menu at The House seems to change every now and then in order to fit whats in season, but also with 4-5 daily specials and a few staples (i.e. wasabi noodles, sea bass, kurobuta pork chop, etc.). Going off suggestions from Yelp reviews, we went with their specials and their tried and true wasabi noodles.

Special Appetizer; Scallops w/ micro greens (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZoZjbOYR-apY8XvommlNUA?select=_eLbj9i0_JeCAaekB8W9Xw)
I have never been a huge fan of scallops, with the exception of in my sushi... but my boyfriend loves them so we went for their crispy scallop special that night. OH.EM.GEE. these were the best scallops I've ever had - and the dish definitely became my favorite of the night! The scallops were cooked perfectly - not a hint of rubberiness, just perfect/delicate break-with-your-fork butteriness. They sat in a pool of this most devine heart-clenching sauce, with a small mound of micro-greens to cut the butteriness... each bite was surreal. If you happen to be at The House when this is on the menu - GET IT; you'll thank me later... 5 stars.

Special Appetizer; Big Eye Tuna sashimi (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZoZjbOYR-apY8XvommlNUA?select=SFv4ba3WHk_rNhltYwrtYA)
It was difficult to navigate our way through this dish, but it was enjoyable - hard to compete with coming after the scallops though... 3.5 stars.

Special Request; Seasonal Fish (Mahi Mahi) w/ Wasabi Noodles (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZoZjbOYR-apY8XvommlNUA?select=ueV5otOBb6fXS9bQOH7tBQ)
YESSSSS, they take special requests! I don't remember how they said they were serving their seasonal fish that night, but it wasn't with their wasabi noodles... so we kindly asked if they would make it like so, and they said yes - yay! The mahi mahi was cooked perfectly, and topped with a nice and tangy salad of pickled onions - which I wish there was more of -  helped to cut the butteriness of the dish. The noodles (udon style) were the perfect thickness and cooked just right, though the taste of wasabi was not very prevalent - A-OK with me, since I'm too weak-sauce for strong wasabi taste anyway, but it did make the noodles less impression-lasting. They also gave us some of their ginger soy sauce (which typically comes with their sea bass w/ wasabi noodles dish) on the side, even though it was totally unneeded since the dish was already perfectly seasoned/sauced. Overall a great LARGE dish, perfect to share between 2-3 people, though nothing extraordinary that I felt I couldn't find anywhere else... 4 stars.

I am typically wary of Asian Fusion, but this was overall a great experience with exceptionally prepared food and caring/accommodating service. Prices are reasonable for the size and quality, plus atmosphere is dim and easy going - perfect for dates or just nights out. I can't wait to come back - I really want to try their deep-fried chicken liver salad and their lunch menu, unagi avocado sandwich :D
author: Lana N.

description: OVERRATED x 2.  Known for their wasabi noodles and the sea bass.  The wasabi noodles was interesting as the steak was cooked beautifully but the sea bass, really?  If this is one of the items that San Franciscans think its amazing, I have no words to say.  The best dish all nite was the daily special appetizer of seared scallops w. a lemon ponzu vinaigrette.  SOOOO good, we ordered another.  I was really excited for this meal but the culmination of the whole night made me disappointed from the debbie downer waitress to rushed service to bad sake to overrated food.   I just wanted to get out ASAP.  The main issue I have w. this place is the menu takes on this modern and pretentious appeal but the ambiance and understaffed service negates the whole theme.
author: Ricky C.

description:
After a long day of walking around downtown, my sister and I were hungry!  I called in and the only reservation they had was for 10pm.  We walked by to see what the estimated wait time would be and we were told about 30-45 minutes.  Perfect timing for us to go home, drop off our things and come back out.  We stood at the door for less than a minute before they seated us.  This was probably my 4th time dining here.  I am always happy with the service and their knowledge of the food.  The servers always have the specials memorized (usually a list of 4 starters and 3 entrees).

STARTER:  We choose the ahi tuna tartare for our starter.  It was okay.  I love the roasted nori chips that it came on.  Should have tried the kobe steak tartare instead, but I kept thinking that I'd rather go back to BIX for a great steak tartare.

ENTREE:  The first 3 times I always had the black cod.  It's THAT GOOD.  But then they didn't mention it as a special tonight so it provided me with the opportunity to try something different.  I decided to try their warm wasabi house noodles with the angus flatiron steak.  I really enjoyed the little spicy taste that came with the wasabi noodles and the steak was cooked perfectly.  My sister had the halibut in a curry sauce.  She liked it a lot, especially the garnish on top.  It was like fried shredded carrots or something.

DESSERT:  We shared the coconut creme brulee with passion fruit puree and the chocolate espresso bread pudding with vanilla ice cream.  The coconut creme brulee was divine.  Super creamy, which went great with the layer of crunchy sugar.  I personally could have done without the passion fruit puree, but it's perfect for those who like tart desserts.  The bread pudding was more like a cake.  It was super soft and went well with the vanilla ice cream.

Reservations are a must for larger groups.  If you don't have reservations and have a party of 2-4, I recommend to walk in, leave your name and number (usually a 30-60 minute wait) head up to the King of Thai on the corner and enjoy some $2 draft beers or $6 shots/cocktails while you wait.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco hands down. 

The almost 1800 reviews don't lie, and i don't have to speak much about this place as most of the work has been done for me.  

What I will say is that i highly recommend getting reservations here, the way i see it, if a place offers reservation, why not do it and avoid any hassle and/or potential waiting. 

The reason why I love The House so much is that you know whatever you order will be solid and the prices are very reasonable. I hate eating at a restaurant and feeling like my meal is a small piece of art, with 3 dots of sauce and a splash of this and a smudge of that with a tiny piece of meat in the center that i'm suppose to call my main course.  With that said, the dishes at The House are not only beautifully presented, but generously portioned as well; imagine that! 

Appetizers: $6-12 

I highly recommend the crab cake and the oysters if they have them 

Entree: $14-22 

The pork chops w/ pomegranate sauce is amazing, i'm not a fan of ordering pork chops, but the pork chop at The House is extremely tender, melt in your mouth. quite amazing.

I usually order the steak whenever i come and it never disappoints, comes out perfect medium rare just the way i ordered it, very flavorful with a great crust on it.  perfection, and for about $25 you can't go wrong. 

I always have a great experience whenever i come to The House and i try to take my friends whenever i get the opportunity.  You not only leave full and satisfied, but you won't have to pick up three extra shifts just to pay it off.  Perfect location to go out after dinner also. 5 solid stars!
author: Randy N.

description:
I would have given it 41/2 if i could, but i can't so 5 stars it is. This place has great food and that's what i love, great food. 
Kobe beef with black truffle reduction- Superb! Steak was cooked perfectly and the flavor of the steak was great and the truffle reduction matched the steak with just the right flavor, the mashed potato was a bit dry and lacked thoughtfulness.
Wasabi Noodle with Flatiron steak- Awesome! Steak was cooked well and the wasabit noodle is one of the best items at the place, not too spicy and the flavoris very special.
The appetizers were also very good.
I would say try everything if you had enough people, each item has its unique strengths, depending on your likings.

The only half star is the location and size. I called in to make a reservation because you can't make reservations online and they asked me for a credit card to make a reservation, which was also a first for me. Secondly I've been here a couple of times and there are always bums and weird people walking around, obviously because its located near a filthy area. Lastly they included gratuities in the bill for a group of 6 people. I thought it was for 8 or more people unless the specify, which i don't think they did or wrote it anywhere. haha i know i might be nit picking at small things, but its just FYI. I still gave this place a 5 stars tho, =)
author: Nicholas C.

description:
We took a chance of not having a reservation and went for it.  Although we ended up waiting for almost 30 minutes, we got seated at about 8:30.  There were a few tables where the reservations were a no show, lucky for us!

The waitress seemed a little stress out but she was still friendly and polite.  We sat next to the entrance so we got the gush of cold air whenever the door opened.  The food came out promptly despite it being a full house.  My friend ordered the pork chops, I ordered their steak and my other friend had a couple of appetizers.  

The food was absolutely delicious!  The pork chops were cooked nicely with no dry spots around the edges (I hate that) and perfectly glazed with a delicious sauce.  My steak was perfectly cooked to my temperature of Med-Rare.  It was slightly crispy on the outside and soft and chewy on the inside, perfect!  The appetizers were nicely presented also tasted good.  

This would've been an easy 5-stars but the staff seem short-handed and rushed.  But they did do a great job with the amount of people in the restaurant.  I would definitely visit this place again.  Thank you Yelp for the suggestion!
author: Hugh B.

description:
Now I can see why there's always a line out the door... everything on the menu was delightful... the atmosphere and ambiance is just right despite how small the place was (I guess some people like small places)...

We had the beef tartare/oysters/and chicken salad for starters and had the butterfish *drool* and steak for entree... 5 out of 5... if I had 2 stomachs I would have ordered one of each on the menu... oh Gluttony, thou art my favorite of all sins...

Top it off, our cute japanese waitress was very attentive and friendly... definitely worth the time and money...
author: Nathan D.

description:
We arrived at 5 pm tonight (after walking from pocket opera Yanked From the Harem) and were seated immediately. They bring a nice pickle dish to munch while deciding what to eat,
.
We had the crab and mussel chowder which was a special and it was great.  The white shrimp dumplings arrived at the same time, which they do here.   They really rush you.  I've had better dumplings, partner liked them more

We finished our appetizers and the main course came immediately. The fantastic pork chop with pomegranate sauce. I had the salmon roll and loved it

We were walking home at 5:50 p.m.   So you know it was fast.  I would recommend ordering one thing at a time.

We plan to go back because we enjoyed the food so much.
author: Foodlover B.

description: This is some damn good Asian Fusion... I've eaten at some of the best places in SF and LA and this is def up there. You must try the steak and the salmon appetizers.  Desserts are also great. My gf had the special "halibut" which was also great. It's a bit tight in there but I was able to get a table within 45 min of walking in. I just went down to north beach and had a couple of beers and came back.
author: Ed L.

description:
One word: AMAZING!!! Everything from the presentation of the food to the quantities to the taste was impressive. 

I went with a group of friends; we were 6 altogether. So we got to sample quite a few dishes. We started with 2 appetizers: blue lake bean tempura with pickled ginger soy and the soft shell crab tempura (a special not on the menu). Both were yummy, yet if I had to pick one it would be the bean tempura. The crab tempura may have been a little hard to share because there were 6 of us. 

I ordered skate as my main dish, which came with cauliflower and mashed potatoes. I ate every last bite of this dish! It was excellent. Note: it was a special that night and not on the regular menu. My friends ordered: the mushroom rice with grilled prawns, scallops with orzo (special), and three ordered the grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy. I got to sample each of these dishes. The sea bass was "melt in your mouth" delicious. The scallops, which is one of my favorite sea food dishes, were wonderful as well. And you can't go wrong with the prawns.

Finally, we ordered 2 desserts. Yea, we had a feast! We ordered the apple pie and the chocolate cake with coffee ice cream on top. Our table favored the warm apple pie. Wow, I'm still thinking about it!

Only one minor, yet not such a big deal, issue, is that we were seated later than our reservation, which was at 8:30PM (on a Saturday). Must have been about 15 minutes late or so. It was worth the wait!
author: Rebeca D.

description:
I want to move to San Francisco just so I can eat the Seabass. It was probably one of the best things I've ever ate in my entire life. I'm drooling just thinking about it.
I can't even describe how good it is cuz no words seems worthy!

4 star because its a bit pricey :/
the place is TINY so make sure you call in to reserve a table!

Enjoy it :) I did!!
author: Ney L.

description:
Even though I have dined here since the mid nineties, The House is still one of my favorite places. Their staff is always friendly, food is always spot on and my favorites are still:

Blue Lake String beans
Sea Bass
Ribeye
Black Cod (when available)
Mango Tapioca Pudding
Bread Pudding (when available)

I have recommended this restaurant to countless friends, family and even tourist so I hope that if you have not visited The House yet that you will soon!
author: Ed N.

description:
How could I not try this place after seeing over 2000 reviews & such good ratings?? What a wonderful find...thank you fellow yelpers!! Be warned - this place is small and a little cramped & reservations are a must. Came here Saturday night & the place was packed but was pleased that we were seated right away.
