I did not think I was going to like this place.
I don't really like North Beach (too touristy and fake) and parking is a nightmare, especially on St. Patrick's Day.

I figured "great, another overpriced Asian Fusion tourist trap".  But, friends had arranged a dinner here, so I went along with the plan.

You know what?  The service was terrific, and the food was excellent.  Appetizers were pretty good but not exceptional.  Most of my dining companions had fish, but I wisely chose the signature porkchop with pomegrante sauce.  Never before have I spoken to my food, but I leaned over to my entree and whispered "You had me at hello..."

But then I had dessert.  Oh my.  I don't remember exactly what it was, but it's off the menu and reads something like "chocolate wahwahwahwah with wahwahwah-wahwahwah ice cream."

I leaned into my dessert dish and sighed "You complete me."
author: dan s.

description:
Ok, before I get started on this review, please note that it takes A WHOLE LOT for me to take time out my busy schedule to write/blog a review and I am a "very-very picky person" (says my bf and family), so here it goes...

First time here, I ordered the Ribeye ($23) along with the steamed mussels ($10). Can I say that they were both outstanding. I've never had mussels as delicious and soft and delicate like this one. Usually, I am kind of hesitant with ordering seafood when I'm dining out, but I am more than glad that I took a chance on these steamed mussels. It literally melts in your mouth. That was finished in less than 3 minutes!
The ribeye- oh, where should I start? I am a meat and steak lover, had steak/beef almost everywhere you can imagine, but here, here is different. The ribeye was so soft and moist (had it well-done) and just melted away on my tongue. How else can I describe it? It was the best piece of meat I've ever had. 

My bf had the fried salmon rolls ($10) and he loved it. I, however, had a taste and didn't like it much. It wasn't bad, but TO ME, it tasted like any other salmon, but maybe because I am not a fan of salmon. My bf called me "F*ing crazy" when I told him how I felt about it som don't let my opinion of the salmon stop you from trying it.

Came in for lunch the other day and had the flat iron steak ($15) that came with mustard greens, mashed potatoes and some kind of delicious sauce. Hands down, my favortie dish! I admit, at first my heaert sank when I realized that the steak was sliced instead of whole because I figured it'll be dry. However, as soon as I stabbed my knife and fork in it, my heart was up and pumping again! So delicious and again, it just melted in my mouth. So tender and juicy and the sauce, the mashed, and the greens just compliments it. 

The bf has the pork loin sandwich ($9) which he said was good, but not great... obviously, because he digged right in my plate as soon as he was finished with his. 

I've been dying to try the grilled sea bass($25-27) which LOOKED super delish.

NOTE: Highly recommend that you make reservations before you come or else you'll be drooling over people's food while waiting.
author: Charisma C.

description:
Definitely need to make a reservation to eat here. Call for reservation.

will order again:
oysters on a half shell - fresh with spicy mignonette 
deep fried salmon roll - cooked on outside, medium raw on inside
sea bass with garlic ginger soy - well-cooked, with noodles and green beans

questionable:
coconut creme brulee with passion fruit puree on top - the passion fruit was way to tangy and overpowered everything else.

For a group of 5, I don't know if I felt like they were rushing us or trying to be efficient. We were out the door in just under an hour. More likely, all of us were extremely hungry haha. Another note, it was hard for me to hear all the specials from our server due to the noise and her accent. I would suggest printing them out on a dedicated specials menu since there's about 6-7 of them. Other than that, a good meal
author: Dennis L.

description: Kurobuta pork chop was amazing. We also had a Kale salad, the deep-fried Salmon roll, and the Bittersweet chocolate truffle cake. Great flavors and great service. Definitely would go back again when in the area.
author: Shayne T.

description: Can't remember what I had but do recall really enjoying my wife's seabass - which many others seem to rave about too. My dish was solid - but the seabass really stood out. Appetizers weren't really memorable. This place is pretty spendy for a pretty low-key joint...but definitely recommend a visit.
author: Sean S.

description:
I'd say this is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  I LOVE LOVE LOVE this place.  

Been here about 4-5 times and loved it every time!  I always order the same dish...the Grilled Sea Bass with Garlic Ginger Soy Veggies and Noodles.  This is probably one of my favorite dishes in the world!!  It never disappoints me and I finish it every time!  (I barely finish my dish all the time.)

I had my birthday dinner here last year and our table ordered almost every entree.  Got to try the ribeye (my boyfriend's favorite dish here), pork chop, and the blacken cod with sushi.  Everything was delicious and worth trying.

Last time I came with my boyfriend, we ordered the clam with okras appetizers.  I was a little disappointed on the dish since I usually have high expectations for this restaurant.  Think I can go without this appetizer next time.  For entrees, he ordered the night's special of the strip steak.  That was no disappoint either.  He said it might be his new favorite dish there. I'm no different - ordered the sea bass!

The restaurant itself is super small and the tables are really tiny.  The ambiance is dim lighting, but can get a bit loud among all the customers. You definitely need to make a reservation upon going and I highly recommend bringing friends along with you.
author: Nancy S.

description:
The House may very well be my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Since I live nearby, I come by for Saturday lunch almost every other weekend and it's a great way to start the day =p. 

I'm really writing this review so I have a record of different things I've eaten there. 

Deep-fried Salmon Rolls:
Two rolls of salmon wrapped in seaweed & deep-fried. Slice diagonally before serving for a stunning presentation. Spicy mustard, crunchy seaweed, and juicy salmon makes this an instant favorite. 

Uni Clam Chowder:
As a disclaimer, I like the earthy sweet taste of uni. As the waitress(who's awesome) put it, it's not going to change your mind about uni, but if you like it, this dish is for you. 

The uni goes phenomenally well with the clam chowder, I'm amazed at how well the two flavors go together. All the other ingredients are fresh and add different perspectives to the soup. When I bit into one of the small potato bits, I finally realized how much a simple potato can add to a dish

Grilled Seabass with Garlic Ginger Soy:
The seabass was well seasoned on it's own, so you must have some of it without the sauce first. However, once you dip it in the garlic ginger soy sauce, you really taste how the two flavors combine (like that scene in Ratatouille). Awesome!!!

Grilled Chinese Chicken Salad with Soy Vinaigrette:
Normally, I don't like salads, but the Asian-style grilled chicken goes superbly with the soy vinaigrette. Add in really tasty greens and you have a salad worth ordering.
author: Jeff L.

description:
Based on the rave reviews on Yelp, I expected it to be better.

First, the restaurant was super crowded for most of the evening -  we stayed there from 8 to closing.   It was loud.  The tables are small and there is little space to move around.  There was just one bathroom for men and women, which made it at times for a longer wait.  But considering it's North Beach, it would have been ok if the food had been fantastic.

The food was just ok. We ordered:

Appetizers:
fried calamari - a bit too crispy and not enough calamari with sauce that reminded me of Trader Joe's ketchup
octopus salad - you really need a microscope to find that octopus in the salad, although it was nicely seasoned
dumplings - the dough wrap was nice and thin, the filling was ok

Main Dish:
angus steak with wasabi noodles - very nice dish with interesting flavors
ahi tuna - it was good with tasty sauce and rice, also properly prepared
mushroom rice with shrimp - the shrimp was overcooked, and the rice was a bit too carroty for my taste

Desert was subpar:
The creme brulee was FROZEN.  When we complained the head waitress said that they make them ahead of time and they are all like this.  (She made us feel like there is something wrong with our taste buds.)  But honestly, i understanding making the cream part ahead of time, but the sugar crust needs to be done at the last moment.

Special persimmon cake/pudding - was a bit to sweet.  When I asked where do the persimmons come from, since it's not the season.  I got a blank stare... probably some overnight/pre-made crap again.

The mango tapioca was ok, but I found that it was a bit too lumpy.

Drinks:  an ok selection of wine and beer. great selection of green and other asian teas.

Overall, I would recommend sticking with the main dish and expecting a pleasant rather than a "wow" meal.
author: Dasha M.

description: Came here for my birthday with my fiancé, cozy place :) Reservations are a must because this place packs up! Really enjoyed the grilled sea bass and the steamed mussels. Flavors were wonderful, of course, asian fusion and the creativity that comes with it ;)
author: Cindy L.

description: Hungry for Garlic Wasabi noodles? Add salmon to it why don't you! This place may get packed for weekday lunch so plan with wisdom. It's Asian-fusion, artistic food and delicious!
author: Joanna V.

description:
So I read all the reviews before going to this place.  And they were mostly great.  Even after reading the not-so-good reviews, my husband,guest and I still decided to go.  THE FOOD IS AMAZING.  REally really great.  The reviews are accurate in saying that the place is really small and the furniture is cheap, but who cares?  I would do the same thing if I had a restaurant like this.  The food speaks for itself.  

The only downside I see is that the meals are small.  So for my husband, he was still hungry and the place isn't cheap so it's not easy to just order something else.
author: Jeanette M.

description:
This place is amazing. I've been here 3 times and I have no complaints. I also took an old friend here while he was visiting from LA.  He is a graduate of Le Cordon Bleu Pasadena. He also had a great experience. 

A few things:
1. The food is fresh and each core entrée item has 2 complimentary sides included on the plate that serve your taste buds well. For the foodies, I suggest tasting each item individually then all three together.  The individual taste and the blended taste are so different, but it's a great experience to say the least. 

2. The presentation of the food is pretty amazing. It not only taste fabulous, it's food art in my eyes.  

3. Another great "date" spot. 

4. The menu is small and controlled. The chefs know what they are doing and have mastered the menu. Since the menu is small and mastered, you are going to get a good meal out of this place no matter what you order. 

5. The space is very intimate, so if you are not a fan of tight seating, then I highly suggest getting over your phobia. The food is worth a visit. 

My only suggestion: Make reservations and don't be late. If you are running late, call in advanced. They are pretty accommodating.  This place is always crowded hence the location and the quality of food. At least on the weekends.  

Enjoy.
author: Rox T.

description: Food is awesome, nice service from the waitress and waiters, and the price is totally worth and acceptable.
author: Kevin P.

description:
I'm gonna cut right to the chase.  House is one of my favorite restaurants in the city and that is why I am giving it 5 stars, a rating saved exclusively for my faves.  

Just an FYI, pork shoulder = pork butt and it is amazing!!!  

I had the pork shoulder with enoki mushroom braise and it is last meal on earth good.  

Very small place with an average atmosphere, but I'm all about the food.

Try to make a reservation if you can.

(''') ^___^ (''')
author: Hansen L.

description:
I went here for the first time with my friend Sam because he is on a mission to try to replicate the "Wasabi Noodles" here. Its a very small venue. You are so close to your neighbors you might accidently fork their plate. If you are going to come try this place out definitely make reservations or you will be like us and have to togo it and eat in your car.

I had the white shrimp, avocado with green dish. There is nothing fancy or makes it stand out that I would have this dish again. It was seriously greens in a light vinaigrette and some deep friend shrimps on top of paper thin slices of apples and avocado with a mystery white sauce (not very typical in an Asian dish). I think that is what cause me to make my own sauce later.

My friend Sam got the Wasabi Noodle dish with chicken...maybe because it was in a brown togo box that made not want to try it but I did. It was quite good and made me wish I got the same dish.

I think it is the Asian in me but I don't like fancy Asian "Fusion" joints. If I am going to get some Korean Ribs or a Fancy Salad I would hit up an all you can eat Korean BBQ joint or Plutos.That's just me...if you have a few extra dollars to throw out there for French size portions this place is for you.
author: Duy T.

description:
My first visit was on accident.  My second visit was because this is a friends favorite spot.  My third visit was out of need - i could go no longer without the place.  My fourth visit was to introduce some folks to the place, something I love to do in a city that isnt mine.  The fifth was for work and I needed a place that was unique (read boring work companion).  The sixth is yet to come, but you can be sure I will order the halibut if they have it as long as I can have a bit of the steak.  If you havent been, go.  Its small, you might accidentally play footsie with the table next to you - but that can be fun too.  Go.  

Rated from 1-10: 
Taste - 10
Presentation - 7
Vibe - 8 - cramped, but I like to be in a busy place
Service - 9
Wine / Beer - 7 - could be better, but the food is so damn good. 


Needless to say (hate that saying) I will go back.
author: Dustin S.

description:
The House.  Heard the rumors, had to go there one time.  With my visiting girlfriend from Miami, I finally had an excuse to go and try The House.

First off, the food is delicious, but the service sucks.  There were two four person tables available the entire time, but the hostess let my date and I (who had reservations) just wait and stand for about half an hour before we got seated.  There was nobody waiting except for us.

Next, it was a sprint.  They literally hurried all the dishes off to us and I felt like I was running a 100 yard dash rather than eating at a fancy restaurant.  I even purchased a bottle of wine so they would slow down, but they literally shoved the food and the bottle down my throat.  I felt like I was back in my college days chugging Franzia at the house.

Finally, the food is great.  BEST SEA BASS I HAVE EVER EATEN.  I also had the steak, which also was so tasty, but the SEA BASS.  If only they deliver, and I could get it to go.  It's pretty tasty, but definitely not worth the service, so that is probably my last bite.  

I gave it 4 stars because everyone should go and try the sea bass once, as it is life-altering, but makes you realize how much service affects your mood sometimes.
author: Min P.

description:
I've been wanting to eat at The House since I moved to San Francisco based on the raving reviews I've not only read but heard. The restaurant itself is small but that doesn't bother me. As long as it's clean and comfortable and the foods good I can care less of its size.

The menu was short and sweet just like how all menus should be. I hate long menus with millions of items, a nice restaurant will always have a short menu with just enough description on each item to make you salivate.

I went with 3 other friends and ordered the fried green beans to start off with which was good, anything fried is always good. Although I did enjoy the dipping sauce that came with it- a spicey aoli mixture. We each also got complimentary scallops from the chef and it was pretty divine. The scallop was cooked perfectly with all the perfect spices and sauces complimenting it.

My entrée was the chicken breast topped with truffle mushrooms. 
Chicken was cooked the way I liked it-  not overcooked, lots of moisture and seasoned well. Truffle is the key to my heart, it should be the the key to human kind's heart. We'd be so fuckin happy if a truffle could lead to world peace. Anyway my plate fell together like a piece of art. I wouldn't have changed a damn thing.

I also tried my friend's dishes, a bite of the salmon- delicious sitting on the best broth/sauce. The wasabi noodles was brilliant. The piece of steak I tried was juicy, cooked just right.  Keep in mind all these dishes come with sauces and seasoning that you will be not be able to figure out. I kind of wanted to go to the bathroom about 5 times so I can see how they prepared everything haha.

Dessert: Creme Brulee- One of the best creme brulee's I've ever had! Perfect creme texture and the caramelized sugar/orange top was such an originally delightful touch.

Overall, I love this place like I knew I would. Worth every one of my college pennies.
author: Vicki B.

description:
You need to start with the classic Fried Salmon Rolls.  After splitting that (which is a perfect size for two to split) my girlfriend got the Special which was a Black Cod with Crab Roll, and I got the Seared Tuna with spicy mustard.  Both entrees were incredibly good...but the Black Cod was out of this world.  A melt in your mouth fish with a delicious teriyaki glaze (highly recommend going whenever they offer this dish).  Prices were high, but definitely fair for what you get.

Overall we had a great time with awesome food.  One downside was it did seem like they were eager to move us on to the next dish when we kind of wanted to take our time and enjoy it slowly.  Still a must go-to!
author: Sam F.

description:
Some hits and some misses.

SPIFFY FOOD:
- Lots of great dishes... I really liked the salmon rolls, the ahi tuna tartar with roasted nori chips, the unagi on rice, and the flank steak.  Totally want to try the sea bass next time.
- Non-alcoholic drinks: The lycee iced tea was quite good with free refills.  There were many interesting hot teas on the menu too I was tempted by, including the cool tea that blooms into a flower inside your cup.  All this stuff was really affordable ($2-5).

UNSPIFFY FOOD:
- Too many dishes used a similar wasabi-based sauce.  I'm a huge wasabi fan but you can only have so much of it before it starts feeling gimmicky.
- I didn't really like the green bean tempura appetizer the waitress recommended as "easy to share".  First it was arranged in a Jenga arrangement (remember that game?) with the sauce container underneath so there was really no way to access the sauce without knocking all the beans over.  Plus, you know how when you go to a Japanese restaurant and you order a bento box with tempura and the suckiest pieces are always the veggies at the end?  Yeah, this was like that only the whole thing was green beans.
- The portion size was probably a bit too generous on the entrees.  It was an ordeal to finish my entree.  I would have preferred family-style or tapas-style and the opportunity to sample more dishes.

COOL:
- The paper placemat was cute with a little house punched into it.
- Really efficient and friendly service.  They were very accommodating of our large group.
- Very cozy seating and ambiance.

LAME:
- They were crowded and we were strongly encouraged to vacate our table after the check arrive, which sort of sucked since we were mid-conversation.
- It would have been nice to have the specials written somewhere on a blackboard or on a piece of paper.  Even the waitress had to reference her notes to remember them all.
- It was uncomfortably cold in the restaurant.  Several members of our party kept jackets on.
- Parking in this neighborhood is terrible though there's a garage about a block away.

I probably wouldn't plan a trip back to The House, but I do recommend checking it out at least once.
author: Wayne K.

description:
Great little restaurant nestled in the North Beach district (one of my favorite areas of the City) on San Francisco's oldest road.  Very good food, excellent and artistic meal presentation, good service, pretty good date spot, reasonable prices, and very close to some of the City's touristy and nightlife spots.

If available, try the hamachi dinner special (when cooked rare the hamachi practically melts in your mouth with its tender and buttery texture), wasabi noodles with flatiron steak, caesar salad with scallops, and the mango tapioca dessert.
author: Erich D.

description: Still awesome, still love you House.  I had lunch here for the first time a couple months ago.  I had the seared tuna BLT, and my lady had the fried scallop ceasar salad.  They were both delicious, but the tuna was better IMO.
author: Spencer W.

description: wasabi noodles with steak, salmon rolls, and chilean bass. everything was good but 4* 5* good? my conclusion is that since most sf ppl are transients and probably never ate good asian food, they prob consider this spot the gospel. its good, yes, but not for the price. a fine balance. will i go again if im paying? no. if someone else is paying will i go? certainly wouldnt object.
author: Kai P.

description: One of the BEST dinners I've had in SF! Started with a special appetizer- tempura fried soft shell crab with spicy noodles. Amazing! Shrimp and chive dumplings. Great! The dinners were to die for- Grilled sea bass with noodles and green beans. The fish was grilled to perfection and noodles had a wonderful seasoning and green beans were still crisp and perfectly cooked. The pork chop had this amazing sweet sauce, served with mashed potatoes and asparagus. Dessert was a coconut creme brûlée with passion fruit puree on top....OMG....  I left that place so happy and satisfied. All of that and 3 glasses of wine was only $116! Not bad! And the waitress was great at recommending a wine to go with our dinners. Wonderful experience!
author: Heather G.

description:
After the four of us struggled with getting enough coins to fill the parking meter, we sat down for a nice lunch at The House.  I liked the feet paintings that were on the wall, and I liked our waitress who resembled Vera Wang.  

Deep-fried chicken liver with baby greens- everyone at the table seemed to enjoy this but me...meh.
Wasabi house noodles- Hella Good.  It took a few bites to really taste the wasabi flavor over the teriyaki-ish sauce.  I loved the cole slaw-kim chi pile of cabbage on top.
Curry noodles- tried a bite and it was very tasty.  You can't really go wrong with curry.

We were full from our meals and were in a bit of a rush so we didn't get dessert, but after hearing from a friend that they have excellent passion fruit crème brulee, I sorta, kinda, maybe wish we tried it.
author: Agent X.

description: One of my all time favorites. The bass is always great. The kale salad is amazing! Must try. I wanted more. The curry udon noodles are also good.
author: Musetta S.

description:
My favorite fusion restaurant so far, and I tend to avoid them.

Love the ambience of the place at night with the fellow diners. I brought my unsophisticated coworkers during a conference, and everyone loved the food + desserts.

I don't chime in on highly reviewed + rated places to be another of the homering masses... but I wanted to yelp the Coconut Creme Bruleee was amazing. I still want another one, it was that good. I licked the whole damn bowl clean. And I begrudgingly allowed my coworker to sample a spoonful. I considered making him regurgitate it when my selfishness kicked in. In fact, I went the next day and discovered they sold them all out. Darn you city dwellers, leave some for us out-of-towners!!!!
author: Jeff H.

description:
Heard about "The House" through a co-worker, then found it on Yelp!  I made a reservation, which was key, because even though it was Wednesday night, the place was packed.  I was annoyed that their online menu didn't contain prices, but appetizers are $6-$11 and mains are $16-$25.

I had a seared scallop appetizer, which was delicious, and the miso black cod with California roll.  The cod was incredibly buttery and delicious; the California roll was good but felt out of place with the cod.  That said, I was scooping up every last drop of the sauce with my fork.

My friend had a grilled calamari with bonito shavings -- and when they set his plate down, the bonito shavings were wiggling around as they radiated heat from the oven.  The effect was that his appetizer was still alive, which was both bizarre and awesome.

Portions are a little on the small side, but not terrible for the price and quality.

For dessert, I had the chocolate cake with ice cream; good but not decadent.
author: Kitt H.

description: I go with my family very Friday night I love this place because they have 4 like and great service thank you for the manager David for giving us fresh food
author: Reuben B.

description: I feel this is overrated. i was very excited about the wasabi noodle with iron steak, it was okay, the salmon roll was okay too.
author: Ashley C.

description: Absolutely delicious!! Remember to make a reservation a couple of days ahead of time. Highly recommend the mussels appetizer, the pork meal, and the wasabi noodle plus steak meal :-) Will definitely be back.
author: Brooke B.

description:
Dayummmmmmm.... this restaurant is the shizznit as they say! The husband unit decided we would go out for a date night and introduced me to this wonderful place. At first you walk in and see this teeny tiny place with every table full. We were seated immediately and scored with the one and only window seat, great for people watching. 
We ordered: 
-raw oysters (superb, the chili sauce served with them Divine) 
-mushroom soup (decadent, rich and finger licking good) 
-ribeye (soft, flavorful and buttery as a steak should be) 
-halibut with mussels in a coconut creme sauce (knock your socks off) 
-chocolate cake (had a bite, ok for me, I'm one of those rare people that doesn't like chocolate) the husband devoured it so I suppose it was to his liking 
-house Pinot Grigio (perfect compliment for the halibut) 

So many other dishes looked just as good, our neighbors to the right had Divine looking sushi, pork chops and ahi tuna... 

The service is kind, quick and cool. We felt like a well taken care of guest. 

Parking: totally based on luck in the area, we scored one a block away 

Now I understand why my husband totally raves about this place, he and his coworkers have been here many times and never had a bad meal. 

I can't wait to go back again, I would definitely like to try the pork chop and sea bass entrees. Oh and the great looking apply pie ala mode.
author: La C.

description: Delicious food and service. A little on the pricey end but overall a very good experience.
author: W D.

description:
This place was great.  My girlfriend and I walked in on a whim.  She had the Black Sea Bass which was amazing.  I had the Kobe Skirt Steak Special which was equally amazing.  The skirts steak came with cauliflower which was hands down the best cauliflower I have ever had (sorry mom).
We didn't make a reservation and were seated right away, but from reading the other reviews below it seems that reservations are a good idea.
I would highly recommend The House.
author: Steffan R.

description:
Eating Chinese style  food without feeling that "i am so full from nan king i might die" is very pleasant. 
Thank you The House!
The scallops were cooked perfectly, and i'm very picky on the over or underdone scallops. The wine was a perfect compliment (thanks to the server). The food was delicious and nice and light. Definitely have dessert! Expect long waits, this place is popular!
author: Nikki M.

description:
I had the ahi tuna tartare with roasted nori chips for my main dish and bbq oysters as my appetizer.  It was all delicious.

the House is a pretty small place and very loud.  It's kind of narrow...but who cares you know?  You are there for good food.

It was Jill S.'s birthday and she picked this place and I was so happy and satisfied.  Until we left and we went to a bar (Crowbar, that is now closed) and I started to feel horrible.  I felt all sweaty and hot and exhausted and like I had to puke.  I played air hockey and I just did not feel like myself at all.  I had only had one drink so I didn't know what was up.

I eat oysters and raw fish all the time without problems, although when I was a kid I did have some allergic reactions to crab where it made my scalp itch afterwards.  I have ate like 20 oysters before without having any reaction.  I think House gave me 7 oysters and I ate them all myself.  

Perhaps I ate too much raw-ish seafood that night with the tuna and oysters combined, or maybe I was just sick for some other reason.  Who can really say.

But anyways I puked all night long that night and I felt absolutely horrible.  the next day I wasn't feeling so great either, i was in bed all day feeling like shit.  Even if it wasn't their fault, I don't plan to go back to House.  I had too bad of  a night that night.  

After we left Crowbar we went to Centerfolds and I barely made it to the bathroom before I puked my whole dinner up.  That is totally unlike me.  I never puke.  Perhaps it was seeing Jill S.'s vagina so much as she pretended to be a stripper letting us all know that as always she didn't have any panties on.  LOL,  just kidding Jill.  (Love you), lol.

But yeah, Jill took care me that night.  Ask her...I was sick as hell.  My guess is that I got some bad oysters.  I wanted to get drunk that night but I was unable to because I felt so horrible.  I think I had one drink all night, maybe two tops...and I can drink a lot.

House is a beautiful restaurant and the staff is very cool.  I am sorry to bitch and moan...but the story is the truth.  I guess when you eatoysters it is a risk you take?  I don't know.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
4.5 stars

This has got to be one of my all time FAVORITE places for Asian Fusion Cuisine in SF- defined in 2 words: simplicity and perfection (ok, almost perfect!) 

I've tried practically everything on the menu.  My advice is to get any fish entree, you can never go wrong!  I am a HUGE fan of the SEA BASS!!  You put it in your mouth and you're like O M G!! The fish is simply packed with massive flavor, rich and light at the same time, just soooo DELICIOUS!

Oh, and I also want to mention this place is reasonably priced, won't burn a hole in your pocket. A good comparable restaurant is Chaya Brasserie (which i also like) without the hefty price tag. WOOT GOOT! =)

Minus 1/2 a star for this disappointing item:
The deep-fried chicken liver with baby greens- which was still raw in the middle and a big NO NO in my books!! We had to send it back! =(

*Make sure to reserve a table, this place is TINY!!
author: Leeseuh K.

description: Great food.  Creative menu.  Unique tastes.  Wonderful service.  Worth every penny.  Try the calamari!
author: Joseph K.

description:
My girlfriend took me here on a date night, and wow, the food just blew me away.

First off, make sure to make a reservation, because this place is small and quaint, and you will NOT get a table if you decide to just stroll in.  Also, be prepared for turn-your-hair-white frustration as you find parking around this area.

We started off with two appetizers: the calamari, and the Kurobuta pork cheek buns.  The calamari was fried crispy and delicious, and the kimchee salad that came with it was equally delightful.  The pork cheek buns were equally tasty, and left me longing for more after the two pieces were devoured.

She had the Kurobuta pork chop for her entree, and I had the sea bass.  I really loved the pork...the meat was so tender, and the pomegranate currant sauce was a great compliment.  My sea bass was great as well...perfectly cooked and seared, and the noodles on the side were so good it actually appeared in my dreams last night.

My only complaint is that the food arrived fast...and by fast, I mean REALLY fast.  It almost seemed like they were just jamming plates onto our table, something I'm not very used to in a higher-end establishment.  

Still, I would have to say House is one of the best places I've been to in SF.
author: Loren L.

description:
Appetizers: Deep-fried salmon roll with chinese hot mustard, Ahi tuna tartare with roasted nori chips
Entree: Grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy

Appetizers were decent but nothing to rave about. Not a fan of the ahi tuna tartare -- the wasabi aioli was overwhelming. Sea bass was grilled perfectly, but the sauce on the side was way too salty. Dip at your own risk.
author: Linda D.

description:
I live near Washington Square so I've eaten at almost every restaurant in the area. The House is easily the best restaurant within a 1 mile radius of the park. The dishes are creative, presented beautifully, and very reasonably priced.  I usually come here during lunch because there's typically a line out the door during dinner (unless you arrive very early).

Most things are good, but my favorites off the lunch menu are the flatiron steak, sea bass, and wasabi noodles.  I also love their lychee iced tea.  Now onto the bad...I tried the soup noodles once only to be seriously pissed when I discovered that the restaurant does not have soup spoons!!!  They give you a regular metal spoon which is completely inadequate for downing a giant bowl of soup noodles.  Also, avoid the unagi avocado sandwich. A friend of mine ordered it once and found it extremely disappointing.
author: Sally C.

description: Insanely great food! Started with pork sparerib appetizer that came with a spicy tangy ginger sauce and some tempura green beans. Both were outstanding the presentation is half the fun. Our entrees included: Mahi Mahi on top of clam chowder, pork chop with a pomegrante sauce, flank steak and the wasabi noodles and sea bass with green beans and garlic noodles. I hesitated after I ordered the sea bass thinking that I should have gone for something a little more unique. I was so glad I didn't. The sea bass literally melted in my mouth, never had sea bass this way before. They serve it with a sweet and tangy ginger soy sauce that equally makes the dish but I could have eaten the fish all by itself.  Quick service, prompt attention to water and drinks as well as clearing your plate. Tight quarters on one side of the restaurant getting in and out of your seat. Fun place!
author: P G.

description:
My lady friend got us reservations for The House for Valentine's Day this year, and she definitely gets points for picking this spot.

We walked up to people spilling out of the restaurant into the street- and were seated after a few minutes (much to everyone's chagrin around us waiting!). We were seated at a four top, which gave us a ton of space. We ordered a bottle of wine, the scallops (which were to die for), and I got the cod with sushi roll- it came out looking like a dragon, which I loved. My lady got the steak with chanterelles. Both plates were beautiful and delicious. The details the staff paid attention to here were really what set it apart from other restaurants. I would highly recommend this spot!
author: Lara M.

description: it is absolutely a brilliant place for Asian food in San Francisco. Though not saying that its major dishes aren't good, I LIKE the Mango Tapioca Pudding a lot. It is super creamy and has a thick authenic taste of the mango!!!! The whole environment is relatively modern and cozy. The service and food you get are definitely worth the price and a possible long wait.
author: Shuyin Christal W.

description:
The House feels like home.

My friend put me with the task of picking a restaurant that she "had to try before moving away from SF".  After reading the wonderful reviews, I decided to go with The House.  Fortunately for us, they had a same-day reservation for 3 at 7:30pm on a Wednesday night.

We arrived a few minutes late, but our table was ready and waiting for us.  As soon as I stepped in, I felt good about my choice.  The decor is pleasant, and the restaurant was busy.  To drink, we each ordered a different hot tea.  I got the chrysanthemum, and it was great.  For appetizers, our server listed off some non-menu specials that sounded delicious... he recommended the pork belly, so we ordered that and the grilled calamari as well.  Both appetizers tasted perfect... they were just the right size to share between the 3 of us and not get too full.  The pork belly reminded me of a Chinese dish I've had before.  It was definitely not the healthiest thing to eat, but it just melts in your mouth.  So good!

For a main course, I selected the sole, while my friends ordered the yellow tail hibachi and the ahi tuna.  Each plate arrived in a beautiful arrangement on the plate, with colors that jumped out right at you.  My sole was cooked perfectly, and the mashed potatoes underneath were devoured quickly.  My friends each enjoyed their dishes as well.  Now, it was time for dessert.

One of my friends was a pastry chef, so she was particularly excited.  She selected the creme brulee, while my other friend went with the red velvet cake.  I chose the apple cobbler (without the "a la mode" since I'm a lactard).  My apple cobbler was solid, while my friends each very much enjoyed their respective desserts.  Being a pastry chef, I trusted my one friend when she said the creme brulee was delicious.

We never felt rushed at any point.  In fact, the table of 3 older ladies next to us received their check a few minutes after we sat down and only left 5 minutes before we paid out.  It was clear that this was a restaurant that wanted each party to enjoy their meal to the fullest, even if there were a few folks waiting to be seated.  After tax and tip, we spent about $52 a person... definitely reasonable for a good meal, considering all of the food we ordered.

I'll be back... I think I may have a new favorite restaurant in SF!
author: Kenny L.

description: This place was surprisingly very small but intimate and that's what I like! They don't have a bunch of food on their menu but everything they have is delicious! I came here for my anniversary with my husband and I had the sea bass while he had the ribeye. The two entrees were soo yummy. They cook the steak exactly how we want it, which is medium rare. It's literally the best sea bass I've ever had along with their garlic noodles. The only thing that didn't taste all that great was the appetizer mussels. Definitely make reservation in advance because it's always a full house!!
author: Trang L.

description:
On a Sunday night, there isn't much beyond Italian to choose from in North Beach, so we opted to try out this place tucked into on of my favorite alleys of the area to get some variety.

We were seated and served almost immediately; as we were a couple we got ahead of a group of five. Our waiter was 100% on top of his service and very personable, friendly and helpful with his suggestions. 

But I'm sorry, I can't give it 5 stars and hold to a strong 3.5. While the restaurant is clean, personable and relatively quiet considering the small space, there are a few things that took off the edge. 

I also don't eat seafood and my boyfriend opted for pork instead of seafood at last minute, so the menu was a bit limiting in that sense. Prices for appetizers and their size were decent, though! 

My steak was flavored well with teriyaki, but wasn't as rare as I would have liked for it to be and my potatoes were kind of flavorless for being garlic mash. His Kurobuta pork was more on a bbq style side, which is odd considering the nature of this pig. Kurobuta means "black pig" in Japanese, which is a rare type of British pig that is on par with Kobe beef in terms of its stature in the meat world. That being said, a lot of asian fusion restaurants that feature this like the mark-up capabilities and this is truly a tender pig. These guys did a pretty good job with getting across the tender layers with a crispy outside layer, but in terms of meat flavor, Yoshi's preparation was spot on in comparison. 

For dessert, an apple crumble for my man and cheesecake for me. I went with our waiter's suggestion over the coconut creme brulee with passionfruit compote, which sounded exotically appealing, and it was a very simple, classic dessert. I guess I wanted more "umph" and should have taken the leap with the creme brulee. I did also end up with an excellent chardonnay, which is rare as most chards are too dry for my tastes. 

Mostly, it was the table we were seated at that took things down the most. Behind the host stand by the door, which meant my boyfriend was feeling cramped by waiting customers and my feet were freezing from the draft coming in underneath the divider. So try to avoid sitting here; I'm sure this would have easily take the edge off and lead to a happy 4+ rating!
author: Alita M.

description: Remains a solid restaurant after many years.
author: Jeff S.

description:
Go to THE HOUSE if you want to eat and die in HEAVEN! They are THAT GOOD!!! 

I am truly a foodie, dining out every day of the week and have been doing this for eons. Somehow, although new restaurants pop up and of course...there are many solid ones that have been around, we always end up at THE HOUSE at least 3 times a week! For newcomers to town, tourists, corporate friends and family, we ALWAYS, AWAYS go to The House! We know what we are getting--consistently AWESOME. You can't miss-- every dish is superbly executed by my favorite chef :arry Tse. His wife Angela, who runs the front of the house, watches every move making sure every diner has the best experience. She runs a tight, tight ship, taking service to a new level.

For an out of this world mouth watering experience....GO TO THE HOUSE!!!!!
author: Sharon S.

description:
Food here is just OK...not great, not bad...just ok.  Not sure why it has such rave reviews.  Presentation of food is nice though..too bad it's not as tasty as it looks. Shared the following 3 appetizers & 1 main course:

Roasted unagi (eel) with avocado sushi rice(3.5 stars): Typical sushi you can get at any restaurant.  I liked how the bonito flakes are "moving" on top when they bring it out to you.  "Safe" dish b/c it's very typical.

Deep-fried salmon roll (2 stars):  Did not particularly like this one..maybe wasn't a fan of the cooked salmon (bit dry)?  Wasn't bad...but wasn't good either.  Skip this dish.

Softshell Crab (3 stars): Also very typical.  Good, but nothing special.  Also served with small portion of noodles.  Nice presentation though...there are these fried "wonton-stick" things that stick out of the crab that give it a tree-like look.  

Grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy (4 stars):  Best thing I ate out of the 4 dishes.  Good BUT it still isn't anything to rave about.  Sea bass was nice & buttery, and I liked the green beans that came with it.  It is also served w/ Udon noodles I believe. It's already well seasoned & salty enough, so even though they give you extra sauce on the side, you won't be needing it.
author: Christine V.

description:
I finally had a chance to try the black cod.. 

DIVINE. It melts in your mouth. 


I love working near here!
author: Donna H.

description: I've been here 3 times (for lunch) there is always a crowd, definitely make reservations if possible. Service can suffer when the house is packed but every one is very polite and well informed about the menu items. Things to try 1. Lychee iced tea 2. Warm Wasabi noodles w/salmon (possibly the best grilled salmon I've had in the city) they also have great special menu items. 3. mixed green salad with chicken livers. 4 the fried salmon rolls.
author: Wei W.

description:
The Wasabi Noodles...mmmm mmm good!
Great food, fun ambiance, vibrant, overall awesome.
The one downfall is we had to wait still about 15 minutes even with a reservation which isn't really that big of deal but wish they had a bar to grab a drink rather than wait outside.
author: KJ G.

description: Great place. Small, quaint, almost romantic. Expect to pay about $40-$60 per person including tips/drinks/dessert/appetizer. I came here on a lunch so I'm sure a little more during dinner. The most fun is when someone else pay. Hehe. With all jokes aside, and even if I did have to pay, I think this place would be definitely worth it. Good food! And presentation is top notch!
author: J C.

description: Misoyaki cod, I could eat you every day. I'm really, really picky about how my fish is cooked and as a result I usually stick to eating it raw...but this dish was SOOOO DELICIOUS. I'm giving this place 5 stars even though my bf and I were seated so closely to our neighbors, we had to adjust the tables to get in and out.
author: Jean L.

description: This place was suggested to me by a local. I called a couple hours in advance and made reservations (HINT). It is located in the artsy district surrounded by restaurants, strip joints, and classical bookstores. The place was packed and there was no room to wait. The space is pretty small which is why you feel like a sardine. Let's just say you get to know who you are sitting next to very well as you are basically sitting on top of them. This makes it easy to steal a few bites of their food when they aren't paying attention (jk I did not commit this act, though I was tempted). For appetizers we started off with the fried salmon rolls. Deeply fried and crunchy on the outside, but soft and juicy on the inside, with an excellent sauce. I had the steak and my bf had the chicken. We were both fighting for the steak, but since I got to choose the place, I won. Both were very delicious. The steak was perfect, incredibly succulent. The service was great too even though they are busy. I will definitely be coming back here.
author: Golnaz P.

description:
HANDS down my FAVORITE restaurant in SF.  This is what I recommend to all my friends when they ask me where to eat in SF.

Reservation is a must, it is a rather small restaurant and they don't often take walk-ins, although I have seen a few lucky individuals score openings.   This is some of my favorites.  I would keep the party size small, since they don't have a lot of tables for large parties.  Once went with a party of 6 and got squeezes into a 4 person table.

Appetizers:
Deep fried salmon rolls: filling and skin ratio is good, pretty generous with the salmon.  
Kurobuta Pork cheek buns: devoured within minutes, wish there were more.
Tuna tartare: flavors are simple and straight to the point.

Entrees:
Pomegranate Currant Porkchops: The dish that won me over, I believe this is the perfect example of asian fusion.  The porkchop has a hint of the spices and flavor that my mom use to make her porkchops and the pomegranate give it that hint of acid and sweetness.  Must try!
Sea Bass: my second favorite dish, the noodles it comes with..drool..and the vegetable has been different each time I've gotten it
Miso Cod: The California rolls that come with it are very interesting, definitely the only time I've seen them served like that.  Also yummy.

Unfortunately their desserts aren't that memorable.  But, the restaurant is located in the heart of North Beach, there are tons of cafes within walking distance with great pastries or small gelato shops.

Service is good, almost too good, they clear the table and have the next item on your table within minutes, doesn't allow much time for digestion.  As long as you don't feel hassled by this, you should still have a memorable dining experience.

Parking in North Beach is horrendous, really make sure you leave enough time to look for parking, or else fork up the money to park in a private lot.
author: Tabitha C.

description:
OVERRATED!!!!

Yes, the food was good but not the best.  I find it to be too salty for my taste.
Service was good and memorable.   Generous portions.
author: Emma G.

description:
This place is great! I brought boyfriend here for his bday and we had a great time! Parking was a total b*tch but we still managed to arrive 20 minutes early. :-/ They were also able to seat us early which was great! 

We ordered the mussels to start and they came out super fast! Probably the most tender mussels I have ever had. Our entrees were delicious as well. He had the sea bass and I had the seared Ahi tuna. Yummm. Presentation was beautiful as well! 

Service was super attentive! We really enjoyed ourselves!
author: Jamie S.

description:
Wonderful. Lived up to the great reviews. Attentive, informative servers. Black Cod was so good and fresh, I swear it came off the boat right before the meal. 

Set in North Beach, a great walking destination.
author: Stephen P.

description: This place really embodies Asian fusion. When I first walked it, I was pretty surprised. I thought it would be somewhat fancy but lo and behold, it's a pretty cramped restaurant with your standard wooden tables at Asian restaurants but with fancy ceiling lights that provide an ambient setting. I would have to say the restaurant is a little too dark though. My mom had to whip out her iPhone flashlight to read the menu. Overall, I would have to say that they know how to cook their meat and their seafood. From their fried salmon rolls to their pork chop to their skirt steak to their shrimp, they really cook it perfectly, keeping everything perfectly succulent. My only complaint of their food is that it feels a little too heavy and salty. My mom commented in the middle of the meal, "we should have ordered rice!" even though one of our plates was a mushroom rice and the other was a noodle dish. The flavors were just a little too salty for real. I would have to say the highlights of my meal were the fried salmon rolls and the house wasabi noodles with skirt steak. The salmon rolls were pure genius - salmon wrapped in seaweed then finished off egg roll style, just so some of the salmon is cooked while the inside is raw. The house noodles had a really nice texture and had just a hint of wasabi and paired well with the perfectly cooked steak. For dessert, we had the chocolate truffle cake and the mango tapioca. Both were good - the cake was nice and dense and the tapioca was chilled and refreshing though I wish there was more mango flavor! Overall, this place is pretty good - just make sure to make a reservation if you want to be seated right away!
author: Naomi S.

description: Fantastic, top of the line restaurant.  I came here about 10 years and then returned now and it has not changed a bit.  Still the same excellent food and atmosphere.  The fishes dishes are remarkable.
author: around town e.

description: We dine on the Sea Bass every time we visit San Francisco. Last night the scallop appetizer special was tender and perfectly seasoned. Service is fast and friendly. Small cozy gem. Lingering feels rude when there is a line out the door. So get there early.
author: Stacey K.

description:
For 4.5 stars on yelp... I had some pretty high expectations but sadly I just couldn't put it up there with SF's finest in my book.

Salmon roll ($10) - best part of the meal. If you like spicy, this wasabi sauce that comes with it is AMAZING

wasabi house noodles and steak - so greasy, so heavy, so everything asian food should not be. The steaks were cooked to medium perfectly as we ordered but the accompanying noodles were like 'oil with a side of noodles' instead of 'noodles pan-fried in oil'

sea bass - even heavier and greasier than the noodle/steak. The piece of fish was fresh but everything on this plate from the fish to the noodles to the greens were just doused in oil.

I am no stranger to comfort food and can kill a bucket of KFC, but eating just half my meal here gave me heartburn... 

Don't get me wrong 3 stars for the taste and large portions but you'll probably won't be able to stomach this if you're body isn't accustomed to eating poorly
author: Noah P.

description:
Five stars ALL. THE. WAY.

A friend was in town from the east coast, so we got group of 5 together to eat here. After reading the reviews, we were excited for the great food and undaunted the possibility of having a hard time finding parking. One friend made reservations and off we were!

Luckily, the stars were aligned that night and we ended up finding a parking spot half a block away. While we had reservations, the restaurant didn't look too crowded (it was a Monday night), and we were seated promptly at a four top with an extra chair. The place is pretty small, but it's cozy.

Appetizers: 
- Seared dayboat scallops with micro greens and a ponzu sauce: sooo good. The scallops were seared perfectly and the sauce and greens all went together beautifully.
- Deep-fried chicken liver with spring greens: I'd never had a liver salad before but this was pretty good. Luckily a few of my friends liked liver as well, as this was a bit large to eat by yourself.
- Tuna tartare: I wasn't too impressed; the wasabi taste kind of overpowered it.

Entrees (the good thing about dining with others is that you can try more stuff. Yay!):
- Grilled sea bass with noodles: THIS HAS RUINED ME. I've never seen a piece of fish that thick cooked to such perfection. I'm not even kidding, this is the BEST sea bass I've EVER had.  You don't even need the sauce; it's THAT good. It has a nice seared crust as well. The noodles that go with it are a bit greasy, but flavorwise, everything goes really well together.
- American Kobe flank steak with black truffle sauce and mashed potatoes (special): this was my husband's dish. When our server set it down, the aroma floated around the table and we made a collective "OoOoo." Cooked to a perfect medium rare and sooo soft.
- Kurobuta pork chop with pomegranate currant sauce: I did not expect this to be as good as it was. It was so tender and flavorful, and I only got to try a bite! The friend who ordered this, however, floated out of the restaurant afterwards in pure euphoria. I'm definitely ordering this the next time we eat here.

The portions are a good size; we left full but not about to bust open our pants. We did skip dessert though...the choices were kind of standard and nothing stood out.

Service was good, attentive but not overwhelming, and our water glasses were constantly getting refilled. Prices were a little on the steeper side, but hey, you're in SF and the food was better than some of the fancy shmancy places I've been to that charge at least double. 

The House, we will see you again soon ;)
author: Faye S.

description:
Had a good meal here but not as good as I was expecting from all the reviews and my friends hyping this place up.

*Ahi tuna tartare (B-): i've had way better, and way more creative, and the fish didn't taste super fresh (plus there was wasabi...which does not agree with me)
*Tempura blue lake beans (B+): solid performance, but it's just tempura beans (i actually think the ones at Yuzu are better)
*Sea bass w/ garlic noodles and long beans: YUM-O! i really loved this dish.  i'm so sad that i drank too much root beer during apps so that i was too full to really enjoy my entree.  the fish was tender/flaky/juicy, and the garlic noodles were awesome and had cloud ear's in it!!
*mushroom risotto w/ grilled prawns (A+): loved this asian take on mushroom risotto.  super rich and complex!
*apple crumb pie w/ vanilla (A): bf ate it all up w/o talking
*red velvet cake w/ cream cheese frosting (B+): good flavor, but the cake was dry...boo

Service is super nice and it's a nice place for a date.  TAKE A CAB though! Parking in the area sucks.
author: Priscilla T.

description:
Honest - It was a little overrated.  

The food was... fine.  It was good, but nothing to "write home to mom" about.  The service was spectacular - even though they were late seating us for our reservation.   

We had:
The deep fried salmon rolls - overcooked 
Garlic noodles - great!  But you can get them elsewhere for less 
Flat iron steak - good 

If we happen to be in the neighborhood and a table is open, sure - we'll try it again.  But it is not on our "must go back to" list.
author: Paula S.

description:
Watch out for this guy...
To my left, a table of college kids screaming at the top of their lungs, as if they were across the room from one another.  Worse, one f-er laughs like a hyena.  I wanted to punch him!

Watch out for this couple...
To my right, a baby crying at the top of her lungs.  I like kids, have two of my own, but it is ridiculous to bring them anywhere but McDonalds.

Atmosphere...
If you haven't figured it out, this place is incredibly small and obnoxiously loud.  Due to the North Beach location and visitors from all over the world, this is to be expected.  So expect it!

Service...
Good enough.  I can't get my neighbors to shut up so I couldn't focus on what she is or isn't doing.

Food...
Sea Bass (5 stars) melts like butta and is a must.  Specials of the day: Halibut, Scallop, and Soft-Shelled Crabs are great too (4 stars each).
author: The T.

description:
I love it !

A friend of mine recommended the restaurant to me, so finally we decided to go together so I could see if the food was as amazing as she reported. It was. 

I ordered the sea bass which was done to perfection- delicious flavor , and yes I can now confirm that it does melt in your mouth. I tried some of my boyfriends wasabi noodles and those were also fantastic. 

The place was packed when we were here, which makes sense, but still had a relaxed atmosphere.

All around good experience, this is the kind of place that I could keep coming back to and not get tired of.
author: Christy D.

description:
We arrived at 6pm and got a table for 3 straight. we were delighted as previously we had arrived at 8pm and there was a wait for 1.5hr. So either come early or book as this a popular place and for good reason.  The food is awesome.  I had the special which was kobe beef with garlic potatoes and cauliflower with mushroom toppings.  Delicious. My wife really enjoyed her salmon and sister in law only had a mushroom soup which wasn't even on the menu but they happily provided.  All the portents we nicely sized but would not be considered large

Right after we decided we were definitely coming back.  The only thing to note is the price.  It is not cheap especially the wine but we were all in agreement that it was worth it.

Oh yeah and a big tip is to have the creme broulee for dessert.  I wanted to lick the bowl.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Apps were the softshell crab, fried salmon rolls and ahi tuna- 4 stars

Entrees were the seas bass and cod - 4 stars

Dessert was coconut creme brulee with passionfruit sauce - 3 stars 

Overall the food was solid (4 stars). the food/food quality itself is as good as some of the better chinese/japanese restaurants i've been to, but it didn't exceed them. Like, i've had as good tuna tartare and even better softshell crab at good japanese restaurants; i've had as good of garlic noodles as chinese restaurants, etc. The cod an bass were exceptional, but i've had as good of bass at Katsuya in LA and prime 112 in Miami, but it's up there with the top 3. I think what really set this place apart is the presentation (as you can see), but then it almost sets a higher expectation for how good the food should taste. You're almost primed to think that the food should be better than what it is (even though it's already GOOD), and then you find that the food is not as great as the presentation makes you think it should be - does that make sense?

Anyway i'd definitely recommend people try it out; i kind of like the casual/hole-in-the-wall atmosphere cuz then the food takes you by surprise, but it's not necc a restaurant I would keep going back to since only the presentation is truly unique, not the food.
author: Erica L.

description: What a delightful experience! My profile pic, taken at The House, sums it up. We had some of the most unique and delicious seafood dishes here. I can't remember shh'd because it's been a while but I remember taking pictures of the yellowtail appetizer and even the blackened cod...ithink... and we NEVER take pics. Trust me, it's worth the little hole it'll make in your wallet. Those on a date... He or she will feel obligated to put out after the awesome dinner. You are now wise.
author: Ash T.

description: Place is a bit small, and tables are very close to each other. But the oyster appetizer has the best sauce. And most entrees taste great.
author: Xiaohui Y.

description:
The House is a sort of hole in the wall, Asian Fusion eatery somewhat misplaced in the Italian neighborhood of San Francisco. Parking is definitely a challenge, as well as, getting a reservation. But the food makes the effort worth it for sure.

The deep fried salmon rolls are really good. Also tried the pomegranate pork chop which is ok. But the real start entree was the cod. It simply melts in your mouth. I've never had anything like it before. Totally worth a trip or two back.
author: Joey C.

description:
I would give it a 5-star if they actually paid attention to my reservation and didn't have us waiting as long as walk-ins. Also, the desert was just ok.

The food was amazing. My pork chop was just delicious as it was just prepared right (they do it medium by default) and the pomegranate sauce was just heavenly. The sea bass that my girlfriend had was also extremely good (but I like the pork chop better). I will definitely come back but come on guys, respect the reservation as people who call in to book don't have to wait in line like people who just walk in there!
author: Farid F.

description:
simple clean style and ambiance.
tasty flavorful dishes.
started with some hamachi sashimi - very fresh and good.
soft shell crab sandwich was tasty but the bread was burnt.
the Chilean sea bass was stellar.
Chef Larry Tse's cooking skills still shines on  after all these years.
author: Jeff W.

description:
I like this place...this place almost everyday got crowded..so it is better to make reservation when you want to eat at this restaurant...i ordered the wasabi noodle, deep fried salmon roll, sea bass, and the calamari..all of them taste good...

CONCLUSION = RECOMMENDED!!
author: Aris L.

description:
Came here for the first time after seeing all the great Yelp reviews. It's so close to where I live.  Had to give it a try.  

The place is VERY small.  You get the feeling you are eating at the same table with everyone else.  

First, when we walked in, NO ONE greeted us.  We had to hunt someone down for a table.

We ordered the Pork Chops.  It was good.  Had a nice sauce over it with mash potatoes.  

I'd like to come back & try other things.  

The waitress was very friendly.
author: Marie E.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant. Therefore, it is only fitting that I write my first Yelp review for The House. 

I usually despise any thing that's "Asian Fusion," albeit I am an ABC. Asian Fusion usually translates to something cooked improperly and marinated with ginger, miso, soy, or sesame. So when my mom told me about this place, I had my doubts. However, The House breaks cultural barriers and the gastronomical taboo. Their version of Asian fusion is Asian ingredients cooked in a Western way, and served with Asian speediness. 

My favorite dish here is the pork chop. It has so many flavors! It's brined, with a sweet fruity sauce that's also tangy. It's Asian, it's American, it's everything! 

Make sure you listen to their specials list every time you go in, although the waiters/tresses have a tendency to stare at the wall while trying to remember what their specials are. The specials are fresh and tasty and usually better than what's already on the menu.

Hits? The pork chop as mentioned, rib eye steak, soft shell crab appetizer, salmon skin roll, short rib pasta, oh the list goes on and on. 
I don't really love some of their fish dishes. I find them to be a little on the bland side. Their specialty is food on the grill. So stick to that and you're in good hands! 

You won't regret coming. :)
author: Melissa C.

description:
We got take out from here because we really wanted to try the food but were low on time... BEST. DECISION. EVER.

Had the fried salmon roll and the unagi nigiri style roll.  The salmon roll has a chinese mustard kick that is fantastic for spice lovers, and it heals sinus problems.  What more could you ask for?

The unagi was delicious... melt in your mouth goodness with a bit of a crust.  Yummyness.

Next time we are in San Fran, will definitely opt to sit in :)
author: Hiba A.

description:
Omg, the Coconut Creme Brulee with Passion Fruit Puree was beyond perfect....

Their Green Tea was just OK though

Make Reservations early!

We got a table at 5:30, & the next one available was at 9:30

Good quality, tasty food!!
author: Andrea V.

description:
We ate lunch here and didn't realize the lunch and dinner menus were slightly different, but it didn't matter. Everything was great, and some were even delicious! 

Deep fried salmon roll 
Special fried oyster salad 
Shrimp and chive dumplings 

Flat iron steak w/ shitake mushroom 
Unagi and avocado sandwich 
Special fried chicken sandwich 
Udon noodles with salmon 

God fearing mango tapioca delight for desert. This is definitely a go again place, maybe for dinner next visit.
author: Richard M.

description:
I've been coming here for the past 4-5 years.. i live up the street. the food is delicious... especially the black cod special they frequently serve and their steak dishes. solid 4 stars for the food... Tonight I came with three foodie family members who were in town visiting from the Philippines. 

Now I rarely take the time to write reviews, unless I've had an especially good or bad experience at a place. Tonight at The House was DELICIOUS as always, BUT our waitress was probably the worst I've had in my 7 years living in the bay area.

She was extremely rude to us from the start. She would roll her eyes when my family, who have filipino accents, asked questions about the specials. Funny.. has she not had to deal with foreigners before, being in north beach and all?  

We tried our very best to be patient despite her EXTREMELY HOSTILE demeanor but nothing we did seemed to be enough to change her mood. We ordered a ton of food and wine and tried to ignore her awful manner. Did she not want us to order more?? I think we were way too patient for the kind of treatment we received. I don't have time to be more descriptive here and because I have been a fan of this place for a long time I will just say that you will probably have a great meal there if you manage to be lucky not to get this particular waitress. 

Hopefully I dont encounter you again. You need to leave the House and work somewhere low quality like your attitude.
author: Danielle C.

description:
i rarely give out 5 stars, but this place deserves it, even with the over-an-hour wait time. 

PLEASE MAKE RESERVATION AND NEVER COME HERE WITHOUT ONE.

The food is as good as it gets, very fun and healthy, and they look good on the plates, but other reviewers have done the job for me so this is not the point of this review. 

The service is the main entree here and it is amazing!!

As you can probably tell, I was one of those idiots coming here without a reservation and had to wait over an hour to get seated. Unfortunately, I was on tight schedule, but I really wanted my mom to try this place before sending her off at SFO. So we waited and waited, then when we finally got the table, we only had about 40 minutes max or the TSA security people are gonna be real ugly with my mom, and in turn, she will be with me. 

So I quickly notified the waitress that we are in a hurry and we ordered almost immediately as we sat down. And the food came within 10 minutes!! What a savior! We finished the food in 20 minutes or so and immediately got our check, paid, signed, and left. (Actually I don't think I finished my wasabi noodles. But I will never say no to leftovers from this place. It was a good day the next morning because of the leftovers.)

ps. the bass is amazing. simply delicious and fresh.and wasabi noodle is, too. I still don't know how they maintain the wasabi taste without getting it all spicy.

pps. [TO FELLOW DINERS] I saw a table of 6 who had sat down for 40 minutes and there were no food on the table, just wine, bottles, and glasses. I also literally saw a table of 2 leaving the table with all their belongings for at least 15 minutes and then came back to finish the rest of their courses. I am pretty sure the wait time could've/would've been cut down had they (us, you, me, everyone!) just be a little more considerate and caring. I know you had the reservation and you would like to enjoy the experience and the atmosphere (actually there's no atmosphere, it's so tiny, noisy, and dark inside that there's really nothing romantic about this place other than the substance itself), but to do it at such a busy and popular space, it just seems a bit selfish to me. But that's probably just me. You can carry on doing what you doing and I will definitely book my reservation next time so I can get the tables moving.
author: Michael W.

description: The House was one of the best restaurants I've been to in recent memory.  The quality of ingredients, inventiveness of menu items, presentation of dishes, fusion of ingredients, price point, simple but modern decor, and of course the flavors...this restaurant offers incredible value and I highly recommend it for anyone looking for a great meal in SF.  The seabass and wasabi noodles were nothing short of outstanding.  I feel comfortable hyping this place up because I know it can live up to high expectations.  I can't wait to get back here one day!
author: Johnny B.

description:
This place was sitting in my "to try" list for such a long time, and when my date asked which restaurant I want to try, I just jumped on the opportunity. Finally!

Maybe it's because I had such a great expectation to this place (but with 1900+ reviews with 4.5 stars, how could you not have high expectations?), but at least to me, this place turned out to be a bit of disappointment.
The service was okay. Nothing outstanding, but it's not like we were ignored or anything. Although we had a reservation, we still had to wait for about 20 minutes, which was still acceptable.

[ Appetizer ] 

Scallops: Great. Sauce was amazing and scallops were very well cooked with full of flavors. 
Lobster Tempura Salad: Tempura was not at all greasy, so it worked really well with the salad. Again, the dressing was amazing.

[ Entrée ]

Seabass: Of course, I had to try their famous seabass. Yes, the fish itself was excellent - no argument about that part. But the ginger soy sauce was way too salty and too strong. From the moment I tasted the sauce, I knew it could ruin the whole dish. The sauce was completely unnecessary. And then, it came with this sad looking noodle, which I couldn't even figure out what it was. It almost tasted like Japanese Yaki Udon, but the texture was way too soft (it did have a nice flavor, though). 

Angus Flatiron Steak: The steak was cooked very nicely. It was tender and juicy. But what is wrong with the noodle?? It was again very soft and too spicy. The spiciness was definitely from the chili and not from wasabi.
I tried the noodle and it was so spicy that I couldn't even have a second bite. And again, where is wasabi??

[ Dessert ]

Crème brulee with passion fruit sauce: Nothing outstanding. Very mediocre = disappointing.

The bill came out about $90 for two, which I think it's relatively affordable. 

I just don't really understand why this place gets such great reviews. Did we just order wrong dishes?
Don't get me wrong, I actually like Asian Fusion Cuisines, but I've been places that can execute the dishes better. 
The House has such great potential and they do some dishes really well, but I really felt they're just not able to perfect the entire meal. 
In other words, there was always something wrong in a dish, which is disappointing because they did their appetizers so well.
author: Cupie M.

description:
I called to try to get same day reservations, but the only opening was at 10pm.  I decided to chance it and just do a walk in around 7:30pm, and we ended up waiting half an hour or so for a table.  The place was completely packed and the amount of people only grew after we sat down.  It was worth the wait though!  We got the deep fried salmon rolls, the seared sea scallops, the grilled ginger soy sea bass, and the miso black cod.  

The salmon roll was great, and the hot mustard sauce it came with had quite a kick, so just try a little before you drench the roll with it.  The salmon roll was crispy and cooked on the outside and just barely seared on the inside, making for a delightful combination of flavors.  The seared sea scallops was delicious, as all scallops cooked in butter should be. The black cod was outstanding!  The flesh was soft and buttery, and both savory and sweet.  It was even better than the sea bass in my opinion.  I think it's because they grilled the sea bass, which sort of ruins the texture of the fish.  Sea bass should be steamed rather than grilled to take full advantage of it's naturally soft and buttery texture!  The noodles that came with the sea bass was really good though.  It was flavored with a garlicky soy sauce, and I think I could eat it all day.

All in all, the food was very good.  It was quite expensive as it came out to a little over $90 for the 2 entrees and  2 appetizers after tax and tip.  However, if you're gonna splurge for dinner, the House is a pretty good choice.  I'm a fan of Asian fusion when it's done well, and I can't wait to go back someday and try some of the other dishes that they offer here.  

P.S. - the restaurant is pretty small and it's crowded in there, so it can get kind of loud.
author: Tyler C.

description:
As my friend and I were roaming the streets of North Beach looking for a place to eat, we wandered into the HOUSE.  She's eaten there before and loved it, I wanted to give the place a try.  It's a really small restaurant that probably seats about 35 people.

We did not make any reservations(as it is best to do so) and the hostess told us that it would be about half an hour wait.  She suggested we take a walk around the neighborhood and asked us to leave our cell phone numbers and would call us when a table is ready.

After 45 minutes, no call so we decided to head back to the restaurant, to find that people who arrived after us were already seated.  NOT COOL. we asked about our table and she said we were next, but as soon as a table opens, tell me why...some stupid couple swoops in and sits there. It's not even for them...I guess they hadn't realized that we were first in line. PSHH whatever...we were seated shortly after.

GOOD THING THEIR FOOD MADE UP FOR THE WAIT, OTHERWISE I WOULD GIVE IT A 2 STAR RATING.

We started with the:

AHI TUNA TAR TAR: we love tuna tar tar so we ordered it.  It came in three layers each held in place with a piece of nori chip. we each grabbed a chip that was filled with the ahi tuna tar tar.  My friend took a bite and she made a face. UH OH....i took a bite...and then I knew what the face was about.  The both of us are not fond of wasabi and there was a hint of wasabi in it. BOO! I tried to make the most out of it, but she couldn't handle it at all.  We were very dissappointed with our first dish and would have enjoyed it A LOT more if there was no taste of wasabi.

SEARED SCALLOPS: it was a special that night.  I love scallops so i had to get it!! this dish did not dissappoint at all. the scallops were cooked to perfection and the sweet mustard-like sauce complimented well with it. YUMMY!!

GRILLED SEABASS: it came with string beans and garlic noodles.  The fish was also grilled to perfection.  I loved the somewhat crispy outside with the buttery soft tender meat in the insides. The meat was really smooth and melted in my mouth.  String beans were nice and crunchy, but the garlic noodles was a bit to salty for my liking.

MISO BLACK COD: it was a special they had just like the scallops.  It came with chinese brocolli and california rolls. I thought the seabass was good, but this was even better.  The meat was softer and juicier and it melted in my mouth even MORE than the seabass. Chinese brocolli was nice and crunchy and went well with the fish and the sauce.  I thought it was weird to have california rolls with it, but it was perfect because the flavors balanced out very well. Overall amazing!!


We had this with a glass of wine each=]

EACH DISH WAS BEAUTIFULLY PRESENTED and i highly recommend giving this place a try, but remember to make reservations!! it's great for couples, friends and small parties!!

Sucks that there's only one bathroom stall!!!
author: Sarah F.

description: Showed up slightly late after reservation, was asked to be finished with meal in under an hour. The food was good despite the fact that everything was rushed to our table. The green beans were undercooked. Due to the poor treatment by the staff, I will not be returning.
author: Aini T.

description:
Good food, nice service, perfect dinner for my Princes's birthday!

Recommended:
oysters on the half shell with spicy cilantro mignonette
Warm wasabi house noodles with angus flatiron steak
Grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy
author: Mark T.

description:
A hidden gem.  At our lunch, the food came quickly and was hot.  All good, but the salmon roll and sea bass stood out.  Outstanding combinations. House wine also very good which is not the norm for a small eatery.

Is it perfect?  No, but few restaurants are.  Our experience was enhanced by the surprise - intimate, low key, excellent chow overall.
author: Pierre W.

description:
Came back to House after a 2 year hiatus for dinner. We made reservations in advance, and thank goodness, because the place is packed at night.

For four of us, we ordered:
--Halibut (Special): A pretty large piece of fish. It was delicious and the most expensive item we got, priced at $28. Comes with mashed potatoes. 
--Pork chop: A really nice sauce that came with the pork chop. If you're a pork chop fan, you'll like this meaty dish. It comes with mashed potatoes and asparagus.
--House wasabi noodles with angus steak: Noodles were perfect, and the beef was cooked to medium rare perfection. Lots of flavor.
--Warm kale salad (Special): Wow, if I could eat this for lunch every day, I would. Having salad prepared hot really brings a different dimension to salads. It was delicious with goat cheese in it. I wanted more.

Total was about $115 before tip, so not bad. We shared everything. Probably a good idea to do that so you can try all their dishes!
author: Jeanne C.

description: Nom. Seriously such an amazing meal. Very small interior but if you can get in... Do it. Salmon roll was incredible. I cannot wait to get back to San Francisco to have this meal again!
author: Lauren W.
