Why do I like The House so much? Because they were the first to put me, and my stuck up A.Z.N ass, in place.  I was never a believer in asian fusion and steered clear of anything that would remotely indicate dredging X into tempura batter with a side of soy sauce.

The House proved to me that the asian doesn't need to be in your face to be fusion.  It's been two years and I can still remember the pork chop in currant sauce (Is that still even on the menu?)  If it is, I still refer to it as one of my favorite pork chops in the city.
author: Doris K.

description: Food is definitely very good especially the seabass which is cooked perfectly and melts in your mouth goodness Five star for food.  SErvice as well is vry good.  The place is small and cozy  (and I spied "Prisoner" in the bar....my very favorite wine); but the tables are so small so it limits you from ordering more.  I like ordering "family style" so I can try more and share the dishes with whoever I'm with, the last time we were there, it was a good thing that the table next to us was empty, otherwise, we would be having the dishes on our lap.
author: Tess G.

description: This place was a good Asian fusion restaurant.  I'm not a fan of this kind of food but this place left a good impression on me.  The service was nice and its in a nice location.  I would try this place again
author: Warren G.

description: Why doesn't anyone know about this restaurant when it has over 500 reviews.  I'm alway.s asking people if they've been to The House, the answer is has always been no. Ask anyone about Slanted Door and of course they know it, I personally think it's overrated.  Can't stand the wait or the noise or the prices at the Slanted Door?  Don't walk, run over to The House.  Okay, you might have to wait, it's tiny
author: Jax G.

description: I love the food here!  Everything on the menu is yummy...the only problem I have is that the restaurant is so small and the wait for a table can be forever long!
author: JenJen W.

description: Brilliant food, service, and wine selection. The sea bass was recommended as a favourite, and was definitely a winner - exquisite taste and mix of subtle flavours. The pork chop was lavishly decorated and was tender and went perfectly with the pomegranate dressing. The deep fried salmon rolls were crisp and flavourful, and were perfectly complimented by the wasabi-infused sauce. Don't skimp on dessert - the chocolate cake with coffee ice cream was perhaps the best dessert I've had in San Francisco yet.
author: Pamela R.

description: I had my doubts...I always do when it comes to fusion cooking.  So I was pleasantly surprised by The House.  had the unagi roll app and the halibut curry dish.  my friend had the sea bass.  we both enjoyed.
author: ann m.

description: I have just one thing to say, and that is: chicken breast with roasted portabella white truffle oil sauce...YUM. Eat here. You won't be sorry. Make a reservation, though, because this is a tiny place.
author: Kathryn E.

description: Yummers. Dad was in town so I could afford to eat to his wallet's content and it was soo good. I want that pear shaped crab cake every week!!
author: Heather K.

description: One of the best restaurant experiences I've had in years. The atmosphere was fine and simple - a bit crowded and noisy. However, the food made the place feel bigger and the atmosphere spa like. The food is what matters here folks. Every taste of every dish was full of unique and artful flavor. I always judge a place according to whether I get a feeling that a real love of food and making the dishes is permeating in the each fork full (or spoonful, chopsticks full..) I put in my mouth. Creative, but not trying too hard. Perfect portions. Thank you, thank you, thank you! FYI - the customer service was lovely.
author: Sharon G.

description: normally i am wary of asian fusion cuisine, but the food at house was so tasty. worth the mony. def order the sea bass and the pork chop. make reservations.
author: Clara H.

description:
Loved it!  Okay, maybe it was the 2 bottles of wine we had with appetizers and dinner, but everything was delicious.  We split 3 apps, 3 main dishes, and 3 desserts. The only thing that I found mediocre was the pumpkin pie.  
The unagi appetizer, sea bass, and fried salmon rolls were as good as everyone else says.  We also had a hamachi sashimi special for an appetizer (simply amazing) and the butterfish entree special ---which I personally was even happier with than their famous sea bass.  Last but not least, the pork butt (yes, it really is called that).   It is as tender and juicy as any butt should be.  You didn't even need a knife to cut it, and it has a little slice of fois gras on top to make it even better.
The creme brulee was fabulous as well.  The chocolate cake was good too, but I still think the creme brulee was better. The coffee ice cream on top of the chocolate cake was good, but again --- it is just your standard coffee ice cream.  As stated before, the pumpkin pie was nothing special.    It wasn't really my selection, and the person who ordered it thought it was good.  I guess it just depends on what you are craving to some degree.
Overall, I am a fan of nouveau asian, so I am biased towards this type of food.  Even so, I still think it was a great experience and will come back.  The only problem is getting there.  It is in North Beach, so no parking for miles around. Take a cab.
author: Christie F.

description:
Fusion so good the Sun would be jealous.  Larry Tse creates magic at this house. It is so unassuming that, while being right smack dab in the middle of North beach, we have ignorantly  walked or driven past it on prior occasions. May be that's a good thing, reservations might be even tougher  if it announced itself like the other flashy mediocre italian places and strip clubs that abound North Beach. 

Once you are in, the tables are closely packed with diners glancing over at other tables. Mostly in envy to catch glimpses of the magnificently plated dishes. It doesn't help that it is hard to chose from a menu where everything looks like its worth ordering. You almost wish you had dietary restrictions to make the choice easier.
 
Everything we tried here was fabulous. The Sea Bass, if at all possible,   is better than the hype. The soft shell crab tempura special... divine. The flat iron steak with wasabi noodles ... excellent. The scallops appetizer ....also excellent. 

The service is spot on. The prices are a steal for the quality and portions. The House most certainly deserves all the great reviews and accolades. The unpretentious but excellent food with great service in a simple yet elegant decor is  worth every penny. 

To selfishly preserve future reservations for me- This review will self destruct in 5 seconds and your memory of it will be wiped for your own safety.
author: Arun R.

description: Sure there was wait for a table on the Friday, however, the wait wasn't very long.  And the wait was worth it.  I've had the sea bass on multiple occasions and it has been great every single time.  Scrumptuous and juicy!  If you want to order a special, make sure you listen closely to your waiter, the list can be long!  The service is very friendly, even with the hectic pace.  So yeah, make sure you make it to The House soon!
author: Eric T.

description: Yummy lunch with boyfriend, boyfriend's sister, and boyfriend's cousin.  had the unagi and avocado sandwhich.  sooooooooo good.  I'm not even really a sandwhich person, but it was heavenly.  i also had a passion fruit salad that was good and different than any salad i've had (I eat a lot of salad so rarely is there a time when a salad doesn't taste like one i've had before).  portions are generous.  great lunch with good wine.
author: Vonnie L.

description: I frickin love this place. There are already eighty zillion reviews, so this doesn't really add much but the salmon roll appetizer is one of the top four dishes in the city. Seriously. I eat here on business all the time and insist on splitting it every time.
author: Josh O.

description: My friend recomended this place so we had lunch here.  My salmon was good but the sea bass was a lot better.  I didnt really care for  the shrimp dumplings and the salmon rolls were not bad.  Good food for a fair price.  I would definately come back for another experience.
author: tai t.

description:
This is one of my favorite places to eat at, period.

The food is great, the service is excellent and the prices are beyond reasonable for how good everything is.

Out of the restaurants I've been to, this is definitely in my top 2 (it's really hard to pick between this and Rivoli in Berkeley). Both places are practically flawless IMO.
author: Dave A.

description:
i love the seabass. order it.

kind of pricey though, but still an experience.
author: Katherine F.

description: Of all the very few restaurants I've been to in SF, this is by far my favorite.  I have however been to many restaurants elsewhere and The House still rivals for my favorite overall.  A 5 every time, everything on the menu, service too.  The only thing I could ask for in a restaurant otherwise is a less tight, busy environment.  The House is small, tight, crowded and always busy.  Thats just who they are though so I can't fault them for that.  I will always highly consider going back when I'm up in the SF area, even w/ all the many choices.
author: Andrew W.

description: This place is no doubt, a foodie joint.  Everything is all about the food.  My only problem with this place is how small it is and how crowded it gets.  The food was stellar and the service is as good as it can get when it's that crowded.  I ain't no prima donna so I don't expect them to drop everything to serve me.  But, dang, they got some fans.  I'd go here on a weeknight, not on a weekend night.  Or go early, with reservations.  Otherwise, you'll be waiting by the curb with them street walkers.
author: David C.

description:
So good.
FOOD- had the filet mignon salad (yes, salad!), the sea bass special (and boy was it!) and to top it all off, the coconut creme brulee with passionfruit.  Holy guacamole.  I didn't know what to eat next, from bite to bite, it was all SO GOOD.  The porkchops with pomegranate was fantabulous, too.
SERVICE- Amazing.  Really.  Our server.. wow, did she know the food!!    All the other servers were also very attentive and friendly.
AMBIENCE - this is a small space.  Perfect for groups of 2 or 4.  More than that and it gets a bit tight.  They do have one row of tables, if you have a larger (6+) party, you can reserve in advance and be fine.
DRINKS - note that they only have beer and wine.  No mixed drinks.
author: Cat M.

description: So what that management here handled a blushing bachelorette vomiting all over one of their tables with class and aplomb (read: looking hard away and then scrubbing quickly). They manage to seat people just as they're about to explode with hunger and impatience and then serve them food done quite right. The roasted unagi is laid atop rice that sets off its sweetness very well. The shrimp dumplings don't demand your attention, but are worth the short wait 'till they make it to your table. The main courses are well done. Seafood stars, but the meats can steal the show if your plate is graced with one of their fantastic sauces. The pomegranate currant, for example. Really though, what matters is the food made me forget that I had just seen a young girl about to be married vomit on herself. Sweet.
author: Tilak S.

description: I really like this place. The menu was great and the service was good. I had salmon roll as an appetizer and they were scrumptious! For my entree I had the Sea Bass. Lets start with the sides first. The noodles were really good. It had a great after taste to them.  The asparagus...well they were perfect! It was like the noodles juices just flowed on over to the green veggies whitch made me just want to eat them fast. OK the sea bass was really good. It had a dip that was a little too salty, I just slightly dipped into it and it was enough to have the whole piece taste good. It may be a small place but that's what makes it a special place.Oh make sure to call before showing up! I strongly suggest you make reservations.
author: Jorge V.

description:
Oh, the House.  I would treat you much better if you were in my house.  I'm so completely utterly disappointed with the service here.  I walked in and was ignored for a bit by the hostess before she looked up and finally acknowledged me.  I was in a good mood, so I didn't hold it against her.  But then comes dinner where the waitress seemed a bit more than annoyed by me.  So much, in fact, that she decided to ignore our table during our meal, but made a point to check up on the table 2 inches away from us twice during their meal.  If you're going to give me crappy service, don't rub it in my face by giving other tables stellar service.  After finally asking for our check and putting in our card, we sat...and sat...and sat waiting for our bill to come back.  It was late at this point and there were probably 3 other tables in the place, so what's the hold up?  I watched as the table next to us received their bill and consistently better service from the same waitress.  We finally asked someone for our card back so we could sign and be on our way, but she looked somewhat confused.  We didn't even get half of an apology for being forgotten.  Oh, and almost forgot to mention the wine my friend had, which left her with a mouthful of unfilter crud.  Please decant your wine before serving.

So onto the food:

Sea bass with soba noodle and green beans - a tad bit too greasy (my lips had a nice oily sheen after I devoured the meal), but the flavors were on point.  Bass melted in your mouth, probably the best bass I've ever had.  Everything on this plate was delicious.

Mushroom and rice with shrimo: my friend loved hers, although I felt the shrimp were a bit overcooked and too salty, with too much of a charred smoky taste.  I didn't care too much for this dish.

Tuna Tartare: Simply put, I've had better.  Nothing really special.

Crab cake:  Would've preferred more lumps of crab meat, it seemed overly mixed with mayo and other ingredients, so you can't really taste the crab meat.  Flavors were good, just not amazing.

Salmon Rolls: effing amazing.  Salmon was buttery and delicious and cooked to perfection.  Didn't care too much for the salad it came on, but the rolls and dip made me very happy.

Kobe beef salad with crisped rice and papaya: not too flavorful, and desperately needed some acidity to cut the meat and the ripe papaya.

I wanted to like you, House, I really did, but I don't like paying good money and made to feel unwelcome.
author: Sophie P.

description: As I write this The House has 655 reviews and 4 1/2 stars. I'm adding in my 2 cents here and giving them 5. Amazingly mouth-watering food. Well balanced and cooked to perfection. A great blend of Asian fusion with (thankfully) a heavier emphasis on the Asian side. This has to be one of my favorite restaurants and if I didn't live in NYC, I would be a weekly fixture.
author: Brendan P.

description: The place is a little small. i had the sea bass which was to die for....my date had the wasabi noodles which he enjoyed. make reservation before you arrive!! a great place for a date!
author: LaLa n.

description: Came here for NYE dinner with a group of 8, not exactly the best place for a large group, but it was worth squeezing in to try the food. We shared a bunch of appetizers, I particularly liked the hamachi sashimi and also the fried salmon rolls.  I ordered the sea bass since everyone here recommended it, it was good but I've had better. The soysauce was really unecessary since the dish was already seasoned, and overall, the beans and noodles and fish were slightly greasy.  My friend's black cod was delicious and the pork looked pretty good. However, the meyer lemon pot de creme was DELICOUS! The perfect end to a v. good meal. Service was alright, nothing special. I would definitely come back here again for the food!
author: Jessica H.

description: Good service, great food.  I highly recommend the mushroom rice with prawns.
author: clay m.

description: Went back last week for the second time and I have to say I wasn't blown away like I was the first time eating there.  Don't get me wrong - it was still delicious.  We ordered the kobe papaya salad which was a special that evening and it was delicious.  Also had the pork chop with pomegranate sauce (I know that's not the name of the dish) and it was delicious as well.  The salmon rolls were good but the major disappointment of our meal was the sea bass entree that we ordered.  The first time I had this dish it was so amazing - this time it was dry and overcooked.  The sea bass comes with snap peas and wasabi noodles ... the noodles were a little too rich to go with this dish.  The next time I return I'll just get the kobe papaya salad (if it's offered) and the pork chop.
author: Lisey W.

description: OK, this place was good.  The food tasted good, was pretty interesting/unique, and was reasonably priced.  Service was good as well.  We got the deep fried salmon rolls, the BBQ oysters, and grilled calamari in a spicy sauce as appetizers.  The oysters were huge, but that was my least favorite b/c it was like backyard BBQ sauce on oysters (although the gremolata on top was really good).  I was really excited about the deep fried salmon rolls, but they were kind of over-cooked (which i guess is necessary for it to keep its shape).  The mustard sauce was great... but I love all kinds of mustard.  My entree was just OK... it was one of their specials... Halibut in coconut curry with mussels. The fish was cooked nicely and I liked the tomato/potatos and especially corn in the curry.  But the other entrees (sea bass, pork chop) looked better.  Dessert was good.  Now while all the food was good, it wasn't awesome.  People were talking to each other at the restaurant orgasming about "oh this is my favorite restaurant, this food is the best I've ever had, etc..."... and the reviews say much of the same thing.  Blah... yes I'd recommend it to anyone, but it didn't blow my mind.  The best part of the experience was after dinner, we were standing outside and this hot drunk chick was running down the hill and she total face-planted on the pavement.  I think she started crying.
author: Easter E.

description:
This place is the shiznitz.  Great food and great service.  My gf wanted to go here for her birthday and I'm glad I took her.  I ordered the pork with the pomegranate sauce and it was damn great.  When I took my first bite into the meat, gat dang!!!  The meat was super juicy (maybe cuz it was cooked medium); it's probably one of their best dishes.  My gf ordered the sea bass and it was really good also.  Some parts of it was a tiny bit salty but nothing to complain about.  From what I saw at other tables, all their food looks great with nice edible decor.  

The place is small but I made reservations so it was no biggy.  The atmosphere is very casual, it can get pretty loud though with all the customers talking.  It's not  a place you want to go if you want to have a nice quiet meal unless it's one of the odd hours where there isn't anyone there.

Overall, for the price you pay, this place does not disappoint.  Definitely will recommend this place to everyone I know.
author: Mr. Anderson N.

description: ho-lee crap. the sea bass literally melts in your mouth. roomie got the cod special and was also insanely delicious. they obviously know how to cook their fish, but i felt that the garlic noodles and other sides were over-salted. will definitely be back. what a cute restaurant!
author: Lia A.

description:
Food was great, but damn the portions were small.  We ordered the salmon roll, bass entree, salad, salmon entree, calamari, and noodle entree.  All very well seasoned and delicious.  I have to say I was still hungry when I left.  Veggies with the entrees were cooked perfect and seasoned well.

Service was kind of slow cause it was pretty packed.  Come here for lunch, you pay less then what you pay for dinner.  Lunch and dinner are the same menu.

I'd recommend this place.
author: K T.

description:
this place is a little small and crowded, but the food is good.  you need reservation or else forget it.  they have maybe 14 tables.  the food is Asian/fusion.  we tried wasabi noodles with Kobe beef, prime rib, sea bass. the vegetables were tender. desserts were ice cream and cheesecake.

food: 4/5
ambiance: 3.5/5 (tight and dark)
service: 4.5/5
cleanlyness: 4/5
cost: 4/5

overall: 4/5 
I probably eat there again, but only if I make reservation ahead if I travel to San Francisco.
author: nicholas n.

description: WOW. I loved this place. The tuna salad and scallop specials were out of this world...great service too. Both the kobe beef and sea bass were perfectly cooked and filled with flavor. The only downfall is the noise level and cramped seating.
author: A D.

description:
Server was a very cool guy. Went on a super busy Thursday night. Tiny place so it got crowded really quickly. Food was beautifully presented but not so fresh ahi tuna made partner queasy later. I wasn't so lucky.

Partner here: can't help it if I have a cast iron stomach

Me again: I would love to complain about parking, but that's not fair in SF.
Vallejo street garage - 2 blocks away.

We ordered 3 deserts, all of which were .... blah.

End of story, good place, will be back. 
Go too, just not when we are there, too crowded.
author: Crystal M.

description: When I was younger, a friend treated me to dinner at The House, at the old location in the Sunset.  The food was divine ~~~  Some of the best sauces and combinations of food ingredients ever prepared.  I treated him back to Asia de Cuba but it wasn't nearly as good quality as the House.  Recently, a group of us dined at The House in North Beach and although it's a small place, the food is still just as good.  It can get a bit cramped/noisy/rowdy depending on the clientele.  This restaurant is a great, off the beaten track place known by foodies.  I've always had a great time here with the drinks and food.  Sadly, it's hard to navigate a parking space in the area during the weekend.
author: Jenny K.

description:
My favorite place for fish in the city.
I don't want to pimp this place too hard....wish I could keep it all to myself...mmm yummy butterfish.
author: Aditya P.

description: The food is good and constant.  The sea bass is their signature entree and definelty worth the title.  The seating is a bit cramped but a good choice if your looking for some moderately priced Asian Fusion.
author: Lauren H.

description:
3 stars for the excellent food. Will definitely come back, and see if we can give them one or two more stars in the future.
lack of the 2 other stars for the pretentious service, the fact that they ran out of their special at 7:30 pm, the very warm bottle of wine we were served, and the dumb, unapologetic excuses we got as to why the wine was so warm.
author: Carla L.

description: Looking for delicious, fresh and reasonably priced food in North Beach that's not Italian?  Then House is the place for you.  This spot is exactly what a neighborhood restaurant should be- changing menu, friendly service, and well- small and a bit loud at times.  The seafood is always perfectly prepared and they have a decent wine list.  Definitely make a reservation regardless of the night you're visiting, unless you want to eat before 6 pm.
author: Amy K.

description:
the steak, eel appetizer were good.  the mushroom risotto was not.

prices are on the high end.

parking sucks
author: Huy Z.

description: Celebrated a friends birthday a few months back and everyone was satisfied. Handled a table of 8 with great care. Service was spot on, and the food was delicious. The place itself is small, but the rest made up for it. Will be returning!
author: Jonathan R.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in SF. Excellent food and presentation. Service is great also. 

The place is somewhat small...wish they can expand their location.
author: LL d.

description:
it was a long work week, and we needed to get out of the house. living in NB, it's very easy to get lost in the maze of mediocre Italian restaurants and just end up grabbing a burger at Buster's or pizza at Golden Boy. 

the House does a great Asian fusian-style menu. everything tasted very fresh. the portions are generous; we each had a small plate and a main course and dessert and were stuffed beyond belief. 

the sea bass, the scallops, the short ribs and the quail were all amazing and worth trying. i'd eat here again in a heartbeat.

wait staff was attentive and we didn't see any roaches.
author: George R.

description:
My best friend took me to here for dinner after she did a little research on yelp (of course!) for a place that served good sea bass & ahi tuna tartare. My absolute favorites in terms of seafood dishes!

This place was busy on a Thursday night... maybe since this place is small & it was prime time for dinner.  We had the ahi tuna tartare & salmon roll as appetizers and the grilled seabass to share.... Delicious! The tuna tartare and seabass both tasted fresh and was prepared just right... flaky and not overcooked.  

The service, on the other hand, was mediocre... my friend arrived before me & told the guy she had reservations, but he could not find her reservation in the book.  (but she did receive a confirmation call the day before to confirm the reservations)... How can that be, if someone from their restaurant called to confirm... STRANGE!  Luckily, there were a couple of tables opened, so he sat her down.  During the dinner, we felt a bit rushed, as the waitress kept asking if we were done with our meal, even though we were clearly still eating... fork in hand  & picking at the food... and when we were finally done with our meal, she brought us the check without asking if we wanted to look at the dessert menu (I LOVE desserts.. so YES, I wanted to look at the dessert menu)... so when we got our dessert, she brought out the check again.... I understand other ppl were waiting to be seated (we were seated for about an hour & 10 minutes)... but let us enjoy the food.. GEEZ! (dock a star & a half for so-so service)

I give this place a 3.5 - 4 stars... the food is awesome; service is ok, maybe better if you can eat a 3 course meal in 45 minutes or less!  Also, make reservations & get the person's name if you can, just in case they can't find your reservations.
author: Cathy P.

description: For the last ten years, this has been one of my favorite restaurants, the food has been consistenly delicious - some of my favorites are the ahi tuna, butter fish, angus steak and garlic noodles.  It's all good!!!  The appetizers and desserts are great, too.  You will love this Asian Fusion Restaurnt that is more of a local hangout.
author: Zoe P.

description:
I came back to the House to celebrate a couple of birthdays but we only had one hour to spare. I immediately ordered 3 dishes to starts. 
The server did not tell us the daily specials.
We had:
Sea Bass-  Very yummy as always  4-5 stars
Salmon Roll-  Everyone one liked it, but deep fried. - 3 star
Scallop salad- caesar dressing does not go well with fried scallops. Cesar salad reminds me of fast food.  2 star
Udon soup- came with rubbery fatty chicken. The bowl itself was a nice large portion, but it was awful spicy and chicken is not edible. It was raw with chunks of fat.  0 star
Unagi Sandwich-- Pretty Yummy  4 star
My original reviews still stand. The place has some great food.  But service can be a challenge, it wasn't an even full house that day, 60% of tables were empty. 
I would not order the Udon soup or Scallop salad again.  I realized later they had some specials I like, but I did not get to order it because the server neglected to tell us the daily specials.
Service- 2.5 star
author: A Z.

description: We had a reservation for 7:30pm on a Tuesday night, got there around 7 to see if we could be seated.  We were told that the table wouldn't be ready until 7:30pm.  Ok, went around the corner for a glass of wine.  Came back to the restaurant at 7:30 and were told it would be a few minutes. 20 minutes later there still was no table.  So we're the only ones standing there, and they didn't offer us a drink or anything, or even try to explain why our table wasn't ready.  We had to leave because we were so hungry. This was totally unacceptable-never going here again.  Went to Far Eastern and had a wonderful meal with great service.
author: M B.

description: Great food, great pricing, great ambiance, great for dates (two of my dates brought me here. lol.) and very small (as in max of 4) get togethers. Bad parking. Definitely get a reservation and come early for parking!
author: Kristine C.

description: Went to the house on a sat night- late about 10 45 and it was still packed. I had read all the reviews and was prepared to be let down. I was not. it was great. and by great i mean DEEEELLLIIISSHHH. we started with the fried salmon roll. i hate salmon and this was sinful. i had the ahi which was great and my bf had the steak. both were so great we wanted to come back for more. the only thing that keeps it from 5 stars is they don't have a full bar.....
author: Lindsey G.

description: I had read the good reviews about this place prior to going and was not disappointed. Delicious, beautifully presented food: I highly recommend the ahi tuna main course, and the specials all sounded amazing. I also really enjoyed the tapioca pudding and like the fact that they recommend a dessert wine to complement each item. The service left nothing to be desired and was everything it should be. My only gripe is that it is a little pricey - not so much the food, which is well worth it, but the wine.
author: Ellen H.

description: I always get a take out at this joint. I always get a $10 sandwhich. A $10 takeout. And I still am served with a $10 attitude. The attitude always comes from the petite Chinese girl with slicked back long black hair. A $10 sandwhich and a $10 attitude.
author: Nicole W.

description:
UPDATE: i went here for lunch and it was fantastic!! i had the curry shrimp udon and loved every bite. the deep fried salmon roll appetizer was fabulous as well. my friends got the warm wasabi noodles w/ salmon (so good) and tuna BLT (i didn't try it). the portions are quite generous for lunch. delish! 

my first yelp review goes to the house restaurant. this place is soooo good! i love, love, love the food. wish the restaurant wasn't so small...we were packed in like sardines. but, that's ok, once you see and taste the food, all is forgiven. this is my favorite asian fusion restaurant. can't wait to go back!!
author: sandra l.

description: I've been to this place twice and both times have been very, very good!  The food is excellent.  Each time I've ordered the specials and have not been disappointed.  The atmosphere is lively, and the crowd hip.  The seafood is fresh; the oysters were yummie that last time I've had them.  It's a little gem in the heart of North Beach!
author: Christine M.

description: I like this place.  It's kind of cramped but the food is excellent.  We got the calamari (great) to start and I had the salmon which was very good.  My husband had the trout which was also very good.  For dessert we tried the apple crisp and the special which was a strawberry-rhubarb crisp which was amazing.  Both served with ice cream.  Service is decent but this place really is more about the food.  We were with another couple and they kind of rushed us out of there as we were finishing up.  To their credit though, the line was out the door.  Great CA dining experience and a good place to take out of town guests to in order to enjoy the city's fine cuisine.
author: Janet L.

description: The sea bass was excellent. Really enjoyed the white shrimp and chinese chive dumplings and the deep-fried salmon roll with chinese hot mustard appetizers. Easy walking distance from FD Northwest makes for a good place to do a fun business lunch. This one is going into the rotation.
author: Brian W.

description: Outstanding!  My wife and I drove in from San Jose for a lunch on our anniversary.  We walked around Chinatown before going in the restaurant at about 11:30.  There was plenty of room, but it was packed by noon.  We started with the famous salmon roll appetizer, and both the salmon and the dipping sauce were perfect.  I had one of their specials:  pork butt with papadalle (sp?) noodles.  The cubed pork pieces were seered perfectly and the noodles were cooked through with a marvelous sauce that reminded me of something my mother use to cook.  My wife had hanger steak cut into strips over mashed potatoes. Dessert was a chocolate torte with coffee ice cream.  We are still talking about it!  It was completely satisfying!
author: Riis C.

description: the food was amazing. I had the pork chops and it was soft , tender but not chewy. Service is excellent very nice atmosphere. You need to call and make reservation because it is really crowded everyday. It is very famous in San Francisco. I give it five stars. If you like to eat outside , I highly recommend this restaurant.
author: krich W.

description:
I crave this place more than anywhere else on earth. Their Chopped Chicken Salad is magical. So many textures, makes it a clear dessert island food. 

Get the Salmon roll!
author: Baker M.

description: The food here is always tasty and creative which is quite an achievement when you consider how long they have been doing this.  Pretty quick turn over allows them to keep prices reasonable especially for the quality of the food.
author: philip b.

description: I was visiting SF for the weekend and wanted to eat at a good restaurant with a cute ambiance and thought The House was perfect!  I thought the food was great for the price (I believe this should be $$ instead of $$$).  I got the Flank Steak with Wasabi Noodles ($17) and a glass of wine ($8), the food was great, I would really recommend it.  The steak was perfectly cooked and very flavorful.  I thought the Wasabi Noodles was bland at first but as I kept eating it started to taste perfect with the steak!  I guess being fusion the dishes were a toned down version of the real thing, for example there was some kimchi on top of the noodles but it was was more like cabbage marinated in red pepper flakes, no fermentation and so it's not kimchi in my book.  Also I could barely taste the wasabi in the noodles, I would call it Teriyaki Noodles instead.  But overall it's the perfect place to go to for a casual dinner with friends or a date!
author: Jane J.

description: Good food, but awful services. We had reservation, but when we got there we still had to wait. That's okay. But the way the waitress informed us about the wait was just horrible.
author: Jerry H.

description: Absolutely amazing. Best food in north beach. Try the eel, or the deep fried salmon roll. Kobe beef special is out of this world.
author: Alex R.

description:
Please don't tell any tourists about this place. This is the real deal! Top favorites:
Blue Lake Tempura Beans
Salmon Rolls
Seabass
Pork Chop Pomegranate
Mango tapioca pudding

If you like just the right balance of California-Pan-Asian, you've come to the right place.
author: test t.

description: This place was pretty tasty, and I even had a head-cold with very low taste capabilities. I shared the scallops apetizer--amazing and then had some steak dish--also very full of flavor even with sick taste buds. I can only imagine what it is like when I can taste.
author: Alisa S.

description:
I love love love the House!  It's one of my favorite and the best fushion restaurants in the bay area.  I love their salmon roll, wasabi beef noodle, halibut, creme brulee...yum yum!!  

It's a small restaurant.  During the weekend, if you do not make a reservation in advance, you will not be seated until 9pm.  Sometimes they will not even have a table for you if you do not make reservation.  Also, since it's so small, it's not an ideal place if you have a large party or a baby in stroller.  Nevertheless, it's a perfect restaurant for couples to enjoy a romantic dinner with high quality food!
author: Gis A.

description:
Wow..I love this restaurant.  The food are delicious.  We came here twice, consecutively...yeah, its that good.  We had several dishes...the fried calamari and crab cakes was up to par but the main courses and salad are delicious.

We had the Curried white shrimp and mango salad,  Warm wasabi house noodles with angus flatiron steak, Niman ranch pork chop with pomegranate currant sauce & the Grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy ( it came with yummy noodles).  Wow, the sea bass was so perfect in combines with the green beans and noodles.  Talk about satisfaction...For those noodles lovers, tried the wasabi noodles or the sea-bass...gosh, I could eat the noodles every other days.
author: Gigi L.

description:
After having heard great things about The House for many years, I finally made it there for dinner.  It did not disappoint.  With a party of 10, we were able to try many dishes:  warm wasabi house noodles with angus flatiron steak, grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy, niman ranch pork chop with pomegranate currant sauce, miso cod with crab avocado roll, among others.  Each dish was delicious, and the pork chop really stood out.  A perfectly flavorful yet juicy, tender pork chop is very hard to come by, so I am generally reluctant to order it while dining out.  The pork chop at the House, however, was exceptionally tender.

Service was fine.  Although the restaurant is very small, with a reservation we did not wait for our table.  I would happily go back with a reservation, but can see the wait being discouraging without one.  Seating is tight, but did not interfere with our enjoyment of the food.
author: Cherie S.

description:
This place is wonderful!

It is the best of San Francisco. Allthough the place is small, they have the best food in town. Compliments for the cook. 

The Unaki is great, my favourite. 

Delicious....
author: bram e.

description: I dropped in here for dinner with two friends from overseas - they wanted a place with great food and a great wine list.  The House, as always, delivered on both fronts.  Dumplings for starters and rare ahi tuna for main meal - excellent!  I'd have given them 5*, but making us wait for 20 minutes after our reservation time isn't cool.  Your cramped doorway isn't big enough for that!
author: Nigel G.

description: So I'm not the biggest fan of fish (although I love sushi which doesn't make sense I know), but after intense nagging and threats from my new coworkers to get the Grilled Sea Bass I finally succumbed to the peer pressure.  And let me just say, WOW!!! Thank goodness I'm weak and yield easily to threats, but I am a now a believer!  The sea bass was absolutely delicious and perhaps the best piece of fish I've ever had!  I love this new city of mine!
author: Lisa N.

description: Since I live in the North Beach/Telegraph Hill neighborhood, everyone always asks me which is my favorite restaurant -- I usually answer "The House." I have difficulty deciding which menu item to order, but I often end up with one of their fish offerings. And the noodles are "to die for"! I enjoy stopping by for lunch, which is usually easier without a reservation -- and always a treat.
author: Mary T.

description:
I'm always satisfied eating here,its small but really chic and compact. Always friendly,my advise is to book reservations! There is always a short wait,but its worth it! 
My Fave  is the Grilled Sea Bass with Garlic Ginger Soy,That's another WOW!!!
They always have an amazing menu but I cant help myself to order the Sea Bass .Its so tender and flaky  and the sauce you dip it in Yum!!!
The Wasabi house noodles or Wasabi mashpotatos are great sides to compliment the Delicious meal. My dessert I always get is the Mango Tapioca pudding!  I hope you have a lovely meal when you try this Gem.
author: Sera h.

description: It rarely gets this good.  I highly reccommend the eel appetizer and the himachi entree.  My companion had the tuna sashimi to start and the sea bass main course.  The meal was a delight and we knew we will never find fresher or better prepared Asia fusion food.  It is noisy and crowded., so live with it.
author: irwin s.

description: After reading other reviews, I made a reservation in anticipation of our trip.  Frankly, it was a letdown.  I had the wasabi noodles with flatiron steak,  There was no discernible wasabi flavor and the steak was bland.  My husband had a different steak dish, and it was simply ok.  We each had an appetizer, and neither was remarkable.  It was cramped, but as a city dweller, that didn't bother me until a table came with a larger group than the reservation was made for and they had a baby in a highchair, to boot, which caused a bunch of shifting of chairs and tables, and made things even more "cozy."  I was glad that we were almost done, because the food wasn't good enough to put up with someone at another table mere inches away from my elbow.
author: A M C.

description: The house continues to deliver on some of the best fusion foods in the city. My favorite appetizer is the tempura string beans, my favorite entrees are most of the fishes and dessert seems to always be a hit no matter what you choose. And they have monkey picked tea too! Parking in North Beach sucks. Worth the walk if you work nearby or live in any of the nearby neighborhoods.
author: chip n. c.

description:
Very small place and sort of hard to find but definitely out of the ordinary.  If you consider it's location (smack in the middle of Little Italy) it's quite odd to find fusion where the next door neighbor is Steps of Rome.   The prices are very reasonable and the food is tasty.  The dishes are not small and the portions are decent.  The platting is quite nice.   The food was very good. 

I would say the only thing is to make reservations in advance!!
author: poCo c.

description:
Delectable and perfectly sized, artful portions accompanied by a lively and savvy atmosphere, and--WHAT?!--non-inflated prices??

The House is not only a crowded hot spot with palette pleasing seafood and chops, it's also a fun dining experience! Every time
author: Ryan B.

description: Delicious! The waitress seemed to be a little rushed as she quickly blast off the appetizers and the entrees so quickly that there was no way that any of us could hear or remember it all by the time we ordered and she was very serious on top of that, but otherwise, the meal was delicious! We had some seared scallops to perfection even though there were only 3 of them! They were topped off with some greens of some sort (unfortunately don't remember) and some sweet sauce that looked liked mustard, but I think contained honey. Regardless, it was off the hook! She said that it would be cooked medium. It was cooked perfectly! I also had a special for dinner - the black cod topped with California some Chinese broccoli underneath. All of us completely devoured all of our plates! Not a complaint here except that we could've maybe gotten better service, but the food was EXCELLENT! I will definitely be going back for the FOOD!
author: Alton Y.

description: On one of the windiest days in North Beach history, we huddled outside the front window staring at a warm, empty dining room and watched as employee after employee entered the restaurant and locked the door behind them.  If we didn't have a can of grapefruit soda spiked with Belvedere to warm us up, we might have gotten pneumonia.  10 minutes passed, and we were already walking back to the car before our host had the good sense to open the doors a few minutes early and shelter us from the elements.  The appetizers came surprisingly fast, and didn't seem to take much effort.  Don't order the chicken liver with mixed greens unless you want chicken liver with mixed greens, because that's exactly what you're going to get.  No bells & whistles here.  No dressing or seasoning either.  The tempura green beans were good because green beans are good right now.  But if it only costs them $1 to make, why are we paying $8?  The miso-glazed butterfish was ok but mine is better.  On the other hand, the wasabi house noodles with flatiron steak were an utter disappointment.  Horseradish and steak...it's gotta be good right?  That's what you would think.  You can't call them wasabi noodles if there's no hint of wasabi in them.  And they definitely did not salt what could have been a decent steak.  Here's a clue:  If a diner asks for a side of hot sauce, "any kind", and puts it all over everything, then you have a problem in the kitchen.  After all that, we were glad we took a gamble and gave the dessert menu a chance.  The passion fruit crme brulee, with its deliciously tangy custard perfectly caramelized all the way to the edges, left somewhat of a favorable impression.  What's the big deal about this place?  Somebody tell me.  And I will tell you that you have no taste.
author: Kevin G.

description: This place is the best.  I go here as often as I can.  The owner is really nice.  The food is so yummy!  The prices are really good for the food that you get.  It's like high end food without the high prices and pretentious atmosphere.  They have great specials and a menu that keep you coming back for more.  I suggest going at lunch when it's a little less crowded and cost less than dinner, but still tastes just as great.  The creme brulee is one of the best I've had. Overall, just a really great place.
author: Michelle W.

description: my favorite restaurant so far in s.f. we have only been here going on a year and eat out semi often but this is it so far. we had white shrimp and chinese chive dumplings, deep-fried salmon roll with chinese hot mustard, warm wasabi house noodles with angus flatiron steak, grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy and all were stellar. can't remember the wine we had but i'm sure it was good and plentiful. i just drink what i'm told in the wine department. so go now and take a cab.
author: roger b.

description: When we arrived at 8:20 for our Saturday night 8:30 reservation, the place was packed and there were tons of people waiting.  There was a bit of a kerfuffle with our reservation (they couldn't find it for a while), but once they found it, they were apologetic that they couldn't seat us right away.  We ended up being seated at 8:50 - not bad, but when there is no place to wait, that seems long.  That, however is the only reason I am giving The House 4 stars instead of 5.  The food was extraordinary and the service was attentive without being intrusive.  We especially loved the scallop appetizer that was a special that night - perfectly seared scallops with an amazing sauce.  We thought about ordering it again as a dessert at the end of our meal!  They also have an interesting and affordable wine list.  We don't live in the Bay Area, but we will come back to The House the next time we are in San Francisco.
author: Cindy C.

description: Great everything...food, service, wine and even vibe... dish range from 14-24 dollars... You have to get the sea bass... some of the best I have ever had!
author: Matt S.

description: Had dinner on Sat night with my girlfried...Ordered 2 apps each had a glass of good Pino and an entree all for about $100.00 and it was one of the best meals I have ever had.........This place rocks....
author: Mark C.

description: My friend Diana and I came to eat here last nite, and because there are so many great recommendations on Yelp and from friends, we got a little bit of everything. We ordered the White shrimp and chinese chive dumplings and Caesar salad with crispy scallops to start with. The Dumplings were really good. Our server warned us about the sauce being a little bit spicy, but when I tried it, all I tasted was chilli. I couldn't figure out what exactly the sauce tasted like. But the dumplings on its own were good.  The caesar salad with scallops were alright, nothing specatular. Then she ordered the Grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy - and the sea bass literally melts in your mouth like butter. So good! I ordered the Karubuto ranch pork chop with pomegranate currant sauce. The pork chop was cooked medium and was just the right amount of tenderness, and the sauce was pretty good. I didn't finish the pork chop because I had to save room for our two desserts: coconut creme brulee with passion fruit glaze and the mango tapioca. The coconut creme brulee was excellent  - but I didn't think the glaze complemented it that well. I enjoyed the creme brulee very much (I ate it all), but I could have done without the passion fruit glaze (it was tart and almost strangely sour). The mango tapioca was yummy, and Diana scarfed that down. We topped it all off with a pot of jasmine pearl tea.  We left the House pretty satisfied and very stuffed. Will definitely come back for more yummy food.
author: Annie Y.

description: i should be giving this place four stars. the foods fanfreakingfastic. if its on their menu, youll more than likely like it. i loved the seabass. i lovd the black cod. for some strange reason, when i try to make a similar dish at home, it turns out nothing like it. go figure. the foods great. staff was great, only two reason i HAD to drop a star. (wish i could drop half a star) parkings an impossiblity only real option being parking in th lot next to sake lab, but more importantly youre freaking stuffed in there like a border jumpers 65 ford pickup truck. im not huge person, but i definately need my personal space. when you bend your arms to bring youre feeding vestibule to your face, your elbows hits the patrons next to you in the face.
author: Euge L.

description: My boyfriend and I ordered seabass and wasabi noodle. The food was great.  The place is like homey that's why the called "the house". People came with a reservation, but I walked in and got the table easily.
author: Elisabeth T.

description:
not bad, not bad at all .... 

a place with great flavor with such generous portions.

it is what it is ... 

AWESOME, AWESOME service!!! this is probably one of the very few asian fusion places i will probably give a decent rating to ... it was a definite toss up btwn a 4.5 to a 5, but the overall experience, and more .. 5 stars it is.. 

the house isn't a place i'd DIE to come back, but a place i would recommend to others ... another local favorite i'd totally recommend to others is probably A16 (http://www.yelp.com/biz/a-16-san-francisco#hrid:ZYSOosxMeDgIuo3P-U5cwA), which is in the marina ...  

the service .. above and beyond ... we weren't the only ones there either ... friendly, upbeat, and extremely attentive ... for lunch hr it was quite busy ... and regardless, we were still able to score a table right next to the window, and watch the people pass on by ... 

the place is quite small, cozy, to say the very least, with wooden tables and covered with fine art prints on moss-colored walls.

we ordered the following, and even though they HAVE this on the lunch menu, we opted for a dinner portion DURING lunch, because we were just too hungry ... we started off with the deep friend salmon roll w/hot mustard $8.50.. it was SOOO good .. you must be a salmon lover and the size was ginormous...  he then, went for the wasabi noodles w/angus steak (lunch $15/ dinner $17)... it wasn't all that but it had a great twist ... i liked my $20/24 grilled seabass w/garlic ginger soy ... my noodles that came out on the side was not only super tasty, but their seabass was cooked with perfection! super flaky, and super crispy!! YUM! you could totally tell that the ingredients were SO fresh, and heavenly! mmm ... 

the drinks were quite reasonably priced too.. 

worth another visit ...
author: Jennifer S.

description: I went there a while back with friends. I heard so many great things so I was excited to eat there. The restaurant itself it not large. Its long and narrow. It has nice decor. Our server was not great. As she was telling us the specials, she yelled across the table to a co-server teller her to leave the table. How about you excuse yourself to speak with her rather than yell at someone mid-sentence? We ordered appetizers (oysters - very good, crab cakes - mushy) and entrees (seabass - ok, I've had better at a chinese restaurant for weddings, salmon - friend didnt care for it, porkchop - good). From reputation, it didn't meet expectation. Maybe they were having an off night but it didn't make a good impression to get me back.
author: Master C.

description:
i'm not much of an asian fusion fan. i kind of just cast it off as asian food for those who can't handle true ethnic tastes. i just like traditional asian cuisines. period. my boyfriend insisted i try the kobe beef at house. House has made me a believer, in that i should be more open, and i will no longer knock asian fusion restaurants.

i've been here on a monday night for the special of the day, domestic kobe beef. i was a little hesitant, b/c it was "domestic", and i was in a snobby mood, so i was thinking, the kobe beef i had at the wynn at the sw steakhouse would completely shatter my meal of domestic kobe beef into lame slices of mere mediocrity, but i was pleasantly put in my place. i had my beef cooked medium rare, it came with stringy potato fries (super thin. kinda annoying to eat after a while, since they're so skinny and you just want to eat already, but you have to grab a handful so you can at least feel like you're eating something instead of potato toothpicks. it was succulent, juicy, tasty, mouthwatering, and you finish with a fairly satisfied appetite (i had the scallop appetizer before this) but being me, i was still itching for more. it was so delicious!  i would def come back here to either try a new dish, but why do that when your first time was such an experience, i'd def like to replay that again. its a shame that its only on certain nights. 

i also had the seared scallops as an appetizer. topped with sprouts. it was cooked just right. def NOT rubbery and overcooked, it was nicely seared but NOT charred. it was an interesting spin b/c it was the first time i've had scallops seasoned like you would a steak. it was like grill seasoning. very good. it wasn't overpowered by sauces or other bells and whistles. it was just plain good. fresh ingredients too. 

decor - modern, low key, candlelit, good for pairs (dates) and groups up to 6 people or so, clean bathrooms. 

service - excellent, unobtrusive, always there for refills, staff is easily accessible in case you have concerns or requests.

parking sucks around this area (where does it not?), but its still worth it!

location of the restaurant is nice b/c its close to a lot of shops and restaurants, so its nice to just walk around and take it in and chat w/ a companion, if you're waiting to be seating you can pop your head in next door to a cute clothing shop for women. i didn't think too much for the desserts, so i walked across the street and got some great tiramisu from some cafe in little italy!!! :)
author: Irene C.

description:
update 13 Apr 07:  came here with a couple of friends.  i was excited to try some of their other fare.  for the appetizer we tried their deep-fried salmon roll with chinese mustard (it was good, but i think deepfrying it overcooked it for me - i only like salmon in its rawest form, or smoked, but never cooked - the mustard sauce really kicks you in the head - be careful!).  we had a butter lettuce salad with golden raisins and pear (at least i think that's what it was, it was a special and it was pretty tasty).  i ordered the duck breast special with a blackberry reduction which was good.  my friends ordered the sea bass (it's his favorite) and his wife ordered the ribeye and they both enjoyed their food.  to finish it off we had the strawberry upside down cake (still good, but not as tasty as the first time) and the bittersweet chocolate cake a la mode (i think that was the name of it, anyways it was on the average side, nothing special).  i think overall the food was not as spectacular as my first time, more like a 4 this go around, SO let's average it to 4.5 and round up =)  still better than any other fusion place i've been to.

original:  before the house came along, i HATED fusion.  fusion for me was a chef pulling the worst elements of several cultures and mashing them into a "dish."  in one trip, i was enlightened (ommmmmm, light shines through clouds).  so this is what happens when they incorporate the good stuff from different cultures - wow!  so what changed my life?  

- calamari salad (good)
- roasted unagi with avocado sushi rice (oh yeah!)
- steamed mussels with garlic infused shrimp broth (we fended off the waiter who wanted to take away our "empty" dish, um, hello there was still broth in there.)
- my friend had the black cod special (cooked to perfection!)
- i had the kobe beef special (there's never enough)
- to top it all off, strawberry upside down cake a la mode (sensational!)

hey, and great and friendly service to boot!  so for those of you seeking enlightenment re: fusion, this is the place for you.  made me a believer!
author: Bob C.

description: Simply outstanding seafood.  Very polite staff.  Good wine selections.  Creative food and presentation.  Intimate setting.  One of my favorite places in all of the Bay Area.
author: M D.

description: So I took my Texan uncle here and we had such a fantastic meal.  My uncle kept saying how it was a 4 or 5 star meal (and he doesn't even know about yelp!).  The funny thing about this place is that the menu downplays the elaborate plating and flavors of the food---It's beautiful and includes many different components.  My uncle's eyes were rolling back in his head as he tasted the scallop Caesar salad and cod with sushi.  I was incredibly impressed with the beautiful plating of the asparagus in sesame oil and sea bass with green beans and noodles.  The flavors really explode in your mouth and are incredibly complex.  I think this meal made my uncle finally decide to move to California!  Having been a pastry chef, I have to admit I was disappointed by the desserts.  I had a coconut creme brulee with passion fruit sauce poured directly on the bruleed top.  It just looked messy and the burnt sugar flavor (over-bruleed) and the intense passion fruit overwhelmed the coconut.  My uncle had a tasty but uninspired dense chocolate truffle tart.  The service was perfect and speedy.  Less ambiance here means lower prices and casual dining.  I'll definitely be back for the entrees but will grab dessert elsewhere.
author: Elena S.

description: a tiny little spot that is normally crowded so make sure you make reservations. i had the wasabi noodles with a flatiron steak. it was soOoOo good! after that i went to a few pubs within walking distance to that place. what a great combo! good food & close to bars!!!! lol
author: Kee G.

description: Had dinner with a good friend here after leaving the company holiday party(before it got too out of hand!). Chose this place for a different taste in North Beach. Friendly atmosphere with a tantalizing fusion menu.  True, its small and not much for ambience, but nonetheless a friendly placefor good conversation(crowded, but I can see why) . We shared two entrees--the seared raw ahi tuna and the promegranate pork chop. The ahi tuna was deliciously fresh, but I thought the (tangy mustard-based) sauce was too typical for this dish. The second plate was extraordinarily beautiful, in both presentation and taste. The promegranate sauce caramelized and poured heavenly over mashed potatoes and the chop, with the pork cooked to perfection and juicy inside. For dessert, we chose to split the coconut creme brulee. The portion was perfect for two, even as we contemplated about licking the remainder! It was really that good... I'd choose this restaurant just for the creme brulee.. mm .. heaven. Reservations recommended.
author: Vicky P.

description: Phrases uttered as I left this restaurant: "I'm going to yelp the !$?# out of this place" and "I'm going to yelp this place silly." In all honesty, a completely incredible meal in every way. From appetizers to main dishes to desserts the food is simply exquisite and they could easily charge double for it (Shhh! We can't let them know). I cannot think of a better place to receive my first 5 star rating. By the way, the service is incredible too. The entire restaurant is as big as a size 11 shoe box so we were definitely seated after our reservations. To make up for it, two appetizers and a dessert- gratis. That is how you run a business.
author: Greg H.

description: if you enjoy fusion and adore strong flavors, this place is most definitely for you. i think they do a great blend of american and asian food together, with strong flavors like the generous use of salty soy sauce and horseradish, finished with great presentation. every dish served up was so pleasing to the eye, as well as the mouth. recommend the ahi tuna and the black cod, which was one of their specials the night i went. had the chocolate expresso bread pudding for dessert. it tasted more like cake than pudding, but still super good. one of my favorite places in north beach, by far.
author: Angie K.

description: Unbelievably good food.  Everything is fantastic.  You'll savor every bite.
author: Mike B.

description: The seabass, pork chop and apple pie is all I need for a satisfying meal! The seabass was perfectlyl cooked and seasoned and the pork chops pomegranet sauce pairing was just right! end the meal with some yummy apple pie alamode. Get these items and you will not regret it. I typically don't go for asian fusion food but this place makes really delicious and perfectly cooked food. You must try it!
author: Sabrina F.

description: This restaurant is a hidden gem! Asian fusion and 100% delicious. The caesar salad was great, which seems unlikely at an Asian restaurant. The asparagus in sesame sauce was also delicious. I had flank steak with soba noodles in a wasabi soy sauce -- the steak was so unbelievably tender -- it was better than many filets I have tasted. My friend ordered the ribeye with potatoes and it was also tender, juicy and flavorful. We ended with a perfectly cooked creme brûlée!!! All in all, I loved every moment at this restaurant. And on top if it all, the service was attentive and the waitstaff was friendly and professional. Tip: make a reservation to be sure you get in.
author: rachel s.

description: In short, the House is not for those who shy away from expressive, creative dishes with an intense taste. The food itself is fresh and prepared to perfection (i.e. no soggy veggies or grease laden fried food). The dishes are not only tasty, but artistically presented with loads of color to match the flavor of the food. It's worth every penny (including the desert).
author: Kimi K.

description: Fantastic. I feel like they had more specials than entrees on the menu (i couldn't remember all of them). I had the butterfish and tuna sashimi. The sauces and presentation were wonderful.  The truffle cake/coffee ice cream was alright as the cake (tasted like a brownie) was a tad overcooked. Place was a bit tight and small, but worth it. We still had to wait 20+ minutes even though we had a reservation.
author: Alison W.

description: Okay I have to say that I have been to many fine dining establishments and have thought the food was amazing upon initial visits.  The problem is that repeat visits usually leave me disappointed.  I appreciate The House because its been consistently good every time.  I usually bring out of town friends because I can be assured that this place wont disappoint.     The price is reasonable by SF standards.  The only reason I gave only 4 stars is because the parking is so difficult in North Beach.
author: sarah m.

description: Found this lovely restaurant having just move into the neighbourhood. Great combinations of flavours, beautifully tender meat and fish combinations and such lovely attentive staff. Highly reccomend
author: lucy f.

description: I rate The House as the lifetime highlight of my San Francisco experience. Luckily, my friend and I reserved a table early on a Friday evening and didn't have to wait long. For starters we ordered the deep-fried salmon roll with chinese hot mustard which was very tasty and pleasingly different from your traditional sushi rolls as well as the asparagus with roasted sesame dressing which almost melted in your mouth. It was difficult making a decision on the main entree; I was torn between the niman ranch pork chop with pomegranate currant sauce and the grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy. In the end, the waitress talked me into trying the angus ribeye steak with housemade teriyaki and toasted garlic butter. I made the right choice. I have never had a more heavenly dinner as I did at The House. Each forkful was bursting with flavor, creativity and complexity. I don't think there's anyone else out there who can pull off these dishes. Of course, I had to try their dessert as well and chose the persimmon bread pudding with ice cream. It was like eating spoonfuls of warm, gingerbread creme brulee drizzled with caramel sauce. The House is always first on my list of restaurants when I visit San Francisco and perfect for dates, friends and family.
author: Penny K.

description: I can not disagree with anything said below.  Amazing food, great ambiance, really good place for a date.  Only downside is small size of restaurant (so it makes it harder to get reservations... don't even TRY to just walk in!) but it more than makes up for it with quality of service and quality of food!
author: Wayne S.

description: Best Pork Chop I ever had. And Ive had thousands. The Tuna was excellent as well.
author: Andrew L.

description: Consistently great food. Service could use a little more warmth. A definite neighborhood gem, seabass rocks, the Kobe beef carpaccio was bam! The salmon roll and crab cakes never fail to wow! Oh and don't forget the mango tapioca.
author: Marie M.

description: My friend recommended this restaurant to us, and we decided to give it a try.  The food definitely lived up to its reputation.  Everything we ordered was tasty.  The pork chop that my husband ordered was flavorable and tender, and my black cod was yummy and generous. However, I must say the biggest surprise of the night was my friend's beef flank steak.  It was the most tender and tasty flank I've every tasted.  In a city full of hyped up restaurants this place definitely lives up.  The prices of the mains are typically around $20-$30.
author: Sharon W.

description: After seeing The House on Check Please and reading yelp reviews...I knew I wanted to check this place out. I made the journey from the East Bay and after walking to North Beach from Bart I was thirsty and not in the mood for wine so I ordered an Ommegang Belgian beer-score!  Next we ordered the Ahi app followed by the Seabass and I ordered the Ahi for my main course (I'm from Hawaii and can't get enough.) The food was flavored/cooked to perfection--the best meal I've had all year (and I eat out a lot!). One slight criticism was that our waitress was not very warm or personable but I think the entire staff was a bit flustered due to a large private party. However, I'm still giving this restaurant five starts because the food was so good ---with Ahi cooked to perfection, washed down with one of the best beers of all time... I wish I could give this place ten stars. I will be baaaaaack.....p.s. owners...please please please open a house in the East Bay!
author: Kate G.

description: It was a bit packed! Yet, I ordered: barbequed oysters, wasabi noodles and steak and creme brulee and apple pie. They were all full of flavor and beyond AMAZING! It is a must in San Francisco!
author: Kate K.

description: Delicious food!  Thanks, Yelpers, for pointing me in the right direction.  I almost made the mistake of going to Asia de Cuba for their DAT (they are the only DAT place open on Saturday for lunch) but saw the bad reviews and decided to find someplace closer and better to where we would be (Chinatown/North Beach area).  I went with my family, and the 5 of us had a great meal.  For appetizers, we ordered the mussels (they don't have bread, so make sure to get some rice for the delicious sauce), deep fried salmon rolls (with spicy wasabi mustard sauce, yum!!), and the special that day, shiitake mushroom soup with truffle oil.  The soup was spectacular, but all of the appetizers were very tasty.  For main dishes, we got curry noodles with chicken, unagi with avocado sandwich, chipotle BBQ pork loin sandwich, and udon noodle soup.  Again, everything was extremely tasty, standouts being the grilled chicken in the curry noodles, the breads of the sandwiches were buttered and grilled to perfection, and the soup with udon noodles was flavorful.  Very innovative flavors, and we were very pleased with the whole meal.  Everyone was part of the clean plate club.  I wouldn't hesitate to go back or recommend it to friends.
author: I-Chant C.

description: i go there for the service and the food. the food is phenomenal and the servers are like you friends (you'll want to hug them by the time you leave) if the black cod is one their specials of the day, you have to order it. if they don't have, anything else on the menu will do the deed. you've got to try everything on their menu, especially if it has fish in it.
author: Connie L.

description: Very nice little restaurant. The food was very tasty - ordered the special, which was steak and it was delicious; the best I've had in a while. Was difficult to get a reservation, so book early!
author: Adam C.

description: Ate at The House based on all the (mostly) rave reviews on Yelp and Trip Advisor.  Our expectations therefore were inflated, and, while the food is good, it did not meet with our preinflated expectations. Began with appetizers of hamachi sashimi and unagi over rice.  Sushi grade hamachi with salad on top-nothing more.  The unagi is grilled nicely, but again these are dishes that should except at any reputable sushi restaurant or izakaya.  The entrees were their signature sea bass-tender and oily but not distinctive.  And the wasabi noodles with flatiron steak had a nice mild spice to it, but again nondescript.  Not really "fusion" but more like a nice Japanese izakaya, albeit with prices that reflect its trendy reputation.  All in all a pleasant meal, but not memorable and seemingly did not match its hype.  It is crowded and noisy, small, but that ads to its hip ambiance and,as other reviews keep stressing, it is nearly imperitive to make reservations, and nice that they do.  We were seated nearly right away as we were led through the crowd bunched in the doorway hoping for a table to open up.  Japanese bbq, izakaya, and good sushi restaurants will over much of the same without the price and hassle.
author: Adam S.

description: The House is The Real Deal.  All 9 people at our table loved their choices-- probably 6 different entrees among us.  All 4 apps were solid.  The sea bass is like Buttah (that is their House special).  You'll love it.  Do it!
author: Henry F.

description: Started with the perfect White shrimp and chinese chive dumplings. They were served with this spicy sauce that bathed my taste buds in six or seven different flavors. Moved on to the masterful Maine crab cake with pickled ginger remoulade. These were just our appetizers and we were already enchanted with the experience. We had heard about the Niman ranch pork chop with pomegranate currant sauce and it lived up to its reputation. The left over pomegranate currant sauce was poured on everyone else's meat dish. We finished with a special Kobe beef NY strip beef steak served over white wax beans. Our desert was the chocolate cake with a strong and wonderful coconut flavor. Simply a perfect meal and a gem we will share with everyone. The service was nice, but trying to rush us out a bit after only 45 minutes at the table. It is a small and popular restaurant and a line was forming at the door (at 10:30 at night). Make reservations ahead of time so the wait doesn't damage the perfect dining. This restaurant gets on of my rarely awarded five starts.
author: Travis M.

description: I go to the HOUSE maybe twice a year, and time and time again, I am impressed with their food and service.  Things you should definitely try are the salmon rolls and sea bass!  Check out the House If your looking for a kinda romantic, trendy, and a great place to eat...
author: C C.

description: Great Restaurant. I have never once had a bad or even okay meal here. I highly recommend this place. The amuse bouche, appetizers, and entrees are all wonderful.  I recommend the seabass with the soba noodles!
author: Alexandra S.

description: The salmon roll and sea bass is really really good.  Be sure you make reservations, it gets really crowded.
author: Heidy M.

description: Who's in the house?  I'm in the house!  Bring in the beat.   My all time favorite restaurant in San Francisco and that is a bold statement which I stand by.  I adore The House.   I wish I could make The House my house and eat from it's kitchen everyday.  Every dish I have ever had here and there have been many many many of them has been excellent.  Every person I have ever brought here has walked out beyond satisfied.  There are not many places you can visit on a consistent basis and have it be dead on every time.  EVERY TIME!!!  The Sea Bass is the one I always come back to but the wasbi noodles, the blue lake tempura green beans, the specials.......mmm.....  Mess with the house and you mess with me!  Not that I'm scary.....
author: Allison M.

description: Wow, what can I say about this place.  Only two words, Sea Bass.  Absolutely delicious!
author: Steven L.

description: great little place! hate the neighborhood, but it was totally worth it for the Ahi tuna. great apps. we had the unagi, crab, & scallops-they were all winners. i had the tuna, the BF had the steak, it was win win. the mango tapioca was amazing,  yumms! it's a great reward for enduring the hell of north beach. it was even worth finding parking for, and thats saying something!!
author: Lisa S.

description: I'm going to have to join in with the chorus of "ehs" about this place. The service was excellent, which is always appreciated, but the food was kinda mediocre. We started with the crab cake, which had an interesting presentation (I forget exactly, but some kind of tower of crunchy stuff), and it was tasty, but, you know, very fried. Like, the kind of crab cake I could probably grab at a sports bar, but with better presentation. A lot of fried breading and a little bit of crab meat and some tartar sauce is always going to taste good, but I wasn't really that impressed. I got what I think was a butterfish in ginger soy broth (or miso broth?), and the boyfriend got the steak and wasabi noodles. I thought the broth that the fish was in was bland, bland, bland, although I think there were some tasty vegetables of some kind. The steak was cooked just right, which was a plus, but again, it just wasn't that special. The noodles were my favorite part, the right amount of spice for my taste,  but they were still pretty standard fare. It was a bit of a celebration, so we went for dessert, which we usually don't do, and let me tell you, the chocolate cake is incredibly boring. It tastes like brownie out of a box, and it's not even served warm! Overall, the food isn't *bad*, exactly, it's just not that exciting, and the execution of the fusion concept seems a little incoherent. Tartar sauce? At an Asian Fusion place? Really?
author: vanessa r.

description: small, hidden, restaurant in sf's north beach.  eaten here a few times, and loved the food and dessert!!  do make reservations if you plan to go.
author: R K.

description:
This place is awesome!!
This place is in a little nook in between Chinatown and NorthBeach, and it was definitely a real find.  Although the restaurant is quite small and cramped and the ambience was simple, the food just squashed everything else. 
Since I went with a big party we had some appetizers...oysters on a half shell was super fresh and the fried salmon roll is a must get.
For entrees, I had the grilled ahi over rice.  The presentation was beautiful and the ahi was cooked just right (still raw).  There is this wasabe puree to add color to the plate and it will get your eyes watering....
For desert, we had the special for the day key lime pie.  It was super sour but was generally what is expected.  The mango tapica was a unique desert...very creamy like a soup with soft tapica...I would get that next time.
The service was excellent....maybe because we had the manager serving us and he knew the menu inside and out.
Definitely go here for some good food!!
author: Randall W.

description: This place is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Chilean Sea Bass is absolutely perfect!! there is literally no bad food at The House.. Everything that you order would always be good and they are very consistent. Best restaurant in the city... one complain I have is the service though. Some of the waiter can be extremely impatient and unfriendly which is annoying but other than that... This place is definitely worth going for.
author: debora t.

description: this is one of my favorite restaurants in san francisco. it's a great place for lunch and dinner. their prices are very reasonable for what you get - they use very fresh ingredients and amazing sauces. it's a small, intimate space, but large enough to seat a medium party of 6-8 as well. you will need a reservation, but it's totally worth the wait!
author: Jenny C.

description: Ok. So my girlfriend to me to find a restaurant and I wen ton Yelp to look. I stumbled upon THE HOUSE. I read some of the reviews and I must say there was  no over exaggerations about the SEA BASS. It was OFFFFFF THE HOOOOOOKKKKK...... LOL. It melted in my mouth and was just good to have some nice fresh SEA BASS. The servers were also friendly and recommended us to try the scallops for appetizers. OMG.... So delicious. Everything was great about this place. The only thing was the CREME BRULE had a passion topping that threw it off. but other than that i wiped it off and scarfed the whole thing down.
author: JAMES R.

description: Okay, this review is biased as I used to work here. But I can honestly say that I crave the food here. The salmon rolls... salmon, perfectly crisp with the salmon still pink in the middle with a great  soy dipping sauce. His coleslaw is a fusion of different textures and layers of flavors, vinegar, ginger, spicy and sweet. A guilty pleasure of mine is the Chilean sea bass which is cooked perfectly , flaky, moist and the seasoning is yummy and is accompanied by a sweet ginger soy. The chef cleans and cuts the fish himself. Curry Noodles with grilled chicken is also one of my many favorites. The noodles are tender, the curry sauce is velvety with good heat and the chicken is grilled and seasoned with soy and other spices. The chef likes layering flavors and textures.
