Order Lamb chops, Pork chops, any sashimi on the special menu.  The food here is definitely a culinary experience not to be missed. Many have tried to take on his ideas...but I have yet to come across food as delicious and inventive as his. It gets very busy here...so I recommend reservations.
author: Chris O.

description:
There is one restaurant that throws out the checkered tablecloth of its famed neighbors and the over-done pandering to tourists and does something deliciously different. The House's small, gray, unassuming storefront is flanked by the blinking lights and crowded sidewalks of patio dining, causing most visitors to pass by without a second glance--much to the delight of locals who cram into this Asian Fusion haven nightly. 

The House doesn't serve up much scene with their dishes--tiny dark wood tables and a decidedly minimalist philosophy in terms of decoration mark the small restaurant. But the food is all the ambiance The House needs. Dishes take on art form in sculptures that blend color, smell, taste, and even the looming sky scrapers and hills outside, making up for the uninspiring decor and small quarters. And once the perfectly cooked soy glazed salmon or unagi roll appetizer melts in your mouth, you're in for non-stop taste bud bliss that may dull your other senses or your ability to notice anything around you but the masterpiece on your plate, which perhaps points to the owner's design of white walls and crisp stainless steal counters. I would say it is a good place for a first date; just don't confuse the love affair between you and your meal with romantic feelings for your date. 

East-meets-west comes alive with hearty main courses, such as Angus flatiron steak on a bed of wasabi noodles or grilled sea bass with garlic ginger soy. The mastermind behind such ingenuous pairings such as chipotle pepper and Chinese hoisin sauce or green tea ice cream with caramel sauce, is Executive Chef Larry Tse. Tse immigrated from Hong Kong at the age of five and grew up in San Francisco's famous China town where he worked at his uncle's restaurant and began brainstorming unusual ways to infuse the foods of San Francisco with the flavors of his home. He still gains inspiration from weekly trips to the China town marketplace. The result comes to life in the form of colorful sculptures on a plate that mix the sea food that the city by the bay is known for with a kick of wasabi or the crisp cleansing properties of ginger and soy. Even the unagi appetizer defies sushi's tendency to be too delicate and bite size to be filling. Instead tender slabs of roasted eel lie on a bed of sushi rice and fresh Californian avocado.
 
Zagat rated The House extremely high for its food and service, with an overall impressive rating of 26 out of 30. And it's no wonder why: when I asked if I could sort of combine two dishes I couldn't choose between by getting the soy glazed salmon in the miso soup instead of the bonito sake broth, the waiter responded with not only yes, but "that sounds even better than the original." The salmon was cooked to perfection and blended deliciously with the spicy miso soup broth that combined the aspects of the traditional comforting recipe with a surprising spicy kick as the broth slid down the throat. Just as the sculptures typically start with a hearty base, such as mashed potatoes, noodles or a bed of greens, the taste climbs and opens up to unexpected flavors, as if timed perfectly. The first touch to the tongue is often not the last taste you will experience between the time the food rests on the tongue to the time it slides comfortably down to your stomach. Food as exciting as this calls for drinks that will not over power the nuances in every bite. The restaurant's knowlegable staff can help you navigate wine list, comprised predominantly of wines from local Napa and Sonoma Valley wineries.
 I must preface my gushing review of the Crème Brulee with my tendency to be a crème brulee snob. I can wax poetical about the perfect caramelized ice-skating rink that gives way to rich, creamy custard, but only if the high-maintenance dessert reaches my high standards. Savoring my favorite dessert becomes an experience of stopping all conversation so I can discernibly run my spoon along the top, testing its smoothness, and revel in the first crack into the custard. Then the first bite, with the perfect ratio of caramelized topping to cream--eyes closed, life paused in something akin to a spiritual reverie. While I'm usually a traditionalist when it comes to crème brulee, The House's island twist on the French dessert has converted me. Passion fruit puree is drizzled on to the golden brown topping so that at first crack, the purée seeps into the custard below and transports its lucky customer to an island vacation. The creamy custard, although not as thick as I prefer, has a whisper of coconut that adds lightness to the traditionally heavy cream.
author: Amy C.

description: The House is by far, one of my favorite places to eat! The Pork Chops and Steak are the best! Just be sure to get a reservation in advance as it is a small place and fills up quickly.
author: Steph V.

description: Easily one of the best spots in SF. Wish they'd open a place in Boulder.
author: John D.

description: good food but jam packed crowded.  would come again but not in a hurry.  so many other reviews ...no need to carry on.
author: Mei B.

description: By now, The House has amassed a loyal group of devotees who love fresh ingredients, impeccably prepared cuisine, and flavors that marry the best of East and West. My own personal favorites include the crab cake, which is perfectly seasoned with plenty of crab meat, as well as the seabass and pork chop. The seabass is marinated in a sweet and savory soy and, I presume, grilled, giving it a subtly smoky flavor. One of the highpoints on the menu is the pork chop. Thick but tender, this is the mother of all pork chops! Tasting vaguely of classic chinese char chiu pork, yet prepared using western techniques, it is a little taste of heaven. In short, the food here is exceptional and for the quality, a bargain. The service is also extremely efficient and no fuss. The interior of the restaurant is soft, subtle, very cozy, and always packed with adoring foodies. I could not ask for a better dining experience, and recommend all to visit or revisit it!
author: Yb W.

description: the first time i went was 2 years ago and i remembered that i thought this place was super good, but i went last month and i thought the food could have been better. my boyfriend and i got dere and we were waiting for our friend (another couple) we sat down for 10 mins den the waiter finally gave us menus and water. the place is really small. u must make reservations b/c it is packed all the time, but service starts out a lil slow. finally my friends arrive and we ordered tartar (good) crab cake (good) sea bass ( yummy) pork chops (ok) chicken (sauce is good, but chicken really dry) an steak ( ok) i would come back here, but it isn't a place that you can go to all the time
author: Karen H.

description: 3.5 stars, love the butterfish; apps were okay, great 2nd date place though
author: Peter L.

description: a bit downhill since louis went away. but still fairly consistent fusion. sea bass is a must. salmon rolls are great. steak is nice. ooodles of noodles are good too. try specials once in a while they're worth it.
author: Marcus D.

description: I will start this review by stating that I used to hate Asian Fusion. After my several experiences here I must say that I hate Asian Fusion unless it is done right. I've eaten here on numerous occasions and I absolutely love the food here. I especially love the Sea Bass which offers a very exciting combination of flavor for the palate. It is both juicy and savory and the sauce adds just the right amount of zest. The noodles on the side offer a more subtle taste while cleaning the palate again for some more of that sea bass. I also have to say that I love the service here as well, something that you can't generally say about most Asian Restaurants(I'm Asian, so I would know). One particular instance happened a year ago when I had to make reservations for about 14 people. If you've eaten here you know that 14 people is a lot to put into the small space. I honestly thought it was a long shot and I placed the call for the request. The host stated that the owner would need to approve it. I already figured that I was going to get a no and so I was looking for another restaurant that would be more able to accommodate my group. Within about a week the owner called me, which was a shock. Angela, the owner asked me about my group and the occasion, and I stated that I was planning to propose to my girlfriend and I had our friends coming in from out of town to celebrate after. She told me that she could make it happen and approved it on the spot. To have the owner do that and help make that occasion happen was the best, because I really did want to have our dinner there. And it was a great night, one to remember. Awesome place, awesome food, and awesome people.
author: M L.

description: omg i love this place. it's small and can get really loud but i promise everything on the menu is delish.  close your eyes and just point to an item, you wont be disappointed. yes its really that good
author: M S.

description: I tried the tuna tartar appetizer, which was probably the best dish I had.  For the main course, I had the pork chop, which was cooked perfectly.  The pomegranate sauce was a nice complement.  I also tried the sea bass which was also very good.   The portions are on the small side.  We left still hungry and went to a cafe in North Beach for dessert and coffee.  We would have had dessert at the restaurant but the staff reminded us several times that we needed to leave within an hour of being seated since we didn't have a reservation.
author: Edmund W.

description: Called on a Saturday afternoon and they were able to squeeze us in at 630pm. This place is always packed due to its small confined space. We should have went somewhere else since I knew they were gonna try to rush us out for the next group. For appetizers we had the fried calamari and the crab cakes. The calamari, although tasty was over-fried and almost burnt. I found the crab cakes too moist since it was in the shape of a teepee. As for our entrees, the seabass, seared ahi tuna and cod were all very tasty. They have trained their mexican staff very well as the fish is perfect every time. Price was average but the three stars goes to the rushed service and not so good appetizers. The House is a great choice for asian fusion but make sure to make reservations at least a day in advance.
author: Jerry H.

description: I've eaten here before so my reservation on Valentine's Day came with high expectations.  Sadly I was very dissapointed.  The "special" menu left quite a bit to be desired.  We started out with the scallop appetizer and it was cooked very well and set a good opener for the night.  Or so I thought.  We had the kobe beef tartare which sounded good on paper but when it arrived it was mixed with some chile verde style stuff and placed on a buttered brioche.  It was decent but I would have liked to have been able to taste the kobe beef as it should have been the focal point of the dish.  Instead it's flavor was buried and i could not tell what kind of meat it was.  The next dish was pork belly and mushroom salad which was okay but they skimped on the pork belly and that was the main reason why I ordered it.  For entrees I chose the pork butt with fois gras in a miso broth and upon my suggestion my girl got the Hawaiian butterfish and mussels in a curry broth.  My pork butt was cooked beautifully but the odd topping of a morsel of cold fois gras was really out of place.  In addition the fois gras was seared but served to me cold.  I couldn't figure that one out.  The miso broth was way too salty and left me slamming my glass of wine with reckless abandon.  My girlfriends' butterfish was way overcooked and nothing reminiscent of the butterfish I ate in Oahu.  I felt bad for recommending it to her.  The curry broth had good flavor and the muscles were large but to have to entrees served in a broth on the same menu seemed like a culinary cop out.  When we saw the desserts we were crestfallen when there was no passion fruit creme brulee to be found.  Why would you remove that from the menu when everyone who has tasted it knows it is truly orgasmic and befitting on Valentine's Day?  We settled for the meyer lemon pot de creme and the persimon pudding cake catastrophe.  The lemon thing was so sour it made our faces cringe.  I HAVE NEVER HAD A DESSERT THAT TERRIBLE BEFORE.  Whoever made that didn't taste it and should be ashamed of themselves.  The persimmon cake pudding whatever tasted like a shitty spongy cross between pumpkin pie and gingerbread.  If I hadn't paid for them I would have left them to die alone.  Sadly, This menu was a total letdown and showed me the lack of range at this restaurant.  Whoever put this menu together didn't think this through and they should just stick to what they do best.  Bring back the old menu and leave it at that.
author: Jake S.

description: My boyfriend and I went to The House today for lunch. We ordered the shrimp dumplings, fried salmon roll and tuna BLT. The total was $32. Everything was good but not great for the price and quantity. The dumplings didn't have that much flavor.
author: Molly B.

description: Asian fusion with very high quality food.  the Unagi roll is awesome.  The sea bass was out of this world while the seared ahi was just "pretty good".  The spinach that came with the ahi was way over cooked adn tasted like it had absorbed a lot of bitter/burnt garlic.  To be fair, we brought this to our waiters attention and they prompty brought out a new side of green beans which were very good.  Service was attentive and if the ahi had been as good as the sea bass, easily 5 stars.  make sure you have reservations as this is a tiny place.  we will definitely return.
author: Stacy N.

description: I had lunch here for the first time and was very impressed. The food was reasonably priced, although I have heard dinner is a little more expensive. The food had great flavor and presentation with many uniques options.
author: Justin M.

description: i went to lunch here today. the place is pretty small and the decor is plain but it doesn't really take away from the experience. i love fusion food. i had some hamachi sushi appetizer and some seared ahi tuna for entre. the food was pretty good but nothing that is exceptionally memorable. for some reason the wait staff was nice but they seemed to be attentive to everyone else but us. perhaps we didn't look like big tippers. oh well, it was overall a positive experience, i definately wouldn't mind going again.
author: Doris Y.

description: Great restaurants. Unique tastes that go well. Everything I've had here is tasty. Parking can be a little difficult and it can be noisy at times. Overall a great place. Seabass is excellent.
author: Erik B.

description: Make sure to make reservations or you will be eating at a cheesy chinese restaurant nearby. The sea-bass with their special noodles is awesome. I think I've been here at least five times in the last six months and always had the sea-bass.   If you love liver, you have got to order their liver salad, a great start to the entree. Highly recommend this place. However, if you are on a first time date and nervous about people next to you listening to your business, then another venue is better.
author: Caleb N.

description: mmm mmm good.....been to house three times in the past 6 months and love the place. check it out they have something very tasty for everyone.
author: John F.

description: The food, presentation and service were excellent.  I would have given the fifth star if my fish special was as good as the Pomegranate Pork Chop my wife got.  Don't miss the Tuna Tar tare or Tuna Tempura appetizers.
author: Justin R.

description: Hands down. THE BEST RESTAURANT in SF - no doubt. You know the Asian food is good when more than half the people in the place are also Asian (its true). Everything on the menu and all the specials are always the most delicious thing i've ever put in my mouth - and I usually hate how cliche Asian fusion is! Top notch service, wine, and fresh tasty food.
author: Christie W.

description: the food here is delicious! the restaurant is very minimal. you're crammed elbow to elbow with people. it makes for interesting conversations with different people. the prices are very reasonable and the food is flavored very well. they have a small but decent selection of cheap wines. as long as you come here knowing its going to be crowded and crammed with bad service, this place will be very good.
author: Molly C.

description: food was better than expected, even after hearing about others' raves.  Service felt rushed, space felt cramped.  Innovative dishes, but the ambiance leaves a bit to be desired.
author: Benson J.

description: This place was incredible, I would give it 10 stars if I could!  I am a picky eater and their menu is small so I was worried.  I even went out on a limb and had the pork chop even though I am not a pork eater.  It was divine! I will be back to order that again. Next time I will need to try some of their deserts as they sounded incredible too!
author: SJ G.

description: good food, reasonable prices. one of those california fusion places. love the swordfish. and one of my buddies absolutely swears that it as a fantastic first date place.
author: Dean E.

description: This is hands down my absolute favorite restaurant in SF.  any time i have an out of town guest, i take them here and it never fails to impress.  i must say that not everything on the menu is fabulous.  but the items that are good are TO DIE FOR.  things you should not miss:  salmon rolls, ceasar salad (but only if it comes with scallops), sea bass, rib eye.  those dishes are always delicious!  most of the specials and desserts are great also, but especially the mango tapioca: so creamy and sweet but not overly sweet.  just heaven in your mouth.  I LOVE THE HOUSE!  it is a small space though so make sure you get reservations.  too bad they closed the location on the inner sunset.  it was bigger and easier parking over there.
author: yelp a.

description: well-seasoned, very tasty food. service was great.a little loud and a little cramped . the dessert could use some improvement. overall, one of the best asia fusion restaurant.
author: aj s.

description: The food was amazingly delicious. I highly recommend this hole in the wall for everyone!! This by far has to be my fav place! :D
author: Karenka N.

description: One word describes this place and the food.. amazing.. For starters our group shared the salmon roll, hamachi and ahi dish, all were simply great, I would have to say the salmon roll was the best of the trio. For the main course, I opted for the rib eye steak. Loved it.. Great flavor and cooked just right. What I love about this place is that, they are priced just right for the food they serve. Great food at very fair prices. Paid about $40.00/person in our group and that included appetizers, main course & desert.. can't beat that.. Only negative... PARKING..... -1 star for having to drive around for 20 mins.. they need valet here!
author: Sean K.

description: love it love it love it. decor is so cute. home cooked feel. curry udon noodles. do it, go to the house.
author: Tara S.

description: Altho this place is small and intimate it never fails u just dont order the kobe beef but the escolar and sea bass is amazing a flavorful.. On top of that the staff is very nice and attentive,,,, great place if you want ur tummy to be happy!! ;)
author: Vana T.

description: I've never had a bad meal here, but the food seemed over-salted during my last visit.  Had the seabass with noodles, which was already salty without the sauce.  Fried calamari was also overcooked...could tell just from the dark brown color of the fried breading before even eating it.
author: M W.

description: I love this place!  Even though it was "cool" quite a few years back, the food remains excellent.  You must try the sea bass!  The fish is tasty and cooked just right and the noodles that accompany it are to die for!
author: Piyo's Mo M.

description: worth the wait??I wasnt too impressed with my meal,the seared alcacore,. the very nice presentation got me excited,it just didnt deliver.to be fair I sampled my wifes kobe skewer(excellent)Kookies sea bass(excellent)dumplings and salmon roll were so so..the dessert,really good..if i were judging strictly my meal,the wait (although we had reservations)and the waitress(everyone has a bad day)it would have been a 2...but im sure i just picked the wrong dinner!!
author: j g.

description: Jesus the food here hit the spot.  I was shocked by the large size of the portions.  I wasn't in love with the atmosphere though - a little too bright.
author: Greg S.

description: I had scallop, Rib Eye, and Lamb Chop.  All of them are good.  Esp.  the Rib Eye....  Excellent.  Price for all of them is $86 included tax and tips.
author: zcx p.

description: This place was packed on a Saturday night. We made a reservation at 9pm for 4 people and didn't mind the late reservation because we were watching some March Madness basketball and waiting for a friend. We got there on the dot, and still had to wait 30 minutes. However, the staff was very nice about it and even gave us a free appetizer (the salmon roll thing, which was delicious). I ordered the steak with wasabi noodles, which was cooked perfectly and came with tons of meat. Two friends got fish dishes, which were also good (miso snapper and a cod). The other person got a kobe special. The dessert was also good. We got the mango tapioca, which was pretty light. This ended up costing almost $50/person (because we shared a bottle of wine and 2 other appetizers). I don't know if it was worth that price, but the food was pretty good.
author: T C.

description: Always consistent, always good, always leaves me completely satisfied.  The "perfect meal" starts with the salmon tempura as the appetizer, the seabass with garlic noodles as the main dish and the mango pudding for dessert. It doesnt get any better than that. The place is a bit small, the service always consistent. You can walk in here, order anything on the menu and be happy.
author: Ravenous T.

description: I tried The House after reading all the great reviews on Yelp.  I was a bit disappointed with the selection of food and my fish was a bit over-spiced.  The flavors are strong and tasteful, but I guess I expected a lot more.  The one con about this place is size.  I came here on Valentine's day for dinner and during the entire dinner, all I could hear was the conversation from the table that was 5 inches away from me.
author: P L.

description: The best Asian Fusion restaurant.  Change that. Let say the best restaurant!  Have not been sorry yet.
author: A N.

description: An unsual find in North Beach and a little (really little) gem of a spot -- and I am not just saying that because one of my fellow diners is friends with the owners and the restaurant has become her favorite away-from-home dining room.  Appetizers were super-tasty and my entree delectable.  I finished with a citrusy creme brulee which was outstanding.  The prices were up there for the portion size but not necessarily for the quality of the food or the San Francisco market.  It was a little too fusion, I think, for one of my fellow diners but he's a self-admitted "no longer adventurous due to his age" type and he did pick-up the pricey tab!  I liked the decor, particularly the frames cleverly inset into the wall (how'd they do that?) but the place was on the noisy side, luckily our fellow diner ("the insider") garnished the perfect table which was buffered by a wall on one side!  I'll be back (I said that with an Ah-nold sort of accent!)
author: Mia C.

description: as you can see from the previous reviews, the house is a MUST if you're looking for an amazing, well-rounded dining experience in SF.  the specials never disappoint and the sea bass on the menu always gets a standing ovation.  on our last visit, we tried the short ribs, blue cheese & asian pear salad, lamb and mushroom rice, all of which were flavorful and beautifully presented.  the staff provided great service and the wine/beer/tea menu offers something for everyone.  the intimate dining room feels cozy, but modern, clean and simple.  whether you go for the food,  for the ambiance, or for the experience, definitely go!
author: Kim S.

description: Solid food but the waitstaff rushed us through our meal.  While we still had two appetizers on our table, barely eaten, the waiter told us that our entrees were about to come out.  It was as if he was warning us that there would be no room on our table for the additional food we ordered.  After ordering dessert, the bill came a couple minutes after the dishes arrived.  We were not offered coffee, and when I asked for more water, the waitstaff appeared irritated.  Clearly, this place is more interested in turning tables than serving their existing customers.  Again, good food but cramped quarters and rushed service greatly marred the experience.  For the prices they charge, they should not make people feel like they're in a race to finish their meal.
author: lovegreatfood a.

description: This place is busy so yalls better place a reservation cause even though you get one its still not on time so.....minus one star for that besides the wait food is grubbin and wells,  portions i can eat alot wish it wuz a bit larger but yea prices are reasonable check this place out!
author: geo t.

description: oh my goodness! the best porkchops i've ever tasted in my life! for fine dining this place is actually pretty affordable. expect to spend about $35 a person with appetizers and maybe dessert.
author: Tommy B.

description: I went there the first time last year I think.  Customer service was great.  Food was ok..not like WOW but not bad.  They have a way to present their food so that it looks really nice.  The steak's AWESOME but everything else was..just ok.  I do plan to go there back for the steak and probably try other things.
author: T Y.

description: Even though we had a reservation, it took them a while to get us seated. The service was friendly and efficient. I felt we were being rushed so that the long line of people standing outside can get their turn. That being said, the Sea Bass was divine! It was light, fluffy, juicy and just absolutely delicious. The Salmon rolls lacked flavor but all the other scrumptious appetizers made up for it. Because its such a tiny place, I recommend it for small groups of 4 or less. If you like Asian Fusion food, House is a must.
author: F K.

description:
awesome for a tiny intimate dinner. and i say tiny for reals, it is almost a hole in the wall except it's a bit bigger! you're almost elbow to elbow with the next table....depending on how packed The House is that night

luckily i was able to reserve (a week before) a table for new year's night. whatta savior.  service was great. we were seated promptly. 
food was delicious but portions were a bit wanting (a bit light?). definitely order appetizers and there would probably be room for dessert as well.
- nice to walk around the neighborhood before getting our table
- we ordered one appetizer i believe
- i had miso fish (good but i wished the portion were bigger?)
- friend had the steak/beef (tasted better than mine)
- i heard they're big on wine if you like that...

it was a good time! like i said a tiny intimate dinner would make this an enjoyable experience for you. reserve in advance for the best options.
author: Pamster j.

description: Great food!  It's one of our favorite restaurants.  Try the salmon skin role, oyster and mussels.  Yummy!  Dessert is not that great.  We usually head to Cafe Pucci down the street and have flan and tiramisu there.  It's a really small restaurant so make sure to make reservations.
author: Liz N.

description: Been here a few times and the food is always really good!  My favorite is the Deep Fried Salmon Roll.  Only trouble is, with good food, comes with lots of people and lineup.  Can't wait to go back again!!
author: Yvonne H.

description: I can't believe I've lived in SF for so long and this was my first visit. Excellent food. We had deep fried salmon roll for an appetizer and for mains Sea Bass (one of the best I've had in my life) and pork chop. Minus 1 star for the dessert - Creme Brule was just bad (tasting and the crust was burnt). Service was great. Can't wait to go back.
author: I W.

description: awesome. the decor/ambiance is sort of eeh but the food is great. i had the pork shoulder with foie gras ... oh so healthy yet delicious. one of our favorite restaurants
author: hugh k.

description: The appetizer(Asparagus with Roasted Sesame Dressing ) was very good. Not many vegetarian choices for entrees though. We ordered two noodle dishes and they tasted very good. Those were the only two vegetarian entrees on the whole menu. I was disappointed because when I called to reserve they told they have lot of vegetarian choices. Its not a place for nice romantic dinner either as there is lot of noise.
author: mano e.

description: OMG.  Fabulous food and wonderful staff.  I had the Tuna (Ahi) BLT for lunch the other day.  Everthing we've had here is great!  We shall be back again and again.
author: Marina F.

description: 3rd time here.  made a reservation ahead of time (smart).  still running late - so they recommended going to the saloon across the alley for a drink. i was impressed that they actually sent someone over to come and get us when the table was ready!  but i'm really writing this review b/c the "special" grilled calamari was SO GOOOOOD!!!!  not large - but melt in your mouth - kind of buttery - yet in a bbq type of sauce. yummy!!!   if only they had bread to dip into it!!!!
author: carla a.

description: Awesome! This tiny restaurant packs a punch! We had the Ahi Tartare, the Crab Cake, Salmon Rolls, Fried Calamari for appetizers.....all of them amazing. Entrees: Salmon, Sea Bass, and the special Black Cod w/Crab and Avocado roll....again awesome. Everything was perfectly cooked and the flavors were right on. For dessert we had the apple crumble, chocolate truffle and pumpkin cheesecake....WOW. The service was great too. Highly recommend The House!
author: SurferMom M.

description: My husband and I finally got a night out and decided to spend our precious evening at The House.  The food was delicious but we were quite disappointed after a large group was seated next to us and the server basically ignored us after that.  We were thrown the desert menu in addition to the check without asking if would like anything additional.  We were quite disappointed and am ranking lower for the service.  Please treat all parties equally please...
author: Jen S.

description: This has to be my favorite restaurant in the city.  I usually get one of the specials because they're always amazing and it's always different, but then one night I tried the sea bass that they have on the regular menu.  Oh my god, it is sooooo goood.  I get it almost every time now.  I've had wonderful foie gras on roasted pork butt, kobe beef in a Korean style stew, fresh halibut served with ahi and CA rolls, and it's always amazing.  The appetizers are wonderful too.  We always end up getting the oysters (served with a spicy cilantro mignonette) and the crab cake (one of the best crab cakes I've ever had).  Their desserts are also very good, but we're usually on our way to see a comedian at Cobb's so we usually skip out early, but when we do have time, it doesn't disappoint.  I've recommended this restaurant to everyone I know, and no one is ever disappointed.  They all thank me for telling them about this place.  It has a real cozy environment, and if Asian Fusion is your thing, you'll be blown away.  It definitely screams fine dining, but at a much more affordable price, and a much less pretentious setting.
author: James Y.

description: HORRIBLE SERVICE!!!...OVERRATED...RUDE...UNSANITARY...If I could, I would choose NO STARS!!!..We had a party of 9 and reservations at 8:30.  The first of our party showed up at 8 (the rest were there by 8:30) - we were not seated until 9:45 - all along seeing other people getting seated...After arguing with the hostess on seating us, she crammed 9 of us  in the table that realistically seated 6 - and promised to take care of us.  Since it was nearing 10 pm and we have not even started dinner, we felt defeated and just wanted to eat...when the hostess brought our water, she leaned over and her hair completely dipped into a water glass (she kind of resembled Samara from "The Ring", black hair was all over her face and hanging down)....The waitress had a bit of an attitude too...We ordered our apps and actually got them pretty quickly, but dinner took a while.  when dinner came, my husband joked to say after us making a fuss to check your food for hair..well SURPRISE guess what he found...BLACK KINKY HAIR!!!!  The waitress quickly swapped his order, almost so fast, I'm sure someone had to wait for a new order and I had to make sure it wasn't the same plate....Next thing you know, i found a piece of hair on my plate!!!..I called the waitress over again and she proceeded to argue with me that it was not hair, but fuzz from the napkin...I pointed out impossible, as the napkin was WHITE and it was a piece of BLACK HAIR on my plate!!  I was so disgusted i could not get a replacement (personally I was afraid what type of manhandling they would do to it)...When the bill came, they charged us for my husband's meal that he had to send back and also charged us gratuity (which we refused to pay)...so where is it in there that they "took care of us" as the claimed - we got 12 wine glasses as opposed to 9 (because we ordered a bottle of white and red)...well that's just great....DON'T WASTE YOUR TIME OR MONEY TO COME TO THIS CRAP HOLE!!!!
author: Michelle H.

description: i think this has become my favorite sf restaurant.  here's why: amazing flavors, never had a dish i regretted ordering, great hard-to-find japanese "red rice" beer, and good natured servers (which is becoming rare.)  it's always packed but i have never seen a server have an attitude.  i just love this place.  recommendations:  blue lake beans tempura, black cod, unagi app., sea bass.
author: dink f.

description: definitely not a 5-star restaurant. the food is not bad, but very similar to all the other asian fusion restaurants in the city!
author: karen y.

description: Ate here last night with a friend.  It's very small, cozy.  Detractions: thought that the house music was too loud for such a small place.  Service was pretty good.  We had to ask for our beers, which arrived after our appetizers and our server cleared a plate lightening fast without asking if we were done, which we weren't.   It was hard to pick out what we wanted because there were so many amazing looking dishes to choose from.  We started with a beautiful butter leaf lettuce salad with huge golden raisins, avacado, and blue cheese.  It was dressed perfectly.  Flavors were balanced and popped in your mouth.  I could have just eaten 3 plates of the salad and been very happy.  Next, we shared the white shrimp and chive dumplings, which were very tasty- shrimp was plump and flavorful.  Came with a lovely soy / vinegar dipping sauce.  I used very little of the sauce cause the dumplings were so tasty by themselves.  For main course my friend and I shared the seared ahi- 3 generous pieces that were cooked perfectly.  It came with a mustard cream sauce which was so different and delicious.   The presentation was stunning.  The fish was fresh and flavorful but had too much connective tissue.  We ordered the asparagus, which was fresh and very good.  They serve beer and wine only.  Lot's of nice offereings.  We ordered a red rice beer, which we loved.  I live in the Bay Area and eat a lot of Asian fusion.  This place is different.  Nice combinations of Calfornia fare and Chinese food.  Light but  very flavorful and satisfying.  For what you get the prices are reasonable.  I would defininitely go back.
author: Anastasia C.

description: this place is LEGIT. may be a bit expensive to some people but for lunch, $10-$20 for some of the best food i ever ate, no lie. my $20 seared ahi tuna beat out the $50 fillet mignon i had elsewhere. dont even know where the godly flavors come from. the food is very nicely presented as well.
author: Bobby J.

description: I generally stay away from trendy North Beach restaurants (I enjoy the old school Italian NB restaurants)  but my girlfriend wanted to try this one out due to good reviews on yelp. I'd say the food was pretty good, but nothing I'd particularly recommend to anyone, and on par with just about any upscale Asian fusion in the city. Generally, almost every dish was sweet from the sauces to dressings, and thus the meal was a bit unbalanced. Specifically, the liver was bland, the tuna tartar good (bar crudo much better), the pork belly was very good, the dumplings had no taste in my opinion but my girlfriend liked them a lot, the steak was fair at best, and no more than 1/2 step above what you might cook for yourself from Safeway cuts. I found the servers to be polite, but a bit inattentive in pouring water. I did not have to wait and was immediately seated per my reservation. I did not find it too loud as others commented. At a lower price point, I'd recommend as a decent place for lunch, but probably wouldn't have dinner there again.
author: Andrew Z.

description: My first experience was at the Inner Sunset location before it closed down.  I loved the food and had my first Valentine's date with my husband six years ago at the North Beach location when we were starving college students.  The food was just as good the second time.  Even though it's one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco, I haven't been able to get back too often.  However, I have never been disappointed when I do eat at the House.  Last night, I had dinner after work with some girlfriends and we almost licked our plates clean.  The House just serves up some of the yummiest food in town.  The parking in the area sucks though and that's probably why I don't go out there too often.  I did discover a parking garage right where Chinatown meets North Beach (Pacific and Grant).  So if you're willing to throw down 6 or 7 bucks to park just a few blocks away and you make reservations in advance, you can have a pretty hassle-free and delicious meal at the House.
author: Lisa C.

description: this is NOT one of those places that's like, "oh not all your party is here yet?-  no seat for you."  so for that alone you get points.  but then they go on to impress us with their tasty, awesome, scrumptious food.  some friends from south bay came up and i felt the pressure to take them some place good but not touristy (hard to find in n.beach).  house happened to be a) not italian b) reviewed well in yelp.  so to house we went.  and we were not dissapointed.  it only serves wine and beer but the beer/wine selection was good.  and the waiter made good reco's re: dishes.  we had the following starters: tuna tartar (excellent), clams in spicy miso (pretty good), sea scallops (excellent).  my husband and i split the kobe beef special and the sustainable sea bass.  YUM.  i tried my friend's cod with crab special thing and that was excellent as well.  the dessert was some chocolately thing but that was super tasty too.  overall it was a very good experience but definitely a price tag to match- for my hubby and i it was at least 60 each with drinks, apps, dinner, dessert.  not sure if we'll be back but it was sure delightful.   it seemed to be the only asian fusion option in n. beach.
author: Ann F.

description: overall is above average.  the pork chop and the sauce are so good, the meat is so tender.  sea bass is over rating, is good but not as good as i think.  for the Ceasar salad with scallops, it just regular salad to me.  because i am an asian, it's asian fusion food. i may have a higher expectation.   the fish  just ok to me, nothing suprise.
author: serena j.

description: cute place, except for the harleys that kept parking in front and blowing their  exhaust into the restaurant.  our waitress was not polished but friendly and attentive.  good wine list with decent selection and price points.  all the food seemed great.  sea bass was buttery.  salmon appetizer seemed really good.  the eel over rice appetizer is big and unique due to a cole slaw like sauce.  the sashimi salad was a bit boring.  but all the dishes had a  nice flavor.   good size portions.  great local place.
author: Yelper S.
